Why not just keep the first one, or not have a gun at all?Instead of having the heroes, (or heaven forbid), the audience think, the movie always plays dumb. The climax is set in a ruined space ship that has been sitting in the desert for thousands of years. This ship (a hugely impressive set) has rusted through almost entirely, collapsed in places and is filled with sand. Yet little tiny switches work first time, convenient doors open and close with satisfying swooshing noises and there are video clips to explain the plot to the hard of thinking. There is simply no magic to the film, no satisfaction in working it out for yourself.And when its not playing dumb, it has gaps in the logic that make you go 'eh'? For instance, if the apes and the humans are both only on this deserted planet because of a crashed space ship, where did the horses come from?Is there anything worth seeing? Yes, Tim Roth's performance *IS* excellent, he does convince you that he is playing an ape and has a fine time chewing the scenery in the finest pantomime tradition. This is helped by some truly astonishing prosthetics used on his face. The rest of the ape designs are less successful, particularly Helena Bonham Carter's mask which is so thick and expressionless that she looks like a Muppet and forces her to talk with an irritating lisp.But if there is one thing that sums up all that is wrong with the film it is Estella Warren - beautiful, blond and completely and utterly pointless. Long lingering shots are devoted to her pouting and flicking her hair, but she does nothing else. Perhaps it's my age I couldn't help but think of Raquel Welch in 'One Million Years BC', but at least she had the decency to be chased by a dinosaur, Ms. Warren just stands in the background like a sulky teenager appealing to the teenage demographic. Perhaps I'm being too hard on her, because she does provide a tiny glimpse of hope for humanity. Apes may well be ascendant, mankind is reduced to savagery and the whole edifice of Western civilisation has come tumbling down but thanks to Estella Warren we know there is a bright future for orthodontistry, a girl can be sure of a fabulous leg wax and there is no shortage of non-smear lip gloss. A planet run by apes doesn't sound quite so bad now does it?

As always with Tim Burton, you know the film is going to look good even if it is rubbish. Well his remake of Planet Of The Apes does indeed look good, but is it rubbish? Although it has vastly different bookends to the 1968 original (in which respect it is, perhaps, closer to Pierre Boulle's original novel) it treads broadly similar grounds in terms of a spaceman from Earth whose arrival disrupts ape society in a big way.There is much to savour. There are quite a number of very well-known faces which you don't see because they are covered in ape makeup. That ape makeup, and the ape physicality of the actors, are both fantastic, and far superior to their 1968 equivalent. And Tim Roth's chimpanzee General Thade is a stunning performance - very physical, and very intense. On the other hand Mark Wahlberg was not, at this point in his career, the right man to play the lead, Helena Bonham Carter's society gal chimp doesn't work visually, and the final twist scene is a downright cheat.The fact remains that although the remake is not a disaster by any means, the original didn't really need remaking. Even so, there is something poignantly pleasing at witnessing Charlton Heston, at the very end of his career, revisiting his classic line from 30-odd years earlier from the other side of the species divide.

Tim Burton proves in this one that improving a modern sci-fi classic is nearly impossible. When remaking the 1960's classic, it created some ticket sales because of the original franchise. The trouble with this remake is that the golly-gee whiz special effects of today are put in as replacements for the original dramatic script of the past epic film.The result is definitely mixed, and skewed towards the lower end of the scale. The remake is so focused on using these new special effects, they create a new ending for this film which is truly horrible compared with the original Rod Sterling epic.The story of reverse evolution theory is classic with Ape evolving from man, and Tim Burton's legion of fans might get a kick out of this, but my take is to see the original. It tells the story better and is dominated by drama more than special effects.

This movies deserves a rating of 8 just for the surprise twist at the end, about which I will say no more.I hadn't really been expecting that much from this when I rented the video; I rather thought that the "Apes" franchise had been done to death back in the late 60's - early 70's, with a collection of movies and a TV series that went progressively downhill and became more nonsensical with each installment. But I was very pleasantly surprised by this movie, which was very entertaining and - if I recall correctly (although it's been many years since I read it) is more consistent with the story of Pierre Bouille's original novel. So, my advice is that if you're either avoiding this or watching it because you expect it to be like the "Apes" movies of thirty years ago, plan to watch it on its own merits instead.The cast was in general very good. Mark Wahlberg did a fine job as the astronaut Leo Davidson, stranded on this nightmare of a planet (for him) with no obvious way of getting home. Tim Roth as his primary ape antagonist, General Thade, was also very good. I had a mixture of reactions to Helena Bonham Carter's role as Ari, the human-loving ape. Her performance was quite good, but, frankly, I found her character to be rather irritating. It's a necessary role. We have to see these divisions in ape society, but the character just didn't appeal to me in the same way as, say, Cornelius and Zera did in the original movie. I also thought the ape makeup was rather weak. Frankly, they did a better job thirty years ago.But those minor criticisms aside, I really did enjoy this movie. It was a fast-paced story that held my attention, there was enough humour to make it fun, and enough drama to make me wonder how Davidson was ever going to get out of this. And - as I said at the start - the end itself is worth watching the whole movie.I rate this as an 8/10.

No offense to you Planet of the Apes fans, but I expected a little more out of this one. If your going to remake a movie, then you need to attempt to make it even better then the original. Mark Wahlberg is a very talented actor, but was not the best to play the character he played in the movie. I thought this one along with Ishtar was probably one of the most un-necessary movies in film history. I mean c'mon, that's like making a Problem Child 3!

I knew this was going to be a bad movie. I loved the original so any attempt to top it was, in my perspective, bound to fail. And surely, it did.
This is one misconceived film, and has nothing in the form of pace, believability or lovable characters. The ending (here we go again) is glued on for no apparent reason, other than trying to be true to the novel on which the film is based. The plot is more or less non-existent. And why is it that these "wild" humans, are running around with nicely combed and washed hair, and look like a million? A film such as this, has got to be more dirty. We're talking about a planet ruled by monkeys damn it! And when humans can talk and communicate with the apes the analogy to our own world is lost, along with any reason as to why Mark Wahlberg would make a difference.Speaking of; one of the main reason for the failure is Mark Wahlberg. I havent seen an actor do such a bad job in....well, ever actually. He has got the face of a robot, and less talent than one. And why does he make such a big difference in this world? He has got no charisma, he displays no leadership, he has trouble raising his voice, he delivers all of his lines with the same tone of voice and is generally as inspiring as a taxaccountant. Why are we led to believe that he could lead a rebellion against monkey-tyrrany?Without a doubt Tim Burtons worst film. Avoid!4/10 for good makeup and nice FX's.

reviews.review_title: stunning makeup 'makes up' for weakness elsewhere
reviews.content: i gave this a high rating partially as a razzberry to the higher marks the current cgi films are getting, but mainly because a great deal of what i loved about the 70's movies was the makeup. it made even the last films of that series watchable (and paul williams as an orangutan!). so, in spite of a typical Hollywood snoozefest type plot/script and, worse yet, miscasting mark wahlberg in the lead (more digression, his human 'love interest' should have taken a page from the original and kept her mouth shut) , the wonderful makeup is just so fun to watch! i can't describe my disappointment at knowing we'll never see this again. i cannot abide the cgi cartoonish current apes versions with, if it were possible, even worse plots/scripts...in fact i'm on my way over to them to give them '1's right now, ciao!

As usual, Burton is brilliant at production design, but the characters suffer ... and suffer ... until in the end no one is doing anything for any reason but that Burton thought it would be neat if they did.  The ending in particular is laugh-out-loud preposterous.  Oh, what a shame.  He should really stick to producing.

reviews.review_title: Very Entertaining, just don't compare it...
reviews.content: After seeing two really bad summer fiasco's (AI and Tomb Raider), I finally saw a movie where I smiled as I walked out.  Granted, some of the lines were questionable.  I saw it opening night in Westwood Village (the UCLA crowd) and when Dirk Digg... Leo said something to the extent of "I'm going to show something that will rock your world," everyone in the theater began chanting, "BOOGIE NIGHTS, BOOGIE NIGHTS."  Also, that wannabe model/synchronized swimmer/waif did not need to be in the movie... what role did she play?  Hmm... semi-eye-candy is what I give her.  Regardless, the rest of the cast pulled this movie together rather well.  Tim Roth was amazing, Helena Carter was decent, as well as Marky Mark himself. Visually, the movie was stunning... absolutely great.  Props to the Prince of Weird >Tim Burton.  Danny Elfman (will there be another Boingo album?) = never fails to set the mood.  The flick has some good twists, good action sequences, and all in all was a good movie all on it's own... please just don't compare it to the original... watch it as it's own movie.

Tim Burton is a favorite director of mine. So I went into this film expecting great things. I have to give this version points for make up and set design. But what it really needed was a better script, and an ending that makes sense.Minor spoiler ahead.Don't rent this expecting even a close copy of the original movie - no Dr. Zaus, no Statue of Liberty ending. And yes, there are a few jumps in logic. I'm still trying to figure how the burnt out remain of a space ship magically turn into a plasma cannon. Or how a tiny one man spaceship can travel from beyond Jupiter to Earth in about 30 seconds.Oh yes, Charlton Heston as an ape who fears human weapons. Ho Hum.And the ending? Don't get me started. My guess is the screenwriter wanted something as dramatic as the Statue of Liberty ending, but couldn't because it's clear from the start that this isn't Earth. So the ending doesn't make any sense. It's almost laughable.Tim Burton said in an interview that there will be no sequel. I hope he sticks to his word.My advise, rent the original and the sequels. They're much more fun.

Having watching this film for the first time and not having high expectations, one came away from the film having somewhat enjoyed it at parts but yet again this Planet of the Apes feels very much outdated.Not having seen the original film from 1968, but seeing two of the more recent Planet of the Apes films, it is clear that this 2001 version feels very much different in tone, content and is more silly. The visuals are obviously not as great as the more recent films due to technology and even so the story and content isn't as great.Now as a stand alone film, it is watchable and not as bad as some fans and critics are claiming. It could have been better with more humor and more lightheartedness. A lot of the hate for this film seems to stem from the fact that this remake wasn't necessary and that it's a downgrade from the original.Yes this film is strange and the plot doesn't go very far, as the pace is somewhat dragging at times. Much of the plot focus is Mark Wahlberg's character trying to escape from the Apes planet, doing so along with the help of other humans and some other apes.Not much of note left and the very ending was somewhat confusing. Where exactly was he? Did he not go back far enough in time? As a rewatch 11 07 21' opinions remain relatively same. This 2001 version pales far in comparison to the 2010's trilogy of the Planet of the Apes. Although watchable, this film is only decent. We can see why there wasn't a sequel to the film.

This film was bad because there was nothing interesting about it. It was sort of a remake but then again, not really. I was very disappointed considering the tools that Tim Burton has at his disposal. He had great make up and CGI available and lots of money ($100 million) but can you honestly say that what we got was as good as the original film that was made for less than $6 million? Heck no. So in that regard, the film fails.At least in the original film, the statue of liberty scene was shocking but there was nothing shocking in this film even the end scene because you could kind of see it coming. And, by the way, if you give it some thought, and I did, you can figure out how the ending could come about. I just wish I had back the time that I wasted thinking about it.This film would have been brilliant and fun if it stayed along the lines of the first film and adopted part of "Beneath the Planet of the Apes". Here's how I would have written it:An astronaut (it really should have been more than Marky Mark because he's not good enough to care a film all by himself so I would have put in three guys) that would land on what they would think would be another planet, encounter humans (not mutes), a city ruled by apes, were hunted, made friends with some good apes, discover that they're on earth via finding some destroyed ruins, end up running into crazy mutant humans living beneath the earth, a war breaks out between the mutant humans and the apes, and then....well, let your imagination run wild on how you want to end it.But my point is that there could have been so much more to this film. Sadly, Tim Burton really knows how to wreck a good thing. Consider what he did with the Batman series. He's a rotten director inspite what of people think. He's trendy so he must be good goes the thinking. Sorry, but no. If anyone else had done this film, it would have turned out far better and would have been far more satisfying.

reviews.review_title: Relevant Today, Not As Good As Heston's
reviews.content: (Flash Review)This is a reboot of the original Charlton Heston's classic. This time Walberg plays Heston's character who is part of a space research team using monkeys as living test instruments that are considered to have less value than their mechanical equipment. After sending an monkey in a small ship into space, something goes awry and Walberg, who cares for the him, tries to save it and ultimately crashes into a planet inhabited by an ape society that enslaves him as well as some other humans. They escape imprisonment with the help of a couple sympathetic apes and the chase is on. Will the humans escape captivity? Will they be able to show the apes that they are nice and have feelings? Though it was directed by Tim Burton, this didn't feel Tim 'Burtony' enough. Overall, the movie addresses race relations using different species and the spectrum of perspective race views from acceptance to negative biases and the sad viewpoint that there is still lots more work to be done. Even Rodney King gets quoted in this.

Oh god no! why!? Planet of the apes is such a classic ground breaking film. It's a true masterpiece because it said more about ourselves & society then any other movie, so when you try and remake it your really asking for trouble. The expectations would be so high that such a film would be doomed for failure, which is kinda what happened.I don't care what anyone says, it's always a bad idea to remake a classic like Planet of the apes, hell look what happened to Psycho! it's just better off not to be remade. Heres why this movie ultimately failed: For one thing this really doesn't fit directors Tim Burton's resume. Tim Burton has done masterpieces like Edward Scissor Hands, Sleepy Hollow, Nightmare Before Christmas, Big Fish, etc. So how does a Sci-Fi Action movie fit his bill? I give him credit for having the balls to try but come on! The Lead character (Mark Whalberg) was stupid, Shallow, Arrogant, and bone headed. Whalberg could never fill in the shoes of the late great Charlton Heston. Heston was Larger than Life, Whalberg is kinda annoying in this film. Besides him most of the acting is shallow & over the top. Seriously the dialogue is ridiculous, were the screen writers monkeys or something. The best performances by far were Tim Roth & Michael Clarke Duncan, they were the only bright spots in the film. I thought the Make up was fantastic and worthy of Oscar consideration but that's it for the positive's of this film.I've heard from many people who like this movie and say don't compare it with the original. Of course were gonna compare it to the freaking original! They both have the same titles and similar story what do you guys expect!? My problem is that there are many references to the original, but this film lacks any soul or message that the original had. The original made a serious political statement on society and where were going in the future. This remake is basically a way to cash in. It lacks any of the magic of the original, It doesn't take itself seriously, there are way too many moments of comic relief, The ending made no F*****g sense, and it's just totally forgettable.Planet of the apes probably should have never been remade. Perhaps with a different director, and definitely different writers, a Remake could have been meaningful. Unfortunately this film is a major disappointment, and is totally forgettable. 10 years from now we will still be talking about the original, and the remake will be largely forgotten.

Well, at least after Sleepy Hollow and the incredible waste of celluloid that is Planet of the Apes it should be clear to everybody that Tim Burton is one of the two most overrated directors of our time (the other one is called David Lynch). Apart from some mildly scary effects there is nothing interesting at all in this film. The actors walk around like zombies, and who can blame them for not being terribly interested in what's going on. The original Planet of the Apes was certainly no masterpiece, but then again: compared to this, maybe it was. Avoid by all means.

Some movies are bad because of low budget. Some movies are bad because of a bad plot. Some movies are bad by design, i.e. quickie, cheesy exploitation movies. And some movies are bad because a director goes hopelessly out of control... pounding home his vision with the force of a gorilla's fist in an iron glove. Joining the ranks of "Water World", "The Wild, Wild West" and "Battlefield Earth", "Planet Of The  Apes" comes yelping and screaming to the screen as a comic book come to life. The trouble is, it doesn't know what it is. A science fiction thriller? A horror story? A comedy? High Camp? Unintentionally funny. Stilted. Stupefying. Kris Kristofferson is left hung out to dry as a sort of latter-day Tumak from "One Million Years B.C.;" loincloth-clad Estella Warren appears baffled throughout and although a love interest, has surprisingly little to do . Various human characters are introduced only to later stand around and gawk. Some great ape makeup is wasted on some of the sorriest, most hapless ape villains in movie history. Apes snarl. They grunt. They scream and jump on a planet that seems to have the gravitational pull of our moon...one blow will send an ape or human flying 20 feet into the air on obviously ill-concealed wire harnesses. We have comic(?) relief in the form of a Gilbert Gottfried patterned ape slave trader who is one moment sadistically brutal, the next moment a wise-cracking borscht-belt comedian who may be the most annoying movie character this side of Jar-Jar Binks.  Hero Mark Wahlberg makes one yearn for a real hero in the mold of a Charlton Heston or a Harrison Ford...his heroics consist of simply unfastening a few poorly locked chains and walking free. Couple all this with a some outlandish spacecraft wreckage that functions perfectly after 3,000 years and an army of 10,000 apes that inflicts absolutely no damage to its enemies and you have a turkey that defies description. Tim Burton slips on a Kong-Sized banana peel. A  stupendous, colossal, preposterous yawn.

This movie has had a lot of bad reviews through time. Well, people complain that this isn't a good replacment to the original planet of the apes. This is not the case, for this is a prequel of the movie escape from the planet of the apes. The movie was to imply that the apes came from human activity, and the ending was a possibility for a new movie. The sequence of the movies are, planet of the apes (2001), escape from the planet of the apes, conquest of the planet of the apes, battle for the planet of the apes, planet of the apes (1968), and beneath the planet of the apes. The new movie rise of the planet of the apes is just a new way of showing how the world resulted to the scene of the planet of the apes (1968). So, don't bag on it, for it is good for what it is.

I'm amazed by all the positive reviews this piece of junk has been getting. The plot has more holes than Swiss cheese and is full of logical errors, even within the boundries of science fiction.For example:**WARNING there are spoilers in this list!**1. How did the clock in the mini-spacecraft know what year it is? You see the year quickly moving forward - on what signal or date is this based?2. In the original movie, the humans could not talk. This made it believable that the apes would treat humans like animals, because in our own world, animals do not talk. One of the biggest problems in this remake is that the humans CAN talk. This makes the idea that they would be treated like animals ridiculous. You can bet that if apes could speak English in our world, we probably wouldn't keep them in zoos, animal rights notwithstanding.3. How is it that a chimp is able to land a spacecraft but that a human crashes it TWICE?!4. How is that when Capt. Davidson (Wahlberg) lands on the planet, he enters it in the future, but when the main ship crashed on the same planet going after him, it was thousands of years in the PAST? Wouldn't the time be the same for both - after all, they are going through the same space-time distortion?5. It's never clearly explained how the chimps mutated to become apes, and intelligent, English speaking apes at that.6. How did those monkeys survive the blast unleashed on them from the crashed ship?7. Last but not least - that ending made no sense on any level whatsoever. How did the apes get from their planet to Earth and replace all the humans? And even if they did, the timeline would have been completely different. There wouldn't be anything like the Washington monument, the Lincoln statue or even Washington itself, because Earth would have been a COMPLETELY DIFFERENT place!Unfortunately, "Apes" is another in a long series of films by Burton that are visually appealing at times, but lack any kind of coherent plot. Beetlejuice and Ed Wood remain his only good films.

What's Wrong with this Movie? A Question that has many answers, here are a few of them.1/ It didn't need to be remade 2/ You can't tell that Tim Burton Directed it, by simply watching it, it has none of his hallmarks. (Where's the magic?) 3/ The Script is weak.4/ None of the cast stand out enough to be given credit (even though their was plenty of raw talent in the cast) 5/ It is too long.6/ It pales in comparison to the original.7/ Its pretty Boring.I've got an idea - What's right with the film? Answer - The Make-up and Effects are good, and it has some elements of the original story.That was easier to answer.3/10

Take a work of a great painter like Rembrandt and called someone to make this paint daubs. Well that's what has to do with the movie "Planet of the Apes."And as we are aware when making a pact with "the devil", it must bear the consequences.This "Remake" is a bunch of bland action movie any. The dwarf "Tim Roth" is really funny to want to do too much. Moreover it should stop doing action films of science fiction (as Al Pacino). This kind of movie is not really for people of small sizes. It is like seeing actresses frail and without muscles (Jennifer Garner, Jennifer Lopez, etc.). Making action movies. We do not believe it for a second. It is true that men only look at the beauty and forget the rest most of the time.Mark Wahlberg is bad as always. Looks like a guy who is always angry and frustrated. Like his brother also. Proof that he is wrong because he always plays the same roles.As against this film is very 21st century. A century that goes nowhere, based solely on the profile, money, money and more money. A century without moral or value except money. A century where we are when God has money. A century that saw the birth of trillionnaires and quadrillionnaires. A century or 95% of all the money in the world can be found in tax havens. A century or the capitalist system is considered divine. A century or 99% of all existing money in the hands of 0.0001% of the population. A century in which we only speak of crises. A century where there is normal to see everyone in debt, all cities in debt, debt across all states, provinces, territories indebted all indebted countries, all continents and all indebted indebted Earth. And during this time to see billions of billions of billions of billions in tax havens that will never do anything. A century where we find normal sale $ 20 a pill so that it is worth $ 0.00002. A century or bandits, are no longer.In Hollywood movies now 99% are only turnips. Action movies and / or science fiction with huge budgets and have no body. Films with special effects only always the same script.A century or ideas without a single idea: make money! A century where everything is uniform and lifeless. A century of Globalization.

reviews.review_title: The Worst Movie of the Year Winner!!
reviews.content: Quite possibly the most unrealistic movie ever created. They abandoned the original story which is ok, if you have a replacement story. There are no 'shocks', like "the human spoke!". All the humans speak. They speak better than the apes! Yet, they are 'not intelligent'? Mark Wahlberg crashes on this planet and never once shows shock. Apes are are in control? Ok, go with the flow. The original had a nuclear war throw the apes into control. What put them in control here? Beats me. All those scientists on a science station couldn't keep control? They couldn't keep the education level up? Their computer seemed to work still. They couldn't use that? Where did the horses come from? They were on a science space station? For what purpose?These are the types of questions I kept asking myself. The answer to these questions? A script writer who lacks imagination. That's what "re-imaging" means.

This Tim Burton remake of the original "Planet of the Apes" from 1968 (and starring Charleton Heston) is a far, far cry from the quality and plot of the original.Certainly special effects have improved since 1968, but writing has not. The characters were boring and the dialog was awful.  I sat through the entire film with a friend (who thankfully only rented it) and completely understood why, before Christmas, all of the "Planet of the Apes" toys at Target were in the clearance bin.My advice to Tim Burton: don't put this on your resume.My advice to everyone else:  watch the original 1968 "Planet of the Apes" movie.

reviews.review_title: Only thing worse is Burton's explanation
reviews.content: My first viewing of this film was on DVD...after not understanding the ending, I decided to watch the final chapter a second time, but this time with Tim Burton's commentary track turned on.  This must be heard to be believed!  He goes on for the whole chapter and also half the final credits trying to defend the ending, but he is stammering and interrupting himself and making no sense at all.  It seems he rarely finishes a sentence during this explanation and for all the noise he makes, he doesn't say a single thing.  His basic message is apparantly, "This ending does not make any sense, I only put it in because I thought it was a neat visual," but it takes him forever to say that because he's trying to validate it at the same time even though he himself has no explanation.  Wow...I don't know how the rest of the commentary track goes, but the commentary in the final chapter is the worst commentary I've ever heard on a DVD.  I felt embarrassed for Burton just listening to it.

reviews.review_title: Good acting, make-up and special effects but terrible story
reviews.content: I like the special effects and make-up. The acting is good. TimBurton sent every actor to ape school. So the actors really had apelike behavior. The ape masks and make-up are so good that theactors can act right through them. But this all can not hide the terrible story. It's full of holes. I really like Tim Burton films but I was disappointed with this one. Hope the next Tim Burton film will be a real Tim Burton film again.(Voted 4)

reviews.review_title: Well made just not as well written
reviews.content: I'd give this one a solid 6.5,,,It's well worth watching and enjoyable. It has a GREAT cast! Well directed by Burton, well acted,, but somewhere in the writing it just didn't go as well as hoped. Also,, where as the ending set's up a sequel that never came,, it also wasn't my favorite part. All that being said,, it's a pretty good movie if you want to watch one.

reviews.review_title: Full of sound, occasional fury, signifying nothing much
reviews.content: All right, I give up - why was this film ever made?I tolerated Burton's Batman and Chocolate Factory remakes, because he demonstrated real respect for the original materials - the Bob Kane comic book, the novel by Roald Dahl. But this ape film not only undercuts the original (while trying to look oh-so-much-more impressive), it also trivializes the novel by Pierre Boulle.Pierre Boulle's novel was a fable exploring the post-WWII problems of racism, nationalism, war and nuclear war. The world had already danced close to the brink of self-extermination in WWII: if we believe all the reports (and alas, there's no reason to doubt any of them), some 150 million people lost their lives during ten years of one major conflict after another, from the invasion of Manchuria and the Spanish Civil War to VJ day. That was a larger number than that of the population of the US at the time.Military-Industrial Complex profiteers notwithstanding, it became clear to intelligent people across the globe that ethnocentrism was not healthy for children and other living things, and it was a decent person's duty to say so as clearly and decisively as possible. "Planet of the Apes" may not be a great classic of literature, but it's no throwaway for a rainy day.To rip the heart and mind out of Boulle's story - well, what is the point? The world doesn't need yet another "alternate universe" comic book display of flexing ape muscle and tasteless jokes masquerading as wit. If all this is merely taking place in an "alternate universe", just so we can have a peek at a possible "alternate universe", then the "adventure" is nothing more than the protagonist's daydream.All we can do is shout "Wake up!" at protagonist and film-makers alike, and hope never to see such a self-indulgent waste of money on a theater screen again.

reviews.review_title: Low rating because you didn't get it or confused after the end??
reviews.content:
The movie don't deserve to be below 6 should have been 8+
Many people giving negative reviews because they didn't get the ending or confused after the end.Here is a little explanation from my side:
There are two earth in the movie one is normal human earth and second is monkey earth where Leo landed, you can see two moon in monkey earth so both normal and monkey earth can't be same.In the end There was 2 pods one of Leo's and other one of that trained chimpanzee so in one pod leo travel back to earth and in second pod Apes follows him.Electromagnetic storm works in reverse, remember Leo goes in after the trained chimpanzee in storm but came out before him in the monkey earth.Similarly in the end Leo goes first in the storm and then Apes follows him which is not showed in the movie.Because of electromagnetic storm, Apes landed many years back in the past and they did what they were doing in the monkey earth, whereas Leo landed many years after in the future on the same earth and that is why he sees that difference in the end.

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton starts a bad trend!
reviews.content: When I first saw Tim Burton's 2001 remake of Planet of the Apes, my first thought was of how it was totally different from the classic 1968 original. Other than a smattering of obvious character similarities, the ONLY similarity to that film that this remake has is that apes rule and humans are enslaved. Yet, while the original film's social commentary was enlightening and provocative, this remake's social commentary is done on a much more superficial, generic, flimsy level. It is nothing more than a "summer action movie", with no substance to speak of.Burton's basic premise is completely different from the original. Mark Wahlberg stars as astronaut Leo Davidson, who in the year 2029 defies orders and leaves his space station to save his test pilot chimpanzee, whose space pod gets lost in a cosmic storm. Davidson himself gets lost in the storm and ends up on a planet ruled by apes, gets captured, is enslaved, and embarks on a rescue attempt with several humans in order to find a way to get back home. The usually reliable Tim Roth plays General Thade, military leader of the apes and the great Helena Bonham Carter plays Ari, a scientist and "humanitarian", who hates the enslavement of humans. Ari joins Davidson in the rescue, which includes humans Karubi (played by the iconic Kris Kristofferson) and Daena (Estella Warren in an extremely bland and annoying performance).I find this remake to overall be very cheesy and one-dimensional. The only character that has any depth is the ape Ari (superbly played by Bonham Carter), faithfully playing homage to Kim Hunter's memorable Zira character from the 1968 movie, while sporting a unique portrayal of her own. Carter is such a great actress that she manages to overcome the flimsy material, but unfortunately, the other lead actors Wahlberg and Roth are failed by a by-the-numbers script. Wahlberg's Davidson isn't remotely compelling and doesn't have the stature of Charlton Heston's iconic astronaut Taylor from the 1968 film, who spoke for ALL humans! Davidson is rather uninspiring and selfish throughout the movie. And Roth's Thade is simply evil without any complexity.The worst character is Warren's Daena. It really doesn't help the film that Davidson is stuck with such a bland, blonde bimbo for the bulk of the it! Daena is obviously SUPPOSED TO BE like Linda Harrison's enchanting, beautiful Nova character from the 1968 movie, but I don't even think Warren is very attractive, much less enchanting. Harrison evoked more feeling and spoke to the viewer through pure emotion and expression than Warren did with TONS of dialog! But the biggest culprit as to why Burton's remake is a failure is that the premise and plot is utterly absurd. I know it's science fiction, but too many things in this movie just don't make any sense, especially the ending, which is ludicrous. Also, the movie has an obligatory, "summer blockbuster movie" comedy element that is rather unsettling, as if Burton isn't even taking the film seriously. The dialog is generally silly, including borrowing a famous, powerful line from the 1968 film and turning it into a joke. The ape planet settings looks very cheesy and fake, like a costume drama. The climax is the typical summer action fare.Unfortunately for Burton, this remake was really the beginning of his downfall as a director (discounting Mars Attacks, as he rebounded successfully after that one and I honestly only ever saw that movie once, recalling it so bad that I vowed never to watch it again!), as virtually every film he did after and including "Planet of the Apes" was a remake of a prior classic film, and so far, NONE of them have been well-received or successful. And it all started with this turd!

reviews.review_title: So ditzy, even an ape-man wouldn't sit through it
reviews.content: Was this film a joke? Or did Burton lose his mind?Let's start with the few positives first: the ape characters were rendered well. The make-up, costuming, characterization, even the quadrupedal movements by some apes; excellent stuff. Bonham-Carter's work was fine, although she looks like she just had a wardrobe malfunction or something. By the way, she's in so many Burton films, you'd almost think she knows the guy. Anyway, all positives are lost amidst a big, dumb, growling, lumbering primate of a flick.Some astronaut ends up in a post-Apocolyptic world filled with evolved primates, directly adapted from the original. But, after that, the story resorts to Sunday afternoon serial tactics, and throws cerebral thought into the tar pits. A battle scene where bodies are constantly being tossed in the air: come on. The whole battle scene is just a mass of extras shouting, grunting, and slashing each other to bits. But no meaning to why it's being fought, or what the outcome means.Loud stupid, unintentionally campy. The director's paycheck was unearned. Beware the farcically moronic ending; it's so utterly ridiculous that it's sidesplitting. It's also a brazenly obvious set-up for sequels (that were never made, lol).Good to laugh at with friends.

reviews.review_title: Chimp God and Marky Mark Moses
reviews.content: Tim Burton and company definitely double down on "Planet of the Apes" as a Jewish parable, with Mark Whalberg playing a slack-jawed Moses to the human slaves, along with a few apes, whom he leads through the desert of the forbidden zone, evading capture by crossing a sea of sorts, even, and to the mountaintop, where, near by, he wanders off to communicate with the burning bush of his ruined spaceship. He also wars with the various tribes of apes, to deliver the promised land of equality to all... or some such thing. There's the chimp god from the stars, too.It's an entirely unwarranted remake. Although the makeup and CGI effects are OK, I, at least, had no desire to see an attractive, talking, super-intelligent chimpanzee, such as Helena Bonham Carter's Ari. Nor do I care for the suggestion of a love triangle between Ari, Whalberg's Moses stand-in and a female human, who unlike the original film's Nova, can talk, but still has nothing worth saying. Worse still, Tim Roth merely snarls and jumps around, jacked up on CGI, and the human boy who wants to be on the front lines is just laughable.

reviews.review_title: Lovely costumes, great sets, unconvincing story
reviews.content: Glorious make-up and costumes, a fine, ferocious performance from Tim Roth as Thade, the Ape general, some dark moody sets (Tim Burton repeats his Batman effort) and occasional good lines do not save this movie from being generally boring and predictable – and the ending is inappropriate.WARNING: SPOILER AHEAD. At the end of the 1968 original, astronaut Charlton Heston, having crashed on the Planet of the Apes after a long space journey and having escaped from its inhabitants, the partly civilised Apes, wanders along a beach and discovers lying in the sand the head from the Statue of Liberty. He realises that he had crashed back on Earth, where the human race had managed to nearly wipe themselves out with a nuclear war, thus setting the stage for the rise of the Apes. The sight of the statute was one of the most chilling moments I have experienced in the cinema.At the end of this version, Marky the astronaut, after sorting out the politics of the neo-medieval ape-human divide, flies off from the planet into the electro-magnetic storm nearby to try to get back to Earth. His instruments show him going back in time, and he crash-lands in a familiar looking Washington, DC, right outside the Lincoln Memorial. The only trouble is, Lincoln seems to have turned into Tim Roth. . Marky's instruments must have been wrong. The only possible explanation is we have gone into the future again. It seems that the Apes have triumphed over humanity despite Marky's efforts – but so what? Evolutionary biologists point out that no dominant species has ever produced its successor. Our successors may well be descended from apes, dolphins, or even cockroaches (if we ever do have a nuclear holocaust). In short, there was no punch in the punch-line. In a few billion years' time the Earth is going to go up in flames when the sun explodes; the apes, or cockroaches are welcome to it.I quite liked Helena Bonham-Carter as the kind-hearted liberal-minded ape Ari. While you should never confuse the background of actors with their roles there is something cosmically appropriate in the casting. Her great-grandfather H H Asquith was a leading British liberal politician in the early part of last century and prime minister (1908-16). She is a 'limousine liberal', but as Seinfeld says, 'there's nothing wrong with that'. It's what you do that counts, not where you come from.I also love the confidence shown in technology when it's apparently possible to fire up the spaceship's engines and get a tolerably good picture on the control panel TV monitor thousands of years after it has crashed – maker's name please!

reviews.review_title: Like Instinct, this should be studied for years to come
reviews.content:
Warning! May contain spoilers.What I have always found incredibly funny and yet at the same time downright scary about us as human beings is our ability to be so stupid and so cruel at the same time.  We are the best at cruelty.  As far as I know, we are the only species that hunts for sport and kills for pleasure.  Everything else in the animal kingdom does so for it's very survival.  When lions hunt gazelle, it is to feed their young or to feed themselves.  Even the fearsome and loathed Great White Shark hunts and kills for it's very survival.  But human beings are nothing but charlatan when it comes to our apparent benevolence.  Not all of us of course, but a good majority of us.  Even myself, who I consider to be somewhat of an animal lover, will go out and eat the latest slaughtered cow from the supermarket and I can justify that because in mind, that cow has been killed more humanely than a pig ( which I will not eat, have you ever seen the way a pig is killed at a Portuguese barbecue, well it is even worse when it is killed for mass consumption ). Human beings are not magnanimous in the least.  We take what we desire, not what is necessary.  That makes us gluttonous and that is unacceptable.  But no one does anything about it because we are used to living the way that we do and for some reason, we have laws and human rights for criminals ( including rapists, murderers, child molesters and arsonists).  But we have very little regard for our next meal and how it dies.  Doesn't anyone else out there think it is inhumane to boil a live animal before you eat it? Well?I begin this review of Planet of the Apes with this sanctimonious "holier than thou" sermon because I think this film and the writers do think about these things.  Planet of the Apes is a great action film and has some outstanding special effects but the core of the film is one that is perhaps overlooked.  This is a film about man's comeuppance and what would happen if another species could do to us what do to them.  Battlefield Earth, as awful as it was, touched briefly on this subject matter.  Instinct, the under-rated film starring Anthony Hopkins was also critical of man and our abuse of not only this planet but the inhabitants of it.  See also the Matrix and even Free Willy.  Sometimes movies come out and have outlandish theories and sometimes they thrive at the box office.  This is going to be one of those films.  But people do not often advocate change after they see these films.  They makes hundreds of millions of dollars but that is all they do.  They entertain.  But maybe films like this are about more than entertainment.  Maybe there is a message that Burton and company want us to hear.  Maybe what we are watching is not just about entertainment.
Spoilers ahead!!!What was fascinating about this film is that the theory that it subscribes to is that this ape world would not have gotten as bad as it did if it wasn't for human beings.  When captain Leo Davidson ( Mark Wahlberg ) lands on this distant planet, he travels through time hundreds of years.  He is immediately thrust into a chase involving humans and super intelligent and herculian apes.  He is captured and brought to their camp and here he learns that the world has been ruled by the apes for years now.  He can't understand this because not an hour earlier he was on a his ship that used animals to try and figure out complex problems and to basically use them as guinea pigs.  When there is a dangerous mission to embark on, they would send out the monkeys first to see what the danger was.  If the monkey did not survive the ordeal, then their human soldiers would not go.  So this is a great shock to Davidson.  When he asks the humans how the monkeys got like this, they don't understand what he means.  To them, it has always been like this.The apes, lead by Thade and his right hand ape, Colonel Attar, rule with an iron fist and want to rid the planet of the humans.  They enslave them and put them to work.  But there are human rights activists that think the ethical treatment of humans should be advocated by all so for now the humans are allowed to live.  But most of them live on the outskirts of the world, cowered in little huts or caves and living like rats.  There is great detail that goes into reversing the fortunes of man as we are used as pets.  We are chained up at night and kept in cages and it is even a far fetched theory for the apes to believe that we have souls.  Humans are also branded like horses and are forced to wear the mark.  This is a little like Naziism but more like humanism.Aside from all of the politics of the film, it has to be said that it is a treat to watch strictly from an entertainment form.  Burton never lets us down with the action sequences and the team of art directors, costume designers and make-up artists should be nominated for Oscars this year. Rick Baker leads the team of make-up artists and his work here is absolutely incredible.  Actors, and that is plural, meaning hundreds of actors, spent six hours in the make-up chair ever day.  But it pays off as the apes look fantastic.  Michael Clarke Duncan was the most impressive to me.  He transformed wonderously into Attar and even though it is not the kind of performance that you would say is Oscar material, it certainly is fun to watch.  Others that should get mentioned for their work is costume designer Colleen Atwood.  She too should be remembered at Oscar time.  The set decorators, Rosemary Brandenburg and Peter Young, created a wonderfully dark and sinister home for the apes from the ground up.  It is truly remarkable to see the village and realize that it was once nothing but a vision on some scrap piece of paper.Planet of the Apes is an excellent film in all areas.  It is entertaining, action packed, littered with humour and it is a great summer film.  It is actually the perfect pastiche of a summer film.  It has all the ingredients. But to me it is much more.  This is a smart film and it has a little more on it's mind that just talking monkeys.  It would be interesting to see a film like this produce more than just hundreds of millions of dollars for 20th Century Fox.  It would be nice to see someone out there take a film like this and truly re-examine how we are to the species that we depend upon and for our very survival and abuse in the process.  It would be interesting, but impossible.  After all, we are human.8.5 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Don't watch this underrated movie as a remake, watch it as a different movie
reviews.content: I watched this movie first before the original. I have watched both films many times. In my viewing experience, this movie was definitely better than the original, but that may be because I watched this first. This film did lack something extra, but there were many interesting parts. The quality was definitely better than the original. The apes were more ape like. They used their ape strengths instead of being more like humans with a mask on. A must watch if you did not watch the original.

reviews.review_title: Favourite Film Of All Time, makes POTA'68 more enjoyable too
reviews.content: This film is the best one I've ever seen. I don't see what is so bad about this. I even enjoy the first film even  more. The movie has everything: laughs, effects, cool costumes/makeup, huge sets, great acting (estella warren was okay), terrific music, direction and a great ending! Giving it a 10, and I don't care what you say.

An adequate summer blockbuster, but a very poor film nonetheless. Poor attempts at comedy, designer apes and an inexplicable ending. Wahlberg looks like he's on drugs, and the film is a mess. Burton has done much better, and this is not a vintage effort.Check out the 1968 original. Aside from the great ending, it offers a much better intelligent angle on race and the nuclear weapons.

The worst movie I have seen in a long time.  The ending made no sense in any possible permutation of events.  There were so many holes in the movie I could use it as a strainer.I am very upset because I was hoping to like this movie.  Instead, a wasted money.  I have never openly discouraged anyone from seeing a movie before but... Don't go and see this movie! Please, for the love of god! Stay away!

reviews.review_title: What in God's name is this?
reviews.content: I'm not going to sugarcoat this - this movie royally sucked.  Tim Burton, I'm afraid is losing his Midas Touch; his last film, Sleepy Hollow was amazing, but this, this is a pile of human waste.  Blame it on the screenwriters who obviously didn't discuss this film with one another during the production process.  First of all it was too slow, and ... well, the ending?  What's with the ending???  How could something that happened 300+ years into the future, on ANOTHER planet, change the entire evolutionary process on Earth, resulting in Abraham Lincoln becoming Ape-raham Lincoln??? This movie nailed it's own coffin shut, and stunk worse than the theatre loungechairs.  Aside from paying to see the opening credits, which may have possibly been the only intense moment in the film, and the wonderful make-up jobs, don't waste your time on it -

I loved this movie.  When I first heard that Planet of the Apes was being remade, I was so incredibly disgusted.  I loved the original series of movies, and I felt there was absolutely no way they could even come close to making a decent film.  And I was pleasantly shocked.  Right from the beginning of the film, you could tell it was directed very well.  And the movie kept a very good pace, I was never bored.  I loved the costumes, the music, and the attention to detail.  I also thought the film was very well acted by all.  In a weird sense, I was reminded of Star Wars, maybe it was the scenes of the ape city.  The ending, I'm not sure it sat well with me, but I understood why it was done that way.  I really enjoyed this film, which is a very rare occurrence these days.  I'm a movie snob and tend to only like the older films.  But this new film was very good and I highly recommend it.  The story stands out on it's own and doesn't need the original films at all.  Even Charlton Heston's cameo was great!

reviews.review_title: There should be a prequel, not a sequel
reviews.content: "Planet" was, until the last 5 minutes of it, a great movie. The apes look very realistic thanks to Rick Baker's make-up design, which definitely is Oscar worthy.  The actors playing the apes were superb, I almost forgot that there were humans under all that make-up, while the human actors almost took away from the movie.  *SPOILER* The time travel story line is what really hooked me onto this movie.  The twist of Leo being indirectly responsible for the apes creation and domination over humans yet also being directly responsible for getting apes and humans to live in peace is genius.  I'm very curious as to how exactly the apes got smarter and stronger.  Instead of a sequel from the absolutely awful ending, I think there should instead be a prequel, something like "Before the Planet of the Apes".  I heard the rumor that 5 endings were shot for this film but both why Tim Burton chose this ending makes no sense.

reviews.review_title: Not even a transient craze: Saving Monkey Pericles
reviews.content: The least you could say about that remake is it's poorly scripted and it lacks of tempo. Did they need Tim Burton to shoot this? The story is flat with no real tension created in line with most of the characters. Mark Wahlberg is a dull paleface astronaut and Tim Roth is great, unfortunately his character is so foreseeable it adds little to an already poor suspense.The beginning is neither creative nor tense and the subsequent chase scene is hardly impressive. Two points that could have been easily improved from the original. Hence the film is never working so as to have you get into it. The novel was a good material to make something different if not better. I do think a human massacre as the one right after the chase described by Pierre Boule would have helped to write a good scene. And seal the audience right in! Unfortunately the lazy penbums focused on how to match the 1968 version's ending so they only read the very end of the book. And they adapted it to issue an ending halfway between the book and the Schaffner film.(spoiler ahead) Halfway is never the right way (sat half-buttocks between two chairs as we say in French) and the Burton ending looks more like a quick way for him to get to an end with such a painful script. Burton reportedly shot 5 different endings (to pack the DVD with some supposedly creative stuff). Eventually they decided to stuck that one. It's all the less clear and eludes the fact that to impress audiences in the end it should at least be easily understood. So it only aims to revive the image of general Thade (as for King Scorpion in the Mummy) for a possible sequel. With the Abe Thade Memorial the explanation lies somewhere in the imagination of some scriptwriting genius.Be right back next season and we'll let you know if Marky Mark is to mary Ari or to go damned with Daena. Well frankly, we don't know yet. Have a nice holiday!

reviews.review_title: Looks great, great attention to detail, loses it's plot half way through
reviews.content: Great looking film. Great acting, particulalry Tom Roth and Helena Bonham-Carter. Ape movements and portraying them as a culture used to moving in all three dimensions is excellent, well thought out. Great use of cameos and dialogue from first films. But...Estelle Warren has a pointless role and is completly wooden. The plot peters out into cliches on top of cliches as soon as they arrive at the final destination. Brave but idiot child doing something idiotic, so hero has to rescue him - even has the old weekly serial device of the danger being right on top of him them shifting to not being nearly so close once the situation is resolved. Gimmick to resolve the major conflict is unconvincing, no explanation of why secondary protagonist should drop all his objections and want to live in harmony with species he has despised all his life. Hero doesn't even make a case to him as to why he should do so. Doing for mere appearance of an apparent saviour is incredible. Using small pod to traverse god knows how many universes and our solar system to get home requires too much suspension of disbelief. Ending is just silly.

In another ape universe far far away...sorry, I just hadda do it! Anyway, this reawakening of the ape universe something was left behind...like an amazing, coherent story that grabs every fiber of your being. Sure, it had the obligatory special effects that permeate todays theater world, but it also bears little resemblance to the original for which it was named. Yes, I am essentially a purist so for me if you find an equation that works don't mess with it! At least not much...this version simply did not have any of the magic, the wonder that was in every minute of the 1968 masterpiece. It felt like a pasted together puzzle of several story lines. Chimps are taught to fly souped up space pods for exploration, space storm captures pod with chimp inside, "handler" goes frantic and takes another pod to rescue chimp and gets sucked in to a space warp. OK, that's story one. Story two: chimp handler exits space warp and lands hard on "Earth", only to run into a Super chimp raiding party hunting humans as pets and workers...OK OK, so that is a sorta direct clone of the original. But the remaining 90% of the film is a third story of the handler being befriended by a "cute" female chimp who sympathizes, then she helps him free the oppressed humans. They fight a mini-war with thousands of war apes led by a deranged chimp general, and at the last second we have "missing chimp" arrive in his pod and all the warring apes bow down to "missing chimp" who just happens to resemble their God ape from antiquity...well, that takes you up to the last five minutes of the flick, which turns into a misguided attempt at irony. Not amazing, not incredible, certainly stressful to watch in its entirety.

Pros:
Decent sets, costume designs were pretty inspired as well
A lot of the apes move like apes
Can be a bit funny, even some clever writingCons:
Pretty bad acting, even from people who didnt have 3 inches of makeup
Terrible action due to over reliance on wires
Boring plotline, didnt really care about our heroes or what they were doingBest part: ape politics at the dinner table, purest look at an ape civilization and how it works
Worst part: big final battle, wire stunts and bad sound design, a lot of weak looking hits, generally uninteresting and bad

This film was a monstrosity, a complete and utter failure. Mark Wahlberg is definitely wrong to play the lead and the plot is a million times worse than the original, the ending makes zero sense and is hilariously bad. The script is far inferior to most other Burton films and it takes itself too seriously as a big budget blockbuster, despite being ridiculous.There are however a few positives, the costumes are quite good and the sets are brilliant in parts and Tim Roth is suitably villainous but that's not enough to make a good film.3/10: One of Tim Burton's worst

Average sci-fi movie which was held back by reckless script and lack of attention to detail.Good special effects though but do not expect a very intelligent movie.Action packed and with some thrills for sure but the original 1968 version is so much better folks.See this one only for curiosities sake if you are a big sci-fi fan.Marvel at it's magic and laugh at it's obvious flaws.......

Many others have eloquently lent their perceptions, and I concur wholely with their assessments... and so I will hope that my brevity will not belie my reasoning as I say: this was a travesty of an idea to begin with, and Tim Burton made a mockery of an excellent film.This movie can only hope to be forgotten by the passage of time, rather than remembered for the abomination that it is. I am sure that many of the actors are thankful that their faces cannot be seen, as it perhaps spares them from the shame of being recognized on the street as having been a part of this wretched, awful, poorly-contrived movie.And I won't even begin to discuss the trite ending.Avoid this movie at all costs. Watch the original film.

reviews.review_title: A planet where the apes oppress the humans.
reviews.content: The miseries, believes and thoughts of our planet Earth are shown in another planet where higher apes rule. This is a good film for entertainment. The major deficiency is that the apes speak English and the hero, an astronaut is not coming from Russia, Germany, United Kingdom or Japan. No, as usual is another Flash Gordon-like North American. The end of the film is perhaps its best moment when the hero back to Washington D.C. discovers that  during his absence the planet was invaded and governed by the same apes.

The best way to describe Planet of the Apes is mechanical.  It's a high-tech movie made by a high-tech machine.  It is coldly put together like a car on an assembly line.  The actors are so laden down with makeup, emotional expression is impossible.  Even actors who are lucky enough not to wear any makeup have one-note performances: p***ed-off.  Tim Burton, whose fish-out-of-water thing is getting real old, forgot to add what made Batman, Sleepy Hollow and Beetlejuice work - a sense of humor.  This is, after all, a ludicrous situation.  Why not treat it as such?  Instead, we have Mark Wahlberg who seems to have a permanent scowl etched into his face.  Where is the wisecracking Arnold when you need him?  Tim Roth is no better.  While his mannerisms and swagger are excellent, his over-the-top anger makes his General Thade into nothing more than an enraged chimp throwing feces at everyone in the film (and the audience).  Somebody please call the animal control unit!  Planet of the Apes is SO cold, SO angry, and SO dark that I finally became bored with the whole thing.  Burton, however, is clever.  In an effort to generate repeat business, he tacked on an ending that is so baffling, audiences will be lined up a second and third time just to try to make sense of it.  Lacking the clarity to be shocking, it is simply an inexplicable, absurd anomaly.  Like the rest of the movies this summer, Planet of the Apes fails to live up to its promise.

As one of those remakes that has been much hyped, I was looking forward to seeing this.  So when I opened the DVD and started into it, there was anticipation bubbling up.Apart from the costumes, make up and sets, this really was a bit of a let down.Any Tim Burton film is going to be dark, and this is no exception for the first part of the film, but it does brighten up [literally!] towards the end.Interestingly, you have to wonder if he got a cheap deal on Gladiator stuff!There was a definite Roman theme throughout the apes' society, right down to what were basically legions of apes going to war, even carrying flags and insignia.Wahlberg is passable -- although no Heston, of course -- and Bonham Carter is excellent as the compassionate and caring ape.  The cast as a whole is reasonable without achieving a lot.One to catch when it's on the telly, but given the hype this is a bit disappointing.

reviews.review_title: A Refreshing look on a classic.
reviews.content: Planet of the Apes could perfectly be a part of the selected group of good remakes. This group of films could include movies such a The Fly, The Thing, and some others. The criteria to be a part of this selection would be that every new remake should try to take distance from the seminal classics. Those old and dear movies are classics, there's no sense in make the same movie using the same script and so. If there's any need of release a remake it is necessary a new take on the same tale.Tim Burton has done just that with his version of Planet of the Apes, and also has made the whole myth of this saga his own. Leo Davidson is a hard action astronaut but still he's very innocent just like many of the heroes of Burton. And these Apes who are a distorted image of us as society (greedy, intolerant). The special apes that don't follow these ideologies are the good sensitive beings. I think this is probably one of the most important messages in every good movie of Tim Burton, the special outsider view of the artist in a world who's not sensitive.Owning an amazing design of make-up, scenarios, and lots of practical FX, P.O.A is honest to the old fashion style of Sci-Fi .This is the remake that the seminal classic of 1968 deserves. A great cast of actor and actresses is here and they deliver over the top performances even wearing pound of Makeup! This new version pays homage to the first Planet from the first minute to the last. It deserves an absolute 10.

This is the kind of big, dumb movie Hollywood can make in it's sleep, and in this case, someone did.  The producers knew what they could sell; good visuals and the Planet of the Apes name, and that is all they deliver. This movie is only about how it looks.  If you care about story or characters (the makers obviously did not) you should look elsewhere.The half thought out plot has holes you could push a planet through.  Tim Burton tries to paper some of the holes with action cliches, most of which are embarrassingly bad.As to the cast, Mark Wahlberg is not bad in the lead, but the rest of the cast saved their good work for another film.  Tim Roth badly overplays the villain, General Thade.  Helena Bonham Carter is just there as the pro-human chimp Ari.  The rest of the cast has so little to work with, that they must have collectively said to themselves, "why bother?"Then there is the surprise ending.  It is a total waste of film.  While the ending of the original (and far better) Planet of the Apes was integral to the story, the surprise in this new version has that unmistakeable "tacked on" feel.  It comes out of nowhere, goes nowhere, and does not make sense at all.  It is as if the film makers wanted a visual surprise ending for no other reason than that the original had one, but that they didn't want to put very much thought into creating it.That is the overriding problem with this movie.  It goes for the easy sell visual, without putting any thought behind it.  As a result, it is only good for shutting off your brain for two hours.  If that's all you want from a movie, go for it.

Remakes are a hazardous business. Shown not least by all the completely wasted remakes floating around out there. And it seems remakes are all the rage today, considering how many movies are actually based on previous works. Right now the Asian industry is the one being plagued the worst by this trend.When it comes to unnecessary remakes i would have to rate this 2001 remake of the classic "Planet of the apes" as one of the foremost. This version of the movie is not without it's qualities, but in general it's a step down from the original in many ways. The social pathos is more or less completely removed, replaced instead with a focus on action and comedy. While the original movie commented on segregation in society and the arbitrary treatment of certain groups as lower standing, this movie doesn't deal with the themes at all. Of course there is a general discussion going on through the movie, and a tension between liberal and conservative powers, but it never feels like more than window dressing.The qualities here lie mostly in the sure-handed visual style that is director Tim Burtons hallmark. The effects as well as the set designs are top notch, as is the sound and music. The acting leaves a mixed impression. Tim Roth is quite astounding as the evil ape commander Thade, Mark Wahlberg is his usual pale self as the protagonist. The acting from the rest of the cast is decent enough.The qualities of this remake fall tragically short of making up for it's weaknesses. I feel that a remake should always have something new to offer if there is to be a point in remaking a movie in the first place. Not only does this movie have nothing new to offer, it even deducts many of the points of the original. And that makes this one of the most pointless, and even degrading, remakes ever. I rate it 3/10 for the entertainment it still provides despite it's obvious weaknesses as a remake.

I rated it a 7 for pure entertainment value, but...
Mark Wahlberg can't act. Perhaps we can blame some of the lines on the writers. Too monotone... sounds like a street thug instead of an educated astronaut.But where the original movie ends at the Statue of Liberty with the best (surprising) ending ever, especially for 1968, this movie may have the worst/silliest/rushed/predictable ending ever.I see similarities with the remake of The Time Machine where the Moorlocks seemed fairly weak in the 1960 version and they seemed to have super strength in the 2002 remake (gee, just a year after this movie).Here, in this remake, the Apes seem to have too much strength a la the Time Machine remake.The best thing about remakes are the inclusion of more sophisticated CGI. However, the script and action are inferior.Always love to see Paul Giamatti. He adds the only humor to this dark movie.

reviews.review_title: Not Going Ape For This One
reviews.content: I had anxiously anticipated the release of this movie since I first saw the trailer.  It looked promising, exciting and fun.  As I sat through this movie I was wondering..."Why am I sitting through this movie?"  "Planet" leaves much to be desired.  The only thing great about this movie are the visual effects.  If you love effects, you won't be disappointed.  I like effects but not in place of a good story line which this movie certainly lacked.  I saw the original and was floored by the awesome story told. This version said nothing.  It had no balance, no texture, no nothing but lots of awesome effects.  I guess Hollywood thinks audiences today are too brainless to follow a plot that they feel they need to entertain us with an all you can see buffet instead of giving us some credit to THINK!  I was disappointed to say the least.  But the effects were great! :)

....after 16 years Tim Burton finally disappoints me!!!! Whatever happened to the old Burton who read "The Dark Knight Returns" by Frank Miller as research for his preparation to direct Batman back in 1988-89? By the looks of it Burton didn't research the book nor the movie cause he got everything WRONG! This movie sucks! It's not as good as the original and it doesn't deal with the same subject as the original. If you want a good ape movie watch the original.**out of****stars

reviews.review_title: Didn't Live Up To The Apes Legacy
reviews.content: Burton took the great 1968 heady drama and simply turned it intoan action pic with tons of makeup, and I have the impression hemissed the whole point of POTA.  It wasn't supposed to be anaction-packed tour de force, but rather a thinking man's film.  Whathappened to the debates about man's role in this society?  Whatabout the science and experiments conducted on man in the oldermovie?  I had other problems with the film too: Helena BonhamCarter seemed too overly obsessed with this human too quicklyand for no reason.  Where the heck was Cornelius anyway?  Sowhy did I give it a 7?  The makeup was truly fantastic, and theaction choreographed well.  As a standalone movie, it would havebeen alright, but unfortunately, it has a legacy to live up to.  Thesecond reason for the high score was the sexy, sensuouspresence of Estella Warren.  It seems she was cheated out of arole here; why didn't she become romantically involved with him? What was her backstory?  Anyway, a fairly decent action flick worththe matinee price; not $8.25.

reviews.review_title: Didn't Live Up To The Apes Legacy
reviews.content: Burton took the great 1968 heady drama and simply turned it into an action pic with tons of makeup, and I have the impression he missed the whole point of POTA.  It wasn't supposed to be an action-packed tour de force, but rather a thinking man's film.  What happened to the debates about man's role in this society?  What about the science and experiments conducted on man in the older movie?  I had other problems with the film too: Helena Bonham Carter seemed too overly obsessed with this human too quickly and for no reason.  Where the heck was Cornelius anyway?  So why did I give it a 7?  The makeup was truly fantastic, and the action choreographed well.  As a standalone movie, it would have been alright, but unfortunately, it has a legacy to live up to.  The second reason for the high score was the sexy, sensuous presence of Estella Warren.  It seems she was cheated out of a role here; why didn't she become romantically involved with him?What was her backstory?  Anyway, a fairly decent action flick worth the matinee price; not $8.25.

Planet of the Apes Tim Burton-style is a disappointment. It's a good film, but I have learned to expect more from Burton than just 'good'. As with all Burton-films though, Planet of the Apes is visually stunning. Costumes, make-up (brilliant!), the production design, the cinematography... Simply amazing. However, the script is seriously lacking pace in the first half hour and the ending is an abomination! One of the worst movie endings in years. Doesn't stand a chance in comparison with the ending in the first Planet of the Apes. After the slow beginning, the movie builds up nicely to a final battle scene, which is great, but that ending... My, my... What a mistake.In a fine cast (though Mark Wahlberg is a bit boring) Tim Roth is certainly the stand-out. He delivers a great performance as Thade.In short, an entertaining sci-fi adventure which is let down by a silly ending and a slow start. Visuals are stunning and well worth the admission price.Could have been such a great film... (6/10)

reviews.review_title: Weak second half of the film capped by nonsensical ending
reviews.content: * WARNING - THIS COMMENT CONTAINS SOME SPOILERS *I haven't seen the original movie, so I watched this with a completely open mind, without any expectations (except for the fact that I expect Tim Burton films to be top notch!)... ...anyway, the movie starts off in great enough fashion with some nice special fx. Burton does well to convey the Wahlberg character's sense of desolation after crashing on the planet and an interesting subplot ensues, involving Helena Bonham Carter's ape character and the attempt to escape from their masters. Tim Roth is absolutely outstanding as the general - you won't see a more expressive pair of eyes! The love triangle element with Estella Warren's character (what a beauty!) is also fairly well handled.The film simmers along nicely for the first half and then completely degenerates towards the end. The first absurdity is when (*SPOILERS AHEAD*)Wahlberg's monkey jets in and stops the battle - the scene just looked silly, it did not look like it could turn the tide of the battle...then later the henchmen (sorry henchapes!) of the general capitulate too quickly without really being convinced.And the "twist" ending was just well...incomprehensible I thought...another writer here said he found it easy to understand because it was a take on the original film's ending....but for someone like me who hasn't seen the original, I just thought - huh? Was it meant to be a "what-if?" scenario, or was it a direct consequence of what had happened before? I couldn't get my head around it...maybe I'm thick...need to think about it a bit more, but I suspect that I still won't get it...Overall - a good first half to the movie....great performance from Roth and Wahlberg was good too...Burton got the visual style of the film spot on and the costumes and ape make up were just awesome and any special fx used looked good...unfortunately, plot holes and inconsistencies in the second half of the movie undid all the good work and effort put into the rest of the film.

When I heard that Planet of the Apes was coming to theaters I was excited. I had vague memories of the T.V. show from when I was a kid, but not enough to give me any real high expectations of the movie. Now, even with no high expectations, and not knowing what the eventual outcome would be, I was still disappointed.This movie was really predicated upon action and suspense, but little other content value. The standoff at the end was OK minus the incredibly stupid and cliché stunt by the young boy. The story just lacked creativity, especially in light of my having seen the original Planet of the Apes. There was absolutely no comparison. The story, the dialogue, and even the ending was so cutting edge and socially relevant. Planet of the Apes 2001 did not do justice to its predecessor.

reviews.review_title: Hollywood has a hopeless predilection for ripping itself off during the 21st century
reviews.content: The original PotA movies will eternally be ground-braking, epic and timeless. Once you've reached the top of your game there's nowhere else to go but downhill. It's a fool's errand attempting to improve upon perfection. Stop with these unnecessary unwarranted jackass remakes marketed solely to millennials including their hokey cartoonish CGI embellishments.

reviews.review_title: Just Not the Same Without Charlton Heston in a Loincloth
reviews.content: Tim Burton takes a disappointingly literal approach to remaking the 1968 cult classic, and what he gives us is an undistinguished action film, not necessarily worse than any number of action films produced in a given year, but so much worse than it could have been given the source material and Burton's fierce imagination.Tim Roth is the standout among the simian characters -- he actually scared the crap out of me. The shock ending to the original was so well known that Burton knew he had to come up with something different, and to tell you the truth I can't even remember what it was; that might give you an indication as to how effective it was.The opening credit sequence is this film's high point, and it all goes downhill from there.Grade: C

This movie is definitely Tim Burtons best. This movie also gets criticized by many people which it does not deserve at all. It is entertaining and has terrific make up work. I think it should get nominated for an oscar for its make up. The movie did not make as much money as I expected. It made $178 Million and I expected it to make at least 200 million but there was so much competition that i think it did fine, and will do much better on video and dvd.

I have NEVER ever been do disgusted/disappointed with a movie. (Well, there was that Artificial Intelligence movie that made me laugh SO hard @ the end I had to plug my nose from laughing so hard so the REST of the people in the audience wouldn't hate me, since most of them were INTO it.!!)Please don't see this movie. It's stupid. There's nothing good about it except the makeup/costume bit. The ending was ridiculous. The acting made me vomit.
