There was *no* character development, and the character you DID get developed to was that stupid Chimp, who by the time made his second appearance, you wanted to leave.Come on. Really? I want my money back.

reviews.review_title: The worst movie since Waterworld, and the worst remake ever!
reviews.content: This movie is so bad that the only thing that could adequately describe it would be a particularly-foul-smelling, one-hundred-minute fart. The producer, director, and screen-writer should all win 'Chumpies' (or should that be 'Chimpies'?) at the Anti-Oscar Awards.The acting is so bad that, no doubt, Kris Kristofferson pleaded to be killed early in order to escape the locale. Most of the other actors were mainly trained to say, "Grrr!" and leap about like demented chimps.The attempts at humor are pathetic, being mostly banal take-offs on modern stand-up one-liners. The hero is a blockhead space pilot who can't fly as well as a trained chimp, and whose face is far less expressive.If you're going to rent this movie, be sure to rustle up a biiig bag of popcorn, 'cuz you're going to want something to put over your head to escape the worst remake, ever!

reviews.review_title: This Ranks Amongst the Worst of This Franchise.
reviews.content: Planet of the Apes (2001): Dir: Tim Burton / Cast: Mark Wahlberg, Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth, Michael Clarke Duncan, Paul Giamatti: Pointless remake about a dominating factor higher than man. This planet is dominated by advanced apes who conquer human tress passers. Mark Wahlberg leads a team in space and they send a chimpanzee into orbit. After crash landing they are enslaved by ape warriors. Ending is a laughable mess that makes one wonder whether Tim Burton is losing his touch. This is not the superb work he demonstrated with Ed Wood and Sleepy Hollow. Wahlberg delivers one of his worst performances as this space captain thrust into a constant ass kicking by apes. Helena Bonham Carter plays a female ape who has compassion on him. Unfortunately that compassion boarders heavily on bestiality. It is disturbing watching these two ogle each other. Tim Roth plays a heavy tempered ape who just wants to use Wahlberg as a trampoline. Michael Clarke Duncan plays a humungous warrior ape because this is what we all call type casting. Paul Giamatti plays an orangutan meant for comic effect but the joke is on him. The makeup effects and visual elements are about the only aspect worth going ape over. Hints of bestiality are totally disgusting but the screenplay is totally monkey brained and without the complexity of the original. Score: 2 / 10

Perhaps I had too high of expectations for this movie. Tim Burton has made some great films -- Beetlejuice, Batman, Edward Scissorhands, Nightmare Before Christmas, Ed Wood and Sleepy Hollow. He also made some turkeys in Batman Returns and Mars Attacks! Put Planet of the Apes down as another turkey, one of his worst.This movie is billed as of the Sci-Fi Action genre, but there is little science in it. We are supposed to believe that a chimp and later Captain Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) flies through a cosmic storm and is instantaneously transported through time into the future. Not only that, the ship that tries to save the insubordinate Davidson ends up crash landing on the same planet but in the present time. They were carrying a cage full of chimpanzees and one of them starts a colony on the planet. Some of the humans who survived start a human species, but yet on this future parallel world, for some unexplainable reason the chimpanzees evolve faster and become masters over the humans. The air and water is equal to that of our own Earth but mysteriously the planet was uninhabited before.Given the chance, Burton can make some great character driven and imaginative movies such as Batman, Edward Scissorhands and Ed Wood. In Apes, he doesn't have a chance with the poorly written script and weak direction. The movie instead focuses more on the action and we don't see a buildup of Wahlberg's character except towards the end. Other characters are introduced, but there are few connections with the audience. Helen Bonham Carter's performance as Ari is worthy, but we don't know exactly why she feels a connection to humans enough to risk losing her life. Kris Kristofferson is there to be killed off. Tim Roth does a creditable job as the angry and malevolent General Thade, one of the descendants of first chimpanzees on the planet. Both Michael Clarke Duncan and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa are good as Attar, General Thade's friend and trusted warrior Krull who is Attar's foil and Ari's guard.The cinematography, set designs, and technical aspects of the movie are fabulous. Rick Baker and Colleen Atwood does superb and remarkable work as the make up and costumes. Danny Elfman, who won an award for the Batman score, does a fantastic job again with Apes. This was a big budget picture and money was well spent in these areas.The ending made no sense whatsoever. If you get that far, suffice it to say the final scene looked as if it was added just so there would be some storyline in order to make a sequel. I truly hope the producers of this stinker lost so much money, they won't dare try again.

reviews.review_title: No point to this film - avoid!
reviews.content: The original Planet of the Apes is a much more satisfying picture than this pathetic attempt. There is no point to this film. There's no strong narrative, there's no strong plot, and a major miscast!Marky Mark gives his worst performance yet, there are no layers to his acting in this one! He looked bored!The film lacks original plot ideas, anything new is laughable. The humans serve no purpose in the film, there's no conflict amongst them. The whole slave thing is old and tired.The make-up is tremendous, Baker deserves all the accolades! The direction by Burton is easily one of his worst, he needed a lot more time to develop the picture. Visually, the film is excellent, dark and moody at times. A sequel might be better handled by Burton, I think it's suited to his eccentric style.Stick with the original, miles better than this post-modern work.

reviews.review_title: It's hard not to like a Tim-Burton-film
reviews.content: ATTENTION, SPOILER!Many people told me that «Planet of the Apes» was Tim Burton's worst movie and apart from that much weaker than the original film. So I decided not to see it. Another friend of mine who hadn't seen the movie yet, advised me to watch it in spite of this because `a Tim-Burton-movie is still a Tim-Burton-movie'. I decided to do it, and I found that he was right.It's clear that a remake of such a famous film as `Planet of the Apes' is automatically influenced by commercial thinking. Still, Tim Burton managed his film to represent his weird playfulness just as well as `Beetlejuice' or `Batman'. If you are already fond of Burton-movies, it's hard not to like one of his films, even if it has some flaws: nerve-racking monkey squeals, over-dressed apes and a leading actor who could have been, without difficulties, replaced by anbody else.What the film gives us in the first place, is an answer to the question: What's the result when Tim Burton is instructed to create a remake? First of all, Burton wouldn't be Burton, if he wouldn't refuse to call it a remake from the start; it's a `re-imagining'. On the other hand, Burton knows that almost every viewer of his movie has seen the very first film version starring Charlton Heston (as human), and he knows that a remake doesn't exist without its model and that the two films will not stop being compared. So all he does is playing with this comparison at every moment of his film, e. g. by referencing to quotes. Concerning the story-line, Burton does a brilliant job by answering open questions of the original first, and then driving the whole audience to despair by destroying this wonderful clarity and ending the movie with  AND HERE IS THE SPOILER  Leo coming back to earth and finding himself inside a world that seems to have been ruled by apes forever. Now, this is the burtonesque answer to people's expectations they hold because of the astonishing, shocking ending of the first `Planet of the Apes'. An ending, even more unexpected, more astonishing and: completely confusing, because  and here I'm disagreeing with various `Planet of the Apes'-homepages and -platforms  it does not make any sense. There cannot be a meaning to it, or just a so complicated one that it becomes ineffective. Tim Burton is playing his cruel games, he does it with a grin and he does it well. Burton fans will sure like it, others may feel betrayed and complain about some sort of manierism. Well, and I don't think producers will ever ask Burton to direct a remake again

You really have to wonder sometimes about big studio decision making. Do they screen movies like this and pat each other on the back, hand the director a cigar and crawl off to bed thinking how incredible smart they all are? Or is it that halfway through production, it all begins to fall apart and money already spent cannot be recovered and the project becomes a salvage effort. The balloon ego of an overrated director is pricked, and although he must still put his signature to it, decides to punish the studio for its blindness to his genius vision, by handing them a bomb that they all hope people wont recognizes. Who knows, I actually believe that while movies in the past have been miscast, this is an example of a movie having been misdirected. Burton's world creation just doesnt work here. Its completely claustrophobic, and unrealistic. Contrast to the original classic, which utilized all open panoramic scenery that was disturbingly too realistic. Burton creates a Gilligans island atmosphere, and coupled with the horrible story - you get a bad bad movie. So lets recap, you have a good book to work with, a great original movie to study, and the end result is this piece of junk that ignores both. Again, its not Burtons fault. He is a one trick pony, and some of his movies are great. But selecting him to make this was stupid, and allowing him to actually complete and release it, dumber still.

`Planet of the Apes' is a joyless, soulless and utterly pointless remake of the 1968 sci-fi classic.  The original film had two strong elements going for it:  its expansive visual style and its playful spirit.  Both qualities have been effectively eliminated in Tim Burton's update, along with the sense of wonder that came, thirty-three years ago, when the material was still innovative and fresh.  What viewer can forget the time he first saw that stunning final shot of the earlier version, with a weary Charlton Heston coming upon the remains of the Statue of Liberty - then bellowing in outrage at the tragic reality hitherto unrevealed to both him and us? Burton, not wanting to be a slavish devotee to the original (and not wanting the audience to know everything about the story in advance of entering the theatre), attempts a similar `surprise' ending here, but the execution of it is so ludicrous, confused and clumsy that all one can do is scratch one's head and giggle in bemused befuddlement.Much of the effectiveness of the original `Planet of the Apes' lay in its deliberately paced buildup.  The early stretches of the film, in which Heston and his fellow astronauts wandered the desert in search of life, helped immensely in generating an atmosphere of suspense and mystery.  In the new version, however, the lone hero, Thade (Mark Wahlberg), crash lands on the planet and, almost instantaneously, finds himself caught in this strange world in which evolution seems to have taken a reverse course, where apes speak and have dominion over docile humans - though they're not quite as docile as they were in the first version since in this edition the humans speak, rendering absurd the idea that the apes would consider humans to be a subspecies.   Also, in the original version, much of the time was spent focusing on Heston's attempts to convince the apes that he was every bit as smart as they were.  Thus, much of the pleasure of the film came from the fact that there seemed to be a duel of wits going on between apes and humans  a contest that often took the form of high-spirited, clever and even witty dialogue exchanges.  For all the ludicrousness of its premise, the original `Planet of the Apes' was not a DUMB movie.  I wish one could say the same for the remake.  The plotting in this version essentially boils down to little more than an extended and distended chase story, with apes racing madly after humans from one dimly lit locale to the next. 
And here we come upon another problem with the movie  one it shares with many modern action flicks, actually, especially those made by Burton.  It is simply shot too dark.  One of the qualities that distinguished the original film from most of the sci-fi adventure films that came before it was the near-epic feeling created by its beautiful wide screen images of the desert setting.  These shots lent a visual impressiveness to the potentially childish material and helped to bring an aura of seriousness to the proceedings.  In Burton's version, however, the visual style is often dark, cramped and confining, not at all conducive to the sense of majesty and awe that Franklin Schaffner's version afforded.Wahlberg is a bland substitute for Heston who, dressed only in a loincloth and hissing virtually every line through clenched teeth, seemed to sense the camp potential hidden beneath the story's surface  a fact not acknowledged by the stolid Wahlberg (or by Burton for that matter).  How we miss the charming personalities of Roddy McDowell and Kim Hunter as the sympathetic ape characters.  Poor Helena Bonham Carter, in the Hunter role, doesn't get to recite even one vaguely amusing line.  It seems amazing that a movie made thirty-three years ago would take itself so much less seriously than a film made today.  One would expect that a filmmaker like Burton, known for his ability to find humor in the most macabre of situations, would be the last director to take such a humorless, deadpan approach to material like this.   The original `Planet of the Apes' managed to combine the elements of originality, suspense, humor, irony, surprise and visual acuity to create a work of lasting value and interest. My prediction is that copies of it will still be on video store shelves long after this remake has hit the bargain-price recycling bins.

reviews.review_title: Awful doesn't begin to describe it
reviews.content: This movie was terrible.  It was essentially a movie about slavery and little else.  There is no logical reason for the premise of this remake.  In the original, the humans couldn't talk and were essentially disorganized savages creating a more plausible basis for the movie.  In this one they are merely weaker and presumably more stupid.  The Apes seemed to continually shift between the intelligent creatures to primitive apes lending even less credibility to the plot.Some of the costumes were very well done and some looked only marginally different from the original movie.  The effects were ok by today's standards but subpar for what this films tries to bill itself up to be.

reviews.review_title: A monkey could have done a better job
reviews.content:
Overall, this movie pretty much sucked.  I mean this could have been great, and the studio even thought it would be by talking about sequels before the first one hit the theater. Boy, were they wrong. I don't guess the sequel will be made because it will be too expensive to make such an awful film.
There is one good thing about this movie. The make-up.  The actors really do look like talking apes. And all the apes look different with their own unique face. The teeth even look real.
Now back to the plot.  Why was Estella Warren even in this? She did nothing. At least the female ape did something.  (SPOILERS): And that chimp landing the space pod at the end, which basically saves the humans, is so convient. I mean, come on, why did it take so long for the chimp to land when Leo crashed his ship days earlier.  And leo is not well written.  I think he should have been more shocked and stuff when he first saw apes talking.(END OF SPOILERS)
FINAL VERDICT:  You might want to watch it for half an hour just to see the realistic looking apes.  But, don't waste 2 hours to see this flop.

reviews.review_title: Tim Burtons worst film so far!
reviews.content: I am a big fan of both Tim Burton and the original Apes films.. So it's easy to understand I was both anxious to see this new version as well as sceptical.I was expecting to be disappointed, but nothing prepared me for what happened. The first hour of the movie was ok, the last was embarresing.The humans could speak. The Gorillas were silly. Helena Bonham Carter behaved and looked like a human.. The only really cool things were the tributes to the original movie... "God damn! Damn them all to hell!" and so forth!Where the hell did those horses come from?

DO NOT believe reviews deeming Tim Burton's vision of Planet Of The Apes as shallow. The film is breathtaking in splendor in the spirit of an epic such as Lord of The Rings. It is also hugely entertaining in terms of plot, script, balanced story structure and cinematography. A possible reason why the average gun loving movie goer (brainwashed by a war mongering mainstream not-so-thought-out point of view) would not appreciate Tim Burton's vision is the Director's anti-war sentiment that carries a subtle under-tone of acceptance throughout the film. The movie is great-looking. Rick Baker's makeup is convincing even in the extreme closeups, and his apes sparkle with personality and presence. The sets and locations give us a proper sense of alien awe. Tim Burton made a film that's respectful to the original, and respectable in itself. Easily a 8/10.

reviews.review_title: WORTH the TRIP - PRIMAL ENERGY to the MAX!
reviews.content: Whether you see movies like this one for the saga, the heroism, or the action, you won't be disappointed.Make sure you see this one in the theater first; don't wait until it comes out on video. Much of the energy and intensity is conveyed by the audio and the especially moving soundtrack. So, unless your Stereo-VCR speakers are the size of a laundry basket, and your TV screen is the size of a beach blanket, enjoy PLANET of the APES on a gorilla-size scale: Splurge for the tix & ENJOY !!

This is one of the worst wastes of money & resources I've seen. From make-up that was no better...and in some cases worse...than 1968's version to destruction of a creative plot line in the original, to screaming, jumping violence that makes it inappropriate for seeing as a bonding experience with children, to the blatant & sophomoric political commentary against opposing political & religious views (clever & subtle in the '68 original) this thing is a hairy, stinky mess. The only reason I "stuck with it" through to the end was thinking there had to be some redeeming value. Rrmembering the shocking ending of the original I'd hoped something similar would happen here. But they mucked up even that. Why I expected more from people with so little creativity that they got paid for mimicking (like chimps?) the wardrobe design of '68, too, instead of doing something new. If you go to the zoo you may see primates throw their poop at you. This movie is why.

reviews.review_title: You should have read the book Tim !
reviews.content: (Spoilers ahead)How is it possible that in the spitting image of Washington the earth is full of apes who can drive, use fire weapons while in the future they don't know anything about modern technology ?If everything was fine on earth in 2029, the year the story begins, how could the apes have evolved this fast in only 71 years (Wahlberg goes back to earth in 2100) ?Is it possible for a chimpanzee to alter into a speaking-gorilla or a orang otang in one century ?If the Lincoln-Thade from Washington is the same monkey as the one from the middle ages, how was it possible for him to drive the shuttle back to earth in order to reduce mankind to slavery ?Is it possible to hesitate between Estella Warren and a monkey ?It's a shame that 100 million bucks were squandered to make this movie. 1 point for you Estella even though your character is pointless and another one for the well-done make up effects. 2/10 stars

reviews.review_title: When give something 5.7 your say it is good you know that write.
reviews.content: Why did this get a 5.7 It is awful. The original Planet of the apes from 1968 is a good movie. This is awful. It has an awful story line. It also has an awful ending. I do not know why people like this movie.

This is possibly the worst movie remake ever.  Tim Burton should be ashamed that he made this garbage.  Planet of the apes without any of the original characters makes this a complete waste of time, and diminishes the original. The only thing that could have made this movie better is if Marky Mark was not the lead.

I have to say that I was disappointed. It didnt have the same shock values as the original... For example, the humans here could talk! And when Marky Mark 1st saw them, it was like "oh, hey, these monkeys can talk... isn't that something?" The visuals were impressive but thats it... The extras are cool... I tried not to compare with the original, but you cant help it. When in the original, Heston 1st noticed the apes running around in horses, it was like WOW!! Then when he speaks, it was like Oh oh... Here is like nothing. When Marky Mark asked some of the other humans stuff like "Hey whats going on here?" The humans where like "Oh, well you see it's like this...". The dvd has one of the things I hate the most... If you miss a line and cant understand what was said, you cant just pop the subtitles... You have to go to the main menu... Same for the sound... The end was neat but I wont give it away... Not to buy, just rent and you'll survive...

I think there are more than enough plus points in POTA to make it well worth watching. Firstly I think the make-up of the apes and the way they move is outstanding, the whole look of the film is excellent. The music by Danny Elfman is great. Tim Burton does a great job directing the action. I thought all the actors were great, apart from Wahlberg who I find a little wooden, I thought the same about him in The Italian Job but he's not that bad. Tim Roth is the best and makes a great villain, one of his best performances since Rob Roy I feel. I'm actually surprised how many of the IMDB users seem to hate this film, probably because the ending doesn't seem to make sense. I too found the ending baffling but I enjoyed the ride in getting there. I must say It took me a long time to get round to seeing this movie, I eventually picked it up very cheaply in a supermarket and I'm glad I bought it. Sadly I think the overall reaction to this film has killed any chances there were of there being a Planet of the Apes II. Pity because I would have loved to have to seen how they would have tried to explain the ending. Also I must say I enjoyed this Tim Burton film a lot more than some of his others namely Batman Returns and Mars Attacks, I think he delivered a great movie here. Oh well each to their own ***7/10***

First of all, one of the central plot elements of the original was that the humans couldn't speak. The second I realized that element of the plot had been changed, I knew it was going to be a pretty rough ride. The capper comes when Marky Mark climbs into a space vehicle which has apparently been sitting out in the desert for hundreds or thousands of years. He tears a six inch layer of dust and crud from the front of a computer console, which, miraculously, still works perfectly. Puh-leeze. The ending was senseless and idiotic, it quite frankly insulted my intelligence, as did the entire film, for that matter. I absolutely hated this movie, I had high expectations going in and felt ripped off after sitting through this weak effort.

I was looking forward to seeing this movie.  After finally watching it I felt disappointed and confused.  Too many questions left unanswered.  Very poor job of making it seem realistic.  The special effects are mildly entertaining but don't make up for the poor story.  This was the most over-hyped movie of the past 5 years.  I wouldn't see it again for free.

reviews.review_title: Nice plastic suits - shame about the rest
reviews.content: Tim Roth seemed a bit apologetic at the Edinburgh Film Festival premiere of this movie `It's just a bit of fun . . . treat it as a bit of fun' he kept saying. Well Tim, get a family of four together with nowt to do on a Saturday afternoon and it might be a bit of fun. Gather several hundred film addicts together for the surprise movie of the festival and expecting the same reception is a bit much (especially when they could see it at half the price the next day when it went on general release). The costumes are very good: technology and makeup has come a long way since the first cult movie classic of the same name. Unfortunately script seems to have gone backwards. The movie starts promisingly enough with a space station time-slip introduction. But having gone to enormous lengths to create the situation and life-like apes, the whole thing is ruined by resting on awful dialogue and corny 20th century jokes that are guaranteed to avert any suspension of disbelief. These super-intelligent apes toy with humans that they capture and one can't help feeling the filmmaker is toying with the audience too. One is reminded of Director Tim Burton's reputed comment that he only wanted to make movies in order to make money. If he has shown great originality and creativity in recent films to suggest he didn't mean that, this film, on the other hand, simply looks like little more than one narrow filmmaker's dream come true again . . .

reviews.review_title: A bad remake of a good movie
reviews.content: Well, here we have Tim Burton's latest opus.  No, not a short fat penguin, but I'm sure he has a unsettlingly dark and creepy film adaptation of Bloom County up his sleeve somewhere.  After all, you saw what he did to poor Batman, once a proud superhero who often found himself in goofy contrived plots fighting pastel colored villains, he now is a dark, scary, menacing type inhabiting the now perpetually nocturnal Gotham City.On the other hand, Tim Burton actually isn't that bad of a director when he's working with original material.  I rather liked Ed Wood and I thought that Edward Scissorhands had some good moments.  But when it comes to doing remakes of older movies, or film adaptations of television shows, he just plain sucks.  Case in point, Planet of the Apes.  What once was a fascinating film with a biting, socially relevant anti-war message has become a "Taco-Bell commemorative cup free with purchase of a large soda" kind of movie. Imagine if this kind of thing catches on, someday we may see a remake of Dr. Strangelove with Gary Oldman playing the base commander, Bill Pullman as the president, Tom Arnold as the Joint Chief of Staff, and Will Smith riding the bomb to his death in blazing color, followed by a hip-hop remix of "We'll Meet Again" playing over the closing credits.Anyhow, getting back to the movie.  There is one particular scene in this movie I find particularly troubling.  Toward the beginning, when the whistle/spaceship thing the hero was flying crashed on the planet, it came in at an acute angle through the trees and crashed in a swampy, wooded area. The ship then subsequently sank.  This is a BLATENT rip off of Star Wars. When I saw this scene, I forgot what movie I was watching and was temporarily disoriented when I didn't see Yoda shortly afterward.  Now, I know that ideas are sometimes borrowed from other movies, and that's okay. But I would appreciate it if they could at least TRY to change it around a little, or give it a new twist.  But no, they didn't.  They could have saved some money if they had just reused the scene from Star Wars (which probably cost one-tenth as much to film).Well, it happened, they remade Planet of the Apes, leaving a nasty stain on the rich tapestry of western culture.

reviews.review_title: Very enjoyable and has some nice homages to the early film & book.
reviews.content: Planet of the Apes, 2001.*Spoiler/plot- A modern exploratory black hole USAF station is using chimps to navigate around the through a black hole. One chimp is lost and his concerned trainer human follows the chip's spacecraft to only find a ape planet in civil war.*Special Stars- Mark Wahlber, DIR- Tim BUrton.*Theme- Exploration can involve time, history, and societies.*Trivia/location/goofs- Location: Planetary desert or 'Calima' was Trona Pinnacles, Ridgecrest CA and Lake . The background performers at the Trona Pinnacles area were poisoned when the film production decided to use crushed walnut shells instead of Fuller's Earth for desert dust storms. Several people got sick because of the allergies to walnut products and the production was shut-down for some days for safety of all. Look for Charlton Heston in this film playing General Thade's ancient father. Also the many famous lines and scenes appear in this film with many interesting Tim Burton twists.*Emotion- A lush and different plot from the earlier 20th Century Fox film franchise series. Very enjoyable and has some nice homages to the early film more brighter dialog and memorable scenes.*Based on- French author's Boule famous book.

Planet of the Apes (2001)This movie was terrific and had non-stop action from beginning to end. The scenery was very beautiful, the photography...breathtaking; the lush forest, the expansive wasteland, the dark brutish city.Leo Davidson  (Mark Wahlberg) is a flyer for the Air Force on a floating base in space itching to fly out of there into the deep and do his job.  But instead they send the genetically altered monkeys, just like canaries into a mine.Well Leo's furry fellow astronaut is in trouble out in space and Leo goes out there to bring him and the flying pod back in an unauthorized rescue mission. And as you can probably guess, from there things take an unexpected turn. Crashing into a simian world Leo has to fight the persistent General Thade (Tim Roth) and his army of apes.  General Thade has a merciless hatred for humans which is boundless and unexplained.  And so the story flows from one battle scene to another.The story is simple and therefore easy to understand; the battle for survival.   The battle for freedom from slavery.  The battle for dignity and self determination.The fantastically twisted ending leaves an opening for a sequel.  Usually it disappointments me when a movie leaves too many loose ends for the purpose of creating a sequel; but this is not the case here.  This movie and it's story is over and leaves an opening for (I hope) another exciting movie.`SweetVenom' Bob

reviews.review_title: Not a bad remake, but it could have done much better.
reviews.content: The 2001 remake of the original 1968 classic, "PLANET of the APES" is directed by Tim Burton and starring Mark Wahlberg as the lead character and since I'm only doing three of the PLANET of the APES film reviews, I decided to start off with this one.The sixth film produced in the Planet of the Apes franchise, it was loosely adapted from Pierre Boulle's 1963 novel of the same name and the 1968 film version. It tells the story of astronaut Leo Davidson crash-landing on a planet inhabited by intelligent apes. The apes treat humans as slaves, but with the help of an ape named Ari, Leo starts a rebellion. The film also stars Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, Paul Giamatti, and Estella WarrenDevelopment for a Planet of the Apes remake started as far back as 1988 with Adam Rifkin. His project nearly reached the pre-production stage before being canceled. Terry Hayes's script, titled Return of the Apes, would have starred Arnold Schwarzenegger, under the direction of Phillip Noyce. Oliver Stone, Don Murphy, and Jane Hamsher were set to produce. Creative differences ensued between Hayes and financier/distributor 20th Century Fox. Chris Columbus, Sam Hamm, James Cameron, Peter Jackson, and the Hughes brothers later became involved.With William Broyles, Jr.'s script, Tim Burton was hired as director, and the film was put into active development. Lawrence Konner and Mark Rosenthal rewrote the script, and filming took place from November 2000 to April 2001. Planet of the Apes was released to mixed reviews, but was a financial success. Much criticism focused on the confusing plot and ending, although Rick Baker's prosthetic makeup designs were praised.The story is a little confusing, but it is easy to look at for me, but for everyone else, a lot of people and critics and also fans of the franchise hates this story and the ending. The ending is just confusing also, but it's easy to overlook these two major flaws.The music by Danny Elfman is just awesome and the song that plays during the end credits titled, "Rule the Planet Remix" is awesome, mixed by Paul Oakenfold and composed by Danny Elfman. The rest of the music including the opening theme music is just spectacular and the film does wonders with the music.The visual effects and makeup is just spectacular also, but Rick Baker did the prosthetic make-up effects for the apes and it is a blessing of him. The visuals are a little cheesy, but works for this type of movie.The acting, is just good and bad. The only credit that will be given to is Mark Wahlberg, his performance as the lead was amazing. Helena Bonham Carter, Estella Warren and Michael Clarke Duncan puts on really good performances as well, but they can get way too over-the- top in some of the scenes. Paul Giamatti is hilarious and he does an amazing job. Luke Eberl and Erick Avari is in the film, too, but they're performances were a little confusing. Charlton Heston has a cameo as Thade's dad. Tim Roth plays the villain, Thade and he is okay, but even then, he is over-the-top as well.Overall, with the 2001 remake of Planet of the Apes, it's not a bad re-imagining, but it could have done much better than this. I like and hate this remake of the 1968 original classic.Despite its financial success, 20th Century Fox chose not to produce a sequel, and later rebooted the franchise in 2011 with Rise of the Planet of the Apes.

reviews.review_title: Why are sequels rarely as good as the original?
reviews.content: I was contemplating that question after watching remakes of The Time Machine and Planet of the Apes.  The answer of course is that people always do remakes of good movies. They really should be doing remakes of bad movies, they are ones that need it.And there is no better example of the above then The Planet of the Apes, a movie that is such a pale imitation of the original that I was angry at myself for paying $4 to see it.Tim Burton is a very good director, I'm usually a fan of his work.  But, with this movie he seems to have gotten so caught up with turning actors into monkeys that he lost sight everything else.  The movie has great makeup, but no soul.  It just reeks of being a directors vanity project. This movie far surpasses the original in it presentation of the monkey planet, i.e. make-up, effects, acting, yet is less believeable.Burton also seems to have been so consumed with his monkey cast, he forgot his humans.  It can not go unmentioned how insipid Mark Wahlberg is movie. A potted plant would have held my attention as much as he did.And finally, nothing illustrates the futility of trying to remake this movie then the "surprise ending".  Obviously, he couldn't do the same ending as the original, it wouldn't be a surprise.  So it became necessary to come up with something totally different, but would still have the power and impact of the original.  Well, I guess they couldn't think anything so they decided to go with nonsensical instead.  Yes folks, the big surprise is that the movie's ending MAKE NO SENSE!!! None, zero, zippo.

reviews.review_title: Out in space somewhere, just like Tim Burton's head
reviews.content: Truly, the rushed nature of this film had plenty to do with the overall lameness of the film. While I'll give it a 6 for ingenuity and make-up, the technical aspects just couldn't provide enough of a punch. Estella Warren and Kris Kristopherson had no business being in this film, as did Markyoops, Mark Wahlberg. The only actors who helped this film were Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter and Michael Duncan Clarke. The story was just far too convoluted in many parts. Perhaps they should have started earlier on this film, or moved it back, simply because acting looked too wooden in so many parts. A sad homage to the original.

reviews.review_title: This version don't offer social, theological and political criticisms but presents interesting differences and fictional alternatives
reviews.content: This remake is headed by the renowned Tim Burton (Edward Scissorhands (1990) Batman (1989), Big Fish (2003), Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (2004), Alice in Wonderland (2010)) and tells the story of astronaut Leo Davidson, that in the near future, participate in space exploration. For farms, monkeys were trained to fly small space capsules recognition not to expose humans in danger and the unknown chimpanzee Pericles ends up being swallowed by a temporal rift in space. To investigate an electromagnetic storm and recover your trained monkey who had not returned to the ship, Leo, opposing his fellow ship enters a small ship and goes to rescue him. But Leo has an accident and ends up landing on a primitive planet and dangerous primates where tyrants and intelligent speakers that form the local, enslave humans who are mistreated and treated like wild animals. Leo ends up being captured as you arrive on the planet along with a group trying to escape, and after the initial shock and disgusted with the way humans are treated, he plans a social revolution on the planet and becomes a threat to primates. Aided by Ari monkey, human rights advocate and a veteran former Army Military ape, deposed by dishonestly fearsome General Thade, a chimpanzee who hates humans and violently defends his extermination of the planet, Leo and a group of humans will try escaping the place.The criticisms made in Pierre Boulle's book and which are on a smaller scale or do not exist in the two adaptations for the cinema are many and well punctuated, such as, for example, the way man treats animals and acts as the owner of the planet Earth and everything in it is criticized with the reversal of roles. And because monkeys are the target of experiments and resemble humans, they explain their choice to stay in our place. The common laboratory tests are also applied by primates, who dissect their brains, observe their behavior in captivity, and do all kinds of tests. Some primates are disgusted by humans by treating them as simple animals. This could certainly be inserted in the films. It would certainly shock the audience in surreal and impressive scenes. Through these same surveys carried out by the apes, the same curiosity that we have to know about life on other planets through research is evident.The organization in society of monkeys is also very similar to that of humans. They are divided into three different varieties: that of the chimpanzees, that of the gorillas and that of the orangutans, where each group has its characteristics and purposes. Even though peace and equality have been decreed between them, the "differences" still exist.Another issue addressed is humanization, at least how we treat this issue in the sense of being civilized. The book is approached through some characters on the planet of the monkeys, where one of them resists instincts and struggles to be recognized as being logical and thinking and the other undergoes a curious process of dehumanization. This issue could also be better addressed in the films.In this version of Burton, there were also some adaptations in the script in relation to the book and the original film, starting with the change of names of the characters and the fact that Leo fell alone on the planet and not with his companions. Monkey society and buildings are better developed. Humans can speak, walk dressed and not naked as described in the book for obvious reasons, and are used as servants or pets of monkeys. Firearms were replaced by spears and swords. Not to mention the evolution in the physical part of the monkeys, now they are no longer people with ape heads and start convincing like real monkeys, being differentiated by races and characteristics, chimpanzees are faster, gorillas are heavier and slower etc. . All this thanks to the fantastic special effects and the makeup artist Rick Baker, an incredible professional who is also behind classics like An American Werewolf in London and The Grinch. Unfortunately, the film was wronged at the Oscars and other awards for makeup. Some actors took two to three hours on average to become monkeys. But the result is chimpanzees, orangutans and gorillas with human faces.Another different factor in this version is that the monkeys of the 70s were more peaceful and similar to humans in their attitudes as well as in the book. Here, monkeys are extremely agile, violent and scary, that growl all the time and that jump and run in an incredible way, more like the reality of these animals. This caused the monkeys of the 70s to be far surpassed by the monkeys of Burton. Also impressive is the attitude of the new monkeys in the way of walking and expressing their characteristic attitudes. Furthermore, in the book, society seems more advanced and in this version of 2001 with more resources, this can be evidenced better.After problems with the delay in hiring a director for the film, fans of the ape series were reassured by knowing what hands the project would be in. Burton did seem to be an obvious choice after all, despite not being one of the first candidates for the job. He certainly better than anyone would be able to explore the conflict between humans and monkeys well, as well as, as expected, be able to use all his known visual competence in the composition of the work. Burton chose to show apes at a similar evolutionary stage, but a little higher than that of classic films. Of course, with the generous amount released by Fox, Burton and his excellent art direction team have achieved far more impressive results than before. To begin with, the makeup is detailed, organic and much more natural and, at the same time, much more complete than those simian masks that drowned out the voices and features of the actors, although for the end of the 60s and the mid 70, they were extraordinary.Undoubtedly, his vision in creating the planet that gives the work its title is in the best Burton style, having seen in his several fantastic works before and after this project. The settings are grand, with a primitive and rustic texture, a dry climate and above all dark, inviting and intriguing. Most of the scenes take place in the dry "Zona Proibidia" where the Oberon space station is found, and in indoor and night scenes, giving a more tense and sinister atmosphere many times. A caveat is that although Burton managed to print his authorial style especially in the graphic motto of the work, it is clear that he ends up being stuck in the not-so-deep script, which accelerated the pace many times in favor of the action scenes rather than in the ideologies and criticisms that were not so explicit.The cast is cohesive and does not at any time compromise the greater realism given to a fiction. Mark Wahlberg as the revolutionary, Tim Roth composing the cruel and ambitious General Thade, Helena Bonham Carter as the rebel Ari, Michael Clarke Duncan as the strong Attar, Paul Giamatti as the comic Limbo, in addition to the participation of Kris Kristofferson as Karubi. paper. Technically, I highlight the soundtrack of the always competent Danny Elfman, Burton's longtime partner, in addition to the impeccable photography by Philippe Rousselot, which deserves applause.Also noteworthy is the scene that pays tribute to Charlton Heston, playing General Thade's father at one point. He saying the last sentence said to General Thade before he died, "Damn you! May they all be condemned to hell !, it was the same used in the original but when he referred to humanity, as a self-destructive and threatening race after unraveling the mystery of the last scenes. In fact, this scene was marked in the history of cinema, in which the astronaut George Taylor managed to escape from the tyranny of monkeys and fleeing by the shore of a beach in the "Forbidden Zone", he ended up finding the ruins of the American "Statue of Liberty", discovering he was in reality in the distant future of planet Earth itself, destroyed by the human race in a nuclear war, and which was now dominated by monkeys. In fact, the 68 film is one of the few films in history that deliver the ending already on its poster, although we only notice this at the end of the projection, but for the most attentive, it is a serious mistake of the distributor that seems not to have seen the film before releasing it.The big problem that made the film not become a success as it happened with the first ones, was that the essence of the Planet of the Apes written by Pierre Boulle, from which the film was adapted, was not present during the narrative. The Planet of the Apes of 1968, for example, is faithful to the book and shows itself to be full of intelligent dialogues, which carry social, theological and political criticisms. There is an intellectual dispute, while the 2001 remake bet only on the war between monkeys and men and departs from the true proposal of Boulle's dystopia. Plot Twist is maintained, but it happens in a different way than seen before and it can be interesting even for those who already knew the outcome of the plot, thanks to well-used elements of science fiction. In fact, the final plot twist, without a doubt, does not have the same impact as the 68 film.Overall, Burton delivers a more commercial film, one of the most commercial of his career, bringing more action than the original half-stopped movie. But that does not mean that this posture is all bad. Undoubtedly the franchise has been reinvigorated with new elements and does not deserve the most exalted criticism from some who even abhor this version of 2001. They are different versions and present their variations in language and technology. This can be considered an alternative version with the same argument, with interesting differences and fictional alternatives, leading the audience to reflect and travel on new horizons, all within the most dark and peculiar world of Tim Burton, making this film a great science fiction .

I despair when Hollywood does remakes , they never get it right. The script to this remake of the classic PLANET OF THE APES contains far too much self referential humour where characters quote Hitler , Orwell and Charlton Heston , and go on for far too long about human rights. Yes we get the message , just a pity the screenwriters didn`t spend so long on developing the script more.Visually the sets are good as is Tim Roth`s make up , but this is the only success Tim Burton has with the film. Didn`t he realise that in the original apes were split into differing castes down to their species ? Here we see an ape army composed of all types of apes.Why ? I have no idea . And worst of all gone is the mystery and other worldliness of the original. Remember the scenes where the Earth astronauts trek through the forbidden zone and the first appearance of the apes  or that final scene ? In the remake we have no similar impact.There`s a rumour that there might be a sequel in the pipeline. I hope not

It's indicative of today's Hollywood machine, that a great story, with real bite, and genuine originality, can be so mercilessly reduced to just another action blockbuster. It's also very depressing to realise that the director responsible was once a 'maverick', with a unique take on his usual subjects, with a propensity to stay away from the commercial, and eke out the esoteric.Tim Burton's re-imagining required little imagination at all. Comparison with the original 1968 film is, obviously, unavoidable, which is as it should be. Because only with this comparison can you see what a major disappointment this version is. Practically all essence of the themes of evolution, religion, the questions of the way we treat our planet, and the way we treat each other (which are probably more pertinent in this age of genetic modification and cloning etc) are either ignored or dealt with swiftly to bring on the next set piece. Charlton Heston's spaceman has to deal with an inability to communicate with both the apes and the humans (through his lack of speech and their lack of understanding) making him an outsider from both species. We go through that wonder and frustration with him. In Burton's film there are no such devices, we are simply given the 'us and them' option, and all philosophising is glossed over in order to accommodate the next chase. Which is what this movie ultimately turns into..one chase after another. The original's council meeting is replaced with a flippant, and jokey dinner party scene. And, tellingly, there are no allusions to human experiments, instead it appears that humans are good enough as slaves and not much else. One of the many lasting images from the 1968 version is Heston's discovery of his lobotomised co-astronaut. It makes no sense that humans who can communicate with one another, and who outnumber the apes by four to one are not the ruling species. Just one of the holes in a weak and dumbed down plot.Much has been made of the ending, but here, at least, Burton has the sense to at least try something unexpected. Once again, however, he has fluffed it in order to quicken the pace. The apes seem incredibly open to the suggestion that the humans were there first, just as Leo gets over the shock of talking apes rather swiftly so, too, do these apes have an unlikely ability to accept Leo's 'understanding' and explanation of 'Calima'. Heston finding the doll in the cave at the denouement of the first movie is a revelatory moment for both audience and ape - nothing in the remake surprises us much.If you can forget the original (or if you haven't seen it), and if you can bypass the dire script, there are things to enjoy here. Although the first half is far too set bound (with some unimaginative CGI), the climactic battle scenes are very well realised. So, too, are the apes themselves, with some incredible make-up effects, and physically engaging performances (mainly by the extras!). Tim Roth injects the much needed energy in a scene-chewing, but also scene-stealing turn as General Thade, arguably the highlight of the whole picture, and Charlton Heston's cameo is good fun, the only glimpse of any humour and irony in the movie. Paul Giamati's slave trader is simply embarrassing.Major disappointment all round.

This movie had high hopes because all the prior movies entertained and gave us something we never seen before. We even got twists and turns and when it was over, we felt we got our moneys worth. In this movie of the same subject, they broke the cardinal rule. They made or make the audience have to work out the movie instead of the movie entertaining them. Now there are some movies that risk this and leave you in an okay state from their efforts. However, if the work to be done is too complex, far out, too detailed and involves much explanation, then it wasn't a movie at all but instead a homework assignment. We become the movie and finish the tale to keep ourselves content and to have a sense of closure. There are some good scenes, acting, and high hopes here and there. But when you expect the paying audience to have to explain a movie so they can understand what they just saw? This is not the best approach and you can forget about a comeback experience. In other words, once is enough. If one likes the Planet of the Apes world, the novel it is based on and the stars like Wahlberg, by all means see the movie. Just don't expect more for less

I like this movie!  This is a really good movie... yet I don't know what it is about it that makes me like it.  That's the strangest thing.  I actually saw this movie in theaters because a friend asked to see it (I only wanted to see Jurassic Park III).  Turns out it could almost be called one of my favorites!I have never seen the original.  I'm sorry to say this, but I don't know if I ever will since this remake was so good.  I am satisfied with the way this one was done.  I am afraid of disappointment if I watch the original.The plot is excellent, first of all.  There's a nice plot twist at the end involving the origins of all apes that puts everything together and just feels right.  There is plenty of action and, in a way, romance, too.  It's a great sci-fi flick with plenty of action.The storyline isn't too original--escape, then get reinforcements to fight off the antagonists.  But it still does its job.  It keeps you watching.The music is composed by Danny Elfman.  He has a certain militaristic flare in this movie which really sounds good.  The music is excellent, taking on tribal drums at some points and bombastic themes that whirl together perfectly.The costumes are great.  The apes look just like they should.  The graphics are decent, but not overall groundbreaking.I was and am still really impressed with this movie.  It has a lot of things that kept me going and makes me want to watch it again and again.  But I can't compare it to the original.  I wouldn't even if I had seen it.  I can only say that this movie is really great.

reviews.review_title: People, this is a BAD movie...
reviews.content: ...it's not as terrible as "Sleepy Hollow", but it's pretty darn bad. The only "saving" grace is pretty design and excellent ape make-up. But there is nothing else - not a damn thing else - to applaud about it. I like action and sci-fi movies as much as anyone - and I don't expect them to be "Citizen Kane." I do expect to care a *little* bit about the characters - this is really just the minimum for buying into a film's world. Unfortunately, this movie only has one performance that even qualifies (Helena, naturally) - and it can't make up for a blank "hero" and a toilet-paper-ready "script." The "surprise ending shocker" is stupid because there is no explanation for it at all to be found anywhere on this planet or another. Twists are great, but they should at least appeal to logic a little bit - and not be just completely inexplicable. If you think this movie is a ten, really, you should see more movies.

reviews.review_title: I have seen monkey fights at the Zoo that are more entertaining!
reviews.content: This movie is BAD. The actors, the sets, the costumes, the everything is terrific, except the lack of a story. Spelled C-l-i-c-h-e can you not grasp the concept? I really wanted to reserve judgement on what I THOUGHT would be a better movie than what I was presented with. The problem is the Apes. Word to the Production, the Apes become TOO HUMAN and that is only ONE of MANY flaws. Damn Boring ridiculous plot! exceptionally boring! if you want that level of reality than for goodness sake have a F****** Story to tell!Tom:)

reviews.review_title: Decent enough to be seen but not to be memorable.
reviews.content: This film, directed by Tim Burton, is a sci-fi work based on a simple script: an astronaut inadvertently falls on a planet similar to Earth, where humans are subjugated to a dominant monkey race. From there, he tries to organize a resistance and create conditions to return to his ship and travel back to Earth. That is, Burton didn't know how to use his famous creativity to show us something new. This story is almost entirely something we have already seen and read (if we consider the origin of everything, Pierre Boulle's book), dressed in new clothes, more modern or different. The work of the actors is generally acceptable, with Marc Wahlberg standing out with the main role, followed by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth. The human characters are downright poor and main character's love interest attempts always seem out of context. Overall, it's a movie good enough to be seen but not enough to be remembered.

What the hell ? This is one of the poorest films I have ever seen. At first it seemed quite average, but then, I decided to think about the ending in the context of the rest of the film. It made so little sense that I threw the DVD into space, hoping that it would travel through time a few times, and give me an idea of what happened in the film.Unfortunately I doubt there is any logical reason as to why the earth became controlled by Apes.I was never quite sure what year he was in, or what planet he was on, so I assumed -at first- that the ending made sense. Of course this later obviously became disproven. All in all there was no need for:Most of the ApesMost of the HumansThe ending

Keep it short and snappy for anyone who cares enough to read this. Being a remake of the 1968 original I didn't know what to expect from this film. To kick things off I do have to say that this film does have a a fairly exceptional cast in Mark Wahlberg, Helena Bonham-Carter, Michael Clark Duncan, and Tim Roth. I thought that Wahlberg was a good fit for his role considering he usually takes up a daring, adventurous role quite well, and that Tim Roth was a bit out of his element I felt but he took on the Role of Thade quite well. As for Clark- Duncan and Helena Bonham-Carter I don't really want to get into my opinions as to how they fit into their parts, but I will say they performed satisfactorily. I liked how the story developed and I enjoyed most of it. Special Effects are lacking, and the ending was kind of lame. But overall I can give this movie a solid six.

reviews.review_title: You'll never look at Curious George the same again!
reviews.content: I was going to use the old cliche, `You'll go Ape over this movie,' but after watching General Thade during the climax of the movie, I felt that the summary above served the movie justice.This was some movie, and while it has similarities with the previous releases, it is a more modern tale of simian evolution.  Just don't call them monkeys...they've killed humans for less.This movie was very entertaining and captivating with very few lulls.  Mark Wahlberg (once known as the rapper `Marky Mark' from the turbulent nineties) performed quite well, although he did not seem to have the proper demeanor for a soldier of the US Air Force.  He seemed to be a bit too `common.'I was also equally impressed by Tim Roth as General Thade.  Thade is a chimp, but not like the cute and loveable ones you see on television.  He was a homicidal maniac with a deep hatred for humans, so deep that he would go so far as to betray his own kind.  He made Adolf Hitler look like the Easter bunny by comparison.The special effects were marvellous.  It was amazing how they were able to design the make-up such that the simian masks mimicked their human facial expressions.  Some of these actors must have spent some time at the nearest zoo or something, because some of them portrayed the instinctive reactions of apes, such as throwing their hands up in the air and screeching loudly. Fantastic.  I also loved the way the apes would leap through the air and land on their opponents.As with the majority of the movies I like, I do not watch them for their artistic content.  If you want artistic content, watch `The Piano' or something like that.  If you want a movie for the adrenaline rush and you have an open mind, then do not hesitate to watch this one.The saddest part about this movie is that I had once seen on tv that Tim Burton is not planning to direct a sequel.  That would be a shame, but you never know - once Tim sees all the revenues generated by this movie, he may reconsider.  Or perhaps another director will take up the mantel.  We can only hope.***SPOILER ALERT***SPOILER ALERT***SPOILER ALERT***I was not kidding about the spoiler alert.  One of the paragraphs mentioned below will briefly discuss the ending of the movie, and if you have not seen the movie yet, I would not recommend that you read any further.First of all, I did not like it that the movie started out in the year 2029. So am I supposed to believe that we as a race will be capable of space flight and capable of designing self-sufficient space stations away from the Earth's orbit in just 28 years?  Unless there's influence from an alien specie, I cannot believe that we will progress that well in such a short period of time.  However, despite this `flaw,' it did not affect my overall view of the movie.Another question I had pertained to genetic diversity.  With so few humans and apes aboard the space station, how is it that they were able to populate that planet?  With all of the inevitable in-breeding (and I do NOT mean inter-species mating), how is it that either specie is not riddled with disease or deformities?  And for those of you who did not catch it, they were on a distant planet.  It even had several moons, so they were not on Earth the entire time.Finally, I was not impressed by Capt. Davidson's flight home.  In a matter of what appeared to be a few seconds, he escaped the planet's atmosphere, flew into the storm, arrived back into his own solar system (near Saturn by the looks of it), and then immediately arrived at Earth.  What makes this all the more amazing, this was done in a spacecraft not much larger than my car (apparently it is capable of deep space flight), and it's fuel and oxygen reserves were likely expended beforehand, yet Davidson made it some in one piece in about 30 seconds.The ending itself was fantastic.  Davidson landed on an Earth that had evolved the same as ours with the exception of one difference - the apes became the dominant species, not us.  Apparently, not only can the storm bend the laws of time and space, but apparently it can throw someone into an alternate reality.  I would just love to see a sequel to determine where this movie left off.

What has happened to Tim Burton?  Given a big budget he just can't seem to put it to decent use.  And, what is worse, he turns perfectly decent actors into inept mumblers (although talking through several inches of latex can't be easy).  Even the great David Warner seems to be wholly uninvolved with the drab performance he is giving.  This is just a very bad move and that is a shame, considering the technical tricks that were used --- and wasted --- in the enterprise.
Should be re-named "Marky Mark and the Monkey Bunch"

reviews.review_title: Devoid of Burton's Creativity... Ending Sucks Too
reviews.content: The only things I liked were the Makeup and Practical Effects. Paul Giamatti was good and weird too. That's it.I knew this movie had bad ratings but I was more than happy to watch a Tim Burton film. I left super disappointed. It seemed like Hollywood scrubbed away any Burton elements and chopped important plot out. The "Twist Ending" made no sense and was terrible.

Good movie, actors, and plot...what more would you need? Nothing in this movie is lacking definition or explanation....it's all right there! The only part that needs description is the ending, but it's just a great leading into the sequel, which obviously there will be. I don't think anyone should criticize this movie unless this is the kind of movie they like. Also, all you old POTA fans, you can't compare this one to the original. The only thing in common is the basic plot....it's not the same movie!!! So I think anyone who likes this type of genre of movies really will like this movie, but only see it if it interests you, not because you like the old POTA because it's just not the same.

reviews.review_title: Never send a man to do a monkey's job.
reviews.content: Do I have the right to comment on this? I mean, I missed the movie I was laughing so hard. This is a movie about a man torn between two females: a blonde and a monkey. You have to see the slutty "Oh!"-look on the face of the blonde when the guy kisses the monkey to know what I mean when I say this movie is hilarious! Anyway, although many efforts went into this--or so the dvd told me, I wondered about the security of a space helmet which was open at the bottom. And why can't the man land a pod right once when the monkey does it so easily! Never send a man to do a monkey's job! The movie's quality allows me to poke fun at its weak spots, the make-up is pretty good, and the ideas not so bad. It's funny that they managed to have the two major gorillas be played by ethnic minorities: The loyal African american colonel Michael Clarke Duncan and the loyal Asian servant Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa.

First what was good about the movie and it wasn't much, the makeup was great. That's it    Does not compare with the orginial, not in the least.  The ending was laughable and  a disgrace. Lincoln (My favorite President as an Ape !!!) Give me a break.

I will admit I only saw this the once and thought it wasn't a great film, in fact, for a while I hated it, but seeing it again, I can see why critics give it three stars out of five, and that it actually is a pretty good film from director Tim Burton (Beetlejuice, Batman, Edward Scissorhands, Sleepy Hollow, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street). If you have seen the original 1968 film, plus the sequels ("Beneath the...", "Escape from the...", "Conquest of the..." and "Battle for the...") then you would know this is a new vision, and mix of all of them (well, besides Escape from, that takes place of Earth). Basically it is 2029, and in a space station, where monkeys are trained to carry out missions, one monkey is sent out, and disappears in the large space cloud, and without permission his friend Captain Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) speeds after him in a space pod, and doing so gets sucked into the wormhole, and crashes in the jungle of an unknown planet, similar to Earth (well, it is). Soon enough though he is captured along with many other humans by human acting and talking apes, and like Charlton Heston before, almost the first words spoken, by ape warrior Attar (The Green Mile's Michael Clarke Duncan) are "Get you stinking hands (paws) off me, you damned dirty human (ape)". Anyway, the planet is afraid of humans, and will only use them as slaves, and sympathetic chimpanzee activist Ari (Helena Bonham-Carter, Burton's fiancée) is pretty much the only ape who thinks humans should be treated equally. Eventually Leo manages to escape with some other humans, including Daena (Estella Warren) with the help of Ari, and they head to where Leo sees a signal on his still working locator. When they get there, the ships appears to have crashed, and there for thousands of years, well, you did the see the travel clock going up rapidly. Meanwhile, the army lead by the great vicious villain Thade (a very aggressive performance by Reservoir Dogs' Tim Roth) is preparing an army to fight the battle for the planet. In the end, thankfully Thade is trapped for lying about humans and apes originally getting on, Leo gets a new pod when his monkey friend lands, and he heads back to Earth, but when he lands in front of the Lincoln memorial, it has the face of Thade (!), just like the ending of the original with the Statue of Liberty buried on the beach. Also starring Paul Giamatti as Limbo, Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa as Krull, David Warner as Sandar, Blade's Kris Kristofferson as Karubi, The Mummy's Erick Avari as Tival, Luke Eberl as Birn, Chris Ellis as Lt. General Karl Vasich, Lisa Marie (Burton's ex) as Nova, Deep Roy as Gorilla Kid/Thade's Niece, and a cameo by the star of the first original, Charlton Heston as Zaius, Thade's Father. The changes besides most of the story are that the humans are not dumb, there's no Dr. Zaius (Heston's character isn't him, he's a general), there's no Roddy McDowall or Kim Hunter, and of course the make-up is obviously more updated, a good remake. It was nominated the BAFTAs for Best Costume Design and Best Make Up/Hair. Good!

I hope that those who complained about this movie changed their minds after watching Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011) and all the movies that might follow.The reason i pointed this out is because Tim Burton's effort is the only movie in the franchise that has a decent script, at time almost at Shakespearean heights. In addition to that, the actors played the apes in realistic costumes. Prior to this movie the costumes were funny, to say the least, and the 2011 prequel used CGI.Personally, this movie was a huge improvement, because the only thing worth mentioning in the old movies has been the scene with Charlton Heston confronted with the Statue of Liberty protruding from the sand. The 2011 and 2014 prequels were visually better but scripts were poor.

One word comes to mind: Stinker! I waited thirty years for this freak show. Numbingly disappointing. A gargantuan gas bag of celluloid claptrap. Tim Burton's dreadful spin on a four-star classic renders off a slickly produced, but lethal aroma of a movie, that, when looked at closely, would have even the gorillas at the Bronx Zoo scratching their heads in disbelief. Burton's big mistake (I think) was creating a different, unfamiliar ape universe from the previous series. Strangely, I believe the film he achieved in remaking here was the Wizard of the Oz. Mark Walberg, the lead, is no Charlton Heston. He's too short and grim. Someone needed to tell him to lighten up. He spends the entire film behaving like "Dorothy." I know. I know. He wishes to go home despite meeting two potential love connections--one human, one ape. AND he starts a global civil war for good measure. Nice fellow. He mopes around the planet like some kind of self-centered jerk. Tim Roth's character is the worst kind of evil: boring. He jumps around the cheap sets as if he was suffering from a terminal case of ants-in-his-pants. I did, however, enjoy Danny Elfman's pulsating score. And Rick Baker's make-up for the apes deserved more recognition and some awards. Also, I felt the Christo-like red tents, that the ape army used on their march across the wasteland, were beautiful and abstract. There are occasional stabs at social commentary--but they fall flat. Rod Serling and Pierre Boulle must be turning over in their graves.

I happened to catch "Planet of the Apes" on PPV last night. I was quite excited because I had missed my chance at the box office. Boy am I glad I didn't waste my money buying a ticket. This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. There is no plot, no character motivation, no life, no story thru-line to carry the picture and the ending is so bad, it reeks of a low-budget, straight-to-video, sci-fi flick. I am a HUGE fan of Tim Burton and I think he is one of the most brilliant directors Hollywood has to offer. In fact, "Sleepy Hollow", in my opinion, is his best film to date. But POTA is a film that could best be described as never-should've-happened. Why does Hollywood see the need to remake classic, highly rated films and turn them into pure trash? This is one film that should NOT have been remade or reimagined or whatever you wish to call it. Why can't Hollywood remake films that were terrible when they were FIRST released instead of doing things the other way around??? The screenplay for this film is drenched with cheesy dialogue. (In one scene, David Warner tells his daughter, Helena Bohnam Carter to wash her hands before dinner after she has been touching humans!!!) The writers saw fit to throw every kind of silly convention of humor that one could relate to humans and apes at the screen and expected us to eat it up. This is one viewer who wishes he could make the writers eat their own words!!! Save you money and rent something else.

This movie is a deception, in the real sense of the word. When I heard about this flick, I though that this "re-imagining" would be at least visually better than the original film. Well, it's not. The new makeup is more complex than the appliances used in the firs film, but the apes are grotesque. Ari, for instance, has hilarious ape features, and so David Warner's character. The problem, I think, is the "realistic" sculpture of the masks, made by Rick Baker. I don't know if "realism" is a good choice in a movie called "Planet of the Apes". The general concept is quite bizarre, and realism can make things even worse.In the original, the characters looked like apes, but had a more sophisticated appeal, a noble aspect. It's very difficult to achieve this balance, and perhaps it explains why the makeup of the new "Planet" wasn't nominated for an Oscar. Add to that a bunch of apes running like rabbits, "primitive" humans that think and talk like evolved humans and poor sets, and you have a natural looser. But what really upset me about this film is the title: it should be "THE VISITOR", as Burton had originally envisioned. "THE VISITOR" is more accurate in the sense that the movie is a "re-imagining", not a remake.

reviews.review_title: Burton provides an entertaining yet flawed ape escape
reviews.content: Tim Burton has a unique, dark style that sets him far apart from other filmmakers of his generation, and he has a knack for getting the best efforts from his crews and actors.His "reimagining" of "Planet of the Apes" is a rare instance in which those qualities never come to the fore. I won't bother with prattle comparing this to the 1968 original, simply because I haven't seen it and don't plan to anytime soon.He brings back nearly the entire crew he worked with on the superior "Sleepy Hollow"  costume designer Colleen Atwood, production designer Rick Heinrichs, editor Chris Lebenzon, and composer Danny Elfman, but this formidable unit fails to fully click this time around.Makeup guru Rick Baker (the "Nutty Professor" series) is responsible for the impressive simian facades, but most of the time they look instead like very expensive Halloween masks that muddle the actors' voices. The diction left much to be desired; some characters speak too low and fast (I sat in the fourth row and the theater had THX sound), and some baritone-voiced males sound as if they're talking with their mouths full.The acting is adequate but sometimes as stiff as the monkey mugs, starting with a wooden Mark Wahlberg as the centerpiece of the film, Leo Davidson. He is an Air Force captain, yet he works way up in space. The setup for his eventual crash landing onto the Planet of the Apes is flimsy and rushed. When that time comes, he doesn't look too concerned about being alone and stranded, and eventually imprisoned, in a strange new world, and he goes through the film as if this is all small potatoes to him.Thanks to bad dialogue, he inadvertently forges what may turn out to be the new pickup line of the 21st century: "I can show you something that will change your world forever."Needless to say, the simians are the best thespians, and that's not saying much. Tim Roth hams it up to the hilt as the villain Thade, but he can only do so much in a movie of this style. His chief henchman, played by Michael Clarke Duncan, verbally berates and knocks a few humans around here and there, and snarls lines such as, "Get your stinkin' hands off me, you filthy human!" and "Bow your heads!"  And, that's it.Helena Bonham Carter is solid as Brit-accented human sympathizer Ari. Coincidentally, out of all the Apes, she looks the most human as well (and is nearly a dead ringer for Michael Jackson). Paul Giamatti, on the other hand, is annoying as Limbo the orangutan, the film's thin attempt at comic relief.The weakest link, as if it isn't too obvious, is Leo's gang of human fugitives, especially an annoying teenage boy and the token Black man whom we all know will get knocked off at some point in the film. They have no personality and serve no purpose in the plot whatsoever except to chip in with a cheesy line here and there. Supermodel Estella Warren, playing a slave girl whose father (Kris Kristofferson) is killed by the Apes, is as pointless as a broken pencil. Her skimpy outfit contained more depth than her screen presence. Most of her activity consists of staring into space with her mouth agape.By the way, I didn't realize the Planet of the Apes contained any beauty salons, because she manages to look like she just stepped out of one whenever she appears on screen.Oh, and Burton brings aboard his squeeze Lisa Marie once again for no apparent reason. This time around, she's buried under an Ape mask. As usual, she has nothing to do here except display her one-dimensional feminine wiles.The cinematography, courtesy of Phillippe Rousselot, does a nice job of stressing the foreboding, moonlit jungle environment. It's the only saving grace of the lackluster action sequences, especially in the beginning just after Leo crash-lands and finds himself in the middle of a wild huntdown of humans by Ape soldiers. Elfman comes through on the music front; because of his powerful score, I loved the opening credits sequence.Unfortunately, while Heinrichs' sets are always a visual treat, they aren't as gripping as his Oscar-winning work from SH. They are small and constricted due to the fact that there are sometimes too many characters cavorting on the screen. Upon seeing the Apes' village for the first time, I couldn't help but think of the planet Endor from "Return of the Jedi." The wreckage of Leo's USAF space station, however, is fantastic. It's also the location of a surprising twist in the story.Now to the plot. The reason why it falters for the most part is what ultimately crippled "Shrek": it has an unpleasant air of preachiness to it. By itself, the plot is as thin as Wahlberg's music career, but in a twist that seems rather uncharacteristic of Burton, "Apes" plays the race card. This I didn't care for. I'm aware that this angle is in the original, but it's a white elephant in Burton's version.And yes, an Ape actually utters those infamous six words...I'm sure you know what they are.The suspense factor is all but nil, and the plot twists leave behind numerous holes, such as, for example, the controls on the destroyed space station being able to work despite the wreck apparently being thousands of years old. (Plus, where did all those horses, the Apes' sole means of transportation, come from?)Then there is the well-publicized "love triangle" between Wahlberg, Carter and Warren that Burton hinted at in interviews. To make a long story short, if you plan to watch this solely on the basis of seeing this angle, you're in for a disappointment.Sorry, but I won't waste my breath on Charlton Heston's forgettable pot-and-kettle cameo.Save for the aforementioned chase sequence after Leo's crash landing, the action and fight scenes are pathetic. Simple punches send both humans and Apes flying a few dozen feet into the air. And don't ask the Apes to hit targets in the water that are two feet from the shore. The huge Apes-humans showdown near the end is a yawner.The much-ballyhooed ending is both surprising and ambiguous. Though Burton has vehemently denied any rumors of his helming a sequel, the conclusion is like that of a comic book and does leave the door wide open for a second installment.The film's most comical moments occurred offscreen.
