Before shooting began, the actors had to undergo "ape training" to learn primate mannerisms, and spent hours in makeup before stepping in front of the cameras. On "failing" ape school, Bonham Carter quipped, "I was told I had AADD  Ape Attention Deficit Disorder." On becoming an Ape: "It's flattering to be cast as a chimp, because you know they haven't cast you for what you look like." Duncan hurt his ankle while filming a pivotal scene with Kristofferson, who slipped, fell, crashed into Duncan and wound up having to get stitches. Duncan was rushed to the hospital (yes, rushed for a turned ankle  that's Hollywood for ya), in full makeup, no less. When he announced himself to a room full of patients, they burst into applause.While "Planet of the Apes" has some major flaws, it doesn't mean it's not entertaining, which it indeed is, but it just doesn't have that signature Tim Burton look and feel to it. It's ultimately just another Hollywood action flick.After all is said and done, his best effort to date still remains "Sleepy Hollow."  7.5/10

reviews.review_title: Disappointing effort to relaunch good series
reviews.content: Tim Burton has made quite a lot of good movies, but none of them would ever give you the idea he would be the director best suited to direct a "Planet of the Apes"-remake. His style of filmmaking pretty much couldn't be further from what was needed here.The film abandons just about every detail from Pierre Boulle's original book. At the start of the movie, Wahlberg's character, Davidson, is working on a space station, and he is involved with experiments with primates. While the back-story behind this seems interesting, you don't get to know much about it because not long into the movie, one of the chimpanzee's from the station disappears with his spacecraft, Davidson follows and ends up on the eponymous planet. Unlike in the original movie, here all humans have the ability to speak and are completely civilized. Since the apes are in that sense not dominant over the humans, that removes a lot of the suspense present in the original movie. The humans still are slaves though, but Davidson escapes with a female slave and convinces a female ape to sort of join their cause. Two apes, military commanders, start chasing after them and we get to see some uninteresting chase scenes. The Ape City also looks badly compared to the one from the original. Later, scenes take place at Davidson's old space station, which crash landed at the planet hundreds of years before he did. The apes apparently created some kind of temple there. Eventually, there is a battle between the humans and the hostile apes.Now, I've heard people say they were interested in seeing this movie because of a cameo by Charlton Heston, but his appearance is so short and since he is unrecognizable I would hardly say it would be worth sitting through this movie just for that.This movie is also infamous for the horrible ending, which deserves a special mention of its own. They must have worked really hard to make the last scene especially as bad as possible, in the vain hope they would get to make a sequel to tie up the infinite number of loose ends they created in this.Fortunately, the series got a proper reboot with "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" in 2011. Do yourself a favor and watch that one instead of this.

reviews.review_title: THE 2001 Planet of the Apes does not compare!
reviews.content: The Planet of the Apes that came out in the late sixties was an incredible film that deals with many social, religious, and political issues. The new remake of this film is awful. The new Planet of the Apes does not have a metaphorical level and it is sheer action just for actions sake. Furthermore, the new film is not exciting or entertaining. I am not sure why the film industry would invest so much money in a film that has already been made. I think that if the original was good, there is not need for a remake! It seems that in this modern era, many film makers have either run out of ideas or sold out. They have begun to remake old films instead of creating new ones. This seems like a waste of talent, money, and technology to me.

Yes, it was visually stunning, and the costume work was spectacular.  Still, this movie not only violated real-world logic, it violated its own created logic, thus making it one of the messiest, frustrating movies I have seen, ever.  Mark Wahlberg was brilliant in Boogies Nights and Three Kings, but here he is unspectacular.  There is never any reason given why he stands out among all other humans as being special, though the story depends on Ms. Carter's interest in him.  He wears a white shirt, that is all.  Otherwise he is quiet, and does nothing out of the ordinary until later in the movie. Roth's Thade also takes an interest in Wahlberg's character, but again, without reason or logic.I believe Thade was the worst villian, ever.  He had no logical reason for wanting to wipe out the humans.  And this is where the story really breaks down.  The motivation is gone.  The apes have achieved supremacy, but yet there is still a need to kill all humans, who live like wild animals, and are thus harmless to the much more powerful and advanced apes.  Apes who ride horses (which the movie refuses to explain why they are on this planet, though it explains the origin of the Apes and Humans).  The logic comes to a complete break down when Thade's general turns on him, for no reason.  He has not seen anything to warrant his turn-around, and this unexpected and unlikely twist further diminishes the story.I thought I was going to vomit and retch, I desperately tried to plead with this movie to make more sense, that if you set up a fantasy world, you must abide by the rules of that world.  But it did not, and it caused my head to explode in complete pain.I give it a 3 out of 10, for costumes alone.  Those Apes looked realistic (save their body-size), and the Roman-theme was a nice touch, albeit Gladitor-esque.

reviews.review_title: Two hours of your life you wish you could get back.
reviews.content: Tim Burton can deny it all he wants, but Planet of the Apes (2001) really is a re-make... and a poor one at that.But even without comparing it to the original (which is far superior in too many ways to even begin listing here), I can honestly say that this movie left a bad taste in my mouth, and dreams in my head of how I would better spend the 6 dollars I wasted if I ever run into the studio exec who gave this film the green light and demanded that he pay me back.The movie drags on and on, and quickly overstays its welcome.  What few special effects are in the movie (make-up, set design, and stunts are totally separate categories, and should never be included under the heading of "visual effects") could have been much better.  The ape makeup is Oscar-quality good, and is perhaps the only thing in the movie worth noting.The story seems like someone accidently dropped the screenplay into a wood chipper, randomly taped pieces of it back together, and then tried to shoot the movie from that: The story leaves us wondering too many things that are not explained, and most of what is explained is downright laughable.  This movie is funny when it tries to be serious, and never funny when it tries to be humorous.  I was so bored watching this, I tried counting (and lost track of) all the plot holes, but the big one at the end completely made me lose faith in this movie as anything but a 99-cent corner store rental to watch with your friends during a night of serious drinking games.Excellent talent like Tim Roth, Paul Giamatti, Michael Clark Duncan, and Charlton Heston (and even the far less-tolerable, media flavors-of-the-month "Marky Mark" Wahlberg and Helena Bonham Carter, whose names we probably won't even remember in two years) are wasted in this contrived piece of junk.  I never once felt anything for any of the characters in the film... except maybe sympathy for being trapped in such a lousy movie.This film is extremely unrealistic (even assuming that you accept the idea that evolved apes have formed a civilization, which itself is an excellent premise for a film, but a premise that could have - SHOULD have - been handled much better than this movie does it).In a summer boxoffice where intelligent dinosaurs roam, a misunderstood ogar finds love, and deceased Egyptians seek vengence, Planet of the Apes (2001) brings nothing of interest or quality to the table.  I usually come out of a big-budgeted, heavily-marketed, action/effects movie ready to get right back in line and see it again.  But this movie made me wish I'd never gotten in line to see it in the first place.

reviews.review_title: A planet that makes no sense
reviews.content: (Spoilers)Illogic that people should have noticed:1. It seems like the heroin was wearing lipstick!2. Why didn't the apes die from that explosion?3. If anyone had written this, they might as well have been on the planet... they were the apes playing basketball near the opening. (Those are kids... get it?)4. Speaking of which, how do apes know basketball?5. Since when do all warriors play for the side they seem to be on? That kid should have just killed the apes!!!!6. Since when does a person disobey his boss on a ship? Marky Mark disobeys the person he was told by to NOT go after his monkey... and he does! As pointed out by Blake French: "Is he stupid, suicidal, or both?"All I have to say is:I want my money back

Once again Hollywood has spent an astronomical amount of cash on a movie and forgot to put aside some money for the writng. The characters are among the most shallow I have ever seen, the dialogue is week and the plot...WHAT PLOT? Tim Burtons visual style could not salvage even a hint of entertainment value from this heaping piece of garbage. And to the argument that "it was just a sci-fi fantasy movie what do you expect?" Aliens, Starwars, Terminator/T2, and the Matrix are as well but they are great movies because they started with great stories then added affects to tell them. Not the other way around. If this movie is the last one on the shelf to rent at your local video store then go read a book.

Tim Burton re-imagines Planet of the Apes. To put it simply, I enjoyed watching it. The original Apes films are masterpieces of cinema to be sure. So Burton decided that instead of merely retelling the original story, he would put his own spin to the tale. As such, it should be appreciated as a film in its own right and not a mere rehash. The cast, namely Mark Wahlberg, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, etc., gave pretty impressive performances. One of my favorite bits has to be Charlton Heston's cameo. In ape makeup, no less. I will not spoil the ending here. it has to be seen to be believed, but I can assure you, you won't forget it. Highly recommended.

This movie was disappointing in so many ways. As my wife put it, they had so much to work with, and they completely blew it. I don't even know where to begin with how disappointing this movie was.The action sequences were non-existent. Times when there should have been a good scene (like the horse-ride through the camp, which could have been really great) were very detached from the action, and consequently quite boring. Both the cinematography and the editing in such scenes were really, well, bad.The acting was stiff. I guess Burton was trying to do this whole thing where people actually moved like apes. But that was annoying. And they seem to have spent two or three times as much time and effort on that as they did on more typical (and effective) elements of acting--you know, emotions, character development, little things like that.The CGI was pretty transparent. When Marky Mark first lands and is standing in the forest looking around, for example, it's SO clear that he's in front of a bluescreen. Ugh. The makeup, on the other hand, was really well done.The score was stifled, I thought. But maybe it was just because it had nothing decent to accompany/illuminate.I expected more cool references to other movies. 2001 was a completely obvious allusion, for example, and they only made one (probably accidental) allusion to it--when Pericles is about to take off in the pod. They could really have done a lot of cool stuff with that--both on the planet and in space. So, what was good about the movie? The makeup, as I already mentioned. That's it, as far as I can recall. Enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Awful... almost as bad (and the same) as Battlefield Earth
reviews.content: What a terrible, terrible movie! I had a high expectation for it too. It's a shame. I'll give the make-up artists (e.g., Rick Baker) credit. Bravo. And Danny Elfman's opening score was interesting. But otherwise, this movie was utter crap. (small spoilers follow) First we get this DS9-like space station shot with the wonderful title card that informs us that it's the year 2029!!! Hello! I knew right then that this was going to suck. Science fiction needs to be smart. Then he finds himself on the Ape Planet and the next 90% of the movie is just simple "escape and chase". Yawn... But to try and make it interesting they throw in some cliché and ever-not-so-subtle comments on racism and religion. The script was lousy, let's face it. Then the end of the movie improves slightly (this doesn't say much) until we get the "surprise" ending. Whatever. Tim Burton has the imagery skills but except from Edward Scissorhands and Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, I'd say he's a failure as far as making good stories. The similarities between Planet of the Apes and Battlefield Earth are remarkable. And considering how lousy that movie was, why would anybody allow this script to pass? Certainly a better movie could have been made from the same idea. Oh well, it already has.

reviews.review_title: I'm not going ape over the re-make. But it's not without its charms.
reviews.content: `Get your stinking paws off me, you damn dirty critics!'  Director Tim Burton's update of Planet of the Apes is here. Is it as good as the 1968 version? Is Charlton Heston likely to support gun control laws? No, of course not. But, that's hardly the point.A clever screenplay by Rod Serling, engaging performances and John Chambers' groundbreaking make-up - the original Apes is a sci-fi classic. However, Director Franklin Schaffner's visualization of  writer Pierre Boulle's source material works on  levels beyond simple aesthetics.In the late sixties, society takes a stumble. Civil unrest, Vietnam and the counter-culture - wow, man . . . the times, they are changing.Enter a film about a white, male astronaut (Heston). Marooned on a strange planet,  Col. Taylor  is not a happy man. In fact, he spends much of his time criticizing the arrogance of mankind. This guy makes the rock band Radiohead seem upbeat and optimistic.He encounters a group of primal, uncivilized humans. However, much to Taylor's astonishment,  talking apes are the dominant species on this world. Confronted with a new social order, Heston yells, : `It's a madhouse, a madhouse.'In one of cinema's most brilliant twist-endings, Taylor learns that he is not far from home. Furthermore, man's own worst enemy is himself.Timing is everything . . . The first P.O.T.A finds an audience because it explores themes pertinent to a volatile era of activism and transformation. The movie casts a long shadow.The 1968 film is  iconic. It transcends the medium and holds a place in our pop culture collective. Burton can't remake the original and hope for the same level of success.The  filmmaker (Ed Wood and Sleepy Hollow)understands that point. So, he doesn't try. Instead, Burton and company re-invent Apes from a different perspective.This time around, Mark Wahlberg crashes on an ape-ruled planet. Faster than Curious George can get into trouble, a primate patrol captures the new arrival. After being sold into slavery, he befriends a left-leaning, pro-human chimpanzee played by Helena Bonham Carter. Along with a group of fugitive homosapiens, Wahlberg's band must elude the tyrannical military leader, Thade (Tim Roth) and flee to safety.Burton's Apes has a quirky tone. The movie isn't as substantial as the earlier incarnation - but, it is entertaining. Take a cameo by Heston. As Roth's dying father, he playfully re-visits dialogue from the first film. Given Heston's political convictions, his anti-gun rant is deliciously ironic. Remember, he's the guy  who  defiantly announces before  National Rifle Association meetings: `You can have my gun, when you pry it from my cold, dead paws.' Calm down, Moses.Make-up specialist, Rick Baker, supplies the latex for the simian characters. This guy has more Oscars than NSYNC has bad songs for good reason. Baker gives each ape its own incredibly detailed look. In a distinguished career, this film is his best work.Still, even more impressive are the actors within the monkey suits. The way Bonham Carter, Roth and their fellow contemporaries totally transform themselves with body movements, ticks and facial expressions  is outstanding.Burton gleefully turns his primates loose - letting them bound across the screen, arms flailing and voices screeching. These factors give Planet of the Apes a manic energy.Although, the movie suffers when the action shifts to the human contingent. Wahlberg is acceptable as the lead. He is distant. Still, his spaceman realizes the absurdity of his situation and just wants out. Wahlberg's detachment is an interesting counterpoint to the ape's dynamism. However, the emerging star's dour delivery does overstay its welcome by the third act.The remaining humans are sadly underdeveloped. They are bland and boring. I've seen more exciting people at Republican nominating conventions.Burton ends the film with an obligatory surprise finale. The closer is hysterical. It is more abstract than the original's final scene. But, if you take the time to piece it together, the conclusion makes perfect sense.What else could Burton do? Audience expectations are high for a shocking last act. At least he answers the call with good-natured playfulness.The new Planet of the Apes is a mixed bag. It's inventive and exciting -humorous, not campy. No, it's not the 1968 version. Who cares? Burton's movie stands on its own merits.  Still, Apes is lacking in just enough areas to hold it back.  Oh, well - better luck in the sequel.This film is a six out of ten.

Myself and my girlfriend left the cinema bewildered and disappointed by this terrible film.  We are both Tim Burton fans and were willing to overlook the mixed advance press.Suffice it to say that this film is a mess, doesn't make any sense, and has severe acting problems.  The male lead is a man who used to advertise underpants and is a complete emotional blank.  Even worse, his love interest is that curse of Hollywood films, a model woman who has no acting ability whatsoever.  Just think: they spent tens of millions of pounds on this, could have had anyone in the world write a script and work on it and this is what was produced.

reviews.review_title: The blundering of Tim Burton strikes again
reviews.content: Let me first off say that I fell victim to the hype of this summer ape-fest. I had high hopes for this recent installment of what might have been Burton's genius manifesting itself again on screen.My proposed delight in seeing something harkening back to days of Sleepy Hollow and Batman, was dashed mercilessly on the rocks of apedom by this very "Mars Attacks" type movie.  The plot does not meander in the least bit for there is nowhere for it to go.  It drives on endlessly whilst my company and I waited anxiously for death or the credits, whichever came first.The acting is quite weak, the characters have no development at all and the only performance worth mention is that of Helena Bonham-Carter.  She plays the role of Ari with gusto, albeit there is no explanation of why she does anything she believes in doing.  The role of Attar had so much promise being played by Michael Clarke Duncan, but there is little to enjoy in his character's action or motives.Everyone loves the villain Tim Roth plays as Thade, but even I could not stomach the growling and snarling of a pointless villain for 2 hours.  His angst-filled dialogue and actions do nothing to advance the story or draw in the audience.There are numerous plot holes that would be passively filled in if the movie made any attempt at epicurian status, but it falls short of even the humor or action of a M.A.S.H re-run.  I would have rather watched a full day marathon of old C.H.i.P.S than see this movie again.  My limited edition lunch box and movie poster will be auctioned off to lowest common denominator to be sureI may not have said much about the movie itself, but there is little to comment apon.  Average effects, weak plot, poor writing, aimless ending. The first 45 minutes is like a walk through the life of apes, which are exactly like human in their mannerisms at the table, in company, and with the help, as we are.  Burton didn't need to bludgeon us to death with the similarity.Spoilers:Don't worry about spoilers because nothing I could say will make you enjoy the ending or plot line, with my robust affirmation or denial.  I can say there was one moment I enjoyed.  I truly enjoyed Charlton Heston's role as Thades father.  It was epic Heston.  He even got to say his most famous of lines, but in reproach of the humans he once fought for 35 years ago.

reviews.review_title: A Remake That Assumes You Don't Know It's a Remake
reviews.content: I'm one of the few people out there that made the mistake of seeing Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes a good while before seeing the original. What kept on making me look away from the 1968 original more or less was the fact that it's over twice as old as me, which I guess you could attribute to me as being ignorant. And after hearing so much complaining about this remake with me and my best friend not seeing why (who also had never seen the original), we decided to just rent both this and the original and see what the fuss was all about.I think after seeing the ending alone you know how I feel.If I'm not mistaken, this film was handed down to several directors before Tim Burton was finally "credited" as the main director (and towards the end of the film's production unless I've misread something). Either way this film really doesn't feel like a Burton film to me, if it did I'd be calling this film "gritty" or "dark"; at least, for a few of the scenes. But other than some great visual style and excellent make-up on the apes it's tough for me to mention Tim Burton along with this film, it just doesn't feel like something he actually directed; not the whole way at least.It's funny that this film is supposed to be a "remake" when the only things it has in-common with the original are the name and the fact that the apes are superior to the humans. This is another odd thing that another reviewer pointed out; the apes don't seem to have that much over the humans other than brute strength most of the time. Whereas in the original the apes were both tougher and far more intelligent than the humans.Outside of this the film has little to nothing in-common with the original. The plot, characters, location(s) and even the ending are all different from the original. The only similarity you might be able draw is that one of the apes (a female that sees the humans as more than the other apes give them credit for) decides to help a few of them escape the ape city and go to the lands of their origins. Beyond this, and maybe a select few throwbacks to the original (the scarecrows part was pretty clever) you might be wondering if this is really a remake or just a very different re-imagining.As I mentioned earlier, this version has some great art/visual style and excellent make-up on the apes, which are even better than those of the original (even though in this day and age it's really a given for that to be the case if enough effort is put in). Really this is the film's biggest strength because outside of all the excellence visually there isn't much of a film to be had. The performances from almost everyone is average at best. Mark Wahlberg really isn't given too much to work with and you'll get plenty of his typical "shocked" stares. Tim Roth as General Thade actually does pretty well with his character and is arguably the most effective character. Needless to say, Helena Bonham Carter was intentionally given a bit more of a human look than the other apes, possibly to reflect her character's views on the humans in the film. Michael Clarke Duncan does well with what he's given and while he likely won't stand out for many he is a very convincing character given his size and voice (hopefully that doesn't sound too odd). Everyone else just feels like they're tagging along so there really isn't much to praise in the characters or actors other than that two of the main ape characters were handled very well. Oh, and I thought the cameo with Charles Heston was neat.Aside from this, a fun battle towards the end with the rebel humans and apes and an ending that'll likely leave those that haven't seen it puzzled as to what exactly happened, there really isn't too much to the film. My biggest problem with the ending is that we likely will never get an answer or resolution to it because of how negative the reception has been towards the film. I hate it when movie studios and the crew make a movie and leave room for a sequel but they never fully take into account possibility that the film will flop or just not do well. And in this film's case we're stuck with a film that had and in a sense still does have potential but are left asking "when" and "what".This film is very, very different from the '68 classic it's based on and as a result, it assumes you haven't seen the remake; or at least hopes you didn't. Since I saw this one before the original, my views on this remake were defensive and while I think it's far from as bad as some might make it out (and even as I myself might have made it out as well), it's very tough to fully appreciate it after seeing the original. So if you haven't seen this film yet (or even the original for that matter), I would personally see this one first so you can make a verdict on the film itself, then see the original and then make up your mind. As for those that have seen the original but not this, just go into it with an open mind and don't expect the same movie. And if anyone has seen both and wants to at least try and like this movie, try and watch it without having the original in mind. Keep the original in mind, and this film stinks. See this as its own film, and you should be able to find some redeeming values.

reviews.review_title: Wanted to fling my feces at the screen
reviews.content: Argh. There was a time when Tim Burton had a flair for the visually interesting. Remember Gotham City? Sleepy Hollow? The Afterlife waiting room in "Beetlejuice"? Not anymore. Here he had a chance to re-create a whole planet and my response was a huge yawn. The movie's not all that good either. It's not sure what it wants to be at times - a run-of-the-mill action flick (With cliched dialogue); a remake of the original; even an English bedroom farce (when Marky Mark & Friends escape they HAVE to run through the bedrooms of each important ape in the city, apparently). It also criminally mis-uses Michael Clarke Duncan and Tim Roth. In the end, the whole thing ends like an episode of "Sliders".

reviews.review_title: Yes...A Remake! (& a Poor One at That)
reviews.content: The difference is this; the makers took a little from all 5 prior Ape films, plus the TV series. Any reference to the original novel is non-existent.All that hard work recreating the (improved?) makeup has come to naught when the movie doesn't ride on a good script. At least the 1968 original took its time to pace the story properly to create some sort of suspense. The 2001 remake jumps from one scenario to the next in episodic fashion that leaves no room for the viewer to really care what happens to anyone. And except for the last half hour, you never get the feeling that you're out in the open air. Everything feels claustrophobic; like being on an over crowded sound stage.I still appreciate many of Burton's other films, but this is a misfire with too many cliches that most of us have seen before. And it seems that so much time was taken with the makeup; so much time was taken with paying visual homage to the original and its sequels; that they forgot to let a proper narrative flow take over the story and at least include a LITTLE logic (and I'm not even referring to the ending). The homages? 'Ari'...spell it backwards and put a 'Z' in front. Any more, I'd rather not spoil...you might have fun spotting them on your own when referencing 'Planet..', 'Beneath..', Escape..', 'Conquest..' and 'Battle..' (and the short lived TV series and cartoon).Stick with the original...as long as it is in wide screen (the pan & scan sucks to the point that you miss half the movie, especially when there are characters and events taking place on both ends of the wide screen).Perhaps the writers should have spent a little less effort calling this a 're-imagination' and instead used some 'real imagination' to create a compelling staple in the sci-fi genre that this deserved.5 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Oh my god, this is a real stinker!!
reviews.content: Never before I felt a movie SO rushed. The acting is pretty bad, and there is plenty of horrible and cliched dialogue. I haven't seen the original, so I can't really make a comparison. I will only tell you: This movie just plain sucks. Avoid it!! (the ending DID work for me. The problem was the rest of the film).

Tim Burton, known for his visual style, delivers yet again with Planet Of The Apes (POTA), but the film is lacking in virtually every other aspect, from the thinly drawn characters, the barely-there script, to the shockingly bad/incomphensible ending. I'll start first with the character development. There is none. Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg)is so one dimensional that at no point did i care if he ever got off the planet and back to, well, whatever and whomever. His entire time is spent throwing out cliched lines instead of being awed, inspired, terrified, or confused of his surroundings. Any emotion would have worked. As for the humans who live on the planet, I'm not sure what their problem was, they werent savages, they outnumbered the apes supposedly, they could communicate at the same level as the apes (unlike the original movie), so why exactly were they living in the hills scared for their lives. Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and General Thade (Tim Roth) are by far the most interesting, and well acted, characters.  Miss Carter brings a sensual aspect to her character that is very appealing (yes, i know shes playing a simian, but it doesnt seem to matter). While Mr Roth plays Thade deliciously evil and cunning, and his ape-like movements are a sight to see.I was especially disappointed with the relationship between Leo, Ari and Daena (played by model Estella Warren, who is way to beautiful here to pull off a role as a jungle woman). There are obvious hints of attraction between Ari and Leo, yet these scenes go absolutely nowhere in developing the awkwardness of it all. The script doesnt go beyond yearning glances, which is a shame. The last half hour of the movie was basically the standard action plot. The movie builds up to an inevitable war between the humans and the apes, with Leo devising this absurd plan to stun the first ranks (out of thousands of CGI created apes) with the remnants of his old ships ignited fuel tanks. Never mind the fact this would only eliminate maybe 5 percent of the total forces they are up against. The final conflict is never exciting, but then how could it be when we have no emotional investment in the characters.I will not discuss the "surprise" ending, except to say not only is it not surprising, it doesnt make sense, and i defy anyone to explain it.In fact, i read an interview with the higher-ups involved in this fiasco, and they revealed that the ending isnt supposed to make sense, its supposed to leave the viewer confused and guessing. Well, thats just what i want after watching this for two hours, and ending that insults the viewers intelligence by admitting "we didnt even care enough ourselves to give you a plausible ending." Thank you Hollywood. And thank you Tim Burton, for reminding us once more that classics should be left alone and time honored. If you're going to remake a movie, remake a bad movie. In fact, remake this remake.

Sure proof of the coming idiocracy was this pointless, pathetic remake and the fact that it has a rating higher than 2 stars.The title should be changed from "The Planet of the Apes" to "The Planet of Tim Burton Collecting a Paycheck."I am stunned that so many reviewers focus on the mindless ending to this movie, when the entire movie is mindless.One gets the impression that the scriptwriters were writing under deadline duress, panicked, and decided to do drugs instead. Meanwhile, if you watch the behind the scenes making of this film, you also get the distinct impression that Tim Burton knew the script was crap and so he gave up on it and treated it like a joke that he was getting big bucks for delivering. Which it is.But having said all that, I have a suggestion for a sequel. In the sequel, Wahlberg, Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Burton play themselves. They all get into a spaceship and try to go back in time to change the future where no remake of the Planet of the Apes will appear on their resume. After 2 1/2 hours of mindless hijinks and special effects, they emerge in modern day to find they didn't change a thing, because as Alec Baldwin's character states so glibly in Glengarry Glen Ross: "a loser is a loser!"And anyone who read the script for this film and didn't walk away was -at least in this instance - a loser.

Tim Burton is my absolute favorite director of all time and he rarely strikes out but when he does, it can be quite embarrassing. Case in question: the 2001 remake of one of the most famous sci-fi films of all time.I do have one confession. I've never actually seen the original 1968 film but I am familiar with the story. Here, astronaut Leo Davidson (played forgettably by Mark Wahlberg) crash lands on a distant planet ruled by intelligent apes. From there, he treks with a small band of outsiders towards these mysterious, ancient ruins which may hold the key for his return home.Where do I begin? Well, the cast is thoroughly wasted and this film has quite a cast (David Warner! Michael Clarke Duncan! Paul Giamattei!), the special effects are pretty generic, and the production design is slimy and claustrophobic. On top of all that, the final battle is very lackluster.Adding to all this, the ending is a joke. While the original film had an ending that was surprising and strangely appropriate, this one feels forced and confusing. Additional sore spots include a bland score by the usually reliable Danny Elfman and a pace that BEGS for a steroid shot.You may be wondering are there ANY redeeming values? Well, Charlton Heston's cameo is pretty good but since it is just a cameo, he's not in long enough to truly save it.What else can I say? This film stinks.

Tim Burton remake of Planet Of The Apes is underrated. No deep message like most of the franchise but the comic relief gives some breath. The acting, Human eyes underneath it all makes it more real for me. Ending people cry about was a nice twist.

reviews.review_title: Take 1 part Apes, 1 part Beneath & 1 part Battle. Mix. Flush down toilet.
reviews.content: ><SPOILERS AHEAD>< How disappointing this is. No memorable characterization. No wit. No one to identify with or care about. No satire. No acting of any consequence. No opportunity to pause and look around and take in the culture, scenery or costumes. Kristoferson, Markham and Bonham Carter(playing Michael Jackson)all have thankless roles that are mere shadows of their 1968 counterparts. Tim Burton ruins another project with great potential. He's getting like Spielberg, so full of himself that he's forgotten his craft. The good stuff: The ending almost saves the film. This is taken from the original book. I won't spoil it, but it's worth the wait. Tim Roth and Michael Duncan make the most of their underwritten roles. A nice cameo occurs half way through in Roth's father. The slave-trader, the kid and the bald servant are very good, too bad I have no idea who their characters were. There was an interesting twist to the final third of the film. I still have no idea whether he went to Earth the first time or if he's on our Earth at the end. We'll have to wait for the sure to come sequel. RATING: 6 out of 10. For a comparison, rent the 1968 original. This is a 10 out of 10.

This movie was 100% boring, i swear i almost died from boredom at the theater. It wasnt funny and didnt really hve that much action in it either, it was BORING and i hope whoever out there that liked this movie, god be with you in the future when you find out what this movie was really like and try to jump off a bridge or something like that

reviews.review_title: Excellent retelling of a classic film!!
reviews.content:
Apes rule! This movie is simply fantastic! From the great special effects, to the incredible cast, to apes that look and move like apes, nothing is missing. Roll over Heston, as Mark Wahlberg now rules the planet as head human.The story is different from the original movie, however, director Tim Burton did a very credible job in this film. The movie begins with Mark Wahlberg going after his lost chimpanzee into an electrical storm in space. This electrical storm sends our hero hundreds of years into the future, where he crash lands onto the planet of the apes. I will stop with the summary here, as there are many unexpected occurences throughout the movie.The greatest part of this film, is the casting of Tim Roth as Thade, the ape general. This is definately the best acting job he has ever done.
Take a chance on this one, I really do not think that you will be disappointed with it.

How in the name of everything holy could Tim Burton do this to us?! The director best known for "Beetlejuice", Batman", "Edward Scissorhands", and "Sleepy Hollow", gives us something that looks like it should star Arnold Schwarzenegger. Everyone knows what happens, but the dialogue is just silly - mainly mocking the original. Mark Wahlberg, as hero Leo Davidson, does as good as he can, but he can't escape the fact that this movie (correction: this remake) should have never been made. The only remotely interesting scene is the end. All in all, Wahlberg suffers, as do Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth, Michael Clarke Duncan, and everyone else. Dreadful.

reviews.review_title: Not nearly as good as the original
reviews.content: This is not a bad "remake" but I still get a feeling that the original is, even though it is set back more than 20 years still highly superior in every way, only special effects are better but that can hardly be called an accomplishment considering the technical possibilities compared to the 60's. The first Apes movie spawned 4 sequels that got worse with every film, If this one is followed by one or more sequels I really hope these sequels can beat the sequels to the original ones. Go out to the video store and rent them both, you will know what I mean, the original is super(ior), the "remake" is not bad.

Being a big fan of the "other" PLANET OF THE APES films, I rented this DVD despite my aversion to all things Tim Burton.  Once again, he doesn't fail to disappoint with his uninspired direction.  Even the ape makeup looks second rate, which is unforgivable considering the monstrous budget of this monstrosity.  Mark Wahlberg proves once and for all that he is not an actor (as if BOOGIE NIGHTS wasn't proof enough).  I was embarrassed for genuine talents such as Tim Roth and Helena Bonham Carter.  No doubt their paychecks motivated them since it couldn't possibly have been the cliche-ridden screenplay.  I rented this DVD on a special $1 night and I still feel ripped off.

For all the special effects and souped up ape costumes the remake isn't as good as the original. I wasn't much struck on the acting or the story line for that matter either.  The Charlton Heston as Taylor version still stands the test of time despite being made way back in 1968.

reviews.review_title: You Maniacs, You F@#$%ed it up!!! Damb you, Damb you all to Hell!!!!!!!
reviews.content: First there was New Coke 1985, Then Godzilla 1998, And now Planet of the Apes 2001. What was Tim Burton on when he was making this awful remake of the 1968 classic? Wasn't Cabin Boy,Mars Attacks & Sleepy Hollow bad enough for us movie goers? This film makes Planet of the Ape fans wanna cry! Why is it that new movies nowadays with great makeup and special effects has to have an awful plot? They just don't make them like they use to! Tim Burton obviously can't afford good movie writers. That's probably why his latest movies were so weak. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is an exception. At least it has a lot of plot. All though I haven't seen Big Fish yet! I just hope that Corps Bride does well. Even better than James and the Giant Peach. But Planet of the Apes, Forget it! Don't waste your time for this movie. It just ain't worth it! It's not a movie you wanna go ape over.

reviews.review_title: Trite dialogue, over-edited, lacking en todo !
reviews.content: Poor Mark Wahlberg: this honestly could have been a chance for him to extend upon steadily improving performances in the past few years, but the fault is not his. Equally, I imagine the screenwriters probably did an admirable job with their story. But any hope of a performance by Wahlberg, as anything more than a stereotyped dosage of testosterone, was trashed. It's really a pity. And to think that Tim Burton's name is attached to this film leaves me reeling... Having seen so many of his films and his genius revealed, I cannot help but believe this latest project suffered nuclear fall-out. Just think back: "Sleepy Hollow", "Nightmare Before Christmas", "Edward Scissorhands", and so many more: I could just keep writing... They were all fabulous.The most to be said for the end-product is that it allows Wahlberg to be likeable. Tim Roth, on the other hand, comes off so badly that he reminds me of Gary Oldman (whose talent, by the way, is huge and underutilised...) with too much make-up and a bad hangover. Only Helena Bonham-Carter and the special effects (read: Tim Burton) make this film worth seeing. Bonham-Carter is not only likeable, but believable, convincing, and showing real talent despite the obvious handicap of the costume. She really does deserve high marks here, but I don't think the voting public will take the end-product of this film seriously. Again, what a shame... The Marketing Gurus and Editors really need to be strung-up for hacking to bits what could have been fabulous.Entertainment value. Go see it for the special effects and noted items above. Recommend letters of condolence for Wahlberg and Burton; I am ABSOLUTELY CERTAIN this project could have been saved. Rating based on sentimentality = 3 stars (on 5).

It's only saving grace is that it looks good for it's time. Everything else is below avarage. Absolutely boring, especially for an action movie. It has like 15 minutes of action in total. The plot is forced, just as the dialog. Everything is inconsequential, most of all the ending.It has one touching scene in the last act but that is taken away after a couple of minutes.But most of all it's dumb and shallow. Skip this borefest. It's essentially the last original Apes movie, Battle for the Planet of the Apes, made with modern technology and a budget.

reviews.review_title: Those nostalgic for the original take heart- there's still only one Cornelious
reviews.content:
Show of hands...how many of you were secretly ecstatic over the thought of A. Marky Mark, er, Mark Wahlberg (excuse me) all muddied up running around a Tim Burton set and B. that they were even remaking this accidental classic, which easily is near the top of America's Cheesiest Films Of All Times list (right below Blackula, Killer Tomatoes and Jon Waters' purposely cheesy farces of course).For those too young to remember, Planet of the Apes first appeared in 1968. It was a sensation with audiences and panned by critics. The costumes were state-of-the-art for the times and the sets were as other worldly as they could portray in a sixties Star Trek quazi-realism way.Those who enjoyed the first version(s) even passed up the concession stand goodies for fear of losing that comfy close-up seat. The suspense of what the apes would look with all the modern gizmos the FX folks have at their disposal nowadays was almost unbearable. Like with The Grinch's recent successful transformation into 21st century-gadget- hoopla- infused- bing- bam box-office magic, TPOA does not disappoint on that level.As for the the rest of the film? Well, the plot is as deep as Green Eggs and Ham and the "human" cast is about as exciting as an instructional video on an anal polyp removal from the lower bowel of a brown field mouse, yet still, mad-director Tim Burton left just enough camp to keep it, surprisingly, enjoyable.The story goes...Astronaut; Leo Davidson (Mark "softly spoken" Wahlberg) is aboard a space station USS Oberon, training primates to play Astronaut. One starry night he is told to send one of these Chimps out to research a menacing energy field approaching fast on their starboard side.The "canary in the coal mine" never returns...So, Leo, bored with his mundane duties anyhow, jumps into a delta pod to rescue the fellow, and, surprise, gets transported through time to a place ruled by...He crash lands safely in an eerie swamp. But, before he can shake his banana dry, he is over run by a group of fear-for-their-lives types ricocheting through the forest being pursued by dressed, orating, violent apes. Leo is trapped, along with these ratty anorexic -Mad Max looking- extras each with a perpetual glaze over their faces like deer locked on headlights (or Nick Cage in an emotional scene), and sent to market. The market is run by Limbo (brilliant Paul Giamatti) a sleazy Orang creep.Leo and a boopsie faced tribe gal, Deana (Estella " be careful of bimbo typecasting  dear" Warren), meet in one of Limbo's human slave holding cells. She's smitten, but he's focused on his personal inner dialog, his sequel, "Exit El Quicko from the Planet Of The Apes."They end up working together and gather a few others including, human rights activist girly ape Ari (Helena Bonham Carter). They all escape the city and head to "rendezvous" with Leo's space colleagues who have been sending out a signal to him via his space age transmitter he rescued from his sunken space pod. The humans hope Leo is their savior fallen from the sky to save them from the mini-Kongs that suppress them. Leo hopes his friends are waiting for him, just over the mountain rangeThe fleeing party faces some pretty mean mother-apers en route to Shangri-La! One ape in particular, General Thad, (Tim Roth) hates humans in a Hitler- southern plantation owner-circa 1800 way. He wants the filthy creatures (humans) completely annihilated and is schmoozing with the ape senate to get his wish. Leo is just what the nefarious Thad ordered when praying to their almighty Semos for a sign the humans must all go. With Leo's frightening display of intelligence and back bone, the senate will be scared bananaless into giving Thad the Marshal Law decree he so desires.
Will Leo and his new tribal friends make it to the space command center before Thad's wicked army finds and crushes them? Is Leo the god they have waited for all these years? Could the last fight scene be tackier?Don't worry, I'm not ruining anything here for you...It's so telegraphed G.W. Bush would know the ending half way through. Okay, maybe right before the credits at least.The story is a tad blasé. You may find yourself adrift about the screen, looking for something to busy your brain when Mark and crew aren't battling the Apes. Which brings up a kind of humorous point of observation, Wahlberg's "Leo" has like three sentences of dialog in a scene, then smacko, he's immediately in primal combat again; like an odd ballet of film you watch and keep a mental metronome swaying in your head1-2-3 fight, 1-2-3 fight.TPOA is really all about the visual treats; like watching intense thespian Tim Roth bounce about like an extra at Ringling Bros. & Barnum Bailey Circus of the Cruel in his cute little money, er, ape suit. Tim Roth's "Thad" was super creepy. Hate oozes from his furry little pores to the point were you feared he may really have gone rabid. Even with all the schtuffamagal Roth had burying his features, the feeling and depth from the actor beneath came through. Or Helena Bonham Carter, all made up in ten pounds of latex, a far cry from the West End beauty she is, for sure. Still a lady, even as an ape.Then there's MM Wahlberg. His picture is in Compton's Encyclopedia under "example of the Male Homo Sapiens " -In my version anyway The man's body is, simply, dare I say, perfect. He's a double cream serving of Pistachio Ice cream with a hidden layer of marshmallow fluff. Scrumptious. Leo was a dull character so MM's signature "whisper" delivery worked. I think I need a Boogie Nights fix...TPOA has quite a few exciting moments. Enough to recommend it. Those nostalgic for the original take heart- there's still only one Cornelious (Roddy McDowall) and this is not a replacement, it's just another look at a pretty wild concept , modernized for the new generation to enjoy.
An aside: Danny Elfman, Timmie Burtonski's favorite music man, is back incahoots producing the film's score. As always, Elfman delivers a catchy, flowing gently ominous orchestration of notes.Snack recommendation: Banana nut pound cake and Pistachio ice cream.

reviews.review_title: It's a one star disappointment. Hopefully the sequel will be an improvement.
reviews.content: I have to admit, I never read the book.  Maybe this thing was true to the letter.  If that's the case, the creators of the original movie were even smarter than I thought.  Regardless, this time around was an abysmal disaster.  I gave it a "4" because Charlton Heston was awesome in his cameo. Nothing else impressed.

A planet full of nasty apes is a great idea. Someday somebody will make a great movie about it. Until then you'll have to watch this one:Wahlberg is lost on a strange planet and who of all people does he encounter? Kris Kristofferson! Complete with his groomed beard portraying some kind of a caveman. One wonders why he isn't wearing cowboy hat and boots. Then we have little Tim Roth as a British(?) chimp. Burton orders: "You're a chimp! Act like one! Make at least 10 grimaces a second!" And Roth obeys. He is the bad chimp, so he tries to look really mean, but doesn't. Roth also hops around a lot. It's real method acting, you know. As if the bad apes aren't, well, "bad" enough, there are also "good" apes, who talk like liberals, so the kids who watch this mess hopefully will turn out as "good" citizens one day. Of course they won't listen to the drivel of the good apes. It's too boring. Talking of boring: Wahlberg gets captured by the bad apes in a boring way and soon escapes in a boring way. Then he's on the run and has to talk a lot to the other humans and a female chimp (Carter) which has the desire to be just as smart as him. Sometimes we see Roth the chimp, who wants Wahlberg back. he gives orders to his favorite gorilla, then hops out of frame for the most time. At the end he and a lot of other apes get whacked in the head by Wahlberg and his feel-good-posse. Some big apes roll around on the floor in deadly combat. The final duel belongs to Wahlberg and Roth the little chimp, which leaves the monkey completely bonkers. Finally a real chimp saves the day and shows Roth and the others how to act. Obviously Burton had no influence on the animal. The last minutes gives us a tiny impression what this remake maybe should have been about, would it have been made by a director with a vision.

How do I put this lightly. . . . I loathe this movie with the entirety of my being.This isn't a Planet of the Apes movie. I can't just turn off my brain and enjoy a mindless "re-imagination" of one of the most thoughtful movies I've ever seen. Watching this movie made me feel physically sick. Writing about it made me feel physically sick. I was literally on the floor. I can't handle this movie. That being said, this movie isn't necessarily an assaulting kind of bad. Some will find entertainment value in it, at least it has a plot, and (generally) it has a nice aesthetic quality. But it's still bad.Tim Burton is someone who I have a lot of respect for. I think he's a fantastic filmmaker, and more blame belongs to the writers than anyone else on this project. Burton's hands however still aren't clean, and he's committed his fair share of offenses here. On the commentary he actually explains that apes make him uncomfortable (which would explain the apes' performances), and he gave the impression that he didn't want to direct the film in the first place. It shows.This is one of his weakest efforts in terms of direction. For example, we actually don't get to see all that much of the Ape City--only dimly lit, claustrophobic sets and homogenous formations can really be observed (though what we do see looks pretty good). We get a few wide shots, usually attached to other sets like the forest, adding a kind of close-knitness that detracts from its sense of scale. Making that issue worse, relatively little time is dedicated to travel, so even the military camps and the set from the battle scene don't feel very distant. This simply isn't the best effort Burton could have given, but was maybe the best we could've hoped for given the script.The screenplay for this film was written by William Broyles Jr., Lawrence Konner, & Mark Rosenthal, the last two of whom worked on such hits as Superman IV! Now, to the writers' credit, at least there's a plot for the most part, but that's about all I can praise them on (if that indeed counts as praise). I'm not really quite sure where to begin with the flaws actually. As I watched the film I started making a list of questions regarding anything that disregarded logic or broke my suspension of disbelief. I can only use so many words, so I guess I'll just post the list:Why send a baby chimpanzee into space? Or a chimp at all? Humans pulling the carriage instead of horses? Wild humans have the time and resources to curl and dye their hair? Where'd she get that 20th century hair dye? What's with the stoner apes? He's feisty? He just grabbed your leg on accident and looked at Thade all confused- like. Where were the doors in the houses? Why won't the humans talk? They're not mute so. . . . Why'd the one human signal not to talk, then? Do the apes not know they can talk somehow? They didn't seem surprised. If humans are lower on the evolutionary chain than monkeys, why can humans talk but not the monkeys? Are there talking monkeys we don't know about? Were there even any monkeys on the ship they came on? Considering the ship's population, they'd be really inbred by now right? How were the apes in that blast only stunned? Did they see the 1968 film? Did they even read the book? It's closer to the book, but still nowhere near it. Should have just called the movie something else, like: "Inbreeding: The Movie".A few other points: There's some almost-commentary on religion, but nothing that pans out. Any allegorical content is an afterthought at best. It's tonally unsure of itself: half wants to be taken seriously, half cartoon. Mark Wahlberg's character really just doesn't care, and is too blank to be relatable. The apes might be talking about something expository or of their interest, and then Leo just mentions something unrelated that pertains only to him. It's almost pleading you to assume character depth for it, but you don't because there isn't any. The apes in this movie are completely cartoonish, including their preposterous fear of water (maybe they can't swim because their prosthetics will fall off, as my sister observed).Mark Wahlberg and the Chimp are pretty damn cute, I'll give it that. Otherwise, Tim Roth is a cartoon. Paul Giamatti is a cartoon. Helena Bonham Carter is a cartoon. The humans are all bland. I suppose the actors are into it enough to pass as flamboyant caracachures. They sell it, but it's for the wrong movie. And I love Paul Giamatti. He doesn't belong in this movie, but I love him.The wirework is pretty bad. The CGI is fine. Though the sets and colors are nice. If there's one thing I can give Burton credit for it's for making a (generally) good-looking movie. The prosthetics for the most part actually look pretty good, sometimes as good as Chambers' work from the 1968 film. Some of the makeups look out-of-proportion or bizarre though, like stuff conceived on mutations or not-to-be-named perversions-- genuinely concerning designs.The score by Danny Elfman is simply fine. It's inoffensive, maybe slightly better than the average modern-age film score, but that's not really saying much. At least there's actually a melody (even if somewhat derivative of his Spider-Man score), and as bombastic and obnoxious as the drums are at least they have personality, though it's a far-cry from Elfman's best.This is not a Planet of the Apes film. It's a movie with apes in it, completely unrelated to Planet of the Apes. If you're a die-hard Planet of the Apes fan, maybe watch it once. Otherwise, seek out the 1968 film. Don't bother with this.Score: 3/10

reviews.review_title: CANNOT WAIT FOR THE SEQUEL! TIM BURTON BETTER MAKE A SEQUEL! AND MORE SEQUELS!
reviews.content: This dramatic, dark, deceptive and very entertaining tale of action, fantasy, black humor, romance, and drama was brilliant! Great make up work was put into this movie, some brilliant performances by humans and apes and I've never seen the original but I'm convinced that this one is much better! I better not give you the ending, BUT I CAN TELL YOU RIGHT NOW THAT TIM BURTON BETTER MAKE A SEQUEL OR 2 OR 3....! WHATEVER!

reviews.review_title: A travesty of a sham! A sham of a travesty!
reviews.content: Is there anybody left that actually remembers the original 'Planet of the Apes'?  If so, do remember the point?  Man, given enough time, will destroy himself with technology.  Simple ebough.  Flash forward to the present, and the film is remade.  And what does Tim Burton do?  He gives the moral a 180 and suddenly man is the utmost being and technology is his savior.  It just goes to show how self centered and over confident we have all become.For the record, even if there was no original Planet of the Apes, this would still be a worthless movie.  It becomes more campy by the second, there are far to many innconsistancies to mention here, and the ending was quite possibly the most ridiculous thing I have ever seen.  What, did they have a whole bunch of left of monkey suits to use?  Not only am I about to give up on Tim Burton (that's two, Mr. Burton, remember Sleepy Hollow?) but I am completely fed up with the bastardization of old movies.  Has hollywood run out of new ideas?

When I first heard that Tim Burton was going to "re-imagine" the original "Planet of the Apes" (which is a much nicer word than "re-hash"), my question was, "Why?"  Now I've seen it, and I still don't know.  When you remake a movie, it will inevitably invite comparison with the original. You need to bring something new, interesting, and different to it, and most importantly, it helps to know what that something is.  And that is the chief weakness of the new "Apes".The original movie had weirdness and originality, plus satiric bite and subtext out the wazoo.  The apes in Burton's movie behave more like real apes, which is neat, but part of the original's charm was that its human-ish apes lent it a surreal "Twilight Zone" quality, no surprise given the involvement of Rod Serling.  Plus the original had that ending, which has become a classic cinematic moment.  The new "Apes" obviously lacks that dramatic punch, and the makers were wise to alter its premise accordingly. But to what?  The new movie works best as a comic takeoff on the genre (since the original spawned four sequels and an armada of imitators).  It's fun to spot all the references in this movie, both to the "Planet of the Apes" series and to other cultural icons.  But the movie fails to keep the satiric edge through the second reel until the bravura, witty finale (which suggests that any sequel might be funnier and better than this one). Otherwise we get a lot of ho-hum posturing and a surprisingly yawn-inducing battle scene.  The movie also leaps over gaps in the plot like a steroid-crazed chimpanzee.  As an example, the hero is confronted by an army of human refugees who have come from all the land to "see the human who defies the apes."  That's impressive communication: he'd only escaped the night before.The story is weak and wandering, and the cast isn't up to the task of buoying it.  This is especially true in the pivotal lead character. Charlton Heston's performance in the original was hammy (but admit it now; we love Charlton BECAUSE he's hammy), but his character had fire and emotion.  You could identify with him because he was trapped in an insane situation, and his fear, confusion and rage were palpable to you.  Mark Wahlberg in the new one barely registers.  Wahlberg is not a bad actor, but neither is he a lead actor.  He is subtle, and best when playing quiet supporting characters to more vibrant leads, like in "Three Kings" or "The Corruptor".  He also has a flair for deadpan satire (he was the best thing in the misfired "The Big Hit").  But this is a role that requires less subtlety and more big expressiveness.  Wahlberg comes across not as an ordinary man trapped in a bizarre nightmare out of time, but just befuddled, like a commuter that has gotten off at the wrong stop.  And, just before the big battle, he gives what has to be the least inspiring speech-to-the-troops in film history.  If Marky Mark had been at Valley Forge, we'd all be mailing our tax returns to London.Heston, incidentally, crops up in an in-jokey cameo as the wizened old leader of the apes.  He shows his son Thade (Tim Roth) an ancient pistol which he says is proof of the ingenuity and wickedness of humanity, in one swoop spoofing both his role in the original and his day job as NRA President.  Between this and playing a gun-toting nut job in "Town and Country", Heston seems intent on retiring the Good Sport Award for this year.It happens that all the good performances in this movie are among the apes (hmm, maybe they ARE superior).  Roth is magnetic as the power-mad, swaggering Thade, and kudos also to Michael Clarke Duncan as his adjutant, with a booming voice that was made to say things like, "Bow your heads!" Estella Warren is very cute in buckskin, but contributes little else to this movie (this is not all her fault; for an ostensible love interest, her character is woefully underwritten).The movie is not all bad; I'd certainly say it's worth seeing.  It has visual flair, there are a lot of funny lines and moments, and the ending is inspired; but as comedy it's too dull, as drama too flat, as allegory too unworkable to rise above the ordinary.  In the "Apes" ouevre, I'd place it above "Escape From..." and "Battle For...", but that's below the level of ringing endorsement.And if you do see it, one last thing to ponder:  Where the hell did the horses come from???

reviews.review_title: What were they thinking? Hollywood bunk once again.
reviews.content: The original Planet of the Apes was awesome for its time. The number of follow up films produced prove it. I admit with each new sequel the quality of the story went down, but one tends to be forgiving because they were made so closely together and had some cohesion.  This new film doesn't have that luxury. They took a chance and changed the story and failed miserably.  The original had implications of mankind's destructive nature which caused this twisted society to be born. In the new version the ape society was born from an astronaut not following orders. How Trite! I'll say that the make-up was impressive, but so what. I'll take a story with some depth and meaning any day.

reviews.review_title: A Good Solid Reworking Of A Classic
reviews.content: This was one of summer 2001's big event pictures, it had lots of hype and lots of people talking but everyone in a fashion knew that this reworking would never top the original even with a solid director and good cast. They were right! Leo Davidson (Mark Whalberg)who works on a large space station goes out in a spacecraft to save his chimp that has gone into a mysterious cloud formulating in space, he too is sucked in and lands in a planet ruled by apes where humans are the prey and are tortured and are pets to the apes.Davidson must get back to his main ship and along the way finds friendship in a female ape called Ari (Helena Bohnam Carter) who helps him and he helps her. But General Thade (Tim Roth) is intent on destroying all humans and Davidson and his band of rebels are top of his list.The film as a whole is very good and i was much surprised at how much i enjoyed it, i was very skeptical with it being that i really didn't get the original film but this film i got.I really got Burtons vision and really saw this as a good attempt at a reworking from the man i like to call a hero of mine, i did think in places his usual directing skills lacked in some places but for the most part he did an ace job.Mark Whalberg put in a very good performance as the hero of the picture, in places i found him to be slightly annoying but like with Burtons direction for the most part he put in a very good performance as did Tim Roth who comes across very evil in his portrayal as a bitter and twisted ape which i don't think would be an easy feet for any actor.The dialog i have to say in parts is poor as is some of the character interpretation. One of the best and great things about this picture is the production design and once you watch the film you really see where the money for this film went and it really is a well deserved effort of the production designers part. Job well done! For the most part this film has spectacle and awe and this is needed for a summer event picture and i wasn't unhappy with the final product at all. Burton gave his usual unique vision to a classic film that many regard as the ultimate Sci-fi film and in comparison many may feel that this film is no where near as good as the original, but if were honest when are they ever! Overall ******* out of **********

reviews.review_title: Would the real planet of apes please stand up? (it aint this one)
reviews.content: Not good! Rent or buy the original! Watch this only if someone has a gun to your head and then....maybe.It is like claiming an Elvis actor is as good as the real King.

reviews.review_title: A waste of a good movie
reviews.content:
Why do they bother to remake good movies?I had hoped that because the technology is so much better than it was in the 60s, that we would see the FX simply enhance an already great movie. Nope.Instead, we saw mediocre special effects and make-up trying to hold together a mere shadow of the original story.The entire beauty of the Original POTA can be summed up like this:  Taylor is a human on a planet that for some reason is run by apes and humans are slaves.  He longs to leave the planet and get back HOME to Earth.  The shocker at the end of the movie is that he already IS home.The new Apes could not hope to compete with that and, given that so many people already know the ending, tried very hard to end with an equal, if different, shock.  It didn't work.One thing about the ending (no spoiler here): you either loved it, or you hated it.  I hated it.  There has been so much discussion about whether or not it made sense...all I can say is that if you have to argue about it, then it wasn't clear enough.  I think the movie would have been much more entertaining if the story line brought you to the ending, (like the original did), instead of throwing it at you from out of nowhere.
I'm glad I saw it.  Once.  I'm also glad I rented it on DVD instead of paying theater prices to see it.And I'm thinking of buying the originals...

reviews.review_title: I hope it doesn't turn into a Star Trek
reviews.content: I saw this film the day it came out with high hopes.  My friends told me how great the original was and i could only think of how awesome a writer must be to create such an original story.  Oh, i was a fool.Burton has had a successful streak, hasn't he?  Batman, Batman Returns, Sleepy Hollow, and the cult favorite Nightmare Before Christmas.  Yes it is an awesome life.  But every career has a hitch.  This is his.  Mark Wahlberg's career has also been rising.  From the innovative Boogy Nights, to the highly rated Three Kings and The Perfect Storm with another blockbuster (Rock Star) on the way.  Maybe this can be an oversight.No matter the director or the stars, our hero, Leo Davidson cannot see that his ape costars are real actors.  Whenever speaking to them, he inserts a short pause, as if trying to prove to himself that these are real people. His eyes are blank and emotionless.  He plays a hero just as well as Steven Seagal, take that as you will.The apes are frighteningly lifelike, but you can't base a movie on its makeup.  The film is dark, very dark (visually) for the first 3/4.  As if these future apes couldn't figure out lightbulbs, or even gas lights.  The film also uses the rope and pulley system made popular by the Matrix.  While it looked new and exciting in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, and even Romeo Must Die, seeing apes jumping vertically eight feet (from a sit down) is just silly.None of the "human" characters, beside Leo, play an important role.  It makes you wonder why he's trying to save them.  Apes have evolved into intelligent, thought processing individuals over thousands of years... but what happened to the humans?  Did we just stop at a certain point in time, and someone said, "This is enough for you"?  The ending is so confusing it's physically impossible.  Burton rearranges time so much i think HE get's lost.  Overall, it's a 4/10- saved by the makeup and the ape's acting.

reviews.review_title: Exhibit A on why Hollywood should be destroyed
reviews.content: This wretched,empty,monkey of a movie is devoid of wit,substance,and integrity.Sure the ape outfits are good.Great.If you want to look at monkey suits,waste 2 hours of your life on this film.Maybe the costumes will win awards.The only other award this film will win is for Tim Burton,earning him lifetime membership in the Hollywood Hacks Hall of Fame. Rent the original,skip this.

It takes a plethora of qualities to make an outstanding piece of cinema. Many things can go awry, from direction to production, casting to lighting. Any one thing can put the whole thing off kilter. Try watching The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, to a background score of 'The Sound Of Music' and you may begin to see what I'm driving at. It just doesn't ring true. It would come across as, if not ridiculous, then certainly somewhat odd. This is how I felt about this film. Mark Wahlberg plays a United States Airforce space pilot who also trains, luckily for the plot, monkeys. It would be easy to harp on about paying peanuts, getting monkeys and other such witticisms. Instead of blindly denigrating this film, as many have done, it would seem more politic to look at the reasons why. Hammy acting, cliched one-liners, `Never send a monkey to do a man's job', for instance. Lack of plot; Star thrown into space turmoil, gets stranded on an unforgiving planet dominated by Apes. Apes catch star. Star escapes from potential slavery. Star gets home again safely. Everybody's happy. Apart from the audience. Widely slammed by critics and punters alike, and fairly so. A poor excuse for a film which tried, and miserably failed, to live up to the original. Bad, bad, bad. Even the token appearance from Charlton Heston could not save this from ignominy.

Mark Rosenthal and Lawrence Konner (The Legend of Billie Jean, Superman IV: A Quest for Peace, Sometimes They Come Back, The Beverly Hillbillies and more) worked with The Polar Express and Cast Away writer William Broyles Jr.After decades of trying to reboot the franchise, Tim Burton was able to get this script to the screen, even if nearly nobody was happy with the end results. Sure, it made money, but even the ending - spoiler, the Lincoln Memorial is now dedicated to General Thade and everyone on Earth is an ape - is the most nonsensical surprise ending of nearly all time.Mark Wahlberg - the man who potentially could have stopped 9/11 - plays Captain Leo Davidson, a United States Air Force astronaut who opens a portal to another world and ends up captured by the apes sometime in the future of 5021.After being captured, Leo and a female slave named Daena (Estella Warren) are bought by female chimpanzee Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), who brings them to work as servants in the house of her father, Senator Sandar (David Warner). Of course, Leo is destined to free the slaves and battle for freedom against Thade (Tim Roth, who turned down the role of Snape in the Harry Potter films to be in this movie) and Colonel Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan).This is a movie packed with actor spotting opportunities, from Paul Giamatti as slave trader Limbo to Kris Kristofferson as Daena's father Karubiv, Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa (Shang Tsung!) as General Krull, Lisa Marie as Nova, Erick Avari (who has portrayed 24 different ethnicities in his career) as Tival, Glenn Shadix (who was the voice of the Mayor of Halloween Town in The Nightmare Before Christmas) as Senator Nado, Freda Foh Shen (the voice of the Chinese takeout in Hey Dude, Where's My Car?) as Bon and cameo appearances by the two actors most associated with the human side of the original films. Charlton Heston plays Thade's father Zaius and Linda Harrison appears as a slave.The films looks great, the Rick Baker effects are amazing, but sadly the film has no soul. There was plenty of studio overinvolvement in the film and Burton was in the midst of ending his relationship with Lisa Marie and beginning a new one with Helena Bonham-Carter. When asked if he'd make a sequel, Burton replied, "I'd rather jump out a window."Planet of the Apes won Worst Remake at the 22nd Golden Raspberry Awards, while Heston (Worst Supporting Actor) and Estella Warren (Worst Supporting Actress) also won awards. For what it's worth, Tim Roth had major issues with Heston and had no idea that the NRA spokesperson would be in the film with him.Wahlberg would later say to MTV News, when the next series of reboots was released, "I haven't seen it yet, but I heard it was pretty damn good. Well, ours wasn't. It is what it is. Ours wasn't. They didn't have the script right. Fox Studios had a release date before Tim Burton had shot a foot of film. They were pushing him and pushing him in the wrong direction. You have to let Tim do his thing."One last weird thing: Two apes in fill makeup appeared on the August 6, 2001 of WWE Raw. They entered the building to the theme song of Kamala and briught gifts for Stephanie McMahon before helping Chris Jericho throw a pie in her face. However, the apes were presented as real and not actors, which made the whole thing appear leven more ridiculous.

I've read some of the comments and I won't add another one that trashes the movie; we get the point! This is a typical reaction of moviegoers who are kinda uptight about certain films, mainly those who deal with humanistic philosophy of good and evil, like Lords of the ring, Star Wars or the Star Trek series. Probably Dungeon and dragon players too. Kinda nerd? I thought the movie was okay, not great but Burton did a good job considering he was touching sacred material (a cult film, woooow!). And I especially like the ending which was like a finger (guess which one!) pointed at those freaks who like to have an ending that answers all questions for them and let them think they are intelligent. It reminded me of the ending of Hitchcock's the Birds which still drive people mad because it doesn't explain why the Birds decided to attack. Who cares: it's a movie!!!

reviews.review_title: What a waste of a good novel
reviews.content:
I saw the original and thought it was great.  This "re-imaging" was so vastly inferior to that, that it's a wonder the script ever got greenlit to begin with.  I had heard that the film was bad, but I liked the original so much I rented it when it came out on video anyway. What a mistake.I didn't simply dislike this version because I'm a fan of the original, it is truely a horrible horrible film.  The script is pathetic and the ending seems like it was made by someone under the influence of heavy narcotics who didn't care about whether it made sense or fit into the movie or not.
This film is almost ridiculously campy with the bad dialogue and lines thrown into it simply to elicit a slight grin beased on a connection from the first film.  The apes act ridiculous and you're never left with the feeling that this could actually happen given the absurd things they do. I'm surprised Burton didn't throw in a monkey car that runs on bananas or something.  There's even a little dwarf that runs around collecting money like a chimpanzee would do at the circus.  Even if they took all the "ape camp" out, it's still a pathetic movie. Mainly because of the script and the horrible directing by Burton.  The stunts look pretty bad and fake. Many things don't make sense, like why apes would ride horses if they can move faster than horses anyway.  Even Wahlberg gives a pathetic performance.The only entertainment value in this entire movie is the "funny" things that an ape society does that compare with what humans do.  The only redeeming thing about renting this trash was that it was the best sounding DVD I've ever heard, and REALLY gave my 5.1 surround system a work.  Almost worth the rent to check it out until some better DVDs come along that have sound work as good.

In short, Great acting, great effects, great make up, great sets, great idea but it just didn't seem right. I'm not a great advocate of remakes anyway, sometimes they work, sometimes they don't, in this case the latter applies. Near perfection should be left alone.
I thought this was a good remake a much more in depth tone for the series as well as amazing special and practical effects

After digesting the hype and then taking in Tim Burton's remake of "The Planet of the Apes", I felt cheated or let us say disappointed. It was by no means any better than the original. An astronaut(Mark Wahlberg) lands on a planet where apes rule over humans, ok. He then tries to lead a revolution, ok. The twisted ending is the only captivating part of the movie. The set designs were awesome, cinematography out of sight and the special effects very good. This is a very interesting movie, but lacks the impact of the original.
