Danny Elfman proves again to be a wizard when it comes to scoring a movie.Supporting cast features Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Clark, Kris Kristofferson, Michael Clarke Duncan and Estella Warren. There is no reason to not think this movie can last over thirty years like the original and still be worth viewing. Hang on to the youngsters and your popcorn. A fun flick.

reviews.review_title: Get yer stinkin hands off me
reviews.content: Greetings again from the darkness.  Somewhat unstable director Tim Burton offers us a very dark, bleak and action-packed re-make.  Yes, it is a re-make despite all attempts to categorize as something other than.  Some wonderful characters here, including the best non-human villain in film history.  Tim Roth creates a truly evil being in Thade.  His walk and talk had me believing!  The sound, make-up and costumes are outstanding, and really had to be in order to pull this off.  Burton provides a few nice nods to the original, but none better than including Chuck Heston in a real flip of roles.  The usually outstanding Danny Elfman (yes, Jenna's bro) has some fine score moments, but overall a bit of let down.  Marky Mark is OK in the lead, but Estella Warren (from "Driven") is downright awful.  No other human has highlights in their hair!  Michael Clark Duncan ("The Green Mile") is chilling as the sargeant of the ape army.  Again the sound comes into play everytime he speaks or roars.  Not really sure of the purpose of the ending. It is not a surprise ending, but I cannot tell if this is a tip of the cap to the original remakes, or if Burton thought he was providing a shocker. The ending kind of flops on both accounts.  But that should not prevent you from seeing the movie.  Just make sure you go to a big screen, with great sound!

reviews.review_title: Did Tim Burton sleep through this?
reviews.content: I've got a theory, and it's the only only way i can fathom how this great tragedy of a movie came to be the way it is... Tim Burton slept through every single take, just to wake in time to shout "Cut!" and then nod through the next scene. Honestly, every single element of this movie was without vision, without style, without anything.There is honestly no one to pick on, cause everyone and everything was equally bad. Even Tim Roth irritated me as the over the top Thade. Where did that stupid kid suddenly come from just before the final battle? The so-called twist at the end seem to have been forced in there just to give this film some credibility when compared to the first film. Ironically, it just highlights the incredible shortcomings of it.There are honestly SO MANY BAD THINGS to pick on, but i'm sure the guys here at IMDB have some sort of limit on the length of comments. So, in conclusion: The entire cast & crew of this flick must have been on an overdose of sleeping tablets, god help them.Burton, you better do something next that's up to your previous standards, otherwise i'm coming for your soul...

Either the NRA has taken over this page, or I saw a different film as most of the other IMDb users.  If this film proves anything, it's that Tim Burton is one of the greatest creative minds in cinematic history.  When I saw the trailer I feared this one wouldn't be as dark as his previous efforts, but there are still plenty Burtonesque images for the fans to be happy.I saw the original Charlton Heston film and although I appreciated the camp qualities and the shock ending, it was basically nothing more then a long episode of the muppet show.  This version has so much more style and the apes are truly impressive, you forget they're just humans, unlike in the original.  Rick Baker deserves an oscar for his work. I also think Mark Whalberg makes a much more realistic hero then Heston. While Charlton was happy enough to fight 'them darn monkeys', the only thing Whalberg cares about is to get the hell out of there, with or without the other humans. About the 'twist'ending (don't worry I'm not gonna spoil it), well I didn't see it coming, as did nobody else in the audience.So don't let all the negative reviews scare you, this movie is really worth seeing!!

I am a 43yr old former screenwriter, who now teaches writing science fiction, and screen/play writing so forgive my bitterness! I was a kid when the POA movies came out(I read the book at age 7, and saw the movie(Heston's version) at age 6. I marveled at the apes, and their culture, but even then I knew there was some dumbness in the script. Like why didn't Taylor place one of his 2 other crewmen on guard duty while they were swimming? They each had a gun in their survival backpack(and didn't all my friends and I want those cool metal packs with guns and stuff inside!)? So my dad and I groaned at that one! But the rest of the movie was cool, and had some important sociological stuff to say. Tim Burton's movie has none of the coolness or important stuff to say!(IMHO). It DOES have what I call "idiot disease"---the current(since 1980 or so) brain rot of writers and filmmakers, which says "let's assume the audience all has double digit IQ or even single digit IQ !" Well, maybe the writers and money men in Hollywood DO have single and double digit IQ, but unless all of my generation and the one before it(and slightly immediately after it) are all dead, and I'm a dinosaur who forgot to extinct, some people who drop large amounts of money for a night at the movies, DEMAND Smart(read that common sense-ical and intellectually adult) writing in our movies. Burton took a totally "let's make money" aim with this "re-imagining" of what was a beloved series. He went for:boobs,babes,interspecies sexual encounters,cgi headache giving animation,and stupidity masquerading as "Art". How in the hell does the spaceship remain "dormant but operational" after what has been declared "a couple thousand yrs"? why not arm the humans with the guns STILL IN THE SHIP? Uh, if the recording said they were fighting, and only holding the apes off because they had the guns, then the guns in THEIR RACKS, must have had AMMUNITION! OR, why doesn't Leo wait till the bulk of the rampaging army of apes is RIGHT IN THE BLAST RANGE? Uhm, shouldn't the apes have been bar-b-qued? Military trained people just DO NOT behave like Captain Marky Mark did in this film! These may seem bitterness driven quibbles, but I'm an English Professor darn it, I cannot see wasting my life trying to educate people who are happy with a world in which there is no common sense, no intellectual discourse, and no intelligence in their choices of reading(?) materials, music, movies, Art. Burton should be spanked for making this trash--He's a brilliant visionary, and a talented thinker--where was his head during this? As for actors, Marky Mark hit the high point in FEAR, with Reese Witherspoon. Helena Bonham Carter threw Lisa Marie from her place in Tim's bed(i was there as a fly on the wall), and Estella--dear, you need to get a life, honey! Only Roth and Heston saved this gawdawful idiot's parade!

I have seen and liked the original film, and expected more from a remake than this.GOOD: Effects and makeup are good.  No complaints about the score and visuals, they are adequate, and the performances were okay (Tim Roth was excellent, the other principals were fine, and a handful of the "supporting supporting actors" did very well with extremely limited roles).  The action scenes were exciting and fun.BAD: The escape from the ape city was terrible.  The characters are going in circles, then suddenly someplace in the middle of town there are tunnels to escape.  Plus, what escape route leads through everybody's bedroom?The story was pared down to include as much action as possible.  I like action scenes but the original film had more meat to it and deserved more respect.Finally, the ending was completely nonsensical as presented.  Without seeing the inevitable sequel, there is no justification for it.

reviews.review_title: Felt outdated for it's time and lacked what made the original at least intriguing
reviews.content: This wasn't a terrible remake but it wasn't really good either. I like remakes that change things up a bit while having some essence and premise from the original. And this movie did change things up a lot compared to the original but it took a lot away from what made the original good. The movie felt like it was more about racism than sci-fi ideology and theory which I found to be interesting in the original. And it lacked the creepy and mysterious sci-fi elements that was in the original. It's a watchable movie but it just goes in a very narrow and direct direction and not in a good way either. Nothing is really imaginative and it just didn't get me immersed or interested on what was going on. I was just going along with it until it ended. The original "Planet of the Apes" was far-fetched but this was is more non-believable and even absurd. Also maybe if it tried to modernize it in a cool sci-fi direction it might have been at least somewhat entertaining but it lacked that as well while having the similar corniness of the original. The apes being apes didn't even play a crucial part in the story.4.5/10

Having just returned home from viewing this film, I remain stunned.  I expected much better from such a fine director and cast, complete with what seems to have been an unlimited budget.Main beef - where's the plot?  This movie was so predictable and lifeless, I don't know where to begin.  The so-called "plot", was rife with absolutely fantastic leaps of logic (ie. an accidental one-button location of a space/time warp - puhleeeeze!).  Such a pity.The film offered no surprises, other than the guffaws of disbelief from many in the crowded theater.  I'm still trying to understand why somebody felt the original movie, deserving of much praise, had to be remade.The primate characters looked like actors wearing rubber masks.  Nearly every set looked like... well, a set.  Several characters (ie. young warboy), invisible during the development of the story, somehow become important near the end of the film.  But without character background, I felt nothing for them.  The requisite buxom blonde was easy to look at, but left me wondering why she was even there.  Any romance angle between man/blonde or man/girl-illa was undeveloped and anemic, and shouldn't have even been attempted.This was one lame waste of a Friday night, and my hard-earned money.

The original movie with Charlton Heston is an epic and fantastic movie but all those remakes made after 2k are inferior in every aspect, I even do like the costumes of the old movies more than the new special effects. The one question for me, why Tim Burton agreed to make this mediocre and uninteresting piece. Stick with the old movies (1968-1973) they are all better than the new ones.

Okay, if you don't know... the original Planet of the Apes movie was hailed as a classic. Despite being basically a B-movie with a load of men in rubber masks, it had a unique ending which will be remembered throughout cinema history (if you don't know what it is, then I won't spoil it by telling you). Therefore, now we have the remake (or 're-envisioning' as the film-makers like to call it), it had two choices: either copy the original ending and leave everyone saying they ripped off the first, or try to match it for shock value.I don't think they would have won doing either. They tried 'shock value' and failed.However, if you ignore that, Planet of the Apes (the remake) isn't actually a bad movie. If you like sci-fi (and can forgive the blasphemy of remaking such a classic) you should at least enjoy the make-up - which is awesome for creating new and varied races of apes.Not counting the ending, there are other negatives, too. There are more human characters, most of which don't get the screen time they deserve to be fully developed (and any fans of Kris Kristophen will feel short-changes as his addition is basically an extended cameo). Plus the action isn't that action-packed (but then Tim Burton is hardly an 'action director').However, despite the negatives, it's still not a bad movie. It'll never be the classic that the original was and it was a disappointment at the box office (meaning the ending will never get the explanation it deserved). Don't expect too much and enjoy the grisly performance of Tim Roth as the evil ape leader and not being able to recognise Helena Bonham Carter in her make-up.http://thewrongtreemoviereviews.blogspot.co.uk/

reviews.review_title: There Is Only One Charlton Heston.
reviews.content: Well what can I really say about this mess?. Except of course that they should not have bothered. The original Planet Of The Apes is a sci-fi classic with Charlton Heston and Roddy McDowell, no remake needed to be made, no remake should have been made. It looks pretty, all of Burtons films do, but it has no soul. This film is a tangled mess that falls flat in almost every respect. The lead guy has no personality, unlike Hestons gritty Taylor, the apes jump about like fleas on a dog and don't seem anywhere near as organized or likable as the originals, and the ending???.Sometimes it's just better to leave things alone, this was definitely one of the those times.

reviews.review_title: I Don't Much Care For This!
reviews.content: I see why people hate this film. In fact, the first time I saw this, I hated this film and I rarely hate films. I couldn't even watch the whole thing. I'm reviewing this movie after viewing it for a second time. I thought it was OK. Tim Burton certainly made much better movies.Leo Davidson lands on a planet with the humans the minority race. The majority race is none other than evil gorillas. Now, Leo needs to help the humans and escape while he can.The acting is so so. Mark Wahlberg is a decent actor. Tim Roth played a great villain. Estella Warren needs to quit acting(maybe she did). Her character is awful.The special effects were pretty good even though there are lots of movies with better effects. The makeup is solid, nothing extraordinary. The ending- well, I didn't like the ending too much. I really hope the prequel is better than this. I rate this film 6/10.

reviews.review_title: A Non-Intimate Version of the Original
reviews.content: 6 August 2001. This updated version reverts to the clash of warring parties and focuses more on ape authenticity, then the more intimate original version which focused more on the individual diversity and complex interaction between man and ape. The silent humans in the original version gave the movie a much more dramatic feel. The original ending was one of the best stunners in the league of "The Sixth Sense," and "The Crying Game." The original held much more of sci-fi instead of the usual us versus them wargames. The original was more thrilling, mysterious, and scary, ominously.

The movie begins as a classic sci-fi suspense flick, then turns to action, quickly followed by fantasy. It slips in some comedy, throws in a lame moralistic tale, provides a bit more action, and finally descends to farce. It was crying out for an emotional interlude by way of a romantic connection between the "hero", Mark Wahlberg and supermodel Estella Warren, but this was denied.I guess the movie must have been made by committee, because Tim Burton failed to develop any consistent threads. Instead we have a disjointed collection of Burton trademarks - dark austere sets, amazing visual detail, slightly warped humor, all competing with tired block-buster themes of choreographed fighting sequences, large explosions and poor scripts.
The best thing about the movie is the make-up and visuals. But even that is not enough to carry the mediocrity of it all. And the ending? - plain silly.

reviews.review_title: A high budget low budget film...Craptacular.
reviews.content: I haven't seen such a beautiful piece of crap since Armageddon. Being a big fan of the original POA film & TV series (& cartoons), I was looking forward to this film, though with some apprehension. I kind of enjoyed the parallels to the originals: "Get your stinking paws off me, you damn, dirty human!" My favorite was C. Heston: "Damn them...Damn them all to Hell!" and of course, he had a gun in his room.While watching this film, I had a problem with almost everything. From the gigantic halls of the space craft to the pathetic sound stage of Ape City. Don't you think that by the 22nd century, people who work with primates would figure out the difference between apes & monkeys? How many USAF captains would disobey a direct order from a 4-star general by flying out into danger? Probably half of the ape actors really walked correctly (as an ape's pelvis would allow). It sure was great that the spaceship worked after so many thousand years. Boy, they don't make 'em like that anymore. At least the apes bungee jumping around didn't look as pathetic as Crouching Tiger.I still can't tell if this was supposed to be a serious sci-fi drama or a spoof on the original. I guess I should have guessed what was in store when I saw in the opening credits "Based on A novel by Pierre Boule" and not "Based on THE novel by Pierre Boule."On the plus side, Helena Carter was excellent, the ape costumes were fantastic and the cinematography was very good. However, they didn't save the movie or the world. Avoid this film unless you are a hopeless Apes fan...like me.

This film is very mixed. There are some good ideas like the science fiction time travel element that sets it apart from the original. The action and makeup was decent. However, the acting was really over the top and you can't feel much for these characters.

This clunker sucked from the word go. The make-up was impressive, but that's about where the good points end. Although I haven't read all of the reviews here, I didn't see anyone mention how all of the actors SOUNDED like they had masks on. It was painfully obvious that their speech was being impeded by the prosthetic teeth that they had to wear, which I found to be ultra-annoying. I have liked about half of Tim Burtons movies but this one knocked him down a few notches in my mind. Do yourself a favor, avoid this crappy remake and watch the far superior original 1968 film. The Charlton Heston film is better in every way, except maybe in the special effects department, but the original holds its own from start to finish against This mess. Viewer beware!

reviews.review_title: A film that's as disastrous as it is completely useless.
reviews.content: You gotta hand it to Burton: when he makes a bad movie, he makes a BAD movie. I question whether they had any real idea of what made the originals so great. Gone are the unique philosophies, nuanced characters, solid comedy & entertaining old-school sci-fi thrills. In their place is the very worst of turn-of-the-century big budget bores: visual dullness, story ineptness, bland characters, tired performances, & a gluttony of embarrassing fan-service callbacks.

The movie begins like "Batman": visual mysterious credits on a great musical theme from Danny, who shows his versatility with loud, brutal drums that match well bestiality.Unfortunately, the quality degrades quickly: there's a big lack of original story as it's only running, hiding, battling. Worst, this world is built on the absurd idea of having the apes learning language as they can eat bananas. The interesting moments of comparing human to slaves, of discovering a world fit to apes are just outlined. The production is cheap, the image is blurry and the cast is a big disappointment: Wahlberg does his macho type as usual, Warren is totally transparent, Carter begins her boring relationship with Tim. Roth is the only character that makes efforts to act actually like a ape.The end is a good surprise but it's too little, too late and above all it shows an entire movie behind: as some wrote on the board, during the absurd fast return trip of Whalberg, we must understand that Thades uses the second time-pod to get back on earth before Walhberg. It sounds like a good sequel much better than this movie.

When Charlton Heston fell to the first planet of the apes, it offered something profound. It neatly and cleverly captured much of the social climate of the late 60s. Though not without its antecedents, it certainly has to stand as one of the more important social commentary films posing as sci-fi. Burton's remake, however, doesn't even seem to have a coherent story line. I first saw the Burton film upon its release and found it sorely lacking then. But I worried that my reaction might be too colored by my affection for the original. Remakes are frequently hated by fans of the original, and I didn't want to spout off with an unexamined emotional outburst. But I just sat through it again (this time on TV) and my loathing hasn't diminished. Wahlberg's performance still strikes me as wooden and lacking in purpose. From the very moment of his arrival to the ape world, his only objective is to escape from the planet. So why did he travel out to the planet in the first place? Heston's character of more than 30 years past at least went to explore (to see if there was anything better than man out there). Baker's ape makeup in the remake was good, but effects alone can't make a movie. The humans were no doubt the worst characters in the remake. Like Wahlberg they lacked any depth, and their passivity to ape domination produced more annoyance instead of sympathy. In the original the humans were primitive mutes whose mannerisms were bestial. They brought on pity one might feel for a hunted animal, which they were supposed to be. Another strikingly annoying element in the Burton film was the strange love triangle formed by Helena Bonham Carter as a chimp (albeit a very cute chimp), the collagen-lipped Estella Warren as a primitive human, and Wahlberg. I have no idea what Burton was going for there. While Burton's early films didn't wow me, they nonetheless didn't annoy me. My first impression was simply that he could churn out glitzy Hollywood pablum. Then he made Ed Wood and I suddenly wondered if I had overlooked a film genius. But the profound lack of substance in Apes convinces me that I was right the first time. (And Big Fish hasn't caused me to alter that view).

Lets start with that tim burton isnt right director for this kind of films and his directing and how he overall made a film didnt worked very well,this film however has a nice cast who did a good job considering with what they had to work with,only wahlberg even in his younger age wasnt so good actor and his deliveries wasnt able to competite to much better actors in film,action was in some moments solid but seconds after it become cheesy and poorly choreographed and without skills to direct a good fight sequance,this film is one of weakest of the franchise that only made a one great film

This movie is FANTASTIC. Everyone complaining that the movie is 'outdated' 'corny' etc.. are actually dumb. The movie is directed by TIM BURTON were you expecting 'The Expendables' with apes? This film is very reminiscent of other cult classic like 'The Dark Crystal' 'Labyrinth' etc. This movie is a wonderful exciting adventure that felt very nostalgic which is OBVIOUSLY what Burton set out to do.
Old heads will tell you this is a terrible remake, stoners will tell you that this is a fine piece of art.
8/10

I'm not entirely familiar with all of the other Planet of the Apes films, but I don't think there could be anything in any of them that would change my mind about the 2001 version. We start off with an electrical storm in space that results in some serious time travel, just like we saw in Lost In Space, which results in our hero winding up thousands of years in the future and on an unknown planet. Seconds after surviving the crash landing of his pod on this mysterious planet, Leo Davidson (Mark Walhberg) finds himself surrounded by fleeing HUMANS. The first thing I thought was that there are humans and apes on an unknown planet in an unknown galaxy roughly 5000 years in the future, but later we learn (also as seen in Lost In Space) that Leo's ship also passed through that time warp and landed in the same place, leaving the humans to go into submission to the out-of-control apes that were on the ship for experimentation, and the apes themselves were left to evolve and take control, ultimately turning into the hard-nosed apes that ruled the planet when Leo crash landed. That was a mouthful. Pretty creative though, once we are eventually informed as to what the hell is going on. So Leo is stuck on this planet where the roles are basically reversed and exaggerated between humans and apes, and now it is entirely up to Leo to save this planet's version of the human race from the oppression of the apes. Tim Roth delivers a horribly annoying performance as General Thade, the militant leader of the apes who is so filled with hatred for the humans (for reasons never made entirely clear) that he operates just like a machine. He's always grunting and growling and always has his head tilted downward like he's expecting physical confrontation at all times, and his constant guttural tone of voice makes him almost amusing after a while. One of the biggest problems with this movie is that the apes are so well made up, but they also have tremendous intelligence, as is made evident by their strikingly human eyes, and yet they switch back and forth from normal speech to the same screeching and screaming that you hear from the monkeys at the zoo. There is a scene where General Thade is told that the humans crossed the river using the apes' own horses, and he jumps all around the place, screeching and jumping and breaking things, and then he's back on the ground talking like a warrior. It's so hard to take this stuff seriously.Helena Bonham Carter is excellent as Ari, the weirdly attractive ape who is disgruntled with the way that the humans are treated by the apes, and who turns against her own kind to help the humans escape. There is a childish scene at the end of the film where Leo kisses Ari that is sure to get a laugh from any audience, while the stunningly but almost weirdly beautiful Estella Warren provides the human love interest. It's a good thing that they had a human woman in this movie to take romantic interest in Leo, because without her we only have Ari, who is 100% ape but who acts exactly like a human woman while interacting with Leo. For the first half of the film, I was a little nervous about the possibility of a little bestiality happening somewhere in there. So we know that Ari is helping the humans because she is disillusioned with her violent species, but they are also accompanied by another ape - Attar, I think (hey, half the fun was trying to figure out who was underneath all that make-up, right?) - and we never know why he agrees to go along, knowing that he will face severe punishment upon returning, which is one of the movies more simplistic but peeving oversights. It is, however, the ending of the film that ruins it beyond all hope for being saved.
At the beginning of the film, when Leo took off in the pod toward the electrical storm, he was going after the pod of his chimp, with whom all communication had been lost. He gets swept away in the same electrical storm as the chimp got caught in, and winds up on the planet described above. At the end of the film, the chimp comes through right in the middle of the climactic battle between the humans and the apes, and the apes bow down to him as their god. This was actually a pretty clever scene, because he was, in fact, one of the first apes of their civilization, and then Leo trades places with him, leaving him with Ari (and with an obviously broken leg, which we're left to assume turned out okay) and taking the ship back to his own time. And General Thade, I guess, was just left sulking under that console on the ship forever, doomed to live the rest of his life as a loose end in a sub-par sci fi movie. It was bad enough that everything on the ship still worked after thousands of years, now they have to leave stuff everywhere unexplained.So we get back to Earth, Leo survives the entrance through the atmosphere and then miraculously survives another violent crash landing without a scratch, and he finds the Lincoln Monument is an ape (when I saw Lincoln from behind, I jokingly said to myself that it would be an ape. I was disappointed and amused to find that I was right). This could, of course, mean only one thing. Seeing how there was barely an explanation for the English speaking humans and apes on the planet on which most of the film took place, and there was literally none at all given for the apes replacing the humans on Earth, we can only assume that they ran out of money or they are just setting up for a sequel. My money is on the latter. Stay tuned for part 9 (or so).

Yeah... pretty poor.I didn't even know this existed until a week or so ago. Gotta be frustrating for all involved that they were in a remake/reboot of 1968's 'Planet of the Apes' that wasn't the 2011 version. This one walked so that one could fly etc.Speaking of flying, what the heck is with the high jumping apes in this? It looks so silly and doesn't add anything; a very odd choice. It is, though, a surprise that this film flopped given who got attached to it. Tim Burton as director, with the acting talents of Mark Wahlberg, Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan and Paul Giamatti. It's neat that Charlton Heston and Linda Harrison (stars of the original) made cameos, though.Wahlberg feels a bit miscast, though Bonham Carter and Giamatti are solid; the latter particularly seemed to enjoy the role. The film does have a Burton edge to it, as expected, but this is one of his weaker films no doubt. Some other negatives, for me, include the make-up, esp. For General Thade, - I'm in the minority there - and the story's pacing.

reviews.review_title: I WANT MY TIM BURTON BACK!!!
reviews.content: The man who directed this soulless and totally unnecessary new version of Planet of the Apes cannot be the same man I have been adoring for the last 15 years. Where is the man who gave us wonderful and entirely unique movie experiences such as Edward Scissorhands, Nightmare Before Christmas and Sleepy Hollow? My theory is that he desperately wanted that his films make money again after the not-too-enthusiastically-received likes of Ed Wood and Mars Attacks, (how else can you explain his fruitless endeavour to resurrect the Superman franchise?) and after the relative success of Sleepy Hollow, he managed to gain access to Fox's resurrection of the Planet of the Apes franchise. However, I think that the studio interfered heavily with this "reimagining" of their beloved franchise and prevented him from making a usual Tim Burton film. The result is a terribly ordinary action adventure which is also an insult to the tradition of pessimistic sci-fi films that the original was so proudly part of. I cannot believe that my favourite director has his name stamped on this. I feel really deserted and I'm sure there are many Burton fans out there who feel the same way as I do. I WANT MY TIM BURTON BACK!!!

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the original
reviews.content: When the first good comment for a film is great make-up, then you know your in trouble. The Planet of the Apes remake is no where need as good as the original film. It was filmed by Tim Burton, but he really was just a gun-for-hire, a film that was not made with his usual Gothic style.Planet of the Apes is set in 2029, and focuses on Leo (Mark Walberg), a US air force pilot based on a space station. On the station the air force use apes to help do tasks and pilot small pods. A wormhole opens and one of the apes is sent to investigate. When it seems that the chimpanzee was in trouble Leo follows the apes through the wormhole. After going through it Leo crash-lands in a strange jungle and encounters humanized-apes. He is captured with other humans and sold to slavery. Leo is brought by a human-sympathiser, Ari (Helena Botham Carter), and with other humans escape from the city. This leads to them getting chased by the ape army, led by General Thade (Tim Roth).As I say, the make-up by Rick Baker was very good and truly Oscar-worthy. The special-effects were good, and there was some good action scenes. However the film was lackluster and really a by-the-numbers affair. There was a poor script with this film, and the story telling was nothing like the original film. There was nothing deep about this film and just shows apes as evil and humans as good. In the original film humans were neutral and all except Charlton Heston were mute whilst the apes were more of a mixed-bag. The original Planet of the Apes was seen at time as a satire, for example the backwards issue of not teaching the theory of evolution. In this film the idea of religion was decent, but could have been more. The remake was really just a chase movie. The acting for the apes was good and well casted. Helena Botham Carter is always good and Tim Roth loved playing the evil general. Michael Clarke Duncan was also decent in it. However, the human actors were not so well-developed and this film was not Walberg's finest hour. I also didn't like Paul Giamatti as an Oranga-tan slave trader, he was only in the film to add comic relief. The other major problem with this film was the ending. The original had a great ending which everyone should know. This film's ending was sub-par. I did not like how the battle ended and the aftermath of the battle (similar to my opinions to X-Men 3). Everyone has also criticised the plot-twist at the end.I admit, when I was younger I did enjoy the film from an action-adventure viewpoint; but even then I did not like the plot twist. However, this film does have it fans like Mark Kermode and Richard Roeper.One to miss in my opinion.

reviews.review_title: It took Tim Burton a long time to make up for this one.
reviews.content: I've been a Tim Burton fan since day one. I actually own "Frankenweenie", and I've watched it about ten times. Pee-Wee's Big Adventure. Edward Scissorhands. The Nightmare Before Christmas. I could go on and on. I love the guy. Then he made "Batman" and "Batman Returns". I winced, but I managed to get over it enough to enjoy "Ed Wood", "Mars Attacks", and "Sleepy Hollow". I had almost forgotten the pain I felt at realizing I paid good money to see Danny Devito drool for two hours.Then Tim Burton went and did it again. He turned out a ghastly piece of garbage, and gave it a sacred name--"Planet of the Apes".Where do I start? Timmy boy screwed everything up right from the start. The plot is too convoluted. The makeup is impressive, but it can't make up for bad writing. Then there's the plot holes. The apes have mastered the art of warfare but can't figure out how to get across a pond. The humans run around in what look like costumes from "Caveman", yet they speak modern American English. Mark Walhberg looks like he's trying to escape from the movie, not the planet. And the ending--WHAT THE &*$%# IS GOING ON??? Rod Serling is rolling over in his grave.Oh well. Maybe if I watch "Big Fish" a few dozens times I'll forget.

I saw WORSE movies than 'Planet Of The Apes' in 2001, but I didn't expect any of them to be good anyway. This movie however should have been something special, but turned out not only to be the biggest disappointment of the year, but one of the biggest of the last decade.Tim Burton has never made a movie this mediocre before! Even his most flawed movie (up til now) 'Mars Attacks!' was more interesting and entertaining than most of his contemporaries best efforts. Everything about this film is a mess. Not just the asinine script, but the direction is dull, the decent cast is wasted under the unimpressive make up, and the "surprise" ending a complete anti-climax.  Avoid this one, it's absolutely awful!

It's hard to talk about this movie without touching on its production history. This is a poster child for a studio using a recognizable name to hit a release date. They were going to release this in July of 2001 no matter what, and they rushed everything along. It's possible to deliver a good movie with a constantly changing script like The Great Escape, but it's more of a recipe for a mess. Tim Burton was not given any time to figure out his vision for the film, and he just filmed, at breakneck speed, a script that didn't know what it was or what it was about.Captain Leo Davidson is a pilot on a space station orbiting Saturn who's in charge of ape pilots. When an unusual electro-magnetic storm sweeps by, they send in an ape who promptly gets lost, and then Davidson jumps into a pod without orders to try and find him. He gets hit by stuff and crash lands in a forest on a new planet. Before he can settle, he's swept up in a chase of apes looking to round up humans. By the time Davidson is in a cage, being carted off to Ape City, a grand twenty minutes have passed in the film, and that's the greatest source of the movie's problems. It just simply moves too quickly, covering everything too shallowly, and more concerned with visual spectacle than actual storytelling.On the space station, we get introduced to two humans beyond Davidson, and neither of them matter once he's off the station. On the planet, we get views of about half a dozen humans who are going to tag along with Davidson through the end of the film and they never make any sort of impression. The apes do a better job, though. There's Thade, an ape general and the chief protagonist, and Ari, the human rights loving daughter of a senator. The thing is that this movie feels like their story, but they don't get introduced until the half hour point and they are very much not the focus. Davidson never gets any sort of emotional connection to anything on this planet, insisting on just getting off as soon as possible. So, our main character is a vessel obsessed with a single object and refuses any emotional attachments, while two of our supporting characters have the actual emotional support but are so far pushed into the background that every moment feels like it comes out of nowhere.Davidson escapes, brings along his human companions and Ari, picks up the slave trader, Limbo, who had bought the humans from the military (whose only purpose seems to be picking up humans in forests), and they walk into the Forbidden Area. Meanwhile, Thade visits his father in the one scene that probably exemplifies everything wrong with this movie in microcosm.So, Thade's father is played by Charlton Heston, proving that he's a great actor even under fantastic ape makeup. In this scene, we get introduced to a character who's never been seen before and gets discarded by the end, an object of great value we've never seen before and gets destroyed by the end in what's supposed to be a great dramatic moment, and callbacks to the original movie that end up falling flat. There's no setup to anything that happens in this scene. It all just happens in quick succession, and none of it impacts with any emotion. It's a dead scene that's supposed to be full of meaning and winks to the audience that end up working against it. Much like the rest of the movie.The thing about callbacks is that they are jokey by nature. It's hard to make a callback of something extremely well known work dramatically because we all have the, "I know that reference," reaction that undermines the dramatic import of the moment. So, when Attar looks down at Davidson and says, "Take your stinking hands off me, you damn dirty human," the audience is chuckling instead of feeling any kind of fear. When Charlton Heston says, "Damn them...damn them all to hell!" we have the same kind of guffaw instead of any other emotion at the death of a character, who we haven't seen before this very scene.I'm not sure when it became de rigueur for pretty much every action/adventure movie of a certain budget to end with a battle scene against two armies, but Planet of the Apes is one of the most ridiculous of them. An army showing up out of nowhere in the minutes before the battle, flying apes with super jump abilities, and the death of side characters with dramatic feel that fall flat is how this whole thing works out. It's bizarre and it betrays the fact that no one understood where the dramatic core of this movie was.There are no ideas at play in this film. It's just a bunch of people running around for two hours without ever giving the audience any time to think about any ideas or characters or even setting.I've avoided talking about the original because this re-imagining of the idea works so poorly on its own that there's really no need for comparison, but I do think that a comparison is justified in order to help explain why the 2001 version fails so badly. Just look at the first half hour of each of them. In the original, we get a very clear idea of who our main character, Taylor, is and what he believes. We get a steady build on the setting of this new world that comes to a shock at the sight of apes riding horses. In the re-imagining, we have a bevy of characters running around talking in inanities that don't matter, special effects, and then an action scene without ever getting to know anything about our main character, Davidson, other than that he loves his ape and wants to get it back. It's thin at its absolute best, and that's not very good.This was Tim Burton's lowest point, but because of studio pressure on the production timeline, it could be excused to a certain extent. However, he went on to make Alice in Wonderland, so we all know that he had further depths to explore. This is a prime example of how not to reboot a moribund franchise. But, the ape makeup is absolutely fantastic, the movie looks pretty good most of the time, and this might be my favorite Danny Elfman score. So, it has that going for it.

In 1968, the world's fascination with outer space was still largely in the science-fiction realm. Sure, we'd put some men in space, but no one had landed on any foreign worlds. We imagined, through the voices of such authors as Arthur C. Clarke and Isaac Asimov, interstellar travel and advanced civilizations. But all of that seemed to be part of the distant future in 1968.Here were are 33 years later, and while we haven't traveled to other galaxies or met any other civilizations (advanced or otherwise, Whitley Strieber's experiences notwithstanding), we have put a man on the moon and are hard at work on the international space station. In short, in 33 years we've come a long way, baby.Anyone who has seen the original 1968 Planet of the Apes knows that the ending is a real kicker. I certainly won't give it away here, because there's an entire generation that hasn't seen the movie and most certainly should. Suffice to say that the original is unique, not simply another sci-fi flick.The new one is termed a "rethinking" of the original. Tim Burton, who gave us Edward Scissorhands, Batman, PeeWee's Big Adventure, and Sleepy Hollow,is the director here, and the film is full of his stylish touch.Mark Wahlberg is Captain Leo Davidson, an astronaut in 2029 on a small space station that is conduction experiments on chimps. An electrical storm strikes, and a chimp is sent out to survey the cause. When the animal does not return, Davidson launches himself - against his commander's orders - to find him. Next thing he knows, his space pod is crash landing on an unknown planet inhabited by talking, aggressive apes - with humans as slaves.Davidson is captured by the apes along with other humans, but escapes. His plan - get back to where his pod crashed, find his GPS-like device that will allow him to locate his mother ship, and get back home. But it's a long way back to the pod, and he suddenly has thousands of apes after him.Luckily, he has on his side Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), a kindhearted ape who feels empathy toward the humans. Ari, of course, symbolizes animal lovers on Earth; she cannot understand why her fellow apes treat their humans so badly. "We can learn much from them," she claims, but her claims fall on deaf ears. Davidson, with the help of Ari, leads a small band of refugee humans (including the Daena, played by the delicious Estelle Warren) to his pod, where he makes some startling discoveries, none of which will be revealed here. (If you've seen the original and know the surprise ending, the discoveries Davidson makes are as intriguing as that ending.)Hot on the trail of the astronaut and his friends is the evil General Thade (Tim Roth) and his fiercest warrior Colonel Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan). The makeup jobs on all of the apes are astounding, and the actors are completely unrecognizable under their disguises. The general has been told by his ailing father (an uncredited Charlton Heston, who starred in the 1968 original) that humans, in the time before time, humans brought violence to their planet; now that apes dominate, humans must be destroyed.
As with the original, this is a fascinating treatise not only on how we treat  other animals but on how we treat ourselves. Is it truly accurate to say that humans are civilized and the apes are the savages? The film actually makes you think about such things, but it's no philosophical hodge-podge of mumbo-jumbo. It's a exciting, powerful movie, worth watching on just about every level.

reviews.review_title: OMG!!!! What a load of crap!
reviews.content: I am 54 years old. I watched Planet of the Apes when it was in the theaters. The original of course. I was 10 the first time I saw it. I watched it a number of times in my life and it always was fascinating to me.This....I just don't know how to describe it. It has nothing to do with the original story. This Tim what's his name seems to think that because he directed a few notable films (never liked him by the way) that he has the right to basically.... well, rewrite the Bible! The film has no plot, no character development, no direction. It's just a simple fill in the screen for two hours of monkey business. NONSENSE! My apologies to this current generation. Please do not rate the Planet of the Apes story on this (cough, cough) film. As backwards as it might seem, watch the originals. Yea, I know that films that old may not appeal to this age of film making, but watch it as a history lesson in film then. You will not be disappointed.I will, however, say that The Rise of the Planet of the Apes film is a great movie. I hope one day that a REAL director will produce a faithful rendition extrapolating from this film. One can only hope.Please, please, please, please. DO NOT WATCH THIS FILM FOR YOUR OWN SAKE.

Hey there chimp! I mean chump! Yes you! You are the ones who went bananas when you heard that the famous classic neanderthal film `Planet of the Apes' was being remade by noveau director Tim Burton. However, after you saw its `mongoloid' ending- you probably went apes and wanted your money back. What planet are you from anyways? Don't worry! I `peel' your pain! The same thing happened to me. However, I was fascinated by the incredible `mono' a `mono' makeup created by the great Rick Baker. I was also `going ape' by the realistic set design. The story was not too bad either; that was until Burton `cheetah' us all with a horrific ending. *** Average

reviews.review_title: Lots of style, little less substance...
reviews.content: The original Planet of the Apes (1968) will always be a landmark in the sci-fi genre (more specifically, the apocalyptic sub-genre). It's an excellent movie, which didn't need a remake, if not to make it more appealing to a new generation of film-lovers. Tim Burton's "reimagining" of the movie was interesting on paper, no doubt about that, but it's also the most disappointing film he's done so far.Burton already did sci-fi in 1996, directing the hilarious Mars Attacks!. Now, that movie may have looked like his most un-Burton-like project, but it worked, thanks to the witty script, which perfectly reflected the director's freaky sense of humor, and the terrific cast (Nicholson, DeVito, Natalie Portman, Pierce Brosnan et al). Planet of the Apes, on the other hand, contains the quintessential burtonian theme (outcasts feared by other people), and it's really, really dark compared to the original, but its strength is all in the style: from Rick Baker's utterly realistic make-up to Danny Elfman's "simian" score, the movie is perfect, technically speaking. It's the storytelling and acting that aren't always as good as expected.The screenplay, while repeating the same basic idea - human astronaut ends up on another world where intelligent apes have enslaved mankind -, is supposedly more faithful to Pierre Boulle's novel, especially the ending (I won't spoil it, but it's far less shocking than what Charlton Heston saw back in 1968), although it suffers from one detail: much of the original version's charm had to do, among other things, with the fact that humans didn't talk on the Planet, making Heston's presence more intriguing. In Burton's movie, they can talk, which leads to an obvious question: why did no none try to have a reasonable conversation with the apes? Sure, that would have killed the movie right away, but it just feels pointless to introduce this new aspect and not develop it.The other weak element is the acting, particularly the "humans": Mark Wahlberg has none of the charisma he had in Boogie Nights, and his co-stars (Kris Kristofferson, Estella Warren) don't impress that much either. It's the monkeys that deserve our attention, most notably Helena Bonham Carter as the human-loving scientist and Tim Roth as evil general Thade (a treat for fans: Charlton Heston plays Roth's daddy). They bring intensity to their characters and Carter in particular succeeds in bringing new life to one of the most loved primates from Franklin J. Schaffner's classic.Overall not a very bad film, but we expected more from the man who gave us the "new" versions of Batman and Ichabod Crane. Too much studio interference, perhaps?

I feel like I'm destroying any credibility when I say this but, despite all the negativity around this, I don't think this is awful. Let me clarify, it's not good, it's just not terrible.For starters, and really the strongest point of the movie, the apes look amazing. The acting isn't awful, and I'm not generally a Wahlberg fan. Then there's the story and all that which are mediocre at best.The problem here is that this movie has to do the Burton thing and go to the weird and bad places whenever given the chance. Put someone, anyone but Burton here and I legitimately believe this is a vastly improved movie.As it stands, this is background noise. The less you pay attention, the better. You can enjoy some great costumes and makeup, some fascinating sets and when you don't focus on it, you don't have to deal with all the crazy.

reviews.review_title: A planet where screenplays are written by apes?!
reviews.content: Tim Burton is not a director. He is one of Hollywood's top production designers, but he is not a director. His direction is all style, and no substance."Planet of the Apes" is too self-consciously jokey, and has a mean-spirited quality that is becoming too common in Burton's films. He seems to resent his own audience.The film is worth seeing because of the ape makeup, and the performance of Helena Bonham Carter, but it is, overall, one of the biggest disappointments of a weak summer.

reviews.review_title: Too dark and too many unanswered quetions
reviews.content: Tim Burton rally can pick them can't he? Having already had to take one of the most popular comic book characters to the big screen in Batman, he then had to recreate the legend of Sleepy Hollow, before turning his eye to one of cinema's all-time classics in Planet of the Apes.Mark Wahlberg was cast in the role of main human (likened to Charlton Heston's in the original) whereas Britain's Helena Bonham-Carter was given a chance to rip up the bodices and put on the make up to become an ape along with Tim Roth and Michael Clarke-Duncan.After being dragged through a wormhole in the middle of an electrical storm, Captain Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) crash lands on a remote planet where humans are the slaves and apes rule. A sympathetic primate named Ari (Bonham-Carter) is against the suffering inflicted on humans by apes however and helps Leo along with the other human slaves escape. Eager not to let their capture get away, the ape army led by Thade (Tim Roth) and Colonel Attar (Clarke-Duncan) give pursuit as Leo frantically heads back to his ship.With so much to live up to in following the original, Tim Burton was always going to struggle to win over fans of the first. His work is as usual, dark and mysterious with most of the action taking place at night. Although adding to the planet's mystique, Burton's style does also often make it difficult to actually figure out what's going on. His re-worked ending is intriguing yet leaves many questions unanswered, with few of the plot lines coming together to complete the picture; this despite the fact that barely an hour of story has been stretched out to fill nearly two.The scenes of violence toward the end are well choreographed, but are also disturbing with all-too-lifelike apes and humans literally beating the life out of each other. It's partly from this though where the one saving grace liesThe quality of the make up work is excellent as Tim Roth, Michael Clarke-Duncan and Helena Bonham-Carter, amongst others, are transformed into perfect ape-creatures. As was shown with Godzilla however, special effects are nothing compared to solid story and the writers fail to offer anything new that can match let alone eclipse the original.Planet of the Apes 2001 is by no means a bad film, but with so much to hype and expectation to live up to it was always going to fall short. It's worth seeing for the make up jobs alone, but if you a real treat then rent the original.3/10

Went to see this last week, and decided before going not to compare it to the old classic. I have to say the make-up effects were pretty good.-Except Helena who really does look like Michael Jackson. I have to say the feeling of physically powerful apes came over very well. Acting was so-so. But I really missed a good battle scene. I thought the included scene was pretty short and pathetic. And then, like a lot before me have said...The ending....What ??? How ??? Huh ????

"Planet of the Apes" was a surprisingly conventional, if entertaining, sci fi movie, complete with references to the "Star Wars" and "Star Trek" movies, as I expected more imagination from director Tim Burton. Mark Wahlberg was also surprisingly bland, as I'd liked him in other dramas and I was about the only female in the audience so I guess he's not that much of a chick draw, though I go to about all sci fi movies anyway.I'm a big fan of Tim Roth but would absolutely never have been able to tell that he was the chief bad guy general without seeing his name in the credits. The ape actors could have been doing voice-overs for animatronics for all the make-up let them emote, which I hadn't felt in the original movie, and Roth's voice really got into the role (he'd turned down the Snapes role in the Harry Potter movie for this?).But sound was the best part of the movie, and it was really loud. Danny Elfman's score was so good, sounding like those Japanese drums a lot of the time, that I paid more attention to the music than to the special effects.(originally written 8/21/2001)

reviews.review_title: Call it a letdown, worsened by the forces of shoddy screenwriting.
reviews.content: Burton's singular vision is missing from this mishmash of a remake, part sci-fi, part adventure, part ape-human romance, but unsatisfying on any level. Mark Wahlberg's pallid turn doesn't help and neither does the PG-13 rating which proves confining

reviews.review_title: Nice planet, wonderful apes, threadbare film
reviews.content: Full marks for the art direction, and I'd like to give even more for costumes and make-up.  I find it hard to believe that this film, dreadful though it was overall, wasn't nominated for an Oscar in any of these categories, especially given some of the lacklustre work that WAS nominated, like "Amélie"? and "The Fellowship of the Ring".  And it's not as if any of the other art direction nominees are particularly dazzling, either.  But "Planet of the Apes" IS dazzling.  The world has its own intriguing version of everything, from tents to buckles to embossed armour designs, and the ape suits are so invisibly convincing we forget that there are human actors underneath even when we have a live chimpanzee as a point of comparison.Tim Burton began life as an animator and the best film he's had anything to do with ("The Nightmare Before Christmas") owes almost everything to his fantastic designs.  But, as is becoming increasingly clear, he rose to hislevel of incompetence when he became a director.  "Planet of the Apes" is superb visually, but in no other way.  And even to say that it's superb visually is misleading.  The climactic battle scene is wrong in almost every way it's possible for a climactic battle scene to be wrong: it's all confusing close-ups of characters whumping one another, with no overall design, or end, in sight - until the deus ex machina that we'd all seen coming an hour ago descends to bring the tedious violence to a merciful end.Burton clearly WANTS to be able to spin a gripping yarn.  Why else does he tell this particular story?  But he can't draw us close to any of the characters, he can't tell the difference between mushy cliché and invigorating simplicity (the "inspiring" dialogue manages to be banal without making any sense), and he can't take three paces without tripping over his own irony.  Irony?  More like flippancy.  Comments like "You can't solve the human problem by throwing money at it - we tried that, and all we got was a welfare state that nearly crippled us" are the work of screenwriters who live in terror of being caught out being sincere about something, who want to cover their tracks by suggesting that, not only don't they mean what they're saying, they don't mean anything.Anyone who doubts that Burton's film is flippant through and through will have their doubts dispelled by ending.  The original film is famous for the twist at the end - so famous, in fact, that that particular twist cannot be used again.  A pity, for it was a good one.  It made sense - more importantly, it made sense OF the earlier parts of the film - and it had a good deal of poetic force.  Burton decided to ditch poetic force and all that jazz in order to preserve the least essential aspect of the twist in the original - its shock value.  His ending is shocking, all right.  It makes no sense.  It's easy to shock if you're prepared to break off the narrative in mid-sentence and start talking nonsense.Mark Wahlberg is as unappealing as he ever has been, and it can't all be the script's fault.  He goes through the whole film without once dropping the belligerent expression of an ex-rapper who wants to maintain his "cred". And Estella Warren looks like one of those almost supernaturally unappealing models who grace the pages of the latest generation of men's magazines (Maxim, FHM, etc.), with computer-generated skin and computer-animated anatomy, dressed up as a cavegirl - not for the film, but for a photoshoot.P.S.:  What the hell did Burton mean when he said that this wasn't a remake, but a "re-imagining"?  What's the distinction?  I thought remakes WERE re-imaginings.

Yup, with all the resources available in Hollywood (not to mention the technical advances over 3 decades), Tim Burton has managed to film the 5th best film in the 6 film PLANET OF THE APES saga. Well, actually, I'd say it's a 5th place tie with the ignominious closer to the original series BATTLE FOR THE PLANET OF THE APES. Advertised as a 're-imagining', it's much closer to 'rip-off' of the original. The thievery even begins with hack composer Danny Elfman's outright mimicking of Jerry Goldsmith's groundbreaking original score. What else has been 're-imagined'? Campy "ape" comedy? - been done. Twist on man/ape evolution? - been there. Use of an American monument for the 'shock' ending? - done that. Call me a heretic, but I was disappointed by Rick Baker's makeup. Not the makeup per se (they are to his usual excellent standard), but the design. Why do all the female apes look like simian version of LaToya and Janet Jackson? Sorry, I believe John Chambers' designs were superior 30 years ago. And, the ending(s)? Well, the main plot "twist" I predicted sight unseen over 6 months ago (Burton kept insisting that it would be "different" from the original, yet have a twist. So, the film's main evolutionary twist was easily forseen). The "double twist" at the end is both meaningless and far-fetched. I don't wanna be a spoiler like that #$#$! idiot Matt Drudge, so all I'll say is that the "shocker" ending is meaningless because it doesn't evolve logically by the events in the film (as the original's did) - it's just a twist for "a twist's" sake. Burton felt obligated to "top" the original, so he "had" to tag one on. Logically, it's far-fetched because for the ending to make sense, EVERYTHING in this new Evolutionary construct would have had to occur in EXACTLY the same way as modern Earth evolution to have THAT "monumental" ending. A disappointment all around

I liked this, though it's NOT better than the first, it certainly has it's good points. They are:*Great makeup. Rick Baker is tops.*Decent acting-though Roth is overkill, I liked Carter, 'Bear' from Armageddon, Bart Giamatti's kid and even MarkyMark. He has a decent Mr Bland everyman about him that kinda works. *F/X are good.*Sets range from impressive(try to tell which desert scenes were shot in Arizona, then Australia, Utah, etc), to YUCK(some of the interiors were right outta the Flintstones) to OK(the ship).*The 'Twilight Zone' ending doesn't make sense unless you keep it in a Twilight Zonish other world. Otherwise it's goofygloo time.*I liked the chimp.*Battle scenes meant to be impressive were a Little ludicrous at times-oh no another wave of Big Monkeys is chimping over the rise at me! But I liked it anyways.*Burton I usually dislike but here, as in 'Sleepy Hollow', he pretty much played it straight and delivers another mainstream hit. Good deal.**1/2 outta ****, a few things to jump up and down about. Don't go ape but do see it.

This was an awesome movie and I don't care what anybody say, it wasn't a perfect movie but it was very entertaining and kept your attention the whole way and this was the movie that showed me how good of an Actor Mark Wahlberg is, he was great in this movie.

It is the year 2029: Astronaut Leo Davidson boards a pod cruiser on a Space Station for a "routine" reconnaissance mission. But an abrupt detour through a space time wormhole lands him on a strange planet where talking apes rule over the human race. With the help of a sympathetic chimpanzee activist named Ari and a small band of human rebels, Leo leads the effort to evade the advancing Gorilla Army led by General Thade and his most trusted warrior Attar. Now the race is on to reach a sacred temple within the planet's Forbidden Zone to discover the shocking secrets of mankind's past - and the key to its future.I was really looking forward to this film and finally, I've seen it. It was a good movie, but the ending ruined it. Let's start at the beginning. The score was appropriately themed with the movie. It was wonderfully cast by great actors and actresses. The action and story was good.Well, what's wrong with the ending? It's one of the most pathetic excuses to leave open a sequel (AKA: The cliffhanger). Ugh, if only that would be different, I would recommend this good picture. The one liners were cheesy but I didn't mind it. The makeup effects were excellent (you couldn't tell which actors/actresses were which). Some CGI shots were also pretty good.I like Tim Burton's look on the whole world is great. The plot was surprisingly complicated (not like a mind puzzle, though). Mark Whelberg plays one handsome protagonist. Tim Roth plays a surprisingly creepy and angry antagonist and Helena Bonham Carter's performance was really sympathetic. And last but not least, Paul Giamatti gives a great comedic role.I'll say it again: The ending ruined the film. I hated it. Still, if you want to watch an entertaining movie with some great action and story, go ahead and watch it but be aware of the ending.

Some people may call Tim Burton Judas for his reinvention of the 1968 classic "Planet of the Apes",but before you cast the first stone pay in mind that Burton is worshipping the film here, not exploiting it.And it shows. This is a overstatement of the original that in my honest opinion did not have to be remade. The special effects here are brilliant,but in all you have to give Mark Wahlberg his props and so that he can prove that can he,well can be in a movie with action and great special effects. You may laugh at that last sentence,but I don't see an Oscar on Charlton Heston's wall for the original(since he has already have several from his Oscar-winning Ben Hur). Tim Roth,Kris Kristofferson, Estella Warren,and a shocking performance by Micheal Clarke-Duncan as the General and cameos by Heston,Linda Harrison(who played Nova in the original),Kim Hunter and George Clooney are added bonuses in this one. A Must See!

Like many others, I rather admire Tim Burton's artistic spin-outs, although for every BATMAN there is a MARS ATTACKS, and for every EDWARD SCISSORHANDS a  SLEEPY HOLLOW. He had NO RIGHT however messing with PLANET OF THE APES, a great film that was majorly under-valued critically (NOT at the box-office) even on its release in 1968. "Are things so bad that BEN-HUR has to start mixing it with Gorillas?" proclaimed one dumb-ass reviewer! Wonder what he would have written about this?Well guys for whats its worth, here's my assessment! In a word, INSULTING to the original! (and to anyone in the audience of moderate intelligence.) Obviously  geared towards two distinctly identifiable social groups: those who have never seen the original series and today's (for the most part) attention-deficient audiences, who just want some one-dimensional entertainment to accompany their popcorn (or ecstasy tablet). Burton is selling himself short here - he is worth more than that.
PLANET OF THE APES (2001) is not categorically a turkey, the special effects are excellent, although the incessant use of digitizing becomes wearisome eventually. What IS wrong with it is loopy Wahlberg as an intergalactic Captain....I mean could you take this guy seriously? Would YOU rather fly to Alpha Centauri with Chuck Heston at the controls or under the direction of some guy who flashes his "jewels" while boogeying?  Aimed at a "youthful," marketable audience, sure he's your man, but in the interests of credibility, Wahlberg is a 10-1 longshot! The film suffers from ludicrously unstable continuity with a script to match - it is sheerly a visual extravaganza. Obviously in an attempt to play down the social and paradoxical issues of the original (coz you might have to actually THINK!) Burton has gone for noise and movement.The marvellous ending of the 1968 film (probably only ever equalled in power by THE USUAL SUSPECTS) is replaced by an obviously tacked-on "lets not worry how to explain this - anything to leave us a sequel" finale.  In the upshot, not the embarrassment Gus Van Sant's PSYCHO was, but totally unnecessary and totally unsatisfying!

reviews.review_title: Triumph! Why I believe 'Planet of the Re-Makes' IS better than the original 'Planet of the Fakes'... !
reviews.content: (Original: 3/10. Remake: 7/10.)Firstly, let me warn readers that this will be more of a rant than an even-minded critique; so if balance and objectivity are what you're searching for, you'd be better served by seeking out a positive review of the '68 version... I'm in the mood to make possibly unfair comparisons, and I'll make no attempt to hide that - so if you don't find yourself disgusted with me at this point, then read on...* I watched the original last night; Heston put a black mark on the film for me straight away. He has the sense of authority and presence only of a poor man's Clint Eastwood; and he looks like he would be better suited to working in Infomercials, with his manner of gazing earnestly into the camera and intoning gravely. OK, to be fair; Wahlberg is no better here, but it makes for a more believable crew and surroundings if the 'leading man' has gone AWOL and you don't have someone who carries his reputation before him constantly looking to unduly milk significance from the script. Wahlberg makes a better Everyman, so you see him more 'in character' than when you watch Heston, who typifies a Hollywood landmark.* You don't think of Kubrick and his Odyssey, when you watch this update. The sinister overlords are revealed much more stealthily. Unfortunately, Stanley cornered the market for 'primate roaming barren landscape' imagery just a few months after Schaffner's work opened, and there's no doubt which is the more memorable image in these modern years. Such is life. Burton doesn't even try to approach from such an angle, and it works. I suppose that's one reason I can get aboard the 're-imagination' train, because at least we get a newer look...* There's less 'blithe imperialism' tossed about in our politically correct days. "Give it a few weeks and you could own this place", someone mentions to Heston on our first trip. OK, now I as the audience think you DESERVE to be subjugated for your arrogance! All our modern young explorers want to do is repair their mistakes, though; so yep, they're the winners of my sympathy vote. Chalk up another 'moral victory'...* A bigger budget and more 'experimental' supporting cast may mean we get better makeup; but what's much more crucial is the improved interpretation of speech. No more do we have to put up with creatures who intimidate and horrify us with their appearance, but nevertheless all have voices that remind us uncannily of the nearest fishmonger from down the high street. Happily, this time our villains manage to sound unfamiliar and scary, to boot!* The forefather possibly started a flagellation fetish for those would be conquerors of brave new frontiers, further exploited by "A Man Called Horse", amongst others... Luckily, Burton opted for uneasy laughs instead; hanging our human friends in cages as an in-joke. It would thankfully be another few years before "The Passion of The Christ" caused some squirming in seats and revived masochism as the cinematic trend of the age...If you ask me; it looks like the passage of time does favours for ALL civilisations... !

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton does 'oddballs in outfits' better than most, not this time
reviews.content: Believe it or not this tale of a time-traveling astronaut faced with a civilisation ruled by super-evolved apes in an alternate universe is director Tim Burton's most straightforward film yet.Leo Davidson's (Mark Wahlberg) love for his monkey impels him to pursue it through a space anomaly that propels him forward thousands of years. Leo finds himself on a new planet inhabited by various types of monkeys, all highly evolved and English speaking, which is a plus But they aren't alone on the planet. The jungles and remote areas around the monkey settlements are rife with humans, some more opinionated monkeys say 'infested'. Almost immediately upon landing on this new planet Leo is captured and bundled in with various other newly nabbed humans to be taken to Monktropolis (not really but it should've been) to be onsold to others.This is where Leo learns of the basic role reversal that this particular 'planet of the apes' experiences. The undisputed rulers of the land are all hairy and like bananas. Depending on their background or upbringing they all deem the humans as potential equals (best case scenario), slaves and house help (middling) or vermin to be exterminated (worst case).The obvious parallels between the current human / animal relationship is constantly and often clumsily highlighted, leading to 127 too many 'tee-hee, they're just like us' moments.After introducing the few main monkey characters including ruthless army leader Colonel Thade (Tim Roth), a slave trading orang-utan played by Paul Giamatti and his human friendly daughter Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), Davidson and a few humans escape from captivity and with Ari in tow head to the badlands, hoping to find answers to questions that needn't be asked.The last hour or so in this uneven two hour monkey-fest descends into a straight up actioner, and not necessarily a good one, the 'twist' ending straight up sucks and is likely the reason that a sequel wasn't even considered, and Burton shows that as a story-teller he does great visuals. Speaking of visuals, the sets are all immaculate and lush, the monkey makeup is for the most part excellent – especially Tim Roth – and the costumes are all well made, the CGI was wisely limited given the limitations of the time and doesn't stand out too much for the wrong reasons.But all the above merely makes Planet of the Apes an immaculately presented, well acted confusing and frustrating effort. After taking so long to ensure that Thade is the bad guy he is never called upon to do much with all his pent up rage and evil, and just why a monkey driven civilisation is such a bad thing is never addressed.After all, lying around scratching yourself and eating is hardly the worst way to go is it? Final Rating – 6.5 / 10. A couple of decent scenes and some creative visuals can't overcome a bland and often lost plot. Tim Burton does 'oddballs in outfits' better than most, not this time

reviews.review_title: It would of been great if it weren't for the ending! [spoilers]
reviews.content: Until the surprise ending [if you've seen the movie, you know what I'm talking about] I was enjoying this movie. I found it to be almost as good as the 1968 original. Before I saw the movie, I read the book. I loved the book. It's my favorite book. Then I saw the 1968 original. I enjoyed the original so when this one opened, I rushed to see it. As I said before, I was enjoying it. Just as I was that this was the best movie ever, the ending comes. Now I heard that ending was messed up, but I didn't know it would be impossible to figure out. Ever since I saw this movie, I have been trying to figure out the ending. I still can't figure it out. It was the worst ending to a movie I've ever seen. Couldn't Tim Burton have done a different ending? I mean this ending didn't even make sense. Hopefully, the video or DVD of this will have something that explains the ending a little bit better [like the secrets and clues after THE SIXTH SENSE video]. It would have been a great movie it weren't for that ending. Now it's just a good movie. Mark Wahlberg does a good job as Leo Davidson and the special effects are amazing. The movie was a bit long though and I wish Estella Warren had some more dialogue because she didn't seem to have a whole lot to say in the movie. Warning: This version is a lot more dark and violent than the 1968 original. Parents with young children might want to show them the 1968 version instead.

I think first of all, one can easily separate the two POTA movies, as both, while sharing some elements, have VERY different stories. Mark Wahlberg stars as an soldier who is based on a space station which is experimenting with using chimp controlled spaceships. When one chimp is lost in a spacepod during an exploration of a magnetic space field, Wahlberg takes off (unauthorized) to find it. When the pod enters the field, Wahlberg loses control as well, soon he crash lands in a jungle. And he is VERY quickly introduced to the dominant species on the planet ;) The story which follows is very tightly directed by Burton, and is very well acted by Wahlberg. Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are (as usual) excellent and don't let the make up (which is designed by the always outstanding Rick Baker) get in the way of the performances. Finally, as usual, a GREAT score by Danny Elfman.

reviews.review_title: Every director has his weakest movies....
reviews.content: and Tim Burton is no exception. Even the greatest of the filmmakers in the world occasionally will make a movie which is just way too flawed to be classified as a good movie. And that's how I feel about Tim Burton's remake of the classic "Planet of the Apes". Maybe it's just one of those movies that shouldn't be remade, or maybe Burton just didn't want to make the movie, or something like that. But whatever the case, it wasn't a very pleasing movie.First off, it's just plain boring. The storyline is worked pretty weakly and much of the acting is terrible. True, the apes were portrayed pretty good and the film did have its moments. But still, about sixty or seventy percent of this movie was just dull and full of unnecessary parts and characters.At first, I refused to believe this was a Tim Burton movie, but then again, like I stated earlier, even the greatest of the great in any business make their mistakes here and there.

Planet Of the Apes with Burton's vision was a good movie. It had action, memorable one liners, good pacing and a great twist ending. The movie didn't get the credit it deserves but it was really good, or at least I liked it I can't wait for the DVD.

reviews.review_title: Excellent masks, but a major disappointment
reviews.content: I entered the theater enthusiastically after waiting to see this film for a long time. And after 60 minutes I was equally enthusiastic to see the end credits and to be able to walk away from the theater.The ape masks were excellent, and the music was quite ok, though a bit ordinary to my taste, but I think that nothing else delivered. I continuously had the feeling the Burton had wanted to say something, but he was in so much haste, that before he was able to say the punch line the next scene had already started.Since this was a fantasy flick I did my best to out any reality checks away, but I still think that extremely beautiful make-up should not be expected from a lady living in wilderness.

Maybe I don't enjoy this film more than I would enjoy the original Planet Of The Apes films, or even the television series, but Tim Burton's recreation of them has gotten a pretty raw deal, all the same. People scream that the makeup effects weren't well done. Well, what do you expect from an attempt to synthesise human faces with ape bodies? I felt they were done just the right way... such that they looked like apes but the actors were still recognisable.Tim Burton's deft touch in the set design and photography lends his usual dark edge to the film, making it far more grown-up in appearance than the pastel-like sequels to the original Planet Of The Apes, especially the television series. Everything looks a lot more believeable, and the sets appear much more functional. The Omeron looks much more like a deep-space research station, and the flight pods look more like they were designed for their purpose.Mark Wahlberg is good as a caring human being, and I really believed in his compassion for the monkey, but he doesn't quite possess that leader quality. I think it would have been better if he'd been supported by one or two more humans from the space station. The ending, such as it is, had me a little perplexed too.
