Here is a man standing on the verge of a brave new world where men and other members of the animal kingdom can be educated to work together in harmony, he has a beautiful woman who wants him, and he decides to go home. Sorry, I just couldn't buy that, but then, it's pretty plain to me that the Earth of 2001 just sucks.Still, with all the barbs about inter-species arrogance, reverse racism, and the origins of cults, Planet Of The Apes is one film that should be given a fairer hearing. Maybe the critics of today just need to put down their Bibles, their filmmaking guides, and their prejudices towards old, outmoded special effects, and just lighten the hell up.

...that is, take an old "classic" and make it more faithful to the source material. From the same man, we've had a Batman who acts more like a real millionaire whose parents were murdered in front of him as a boy would, and a Sleepy Hollow that reads more like a Shakespeare play, highlighting as Washington Irving's original story does how badly this overrated poet's dialogues fail to reflect real human speech. In this new version of Planet Of The Apes, we get to see an air force pilot who behaves like an air force pilot, an ape civilisation that behaves like an ape civilisation, and a metaphor for the civil rights struggle that reads more like the X-Men feature film than the restrained, "don't want to upset the powers that be" style of the television series.I've read on this site that the film is simply rehashed in order to suit those with short attention spans. Not true. All through the film, one thinks of how a simple collection of apes from a research station could have evolved into almost-bipedial, talking ones with more distinctive personalities. The next few sentences may spoil any surprises, so those of you who have not seen the film yet can scroll past them at your leisure. One aspect of the film I found a bit disappointing is the fact that the original talking ape who is referred to as CMOS by his descendants is never fully explained. His origins and the reason he is called that are never really talked about, and I originally thought he would be the monkey that Wahlberg's character shot off into space in order to rescue. I must admit, however, that ending the battle between the humans and the apes by having said monkey land right in the middle of them was a fine touch. The metaphor for religion by showing that CMOS, this figure the apes worship for being the original free ape, got to start his own civilisation by murdering the humans who were originally caring for him, was an ingenious stroke. My only real complaint relates to the ending. I won't spoil it for those who haven't seen it yet, unlike some internet sites, but were I in this pilot's position, I honestly would have stayed. It's not every day that one gets a chance to help build a new civilisation with two very different races are just learning to work with each other. Compared to the planet Earth as it is today, and it shows no signs of ever getting better, it is a real paradise.Given all the displays in the film of appalling behaviour towards humans and each other by the apes, and how they resolve themselves, I think Tim Burton's reinterpretation manages to drive home a point that I seriously doubt the original films and television series would have been allowed to. The fact that not all racism is white-on-black seems a taboo subject in 2001, but one that this film handles metaphorically in an intelligent way. Give it a try without the prejudice of original Apes series fans to blinker you, and it may just surprise you. Encourage yourself to think of a better ending, though. Encourage yourself to think of all the different ways the apes could have evolved, in fact. This is not Planet Of The Apes Lite... it is Planet Of The Apes non-Disney style, something we need applied to more old "family-oriented" piles of cobblers.

reviews.review_title: Haven't seen the original, but this is one cool movie
reviews.content: Not haven't seen the original "Planet of the Apes," I've never been part of the fan club.  I wasn't heavily anticipating this remake, like about ninety-percent of the viewing public.  In fact, I predicted it would suck. For some reason, I'm not a sucker for all these big-budget Hollywood summer blockbusters.  I thought I'd feel the same way about this movie as I did with that borefest "The Mummy Returns."  Even action movies can put me to sleep, if flashy special f/x is the only fuel to keep them going.  But as it turns out fifty-percent of the time, the movies I least anticipate are the ones I end up liking quite a bit.  First of all, it's directed by Tim Burton.  I've always been fond of his work (minus "Mars Attacks").  Just like most of his movies, he creates a creepy atmosphere that deeply engages you--sometimes on a conscious level, sometimes on a subconscious level.  And also like most of his movies, he adds a nice touch of humor.  Some of the humor's pretty silly and obvious and some it's pretty subtle.  Whatever route he took, it often worked.  The ape costumes are amazingly realistic and the set designs are very impressive.  Also we have the great Danny Elfman who composed a great score to help intensify the creepy atmosphere.The premise is quite nifty.  A planet run by apes, where the apes rule and the humans are enslaved and put to work and even treated as pets.  That I found very interesting.  The premise is handled nicely, and it was amusing--sometimes hilarious--to see apes take on a human persona.  Playing card games, running shops, etc.In the comic relief department, we have Paul Giamatti who takes on the bumbling henchman role.  Just like his enormously impressive debut as Pig Vomit in Howard Stern's "Private Parts" he is absolutely hilarious.  Now, my mother saw this movie before me, so she pointed out that Charlton Heston had a cameo appearance.  Watching the film and seeing his name absent in the closing credits, I wasn't sure who he played.  I had a hunch he played Thade's father, and I was right.  The hint that sorta gave it away was when he quotes his famous "Damn you all to hell" speech on his deathbed.  I wonder if others caught on that it was Heston in that cameo, because I don't hear much buzz about it.  The story's not topnotch.  This is overall shallow, predictable entertainment, but it works.  I enjoyed it a lot more than expected, though it dragged at points (especially in the third act) and went on a little long.  Tim Roth is great as the villain.  If I didn't check the credits, I wouldn't have known it was him.  He didn't even use his British accent (something he's amazingly good at covering up).  And behind all that makeup, he's almost completely unrecognizable.  Though I haven't seen the original, I'm pretty sure Heston played a much better hero than Mark Wahlberg.  I don't think Wahlberg's a bad actor.  It's just, he's one of those actors who doesn't seem to go the whole nine yards for his craft.  He speaks in a moderately monotone voice, and never seems to have much substance behind his performances (even in his acclaimed role as Dirk Diggler in "Boogie Nights").  He's good in this movie, but they could've cast a better lead. Someone with a more commanding presence.  Please keep in mind I didn't see the 1968 version, so I might be a little sweet on this remake.  After seeing this version, I'm more anxious to check out the old version.  I heard a lot of buzz about this movie's ending. Though I didn't think it was a bad way to end things, it was...weird.  A little enigmatic.  Something you might have to ponder for a while.  Though it's nothing as subtle as M. Night Shamalyan's ending for "The Sixth Sense." Tim Burton really did an impressive job, this is another score for him. It's good, fun entertainment that doesn't take itself too seriously and leaves sufficient room for comic relief.  So I will recommend this movie, but if you're a die-hard fan of the original--please don't get on my case!My score:  7 (out of 10)

I like Tim Burton. Really, but I'd like him to take his hands off the Apes story. This new film shows where the cinema is going thru. Very very bad characters, poor dialogs, Just hi-tech effects ( the original movie's make-up is better than this one in my opinion if you think the 32 years between them. ) and jumpin scenes. this film would only be a poor cover of a great movie.also many logical problems occur in the story. We have to wait till another new "planet of apes" to learn what the heck happened to th earth, and believe I dont want to watch it even for my curiosity.

reviews.review_title: Apart from Estella Warren, what do this and "Driven" have in common?
reviews.content:
Spoiler for the ending (not the first one, as you may have guessed).
Before the break we asked you what, apart from Estella Warren, do the new version of "Planet of the Apes" and "Driven" have in common?In both films the silver screen's most gorgeous pouter (Angelina Jolie? We don' need no steenkin' Angelina Jolie!) is one of the best things, and in both films one of the high points is watching her swim. Unlike the movie that several people here and elsewhere accurately dubbed "Drivel," however, this one does have some other stuff in its favour, but not enough to stop it from being second only to "Mars Attacks!" as Tim Burton's least interesting movie to date; note that I said least interesting and not worst, because Burton is apparently incapable of making a bad movie (he can, however, have his name on one - "Batman Forever" is billed as "A Tim Burton Production," but that was chiefly Joel Schumacher's fault).The man's never been hailed for his unwavering grasp on story, but his grip on the plot is even more tenuous than usual; he seems more interested in the look than the tale - the elements never really come together (especially the Wahlberg/Bonham-Carter/Warren "triangle," which never quite registers and explains why the ending is a bit weak). In fairness, Burton and the cast aren't helped by the script from William Broyles Jr ("Cast Away," the excellent TV series "China Beach") and sequel specialists Lawrence Konner and Mark Rosenthal (who did "The Jewel of the Nile," "Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country" and "Superman IV: The Quest For Peace" - is that warning bells I hear?), which doesn't give anyone much to work with and makes the first hour in particular a slow haul.The second half is all told an improvement, although it suffers from some hard-to-believe plot points (the phrase 'deux ex machina' comes to mind)...***SPOILER ALERT FOR THOSE READERS WHO STILL DON'T KNOW THE ENDING*** ...and the ending, though closer to the end of the original novel (in both the book and this film the hero returns to Earth only to find out, thanks to a memorial to the Tim Roth character, that the apes have taken over there as well), is clumsy, illogical and idiotic; see "Back to the Future Part II" for a similar twist, which at least had some credibility along the rules the film set itself. There must have been an easier way for Twentieth Century Fox to graft on a set-up for a potential sequel. (That's what you get for leaving Estella Warren behind, Wahlberg!)***END OF SPOILER ALERT FOR THOSE ET CETERA ET CETERA ET CETERA***Technically it's pretty good, with impressive Rick Baker makeup (although Helena Bonham-Carter's makeup, in addition to making her look a bit like B'Elanna from "Star Trek: Voyager," seems to be getting in the way of her speech), fine although non-staggering Industrial Light and Magic (and company) FX - the crash sequence and the climactic battle are standouts - and another good Danny Elfman score (although whoever decided to stick that Paul Oakenfold remix on the lengthy end credits should be taken out and shot). Some of the cast actually manage to come through the makeup, notably Michael Clarke Duncan and Tim Roth (although Mark Wahlberg looks more like an ape than the other humans), and the apes are actually pretty scary... but I miss Roddy McDowall. (Note that I haven't drawn any comparisons between this and the 1968 classic; it's not fair to do so, and I'm trying to look at this on its own merits.)Alas, Tim Burton movies shouldn't be enjoyed for their technical merits - they should and often do take you to another world. It's ironic that the first of his movies that really IS set on another world should ultimately fail to do so; lots of good things (I liked the slave trader, I didn't mind the links to the original movie - good on Charlton Heston for going uncredited, however - and I certainly enjoyed the big action scenes and some of the quieter pleasures, like the unofficial tour the humans take while escaping through the apes' city) but not a success. It's still better than the TV series or the last two sequels, however, but this isn't a real Burton movie. "Planet of the Apes" might have seemed more impressive had this identical movie been directed by Michael Bay, but from a real genius it's something to rank below his best work.But Estella is as sexy as ever, which is where we came in.

My Take: A few good moments and some fine make-up work, but not Burton's very best movies. Director Tim Burton, so far, has started and continued a promising career as a Hollywood filmmaker. So far, his first films I saw was "Beetlejuice" and "Batman", both are well-done. Burton continued such masterpieces like the sequel "Batman Returns", "Edward Scissorhands" and the highly acclaimed "Ed Wood". Even his dark comedy "Mars Attacks", which proved a little different from his other films, is still a great funny entertainment, which was a little better than the too-serious "Independence Day". Besides, when it comes to Burton's different film, it can only be this, a remake of the classic adaptation of Pierre Boulle's classic "Planet of the Apes".Just by looking at the results of this film, I'm sure that Burton was out of place here. No matter how brilliant he is as a director, the epic genre is something he's not in to. His films are usually the bizarre, or fairy tale-like films, combined with some dark comedy and satire. "Planet of the Apes" has none of those. It's a full-blood epic that revolves around man battling a more intelligent species that they weren't aware that will out-evolve them. In other words, the plot for "Planet of the Apes" is darn serious. Burton, most usually don't take everything seriously, and likes to look at the weird side. Since this film has no room for any of those, it's easy to see a failure. The make-up effects by Rick Baker are truly superb, giving each Ape character its own different look and personality. I guess that more than makes up for the films blander human characters, say Mark Wahlberg as a bland, often unconvincing action hero. Certainly, Tim Roth as the overreacting human-hating ape Thade, Helen Bonham Carter's human-loving ape Ari and many of the other simian co-stars steal the show, providing some terrific performances while under that heavy does of make-up. It ain't Burton at his definitive best, and PLANET OF THE APES certainly doesn't end being the summer's biggest blockbuster (even JURASSIC PARK III has more to offer than this). An intriguing yet misguided disappointment. Rating: **1/2 out of 5.

Take this movie for what it is, not a remake, but a completely different approach to the same concept.  It's not an epic like the original, it's more of a popcorn thriller.  Visually, it's incredible.  Everything else was just OK.  For what it is, I think the movie is awesome, but I like everything Burton has done.  People need to calm down and stop acting like it's the end of the world b/c of this movie.  It wasn't supposed to be a remake, and it's not. 
The ending was cool. . I took it as a parallel universe.

Man, am I glad to have missed this movie in cinema. Just saw it on TV now. I rarely get upset about a movie, but I am now: Terribly uninspiring, un-original and one-dimensional, one-way story, terrible acting, especially Wahlberg (who looks and talks like an idiot most of the time) and the blond chick (Warren?). Actually she is not acting at all but only trying to look good all the time. The only decent performances come from Bonham Carter and her big hulky gorilla companion during the escape (missed his name, some ex-General). Tim Roth is too one-dimensionally "bad" to be of any compelling interest. He should have declined this lame role.Terrible, senseless and completely out-of-the-blue ending after the (very poor and thin) "story" is concluded already. The costumes/make-ups and production design are good (2001, so no surprise) but do not save this movie at all.Tim Burton clearly can do better than this. I can't understand what he found in this script as he had a very heavy and uninspired hand here. Complete waste of time and money... utterly disappointing. For me, this Apes is one of the worst Sci-fi movies ever made, and to compare it in any way to the 1968 movie is an offence to the latter.

Now I will admit I love Tim Burton and most of his work but I too was shocked and fearful of his agreement to take the helm of this sci-fi action flick revamp/re-imagining. Many directors were considered and to be honest I think many of them would have been perfect for the film but Burton does add his usual unique artistic style which can be glimpsed throughout the film in armour design, landscapes sets etc..So straight to the point I actually liked this Burton version of 'Apes' mainly because its a fun romp which is both silly entertaining cheese and has that classic semi serious sci-fi element to it. First up the visuals in the film are tremendously good and really make the film stand out, total kudos to Rick Baker and his team, the man totally nails the ape look for all the characters to a tee. The best clearly being Roth as Thade with a fantastic makeup job, next up must be Duncan in his gorilla makeup but how about Shadix and Giamatti in their orangutan (I think) makeup...amazing!The film wins with the look for sure, not only is the makeup excellent but the sets are nicely worked, location is well suited, the apes costumes and battle gear is well designed and the space sequences also look and work well. All in all its pretty much like a top class Star Trek film...I mean a good Star Trek film by the way.Casting choices were good accept for Wahlberg who wasn't quite right for me. Thankfully we had no Depp to endure here but the use of many solid character actors such as Warner and the imaginative use Tagawa really help lift the film, who could imagine Tagawa as a gorilla.I really enjoyed the film on my second viewing, my first was on release at the cinema, and I believe its because the 'Apes' classic plot can be made many ways and is open to interpretation from different angles, its not a case of it only works one way like a lot of classic films, 'Apes' is a franchise that you can seem to mould and recreate without upsetting the originals. This Burton vision is simple yet highly enjoyable as a fun sci-fi romp, not too heavy, not just copying the original, touch of artistic license and the attempt at a twist ending which was brave but rather illogical, trying to equal the original but failing there I'm afraid. Still the little use of CGI for much of the film is always nice in my book.7/10

reviews.review_title: *sigh* I think I want to cry
reviews.content:
This was a BIG disappointment.  I want to cry because I am a huge Tim Burton fan and I have never been disappointed until now.  As everyone will agree, the visual effects and the makeup are amazing.  Rick Baker and crew deserve yet another Oscar.  However, this is where the compliments end.  Let's go down the list of things that I have a problem with:(1) The first 10-15 minutes on the space station looked too much like Buck Rogers for my taste.  Everything was too sanitized and too white. The acting made matters worse especially when it comes accompanied by lines like "Never send a monkey to do a man's job."(2) There was a long period after this where I was happy.  Once he landed on the planet things got better until they reached Calima and it turned for the worse.  Does anyone actually buy the idea that a 3,000 year old piece of equipment that crashed from space would work?  Oh yeah, that's right!  It's NUCLEAR powered.  I guess that the equipment itself would never corrode or rust.(3) Okay... the rest of the humans show up because they heard about the amazing human that will save them.  Uh?  Did I miss something?  Did he do something amazing that I'm not aware of?  At least in the original, Charlton Heston was the only human that could speak.  This ability made him stand out from the rest.  In this version, all humans could speak.  What's so great about Marky Mark?  That's right, he "came from the stars" to save them all.(4) Does anyone else find it extremely cheesy that a chimpanzee lands in a spaceship and saves the day?  Ridiculous.(5) The ending reminded me too much of "Conquest of..." and "Battle for.."
I hope there is no sequel, but I'm sure there will be.  I just pray that Tim Burton does not shame himself again by directing the follow-up.

reviews.review_title: Good but not as good as the original.
reviews.content: I was so looking forward to watching Planet Of The Apes and in the end i wasn't disapointed athough i dont think this version had the same impact on me as the original. The special affects are superb as is the story and like the original it has a great ending. I'm not saying what happened was a suprise because mostly everything that happened during the film was very predictable but dont let that distract you from what is an entertaining movie. When you have a movie that involves such heavy make up you lose a lot,when it comes to acting,which is a shame because you certainly would not have know that underneath all that make up there was superb actors such as Tim Roth and Charlton Heston. In fact they could have saved thierselves a lot of money and had lessor actors in the apes role.All in all a couple of hours of good entertainment. 8 out 10.

What happened? Tim Burton assembled most of the key elements for science fiction success; outstanding makeup, good actors, excellent score, himself directing. But he left out one critical ingredient, a good, tight script. And that omission, in my opinion, sinks the movie. I salute the filmmakers for not wanting a total remake of the original (and better) "Planet of the Apes", and that they wanted to put a different spin on the story. And they did, changing many key plot points including the ending. But there are serious problems with the script, among them: (1) Humans speak English, but don't have much to say. There's not even a hint as to why they think they're in the position they're in. (2) The movie has a blatant political/social message that is forced-fit in to key dialogues. (3) The ending is so bad as to be laughable. The makeup alone is worth the price of a rental, but the movie really never takes off. It's certainly not as good as the original.

Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is dark, macabre, and visually stunning. William Broyles's screenplay is interesting, but the dialogue has it's moments. A dear friend pointed out for me the low point in writing occurs when Leo (Mark Wahlberg) in an attempt to inspire the humans to battle the attacking apes he says "Come on guys! We can take them..." Whoa! Much of "Planet of the Apes" is like that. It has the trademark Burton brooding, dark settings-- great attention to detail. Though the story is in-cohesive and uneven. And there is some killer over-acting, particularly by Tim Roth as General Thade. Mark Wahlberg is okay as stranded astronaut, Leo, who wants to go home. Human activist, Helena Bonham Carter as ape Ari, is convincing in a strange "romantic" role. Liked Cary-Hiroyki Tagawa as Ari's protector, Krull-- the one really heroic character. All the other characters are forgettable. Even with these weaknesses in writing and acting, "Planet of the Apes" is definitely entertaining. It's pretty much an action picture with a slight social context-- very slight. You have great visuals, chases, explosions, and cool looking apes. Burton's reworked surprise ending is also worth staying for.

2 great movies from my youth have been remade into more modern versions and both are horrible. First is Poseidon adventure. Second is this Planet of the Apes remake. Its almost like Burton went out of his way to make a totally bad movie from the original. Just making the humans able to speak in this newer version was a major mistake. Not to mention almost every actor in this movie is miscast. Giamatti had to go out and make a movie like Sideways after this bomb. If they are going to make another movie in this series, maybe make one in the period between Beneath the Planet of the apes and Escape when the 3 apes go back to modern times. Curious how they manage to fly back when from what i remember, Heston's space craft sank and the one Brent used was pretty much blown up. Either way, a bad remake. Message to Hollywood - stop making remakes, aren't there enough good scripts available over there.

reviews.review_title: 117 minutes of entertainment and 2 minutes of disbelief, horror and shock!
reviews.content: This could have been a really good film, one almost equal to it's original, but not yet being a copy. It could have been a modern reflection of the 1968 version. It could have been a re-imaging' and a good one as well, but it was screwed up at the end. I enjoyed this film up to the 117th minute, when everything was is perfect order, but the ending ruined it all. It is preposterous, ridiculous and confusing (only not to say plain stupid). But I guess part 2 will explain it all (oh I can't wait with what they'll come up with).6 out of 10 (disregarding the ending anything between 7 to 7,5 out of 10 can be given)

Not having seen the original, I was forced to judge this movie on its basic credibility alone.  I get the feeling that being attached to the star of its namesake is why it saw theatrical release at all.  This thing was mind-numbing.  The characters made no sense, the plot was inane, and the science was terrible.  You can only watch so many scenes of monkeys jumping on each other and pounding.  That's basically the whole film, briefly interrupted by scenes of Mark Wahlberg trying to look heroic.  The special effects are pretty good, but that's like wrapping up feces in a pretty gift box.  What happened to you, Tim Burton?

This movie is one of the worst remakes. Although it is very spectacular, the main thought of the original story is lost in it. This thought was that the humans became animals and the apes are the superior species. Humans are not only unable to speak but even to think. They are driven by their instinct. Apes are not only able to speak and to think but they even walk righted. The only "good" thing in this film is the ending that gives back the ending of the book. Although the ending of the original movie was not bad as well. It made the possibility to make some sequence for it. This movie can not be continued (Thanks for the Lord for all the small miracles!) and has a very stupid story with a very stupid beginning. Don't waste your time, watch the original instead. 0.1 out of 10.

I'm taking a break from Burton movies after this one.  I just don't like his makeup philosophy and here his vision is watered-down.  Too often this resembles the work of someone else, not Burton.Mark Wahlberg wasn't what made 'Three Kings' and 'Boogie Nights' strong.  He was presentable because the source material is strong.  Here his source is weak.  Under that weak of a structure, he collapses.Overall, the (obvious) subtexts of the original have been exchanged for simple action.  First level science-fiction.I don't see what's so confusing about the ending...Final Analysis = = Cinematic Dud

This film was certainly set up for the sequel, that's all I can say. Wahlberg was wonderful, Heston was excellent, and Helena Bonham Carter's humanity, wit, energy and charm shone through her ape makeup clear as a bell.  The film, though hardly satisfying or cathartic, was interesting as a metaphor at least, and I will of course rush to the sequel, if only to experience a more satisfying ending.

As in the original film, we are once again taken into an  upside down world. The film cleverly avoids imitating the original but at the same time makes amusing references to the original. The sly sense of humor extends to having Heston in ape makeup talking about the dangers of human ingenuity and cruelty -- as he refers to a human gun. I guess the current leader of the National Rifle Association has a sense of self-mocking humor after all.Tim Roth is excellent as a bad-guy who is one of the most  threatening villains since Dracula. The film is worth seeing just for his performance.The story is an interesting allegory about the injustice of human-animal relations as well as human-human inhumanity. Tim Burton seems to be having a field-day playing around with perspective, human-ape evolution arguments, and even space and time.It doesn't have the surprises of the original film, but that's only because it isn't the original. It does, however, deliver a good cynical and comic jolt at the end just as the original did.

reviews.review_title: Quite a bad film but not as awful as its reputation would suggest
reviews.content: This film reminds me of the brilliant "Not the Nine O'Clock News" skit "Nice Video, Shame About the Song", though that isn't a perfect analogy since Danny Elfman's score is one of the best things about the film! The make-up and the set design - particularly Ape City and the ruins of the Oberon - are fantastic but it has a host of other problems. Compared with the 1968 classic (my sixth favourite film of all time), the social commentary is very diluted and not particularly well done even when they bother trying to do it. In his review at the time, Roger Ebert said that, "Intellectually, it's science fiction for junior high school boys." I was 14 in 2001 and I loved it then so I think that he was onto something. He was also right when he said that in ten years time, people would still be watching the original film in preference to this one.Mark Wahlberg is no Charlton Heston and Leo Davidson expresses little to no emotion throughout the film. He's a cardboard cutout, really. He lands on a planet of apes and his reaction is basically "Hmm..." I had the same problem with most of the human characters. Daena's characterisation consists mainly of giving our hero doe-eyed looks, though the conflict with Ari has the (mostly unrealised) potential to be interesting. None of the other human characters add anything to the plot with the possible exception of Erick Avari's character Tival providing a contrast between the "wild" humans and the "housebroken" ones. They focused too much attention on giving the apes personalities, mistakenly thinking that the audience would be interested in the humans for the sole reason that they were humans.Among the apes, the best actors - almost wrote "beast actors" by mistake! - are Helena Bonham Carter as the principled human rights activist Ari and David Warner as her well-intentioned but weak willed father Senator Sandar, who appears in all of two scenes. Paul Giamatti has some good lines and is quite funny as the orangutan slave trader Limbo but, again, the character doesn't add much to the film. The usually very reliable Tim Roth is a too over the top and not all that creepy or frightening as General Thade. I think that his second-in- command Attar, played very well by Michael Clarke Duncan, would have made for a much more frightening villain. Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa was good but not great as Krull. Like Warner, Glenn Shadix only appeared in two scenes but managed to make more of an impression than any of the human characters and quite a few of the ape ones as Senator Nado. My favourite scene in the film was definitely Charlton Heston's uncredited cameo as Thade's dying father Zaius, who is reminiscent of the character of the same name from the original film. It's quite interesting that the only ape on the planet with a gun was played by the President of the NRA! I highly doubt that Heston, then in his late 70s, would have been willing to do an entire film in that make-up but he'd have made a better villain than Thade as well. I also really liked Linda Harrison's appropriately silent cameo as the woman in the cart when Leo enters Ape City.The film was co-written by Lawrence Konner and Mark Rosenthal, who previously performed the same duty on the much more stupid "Superman IV: The Quest for Peace" and the excellent "Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country" (in which the always brilliant David Warner also appeared in a fairly small role as a liberal, sympathetic politician). The script seems like a first draft rather than a finished product. It's mostly uninspired but there are a few little things that I liked in the script such as the occasional good line, the electromagnetic storm / temporal anomaly relaying all Earth broadcasts from across time to the Oberon, the origin of the ape civilisation, the apes' creation myth and Pericles' return. Oh, and I have to admit that I love, love, love the nutty ending, which is more or less the same as in the original novel. Part of me wishes that there had been a sequel to see how they would have followed up on it! One thing that I really hated though was Leo and Ari's romantic subplot because of, you know, the whole bestiality thing. As for the action scenes, they are decent as opposed to fantastic, with one or two minor exceptions.Overall, this is quite a bad film but I don't think that it's as awful as its reputation would suggest. It's one of the only films that I enjoyed as a young child or in my early teens that I dislike now. In spite of everything, however, I still retain a certain level of fondness for it as it introduced me to the original film series, which is second only to the "Back to the Future" trilogy as my favourite film series of all time. Plus, 2001/2002 wasn't the happiest time in my life and watching it over and over again helped me forget my troubles for two hours at a time. Objectively speaking though, Tim Burton and Helena Bonham Carter's relationship and collaboration in almost all of his later, better films are probably the best things to come out of the film.

"Planet of the Apes" is a great retelling of the 1968 classic film. The film is crammed with awesome special effects and eye-popping action!! This is a fun film to see in the theater like I did. Mark Walhberg is great!!! This is a great film that shows you how good of a director Tim Burton is. This is a great hit movie!! I give this film a 10 out of 10!!!! You have to see this!!!!

I have to say it held my interest but only when the apes were on screen-the only well developed characters were Tim Roth's Thade and Helena Bonham Carter's Ari. The "human" cast was weak beyond words and what in God's name inspired someone to cast Kris Kristofferson-of ALL PEOPLE-in this flick? This group deserved to be enslaved simply because they were so pathetically vapid, they'd have a hard time surviving on their own. Mark Wahlberg showed as much emotion and sensitivity as a toilet seat and one just can't imagine him as David leading the robotic humans over the Goliath apes. It also seemed way beyond the bounds of reason that ALL the apes would suddenly become tolerant and glad to consider their former slaves their equals-as we all know too well, racism and bigotry are not so easily erased. And the ending was just plain asinine, and all you Mensans out there who say oh, it makes crystal clear sense, fits right in with the plot,are just thinking too much. I get free cable so it didn't cost me anything and for that I'm grateful.

'Planet of the Apes' (2001) should be watched as a separate film and not as a re-make of the original film because the two films are completely different. I think that a lot of people did not enjoy this film because they tried to compare it to the original 1968 film. In truth, the stories and characters are different. Remaking the original film would not have been a good idea because most people know the ending; this film takes a different approach. The human lands on the planet, and he is taken hostage with some other humans, and together, they learn the history of the planet. In this film, however, the presence of a villain character is an important part of the film. No, this film is not as good as the 1968 one, even though they are different stories, but it is still enjoyable. The script was done well, but it was not as engaging and not as memorable. It's captivating as an action/adventure film with some science fiction elements, even though it does not go the extra way to create a true classic. Still, it's good if you're looking for something fun to watch.

reviews.review_title: Taking out all the substances of a film.
reviews.content: This is planet of the apes for the dummy's. All the questions of society, religion, the horrors of the Cold War and the threat of men's extinction exchanged for explosions and a love story between humans and a monkey.

reviews.review_title: Weak plot, mediocre acting and incoherent fight scenes. A disappointment
reviews.content: This remake should never have been attempted. Tim Burton gives the film a distinct look but forgets completely about the plot. The story is weak and the jokes mostly fall flat. Mark Wahlberg looks lost in the lead. He lacks Charlton Heston's personality and intensity. The fight scenes are incoherent but slick. The final battle's resolution feels like a cheat. To make matters worse, there's an unnecessary epilogue which left me shaking my head. This is probably a case of being too clever by half. The film is better avoided. See it if you must with a finger on the FF button! Overall 3/10

I have to say it blew me away! The movie is easily one of the top ten best sci-fi films ever created. PLANET OF THE APES is based on a 196os French novel, "La planete des singes," by Pierre Boulle. I think one of the reasons there is so much animosity against this one is that it is undeniably dated. This movie kept me captivated from the beginning all the way to the end. This might all sound corny, like a bad B-movie, but that is not the case. This is actually a serious movie with a serious message. It is a powerful film, but I doubt I will ever want to watch it again. Final rating from me: seven out of ten, almost eight out of ten.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the original of course, but...
reviews.content: In comparison to the original this remake suffers but because the source material is so strong, I found it to still be a more than worthwhile viewing experience. The makeup, props, special effects, settings, choreography, and sheer attention to detail are all first class as befitting a film of this scale and budget. However, while the entire supporting cast, especially Tim Roth, is very convincing and in fact is superlative in its performance, the star Mark Wahlberg never convinced me he was in this fantastic situation that almost defied description. He almost seemed 'ho hum' about it! Also in this version the underlying themes of ethics and philosophy and even the sheer sense of adventure and discovery seem to have been overshadowed by a more a conventional 'action movie' approach. Still the movie is marvelously entertaining, 7/10.

This movie was a real letdown.  I was expecting so much more from Tim Burton.  All this movie did for me was help me to appreciate the original that much more.  Whatever it was that made the original movie work is absent in this remake.  Burton's 'Planet of the Apes' is a rental at best.

If this remake of "Planet of The Apes" would have been made anyone else than Tim Burton I'd would have given it a better score, an 8/10 even, because it actually is not that bad as a movie. It had potential, Tim Burton is one of the greatest directors of modern cinema and what does he do? Totally unoriginal version of the POTA. There's nothing in this film, that gives out impression, that it has been made by one of the greatest and visual directors of today. And that was the main reason for me to give only 6/10.AS a movie I actually do find this better than the original POTA, tough the original had more depth in the script, I've always disliked it because of the horrible soundtrack they used on it. I always did find it very difficult to watch the movie because of that. This Tim Burton's version is far more easier for the ears and basically the plot tries to handle same issues with the original. But the problem remains: This was not Tim Burton movie. I don't know what possessed him. He just blurted out this uninspired thing and went on doing something he does best: Tim Burton movies.I wouldn't recommend this for Tim Burton fans. And I don't know will fans of original like this either. But if you are new on the whole subject, then maybe.

reviews.review_title: Does plenty well everything a movie is supposed to do, and does it GRAND!!!
reviews.content: Wonderful movie! Although not without some flaws, but well worthseeing and enjoying. After seeing it this morning, I was surprisedto discover that this evening I felt like seeing it again. So, I'll catch itagain within a week or two.WARNING--SPOILERS The entire gorilla cast was magnificent! Truly and reallyastounding work by the makeup guys-- but more, by the actorsthemselves. Not once did I think-- Hey, there's Roddy McDowell ina gorilla suit! The animal characters were so believable. Thehumans were less than grand, though. Kris Kristoffersen wasamazing-- a welcome and remarkable acting re-appearance, andtotally apt for his role.The blond babe: Whats-her-name, was serviceable, but nothingspecial. Markie Mark -- I mean Mark Wahlberg-- is a fine actor,generally. But here his character is annoying and dumb. I kind ofwanted to see him killed pretty much right away.Helena Bonham-Carter-- all I can say is you've got to see her tobelieve her! Even though any role as a gorilla lady would be,professionally, a bit of a burlesque, she made it into somethingworthwhile. Appropriate to the spirit of the movie-- but I say that hercharacter in this flick outdoes and therefore embarrasses JuliaRoberts, in ANYTHING Roberts has EVER done. Bonham-Cartergets an exquisite performance out of the circumstances, whichspeaks highly of her genius and mastery of acting.The ending, though-- What the F*** was that??? Talk aboutsomething happening simply because the script, or pre-fab cliche,demands it! Knowing critic Roger Ebert's movie law that "No propis featured in a movie without a purpose/payoff later on"-- seeingso much attention paid to the real chimp in the beginning was aclear tip-off that somehow he'd show up later, etc. I also couldguess the secret source of the ape planet within 8 seconds of itsfirst mention. I'm sure most other audience members did as well.But when Wahlberg goes back in time to earth and finds that AbeLincoln is a gorilla dude? That is illogical, even in a 1960's vibesci-fi movie. What's the logic? It makes no sense, and thus hadabsolutely no effect on me.On the other hand-- so what? This great flick does plenty enoughof what a movie is supposed to do, and it does it really well. Maybeit ain't Shakespeare-- but from what I've read, in his time,Shakespeare himself wasn't Shakespeare either.Go see "Planet of the Apes." Be glad; be happy!

I read the novel in jr high and thoroughly loved the ending.  Now that Tim Burton's film is out I can enjoy the ironic ending Boulle had visualized (only set in DC rather than Paris).  This is a much better film than the original.  Thank you Tim!

reviews.review_title: Not too bad until it became horrible.
reviews.content: It was a nice popcorn flik until the chimp came down in a spaceship near the end. Never mind that he went into the time warp first, he comes out last. And then things get really weird as Leo goes back to Earth to find that it's controlled by apes in the current time. It just doesn't make sense.
First act was slow, gradually got better. Final fight scene was average but the dust made it really difficult to see. The ending was a shock but still confusing.

reviews.review_title: A New Nightmarish World of Clever Apes
reviews.content: An energetic, adrenaline-charged and slightly surreal remake of the classic '68 original, still based on author Boulle's novel (oh, someone preferred the term 'reimagined' - as if 'remake' is a dirty word now - too late for such pomposity at this stage). But we can imagine what director Burton's penchant for nightmarish landscapes and dark fairy tales would look like if imposed on the well-known Planet of the Apes storyline. With such preconceptions, it's not at all a surprise what this film ended up becoming - in fact, it's fairly predictable, perhaps its biggest weakness. It's no surprise that many of those crowd shots of soldier apes here resemble the scary monkey-things from "The Wizard of Oz." Ironically, the first drawback for this version is its faithful adherence to the novel; the hero astronaut (Marky Mark) in this one really does travel to another planet, where the inhabitants (ruling apes & underdog humans) speak perfect English. The explanation for this bizarro planet and its presumed natives in the final third is not nearly as elegant as the logical one in the classic '68 film. We're asked to go along with the fanciful concepts and not think it out very much - this is fairy tale madness, after all, dressed up as science fiction for the masses. Burton seems to be in conflict with himself here - at once the eclectic stylist at odds with presenting a standard summer popcorn flic for the consumers.Where Burton and some of his actors do succeed is in presenting most of the new ape characters. Roth pretty much steals the movie from everyone as the central villain, Thade. Interestingly, this film was more accurate than the original in that it understood that chimpanzees are the most violence-prone and bad-tempered of the apes in our reality (gorillas are actually more benign). Thade, a super-chimp for lack of a better term, is possessed of power on several levels (physical, social, political) and uses it in displays of ferocious antipathy. Roth so loses himself in the role that, even as I viewed this a 2nd and 3rd time, knowing who it was under that ape make-up, I still could find no traces of him. It's a triumph of make-up FX and stellar method acting. All the actors who play apes in this picture, including Bonham Carter and Clarke Duncan, succeed in dazzling the audience to such a degree that, unfortunately, all the ones playing humans, including the main lead, come off as very bland. The climactic battle between the two armies is exciting and we tense up some more as Thade's villainy appears to near an end. Then everything becomes abruptly copacetic on this weird world and the final (secondary) climax back on Earth still doesn't make sense to me, not after the 3rd time, and probably not when I see it a 4th time. I think Burton's just messing with us.

I've seen the original Planet Of The Apes and I think it's very good but this 'new updated version' is even better. Mark Wahlberg is brilliant as are the rest of the cast, including: Tim Roth, who plays a real baddie here, Helena Bonham Carter and Paul Giamatti and the little monkey who had a starring role here. The special effects and make-up are obviously amazing and *definitely* deserve an oscar nomination. The twist-ending was a little strange but it was really good and it looks as if they will make a sequel, which I'm more sure will be just as great. I give Planet Of The Apes a 10/10.

I have not yet seen the other Planet Of The Apes (or it's affiliated films from the 70's) so I will make no comparison. Well, I might have seen them, but I was very young and don't recall them or since i9t was the 70's I might have been stoned...who knows.Anyways...I look forward to the sequel...I think this movie is very good...especially all the work and effort that went into it and with 20 minutes of uncut film added to the script, would have made this a kickass film.The only flaw that I found this to have is that Estelle Warren's character served no purpose aside from looking good in skimpy clothing and LIPSTICK...now where would she get LIPSTICK and MAKEUP and EYESHADOW from in a JUNGLE?And why did all the humans have perfect white teeth?Oh yeah...what was the initial reason of the purpose for the humans in the final cut film? Maybe to show us that even in the jungle that we can have a nice tan and well manicured hair and nails.To claim this movie to be bad is wrong...it just missed the mark...and with a staff of over 600 people and so much to do, I'm sure that some oversights can happen when you are directing a film and Tim Burton's oversights were proper character development and motive...but aside of that I think he did a wicked job....as well as EVERYBODY ELSE involved in this film from stunts to makeup, costumes, painters, props and EVERYBODY...I was overall pleased.

Tim Burton was careful to call his take on "Planet of the Apes" a "re-imagining" rather than a "remake."  And he does quite well here.  This version has a dark look that works to a point.  The ape makeup on the actors does look convincing.  And having them actually move like apes was a nice touch.  But, to tell the truth, the new twist ending didn't really make sense.  And I did miss seeing the Statue of Liberty in this version. Perhaps Tim purposefully left Lady Liberty out because people expected her?

I loved most of the original movies. Heck, I loved the tv show too. I didn't read any reviews of this, and bought it on DVD because, heck, its Planet of the Apes, and made by (iffy) director Tim Burton.I turned it off about halfway through. I don't care how many DVD gimmicks are on the disk, it will never get near my player again.Boooooo!

reviews.review_title: Jon Monsarrat review: sub-intellectual but not awful
reviews.content: I'm not very arty and I don't expect films to contain exceptional choreography or makeup. But I do expect it to make sense, be engaging, and have a moving plot. And I like car chases and when stuff blows up. And I like science fiction.But even with these factors in my favor, I was very disappointed by Planet of the Apes.The film is poorly acted -- especially the natives, and the world does not seem realistic, so instead of being spooky we don't really get drawn in. Most importantly, I don't like a sub-intellectual film that insults my intelligence. Some of the plot twists just didn't make any sense. The original version had something to say; that all gets lost here.What a disappointment, and the ending was brutally concocted and unsatisfying.Who should see this film:-- Sci-fi film buffs who didn't mind the stupidity inthe remake of "Lost in Space", or "Independence Day"(which admittedly is a lot of people)-- I can't think of anyone elseI regret I can only give "Planet of the Apes" an uninspired 5 out of 10.

It is amazing how mediocre directors like Tim Burton are hailed as something invigorating, and imbued with genius when actually all they give us are tired and banal films.Planet of the Apes was marketed as something "new", but all parts of it were stolen from classic science fiction films of the 1950's.Basically there is no plot in this film, and if you were a European director, it wouldn't matter, but Burton has the capabilities of a 12 year old teen and those qualities are evident here.He uses "movements" from the first film (ex: the apes catching a human with a neck container) which are part of our collective conscience, except this time around, there is no vitality or energy in them.The cartoonish film has terrible sets, which look like some cheap soap opera, and there is no realist sustainabilty.The characters walk around the same sound set covered with plastic ferns and trees, and it seems like they are going nowhere; even worse is the 'ape city', which is so ridiculous that one doesn't even think that it is populated.Problem after problem punctuates what we see. Walhberg is so boring as a rebellious captain that he doesn't seem real, but the "humans" are worshipping him as a leader? Give us a break.The humans themselves are ludicrious, because they are clean, and have perfect communication skills and the women are half-naked with big breasts. Ghee Tim, are you trying to market your film to horny 11 year olds?What else? Everything, uneven acting, even worse, cliche that puts us to sleep. All we see is how 'evil' the chimp general is, and how 'good' the humans and sanctimonious chimp peace lover are. Yawn, yawn.Even the special effects begin to wear thin, notice how cheap the crash landing on earth looked.I wouldn't see this film again, ever. Burton, grow up and give us something decent to watch, you make enough money.

reviews.review_title: This is NOT Burton's best film!
reviews.content: Remakes come in all shapes and sizes. What's the reason for making remakes of the classic movies that fitted well? Some remakes get to show a different side of view like Martin Scorsese's Cape Fear in 1991 where rather than showing a happy family in peril (like in the original 1962 classic), Scorsese shows a dysfunctional family filled with anger and a disease where it made audience applaud for De Niro's character.Tim Burton is known for making movies in a goth emblem from Beetlejuice, Batman Returns (the best of his work), Sleepy Hollow, Edward Scissorhands and much more. Now he directs this 1960's classic about how a man from space gets stuck in an island filled with talking and vicious primates. Mark Whalberg is Capt. Leo Davidson who doesn't do much except try to wow women with his boyish good looks where one of his lab chimps goes inside a space rocket and leaves the space station where he goes into another planet. Leo tries to find his pet until he realizes that once he arrives everything is upside down with humans in cages and use for enslavement while primates (Gorillas, monkeys, orangutans, etc.) rule the planet. The leader is General Thade (Tim Roth, who stands out) who wants to abolish all humans from the face of the earth. His henchmen involves the volatile Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan), Limbo (Paul Giamatti) the fool, and sweet Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) who crushes on Captain Leo.If you seen the original movie about how the humans and some of the chimps fight off the bad primates, there's a twist in the ending. There's no enthrallment, no cheers, it felt as if certain scenes from the trailer worked rather than the film itself while breathing in relief after I walked out of the theater.

reviews.review_title: One of the WORST I have ever had the Discomfort of Seeing
reviews.content:
I love Tim Burton movies.  I have been a ravenous fan of his since the first of the Batman movies (as we know them today) came out in 1989 (there is another movie made in the 60s based of the classic TV show, starring the one true Batman, Adam West).  Furthermore, I loved the original Planet of the Apes.  It was one of the most well known, recognizable, and thought provoking movies of all time, with one of the greatest twists in cinematic history.  Not only that, but if you look at the series of `Apes' movies, as a whole, you will most likely find that they are one of the greatest, most well fitting together with respect to continuity (if that is even possible to say) franchises ever.  So with that being said, could this movie possibly go wrong?Oh it did. It went WAY wrong. This movie is righteous garbage. The twist at the end (not a spoiler) makes absolutely no logical sense, independently. But if it sets up a plot that will be explained in the sequel, then I don't want to know, and have no desire to see it.  But what is my major grievance with this movie:Marky Mark.  In this movie, he single handedly gives a horrible performance, AS ALWAYS, and disgraces the name of models gone actors, which if you think about it is pretty bad considering they have a bad reputation to begin with. One of the more subtle problems that I have with him, besides his pitiful excuse for acting, is that throughout this and seemingly all of his other movies he has the same facial expression, which is something of a mix between constipation and just got done running a marathon.  Even moreso is the fact that throughout the whole movie, he never seems to be surprised at the fact that not only is he in a world completely different than his, nor the fact that it is primarily populated by gigantic, walking, talking apes, nor does he ever seem to ponder, even ask, or want to find out, `hey, what in the righteous heck is going on here?'Here is my breakdown of the other key players in the movie:Helena Bonham Carter  brilliant actress  waste of her talent.Charlton Heston  cultural icon  waste of his talent.Tim Burton  one of the greatest and most imaginative, and visually impressive moviemakers of all time  completely shot himself in the foot for making this garbage.Anyone else remotely involved in the making of this movie - waste of their collective talent.The only redeeming factors of this movie is that Danny Elfman once again provides a good score to the movie and the shot where they look back upon the city (it's the only shot in the movie that is signature Tim Burton). 
Now I have seen some BAD movies in my day, and not only does this one take the taco, but to categorize it as only a bad movie would be an insult.  This is beyond a bad movie.  This is a complete waste of your life if you watch it.  Please, please, please if you want to see Planet of the Apes, look past the fancy special effects, good makeup and prosthetics job, and the fact that it is a newer movie, and go watch the lower budget, older original. Save yourself the agony.

Planet of the Apes (2001, Dir. Tim Burton) An astronaut trying to retrieve a monkey in space ends up landing on a planet inhabited by talking human-like apes. Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) finds himself captured by the apes and placed in a cage with other humans. All the apes take this same 'human hating' attitude, with the exception of one. A kind, female ape called Ari (Bonham Carter) sees something different in these humans, and plans to help them in whatever they need to do.Even with wonderful performances by the actors, a small amount of action and a poorly crafted ending makes this version of the classic ends up as one of Burton's weaker films.Are you trying to put me out of business? These are the skankiest, scabbiest, scuzziest humans I've ever seen.  Limbo (Paul Giamatti)

well what to say. I was eagerly awaiting the release of this movie,  i was so excited about seeing it and i went to the 1st screening this morning. what a waste of money, dont get me wrong the special effects were amazing rick baker deserves an oscar for his outstanding work. the plot was a total joke, very poorly written and the acting wasnt up to scratch either apart from one person. Tim Roth was amazing, absolutely brilliant as the most evil looking ape i have ever seen. the guy deserves an award , should give him the most evil looking thing on screen award (lol).. wark walhberg does his best bless him but overacts a badly written script. helena bonham carter was fairly impressive as human lover ari but lacked a certain something.. and the ending,  oh my god, what an absolute pile of crap, i came out of the movie laughing at its sheer pathetic attempt at bringing an exciting twist, but people give me a break,  now the ending to the original was brilliant finding the statue of liberty but this was dire. as brilliant as tim burton is i am not attacking his vision in any way, but this is possibly the worst movie he has ever made. i was hugely disappointed by it and would say this, go and see it for the effects which at times can be quite scary, but i guarantee 2 things,  you will come out laughing and you will never want to see it again.

reviews.review_title: Forget the original and watch with fresh eyes, this is more honest to the novel.
reviews.content: Not such a bad film as some people have reported, I actually liked it, and I'm also deeply worried about the talk of the many cuts made.Allegedly Tim Burton made it as close to the book as possible, and even included some scenes such as a human-ape love scene. However, this is also one of the main reasons why fans of the original Heston film were upset, `where is the Statue of Liberty scene?' Well, it's not in the book!However, all this aside, and it is a really enjoyable movie. I'm a growing fan of Mark Wahlberg, and he just proves why yet again with his talent shining through. There's a superbly crafted ending here too, and one that I so enjoyed. This was another sticking point for some critics.My advice would be, drop the ideas from the original, and go and see this movie with fresh eyes.

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton's Epitaph: He Did What He Could
reviews.content: Critics are a little harsher on this semi-return-to-form from Tim Burton than I would have thought from how consistently engaging the picture is. While not as bewilderingly impersonal as SLEEPY HOLLOW, APES still bears the earmarks of a Fox  $100-million-dollar movie--which is to say that the third act takes a turn into James Cameron and GLADIATOR territory that is most unwelcome (and seems designed to provide gung-ho trailer fodder).Audiences will probably be divided by the finale, an attempt to recoup the badum-bum finale of the 1968 APES; it's a little hamhanded, but I think it works. And the incredible deus ex machina that cuts short a not very well executed Maximus-style combat climax is so touching and out of left-field it feels almost Spielbergian. But until then, the movie works as a well-masticated mouthful of the original APES' hidden subtexts: Burton's APES proliferates metaphors of racism, animal rights, individual self-destruction, and militarism-versus-effete-government in virtually every scene. The themes buried in the Franklin Schaffner APES may not be as probingly essayed here as...oh, I dunno, they would be in a Todd Haynes movie. But they are rather surprising in the context of this very big movie--which, to Burton's everlasting credit, must be the lightest on action scenes of any blockbuster of its kind in years. The Burtonian wit is there--especially when Mrs. Burton, a k a Lisa Marie, does a simian dance of sex for her bloated orangutan husband, who trembles like Pontius Pilate ogling Salome. And it's there in Paul Giamatti's side-of-the-mouth quips as an amoral trader of human slaves. (This is the kind of humor George Lucas was attempting, and failing at grotesquely, in THE PHANTOM MENACE.) Much has been made of the "flatness" of Mark Wahlberg's performance as the human hero, but I think he gives the role just what's necessary--an unsentimental desire to get the job done and get out of Dodge. Much has also been made of the hambone-chewing, sucking and swallowing of Tim Roth, who plays the evillest of the apes; as with Ben Kingsley in SEXY BEAST, Americans seem to respond to British villainy when it's spelled out with a magic marker. Better performances come from Helena Bonham Carter, who weaves bits of chimpanzee physical behavior into her role as a tremulous human-rights activist--a sort of chimpish Patty Hearst--and even from the model Estelle Warren, who is perfectly credible opening her mouth and perfectly heart-stopping when closing it. The script is a sound one (even if there's a bit too much time spent following Wahlberg walk around a wilderness staring at a Palm Pilot-like compass) and Burton brings more flair to even the most expositional images than any of the other eligible hacks could possibly bring to bear. Since this movie is  guaranteed to make a sockful of loot, will somebody let Burton  make another ED WOOD or MARS ATTACKS?

reviews.review_title: in my opinion a new classic
reviews.content: Planet of the apes in my opinion a new classic. Tim Burton did a really excellent job on this movie. Mark did some good acting too. The special effects were really cool in the movie. The music helped out with the atmosphere. I dont anything bad to say about this movie at all. Everything about it was great. I really think this movie will be remembered for a long time. I scenery was really cool looking. I recommend this movie to anyone and everyone. This is a movie families can watch together. Plus the ending was really cool. In my opinion. So take my advice watch it sometime.

After all those reviews and comments, I feel that I have to add mine.I'll start with the things I liked:The make-up is fantastic. The always-amazing Rick Baker did an incredible job here and created some truly realistic apes - I'll risk in saying that it's probably the best ape make-up ever made, and - as some people have already mentioned - a lot better than the make-up used in the original series. I especially liked the make-up for Thade (Tim Roth). My least favorite is the make-up for Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), which looks quite different from the rest; I guess Rick wanted her to look "half-human" (a similar approach was used for the wolves animatronics in the 1994 "Wolf"), but for me it was too distracting, as it looked too fake. Actually, she's the ONLY ape who looks fake.In addition to the make-up, costumes (Burton's regular Colleen Atwood) and sets, I realized that what makes the apes especially realistic is their movement and their use of space (jumping all the times, using trees and roots, etc.). This aspect is another credit point for Burton, who always put special attention to the behavior and movement of the characters (Lisa Marie as the Martian Girl in "Mars Attacks!" immediately comes to mind) and made the actors go to "ape school".Danny Elfman's score is always fantastic and this one is no exception. The use of primitive tools and jungle motives in the main titles is great. It starts quietly, as a simplified and primitive tune and builds up (as usual in Danny's themes) to a march piece of heavy metal instruments, "like bars closing in", as one review described it. While the theme reminded me past works such as "Men in Black" and "Dead Presidents", other cues reminded me of Danny's earlier works such as "Mars Attacks!", "Edward Scissorhands", "Batman Returns" and the "March of the Dead" from "Army of Darkness". Now that I listen to the soundtrack, the final part of the track titled "The Return", which ends the movie, seems to be highly influenced by the work of Bernard Herrmann (Danny's mentor).One thing that I liked about the plot *SPOILER ALERT* is the added explanation for the apes being "smart" - the genetic treatment, which is unfortunately ruined totally later on (I think. Depends on how you understand the ending). *END OF SPOILER*Two bits that made the movie entertaining for me were the parts of Limbo, the slave trader (played by the hilarious Paul Giamatti), and the two guest appearances by Glenn Shadix and Lisa Marie (as Senator Nado and Nova) - I wish they had a bigger part in the movie.And now to the things I didn't like:First of all - Estella Warren. From the very first moment she appears on screen, early in the movie, I felt her casting is wrong. Except for putting her as an attraction for the male audience (me amongst them), I saw no reason for using an amazing blonde model, dressed in small rags, for this part. It simply distracts you from the movie and damages its realism. I wanted to see Lisa Marie in this role, just so she could have a bigger part, but this one wouldn't solve the real drawback -Aside for the casting of Estella Warren, the role of Daena (and her entire family, for that matter) seems absolutely redundant - She has almost no interaction with the hero, and seems to exist only to fill the role of the traditional "blonde girl the hero kisses at the end" - not to mention that this kiss seems completely out of place, since they had no interaction before that. The same, though on a smaller scale, goes for the rest of her family, which seems to be "dragging" along with the hero for no apparent reason.I think the biggest drawback of the movie has to be its script. There are lots of things to say about it, and I'm not sure where to start. Here are several points: The script (especially the last quarter) seems like a big mishmash of bits from the movies in the earlier series; The script has no "social meaning" at all - the writers seem to have taken an everyday-life cruel behavior towards animals (and a politically-correct objector) and reverse the roles, without debating any valuable issue; None of the characters seemed to have depth and we get no reason for Ari being so fond of the ugly humans; *MAJOR SPOILERS ALERT* The fact that the apes and humans, who live as primitives without any technology and don't know what a gun is, are not a bit surprised by digital gadgets, spaceships and "a weapon that blow-up everyone", in addition to the fact that is made by primitive humans who can't invent anything; The ending that didn't make much sense to me, other than trying to give a shock and a surprise that would be different from the one in the original movie - one which you simply can not top; This in addition to the disappointment in revealing (a minute earlier) that the "planet of the apes" is indeed a strange planet and not Earth (which, as I mentioned earlier, destroys the rather good logic that was built up to this point). For a moment I thought the writers were trying to play a trick on us: because we were expecting to hear that the humans destroyed Earth, we instead see that apes have overtaken Earth - so perhaps they are the ones to destroy it? But then, the earlier planet is not Earth; There also seem to be some plot-holes concerning the time traveling, both of the money and the spaceship itself; I also found it highly unbelievably, after the money came down from the skies, that all of the apes, who up until then considered humans to be filthy and primitive, decide in an instant that humans and apes are equal - the only reason for that seemed to be that the writers needed to get to the end of the movie. *END OF SPOILERS*

While this film is visually far superior to the original from 1968, the plot and characters fall far short, due mostly to a poorly written script and some wooden acting. Burton's style is out in full force on this one, and it works very well for the film, but the plot dives into action when it should be focusing on plot & character development. The first third or so of the movie works very well, homaging the original while retaining its own style. Unfortunately, the story falters and the suspense, horror, and sci-fi thrills - which were built up very well - are sacrificed for the sake of big action scenes. The final battle is a complete mass, topped only by the unbelievable, albeit intriguing, ending. The twist defies logic in all its forms, but it's still cool to see. A disappointment, to be sure. Something tells me this would have worked much better as a sci-fi horror/thriller than an action/adventure.There are some intriguing concepts at play within the film, mostly dealing with the evolution of the apes and their culture. The fact that they all evolved from the monkeys that the humans took with them is quite an ingenious idea, made even more so by the fact that the apes all worship these simple monkeys. A nice jab at our own religious beliefs when Ari states that their story of creation is nothing more than a fairy tale. The ape culture is interesting because of its apparent similarity to, yet stark difference from, our own - seems to suggest that evolution turns out the same regardless of species. A thought, though - if the apes evolved from the monkeys who rebelled against the humans, then where did the humans on the planet come from? Definitely a plot hole. Still, the overall concept is quite good, marred unnecessarily by the poor storyline.Technically, the film is superb. The makeup, costumes, production design, music and special effects are all top-notch and very cool. The apes look, act, and move like real animals, not just humans in monkey suits. The score, especially during the opening credits, is excellent and quite appropriate for the film. The ape village is very Burtonesque, which suits it well. Some of the early scenes are startling in their dark beauty. Most of the cool shots in this movie are in the first half, save the final scene. The second half goes awry with silly battle scenes and lame attempts at character development. Once again, the script is to blame. The acting is all over the place, ranging from scenery-chewing (Roth) to mediocre (Wahlberg) to downright bad (the blond chick). In general, the apes seem to do a much better job than the humans - not sure why Burton felt the need to make the humans talk in this one; the muteness of humanity in the original is one of the contributing factors to its greatness. The only human that should matter in this film is the lead character - the rest of the humans are just animals to the apes, and if they can talk, it ruins the idea. Still, the film looks beautiful.All in all, this was a great disappointment. A director as visually skilled as Burton, a classic film just itching to be remade, and loads of money for effects? It's too bad the script fell far short - this would have been a modern classic. Still, the first half or so is great to just look at, if you ignore the inane plot and annoying characters. The twist, however cool, is nothing more than a sorry attempt to top the original's ending - but it's not happening. Burton should have just stuck to homaging the original ending, rather than trying to beat it. Maybe have Wahlberg encounter an ape Statue of Liberty - that would have been cool. Overall, a beautiful film marred by a poor script.

reviews.review_title: Could have been a lot better!
reviews.content: This remake of the Planet of the Apes was okay. I feel the movie was not well-written. The characters are way too underdeveloped (especially Wahlberg's). The movie does have a great sense of artistic direction (the scenery, make-up and props are very enticing and alluring). However, I feel the movie moved at a way too easy by-the-numbers pace. There was never any real drama or suspense invested into the script. The interaction between the characters is often stale and almost wishing to be something more redeeming. Another aspect that really confused me was regarding the humans on the ape planet. These humans were obviously able to speak, thus they were intelligent. So, why were these humans unable to have formed a much stronger resistance to the apes?  (In the original Planet of the Apes movie, the native humans were more underdeveloped like cavemen who still could not speak.) The ending of the 2001 remake was too weak and only guarantees us the possiblity that someone else might provide us with another sequel.My advice: catch this movie on cable and don't bother to rent or buy it.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as often said, however not as great as the original!
reviews.content: Boy, I went with the greatest expectations to the cinema, because I´m a huge fan of Franklin J. Schaffner´s unique Sci-fi classic! And yes, there are three plausible reasons to watch this film:1) Estella Warren is damn hot!2) Tim Roth is giving another over the top-performance!!3) The make-up F/X of Rick Baker are really outstanding!!!But...This is a typical Hollywood mainstream production! The end is a cliché and the snappish satire from the brilliant original is totally missing! Instead of it you`re getting a breathtaking, but finally also very empty popcorn movie, enriched with some pseudo-moral..! Actors like Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan or Paul Giamatti are doing solid jobs, but the excellent Roddy McDowall, who played Cornelius/Cesar, can´t be replaced be anyone!! Not a bad film at all, but definitely not as great as the original!!!

reviews.review_title: Nothing like the original, which is pretty much the point.
reviews.content: I have read the other user comments and found that you were complaining that it was nothing like the original.  Well, you're right, but that was Tim Burton's point.  It isn't a remake or a sequel, just simply Burton's take on it.I thought that this movie was very entertaining.  Mark Whalberg was pretty good, Micheal Clark Duncan was great, but the real credit goes to Tim Roth as the evil Thade.  My mom thought that he was pretty scary and almost left the theatre.But there was one thing that was wierd, which many people have pointed out: The Ending.  It was pretty twisted, but I'll buy the DVD to see the other endings.Well, I'm gonna go see the movie again because I love Tim Burton and the movie is really cool, (half of the credit goes to Rick Baker's make-up, which will no doubt be nomminated for an oscar)HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

(spoiler warning)No matter what can be said about the remaking of classic films, "Planet of the Apes" makes for the best of them. This can be attributed to not being very much like the original since only some basic premises and plot lines are the same. And being so lush with fantastic scenery, great makeup and effects, the 2001 edition is much more exciting to watch, despite being a little less concerned with afterthought. Tim Burton is a favorite of mine. His dreamscapes are sometimes a tad lacking in the meaning department, but they are always resplendent with true artistic ambitions. "Planet of the Apes" is no exception.One could argue about some of the differences from the first movie of 1968. A major one is making humans able to speak, which can be seen as a weak spot. Though helping Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) considerably, this "new" feature makes some of the philosophizing somewhat dimmer - the apes ask themselves whether humans have souls. But would one actually argue that a being that is able to form its own thougts and speak them would not have one? I wonder. On the other hand, since Davidson is responsible for the entire future scenario on this planet of apes, ancient grudges can make the apes selective in their thinking: humans tortured them for so long. Philosophic arguments might not go a long way with them.Humor is an important ingredient in the new "Planet of the Apes". While the original is sternly sober and not very witty at all (Heston's grim look is heavy to bear), this one flirts quite handsomely with human characteristics transferred to apes. Very funny and Burton-esque. I also appreciate the careful depiction of the apes movements and behavior. While clearly developed beyond their ancestors, the apes still retain a great deal of "monkey" characteristics - growling, aggressiveness and jumping around rather than walking. The original "Planet of the Apes" had the monkeys walking around much like ordinary humans, which flattened some of the impact.Still, it is unnecessary to compare them in other respects, since the new one is not really a remake and not really a sequel either. I for one welcome it. It doesn't contain the same degree of commentary on humanity that the 1968 movie did, but that one is not anywhere near as spectacular. A good job. I bow my head to Tim Burton and his crew.

reviews.review_title: Wow, the apes really need some prozak!
reviews.content: I know, the apes being villains, that they're not supposed to be the nicest of characters, but isn't it a little unrealistic that EVERY SINGLE ONE OF THEM walks around all day grunting and growling?
