The only apes in this remake that aren't mad all the time are Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and Limbo (Paul Giammatti), and that's only because Ari is the "hero ape woman" and Limbo the comic relief.  Of course, the humans in "Planet of the Apes" aren't really any better.  They're either really nervous all of the time, or really angry.  Maybe if both races calmed down a little, they'd have some peace!Aside from the prozak prescription, this was a reasonable remake.  Not Burton's best, not by far, but his directing it makes it a lot better. The fight scenes are entertaining, and Tim Roth delivers as the evil General Thade.  Unfortunately, Roth is the only actor who delivers a great performance.  Sure, the others weren't bad, but they didn't match Roth's ability to basically "become the ape".  Even Oscar nominee Michael Clarke Duncan moves a little roboticly sometimes.Still, a good, dark sci-fi thriller, 7.5/10.

reviews.review_title: What in the world? (May contain some spoilers)
reviews.content: Ok, I don't get the ending AT ALL.  What does it mean and how could that happen.  I knew there was going to be a surprise ending, but that was shocking.  Is it even possible for them to have a Planet of the Apes 2? What would he have to do, go back and fix it or something!  I thought the movie was good in some parts and i enjoyed watching it.  I just thought that it was weird!  But its a great movie if you are thinking about going to see it.

reviews.review_title: Unmemorable but honourable attempt to revitalise the Planet series
reviews.content: During a failed detour, Air Force astronaut Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) lands on an alien planet where apes rule the world and humans are their slaves. It is pretty much a straight forward remake of the 1968 sci-fi classic as opposed to the recent Andy Serkis fronted reboots which takes the premise in a different way. There are pretty good moments including the opening titles which are delightfully scored by Danny Elfman, making us feel we are certainly in Burton's take of this world. Tim Roth is very good as General Thade; a sadistic warrior ape who is frighteningly murderous and untrustworthy. Roth has a lot of fun with the role and does provide the films standout moment towards the end, delving into the scary energy that chimpanzees can have. The classic twist ending is effectively done and a good homage to the original. Paul Giamatti is also pretty good as the comic relief of the film and it's a helluva role! The production was documented as pretty troubled. As soon as Tim was recruited to direct, there was already a release date a year away as the studio were desperate to start the franchise up again. Script rewrites were being done while sets were being made just weeks before shooting began. Under immense studio pressure, the shoot sounded stressful and tight with editing having to take place in conjunction with the shooting. All the while undergoing personal issues, it's no wonder that the film unfortunately doesn't fully stand up on its own. It's no fault of any crew or cast member who do give it their all; it's just circumstance and bad timing culminating in a rushed and churned out Hollywood flick. There's a certain charm however to seeing Rick Baker's ape make-up work which is a nice homage to the original while also embellishing on their more animalistic mannerisms. It also marks the first collaboration with Helena Bonham Carter who has started a family with Burton since and went on to star in all of his films throughout the '00s

Oh, my god it has finally happened: Tim Burton has directed an absolute stinker. From the opening minutes, where Wahlberg gets on a rescue-mission for his chimp (!) to its final "surprise"-ending (which is everything, but no surprise) this movie goes nowhere. No action, no script, no suspense and no sense at all - not even good visuals, which Burton is known for. What made the director and the producers believe that this is a movie? It seems as if the whole crew had no idea what they were doing. The acting - especially by "star" Mark Wahlberg, who once again proves that maybe he is the most overrated actor ever to emerge from Hollywood - but also by theater veterans Roth and Bonham-Carter - is completely dull. Well, at least it fits the movie. Be sure to miss this one, you could spend your money in a more reasonable way- like throwing it away!

reviews.review_title: "You apes sure made a monkey / You fine-lee made a mon-kee out of meeee!!!"
reviews.content: Um... okay.Well, this is darn near indistinguishable from the original "Planet" except that it *looks* better.  That's funny, you see, because the original *sounds* better, so to speak.So, what about the Surprise Ending?I won't spoil the THREE (count 'em) surprise endings.  The first two were pretty darn obvious.  The last doesn't leave you much to think about except for the nasty, bile-like taste of subverted racism.

reviews.review_title: If it weren't for Tim Roth......
reviews.content: I really wanted to like this film.  I went in pumped up but left feeling disappointed because I probably expected too much.  They did a good job distancing themselves from the original film.  This film has a surprise ending that's not as good as the one in the original (which is my favourite ending in ANY film) but is still very nightmarish.  Unfortunately this movie's mid section drags mercilessly and I wanted to leave the theatre.  It starts off very well and ends well in the last 40 minutes or so but about 45 minutes in the middle of the film is just plain bland.  Mark Wahlberg wasn't well casted.  I didn't buy him as an astronaut and adventurer at all. Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan and especially Tim Roth all have their characters nailed down perfectly.  Roth's General Thade may be one of the top five villains in movie history.  The savage nature of his portrayal made him a great sadist and the make-up spoke a lot for him as well.  Rick Baker could earn another Oscar for his make-up work but Tim Burton was not the man to direct such heavy material.  Burton is good for decorative pop culture stuff found in comic books ('Batman') or heavy indoor and artsy production design stuff like 'Pee Wee's Big Adventure' or 'Beetlejuice' but somehow he just couldn't get me excited enough to embrace this remake of a legendary motion picture.

Well, a typical burton movie some would say. I agree to a certain extent. Burton means a good looking movie with a pretty bad script, but he most often get away with it. Sleepy Hollows is excellent for example.This movie however, has a really really bad script. There are plotholes all over and the ending is terrible. One would think that since he based it on a idea very well covered before that the script would be easy to make into something marvelous. But instead it was predictable and full of plotholes. I will not mention them here since a few of you might not have seen to movie, but trust me on this one.The actors taking the shapes of apes are excellent, and they do a good enough job. Mark Wahlberg is stiff and doesn't really feel like he is in a perilous situation, but that is mostly because of his lack of lines, he says very little, asks almost nothing it doesn't really fit in what a person would do in his situation. You don't really get to know any of the characters.So, pretty good effects, lousy script, a typical burton movie, but in this case, the script is so bad and the effects not good enough to make watching it worthwhile.

While it's not possible to fully talk about this movie without taking the ending into account-- which I'm not going to do-- I will say that no matter WHAT the ending turned out to be, it was definitely not worth sitting through this dull, boring, illogical mess.The make-up is fantastic.  Let's get that out of the way right now, so that we may focus on how uninteresting any of the story or characters were.  Mark Wahlberg coasts through this one, with no character to play, other than a very animalistic, primal human (ironic, no?) who only wants to get back home.  Helena Bonham-Carter and Tim Roth have some fun (and give fun performances) playing their parts, but any political commentary is lost as each scene is just an excuse to blow something up, smash set pieces, or set something on fire.As an action movie, it's so-so.  As a clever, thinking-person's film (which is what the original movie was and is), it fails completely.  In 5 years, no one will remember this "re-do" ever existed.6/10.  Make-up and special effects are NOT enough to make it a good movie. Will someone take away William Broyles Jr.'s parking pass, please?
Ok remake of P.o.A's series. Had the Tim Burton feel, nice cameo's by a few old stars, great special affects to boot!

Lush settings and advanced makeup artistry are the highlights of Tim Burton's quasi-remake of the 1968 Franklin Shaffner film (itself based on Pierre Boulez' novel) but there isn't as much of interest going on here as there was in the first film. It's an action film, pure and simple. Whatever political comment Shaffner's film had is bleached out of the screenplay (by William Broyles, Jr. who penned `Cast Away', Lawrence Konner and Mark D. Rosenthal); about the only stance the film takes is on the humane treatment of animals and the topic isn't nearly provocative enough in this context. There's a large cast, including Mark Wahlberg (not yet enough of a presence to carry an action lead), Helena Bonham Carter (as stuffy as usual, even in full ape costume), Estella Warren, Paul Giamatti and, as the villain, Tim Roth. Everyone seems to be enjoying themselves but their performances are definitely in a minor key. Burton himself seems to have a curious disinterest in the project and none of the passion that infuses `Sleepy Hollow', `Beetlejuice' and even the misbegotten `Mars Attacks!' is evident here. Still, it's a passable, entertaining diversion with a flair for big screen excitement.

reviews.review_title: Remake of "Fistful of dollars" using Klingons?
reviews.content: Tim Roth's "original" villian seems to stem from the touchy-feely evil Ramon/Indio villain in "Fistful of dollars/Few dollars more" spaghetti westerns (titles which sum up what this remake is all about). The bonanza of great effects make for great entertainment but the lack of a visionary story make this a one-dimensional kid's movie which won't stick in the brain for adults. There is no "discussion" on the moral/philosphical place of man in the universe: in the original book/movie, our hero is clearly divided since he neither fits in with the future's primitive humans nor the apes. This version is just another uncompelling "Us vs. Them," and the war-like gorillas sound and look like Klingons in "Star Trek." Speaking of gorillas, whom did they evolve from since there were originally only chimps? Where do they live, since there are too many for that hilltown? Where did the modern-speaking humans come from if the caucasian astronauts all died? Why does the blonde babe keep ducking out of scenes - does she have a bladder like a thimble? And are we on earth in the far future or far past? Or another dimension? This last plot problem ruins the great visual ending (try as it might to be like the book's end). The soundtrack also doesn't credit it's inspiration to the better original. For those who absurdly claim we need remakes because kids won't watch the originals, it was we kids who loved the original enough to generate 4 sequels, a live-action and animated TV series, lunch boxes, etc. and inspire Tim Burton.

reviews.review_title: Not what I was hoping for, sadly.
reviews.content: I am a HUGE Tim Burton fan, the only two films I don't *love* of his are Ed Wood and Beetlejuice, sadly, Planet of the Apes was very close to falling into this category also.There were a lot of things going for the film which were realised at times, the feel of the planet is great, the acting is generally top-notch, the soundtrack is fantastic and the ending - although unfathomable - was atleast unexpected, and that's good in a strange way.Where it failed was in the HUGE plots holes and convenient devices used to drive along the story. All the plot-holes have been mentioned elsewhere in this review section, suffice it to say, there is little ways of getting around most of them. They just don't make sense ! - and the chimp saving the day was a very poor way to end it.The actual plot runs thin half-way through the movie and the final battle was rather anti-climatic I thought. I will go and see a sequel if there is one, but with a lot less excitement than I had for this film.I can't say it wasn't good, because I never looked at my watch during the cinema, but it wasn't the best BLOCKBUSTER SUMMER movie of the year (that was Jurassic Park 3 and earlier Bridget Jones and Hannibal), but it was entertaining enough. Sadly I will always feel the *most* apt word for the movie is "Disappointing".Yd.

I never saw the original 1968 Planet of the Apes, which was extremely popular but I decided to give the 2001 version a watch. Tim Burton once again proves just how great and Gothic that he can direct a movie, Burton has the darkest touch of anyone in Hollywood. Being a Bigfoot enthusiast a movie like Planet of the Apes is just a must see for me. This movie is more than just about a human who has to battle an ape for the rights to get along on the planet. Apes are shown and portrayed as being very smart and clever Burton must have done his homework as he well showed in this movie for example apes bury their dead and of course they can't swim, and Bigfoots are the same way! I strongly believe that apes and bigfoots are among us all anywhere that is proven with the ending of this film!

I can't help but think that people who call this movie 'horrible' are mean spirited. In fact, one reviewer gives a completely false description of how ape civilization started which makes me think he hasn't even seen the movie, but is only spreading bad hype. Folks, maybe you haven't seen some of the other movies that came out this year, but compared to the likes of "Mummy Returns", "JPIII", "Swordfish" etc., Tim Burton's POTA is a modern-day "Citizen Kane".I understand people don't like to see their favorite movie remade, but that's no reason to diss this movie. Besides, it's not a remake, it's a re-imaging.The original movie was a social commentary. The new POTA is a sci-fi action summer movie, and I don't see anything wrong with that especially if it's done the way Tim Burton did it. Racial inequality and fear of nuclear annihilation don't plague the world as much as they did in 1968. The story line is basically same.The acting is top-notch as opposed to the original's melodramatic and sometimes over-the-top acting. Mark Wahlberg gives a subtle and understated performance. Paul Giamatti provides great comic relief. And can you say Academy Award Nominee for Tim Roth and Helena Bonham-Carter. There are a lot of complaints about bad dialog. I must have overheard it, because I don't remember any cheesy or nonsense lines.The ending was fascinating. In two years, no other movie, besides Memento, made me think about it as much. The makeup and cinematography are absolutely amazing, as is the kick-ass score. I see how someone could get frustrated with the ending, because it makes you make use of those damn brain cells. Tim Burton used the original novel's ending, so when you trash the ending, you also trash a sci-fi classic.So don't listen to all the bad hype. Go see the movie and make up your own mind.

reviews.review_title: Mediocre and mildly disappointing remake which lacks imagination.
reviews.content: Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes is a very disappointing addition to his other films. Having seen Batman, Beetlejuice and Mars Attacks! I am surprised to see this unwelcome addition to his list. To be fair though, this is probably his first mediocre film. Its not a disaster and it has its good moments, but there's not enough fresh material in it to make it very memorable. Mark Wahlberg is the film's `hero' but the role really doesn't suit him. While in films like Boogie Nights and The Yards he had good supporting players, in Planet of the Apes he just can't carry the role. On the other hand, Tim Roth is very moody in his role as Thade, the film's menace. Helena Bonham Carter is good as the female monkey with a heart, but the make-up is unconvincing. Most of the other performances are standard but nothing award-winning. The film's direction is surprisingly bland giving Burton's usual atmospheric style. There has been a lot of controversy about the ending. I for one liked it and although it was a big surprise, I thought it was very clever. Overall, Planet of the Apes isn't a bad movie, but it could have been much better. It's good fodder for the eyes but after watching it, you'll probably forget about it straight away. 5.3 out of 10.

Very good indeed, more actions and better theme song. I am about to give a 9 rating for this one but the ending is simply disappointed. Also, that is not a good idea to change America's national heritage to something ridiculous. Although i am not American, i think this is not acceptable.Anyway, about the story, well, at first very impressive opening theme and story. It goes well until almost the end of the movie, the last five minutes of the scene which might some audiences confused. But, a totally enjoyable movie to be seen. Well done.

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton's Unique Different Kind Different Version Of Planet Of The Apes Which i Thought Was Pretty Okay.
reviews.content: Mark Whalberg Plays An Astrosnahnt Who's Space Pod Has Landed On a Deserted Apocalyptic Planet Which it Has Population Happened To Be Taking Over By Apes As He Leads a Group Of Human Fighters To Go Up Against The Apes. The Film Also Stars Michael Clarke Duncan, Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Paul Giamatti, Estella Warren, Kris Kristofferson And The Original Planet Of The Apes Star Charlton Heston. i Thought Tim Burton Did a Very interesting Take On a Planet Of The Apes And The Story To it.

reviews.review_title: Avoid the comparisons. Just enjoy it.
reviews.content: So many people are angered about this film... it's quite obvious something is going on here.Mainly, the fact that, being a remake, this movie had to stand up to the original one. A huge risk that Tim Burton took, and seemingly, with bad consequences.I was born 6 years after Charlton Heston went bananas on the original. I have *never* seen it. Once it was on TV, and I lost interest after five minutes. Not because it was a bad film, mind you, but because it looked too dated for me to watch, and I was in that terrible phase known as "adolescence". It would have been uncool to watch a '68 movie. I will correct this mistake later, when I buy the original "Apes".Anyway, I came into the movie theater with only one image of the original movie forever burned in my mind: the epic Statue of Liberty climax. I purposely avoided all reviews of this film, so as not to spoil the fun. And I found myself deeply immersed in another Burton fantasy, where reality is as dark and grim as the lush landscapes that are always depicted in his worlds of madness. He is an expert in depicting outcasts (as in Batman, Sleepy Hollow and Edward Scissorhands), and although Mark Wahlberg wasn't as strong as Johnny Depp, Jack Skellington (or even Michael Keaton) as a main character, he was credible enough. Helena Bonham Carter is still incredibly seductive, even under tons of makeup and (gasp!) a beard. The rest of the characters are convincingly depicted, and the makeup excels.Again, not knowing the plot of the original, the only thing I disliked about this movie was that during the first half hour it dragged a bit. I guess that was due to the number of characters that were introduced. Afterwards, the movie turns quite philosophical (at least, IMHO). Was it directed at racism (which, from what I've seen, is still alive in the U.S.)? At animal cruelty? Was it a veiled message that we, as a thinking race, are doomed to remain evil and cruel with each other for all time? Or was Burton only trying to entertain us? (I doubt the last assumption). Whatever it is, this is one of those rare movies that open up a world of possibilities due to the use of metaphors. In a way, very similar to fairy tales, where the main character has to have enough resources to thrive and survive in a hostile environment...*SPOILER AHEAD* *SPOILER AHEAD* *SPOILER AHEAD* ...that is, unless you realize this is a mythic story and not a fairy tale, and that the ending has an amazing twist. One that, if sequels are avoided, could be one of the best endings in *ages*.Mr. Tim Burton, please, DON'T make a sequel, and you will have done a homage to the original series. The ending is just *perfect* as it is.I hope watching the original movie doesn't change my mind about this one.

Tim Burton... Planet of the Apes... what could be a better combination? Well, pretty much anything. I was very disappointed by this movie. First the good - it is visually stunning, as you would expect from a Burton movie; there are a couple of good performances, particularly Helena Bonham Carter who is outstanding. Sadly that's it.Now let's get to the bad and the ugly. The story is so full of plot holes that you'll weep with anger. Didn't anyone bother to read the script? Its nonsense. Characters do things that are obviously absurd and have no internal logic. An example (warning: very minor spoiler), when they get to a river crossing guarded by part of the Ape army, Leo tells us that they can't go around because they don't have time - they have to ride through. But then they wait hours until the dead of night before doing that. The only reason they wait is to make the visuals of the "ride through the camp" scene more dramatic. This makes no sense. It is literally nonsense. And don't even get me started on the ending... its meaningless.Its not just one scene, almost every point in the movie is gibberish if you think about it for more than 2 seconds.Beyond that the characterizations are non-existent. Apart from Leo and a couple of the apes, no one has a character. Who on earth are the humans? What motivates them? Would we care about them if they all got thrown into a giant meat grinder? No we would not.What is most annoying is that this could have been a great movie. The visual execution is stunning. The apes look real and move as you would expect an evolved ape to. They must have spent so many hours and so much money on that aspect of the film. Why did they only spend 26 minutes and $2.80 on the script?Finally, however much of a cliche it has become and however cheesy the costumes where, the 1968 film at least tried to be about something and its famous ending was genuinely related to the point of the film and was truly shocking. The new Planet of the Apes has no point; its ending is a crass setup for a sequel. What a waste of a great potential.

reviews.review_title: A fine technical achievement that falls flat because of its lack of a good story.
reviews.content: Tim Burtons interpretation of The Planet Of The Apes isn't the complete disaster it was labelled.It is by no means a great film either.The good things about the film are all in the technical arena.The makeup and costume design are inspired,some of the best i have ever seen.The visual effects are top drawer but the film is let down by a wafer thin plot with a head scratching ending that seems to be more of a homage to the classic original film than a conclusion in itself.Tim Burtons visual talents are on display here but he doesn't seem to have much direction with his film.Its almost as if he decided to make a Planet Of The Apes film before an idea had been decided on.A so so experience.

Here's a rarity - a review of POTA that's not a rave or a pan. 
Obviously it is a good-looking film, with terrific costumes, photography and make-up.  It is also usually compelling storytelling - not Pierre Boulle's PLANET but not the original film either.  Points for originality for sure. I like that the humans could speak - their lack of speech in the first film was never effectively explained.  Even though the film is fleet, there is a noticable lull after Neil and company have successfully fled ape city. Burton wisely gets right on to the film's conclusion and (surprise) ending post haste.  But while the story flies by, the character development is non-existant and the love story is divided between the female of TWO species.  To be fair, our leading man is not the most compelling actor - but Heston was no Olivier either.  The story has multiple holes - where did the horses come from anyway? There's no sign of any non-ape or human life except these equines but no clue is given as to why there are no other creatures about.  The cameos by Heston and Harrison are badly handled though the refs to first film are fun for fans.  The surprise ending manages to combine the shock of the original with the option for a sequel.Burton's film lacks the scope and epic feel of it's inspiration and it will doubtless join the LOST IN SPACE film on the rental shelves.  Now if someone were to make Boulle's vision - that would be something.

reviews.review_title: a movie that deserves a sequel (CONTAINS MASSIVE SPOILERS)
reviews.content: first of all I must say that I am one of those who really liked this movie, one of the most anticipated ever. Perhaps my expectations were lowered after the initial negative reaction by the press, but I was pleasantly surprised at the intelligence, professionalism, and self-awareness of this blockbuster. It was a re-imagining of the planet ruled by apes concept in the best sense of the word; it is taken in a direction completely different and fresh than the original movie. I was chhering through every minute of this film, because like all Tim Burton movies, everything came to together and worked marvelously: the characters were engaging and the story was interesting. The ending was, in my opinion, the icing on the cake. I knew there was going to be a shock ending when I went in, and actually sort of predicted halfway through when Charlton Heston's character started explaining the plot threads. It may not make complete sense, but works within the film's context and wraps it up in an appropriately cheesy way. But I think they should start thinking about a sequel. Leo Davidson's further adventures on OUR planet of the apes. They should show Thade as ruler of the world or president, that would be hilarious. It would again take the ruling apes concept in an entirely new direction. They should bring the entire cast from the remake back and have some other A-list director make it and Burton producing it. Also try and give a reasonably believable explanation of the final events in the story. I think they would make a very entertaining and interesting movie. You listening 20th Century Fox?

reviews.review_title: I have to say it. Tim Burton's retelling of Planet...
reviews.content:
I have to say it. Tim Burton's retelling of Planet of the Apes is more fun than a barrel of monkeys.OK, that's off my chest. No more monkey puns, I promise.Seriously, though, Planet of the Apes is one rip-roarin' summer outing, filled with thrills, action, adventure, wit and bits of funny (dare I say, monkey) business. I know, I know, I promised.And for those film buffs who are fond of the original, Burton's version includes a couple tips of the hat to that movie.Mark Wahlberg stars as Capt. Leo Davidson, a deep-space pilot whose ship gets drawn into a magnetic field and hurled into the future. He crash lands on a planet where apes are the dominant species and humans are hunted, captured and sold into slavery.Despite being darker than the original, Burton's film is not as heavy handed nor as sanctimonious.Some of the movie's flashes of humor are surreal as well as typically Burton: An organ-grinder ape with a midget or an elderly ape taking off a wig and removing false teeth as he prepares for bed. Then there are the parents who buy a little girl as a pet for there young daughter. The seller advises the parents to get rid of the girl before she reaches puberty: "One thing you don't want in your house is a human teen-ager," he says. You don't have to be an ape to realize the truth in that statement. Touches such as these are what stamps this movie with Burton's brand.Lines that hearken back to the original movie are sprinkled throughout: The first words spoken by an ape to Davidson as the astronaut is regaining consciousness and grabs the simian's foot to try righting himself are: "Take your stinking hand off of me, you damned, dirty human." Anyone familiar with the first version of the film will, of course, recognize the irony in that piece of dialogue.Another of Burton's in-jokes is to have Charlton Heston, star of the original, play the chimpanzee father of Tim Roth's Gen. Thade. The young chimp goes to visit his dying father. Both have one thing in common, a hatred of humans. With his dying breath, the elder spews out his vile: "Damn them, damn them all to hell," he says before expiring. That is the famous line Heston's Taylor shouted at the conclusion of the original after discovering the planet's terrible secret.The performances throughout are top-notch. Wahlberg plays Davidson not as some gung-ho hero, but as a confused and somewhat frightened explorer who only wants to return home. He is reluctant to lead the human rebellion; his only objective being to find a way off this upside-down planet. This hesitation is what makes his character believable and vulnerable.Roth is ferocious, cunning, cruel and savage as the fascist chimp who wants to rid his planet of all vestiges of humanity. He leaps and bounds as if he had springs on his feet. It is a masterful turn.Helena Bonham Carter is Ari, the chimp who believes that apes and humans can live in peace and as equals. Hers is a smart, compassionate characterization.Michael Clarke Duncan is big and brutal as Attar the gorilla aid to Thade who blindly follows his leader until his faith is shaken.
A fine comic outing is given by Paul Giamatti as Limbo, the ape slave trader making a living off the misery of the humans he captures. As the battle between apes and humans looms, the cowardly Limbo pleads, "Can't we all just get along," echoing the words of Rodney King.Much of the success of Planet of the Apes goes to Burton's technical crew, especially production designer Rick Heinrichs and the legendary Rick Baker who created the ape makeup.Burton's musical collaborator, Danny Elfman, provides another fine score, though it is not as memorable as his work on Batman or Sleepy Hollow.The movie's only letdown comes at the very end where Burton tries to outshock the finale from the 1968 original. He comes close, but falls short.Otherwise, Planet of the Apes is what a summer movie should be: An amusement park ride filled with lots of action, stunts and a few laughs. This is one feature in which the expectations lived up to the pre-release hype.

ahhh, finally a Hollywood action blockbuster with an intriguing story! Here is the best film of 2001 so far bar none! Critics are just critics, and will never be able to enjoy a movie without picking it apart. This was a marvelous film in so many ways. The script is extremely well written and keeps you guessing. In the end you'll be dazzled and confused, but no less amazed! What made this film so enjoyable was the grand sense of humor and pacing. It was never boring and some of the apes were hilarious. The ending, which has been much talked about, is wonderfully twisted and different than usual. Wouldn't it have been boring if Wahlberg just came back to Earth with a happy ending? Knowing Tim Burton you know something weird had to happen. Wahlberg gave a great performance as the earnest astronaut. From the opening scenes I knew this film would be great. The credits sequence was extremely imaginative and beautifully done. Everything in the film was superbly done. Ape City was truly eye-popping. I couldn't tell if it was done by computer or models. I loved Charlton Heston's little cameo. He really explained the mechanics of the story in just one scene. And it's a fascinating story at that. I highly recommend this film. It's probably best if you haven't seen the original, since I haven't and I really enjoyed this one. So go see it and have an old-fashioned good time at the movies. Best summer action film of the year.

The latest version of 'Planet of the Apes' is an interesting misfire. It has a lot of ideas, good and bad, and seems unable to distinguish between the two, and ends up emphasizing the bad ones more than the good. In a very broad sense, it follows the general idea of the 1968 film, that of a world where apes rule and mankind is considered inferior, and of a time-travelling astronaut who becomes stranded there. The apes behave quite differently in this film though. They are apparently meant to behave like real apes, aside from the fact that they are more intelligent and can speak. So they growl, screech, roar and leap all over the place when excited. An ape army leader, General Thade (Tim Roth), is particularly savage in his manner; the other ape characters seem generally less so. Mark Wahlberg plays the astronaut, Captain Leo Davidson, who is stranded on the planet. He has one of two reactions to any situation- annoyance or confusion. Or both. His one-note, furrow-browed performance doesn't allow the audience much emotional involvement in his plight. As the female ape who cares, Helena Bonham Carter's character Ari very much recalls Dr. Zira from the earlier movie. Here though her interest in Leo seems much more than a professional or humanitarian one; she obviously has the hots for him but don't worry, nothing along those lines ever happens. Carter gives far and away the most credible and nuanced performance, however her ape make-up is far too 'cute,' and provides a constant distraction. Perhaps the main thing missing from this 'Planet of the Apes' is a hero. Wahlberg is definitely no Charlton Heston and it's apparent the script never intended him to be. In fact, despite a few back-and-forth gags vis-a-vis human/ape behavior and stereotypes, it's hard to know exactly how this film wants us to feel about the planet's society and its treatment of humans. (Probably the funniest line in the movie has to do with getting rid of human 'pets' before they reach puberty- "Believe me, you don't want a human teenager in your house!") The huge battle between apes and humans at the end is pointless and unsatisfying, and the tacked-on epilogue is just downright stupid and reeks of desperation to find some kind of clever ending. Rod Serling would not be pleased.

Unbelievable as it may sound, the actors sound like they're speaking... from behind masks. I mean, some of them were paid millions of dollars to do nothing but talk - you can't recognize them and their faces don't move - yet their voices are muffled and their pronunciation is inhibited. It gets worse - they each move in a different style, as if none of them went to the same monkey school. Thirty years after the first realistic monkeyman prosthetics were developed for A SPACE ODYSSEY comes this incredible failure, featuring makeup as bad as that in the original PLANET and its weak TV-budget sequels, and movement training that so far from helped the actors, they seem neither monkey nor man, but simply fake.And that's just the monkeys. Every set looks like a set. Every costume looks like a costume. Every line of dialog screams, "Written for a summer picture!" The lapses in logic, and the errors of taste and judgment, are among the most egregious in film history. And yet this is about as much money as you can spend on a movie. I mean, they really tried. Tim Burton, a bunch of good actors, top of the line fx, expensive writers... and it is really about as bad as movies get.

In the context of the present day audience awareness the original Planet of the Apes (1968) has many flaws but the time travel reasoning and the rise of the apes made some sense. One is inclined to be a little more forgiving given that the movie predates the first moon landing of 1969.As for the 2001 effort, it is very poorly constructed. Most will abandon hope after the first 60 seconds - why have a monkey control the space pod at all? Poor logic and sloppy story line permeate the entire movie.Kids and lovers of wired apes might be amused - everyone else should run for the exit.5/10 being generous

What a bad film! I like to think of myself as a Tim Burton fan. However, I feel that when he gets a big budget, his work suffers. Ed Wood was his lowest budgeted film and was by far his greatest work. "Mars Attacks" and this "Ape" movie both had big budgets and were really horrible. Someone needs to tell Hollywood, that when you revisit a classic story, bring something new to the story. Special effects alone is not enough. I believe that Hollywood thought that by just having more elaborate costumes and apes, they would have a better movie, wrong! The story was just paper thin and the script was one of the worst ever. The first hour of this film was just a bunch of campy jokes. I have never seen more uninspired performances. However, to be fair, the actors had nothing to work with. The story is just patched together. Few characters are developed or have any importance. Man, this was a bad film. However, people will consider it a smash hit, because of the box office totals. However, most of the money taken in by this film was in the first week, so the negative word of mouth had not gotten out yet. This film has dropped like a rock since week one. Let's hope that Burton can return to actually telling a story and a weird story at that. That was one thing this film was missing, there was no "Burton Weirdness" anywhere. Bland and boring. * out of *****.

reviews.review_title: A reimagination of a cult classic?
reviews.content: Without a doubt, the 1968 Planet of the Apes was one of my favourite science fiction movies of the time.  Indeed, a whole generation grew up on the concept of "going ape" over the numerous sequels and the inevitable tv-spin off.  So when I knew that Planet of the Apes was going to re-done, I was jumping for joy - at last a real chance to put a big budget to an original concept penned by the author of the book which inspired the Planet of the Apes movies. CONTAINS SPOILERS But with the movie, came casualties - fortuently, Tim Burton, director of Batman (1989), bravely took on the mantle that other directors (i.e. James Cameron) would not take on - the poision chalice that was to "revisit" the planet of the apes.  Burton claims this version is a reimagination of the cult classic, but it is clear that Burton wanted to outdo the original in every way possible, and in some areas he certainly succeeds.The costumes, the make-ups, the sets, the direction and special effects is brilliant, and a much darker version of the original, but special effects and costumes do not make a good story.  And this is where Burton falls down.The 1968 version of the planet of the apes illustrated and concentrated on pressing issues of the day, namely civil rights, racisim, and to some extents, animal welfare and slavery.  The 2001 version, in contrast, doesn't answer or ask questions on any specific issue outside civil, the effects of time travel and animal rights.  In fact, it seems to taken more from the Amercian Civil War, rather than today's issues.The plot revolves around a space outpost near Saturn's rings - that use's highly trained and intelligent chimps to do missions that humans won't do - one chimp is sent through an electrical storm to a planet, and Mark Walberg goes to rescue the lost chimp - only to find himself on the planet of the apes. Without revealing too much of the plot - it transpires that Walberg blames himself (with good cause).Yet, with all its dark and well developed speical effects, Its clearly intended as a summer blockbuster movie, it could have been so much more - espically from director, Tim Burton.  I expected something wierd yet stragely compelling, yet we have a summer blockbuster movie that tries to get "bums on seats" without a good script and story that was compelling enough.We have the hero, Mark Walberg playing as wooden as I've ever seen him - in a constant state of concentration, with little emotion.  Fortuently we have the over-the-top bad guy Tim Roth as General Thade and the wonderful Helena-Botam-Carter to keep the story moving at a fast pace.  But sometimes the pace is too fast, there seems to be no time to look around, no time to actually dig at the concepts, the ideas, the questions that it was trying to raise to society, whereas the original stopped and took the time to create concepts and build on the ideas with the ability to ask the questions, and then answer them in a concise and logical way.Some may criticise it for being a trashy summer movie, and in some ways they are right.  This isn't one of Burton's best - and nowhere near the original 1968 version - but if you took it as a standalone movie without comparing it to any other Ape movie - perhaps I can agree that it is indeed a good, watchable film - but it lacked the vigor, the charm of the original - and the ending was confusing, yet logical.Thade had gone back to Earth and caused a revolution in the same way that Walberg had done on the Planet of the Apes - the whole story is very similar to the novel - but there is one problem, how did Thade know where Earth was? No-one told him where it was, nor did he know what it looked like.  In either case it was a clever ending, perhaps a bit too clever for its own good - because it made the audience confused.Of course the rumors behind the movie fuel the confusion.  Was it true that Burton had edited the film right to the last minute?  Were scenes cut that would have made the film more of a soul?  Did Burton steal the ending of a General Thade sitting in the Lincoln Memorial stolen from someone else? Were there really five different endings?  All these questions don't detract from the enjoyment of the movie - but it does make one ask where the soul of the film was and what it was trying to achieve.Throughout the movie there are many problems. For example, throughout the film I kept trying to figure out why, in the year 2029 did the American Space Force use Chimps, and not satellites or other robotic system to investigate the electrical storm?  The planet that Walberg lands on is certainly not Earth, as it has two moons - yet, how does Thade (indeed, the whole ape civilisation) move from the planet to Earth?  Why, when Walberg goes back in time, doesn't he try to stop himself or his ship from going into the storm?  And why, when Walberg goes to Earth does he go straight for Washington, instead of Cape Caveral?  Did NASA move its lauch facility to Washington DC?Despite the plots problems, the confusing ending (was Walberg really on Earth all that time or not?), and the general feeling that it had been rushed.  I did enjoy the film, and it did make me think about the issues that it wanted to raise, but I just didn't think about the issues or feel enjoyment of the film as much I enjoyed and thought about the original Planet of the Apes - perhaps I'm giving the original too much credit, and Burton not enough - perhaps I demanded and expected too much and cared too little to what Burton was trying to do, trying to say with the film. Nethertheless, the message was lost in amongst the special effects and little care and detail to attention of the main concept of the film.Overall: An average, yet an enjoyable movie. 7/10

reviews.review_title: Good movie but nowhere near original
reviews.content: Planet of the Apes is a pretty good film but it had its ups and downs. The movie is about a astronaut named Leo (Mark Whalberg) who gets sucked into a portal and lands on a planet where apes rule. Tim Roth plays Thade, an army general who hates all humans. His right-hand man Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) follows and executes all of Thades orders. Leo escapes with the help of a compassionate ape named Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and is now a fugitive on the run from the apes. This movie I liked but I don't think was 100% perfect. I thought the make-up was not as good as the originals. The acting was pretty good by my standards. Like all Apes movies, the endings have to twist which this one did. Overall this movie was good, and recommend to sci-fi fans, but probably not to Apes fans because it really wasn't a remake in my book.8/10

More of a reworking of the idea rather than a remake of the original. I must admit I was pleasantly surprised by this effort. Of course, it was never going to be as good as the original, the ending to the Charlton Heston classic has to be one of the best endings to a film in movie history. I was satisfied that things were well enough explained throughout this film, for example, the talking humans, and how the apes got to inhabit the planet in the first place. What I couldn't work out was the ending, I wont go into details for those who haven't seen it, but I do feel that because the 1968 classic had such a shocking and thought provoking ending, the writers of this version almost `felt obliged' to try and live up to that and as a result it doesn't really make any sense and tie in with the story you have just followed for the past 2 hours  or maybe it does and I just missed the point!, either way  FAR too confusing! (Although it screams "sequel!" - how convenient!!). Wahlberg is okay as astronaut Leo Davidson, while Tim Roth is wickedly good fun as cruel military ape `General Thade'. Charlton Heston appears unbilled as Thade's dying father, who's character name is `Zaius'  is there a doctor in the house?

reviews.review_title: It's a guilty pleasure, so indulge.
reviews.content: It's been over three decades since the original, and original it was. History has not been very kind to the 1968 classic which featured the likes of Roddy McDowall (Lassie, Flicka), the beautiful Kim Hunter (A Streetcar Named Desire) and Charlton Heston, who must have had a lot of explaining to do to his fundamentalist friends for appearing in the original evolution epic and this remake. (Then again, aside from a couple of sandal sagas, his whole career cries out for an explanation), but for a generation it remains one of the most shockingly effective films of its time.This time we get Helena Bonham Carter in the culmination of her costume drama career, looking for all the world like Michael Jackson in drag (as if that wouldn't be redundant), Paul Giamatti, delightful and yet somehow wasted as an aging orang-utan, Kris Kristofferson, as the good guy we can't wait to see snuffed, and, of course, Marky Mark, surprisingly effective in his biggest film to date sans the monumentally untalented George Clooney. (No, Boogie Nights wasn't THAT big.)First of all, the monkey suits were killer!  It was unsettling at first, and then just plain eerie, to see talking apes that looked real, instead of the laughable effect of the original.  Who else but Rick Baker could have worked such magic?  Along with Tim Burton and Danny Elfman, this talented trio simply could not fail.  Still, there are problems.Visually, the film is flawless, thanks to Burton.  But there are holes big enough to drive a truck through if you care to take pot shots.  On the other hand, you could just sit back and be amused for a couple of hours, in which case you could do much worse.  So here's the skinny.  Marky Mark chases a chimp into a space storm in an attempt to rescue him.  He goes through a worm hole and ends up on a planet ruled by apes.  The humans rally... oh heck, why bother.  It's the same film as in 1968.  Got it?  There are a couple of twists that I can't reveal without spoiling the film, but let's just say the screenwriter had to earn his fee somehow.  And the ending?  Well, remember what I said about the truck.This film has been on the drawing board for what seemed like an eternity, and I'm still wondering what happened to Schwarzenegger.  Instead we get Marky Mark?  Well I guess those monkey suits were expensive.  I suppose there could have been a little more humor, and it would have been nice to see the tension between Carter, Wahlberg and Estella Warren played up a bit, but then Warren proves why models don't always make good actors; actors have to act.The high points of this movie, I suppose, were Michael Clarke Duncan as Attar the gorilla and Tim Roth as the evil chimpanzee General Thade.  It can't be easy to act inside that get up, but they pull it off magnificently.What can I say?  This is one you just can't miss, if only for the historical comparison.  It's a guilty pleasure, so indulge.

I am a Tim Burton fan. I respect his work because he dares to leave his imagination free, in an arty yet commercial way. I always enjoyed his movies, but after continuously watching them for many years now (especially since they were released on DVD), I can finally spot their weakness.You see, some annoying feelings come to surface when you watch 'Batman' or 'Sleepy Hollow' for a tenth time. They are boring movies! Or to be fair, the are movies with long, boring scenes. Evidently Tim Burton seems to fear and respect every frame he shoots while editing and this behaviour creates very long dialog scenes, that work against the pacing of the movie.Long dialog scenes that don't provide exposition should be cut in a non-drama movie. Let's face it, Tim Burton has never worked with a 'Taxi Driver' script, so most of the long dialog scenes should be divided among action scenes.Also, the suspense doesn't change much in his movies. 'Sleepy Hollow' runs in the same way from start to finish, so does 'Batman'. I must say that his best work, is his comedies and maybe he should try to transfer the mood of those films to his other work too.'Planet of the Apes' is bad and I'm not talking about the ENDING, which is the best part of the movie. Only a moron would try to analyse what really happened there. Have you noticed that stupid people, always need to lower every situation to their own standards, in order to understand it? Of course this creates even more confusion (to them) and they won't get this ending no matter what, so let's proceed. By the way, true cinema is about expressing emotions and not opinions. If you need to state an opinion, the printed word is the perfect medium for it.The biggest mistake of the movie is this Burton element. 'Planet' needed aggressive editing, in order to become fun and not boring, which is what it is now. Specifically the dinner scene and the escape scene in the village. Burton treated this script like it was 'Godfather', so we watch the apes discuss over dinner about every day and social matters for ten minutes, like we care. They're talking apes! On with the story please! Obviously they wanted to balance the action with some drama scenes, but the writing is very bad. A lot of other scenes are boring too and should be deleted, since they destroy everything. Burton seems to have lost his humor in this movie too, since these long scenes could work if they were funny, but they are merely irritating.Unfortunately the script is quite weak, so even if that editing took place, it wouldn't make a masterpiece out of the story. Mark Wahlberg looks like a little kid in the whole movie, possibly because of Burton. He wanted him to become this anti Charlot Heston, an action hero who's in the movie only for the fun ride. It just doesn't work.On the positive side, Burton shows off his craftsmanship for one more time, providing us with some fairy tale images and an introduction in a space station, which is the most spectacular cinematic work since 'Superman'.'Planet of the Apes' shouldn't be made at all. How can you recreate perfection? What's next, a remake of 'Lawrence of Arabia'? Anyway, for once more Burton made an action movie that doesn't stand the test of repetitive viewings and this is because of his fear for aggressive editing.4/10

The movie is good but not memorable. helena Bonham Carter has twinkling eyes. The tacit love scenes among mark Wahlberg and her are touching. It's amazing how humans can feel threatened all the time . Estella Warren's worship of Mark Wahlberg is challenged by Carter's enthusiasm and worship of the humans. By having this love triangle in this kind of movie plot, Tim Roth did an excellent job potraying humans versus apes, their likes and dislikes. The last scene , to many a confusing ending with different interpretation, is the best scene.

reviews.review_title: bleh, not even worth renting the DVD
reviews.content: I was initially quite interested in hearing there was a remake of this venerable classic movie. I wasn't really very happy to find out Mark Wahlberg was starring in it, but I've been wrong before about how someone can hold up a role so I decided to give it a go.As others have said, Tim Roth does a good job, Helena Bonham Carter is pretty decent, and most of the others are basically blase. Marky Mark, however, was a disaster. He has absolutely ZERO on-screen presence, he can't act well enough to even convince me that he is a human being, much less a astronaut, and the movie suffered badly because of this. I didn't care about his lead character, I had no idea what was going on in his head at any time, he never showed fear, anger, happiness, or any of the myriad emotions that most real people have. It was truly awful. Charleton Heston may have overacted in the 1968 version of this movie, but at least you could associate the word "act" with his performance. And Charleton had the on-screen presence that was so lacking in this version.Others have mentioned some of the various plot problems, including the ending, so I won't go into them except to say they are there and they make a number of plot events implausible. I would also like to point out that, once again (just as in the original POTA), the presence of horses on this "planet" is yet another obvious plot problem.As a straightforward action film the movie is pretty decent. The ape makeup and the ape movement is pretty damn good.Overall, I was considerably disappointed in this version of "Planet of the Apes" It had no originality, they chose the wrong leading actor, and the plot had huge holes. If you want to experience "Planet of the Apes" rent the original...it's so much better that there isn't really any comparison (except for the title). That's too bad, too, because this movie needed to be technologically updated.

reviews.review_title: They made it dreck, Semos help us
reviews.content:
Maybe I should have been smarter, maybe I should have been wiser. However, when I went to see this, I was hoping, maybe even expecting, something intelligent that represented science fiction.  However, this was not science fiction, and did not have an ounce of intelligence in its overly-long body. The movie is crap.  It is dreck.First, I was not expecting the original.  The original had a very '60s or hippy mindset about how humans destroyed the earth, and nature took over. That wouldn't go over now.  So, I asked myself, what could they do to the movie to make it more modern.  It seemed to me that they tried by making it be a metaphor for class wars, or political racism.  But that was soon abandoned.  Eventually it became the usual.  A watered-down post-apocalyptic-like road movie (or escape, whatever).
I was too busy searching for some sign of intelligence to tell you how the acting was (it could have been good, it could have been horrible). Visually it was stunning if you have to resort to that.  And the score was wonderful (thanks Danny Elfman).  But for the rest of the movie, skip it.  I was so frustrated that before the ending came up, my Gatorade bottle was a crumpled mess.SPOILERS****SPOILERS****SPOILERS*****SPOILERS****SPOILERS*****SPOILERSThe end of the movie was just pure hilarity.  Maybe I wouldn't have found it so funny if I hadn't called it before it actually occurred.  Right as Wahlberg got into the pod, I asked my friend, "Wouldn't it be funny if Earth was taken over by apes?"  Lo and behold, it happened.  And with police cars and everything, it kind of reminded me of "Monty Python and the Holy Grail"'s ending.  The Jefferson monument was a hark back to those cool cartoons where they would blow up Mt. Rushmore and it would turn into the villains face.  Maybe I shouldn't be so judgemental, but that was the only redeeming part of the whole movie (and for all the wrong reasons).END SPOILERS2/10

reviews.review_title: Please don't waste your time with this movie
reviews.content: After suffering through the abysmal plot development, I then had to suffer through the even worse execution of the plot! It would have been nice if the actors, who have potential, would've had a script to work with...But unfortunately, that was not the case, there was poor dialogue and the screenplay was even poorer. I was especially disappointed in the lack of any type of sequence among the events that took place. Not to mention, I'm not too thrilled with monkey romances. It was a very hairy experience, no more monkey business for me or Soe. Democracy to Burma.

"Planet of the Apes" reminds me of one of those times when I had no idea what to expect of myself.Was I going to like the movie?Was I going to hate the movie?I waited anxiously for the release of the film,knowing that it was not going to be the best film ever made.Basicly,when I go to see these types of films,I don't worry about the quality of the acting and the directing or it's script.Some people on this website like to watch films with a story and quality performances.That's sensible.I am different.I look at "Planet of the Apes" this way.One,it's a science fiction film.The genre of science fiction takes you anywere your mind takes you.Finally,two.The only purpose these films have is to entertain the audience.I was very much entertained by the way this film turned out."Planet of the Apes" was to me seven dollars that was well spent.Leaving the theatre,even though I knew there were better ones,I appreciated the film for the fact that it led me on a trip through the entertainment world.Mark Wahlberg is pretty good as Leo Davison and so is Tim Roth is General Thade.What else impressed me about this film is Rick Baker's impressive makeup which I believe is a dead lock for an academy award."Planet of the Apes" is a fun filled journey that thought was never a waste of my time.Every minute was worth it.

POSSIBLE SPOILERSAs with many of you reading this, I love both Planet of the Apes (1968) and the films of Tim Burton.However, like oil and water, the two are not a great mix.I like the fact he had a brave stab at one of Hollywood's best sci-fi movies and Rick Baker is bound to get an Oscar for his work on the make-up.However, that script and plot left a lot to be desired.There are little things that bug me, not the huge sweeping visions of apes thundering across the planet in Braveheart mode.When astronaut Mark Wahlberg puts his hand on a thousand year old door lock, it opens with barely a problem. If I leave my car door closed for a month it seizes up.
And when Mark crashes his space pod at the end, he strolls from the wreckage like he's just got up from his chair to make a cup of tea. Where is the logic in simple inertia and seized up mechanics. It doesn't take a genius to apply these little things that make all good sci-fi films work. Okay, it doesn't have to be Nasa approved but it does have to have a modicom of reality we can all relate to.2001 has been one of the bleakest years in living memory for movies and the news. Planet of the Apes will not be remembered for turning things around but merely burying them in a deeper pile of misery.If you only watch one film this year, make it Moulin Rouge and leave Tim Burton's flawed offering well alone.

Doggone it!  I went to see this movie hoping to keep out of my mind all recollection of the original 1968 movie.  Then this remake goes and quotes the original version again and again, in the clunkiest, most ham-fisted way! "Get your stinking paws off me, you damned dirty human!"  "Damn them all to hell!"  Feh!Actually, this movie wasn't all that bad.  It didn't stink to high heaven, which is as much as I seem to hope for in a movie these days.  The story (of which I will reveal nothing - I don't want to spoil it for anyone) is very good, with lots of nifty twists.  The Pride of Dorchester MA, Mark Wahlberg (remembered in Boston as Mahky Mahk), is quite good as the protagonist human.  On the down side, Paul Giamatti's human slave trader of an orangutan provided an irritating dose of little needed comic relief, and Helena Bonham Carter is surprisingly shallow, not showing any presence from under all that ape makeup.  (The same cannot be said of Tim Roth, who exudes much menace as the scary monkey of every little kid's nightmares.)Overall, I'd have to say a very good story was given a formulaic action-movie treatment with some very irritating moments, but not enough to ruin the movie entirely.  It helped, of course, that I saw this at a matinee, so I only had to cough up $5.  Given that, I'd say I got my money's worth.Rating: six stars on my Manos scale.

First off, let me say that I found the original overrated.  Not bad, but not a 'classic'.  When I heard they were remaking it, with Cameron at the helm, I was extremely worried (I dislike everything the man's done in the 90's, with the exception of True Lies, which was fun).  When it turned out to be Tim Burton, I felt that maybe he could make this movie truly 'relevant', with sharp satire, and perhaps a little human development. Alas, it wasn't to be.  Understand that I think that Burton is a director who's style often overwhelms the substance of any film he's shooting (note, see Sleepy Hollow).  That said, he brings enormous creative energy to the film, and is to be respected for massing the talented crew he has.  I'm glad to hear the people mentioned Danny Elfman's score, his best.  It hooks you from beginning to end, and has the strength to become a contender at this year's oscars.  Thunderous, rousing, brilliant, the score is better written then the script for eliciting a dramatic response.  Special credit must be given to Rick Baker, the only Hollywood make-up artist whom I've heard of (he's acheived a celebrity status if you will).  His simian creations are remarkable, and allow the actors to act through their make-up.  Well, that would be more true if the actors had something to act.  The script makes no attempt to achieve any form of nuance or subtlety.  It eschews what could have been a satire, and asks us to accept fight scenes and stunt work.  Discussing the stunt work, it is phenomenal as well. Again, the technical achievements of this film are not to be ignored.  The film is fairly entertaining UNTIL.....  The climax.  What is supposed to be a pulse-pounding scene proves to be a series of cliches, and a horrible use of deux ex machina, and the ending is fairly silly and unnecessary.  As for the actors, many attempt to act, but many have nothing to do (the humans).  However, the performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are excellent.  No kidding, but I think Roth deserves an oscar nomination (as it stands now).  His scenery chewing performance as General Thade is energetic and outstanding.  Having said that, expect this to win a make-up oscar, and receive a nomination for best score, but it's not a film to rush out and see.

I enjoyed" Planet of the Apes" very much but the ending brings the rest of the film down. Tim Burton has a great eye for gothic visuals and he doesn't dissapoint here. Most of the movie is very dark and moody. The performances are good also, Mark Wahlberg does a good job playing an air force Pilot who crash lands on a different planet in time, Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, and Tim Roth also are convincing as apes from another world, the majority of this film is good, but like I said the ending brings it down, it's not totally bad but you're left saying, "oh, sure, Whatever". Other than that, I reccommend seeing this film.

You all already know that I love sci-f movies, especially the post-apocalyptic one!Believe it or not but I have not seen any movie from the series of " ... Apes ". With the new release of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes (2014), I feel like I need to watch all previous ones first (modern versions), even though they are not really connected with each others, at least as far as I know!This movie currently has a low rating of 5.7 and normally I would skip it... but it is was made by Tim Burton and I love this guy's work! Let's see if it's really as bad as people rate it!11 minutes - here we go... and I thought it was so nice... I mean it still is but the logic is out of its place... I can handle it, not a big thing.17 minutes - hooray! Kris Kristofferson! so what that I thought this is Jeff Bridges at first lol, it's always a pleasure to see a familiar face, especially on another planet!23 minutes - so far it's really interesting, kind of disappointed though... I thought they are going to be high tech apes, but they are totally opposite... It's still interesting to see an alternative life.27 minutes - the typical Tim Burton's background music starts being annoying... It's too distinctive, loud and it eclipses the movie...40 minutes - I am not racist or anything but... damn those apes looks fugly as hell! + Mark Wahlberg's facial expressions look like he really need to take a massive dump but he holds it instead...52 minutes - the movie is certainly not as bad as people rate it... and I have to honestly admit that the actors playing apes are doing a hell of a good job.1h - so much hard work has been put in all these nice make-ups, environments etc. but still, it doesn't make up for the movie which is a bit dull...1h 37 minutes - the apes can kill every human in half of a second but apparently Mark Wahlberg is special... LAME...God damn! The ending was really unexpected and nice! This movie is certainly not as bad as people rate it on IMDb but I understand that most of them just didn't like the remake... If the apes would have been high tech, I would enjoy it more :) tgchan's rating: 6/10

To start with I'll just say, the original movie is a true classic, a lot better, and I advise you to see it. Also You'll understand this movie a bit better.Visually this movie is wonderful, and the new ape suits are incredible. Unlike the original movie, the apes have a more realistic appearance, they act more, and sounds a bit more like apes. But the apes are still the dominat and intelligent species on the planet. This movie is more based on the original novel by the French author Pierre Boulle. And I'm sure he would be pleased with the story arc in this movie, even though all the french factors have been Americanized.Mark Walberg show us a strong performance, and the movies "villain" general Thade, portrayed by Tim Roth, is just terrifying. To be candid the two adversarial roles really saved this movie.It may not be as mind-boggling as the original movies, but it's still well worth watching. It's great for remake standards and shouldn't be compared to much to the original.

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton has always been overrated
reviews.content: It may be a bit late to weigh in on this film, but I feel compelled to if for no other reason than that Tim Burton has just arrogantly messed with another classic, Charlie and Chocolate Factory, and has once again screwed things up. Burton has no concept of plot or acting, his style is entirely visual, and he is dishonest as all get out when he wants to make a point. I'm sorry that Tim had problems with his parents, especially his father, but that does not justify his screwing with classic stories so that he can whine once again about how parents just don't understand you and might even abandon you.Having got that off my chest, I would like to summarize POTA as follows. The movie makes no sense and the reason it makes no sense is that the director has no vision, no sense of a story that he wants to tell. Even the highly touted ape makeup is a mistake, because the director has no idea whether the apes are supposed to be subhuman or better than human. As a consequence they behave in a manner that simply leaves the viewer confused.I am a biologist who has studied behavior in apes, so I might be more picky than most, but I defy any viewer to answer the following question. Why are all the female apes chimpanzees? I have watched the ape village scenes several times and to my view there is not a single female gorilla or orang utan in the entire place. Also these female chimps don't look like chimps, but like some sort of odd chimp/human hybrid, which might explain the attraction between Marky Mark and Helena BC, but otherwise feels just thrown in (This is what I mean by Burton throwing logic out the window to make his themes fit his preconceptions). For example why does the female chimp (Carter) have eyebrows, a trait missing from every primate but humans? Also why do chimps, which seem to make up the vast majority of the apes, walk upright except when they charge? This makes them very ineffective as warriors. They can't hold weapons, so why do they wear armor? The acting in this film is confusing and few characters seem realized, and once again I think Burton is to blame. In Burton films the only actors who are memorable are those willing to create their own characters and overact shamelessly, e.g. Michael Keaton's Beetlejuice, Nicholson's Joker, DeVito's Penguin, Walken's headless horseman. In this film this tradition is carried on by Tim Roth's Thade, a character so psychotic it seems amazing that anyone takes him seriously. The cast includes some good actors, but all are handicapped by bad direction. For example, Paul Giamatti an excellent character actor, tries hard to create a believable character in his whining sycophantic slave trading orang utan, but he is made up as a female rather than a male orang utan, which collapses the character completely.Other actors fare no better. Wahlberg, at best a charming male ingénue, cannot act like a leader, so I was startled by the idea that all the humans would follow his lead when he seems to have no idea as to what he's doing throughout the entire film. The other humans seem to be merely tagging along looking confused. Michael Clarke Duncan, subtle and wonderful in the Green Mile, here plays sort of a King Kong who can talk. As a subtext, why are the Gorillas played by Afrcian American actors, and the chimps by white actors? This leads me to what I think is Burton's greatest weakness, his ability to direct actresses. The only actress who has ever turned in a memorable performance in a Burton film is Michelle Pfeiffer's sly, slinky Catwoman in Batman II. Otherwise excellent actresses have been left to flounder by Burton, e.g. Christina Ricci is Sleepy Hollow, Kim Basinger in Batman. Given this history, I find confusing all of the hostility and crass comments about Estella Warren's performance as Daena, the only human in the film with any personality. Estella Warren is a powerful presence, who in every film in which she appears works from the premise that she is, at the least, the equal of all the male characters and that she is smarter even than most of those. She tries to pull that off in POTA, but she is left to flounder, trying to work off the giant vacuum emitted by Marky Mark. Warren acts using her face to communicate subtle emotions and changes of mood, but that tactic backfires in this film, where subtlety is lost. She gets no perceivable reactions from Wahlberg, who seems lost in his own world, and she has almost no scenes with anyone else. As a result Warren has little to do but look distressed and confused. I think most of the negative comments directed at Warren's acting come from silly insecure young men who feel that a pretty woman should not also be strong and competent, and simply want to ogle her.To summarize, this film is probably the worst big budget film ever made, but don't blame the actors. As they say in Russia, fish begin to stink from the head. In this case the head is the director.

This is hands down Tim Burton's worst film to date. A perfect storm of bad luck, bad casting/acting (Wahlberg), messing with a classic, and the ending, oh what an awful ending. I love a portion of every Burton film to date except for maybe Pee Wee's Big Adventure, and even consider a few classics (Batman, Batman Returns, and Sleepy Hollow), but this film has NO redeeming qualities whatsoever. Bad concept, bad idea, bad casting, bad acting, bad writing, bad directing...get the picture (ok, the special effects are slightly above average). Poor Charlton Heston has a cameo as an aging ape and it is by the numbers acting and a shame that Moses and El Cid had to cash a paycheck while participating in this dreck. Skip it.

This was a very good re-imagining of the 1969 classic. I went to the theater with high expectations (because, let's face it, it's Tim Burton), and this movie struck a cord with me, because it is my favorite Sci-Fi film in the last decade and a half, the movie was 'Aliens'.Mark Wahlberg did a very good job as the lost Capt. Leo Davidson, but my hat goes off to General Thade himself, Tim Roth. He was *excellent* as the sadistic, human loathing primate villain. Michael Clark Duncan also was perfect support as Thade's brutish right hand man, Colonel Attar.Every one who was an ape did an excellent job at moving like actual primates. The score kept you with the flow of the movie, the choreography was marvelous, and the acting was good. The action sequences were very intense, and the chase between the humans and Thade's Army was very suspenseful. There was an outstanding surprise to the end of this movie, it was very unexpected. I recommend this movie to any one who wants an exciting, special effects adventure, but this movie also has a very surprise end, good acting, and a great plot.        Do not compare this to the original, because the only thing connects them is a title. Also, Charlton Heston made a pleasing cameo as Thade's father, and blurts out the most famous quote in sci-fi movie history! If you have a choice between this, and Jurassic Park 3, pick this, because this has excitement AND brains. 9/10

reviews.review_title: Watch it for the effects, not the story
reviews.content: I had mixed feelings about this film.Let me start by saying my enjoyment would have been greatly increased had this been a pseudo-sci-fi, action, ape-based flick that stood on its own merits instead of being associated with "The Planet of the Apes".  There were certainly things in this film which made it worth seeing.Despite what is said, the visuals and effects were interesting.  There was enough story to at least hold the interest of most.Sadly, what it lacked are those elements which made the original PotA good. The original had weak effects to be sure and the plot even had its problems. Nonetheless the depth of the plot, the debate about the content of man, the thoughts and concepts that were classic, are all missing.  I would have hoped that in a "re-imagining" the philosophy and concepts would have CHANGED; but not that they would have been omitted.I still use illustrations from the original to elucidate points.  I didn't walk away with such a feeling from this movie.  The debate between superiority of human vs. ape has been reduced to scant allusion to racial tension.  There is enough illogic to not deserve itemization (the horses have already been discussed quite throughly).  Worst of all was the ending. My friend and I are quite familiar with sci-fi, fantasy, irony and great literature.  We "get" most every reference.  However, BOTH of us looked at each other and said "huh"?  While there may be some explanations for this they didn't even establish enough clues for some healthy hypothesizing.  It seemed just "thrown in" and out of context with the rest of the movie.To close out the critique I will just state that there is a positively tragic movement in Hollywood to "dumb down" every creation.  It's like Hollywood has the touch of mental mediocrity.  You'd think for scores of millions of dollars they could somehow come up with a story and content worth the millions of dollars of effects.  Give us something that can stimulate our minds, not just our senses.  I fear this "re-imagining" fell prey to this phenomenon.That being said, I return full circle to the fact that this movie enough going for it to have been enjoyable were it to stand on its own (and taking into account the current brain-dead state of today's Hollywood scripts). There were a couple homages to the original movie which gave us a laugh or two.  As I said, the effects and even visual composition were worth seeing. If you wish to see a movie to go "ooooh" and "aaahhhh" over the effects as opposed to the "invisible effect" approach (where you are engrossed in the story, not aware of the visuals being "effects"), then you will enjoy this.I would recommend watching this.  Just enjoy it for what it is and don't expect a level of content comparable to the original.  At the very least, this movie is FAR beyond the level of any "Apes" SEQUELS, which had thoroughly useless plots without the concession of good effects.

Tim Burton can usually make us feel.  He gives us foreshadowing, atmosphere, and a sense of reality.He did none of those with this movie.I wanted to like this film; I really did.  In fact, most of the movie was enjoyable.  I found that the apes moved realistically, or at least as one would expect, Tim Roth was a good villain - if more than a bit flat - and that the religious element was delicate but not underdeveloped.However, at about thirty-forty minutes from the end of the film, things fell apart.Characters show up for no reason; we are spoon-fed that which the viewer can already deduce; romance is conjured out of nowhere.  Tim Burton could have made this a satire, but instead he made it an action movie that pales in comparison with even a Steven Seagal vehicle.There is no atmosphere, soul, or logic to the film.  If you liked Burton's other movies, by all means do not see this one.And wow, the ending.  I overheard someone mention Rod Serling's name on the way out.  I can tell you, if I had known who said that, I would have looked at him and told him that Twilight Zone endings were foreshadowed, consistent, and above all else, MADE SENSE.  The movie doesn't even play properly within the logic it sets up for itself.I went into this with higher expectations than I should have.  If you see it, don't make the same mistake I did.

reviews.review_title: Is this really a Tim Burton film?
reviews.content: Very boring, very long, very confusing, and an awful ending that I just totally hated.Not the worst thing I've ever seen by a long shot, but definitely not one for me.

reviews.review_title: I thought I was going to see Jurassic Park 3!!!
reviews.content: I saw this movie in a single-screen theatre in Minden, a town just south of our cottage. I thought I was going to see Jurassic Park 3, but this was playing instead. Anyways, I'm not sure why I stayed. This is a really bad movie and, even though I can't compare it to the original which i haven't seen, I'm sure the original made a lot more sense at the end.
