Even though I thought Estella Warren was dead sexy, the movie stunk like crap.I did eventually see JP3, which was better than this movie but still the worst of the JP trilogy. I still say this is the worst thing I have seen in the theatres.

reviews.review_title: PLANET OF THE NYUK NYUK's, or: "I Waited 25 YEARS for THIS??!!"
reviews.content:
(POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD!) God in Heaven, where does one begin? I became an APES freak around 1973 and collected the toys, memorabilia, and all. I even made a fan magazine on PLANET OF THE APES. This franchise was lost in the dust for a few decades and I prayed it would return one day. Well, it FINALLY has - and I'm not so sure it's for the better.Yes, the kids will love this film, and yes, the toys and Ape Popularity will soar once again. But Lord, what an AWFUL motion picture - heartbreaking, really, after suuuccch a long wait. When I heard that Tim Burton and Rick Baker were involved I had some hopes. As I saw magazine articles, trailers, and makeup shots I said "yeah, this may actually work!" But then I saw the finished product...and my worst fears were confirmed, my few hopes were shot down, and once again I knew that there is no escaping the wrath of today's lousy movies.As the last 25 years or so passed before my eyes during the movie, I got disgusted, angered, and bored. Now, it's too easy to charge me with being too biased toward the 1968 original; I fully accepted some changes. Too bad every one was for the WORST. Well, enough preliminary stuff; let's get on to the movie, shall we? ---It's treated as a silly, dumb, stupid, lame joke. It's like watching Looney Tunes on acid or something. Tim Burton reportedly had much fun with this film, even laughing after yelling "Cut!" after each shot - and it shows. Burton has NO respect for this subject and thinks the APES are funny monkeys to be snickered at. And tossing in some lame variations of classic lines from the 1968 version only hinders, and seem forced. Though the unfunny and aching silliness is what peeves me the most, there's more:Where's the script? What little story there is is full of convoluted and illogical situations. The so-called "story" merely zips in and out of perfunctory APES scenarios: A convenient hunt scene as soon as the astronaut lands, and an obligatory escape attempt, for example. The characters are totally uninteresting. ALL of the humans, that's the first thing. Michael Clark Duncan looks good, but offers nothing. Marky Mark is by-the-numbers and not much of an actor. People are speaking highly of Helena Bonham Carter as the girl chimp, but her character just squeals a lot and is afraid of her own shadow. Her Animal Activist potential is hinted at but dropped quickly. When she falls for Marky, it's absurd. I mean, she loves animals but does she want to sleep with them?? When she kisses the astronaut at the end of the movie, who cares, it's another loan from the original, except that at least there had been more involvement and caring between Taylor and Zira. THEY seemed to spend weeks and weeks getting to know and understand each other; this time, Carter and Mark seem to have only been introduced an hour or two beforehand. And her makeup (as with the other females) is VERY POOR. John Chambers runs circles around Rick Baker there, with his original Zira makeup from the first version.Yes, by the way, the other makeup is very good. Particularly Tim Roth's evil-looking Thade. Pity that Roth's idea of portraying a villain here though is to snarl, grunt, hiss, and swing around the room. I was looking forward to Roth's performance most of all, but he blew it.I don't much care for the beastial savagery and more "primitive" apes of this new feature, either. To me, the Apes were more like spoiled Monkeys, and far too irrational and animalistic to run the planet. And how does this make them so superior to the humans, anyway? These talkative homo sapiens look capable enough to plan their own revolt.The character of Limbo was an annoying and unfunny Jar Jar Binks-type, and we needed him out of there ASAP. What a stooge. Assasinate him, please.
Charlton Heston's cameo could have been decent, had it not been destroyed by his classic "Damn Them All To Hell!" line that came off as desperate and embarrassing. It could have worked in a skit from SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE, but in what should be an intense and intelligent sci-fi film.And the ending? What can you say? It is closer to the book, but comes off as confusing in its execution. It looks Stupid, obligatory, and conveniently sets up for a (gulp) sequel. Man, what a dumb excuse for a movie!!!! Whether there ever was another version or not, this is one limp knee-slapper. Nyuk Nyuk Nyuk!Damn You to Hell, Tim Burton!!

I thought Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" was an exciting, enjoyable remake of the original that exceeded my expectations....UNTIL the absurd ending that was nothing more than a cynical ploy by Burton to make you wait for the sequel and then pay good money again to find out what it meant.  I won't reveal the ending, but it made me change my vote from around an 8 to a 3...it ruined the movie for me.  Be forewarned!

reviews.review_title: Its a good flick... with a poor ending.
reviews.content: Okay by now I'll assume you've heard there is a "surprise" ending for Apes. I mean in the original story it turned out the "planet of the Apes" was Earth all along, so Burton had to avoid that, and he did, nicely, but he then felt obliged to do his own twist ending and that is where the movie falls apart. This movie was an interesting visual journey with a nice background mystery (how did the apes get this way?) although when all is said and done I am left wondering two things: 1- Where did they get all the horses? And 2- Where is Rod Serling in the end shot? I can almost hear him saying "Picture a man far from home..."

reviews.review_title: Not as good as earlier version
reviews.content: The casting was poor for the second version and the acting and the plot are awful. The movie makers went to great lengths to get the ape army to walk like apes, but Helen Bonham Carter never learned how. The special effects were of course much better than in the original but they do not make up for its other shortcomings.

reviews.review_title: OH MY GOD! what a bad, bad movie.
reviews.content: I cant believe what I just walked out of. That HAD to be one of the worst movies I have ever seen! I mean, it had potential at some times, and when the crash all comes together near the end, you start the think the plot is pretty good. But then you're shown a surprise- the ending- the bad, bad ending. I wont give it away, but its just really bad. I dont even know why I saw it, I wouldve seen American Pie 2, but it was sold out. I shouldve seen The others. Dont waste your money, but DO rent it, so you can see what I was talking about with the ending thing.

reviews.review_title: A fun movie, though not burtons best
reviews.content: Ok let me say this outright.  The people who were expecting the original planet of the apes are idiots.  The original, though it had its strong points dragged on to long.  The extended walking in the desert scenes were just silly.  And for all these people are hanging onto, it is still just a B-movie. Tim Burtons version, which is exactly that, is tim burtons version.  It is pretty silly to compare it because the whole entire movie was reworked. But people forget the whole entire original book was reworked to have some commentary on racism and nuclear war in the original movie.  But back to the point.  I went in this movie expecting burton to deviate, even hoping. That is exactly what happened, burton reworked everything.  Thank GOD.  (no offense, but the original is a pretensious, seriously flawed, sixties, B Sci Fi movie, that has alot of inconsistancies to it, but it is probably the funniest movies I know of, because of all those reasons) Let me put it this way, this is a film that burton did for fincial reasons, mainly to fund his pet projects(Ed Wood the most notable). I was not expecting greatness, i was not expecting this to be sleepy hollow or ed wood.  I was expecting this to be a b-movie.  The acting was bad, but who cares, all acting in action movies is bad, the exception being batman, where jack nickolson brought it to a whole new level.  That and i did not think burton wanted good acting, or he would have cast his regulars.  Tim burton saw this movie as an opportunity to indulge in the b-movie genre, and make a bundle(which he will).  It was not supposed to be high art, just a fun sci-fi movie, and it would be foolish to expect anything else.Visually the movie is not so trademarky burton, but his touch is there. Yeah some of the battle scenes are silly, and in fact there are alot of inconsistancies.  But who cares.  The movie moved along very well, though a bit to fast at times.  The movie alone is worth seeing for the charlton heston apperance, which is possibly, and probably intentionally on burtons part, the funniest scene in the movie.   So go see it, but do not expect a masterpiece, or a loyal remake of the original(which never was a masterpiece).

reviews.review_title: Entertaining, but doesn't live up to its potential
reviews.content: Tim Burton's remake of "Planet of the Apes" may well be a disappointment to fans of the original and perhaps even an abomination. However, it is an entertaining film which is not one of Burton's finest, but is decent blockbuster fare.The plot clicks along at a cracking rate, so it is never dull, although a bit more time dwelling on the central character and the world of the film would not have gone amiss and would have injected a bit more interest into the film. Burton cannot make up for this lack of development, but he does provide the film with his excellent breed of design which does make this, at times, an interesting visual spectacle.The characters are also fairly thinly sketched, although there are some good lines in this film, particularly those that reference the original. However, some of the performances, most of which are done through extraordinary make-up, are very good. Tim Roth chews the scenery and most of his prosthetics as he delights in the part of the villain, Thade. Helena Bonham Carter is pretty good, and Mark Wahlberg is fine, although this performance gave no hint of what he would achieve later in his career.However, the wayward climax and somewhat bewildering conclusion let the film's solid base slip and this reviewer was left satisfied, but felt that this could have been so much more. This is a bit of a blip by Burton's standards, but, as blockbusters go, this is pretty good entertainment.3 stars out of 5

reviews.review_title: Am I the only one who's glad
reviews.content: Roddy Mcdowell didn't live to see this movie? Unfortunately Kim Hunter probably heard about it & got sick to her stomach.What in the name of God??????? All the Ape faces brings to mind Halloween masks with the backs out. Shoulda recycle "Nightmare before Christmas" & "Corpse Bride" puppets or told it in CGI/animation. & again the low-lighted sets? Memo 2 all involved in film financing & distribution movie: keep his man away from remakes of any type especially musicals &, except for "Mars Attacks", this genre. & and talk of too many humans. The original two Apes films kept the human numbers to less than 20 to my recollection.I thought I'd never say this--The role of Captain Leo Davidson SHOULD HAVE WENT TO JOHNNY DEPP! He's got more versatility; will at least try to stretch his acting (Although for my taste he's being more and more horribly miscast in Timmy films). He was excellent in "Astronaunt's Wife"--Pretty Boy Wooden on Kazoo Wahlberg? Oh please! Or how about this casting Michael Keaton if not Depp??? Timmy B don't know how to cast a male lead to save his life! In terms of female leads he does better with HB-C but her in this???? IMO she should have been skipped over for casting in this flick at any & all levels. Elegant &/or down the down to every woman, whatever the character type or past & present, is her forte. As much as I hate her squat screen time role in "Charlie & the Chocolate Factory", it wasn't a SCI-FI Film! Get Veronica Cartwright, Robin Curtis, Terry Ferrell any experienced sci-fi actress who could rise above the level of unbelievable.The reasons I believe Timmy B had Chalty Heston doing his little bit here are 2 fold: 1) thought it would wow fans of the 1st movie ergo they'll come in droves trying to find what scene he's in; & 2) promised he'd pad Heston's bankroll. In case of reason #1, next time he wants to draw in fans of a media icon to a cinema adaptions, especially in the area of sci-fi, talk to Michael Bay regarding his casting of a main robot character 2007 movie adaption, for crying out loud!Oh wait a sec, just remembered--"The Astronaunt's Wife" wasn't directed by Timmy.

reviews.review_title: Yeesh, what a bad, bad movie
reviews.content: Tim Burton didn't put one ounce of imagination or creativity into thislong, dull film.In fact, he stole ideas and characters from more films than it ispossible to mention.  He's like a music writer who patchestogether everything from a 2-bar phrase to a 16-bar phrase from50 different oldies to "create a new song."Just for example, though, let me mention a few.  He stole frommovies spanning the spectrum from The 10 Commandments (ironically not the Charleton Heston part, the Edward G. Robinsonpart), to The Time Machine, to Star Wars.  And along the way heeven swiped bits from The Wild Geese, Andrew V. McLaglen's1978 film and Red Dawn, John Milius's 1984 film.  I can't imaginehe admires either film, but he wasn't above pilfering from them.Oh, yeah.  Jai-alai cestas?And of course he stole the whole "shocking" ending.

reviews.review_title: Not bad, but still a disappointment
reviews.content: Pierre Boulle's original novel of apes ruling an earthlike planet is an absorbing and truly terrifying piece of science fiction. Unlike the 1968 film version with Charlton Heston, this film retains (an Americanized version of) the original ending, which actually works pretty well. There are good scenes along the way too, but somehow, the story just doesn't quite make it. Excellent performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth shore it up a bit, as does the superb make-up. In the end, though, poorish special effects, unmemorable music, and a seeming indecision on the part of the filmmakers as to whether to stick with the original story or write one of their own mean this movie just doesn't work as it should. Watch it by all means, but a classic it is not.

Just a quick word to say how I enjoyed this movie. No, it is not perfect, neither was the original. This one was very exciting to watch. The film is always visually interesting. The CGI work is top notch. The battle action is suspenseful, and the apes running along side the horses is unworldly.  Most actors did very well, under what must have been very heavy makeup. A successful re imagining of the original. The hero came off a little like "Gladiator" meets the planet of the Apes. No problem here. The twist at the end was a good one. See this picture, don't expect Hamlet, and enjoy. Fine entertainment.

reviews.review_title: Burton's Movie Lacks Innovation, Is Disappointing
reviews.content: Tim Burton has proven to be a director with vision.  Many of his previous movies broke new ground artistically, like Beetlejuice, The Nightmare Before Christmas and Ed Wood.  They were wildly imaginative, visually intriguing and entertaining.  That is why I was so excited to learn that Burton was directing Planet of the Apes.  I expected him to take the classic Apes from the 60's and give it his own Burtonesque twist.  I expected ingenuity and to be immersed into a weird futuristic ape world.  What I got was a modern-day Hollywood formula movie.  It is as if all the creativity and intrigue of the original had been beaten out of the film.You know the story.  An astronaut crash-lands onto a strange planet ruled by primates.  Humans are on the planet too, but the humans are considered `animals' and are treated as slave labor.  The biggest problem with Planet of the Apes (2001) is that it is simply not captivating.  There is no discernable plot, except that the astronaut wants to get back to his mother ship, and the apes want to make him their slave (or kill him.)  And while other `slice of life' films may not need a plot to succeed, sci-fi epics do. There is nothing compelling here to move the action and characters (and us) forward.  The result is . . . boredom.  Burton's job at a minimum with this film was to entertain us.  He fell far short.Mark Wahlberg plays astronaut Captain Leo Davidson in a performance that is largely inconsequential.  Helena Bonham Carter is Ari, a female ape (and unspoken love interest) who cares about the plight of the humans. Carter's performance is measured and effective.  Tim Roth portrays Thade, the leader of the ape army.  Roth is a fine actor whose performance here is at times captivating, and at other times one-dimensional.  The actors who play the humans, Kris Kristofferson and Estella Warren, are almost as unimportant as Wahlberg.  I liked the original movie better when the humans just grunted. Also, Charleston Heston even shows up in disguise to waste away a scene with us.To be fair, the makeup and special effects in Planet of the Apes are well done.  The costumes and sets are all good, if not too dark (but the art direction is disappointing when compared with Burton's previous works).  The music, by Danny Elfman, is great, if not distracting.The film's final scene, which I will not give away, has been deemed by some as clever or cool.  I think not.  Imagine if you will, what closing visual would be as evocative as the Statue of Liberty scene in the original movie? I guarantee that if you allow your mind to wander, you will guess it. That's not innovation, that's more of the same from Hollywood.  What happened Tim?

When I took my son to see this, I tried to set my expectations real low, as I had read the reviews. The visual eye-candy is 100% brilliant, and it's not a disagreeable way of passing 2 hours, so what's wrong? Unlike the original film, the humans haven't regressed mentally, in fact they seem quite cultivated. The film contains no real challenges, no warning of ecological disasters. This film is just a "product" there is no religion, no politics, no racial problems. In fact humans and apes can get along just dandy, just with a twist of the director's pen.
This is the Planet of the Apes series "Phantom Menace". Tim Burton: remember the anguish we all felt in the original film when we saw all human history reduced to the head of the statue of liberty poking from the sands... THAT WAS CINEMA!!!

Oh dear! This is the kind of venture that gives Hollywood a bad name.Talented people making a total dud of a movie. The original POTA was a great adventure movie with an interesting Sci-Fi premise. This version, however,is bleak, violent and muddled.The plot holds little of interest and many of the scenes are in darkness and simply unpleasant in tone. Mark Wahlberg must be the least charismatic leading-man of his generation and he annoys throughout.Danny Elfman's score is loud ,intrusive and headache-inducing. The ending is a bit of a mystery and countless geeks have speculated endlessly on this. However, by the time the ending came I didn't really care about this movie and its characters. Remakes can be done well but their very existence and the number of them indicate the lack of ideas in Hollywood.

reviews.review_title: Planet of the Apes never really knows what it wants it does have a spectacular ending though
reviews.content: This is a tough movie to review.  In its defense, the movie has a charm that I can't resist.  The special effects, while nothing to write home about, are good.  The makeup effects are brilliant.  The story is interesting and involving.  But overall, the movie seems a little undercooked.That is a weird feeling to have in a Tim Burtin movie.  His movies are filled with gorgeous and unusual visuals, unusual characters, and flat-out different ideas.  But this "re-imagining" of Planet of the Apes does not seem like a Burtin movie.  It does not have crazy visuals, interesting characters, or anything unusual.  The movie is dry as it can be.  It's filled with crap dialog.  The actors look like apes, but when they speak it sounds like they have a cold (due to the large amount of makeup, but it could have been fixed with dubbing or something).I think that the movie had a large amount of potential, but it was not left in the oven for long enough.  Fox really rushed this movie and it shows. Not in the special effects, but in the story.Not all of the dialog is bad.  There are some nice punches here and there. But the over all script seems rushed.The characters flat out suck.  I'm sorry, but they do.  Especially the astronaut Leo played by Mark Wahlberg.  His character never seems shocked or amazed at this planet full of apes.  There is a moment of adjustment, but he gets used to it too quickly.  If some one dropped me on a planet full of apes, I would freak out and I think most other people would too.  Honostly, his character is rather boring and not interesting.  The only good characters are Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) the ape that has a soft side for humans, Limbo (Paul Giamatti) an ape slave trader, and possibly Attar (Michael Clark Duncan) an ape soldier.  But everyone else just seems, well, boring.One real gripe I have is with Tim Roth who plays the ape general Thade.  He does a good job, but he breaths real heavily and it gets annoying.  He tries to act like a total "Evil monster" but it would have been better had they just made him into a more emotional guy.  It's fine that they made him into a fearless psychopath, but it would have made the beginning moments (where Thade talks about his love for Ari) more believable.The best part of the movie is the fabulous, Twilight Zone ending that I would never dream of giving away.Over all, the movie seems lackluster and, well, boring.  It's not a bad movie, but I think had they had more time to work on it, it could have been truly great.  I liked the first movie a great deal, but I really wasn't looking forward to this too much.  I guess I sort of sensed it would be this way.  It is worth seeing, but it still lacks a narrative force that makes me want to see it again.  It's sad that they didn't take more time with this, because it had GREAT potential.  Oh well, it's still better than most of the crap that's out.  Except AI.  AI is still the best movie of the year, in my opinion.  Don't bring the kids.6/10

This movie must be a practical joke. It was predictable, silly, and stupid. The make-up for the gorillas was great, but most of chimpanzees looked like pigmen. I hope they don't plan on making any more of these but I'm sure they will. The "big surprise" at the end was obvious once Mark Walberg got in his ship. The only thing this had in common with Pierre Boulle's book was talking apes, and the only thing it had in common with the original film was talking apes. Other than that, everything that makes the book and the original film great (even though they are also very different from each other) is gone. This movie should come with an apology at the end.

About 5 minutes in after the opening titles I knew this was going to be a criminal miscarriage of what could have been. Character exposition in the opening sequence was axed in order to bustle the hero (or lack of one) into the so-called action as soon as possible. What results is a woefully underdeveloped series of events thrusting us along on an adventure that is laughable and miserably cheap. Tim Burton's influences lay in many obscure and cheesy drive-in sci/fi movies and TV shows of the past (which he actually tries to pay homage to rather than satirize) and it's not surprising that this film plays like Lost in Space meets One Million Years BC meets Claude Rains' version of The Lost World meets Planet of the Apes. If Burton felt that people would be excited at the prospect of seeing his own self-indulgent vision of the Book and Heston's classic, full of gawdy touches typical of his style, he was badly mistaken. His realization of Batman was far more successful.When I first saw the commercials for this movie I was immediately taken. Images of marching Ape armies and the atmospheric visuals inspired hopes of a science Fiction action epic like no other. Spartacus conquers the Apes as it were. Sadly it was all window dressing and the truly best parts of this movie are ALL in the commercial spots. What we are subjected to is an unspeakably badly written visual feast which belies a very limited budget lurking just below the surface. The only reason to see this abomination is for the costumes and make-up design, as well as the production design (aside from the space station and space suits which look to have been stolen from the 2001 prop vault).The original planet of the apes is not one of my top ten favorite films but it is an honest and intelligent piece of science fiction. Though a bit of a talk fest, it does bring up some very thought provoking issues (thanks to the great Rod Serling) and ends on one of the most powerful and stunning climaxes in movie history. It's a film deserving of its classic status and rated a better remake than what Richard Zanuck and Tim Burton have foisted on us here. In fact, Zanuck should be fined and his producer's license suspended as he was also in involved in making the original.Any and all intellectual content is missing leaving us with good actors buried under mounds of make-up. Except for Wahlberg, who should have just been buried. This guy is the most vacant action hero since Keanu Reeves in Speed. Aside from disobeying commands in order to rescue his chimp, his motivations are unwritten, leaving him to loaf from one scene to the next muttering little more than "hey" or "what" or "whatever", while glancing more than periodically at his Tandy hand-held. The guy has the intelligence and personality of a soapsud. An actor with a grasp of dead-pan humor might have made this character zing. Wahlberg just sits there, looking constipated as another IMDb reviewer mentioned.As far as the other cast members are concerned, what is the deal with Kris Kristoffersen. He has two lines then gets run through with a spear. Estella Warren is atrocious as the obligatory female human. She's no Raquel Welch in the looks department and is an even worse actress. Helena Bonham-Carter is wasted, as is Tim Roth as Thade and Michael Clark Duncan as his Right-Hand Gorilla. One wonders why they hired big-name actors to be unrecognizable under all that latex when they could have hired medium priced actors and saved some money on the budget. Marquee power I guess. As good as he is, Michael Clark Duncan just sounds like the guy who played Worf in Star Trek.As far as Charlton Heston's uncredited cameo as Thade's father, spouting familiar lines he used to condemn the Apes in the original, though here in reversed context: maybe in another script, with a better director for the material, it would have been sly and humorous. Not here. The same goes for other memorable lines quoted from the original.Much has been debated about the ending, which is about the only pure Burtonian stamp on the movie. It has no relevance other than to set-up a sequel (would anyone care to see it?). It pays homage to Serling and is a twist on the original's shattering ending, but really it comes off more of a tribute to Marty's nightmare sequence in Back to the Future Part II than anything else.What we're left with here, in the wake of other deficient hack jobs such as U-571, The Patriot, Pearl Harbor, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, is a clear message that a great deal of Hollywood no longer cares about providing their audience with a well written and performed production once their marketing machine has lured us into the theatres. If people keep falling for it it's going to end up sealing the end of quality entertainment for good.Here's hoping that The Lord of the Rings doesn't turn out to be a mishandled treatment of Tolkien with GREAT commercials.

reviews.review_title: THE APES WERE COOL... BUT THE HUMANS SUCKED!
reviews.content:
This movie wasn't as bad as some people made it out to be. I found it much more entertaining than the hideous Mummy Returns, and the boring, uninteresting Final Fantasy.Like most 'block buster' movies these days this flick is tops in the C.G.I department but woefully lacking in the plot department. However...BEST STUFF:The apes. Their costumes and makeup were excellently rendered. Their mannerisms were convincingly ape-like (e.g. the tree climbing, the loping gait, fear of water), and they were well-performed by their actors. (Thade, Ari and that elderly Orangutan slave trader come to mind)The different species of apes living together in the ape city. Some of the best ape make up I've seen had to be that huge Orangutan with the enormous cheek pouches and jowls. I liked the idea of chimps, gorillas and Orangutans living together in one big community. The set designs were very pretty.  There's lots and lots of picturesque visuals to look at.NOT SO GREAT STUFF:The human hero. Marky Mark may do better in Funky Bunch music videos (!!) and underpants commercials but he was completely uninteresting here. Spends most of his time running around but hardly looks like he is in any danger. Boring. Thankfully the apes get more screen time than M.M.
The Humans. 99% of the humans in this movie were merely extras in cave man clothes given very little to do. There's supposed to be a romance between M.M and Blonde Cave Girl (B.C.G) but nothing happened (maybe I missed something). Her character seemed to have been added simply to make B.C.G look prettier than the ape woman!The story. Oh dear. I liked this movie for the apes, but the humans and been-done-before plot spoiled it! The numerous holes in the plot must be deliberately ignored in order to enjoy this movie. Why not just forget the humans and have the whole flick about the apes? THE ENDING. It's yet another (SIGH) Hollywood'ised End Act! It's meant to be a shock ending, but surprise, surprise: IT SUCKED!! But it does pave the way for POTA part II!

Until the end of the film this was an entertaining 6 out of 10.  It lost a mark at the end for leaving a bad taste in the mouth thanks to an appalling and ridiculous ending. It made no sense. Until then it was an entertaining film.  Visually amazing, the make up superb and Carter and Roth gave excellent performances. The story just never sparkled, however.  This may be connected to the fact that Walberg doesn't have much screen presence.  Comparing to Heston for a second (not just to compare to the original, but also to compare to a great leading actor), he commanded the screen, made you care what was happening and drew you into the film.  Marky Mark may know how to model underwear, but a great actor he aint.  There is something about him that made me just not care.At the end of the day, unless you've something new to say on the subject, someway to improve it beyond dated makeup, remakes are just pointless.

OK, I like Tim Burton. I did NOT like what he did with Batman, but Edward Scissorhands, Nightmare Before Christmas and of course Beetlejuice, were friggin great. But as Sleepy Hollow taught us, Tim Burton can make a stinker! And guess what? You found another one. Even if (Especially if) you are a fan of the original starring the NRA's Heston, you will hate this movie. All the good actors are dressed like monkeys, so good luck taking them seriously. Then there is Marky Mark. Fortunately he left the funky bunch out of this one. He is good when he plays an idiot being sucked into the porn industry, he is bad as action star. He just is. Rent The Italian hand Job and you will know what I am talking about. He is just not SMART enough to be an astronaut or thief. He is more.... Dirk Diggler. Perfect role. Anyway, if you had to watch this crap (airplane or someone who said its SOOO good) you know that it only gets worse. If you catch the beginning and think, maybe it will pick up, those monkeys look cool. WRONG! Here is a spoiler for you, that part at the end when the monkey saves Marky, is the most contrived predictable piece of doody I have ever seen. Collective groan at the end.

This version of Planet of the Apes was obviously not supposed to be like the mature Heston version.  The original version had more dialogue in which acting ability was so important.  But the old version also moved along at a rapid pace.  This version played more like an action version but was also very good.  Tim Burton for the first time seems to draw the audience in to the movie unlike his previous films which seemed more rock video.  Burton is sure to make many more films and has greatly improved from Sleepy Hollow. 
I saw this film twice and with the second viewing certain details become more understandable.  It is interesting to see how the apes seemed to have imitated human culture.  Burton has the apes doing all the things humans do even saying grace.  But the ape's have no deeper understanding of anything. If you see the film you will understand. I believe Burton has the apes more as a creation from humans and not an evolved species.  The first film has the apes emerge out of a human created disaster of nuclear war.  This film treats the creation of apes in a unique way.I have heard more long debates about this film than any other film of the Summer.  As far as all the criticism of the ending, it seemed much more clear the second time.  SPOILER:  I think it was more of a beginning than an ending.  And if you look on the plaque you will see the name Thade.  Perhaps in the next one we will see a battle by humans to retake a new technologically advanced ape world.  SPOILER: Whatever, it may be that the ending may be another example of apes having imitated the human world by finding books.  Bring on Apes 2 especially with pretty pouty Bonham in it. Lets put Angelina Jolie in it too.

This is one of those films that you just watch once and desist to watch it again. I must confess something: I never liked very much Tim Burton's cinema, and this time it wasn't an exception. The worst thing I find in this film is the whole plot. It's so strange that I'm sure that even Tim can't give a proper explanation.From now on: WARNING, SPOILERS AHEAD.I always heard that time travels are mathematically possible if we follow Einstein's theory. I also saw films like Back to the Future where a change in the past affected the future. But I never saw a film where a change in the present could affect the past. What happens in this film is so weird that it needs a powerful explanation to make it acceptable. As powerful as a second movie, and maybe that's just what Tim was thinking.Here: END OF SPOILERS.Behind the makeup, Helena Bonham Carter looks more like Michael Jackson than like an ape girl, Mark Wahlberg's character is plain and insipid, and the film as a whole is quite boring. I have seen much worse films this year, but this one is bad.5 or 6 out of 10.

Don't get me wrong; Tim Burton has a lot of talent. Most of his films have some eerie, dark atmosphere and quirkiness that's irresistable to most viewers.Something that this film doesn't have.The only impressive aspect of this remake are the elaborate set designs and convincing make-up (watch out for Michael Jackson's cameo as Ari).At first, the film impressed me. It looked cool, the score was good. Then I noticed a pattern in the film.Dialogue scene to running, to more running, back to dialogue, more running, rinse, wash and repeat.Mark Wahlberg is a good actor but he's quite laughable here. Wait until you see his speech about rising up against the apes. This one suffers from the age-old cliche of the band of people too afraid to fight back for the freedom with no choice otherwise. Well, unless they want to die and be put in slavery (at least that would take off the running time a bit).The female character (insert model's name here) is simply used for the sex scene, but there isn't one. The big budget is used for the cool battles that couldn't be done on a small budget. But there is no big cool, entertaining battle. It goes on and on. Should I talk about the ending? If you enjoyed the film you'll say "Wow! What a smart, intelligent ending! Now, if I just knew what it means..." and weeks later you're still puzzling over it until you realize Tim Burton has wasted even more of your time thinking it actually makes sense. Hey, if you're going to have a huge twist at the end most won't figure out, at least make what came before it interesting and atmospheric like Mulholland Drive or something.

*SPOILERS  *SPOILERS*  *SPOILERS*The original is already a classic and here the makers got the chance to introduce the story to a younger generation taking advantage of the technical advantages of today while using one of the original director of today's Hollywood, Tim Burton, whose unique style is something that can give the edge the film needed. However the result is less than you expected from a technical or story and characters development point of view.As usual there are a list of good and bad things and I'll start with the good ones:Make up - Almost perfect. The actors look like apes and you would not guess that there are real actors under the masks(I won't be surprise if the make-up will win an Oscar). That saying there are some reservation. While the man apes are perfect the female apes are less good. They look like actors and not like real apes. The decision to let the apes walk and jump like apes do is used to a great effect and is the big advantage of the film.The dark tone of the story is been reflected in the dark cinemtography. Even when there is light it is not a strong one but it is moody and dark.Music- As usual the music from Danny Elfman is effective and serve the film.Tim Roth as General Thade is excellent and his performance convey the menace and the hunger for power that exist in his character.That all I can say that was good in the movie. The list of bad things will be longer:Mark Wahlberg as Capt. Leo Davidson is weak. He doesn't carry the film on his shoulders and moreover he is not as strong as Tim Roth's Thade. How can anyone see him as a messiah is beyond my understanding.In the original film the main female character, Dr. Zira(Kim Hunter), was a scientist. She fought for the humans to have equal rights because she think they are intelligent but she could not prove it because all the humans in that film couldn't speak. The arrival of Col. Taylor(Charlton Heston) gave her the tool to prove her theory because he could speak. Beside that she was a strong and believable character. Here the main female character, Ari(Helena Bonham Carter,) is been portrayed as "human lovers". There is no reason why shy thinks like that or what made her change her mind in such an hostile environment towards humans. It doesn't help that her performance is so weak and her contribution to the film is less than zero. In general the female apes are less convinced than the men apes.Towards the end of the film,the chimpanzee that was sent in the beginning of the film and that we thought has already died, re-appear,out of nowhere. This development in the story is very contrive and served only as mean to end the battle between the apes and the human. How the chimpanzee has survive the magnetic storm. Your guess is as good as mine. Another development that strike me as contrive is the decision of General Thade's aide to simply turn to the other side just because he doesn't believe The General anymore. Why has this happened? Through the whole film that aide is a loyal servant. He has no reason to doubt The General so what happened now? Was it enough for him to hear Cat.Davidson's words in order to change his heart? In short no logic in both events.The ending doesn't help making the film coherent. The only explanation i can think of is that the storm was not only a jump through time but also a jump through dimension. Otherwise the whole film stand on very weak basis and the ending make the whole film illogical.I like Tim Burton. I have seen every film his has done(not all perffect) and I would continue to see his films. However something is missing from this film. He is in his best when he direct projects that he initiate or are close to his heart. His best films were the ones that have an outsider as a hero that Burton, as an outsider himself, can identify with. I didn't have the feeling that he was fully committed to this project, probably because he was hired to direct this film and didn't initiated it.At the end I was very disappointed. Something that looked good and promise to taste good turned out to be not as good as it should and could have been. Just like an half baked cake. It looks good from the outside but it taste bad because someone forgot to put some of the ingredients that would have make the best in the world.

And with that comment goes the first, last, and only bad primate pun in this review.Leave it to Tim Burton to take a familiar franchise or story, keep enough of the source material to make it familiar, then add his own unique twist. "Planet of the Apes" is much like "Batman" or "Sleepy Hollow" in that respect.  You know what you're getting, but not sure of how it's going to be told, or what surprises lie along the way.This is "B movie" fun at its finest.  Of course, you're dealing with a film about talking monkeys, so if you're going into this film expecting something overtly serious, you're not going to find it.  It's a very surreal film, both in its ideas and in watching the human-like apes, swing, beat their chests, ride horses, and carry on conversations.  It's fascinating and a little scary at the same time.  Burton's quirky sense of humor is definitely apparent in the ape cities.  The make-up in this film is great, especially the gorilla soldiers.  The actor cameos are fun to spot (Watch for Heston - Burton does a good job in paying homage to the original series), and the twist in meaning of the original film's dialogue is definitely worth a laugh or two.The story was an interesting take on the original series.  At times it was silly (and seems aware of this), but not necessarily in an unpleasant way. The biggest problem that I had with the story was in the resolution (I thought a lot of the conflict issues were too neatly and conveniently tied up).    Burton also did a nice job providing a new spin on the classic film's infamous "Statue of Liberty" scene.  There definitely seems to be plans in the works for a sequel by the way it ended.I think this film will get some criticism for what it is, but you know, this isn't the type of film that is going to teach you something about yourself, nor will it provide the solution to all the world's problems by the time the end credits roll.  I had fun with this.  It was wild, it was campy, the acting performances were good for this type of film, and the special effects were entertaining.  I enjoyed this film for what it set out to do, and I'm glad it's not simply a rehash of the original film.Burton has still been unable to let me down, and still remains one of my favorite directors.  I'll definitely add this to my "Burton DVD" collection.

Not much I can add that others already haven't.  This is a typical Burton movie where story is sacrificed to visuals.  There is barely enough story to provide an excuse for all the lush visuals to exist.The movie is entertaining enough, but why does nobody give a crap about script anymore? This movie could have been so much more but its only real contribution is to advance ape make-up technology.  It's not a movie I'm anxious to see again; very few films made these days seem to have that quality.All the various flaws in the film have been pointed out already, but there is one thing I'd like to address and that's the question of female chimpanzees being the sexually dominant one.  First off, why introduce this "fact" if it's not going to be explored?  Second, it's not correct.  There is an offshoot of the chimpanzee, the bonobo, (which tends to walk upright as often as not) where the female is more dominant, but in the main species (the one which scoots around on all fours), the male chimp rules the roost and I don't think this film was cognizant of bonobos or much of anything else, for that matter.

This movie was entertaining and very different from either the original movie or the book (actually it was closer to the book).  The special effects were excellent as well as the make-up and the body movements of the actors.Charlton Heston makes as an ape and quotes verbatim one of his most famous lines from the original movie but it seems out of context.Possible Spoiler ahead:
Not to give away the ending, but it seemed the writer tried to have it parallel Pierre Boulle's ending but it causes great confusion.  You are never quite sure whether they are traveling to the future, past or to a parallel world existing in the same time continuum.

reviews.review_title: how to make a bad movie with big budget
reviews.content: oh come on!, when are they going to stop doing things like this?, when are they going to realize it doesn't matter how much money they spend on fireworks and publicity... if they don't spend some few cents on writing a script that is not insulting to the viewers' intelligence, the movie is nothing but garbage? well, I've had enough of these nonsense, stupid scripts, with all the plot holes, corny sentimental moments and recycled jokes.  Sure I enjoyed the customes, the visual effects and the sexy blue eyed blonde, but I would have enjoyed it more if the movie showed at least a fraction of the impact the original series did. Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter.. they were good enough, frankly I believe they are wasting their talent on garbage like this.  I wish them better vision to choose better scripts in the future. Only one more thing:  I'm really dissapointed at Tim Burton.

reviews.review_title: I've seen it 3 times and I still dont know if I like it
reviews.content: I've seen this film 3 times and I still dont know if I like it or not. There were some element of this film that were great. the special effects were of masterpiece quality.this movie has lots of action. The story moves at a decent pace. the plot(although predictible)is good. The actors did a good job. The real let down to this movie was the disapointing resolution to the climax, and the bazaar twist on the ending that left me wondering what just happened. this film would've been one of the all time great sci-fi flicks ever had the last 10 minutes of this film hadn't have ruined it. All in all I will have to say that Planet of the Apes 2002 is a good special effects movie with a weird and disapointing/empty ending.

I just got back from screening Planet of the Apes at the theater I work at. What I was most afraid of was whether or not the movie had SDDS sound.  It does, thank god. I am a fan of Tim Burton's.  He makes great movies.  When I heard about this movie, I thought, although a bad idea, that it might be an interesting movie.  I'm not too familiar with the original "Apes" movies, so I can't compare, but this movie does have a surprise ending similar to the original's, minus the surprise.I noticed the movie was written by William Broyle's Jr., as well a two other guys.  I got worried after that considering he wrote the horrible "Castaway".  I can't really give him credit for making this movie bearable, though.  Burton and his crew pretty much deserves the credit for that. This movie's plot is riddled with cliches from a General who was outcasted getting revenge only to die to an old Ape guy dying RIGHT AFTER telling Thade (Roth) what WE need to know.  It's as if the writers were afraid their slightly unique version was too unique and was becoming unrecognizable.SPOILER WARNING:I thought some of the ideas in the movie were intriguing and scary.  Not so much the idea that apes COULD become the leaders of a planet due to time travel and evolution from experimental monkeys, but that they DID.  I felt the whole play on equality was too preachy and phony, however.  Planet of the Apes is far from being the best movie of the summer - that title still belongs to The Mummy Returns - but it's a decent movie, although it lacked any humor whatsoever.

reviews.review_title: Reasonable re-imagining of a classic tale
reviews.content: I liked this film... it was not a great film, but it was a good film.  I felt that it entertained me for the 2 hours or so that it was on and I didnot feel screwed out of 6 bucks... however, this film did not MOVEme the way the original film did... it danced with certain issueswithout ever really delving into them... it used the image of slaverwithout addressing the substance (and so had to rely on deus exmachina resolution rather than the more cerebral ending of theoriginal...)Overall, I think that the ending of this film would have been better atthe end of the original movie, reminding us that WE were the apesand bringing home the point of the film a clear way.  However,since this film only used racism a slavery as a plot device theending simply seemed to say 'boo' rather than to make one thinkor reflect.This is not to say that I disliked Tim Burton's version in any way,but simply to point out that it does not have the same resonanceas the original... worth seeing, but make sure you give the 1968one a read as well.

I went on the movie, Planets of the apes, with "semi" expectations. For some reason I didn´t expect much from talking monkeys. In some way I was surprised with how fantastic the make up was in the movie and how well the monkey, sorry, "ape" caracters were well performed. The physical expression off them was believable and worked quite well but thats about it. I hoped that the movie would get better in the second "half" but on the contrary it got twice as bad.I heard that Tim Burton had made 5 endings to the movie and this one was chosen rather than the others. Anyone who has seen the movie must be thinking, how bad could the other four endings be so that this one was chosen. The ending is so bad that it effects the whole plot of the movie and made me give this movie 4/10.If the ending would have been different, would have made a little bit of sense, then it would possibly get a higher score.Please write me if you think this writing is out of the blue, or even smack down in the middle of the blueÁgúst Kr, IcelandP.S. pardon my spelling

Many emotions struck me while watching one of the summer's most anticipated films Planet of the Apes'. Yet, the emotion that struck me the most was that of ingenuity. Director Tim Burton proves himself as an ingenious filmmaker and he proves it twofold in this exciting, inventive and thrilling film. The sets are spectacular, costumes are terrific and Danny Elfman's musical score captures the essence of the film as he does with all his musical compositions for Burton's films. The producers of the film have stressed that this is not a remake, but more so a revisiting' of the original. Anyone who compares this film to the original is gravely mistaken due to the mere fact that the 2001 version has been dichotomized by one of the soon to be' legendary alternative filmmakers - Tim Burton. This film widely separates itself from the original as seen from its' first frame and takes off on a whole new different direction. The film opens with a great credit intro. sequence displaying Danny Elfman's fierce musical score which sets the film's tone not as an unrealistic fantasy, but as a rousing sci-fi/adventure. The opening scene depicts Wahlberg's ill-fated space station attempt at conducting test runs with the ape species. After a mishap forces him off the ship, Wahlberg's character Leo Davidson finds himself crash landing on a distant planet ruled by apes.  This is where the fun begins Director Tim Burton puts a classic spin in this film invoking the notion of role reversal. In this planet, humans are the pets, the slaves, in essence humans on that planet are all the things we as humans on this planet earth shape and torture our inferiors to be. A great scene is one of the very first that immediately displays the intelligence of these iron fist creatures conversing around the dinner table about the threat of the human species. Enter this year's ultimate movie villain  General Thade. The incredibly underestimated and unrecognizable Tim Roth plays this overachieving ape villain who is hell-bent on the total annihilation of all humans with fierce audacity and destruction. Upon the dissection of this film as a cinematic lesson, one will discover many plot holes' - (Did Leo Davidson and Ari, his rebellious ape escort have a love affair?) Many more plot holes -  (Did Leo Davidson and Estella Warren's human rebel Daena also have an affair?). Mysterious deaths not explained - (Why exactly did one character so unexpectedly sacrifice himself for the sake of others and the rest of pack continue on as if nothing happened?) These mind-benders as well as others will occupy the intelligent filmgoer's mind for quite some time after the film.Yet, these questions can all be put to rest because Burton does not set out to win awards with this film (Except for Best Make-Up come Oscar time for Rick Baker). This film is merely a means of the best of the popcorn blockbusters' this summer. As well, we see Burton's maturity as a Director in relation to the grandeur of a film. Let's face it  the revisiting of the classic apes' films is a huge undertaking. And for Tim Burton to create and present a richly satisfying, fun film is quite the achievement. Anyone who expects a brash film course should not watch this film. This film wants the audience to have fun and to dwell into a world never seen before in this uniqueness. Therefore in this sense, the film scores some big points in terms of imagination and vision.  The film makes it a point of paying homage' to the originals yet distancing it enough so it is not afraid to make fun of itself. Furthermore, despite its surreal qualities, fantastic set pieces and incredibly true to life ape creatures brought to life by a wonderful cast, the film's major drawback is that it seems too dark and animalistic for its' own good. We are all aware that Burton's visionary uniqueness is brought forward with dark sets and spooky visions. Yet, it seems as if Burton intentionally wants us to know this is his creation even when we are entangled within the film, resulting in the darkness and primal aesthetic being overused. But in an odd way this is what adds to the genius and excellence of it all. Resulting in this film easily regarded as one of Burton's best films.Giancarlo's Rating: ***

Thanks for selling out Mr. Burton... for caving-in and creating another high action piece of garbage that Hollywood thinks makes a good movie. Sure, visually, this movie is plenty slick and the make-up and costumes are artistry. Too bad that's simply not enough to hold the interest of most ten year olds, let alone adults. The lack of plot and character development really shocked me for a Burton film. I'm left to again wonder if Hollywood really thinks we are all that stupid? From the completely impossible story line and ridiculous scenes, to the humans glossy lips in the desert, I felt like a victim of a very bad joke. Even my eight year old began asking "how much longer is this movie?" a short 30 minutes into it. Save your money and rent the classic - for all of it's weaknesses, it at least has characters that you come to care something about.

I just watched this on tv.  I agree with the earlier comments rating this as mediocre and illogical at every turn (within the bounds of the fantastic premise of course.)  I haven't read most of the 1238! comments but don't see any bringing up an aspect which jumped out at me.  __  To digress, I was stunned to see that, when the film Ghost Busters was turned into a tv cartoon series, Aykroyd's & Murray's characters were transferred not unlike the originals but Ernie Hudson, the one black ghost buster, was replaced by an ape!  Planet of the Apes strikes me the same way.  __  I'm white and do not presume to speak for blacks but I cannot see how this movie, with only one token black human surrounded by otherwise entirely white humanity, can avoid coming off as comparing blacks to simians.  Yes, I realize that this flick is presenting a lame, elementary-school-level case for liberalism.  I do not however see that as negating the fact that, while the film repeatedly instructs us that slavery is bad and that intolerance is bad, the humans are basically purely white, which means that the other set of characters (the apes) must represent blacks.  __  A weak claim is made that humans enslaved apes and now, after turnabout, apes have enslaved humans.  The problem with that is that humans do not use apes as slaves.  Hmm, who did whites used to enslave if not apes?  Blacks.  So then, if this society represents a reversal of our own, who must the apes represent?  Blacks.  __  Other fantasy films successfully make the desired point by either having characters of different colors or races on both sides, thus pointing out that intolerance is not inherently caused by racial difference, or by having characters with cultural differences which in no way resemble actual ethnic or racial groups.  I am in no way saying that the apes in this film resemble actual blacks but I am saying that some of the characteristics (besides their ability to ignore the laws of physics) they exhibit are exactly how bigots used to make fun of blacks.  __  Am I the only one here who was alive before the civil rights movement and thus what I'm talking about is totally foreign to the rest of your experiences?  Please explain to me how I am reading things wrong, if I am.

unfortunate that someone must explain things to a viewer...  is this a flaw with the movie, a fault of the director...  or just a lack of intelligence and imagination on the part of the viewer...?the ("much-controversial") ending makes complete sense and does not deserve the discredit it has received--  remember "...alternate futures...?" "...multiple contexts...?"  "...infinite time-loops...?" As long as CPT Leo Davidson keeps re-launching into the "electro-magnetic storm,"(--their terms--), he will encounter random, possible futures...  As suggested by the encounter with the "unknown" "Mayday" which is, infact,by the Oberon commander (Lt Gen. Vasich???). That's HIM(!!!) in the mayday, in case you didn't get it... But since it hasn't happened yet, it's a clue as to the time-dispatial aspect  of the "cloud" in space...  (Not to mention the "chimp" appearing AFTER Mark Wahlberg int the "future"... Were you sleeping...? Or did film just get too difficult for you...?" less imaginative viewers continue to complain... I thought it was a good movie, overall, although I don't like the use of close- to medium-shots during the chase&capture scenes in the first few minutes of the film...  This is the only point where I find this re-make markably inferior to its predescessor (which I saw in the theaters on it's initial run as a child...) The first film shined superior here with its use of long shots and suspension of clear "ape-"shots...  But then we all knew what this second film was about, didn't we? A congratulations to Tim Burton...  Continue the  good work...

I have just returned from the cinema, having looked forward to this film as Tim Burton is god and I have always liked the original film.However, what started as quite an enjoyable sci fi romp quickly degraded into a godawful mess.  We were expected to believe in the characters and actually feel for them, but how could we when we barely knew their names?  When discussing the film with my friend afterwards we were referring to "blonde slave girl" and "helena bonham carter" and "that guy from the green mile".  but that wasn't the only problem with the film.  The script was full of so many plot holes that by the time the end rolled around you were scratching your head and wondering if they were going to explain it.  they didn't. and then the ending... well, when  trying to fit it in with the context of the preceding story it smacks more of an opening for the sequel... will marky mark escape from the planet of the apes, tune in same time next week!  oh, tim, tim tim... i still believe in you.

This is a great movie. Mark Wahlberg does a great job on being a hero, and Tim Roth plays a great jerk for an ape. Tim Burton made this movie come alive. I hope everyone gets a chance to see this great movie.10/10

Tim Burton is one of Hollywood's darkest, most imaginative filmmakers, so one must wonder what went wrong with his latest venture, a reworking of the 1968 sci-fi classic, Planet of the Apes.  This is Tim Burton-lite, and as easily distinguishable as his prior films are, it's disheartening to see that he clearly gave in to Hollywood blockbuster mentality, as Planet bears no sign of his signature dark style.Planet of  The Apes is loosely based on its predecessor.  Mark Whalberg (here a cardboard cut-out action hero) stars as an astronaut who gets sucked into a time warp (?) and finds himself crash landing on a planet and captured by talking apes who have created a society where humans are their servants.  He finds a friend in female ape Helen Bonham Carter. The rest of the movie follows our hero Whalberg as he attempts to escape from his captors, in particular a nasty General played by an unrecognizable Tim Roth.The story is hardly noteworthy.  It's merely a clothesline on which to hang a few charged action sequences, grandiose sets, and the human actors eluding their captors.  What made the classic so striking was its scenes of the apes treating the humans as livestock.  Here, director Tim Burton has instead chosen to eschew characters and rely on the quality of the first film to garner any sort of sympathy for his characters.  The only likeable characters are, again, Helen Bonham Carter as an ape who sympathizes with and wants to help the humans, and Paul Giamatti, as a wise-cracking ape who by the end becomes very grating with his one-liners.The only true innovation in this updated version is the makeup; it's light years ahead of the 1968 version, and the actors disappear behind it, as well as the militarized costumes.  The apes look more ferocious, but this is a very poor substitute for an actual story.  Even the action sequences are dumbed down, with bullets and spears flying, there is no blood onscreen whatsoever.  Was it the studios who persisted in Burton to not show blood? Sleepy Hollow was a gorefest, but I imagine since this is a huge studio summer blockbuster, all controversial images and language were censored in order to have a more family oriented (money-making) movie.With all its flaws, Planet of the Apes is made watchable thanks to the amazing makeup and the performances from Roth and Bonham-Carter.  Perhaps Tim Burton will push the envelope with his next film, as here his influence seems nonexistent, except for the dark ending bound to leave audiences looking for a total mindless summer film confused.6 out of 10

I'm glad the local store rents DVD's for $1.49 a night, otherwise I never would have gotten to see this.  What gets me is all these "industry" types, who know the film is a total disgrace, but since they really don't give a whit about anything in life but padding the bottom line, are like- "who cares if the acting is miserable and there's no depth to the story, no complexity, no nothing - I thought it was pretty entertaining,  and the costumes and special effects were great!"  Or "we'll recap on the foreign market and dvd special features"  Gag.These people are ruining the medium of film.You put so much money and time and effort into a work like this, but you completely ignore the few things that could turn it from TV-quality crap (with GREAT SPECIAL EFFECTS!!!!) into a real, honest to god movie.  To bad they could collectively care less.  They're not movie-makers, they're just businessmen.Well, I'm glad to say you got all of about 5 cents from my viewing...cheers.

reviews.review_title: the worste movie I have seen in a long time
reviews.content: This is the worst movie I have seen for years! It starts ridicoulus and continues in the same way. I thnik when is something going to happen in this film,,,, and the the acting is worse. The ending lifts it a bit and saves the movie from a total flop. Mark Wahlberg is a bad actor in a bad movie. Sorry Tim Burton Batman was good but this one sucks.

I've read somewhere that this is the worst movie Tim Burton has ever made. Well, for that, its pretty cool !On the other hand, there is nothing in it to get in any way excited about it. Just a very average science fiction story. Well the surrounding are made very nice. The apes really look and behave like intelligent apes. But the story itself lacked any noticeable inspiration, except maybe some nice jokes - such as apes fearing water. On the other hand, there where story holes, and unexplained parts. Especially the end was really bad.For men, there is Estella Warren with her supersweet kissme-mouth. But she appeared quite seldom in the scenes, and had not really much more personality and charisma than the boring Marky Mark, the main actor. Helena Bonham Carter was however very good, as was Tim Roth.I can't really recommend this one.

reviews.review_title: A movie by monkeys for monkeys (or apes or whatever)
reviews.content: Hello, Tim Burton are you out there! No you are not. You were "out there" before and that why I've loved most of your movies, but you've really crash landed with this boring, conventional and leaden remake of "Apes". (I can't believe that I'm using the words, boring, conventional and leaden in association with your name.) In fact this movie was so bad that my friend and I walked out of it BEFORE it ended. This is only the 2nd time I've ever done this in my life. Fortunately for you I'm only 2 years old (if I was living on Pluto that is --I'm actually 43). Hello Mr. Broyles and your co-screenwriter did you ever see "X-Men"? It had similar themes about racism and segregation but it kept it speeches to a minimum preferring to show rather than tell us. I got tired of talking apes early on in this movie (or was it a stillvie because it didn't move much). Barry Sonnefeld once said that when he was done making a movie it was as bad as possibly could be. Well guess what Mr. Burton you proved his point with "Apes". However you are in good company and I'll tell you why. Tim Burton's "Planet Of The Apes" is the biggest disappointment since Stanley Kubrick's "Eyes Wide Shut". Bring back Catwoman.

I saw the clips,I read the bad reviews but I went to see the movie AND BOY DOES IT STINK, The story line is horrible,the acting is hamy,the sets looks like they came from the 68 version,in one scene the set even moves. This is Ed Wood meets the apes.

This is definitely one of the better films I have seen this year, perhaps even the best.  Tim Burton once again delivers a movie that oozes with style, class and sophistication, with a world so detailed and believable it's almost mind-blowing.  Not being familiar with the original movie/tv series myself, I didn't quite know what to expect.  I knew from the few articles I had read that Mark Wahlberg plays a pilot who crash lands on a planet ruled by apes, and in an interesting twist, finds himself as the "alien".  The story is a great concept and really brings up some interesting issues to think about.  This is one of the things I appreciated about it.  It is one big role-reversal but in two different ways.  Firstly we're no longer the master species in control, we're the animals without the souls to be used and abused. Secondly, instead of being discriminated against because we might be black, white or purple, we're now discriminated against because we're simply human. It says a lot about how we as humans treat others, whether it be animals or people...  I really liked this movie.  The actors were great, especially Tim Roth as Thade.  I've never encountered such a menacing, intimidating character as Roth's Thade on screen before.  Helena Bonham Carter's Ari was curious, naive and likeable and Mark Wahlberg didn't disappoint.  In general, all the ape actors did a fantastic job and combined with the stunningly detailed make-up, pulled it all off in a very convincing fashion.Danny Elfman is the man responsible for the film's score and I remember thinking during the credits, "Hmm, that name is familiar..."  I will definitely remember his name from now on.  The score is excellent, and at times spine-chilling, particularly during the opening credits.I'm an every-movie person and I really couldn't find much to fault Planet of the Apes on.  My only gripe is that like so many movies these days, it leaves you feeling just a little unsatisfied somehow..  Maybe it's how film-making has changed these days, or the new techniques they use, I really can't put my finger on it.  But with this film it's only a minor thing.  See it.  You wont be disappointed.

WARNING: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS (though hopefully you'll read them and then not decide to see the movie and thus save yourself seven hard earned bucks...)This movie was garbage in practically every regard. The dialouge was terrible, the plot didn't make sense, the acting was mediocre at best, the action scenes were lame, the hyped "social messages" were blunt and shallow, and the big surprise ending was astonishingly dumb and impossible. Given how many screenplays Hollywood must get, its pretty incredible that they made this one into a summer blockbuster. There are a couple bright spots in this movie: Many of the ape actors do fine jobs, especially Helena Bonham Carter who turns in by far the film's best performance, and Estella Warren looks absolutely gorgeous wandering around in her skimpy outfits. Beyond that, the movie is worthless in every way. First of all, the plot makes no sense at all. A couple examples: 1. The name of the ape's secret city is Calia, which we learn comes from a sign reading "Caution Live Animals" which is covered by dust except for the first couple letters of each word, except that presumably the city was named thousands of years ago when the apes left it BEFORE any of the dust accumulated. 2. When the humans are about to be totally overrun by the ape army, Mark Wahlberg comes up with the idea of using the still intact fuel in his spaceship that crashed thousands of years ago (huh?) to blow up the apes. "Cool" we think, except that all it seems to do is knock over about 40 apes out of the few thousand in the army, and they just get back up again. So then the humans attack and the battle seems to be pretty fair. Huh? If they could put up a fight in the first place, why were they coming up with this dumb scheme that didn't even do anything? 3. Okay, I know Estella Warren is gorgeous, but seriously, neither her character nor any other human character in the movie except Mark Wahlberg had any significance to the plot. I think she had literally about 5 lines and was ignored throughout most of the film. Her father's only purpose was getting killed by a big ape early on, after he said somewhere around 2 lines, and that little kid (her brother?) was also completely insignificant except towards the end when he somehow tips over his horse, except that didn't really matter at all to the plot either. 4. The ending (BIG SPOILER AHEAD) was just dumb. Dumb dumb dumb. Okay, so here he is in PRESENT DAY earth except it's all apes again. First of all, this is predictable, but it still doesn't make sense. We're supposed to believe (I think) that Thade somehow managed to go back in time to earth and change the course of history, but somehow it turned out exactly the same way, down to the archetecture of the Washington monument, as it was when humans were the dominant species. What? what??? Whatever, it's dumb as wood anyway. Also, the rest of the movie was just lame. For one thing, the big hyped action scenes were ridiculously lame. Basically, a human would punch an ape, who'd turn around and punch the human and send him sailing about 25 feet into the air at which point he'd die, unless he happened to be named Mark Wahlberg, in which case he'd be perfectly fine. huh? Also, we were set up for this big climatic fight between the two ape generals, which predictably happned, but it was remarkably tame too. They pretty much just jumped at each other and beat each others chests for around 15 seconds before one the them died. Also, the whole social message thing had been done much better before and seemed unconvincing when done here. You get the impression that the actors in ape makeup are having trouble keeping a straight face while delivering these overly deep and significant but at the same time really really dumb lines... 1/10

I. What? So. I don't know.You see. Uhm. Wait.
That was one of the many problems with this movie was it supposed to a profound commentary or a campy movie?Some of the dialogue was embarrassing. "Can't we all just get along." Bad acting especially Estelle Warren. Great lips a plus but that's it. As for Marky Mark if it wasn't for this movie we would have 'Entourage' so he gets a pass. Great costumes but movie just didn't work.

If this had been the FIRST Planet of the Apes, I think reviews would be quite different of this movie.  But, unfortunatly, because of the cult following that the original series has (me included), it is compared with the classic.  I myself can see why it doesn't compare with the original, and I agree, it is NOT as good as the first Planet of the Apes.All that being said, I must say that taken by itself, this version of Planet of the Apes is actually quite good.  The make-up effects were GREAT as were the other special effects.  As for the story, I didn't it was bad.  The dialogue could have been better, but what do you really want from Burton? As for the acting, so Wahlberg needs some acting lessons?  Tim Roth was very good, as was Michael Clarke Duncan.  And even though she had all that make-up on, Helena Bonham Carter was STILL sexy as hell. 
Although not exactly up to the original classic, this version is a fun movie.  I also, hope that there is a second one.  This time maybe get somebody other than Burton to direct it.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful images don't mean a good movie...
reviews.content: Planet of The Apes is a Tim Burton film.  And, knowing that it is in Burton's habits to put spectacular and beautiful yet dark and mysterious images on film, I expected a "Planet of The Apes" with the same story than the original, but with a different perspective in the images.  But I was somehow disappointed to see that, sure the images were nice, though not as amazing as "Edward Scissorhands"' or "Batman"'s, but the script seemed to have forgotten.  The film lasts two hours, but you don't see them pass away, because you feel like nothing happens in the film, but everything is happening at the same time.  The movie could be separated in like three chapters; The beginning, the core and the ending.  That's it, no surprises, nothing special, except the images and Tim Roth's acting.  This film wasted lots of potential interesting performances *Spoilers warning*(Kris Kristofferson doesn't even play a role, he only runs and die, and Helena Bonham Carter has a very hollow and empty role as an ape who has more feelings, and her feelings are so hard to see because of the limited facial expression due to the make up).  Plus, they put Estella Warren wearing some kind of leaves made bikini, isn't that superficial and commercial?  This is the first Tim Burton film that deceives me, and I hope it's the last one. This is a very good example of a movie which has special and make up effects as a structure.  many people won't realize it, because they'll be fascinated by the images, but this blind attitude is exactly what the makers expected. Planet of The Apes is more a (commercial) vision of The Planet of The Apes by Tim Burton.  It is not so identic to the original, I couldn't say it's a remake.  The ending is good though, but is still pretty predictable.  But really, you can't really get inside of the movie, because it is not attaching enough, all you can do is look at the images...I give it 4/10.

Having never seen the 1968 version, I went into this not knowing quite what to expect. It occurs to me that this film wouldn't exist without the Charlton Heston version and its sequels. Imagine if Franklin Schaffner had never adapted Pierre Boule's novel. Do you suppose that now someone would still come along and say, hey, that would make a good movie? Actually let me re-phrase that: would that make a movie ANYONE would be interested in seeing? Not likely. So having seen Tim Burton's newly 're-imagined' "Planet of the Apes," am I glad there was an original whos coat-tails it could ride? Well, it's not terrible. At times it's downright interesting. Ultimately, though, it's just unnecessary. But that doesn't mean you can't enjoy it as long as it's around. Like any Burton film, this one is about escape. It transports you to another place and time. The sets, the makeup, the effects all work hard to create this temporary reality. It's convincing but, visually, I was hoping for something more like "Sleepy Hollow." I was never amazed by anything in "Apes" but was stunned by some of the things Burton and his crew accomplished on such previous films as "Sleepy Hollow" and "Batman." "Apes" seemed like fertile ground for the same visual opportunities, but Burton doesn't make good. At best, he's made the kind of cheesy sci-fi he poked fun at in "Mars Attacks." The irony! This didn't look or feel like a Tim Burton film at all. Where is the weird coolness that creeps into every single shot? Think of "Batman," how it more than overcame that horrid script with Palance and Nicholson, along with Burton's twisted vision of Gotham City. And where did the humor go? Burton picks NOW to get serious? THIS film? I mean, if this was the best he was going to do with "Planet of the Apes," he should have just stuck his name on it as producer and let some up-and-comer direct (actually, that will happen with the inevitable sequel, er, sequels). Not even Tim Burton can save us from Summer 2001, a film lover's nightmare.
Grade: C-

What took so long to re-make this 68 sci-fi classic? I had been expecting it since the early 90's! From reading the reviews, however, I get the feeling that it was probably only me who made that prediction. Why did I predict or even insisted that there would be a re-make of Planet Of The Apes?  Well, for one thing, I believed that the advanced cinema techniques could add so much flavour to the original screenplay, which was superbly revolutionary (please read my review for the original Planet Of The Apes 68' to see why I consider the original screenplay to be "revolutionary"). I have always thought that the original Planet Of The Apes was full of imaginative thoughts but it lacked juicy action scenes that could have made it even more fun to watch (however even this drawback didn't stop it from becoming a classic sci-fi, probably the best of its genre).
