The other reason why I expected a re-make was because I wanted to see my most favourite sci-fi saga being re-imagined, as director Tim Burton put it. My Vote: 7/10Things I liked about the movie: In contrast to other people, I liked the screenplay. In fact, I thought that it was brilliant. It was probably the best screenplay that could have been written for this movie without the "it-was-earth-all-along" concept that shocks the audience in the 68' version. I was as much amused by the twists in the end, as I was amused when I watched the original 68' version. Even the last 4-5 minutes were such a great enjoyment. I honestly think the screenplay works. But as much as it works, screenplay was not the best thing about the movie. I personally think that there are mainly two things about this movie that left me in complete amazement, 1) Tim Roth's performance and 2) The original score of the movie, both of which well deserve Oscar Nomination. Tim Roth was the only REAL APE in the movie; the rest were just humans under ape costumes. Tim Roth was the only one who really gave his character an identity. He was not just an ape; he was an ape with a personality. The rest of the cast couldn't even manage to act or even look like apes, except for their costumes, of course. The original score was totally mind-blowing. It is a musical expression of what's going on in the movie. Marvellous achievement!Things I didn't like about the movie: In contrast what other people think, I thought that the apes were too human. They were humans under ape costumes. Most of them didn't even try to act or move like an ape (except for Tim Roth). Obviously, they thought that wearing an ape costume was enough. I could puke at the dinner scene when the elderly ape character was speaking: he was just TOO HUMAN. And again, in contrast what other people think, I wasn't satisfied with the make up. Well, for one thing, the cast put too much trust in their make-ups; they didn't make the slightest effort to give themselves an ape-like personality (a couple of scenes showing them hanging upside down from the ceilings or trees don't redeem that - if they are ape enough to do that then how come they are so much human when talking?). Secondly, the make up in the original version was as good as it could get; it was revolutionary in its time. That's why, there was nothing revolutionary about the make ups in this one. Briefly, it was not better than the make ups in the original 68' version. Lastly, I saw a couple of flaws in the make up. For one thing, the one ape character -the one who sells humans as gifts- hadn't had his eyelids painted; every time he closed his eyes, his eyelids would look white (am I the only one who saw that?). Some of the actors' upper teeth had ape-like appearance, whereas their lower level teeth were obviously human-like. What about the hair of Ari (Helena Bonham Carter)? It looked like she had hair done in a beauty salon; it was too human. And her make up was terribly cheap, as if she was a little girl who didn't know how to put a make up. Maybe, Tim Burton wanted to give story a different respective with these ideas on purpose. But honestly, I don't think they work. My last criticism is the inappropriate sense of humour, which has become the disease of Hollywood in recent years. Directors must be very careful about the timing and the nature of the humour otherwise they spoil the whole movie. There are some silly jokes that work perfectly fine in the genre of comedy (Rush Hour, American Pie, Jim Carrey / Eddie Murphy kind of comedies and the like). But when you use jokes out of these movies in a movie that has a totally different personality, it spoils it. Within that respect, I have found the scene where the elderly ape character is taking his fake teeth out and putting into a jar absolutely inappropriate. Other then these flaws, the movie was a perfect re-make of an old sci-fi classic. Possible Academy Awards Nominations: 1) Best Performance By A Leading Actor In A Motion Picture: Tim Roth. 2) The Original Score: Danny Alfman

This movie has great looks, the apes (with a few exceptions) really look apelike, you've got lush jungles, deserts, big, action packed fight scenes, and a whole ape city that looks totally realistic. Director Tim Burton wasted no expense or effort to make this a visual feast. Too bad he didn't put the same effort into creating a terrific story, especially since there was so much potential to work with. The 1968 original is considered a Sci-Fi classic, not just because of the story, but also the issues it dealt with. It used a society where apes are the top species to comment on and satirize our own society. There are moments of this in "Apes 2001", but mostly it's another big budget action film, only with actors in monkey costumes. As proof of this, the lead character, played by Mark Wahlberg (aka Marky Mark) is just another hotshot fighter jock, meaning there's no problem he thinks he can't solve by simply blasting the bad guy to bits. Which is a shame, since it would be much more interesting to see him outwit his enemies, thus showing who really was the superior species. Also, it doesn't help that the female lead, played by Helena Bonham Carter, doesn't even remotely look like a real chimp. I guess Burton & Co. couldn't resist making her look sexy, complete with a fashionable hairstyle. So, ultimately what you have is lots of good looks, but not much in the way of brains. I'm looking forward to viewing the 1968 original, just to see how this film falls short by comparison. 5/10

WARNING:  SPOILERS BELOWIf anyone else in the world wasted its resources the way this movie does the global media would howl.Tim Burton has been quoted as saying he never went to film school, or that he never finished it.  Sad to say, his movies show it.  He's consistently come up with interesting outsider characters but at least the story revolved around them.  Here, there are several out-of-place characters around whom no story is told.On top of that, like in Burton's other movies he substitutes here a weak ending for a hard-hitting one that could have paid off all that gone into the movie.  We get a miasma of red herrings and actions that drag on for no reason because neither Burton nor the writers had the neither the maturity nor the nerve to end their movie with any one thing.  Murdered characters whose discovery leads to no further development.  The fight with Thade ends not with a dramatic kill-or-be-killed but with him holing up undercover - but then we never see the consequences of his cowardice.  One gorilla changes his alliegiance after the battle but we're never given a foreshadowing of this.  The apes survive a rocket engine blast but we're never given an earlier clue that they can.  What we're shown as a space station turns out to be a space ship as well but we don't see that until we see the wreckage on the Planet of the Apes, nor are we given a clue as to how it got there - did it come through the same vortex as our hero?Then they had to end their movie with an post-ironic, self-referential, wise-acre college-student twist that said absolutely nothing about all that had gone before.  Rod Serling these guys are not.If this wins any awards it should be the 2001 Golden Rasberry.  It certainly won't wins Oscars for writing or direction.  I can only hope the Sci-Fi Conventions refuse to award it any prizes

It was late on Friday evening and I was tired, probably too tired to get up after 30 minutes of the film and turn the DVD player off. The story is not much, really, and neither is the acting. Wahlberg has none of the charisma necessary to play a hero. Finally, the ending of the movie is the worst one can think of, defying all logic.

reviews.review_title: Did not work for me for ONE MAIN REASON
reviews.content: Now that I've finally seen the big Planet of the Apes remake, and before I look again at the reviews. I am asking myself why the movie just didn't work.  And I think I know.It wasn't awful, not to me anyway.  I enjoyed the effects, I enjoyed Elfman's score, the makeup was wonderful, the acting of all the ape characters was pretty terrific, the plot was at least interesting.  Those are all good things, and made it an endurable experience, not like, say, Nightfall.So what was wrong?  One factor.  MARK WAHLBERG.He's just *nothing.*  He's this bland, flavorless, rice-cake/styrofoam object filling up air and reflecting light rays.  Not Rufus Sewell obnoxious/bad, not David Birney talentless/bad, just... this-was-supposed-to-be-a-steak-and-it-turns-out-to-be-tofu bad.I will never see Boogie Nights, so I will never have a comment on his "work" in that, I don't remember him from Perfect Storm, so I don't know if Wahlberg is capable of being interesting.  The part wasn't written terribly interesting (but think Sean Connery, John Wayne, Jimmy Stewart - a talented actor can *make* a part interesting).  Doing a lot of standing around and staring, occasionally broken up by some moving around and staring, won't breathe life into a part.And when he did do something or speak, I found his character unsympathetic and centerless.Now, I didn't think much about the original while watching, because I think such comparisons are unfair and usually irrelevant.  But I feel I need to say one more thing: Charlton Heston.  Not one of my favorite actors, but compare the life and scope of that character to this listless... thing.Too bad.  The movie could have been a lot of fun.

When I first read that they were going to do this remake I thought it was a ridiculous idea. The original premise was so silly that I thought if there is one movie that did NOT cry out to be remade it was this one. I was incorrect in assuming this. The prosthetic makeup is so much better than the original(you can see the actor's real faces beneath the ape facade)that the biggest hurdle is immediately overcome. Tim Burton excels in working unusual concepts in his film and this is more of the same. Mark Wahlberg fits as the protagonist and while he is not Laurence Olivier the material isn't Shakespeare either. I went expecting little and was pleasantly surprised. With people staying away from the theatre in droves this summer I don't think the film will do that well in the box office but I will recommend it.

reviews.review_title: But were any humans harmed in the making of this film?
reviews.content: I get suspicious when the director pumps up the audio, darkens the set and puts elaborate monkey suits on the actors. Oops, sorry I meant Ape costumes. If the Naked Apes in this film learned anything from the 1968 edition, they certainly forgot to include it. Except of course voting Charlton Heston to his rightful species. The story is decent sci-fi integrating humans, simians and robotics while taking the original story beyond the basics to challenge your imagination. The dialog though was uninspired with all the tired stereotypes with an ape/human twist. Like we haven't seen the original and endured the ironies the first time 'round. Go to see this film for the effects, the costumes, and soundtrack - with earplugs. Some one higher up the evolutionary ladder should have been tapped to write the screenplay.CyCy

reviews.review_title: Without comparing it to the original, it still fails.
reviews.content: Tim Burton is one of my favorite directors/producers now working in the motion picture industry so I was interested to see what he had done with _Planet of the Apes_. The original movie stands as a classic of the sci-fi genre and many people, myself included, wondered why they choose to remake the movie. Fortunately the current _Planet of the Apes_ is more a reinterpretation of the material than than a remake of the movie and on that note it succeeds.However, the results are disappointing to put it mildly. There are enough plot holes to drive a Mac truck through. Often I found myself looking at my watch to see how much longer the movie would be lasting and felt my intelligence being assaulted. Some effects,  especially several jumps the apes make, would be more at home in _The Matrix_ than here. The occasional resused/reinterpreted line from the original movie are delivered poorly and come across as a weak attempt to pay homage to the original. While the story line itself was OK, plot holes aside, the script writing was lacking and the delivery of the lines by the actors more so. Interestingly enough, the best acting job is turned in by Charleton Heston who make a brief cameo appearance. Overall the production value was good, however, the apes village would be more at home in a fantasy movie than a sci-fi flick and as for the the much heralded make-up, I found it lacking, save for the gorillas. Of course one has to mention the ultimate ending of the movie which reeks of being tacked on and proves that sometimes movie makers just add too much footage for no good reason. The final few minutes should have wound up on the cutting room floor. All in all, it is a failure. Everybody makes a real stinker every now and then and Tim really has one here.

Almost everyone involved in the making of this movie is to be lauded for their individual creative efforts; this much is certain... great costumes, props, makeup, etc.My only problem with the end result of POTA is its emphasis on action, and very little attention to the human vs. ape and mankind philosophies so aptly and dramatically demonstrated in the original 1968 film on which the "reimagined" 2001 Tim Burton movie was partly based (The screenwriters who worked on this one also pulled information from Pierre Boulle's short sci-fi novel "Monkey Planet.").True, everything made nowadays must have one sense-throttling, action packed sequence strung almost imperceptibly to the next, never stopping to look at the wondrous 'flower' that made the 1968 film so unique.  The original film was nature vs man, evolution alongside devolution, and an overall downward spiral towards mankind's oblivion (or pretty much the next worst thing, anyway, since people aren't totally extinct by the time the main character crash lands on either eponymous planet).The best things in the 2001 remake are the handful of pop references made first in the original movie, the references to modern (some 21st Century) attitudes ("I'm having a bad hair day," says one female chimp in Burton's version), and the overall upgraded feel and tone of the movie now that more than thirty-three years have elapsed in the world of cinema.Its a given to say that special-effects are a boon to this new, improved version.  Yet, I miss hearing all that (somewhat) great dialog heard in POTA 1968.Everyone I know who's seen the Burton version has mentioned something about its ending, and the questions it poses.  Let us all hope Simos (the name of the simian deity in this film) answers our inquisitive, and slightly confused, prayers in a rational manner... ...and will there be an even more confusing sequel to this reimagination?

This movie could have been a lot better. In fact, it was fairly decent until the end. However, as others have posted here, I was able to figure out the basic plot of the film after the first ten minutes.The ending was awful. Burton and his people probably thought it would be a killer ending, and, I suppose, it was--it killed the film. The ending did not at all fit with the rest of the story, and now begs the question, "how could that have happened?" I tried to give this movie some seriousness--I tried to think of ways to explain the ending, but they all have Saturn-sized holes in them. Oh, well. My sister warned me that this movie was bad; I should have listened to her.This movie could have been great--but it wasn't. Don't waste your money even renting it.

reviews.review_title: First hour - wow! Second hour - ugh!
reviews.content: I loved the first half or so of Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes. Other than a few lame visual gags that were played as an attempt at humor (i.e. apes smoking hash like humans in the Middle east), the set up of POTA was impressive, a little scary and, for a sci-fi fantasy movie, "believeable."But the logic holes kept building and compouding, so that in the second half of the movie, when even bigger holes appear, the thread is lost and the movie practically shouts, "Hey! This is a summer movie! Don't think too hard!"I don't want to give away spoilers, so I'll avoid several thoughts about the ending. I will simply say that for the end to have occurred as it did requires multiple inconsistent assumptions about that kind of travel travel.Anyhow, one of my larger problems with POTA was the fact that the humans speak English, and in fact they speak the same language as the apes. Yet the apes still treat humans as animals. Now, I don't know about you, but if apes (or any other animal) on our earth started speaking English, I think my first reaction would be to INCREASE my respect and treatment of them, not LOWER it. The fact that apes treat humans appallingly, even though they KNOW they are as intelligent, is silly.This negates most of any kind of message about humans today treating other species badly. Hey, if my dog talked, I would feed him better food and give him his own room. I wouldn't do what these apes do.But then, the movie handles this inconsistently. In one scene, Thade seems shocked that one human look at him. Well, why wouldn't he? The humans can talk and walk and obviously are intelligent. Why wouldn't one look at the ape leader? It's not like they are the mute, cowed humans from the original POTA movie.Speaking of, Tim Roth does an OUTSTANDING job bringing Thade to life. He not only walks and moves as an ape, he moves with a sense of menace. Great job.The other apes, well, they are kind of ape-like. But unlike many reviewers, I didn't think they moved all that realistically. They looked like humans trying to move like apes.And there are lots and lots of convenient coicidences, like in one scene a spaceship showing up at just the right time to play a key role in an ongoing struggle. And a ship thousands of years old that has not only a power source (OK, I'll buy that), but devices that still work (like the wires and other more sensitive components would have lasted that long?).Still, I gave POTA a 7 because, huge holes aside, I just enjoyed it. I hope there is a sequel that is written better.

This movie couldn't be any more bad.   Clearly, the creators of this fill were more worried about how to grunt, look, and walk like an ape, than in conveying a story.   The dialog is, for the most part, grunts on the part of the apes, and practically non-existent on the part of the humans, with the exception of the lead (male) character.   The lead female character has perhaps no more than 3 or 4 lines during the entire movie.As for the story, its ridiculous and unbelievable.  Yes, yes, I know -- we're talking about a sci-fi movie where apes rule the world -- how realistic can it be?   My answer is this: when we see a movie, we allow the writers/directories to withdraw a certain amount of fantasy from our fantasy bank account.   Subsequent withdraws are at the cost of the movies believability.  Continual withdraws, as this movie does, have us thinking the writers are idiots and the movie ridiculous.   In the case of Plant of the Apes, this couldn't be any more the case.Rating:  1 out of 10.

I've never been a fan of any of the "Planet Of the Apes" movies. But yesturday changed that.  This recent version of "Planet Of The Apes" is brilliant, I was shocked by how engrossed I was while watching this movie, it's simply unmissable.Forget what the critics say about this movie, Tim Burton, (Sleepy Hollow, Batman) has once again gave the audience something to be amazed by. 
9/10

reviews.review_title: Excellent entertainment, although not Burton's best...
reviews.content: Sure, this new adaptation of Pierre Boule's classic novel Planet of The Apes isn't a wonderful exploration of human behavior or something like that, but that is not it's target. Instead it tries to be an incredibly entertaining summer movie, while still being intelligent and retaining Burton's gorgeous visual style. And with that in mind, it fully accomplishes its goals. First of all, the soundtrack, made by long-time Burton collaborator Danny Elfman is up to the composer's high standards. The brutal percussion-based sounds of his score fit the movie perfectly. The story is very satisfying and the ending is excellent. Touches of clever humor add to the script. But, of course, what steals the show is Burton's gift for creating memorable images and his army of apes, led by General Thade, a memorable character played to perfection by Tim Roth. For this movie, Burton often leaves his trademark dark and blue colors, but the movie still has his wonderful touch. As for the apes, they are very impressive. The cast is good, without having very hard jobs to do, but as I said earlier, Roth shines. So, this may not be Tim Burton's best movie, but it is the perfect summer entertainment, offered to you by one of history's greatest directors.85%

PLANET OF THE APES   * *   Unnecessary remake brings nothing new to the table in terms of imagination or inspiration.  Performances by Helena Bonham Carter,  Tim Roth and many of the others playing apes are the only redeeming features.  Everything money can buy, expensive sets, makeup, costumes and actors, can't make up for an incoherent and illogical script.   Finally, if the average movie  goer has to research the internet to try to understand the final scene, then the moviemakers haven't done their job.

This movie was terrible.  I went into it with high expectations, only to get a sneaking suspicion that something had gone terribly awry after the opening credits.  These are some of the elements which made viewing this excruciating:1) The set: it looked like a cross between the Wizard of Oz's flying monkeys, the Ewok Adventure and Willow.  I know we're dealing with Tim Burton here, but I just couldn't take it seriously.  And, it always looked like a SET.2)  The cast:  Mark Wahlberg, whom I normally like, just seemed too flat and not commanding enough of a character to lead any insurrection.  Estella Warren, who plays the 2001 equivalent to the original film's Nova, is so bad it's comic.  Check out the first scene in which she's introduced side by side with the Kris Kristofferson character.  The look on her face is so vacuous, you wonder how she's supposedly survived this long on the run. And speaking of Kris Kristofferson: why is he in this movie at all?  His character is completely wasted.3) Danny Elfman's swollen, distracting score:  I felt like I was watching Batman all over again.4) The character development:  The human characters are not developed at all.  We're supposed to buy that there's chemistry between the Mark Wahlberg character and Daena (Estella)?  One doesn't even really know the human characters' names by the end of the film.  I had to look them up on IMDB. I didn't care about any of the characters, and hoped they were all killed by the time the movie ended.5) The tacked-on, twist ending:  Send this ending back for a rewrite! Let's make some sense here, people.In addition to the points listed above, the dialogue was corny.  There were also numerous plots holes and distractions.  One of the distractions was how Daena got lip gloss and managed to shave her armpits while living such a primitive lifestyle.  It's also a wonder that the enslaved and nomadic humans spoke English so well.Helena Bonham-Carter does what she can with the terrible script.  The make-up effects were mixed.  The look of the female primates was not to be believed.  I assume this was done for Burton's lame satiric elements in the film.  The make-up effect on Tim Roth's Thade was more believable.  Tim Roth's scenes fare better than others, although he goes way over the top at points.Don't waste your time with this movie.  Do yourself a favor and rent the original 1968 classic instead.

*SIGH* Once again another sci-fi remake with big budget effects and a dull and pointless story line that is light -years behind the original 1968 film. The Rod Serling screenplay in the 1968 version was such a witty and insightful parody I can still remember the scenes and dialogue today. There is NOTHING memorable about the remake. This movie was doomed from the start because the surprise twist ending in the 1968 version could never be redone. So instead the film makers pathetically come up with their own surprise ending that is a stupefying non sequitur. What a waste of celluloid and ape makeup. The move made monkeys of everyone!

WARNING*** SPOILER ALERT*** While the special effects and makeup in this movie are very well done, the ending of the film leaves you with a sense of "WHAT THE HECK?" I love a good twist and I did like the concept that Marky's character ultimately caused the whole thing. THAT made at least some sense. What troubled me, however, was the ending where we see Leo heading home supposedly BACK in time. Now, if he went back in time, how did Tade become a hero being that he didn't even exist until the future? This makes no sense at all and I think is a major flaw. The original ending is much better. I did like the little monkey showing up in his pod, that made me smile although it was totally predictable. I also did enjoy the references to the original movie with the ape saying to him "Take your filthy hands off of me you damn, dirty human" and then later on when Charlton Heston, in his cameo apparance, repeats his famous line from the end of the original movie "Damn it all to hell" or something to that effect, I don't remember the exact line now. Overall, I would say it was OK. I'd wait to see it on DVD. Maybe there's some explaination with an interview with Tim Burton (who I usually love). In any case it will be interesting to see the behind the scenes stuff. I give it a 5/10

reviews.review_title: A remake is a remake is a remake when the original is a standout.
reviews.content: This one isn't just a remake, it's a spinoff, a miniature update with a celluloid umbilical chord still attached to the mother film released in 1968.  This Ape movie doesn't stand on its own but lopes along in the shadows of its predecessor.  It beats the original only in the amount of violence portrayed and at the box office (which probably results from curiousity about about how they could redo the thing).Not without some clever touches but, overall, it's a massive huh?

Tim Burton has managed to take a science fiction classic and "reimagine it" in a way that manages to be both faithful to the themes of the original film, while accommodating today's action-demanding audiences.Of course in many ways the film IS superior to the 1968 original. Rick Baker's makeup is a marvel, and more than makes up for his King Kong debacle of 25 years ago -- even though they still can't seem to create an ape mask that doesn't make the actors lisp. The action sequences are fast-paced and brutal, and the actors do such a marvelous job ... er ... apeing the moves of primates you're forgiven if you think Burton tossed a silverback or two into the melee just to liven things up.Mark Wahlberg is a disappointment as Leo, coming off as a one-dimensional jerk. The only times he shows any real humanity is when he interacts with a favorite (real) chimp, though he's certainly capable in the action sequences.Helena Botham Carter as the cute, human-loving Ari is the best thing in the movie, presenting a very well-rounded character when she isn't making lovey dovey eyes at Leo (best not to think about it too much). Estella Warren as a sexy slavegirl gets to show off the best lips in Hollywood, engage in an aborted catfight with Ari, wear very little, and go off in a huff of jealousy when Leo seems to want to spend more time with Ari. I get the strong feeling her best moments were left on the cutting room floor. It's always good to see David Warner and Kris Kristofferson, though their time on screen is brief.Tim Roth is fun and scary to watch as the villain, Gen. Thade, while Michael Clarke Duncan makes a menacing figure as Thade's right hand ape.Look fast for Linda Harrison -- the original slave girl in the original movie. Rick Baker himself also appears as an ape. And Burton's longtime love Lisa Marie makes her obligatory appearance, with a funny bit as a snotty, horny ape.The biggest laugh in the file comes from an otherwise dramatic cameo by original film star Charlton Heston. I won't spoil the reasons why it's funny -- only clue: it's not just in the dialogue.Nor will I spoil the ending. I was confused by it at first until I realized... it was CLASSIC Rod Serling. Once I realized Burton was paying homage to the Twilight Zone -- and let's not forget Serling co-wrote the original film -- everything fell into place.My only advice to Burton is to let sleeping apes lie and not attempt to reimagine the other films in the original Apes series. This is a good one-off, but best to move on to the next idea.

reviews.review_title: Not As Good As The Original, But Still Reasonably Entertaining
reviews.content:
Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is not a remake of the original version of the film, but rather a "re-imagining" or different take of that original material.  Wise move.  The original "Apes" is a film that still holds its own as an all-time sci-fi classic; pretty much any attempt to remake it faithfully would wind up like Gus Van Sant's remake of Hitchcock's "Psycho". . . a pale imitation of greatness.  By "reimagining" the original film, Burton gives himself the opportunity to start with the established mythology of the "Apes" series, as well as the ability to travel in a new direction with that mythology.  The end result?  The new "Planet of the Apes" is nothing Earth-shattering (pardon the pun) -- in ten or twenty years, it won't be looked at with the same reverence or respect as the original "Apes" -- but it's still good, and brings enough new ideas to the table to make a reasonably entertaining film.The story, which ranges in spots from good to barely mediocre, possesses some serious gaps of logic and suffers from an awkward opening.  The first fifteen minutes of the film makes little sense, and lurches along aimlessly for awhile until it stumbles into the heart of its story.  (Examples of some nonsense: Couldn't chimp-piloted ships simply be controlled by computers? Would highly experimental exploration pods be able to launch from a space station just by one rogue pilot punching in a two-second launch sequence?) The opening of the film admittedly does make more sense by the end of the film, but it's still not very good.  It appears as though the writers thought of a solid middle and ending for their version of "Planet of the Apes" . . . but had no idea how to get the story past the opening credits to that middle and ending.  The weak beginning seems like their best attempt to get the story moving to those points.  As for the rest of the story, it contains a lot of good, even original elements, but some points are glossed over in a rather hurried fashion -- there's little effort made to explore some plot threads, and some of the explanations as to how and why things happen in the film are either weak or come completely out of left field. The story's excellent  . . . for a second draft.  I've read that Twentieth Century Fox rushed this new version of "Planet of the Apes" into production. Too bad.  The story and script could've been excellent -- and more important, solid throughout  -- with some more work.Despite the uneven story, though, director Tim Burton does a nice job, given the script he has to work with.  If nothing else, Burton has a knack for giving films an eccentric look, and his version of "Planet of the Apes" benefits greatly from his eccentric touch.  He evokes a lot of the weird imagery of the original films (the weird scarecrows, the desolate landscapes) without ever blatantly stealing from them.  He also does a great job when it comes to focusing on the smaller, quieter moments in the movie -- for example, there's a macabre scene where a child ape puts her pet human in its cage for the night that manages to be disturbing and funny at the same time.  Burton, though, doesn't appear to have a clear idea of the overall tone of the movie.  In "Planet of the Apes", he goes for a blend of action, comedy, and seriousness . . . but the blend doesn't always work. Some of the humor seems out of place, and the action often seems stilted, as if Burton didn't know what to do with the apes apart from having them leap around menacingly.  The film is one of Burton's better efforts, but much like the script, the direction contains a few distinct weak spots.
As for the actors . . . again, it's a mixed bag.  The apes comprise the stronger half of the cast, which makes sense, since the apes are the weirder of the two groups - and Tim Burton specializes in weird.  In regards to the human characters, Burton would've been better off making the humans in his version of "Planet of the Apes" more like the humans in the original film - mute.  Apart from the protagonist Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), none of them add anything of import to the film anyway. The highlights of the individual actors come from mostly from the main characters.  Tim Roth nails the part of villainous General Thade perfectly - he's one of the best sci-fi screen villains to appear on screen in quite awhile. Wahlberg plays Captain Leo Davidson in a manner similar to Heston in the original film; he's a man who's not terribly interested in contemplating how he arrived at a planet ruled by intelligent apes . . . he just knows he wants to leave.  Fast. He's a pragmatic hero, one who reluctantly tries to help others in distress, but doesn't want to die in the process.  Also worth mentioning is Paul Giamatti, who provides some much-needed comic relief as the peculiar orangutan slaver Limbo.  On the other side of the acting coin, the biggest disappointment came from Helena Bonham Carter as Ari.  Given the poor quality of her character in the screenplay, she does what she can for her character, but all she really does for the whole film is to go around being nice to humans.  Period.  Some reasons as to WHY Ari feels so passionately about helping humans would've been nice.Tim Burton's `Planet of the Apes' is an action movie that manages to take some of the influences of the original `Apes' films, and then creates something eccentric and new.  Does it always work?  No, although in general, the good outweighs the bad.  Is it better than the original?  Absolutely not.  In a summer filled with blockbuster duds, though, there's something to be said for a film that provides some thrills and some fun, and the new `Planet of Apes' does exactly that.  Overall, it's an enjoyable film; it's just not a spectacular one.  Grade: B

(A spoiler or two) First off I haven't seen the original so I can't compare this psuedo remake to the '68 "cult classic." But even so, I must say that Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is a mess of great effects, especially makeup, shoddy story-telling and with two exceptions badly written characters. The story consists of Mark Wahlberg as an Air Force pilot named Leo, in the near future, on a space station where he ends up getting time warped to an alternate universe where apes rule humans. Of course Leo gets caught but not to worry, thanks to an sympathetic ape (Helena Bonham Carter), he and several humans, along with Carter and another ape, escape and try to find a way to a place where Leo thinks his ship is waiting for him (he has a device, that he got from his crashed pod, that is leading them along the way to wherever the place might be). But of course apes find them and a huge battle ensues. That's pretty much it for the plot, now to the characters. Carter does a good job as the human loving ape Ari, but Wahlberg is a bore as the film's hero Leo, Estella Warren ("Driven") isn't very good either but Michael Clarke Duncan is okay as a Gorilla general though his brain pattern seems to be, "growl, yell, beat someone up, yell again..." and so on. The standout in the movie has to be Tim Roth's character General Thade, the film's main villain. Thade is the most animated and fascinating of all of the characters and Roth gives the role plenty of emotional power, which basically blows away anyone else on screen with him. I'd actually be interested to see a spinoff movie centering on the Thade character is explained more in depth. Most of the characters are a bore and some are killed off so fast we (the audience) never know who the are.  Lastly, the makeup effects are very well done. The actors actually look like apes or gorillas or whatever. Again, Roth does the most with his character and the makeup fits the Thade character very well. Overall it's not a good movie, the choppy story and mostly bad characters take away what little good stuff the film had to begin with. To finish up, Roth is good but the rest of the flick is bad. Oh and the ending (which doesn't make a lot of sense, compared to the rest of the film) is silly and leaves this one wide open for a sequel, oh goody (note the heavy sarcasm here). I give it *1/2 out of 4 stars.

This is a bit of a first for me, the first time I have ever been disappointed in a Tim Burton film.  POTA isn't a bad film (great sets, costumes and the odd great performance) but it could have been made by any off-the-shelf hollywood director. The pacing was very odd, the last third was just spent waiting for the film to end, by myself and the cast.  Tim Roth was excellent, probably the only pleasure in the film.  Come back Tim.

Where should I start? The hype for this movie came out months before its release and generated a lot of interest, including mine. Mind you I've never really seen the original movie, at least not all of it. But from the promos and interviews, this was Tim Burton's version of the movie, which was basically a bit more up-to-date, realistic, and cutting edge. But I couldn't help but wonder what or who would allow the ending they chose to be shown. Let me warn you that there may be spoilers in this review.The basic premise to this movie revolves around a scientist (Mark Wahlberg) getting stranded on a planet years into the future. The situation arises because of a strange anomaly they encounter in space and at the time, humans were using chimps as test pilots to send into unknown or high-risk situations. Their test pilot was sent in to examine the anomaly (which was to do nothing more than to do a fly-by) and suddenly vanished. Wahlberg's character, being the softhearted scientist, against wishes flew in to rescue the test pilot and himself disappears only to reappear hundreds of years into the future to crash land on a strange planet. He discovers very quickly that humans are not the dominant species on this planet but apes are and he is quickly rounded up to be a slave. His only driving goal from that moment on is to escape and somehow get back to his crewmates.
To be honest, the storyline isn't very strong, nor is it overly intelligent. The audience is given a very basic premise and is told to go along with it. However, if it weren't for the ending, I think a lot of people wouldn't have minded. There are little things throughout the movie that make you wonder how it's possible that something could happen. One of the major ones is that in the future on this strange planet, apes have evolved into intelligent speech cable creatures. But they allegedly came from the science station that Wahlberg's character came from as a result of them coming to search for him and crash landing on this planet. However, the science station was using chimps as their test pilots so where did all these apes come from?? As well, there are humans on this planet, which the movie at one point indicates that the entire crew of the science station was killed by the chimps when they turned on them. Where did all these humans come fromand the horses?? Yes there are horses! It seems for the sake of making this movie they made a lot of assumptions and conveniences but the audience is not that dumb. They will pick it out and they will remember when the sequel comes out. There's no doubt about the sequel. The ending was left in such a way that a sequel would be created. Was there anything I liked about this movie? Well they did remain accurate on ape movements and that element created a sense of fear and menace that the apes in the original movie didn't quite have. The make-up and special effects were pretty good but then Tim Burton has always been good at those areas. Overall I wasn't overly impressed. The movie was acceptable up until the ending and after what I saw for an ending, it kind of ruined everything prior to that. It sounds like I'm being harsh but if you don't believe me, go ahead and see this movie. Just don't write back to me complaining about it because I warned you. On a scale of 1  10, I give it a 5. I thought it could have been much better. Not enough time spent on developing a reasonable and logical plot line.

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton's worst film to date
reviews.content: What ever happened to one of the most innovative and brilliant storytellers of our time?  Well, he made the kind of typical summer action fodder that could've been directed by anybody available out of film school...and in fact, they probably would've done a better job. They would've at least have put half of a thought into the dreadful script.Mark Wahlberg plays an astronaut who traveled through some sort of wormhole and landed in a planet ruled by apes. (gasp!) Except this time around, the apes squirm through groan-worthy dialogue, nonsensical plotting, and showy special effects that constantly reinforce in my mind that this money could've been put to about 10 independent films that would have been considered 'masterpiece' next to this tripe.As much as I enjoy the superb acting talent that is Tim Roth, his performance as evil ape leader Thade is nothing more than an intense composition of slouching and heavy breathing.  Luckily for him, the makeup allows he as an actor to maintain some dignity and most of the crap-dialogue is hidden behind his groans and sniffles.And alas, the always dependable Hollywood tradition of taking the male and female leads and hooking them up at the end without any relationship development or cause. And the "haha, we're so clever, aren't we?" way that Hollywood intermingles references from the original POTA into this one. Sigh...Instead of seeing this, spend the night in and call up some friends and rent 'Ed Wood', 'Edward Scissorhands', 'Batman', or even to a lesser extent 'Sleepy Hollow', and reminisce about the days when Tim Burton was a man of vision and originality...not shame and ridicule.

This movie was magnificent. The scenery, the script, and of course- the makeup. this movie is one of Tim Burton's best pieces of work. But there has to be a sequel! The ending is so mysterious that you have to know what happens! This was a masterpiece but there just has  to be a sequel!

reviews.review_title: Burton slips slightly, but still very entertaining
reviews.content: This new version (I can't quite call it a remake) of a sci fi classic doesn't seem determined to light up brain cells, question our place in nature, or examine our society and our attitude toward "lesser beasts". It's just a good, exciting science fiction adventure film, and on that level, it succeeds quite well with only a few small stumbles.Tim Burton remains the only director I can name who has never made a film I don't like.  You might call me biased, but I do go into every new Burton film afraid that this will be the one.  Fortunately, I'm still waiting.So why is this not a remake?  Well, there are no characters from the original story (either the novel OR the film), and the situation is significantly altered.  While still being the story of an astronaut who lands in a strange new ape-dominated world, very little else is the same. Only a few lines of dialogue intended to evoke the 1968 film remind us.What's good?  First, of course, is Rick Baker's absolutely astounding makeup.  The original appliances still stand up quite well, so this was a nightmare assignment for any makeup artist.  Baker is one of the very few who could handle it, and handle it he does.  There has never been such amazingly detailed, expressive work in the history of film; the actors are able to come right through the latex and hair.  Too much praise cannot be heaped upon his work.  Then there's the patented Tim Burton visual approach; this is easily his best-looking film since "Edward Scissorhands", and really helps to lend the proceedings an otherworldly appearance.  The acting from the performers in the roles of apes is uniformly excellent, particularly Tim Roth in one of the most frightening villain roles I've seen in years.  He truly gives the impression of being dangerously unpredictable; a genuinely great movie psycho.  Mention must also be made of Danny Elfman's score, his most dynamic and interesting in years.  It recalls Goldsmith's work just enough to remind us of what we're watching, while also moving into new territory.What doesn't work?  Well, the humans.  They talk, but have nothing of consequence to say.  Why is Estella Warren so much cleaner than everyone else, and where did she get that lipstick?  And if she's intended to be a love interest for Wahlberg, shouldn't they have a conversation or two?  And sadly, we're given only the barest peek at the ape society before our heroes escape and return to the wilderness.  I really would like to have seen more of their culture.Now, the ending has already become much-debated and argued over across the Internet and elsewhere.  First off, I like the ending.  While it may not have quite the punch of the original's, I think it's a good twist for those going in expecting a twist (and weren't we all?).  Without revealing too much, let's just say that the screenwriters have obviously read the novel.In conclusion, this is an entertaining and exciting sci-fi adventure.  It won't open up your mind much, and it may not be among Burton's best works, but it's a lot of fun, and has a great deal to admire.  7 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as you might think (and the ending DOES make sense!).
reviews.content:
I have been a Tim Burton admirer long before most others have (*I* first discovered him through one of his very first animated shorts, "Vincent", shown on The Disney Channel in 1984!). I've enjoyed a lot of his work--especially "Edward Scissorhands", which I feel is his best--and also have been bored silly by a bit of some of his other stuff ("Mars Attacks!"). I got a kick out of "Ed Wood", enjoyed "Beetlejuice" and was delighted by "Sleepy Hollow" and "The Nightmare Before Christmas" since they both seemed to be a return to his more traditional style.This film is by no means a match for the original 1968 masterpiece, but that doesn't mean it's not interesting or fun to watch. In fact, it's more interesting than I expected it to be. Sure, it's just treading water, but what redeemed it in my eyes and earned more respect in me for the script's concept than I otherwise would have had is the ingenious and wildly misunderstood ending.I'm not a huge POA fan, but that doesn't mean I don't admire it. While the original films were simply too dark, cynical and terrifying for me as a child, I admired them very much for their great intentions--that is, to use a sci-fi story as a metaphor for prejudice, intolerance and class problems (basically reminding us all that treating others as less than ourselves lowers us to the level of wild animals instead of beings with the ability and intelligence to treat each other with love, dignity and respect).My main complaint here is "Marky Mark". Lousy actor. He reminds me of Madonna skimping her way through such flicks as "Body of Evidence" and "Shanghai Surprise". He simply can't communicate emotion. Charlton Heston was wonderful as Taylor, a man who begins his dark tale as a cynical jerk who gets a taste of his own I-can't-stand-people-and-think-they're-no-good medicine and comes to realize that his attitude was the same one that led to the nightmarish situation he now faces. In this new version, Leo Davidson is simply bland and almost gives the impression that he's gotten himself as stoned out of his mind as possible just to avoid dealing with his dilemma. This makes it hard for the audience to identify with him, but even so the story's idea is so strong with its ending being so effectively jarring (even when trapped in a cornball script) that it can be frightening in its own right.Which brings me to the twist ending. Before I explain it, I just want to mention something: after reading all the comments both on here and made by paid critics, I am genuinely amazed as a writer how little people pay attention to the finer details of scripts! I guess the modern attention span of folks is so limited that such important details sprinkled throughout the story are lost unnoticed these days (a good example: Roger Ebert's comment that "all the apes' varieties don't make sense considering the film's logic"--YES, THEY DO! Look carefully in the beginning of the film and you will SEE WHY!).Tim Burton and his writers created the ending *VERY CAREFULLY*, and it is NOT--I repeat, *N*O*T*--just "tacked on"! All you need to do is pay attention, use logic and imagination to realize the gaps, and you will see that it is NOT really just some cheap setup for a sequel. In fact, going by the film's logic there isn't really any NEED for one, as the film stands on its own in its entirety!As if in outraged retaliation to the public's criticizing the finale, the videotape and DVD versions of this film contain a featurette re-showing various scenes and saying, "Watch carefully for clues that lead to the explanation of the surprise ending!" It further goes on to say that, just in case you are still too dense to get it, more information is further available on the movie's official webpage.
***WARNING: MAJOR SPOILER AHEAD!***After seeing this film, I was easily able to guess what must have happened. I was delighted to find the info I've mentioned above on the internet later on and discover my theory to be correct!What basically happened in a nutshell was this: Thade was bloodthirsty for revenge (remember, he was never killed in the movie) and learned all about space travel through the information contained in the Oberon, salvaged and repaired Leo's ship, then attempted to pursue him through space and time. When Thade reached earth after following him through the temporal storm, he had arrived before Leo did. In vengeance, Thade set out to disrupt Leo's world the way that Leo had disrupted Thade's own. He led a rebellion of the apes and disrupted it into what we saw at the end of the movie before Leo's arrival.It would appear that Burton wanted a portion of his film to be the same way that such new films as "The Blair Witch Project" are... meaning, films that must also be experienced over the internet and through various other provided sources alongside the movie in order to completely understand them! In other words, asking the audience to use their intelligence instead of spoonfeeding all the information to them! Very ingenious. And different, too!That said, I for one am very impressed.

No, I'm not reviewing "Tomb Raider," or even "Hobgoblins," but a film somewhere along that line: The remake of "Planet of the Apes."It might be unfair to judge something without seeing/reading/whatevering the original, and I haven't. But I nearly did once, and after watching a few minutes, I left. I couldn't do that with this one, because I came with my brother, his teacher, the teacher's son, and the son's friend, and couldn't go anywhere else. [sob] Just kidding there.I have got to start coming into movies with NO expectations. When I want an okay film, it sucks; when I think it'll be bad, it is; and whenever I think it'll be good, it's okay, and that isn't good enough. Here, I thought it would be bad. Tim Burton's remake (I'm not calling it a reimagining, it doesn't deserve such a title) was such a bad film, that whereas I thought in the theater, it was closer to the "okay" line, now I think it was closer to the evil of Tomb Raider. (Maybe it exceeded that.) Quite a turnabout!I'm an 11 year old (and am awfully smart for my age), and I had to do homework for a week-and if you knew me, you would know that I wouldn't consider it without a bribe-to see this. I barely got by, and after leaving, I said to myself, "I did a week of homework for THAT?!" It's that bad.The only redeeming part was the ending. And even that sucked. (Spoilers ahead, just as you would expect from me.) I mean, the first part was stupid-the apes caused the humans to mutate like that? (It was subtler, but that's the general point.) The final scenes where he gets back to Earth were cool-replacing the Abraham Lincoln statue with an ape-but it leaves a plot hole bigger than my lust for death after the film. If Earth's humans get turned into apes like that, how the f*** did Leo stay human? (I'll leave out the words next in my mind, because the IMDb would reject this thing.) Plus, how does the theater audience stay human? (Just kidding, but still...)This is the type of film that makes people consider suicide. Name a worse film that I haven't seen, and I'll consider seeing-and destroying-the film. No? FiguresRating: -2537396746584475673/6 (Lately, that thing hasn't been working.)

A terribly horrid film.  Predictable, with a poor script, and worse dialogue.  Sadly, the ending was, as expected, just horrible.  It's a shame because the original film is just excellent, and I don't understand how Tim Burton got involved with this.

reviews.review_title: Planet of Apes + Star Wars + Back to the Future = Silly
reviews.content: Very disappointing. Most of the criticisms are correct (no plot, bad acting etc.) but I also thought that the special effects were so-so. *Very* derivative and I can only assume that everyone was in it for the money. So save your own money and avoid. 3/10 (5 for Tim Roth and -2 for the rest).

The new Planet of the Apes flick is sheer entertainment from the very beginning, right down to the insanely amusing finish. Tim Burton directed it, but it doesn't seem like a Tim Burton film. He seemed to want to pay more of an homage to the original than change it with the distinguished macabre feel of his other films. The story is great. It has been modified a bit, but nothing has really changed. Everyone in the film is superb especially Paul Giamatti as the wise-cracking comic relief. Though some of the plot twists and situations don't really make much practical sense, they are all interesting and brilliant. A+!!
            9/10

I thought that the film was good.  I did not really have any preconceived notions other than the "Burton" touch.  His films are usually dark but beautiful spectacles in my opinion.Sometimes I wonder why people take movie plots so seriously.In the original, a lot of political statements were made (not unusual for Sci Fi films of that area).  It was safe in that genre to make political statements that would be blasted in other genres.The original Planet of the Apes series adequately addressed the issues of the time.  What would be the purpose of reiterating it in 2001?I actually liked the plot.  It was an interesting take or twist of the original.  There was some tongue and cheek dialogue as well.  The ending was the kind the either you liked or thought was really corny.  I liked the ending though, even if it did catch me off guard.I really liked the movie and would buy the video when it becomes available. I am really happy though, I saw it on the big screen.The choice of actors was excellent, I think Tim Roth stole the show, he was so convincing and seemed to enjoy every minute.  I was impressed with the good job that all the actors did.  It did not look easy.I wonder what Tim Burton will do next.  He is truly an artist.

I had high expectations for this film. Man, was I disappointed. I don't want to spoil the ending, but the original film had the best ending I've ever seen. When Tim Burton was the director, I was sure he would find something just as good or even better. He didn't.The film is one long fightscene and the actors smell bad. It isn't very realistic either. Especially when you find out that the apes learned english from Americans. I mean, if that's how they learned it, how can Helena B. Carter speak with british accent all way through?It appears that the actors must've chosen this script because it was a remake of a classic film-history film. And because of the directors name. Tim Roth is wasting his talent. Why won't anybody give him a charater as a major bad guy in a human-film? If he hadn't been hiden behind a stupid mask I'm sure he would've stole the picture from a (once again) poor performing Mark Walberg.If you like lots of action and nothing ells, I'll give this one 9 out of 10.In my own book it gets 3, from the fact of Charlton Heston being in a cameo!

reviews.review_title: DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING!
reviews.content: DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING! Tim Burton...what can you say about this guy. He just keeps coming up with spectacular, off-kilter films that no-one else could. Batman, Edward Scissorhands, The Nightmare Before Christmas, and now this stunning re-vision of a sci-fi classic. To be honest, today's youngsters aren't likely to watch a film from the 60's anyway, so it was quite acceptable, and logical, to update it. And what an update! This and Jurassic Park III and going a long way to making up for the lame-ness we've had so far this summer. DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING!

I enjoyed this film, having seen the original I expected great things. The story was poor i admit that, but the scenes were great and the opening sequence was very good. It was worth a watch but i wouldn't go expecting great things.One of the main things which makes or breaks a film is its ending and unfortuantly the ending was poor. It doesn't make any sense and if someone could explain it to me i would be ver grateful.

reviews.review_title: You have to really try hard in order to like this one
reviews.content: I was not going to comment on this piece of stylistic dreck. Then I saw reviews from some folks who claimed that the movie was actually quite clever and people who disliked it were clearly not paying attention to the details. So, I carefully rethought the major plot points (there are few, so this was easy), and have a few spoiler type comments. Perhaps those who have not seen the movie yet can bone up on these thoughts and then see if I am still missing something.1) The monkeys in the beginning are genetically engineered to be smart, so that is why they were able to become dominant on the planet....OK, so one little chimpanzee crash lands on a planet with no monkeys. A whole bunch of years later, this chimp has not only acted like a plant seed and sired lots of other monkeys (of different species, no less) without sex or other monkeys to mate with. That IS intelligent. But wait, there WAS something about the 'crashed' mother ship that the hero finds on the planet...maybe our hero mated with those, but no, they are dead by the time he arrives. So maybe the apes on the planet came from the monkeys on the mother ship instead. This is lots better! It could explain how they turned into gibbons, gorillas, orangutans, and every kind of ape EXCEPT chimps, and this in a very few years. I guess that they were genetically engineered to evolve in amazing ways too. I could go on and debunk every argument I have seen for any part of this making sense, but I don't have all day. The plot in this regard is pure nonsense, and that is pretty much it.2) Humans had developed genetically engineered monkeys on Earth, and these clearly had also taken over, so the hero returns to Earth and finds out that they have become dominant there too. Well, I seem to have missed how this would change Abraham Lincoln into a monkey. Perhaps the symbology was just too extreme and the Old Abe thing a bit overboard. OK, then how did the Earth ape culture know the name of the general on that other planet to celebrate him? It was pretty clear that the hero's mother ship was not near Earth, but maybe the time warp ALSO send him back to Earth as well. Or not. The coincidences really need to pile up for this to even begin to be plausible. And since the film makers did not contrive the plot development to demonstrate any such path of reasoning, I don't think THEY actually had thought it through either. They just came up with a stupid and unsupported twist for the end of the movie. If you really need for the movie to make sense in order to enjoy it, then go ahead and rationalize meanings to your heart's content.3) By the way, it was pretty realistic that a huge and obviously orbital-space-only mother ship was able to land on a planet at all, much less intact. Enough so that the apes and humans on board could survive to populate another planet. Enough so that the engine(s) still work after so many years. Right.4) It was pretty clever for the film makers to suddenly let a tiny shuttle craft become capable of interstellar travel. Even WITH time warps, etc.The upshot is, this movie has no real level of excitement, no plot worth mentioning, no character development, no internal logic, unreliable presentation of core 'facts' to the audience, and precious little entertainment value. The money makeup was pretty decent though.

reviews.review_title: Not as shabby as I thought it was going to be!
reviews.content: I say if you were even thinking of going to a film that just plain visual and somewhat entertaining....see this in the theater!  I won't tell you that parts of it weren't just corny or over-Hollywood-ish, but it is rather fun and if you don't go into it expecting too much, you may leave thinking that it really wasn't too bad!  Like I did....... I thought that the special F/X were great, the costumes were pretty well designed, and the scenery was very enticing to the eye and mind.  Granted, the dialog was mostly silly at best, but again, for an entertaining film with interesting effects and a nice twist on the Ape saga, Go see this movie.  It may be good on DVD with surround sound speakers on a big TV, but if you don't have that, go see this while still at the theaters.  I think that the graphics and visuals will be lost on small screen.  I gave it 7 out of 10 - just for shear entertainment of the flick, not anything more than that.....  Burton's mind is very creative, too and deserves a lot of credit for this film.

reviews.review_title: Roth sells out! Puts on Ape Suit!
reviews.content: This movie is a muddle, lots of things make no sense, not the least of which is this; why are all the big mean apes afraid of little Tim Roth, jumping about like a gnat? And why is Estelle Warren wearing lipstick? And just how many millions did it take to get good actors to dress up like apes? I won't even address the ludicrous ending, or the waste of Tim Burtons great talent doing drek like this. Please, Mr. Burton, go back to your original films, stop with the Hollywood crap! We your fans miss you!

reviews.review_title: Better than I remember but the ending.
reviews.content: I remember watching this in the theater and being extremely disappointed. The original POTA is imbedded in the culture and it's ending can't be topped. In this reimagined version you can't have a twist ending, nothing can beat the original. Looking at it again it's makeup and acting ( not Mark Wahlberg ) is exceptional. The creepy way Lia looks at Davidson is culminating in a crowd inducing cringe kiss. The new ending might be interesting to those people who have read the book but it disappointed everyone else. So much work and potential waisted on a weak ending. It's better than my first reaction maybe you should give it a second watch.

Let me preface this by saying that I am a huge Tim Burton fan. He could direct a remake of Ernest Saves Christmas starring Pauly Shore as Ernest, and I'd probably like it. Well, maybe not with Pauly Shore.Having said that, let me just say that I loved Planet of the Apes, but here's the catch...DO NOT go into it thinking about the original. Forget everything you know about Planet of the Apes starring Charlton Heston, and think of this as a brand new concept, and I'm pretty sure you will love this movie as much as I did.I mean, think about it. Burton directed "Sleepy Hollow" which really didn't follow the original story, but can you honestly tell me that "Sleepy Hollow" was a bad movie?The original "Planet" is a classic. I am so glad that Burton didn't do a shot for shot remake of it, like that horrible "Psycho" remake a few years ago.By the way, the Heston cameo will go down in history as one of the finest cameos ever. Ranking right up there with his cameo in "Wayne's World 2".Like I said in the summary, this "Planet" is not the original, and thank goodness for that. It's a brand new movie with brand new apes, and brand new humans. Burton you continue to amaze me!

I've just bought it on DVD and yeah, it is REALLY good and the apes look very real! It's about an ape being sent into some big magnetic storm in outer space. It's being sent to see what that storm is, but it doesn't come back so our hero takes a little spacecraft and heads in the same direction as the ape. When he hits the storm, his spacecraft goes nuts/out of control and suddenly a planet appears. Too late, he regains control, just to crash down into a lake in a rainforest. After he has rescued himself out of the craft, the movie first really begins! He has crashlanded into a world where apes are like humans and humans are like apes, locked up in cages. He get caught, but after a short time, he finds out that there is this one ape that's not like the other apes...I've heard people asking me if this really just ain't either a follow-up or a remaking of the original planet of the apes - the answer is definately no! It's a whole other story. I gave it 7*

This is without a doubt, Tim Burton's worst film to date. I've read other reviews of the film and agree with the general consensus that the score (Elfman) and the makeup/special effects (Baker, etc.) were spectacular. Of course they were! Why shouldn't they be? With the current level of sophistication we enjoy in special effects and advanced makeup/prosthetic applications there is no excuse whatsoever for shabby makeup and crappy effects. What are we left with after the glitz? Stuntmen jumping 20, 30 and 50 feet into the air again and again and again. That particular effect was so overdone throughout the film as to render it completely flaccid by the end of this piece of garbage. Plot? There was none, really. This was purely an action film with a "screenplay" that was written by and for idiots.

Let me say first that I am a huge fan of the original Planet of the Apes. When I first heard that Tim Burton was directing the "remake", I was a little concerned. I have been waiting to see this film for quite some time. I finally saw it earlier today and I was not disappointed! 
***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!!!!!!!***
I really enjoyed almost everything about the film. First, the story was good including the surprise twist ending. The performances from Roth to Wahlberg to Carter to Duncan were all top notch. The special effects were about what I expected with a couple of minor flaws. The settings of the villages were realistic and convincing as well. My one complaint would be that the film was a little dark. I am not referring to the mood either, I mean the actual shots were too dark at certain times but it did not take away from the film overall. Really good movie that I would recommend to any sci-fi fan!

I had read mixed reviews on this movie and having not seen the orignal I didnt know what to expect, so I cannot compare it to the first one. I was very impressed at the makeup on the characters in this movie. The apes looked so real its obvious alot of time and money was put into the makeup alone. I liked Helena Bonham's character-she was the one friendly likeable ape that didnt hate humans like her counterparts did. Interesting contrast in the movie on how on this planet apes control the humans and on earth its vise versa. Ending was kind of cool and made you think a little. Good movie overall. 7/10.

reviews.review_title: Damn You 20th Century Fox! Damn you all to hell! (Mild spoiler alert!)
reviews.content: Remember the 1968 original Planet of the Apes?  Now imagine an updated version of that same movie without the creativity, witty social commentary, and entertainment value and that's what you get out of Apes circa 2001. This year has proven to be a wasteland of one bad movie after another, and Apes 2001 will most likely be looked at as a contributor to this wasteland, at least by me.The original and subsequent versions had social commentary that mirrored the current events of those times, such as the Watts riots and the Vietnam War. Apes 2001 was just a lame attempt to make a blockbuster movie by trying to capture lightning in a bottle a second time with name recognition, cliches, and special effects.  I started looking at my watch well before the halfway mark of the movie.The movie insults the intelligence of the moviegoer by having the apes give that annoying, piercing, headache-inducing shriek everytime they get excited, mad, happy, etc.  I suppose that director Tim Burton wanted to drive the point home that they are in fact apes in case we couldn't figure that out from the title of the movie and that they call themselves "apes" a lot.  It felt more like being at a zoo than a movie theater.Let's not forget the touch of absurdity too.  Apes teases a love triangle between Capt. Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), a native human woman, and Ari the bleeding heart ape.  Yes, you read it correctly.  Thank goodness it was only a PG-13 movie.Nothing noteworthy about the acting.  Wahlberg struts around as the hero, which is par for the course.  Tim Roth as Gen. Thade came across as more of an annoyance than as ruthless.  Kris Kristofferson contributes little, other than to continue his own streak of being offed in a movie before it's over. Of all the actors here, I felt bad for Michael Clarke Duncan.  After his breakthrough performance in The Green Mile, he was typecasted as a dimwitted giant ape in most other later movies.  I never expected for him to be literally typecasted as that to boot, but Apes 2001 does just that by feeding him the limited role as the stooge/friend of Gen. Thade.The ending - which by the way many will see coming a mile away - leaves the door open for a sequel, and if Apes 2001's undeserving blockbuster numbers hold up, sadly that's what we will get.Stay far, far away from this movie, even if you're a diehard fan of all the original Apes movies, have all the episodes of the TV series and cartoon on tape, have back hair, and crave bananas constantly.  Rent the original and just leave it at that. (1/10)

reviews.review_title: An original plot makes all the difference
reviews.content:
I was pleasantly surprised with this one.  I was expecting a re-done plot with new affects, but Tim Burton takes the extra step to make an all new movie.  I enjoyed the first Planet of the Apes and I was very happy to see this one had a completely original plot.  This gave the movie a new flavor. 
The story, for the most part, was well presented and it made sense as well. However, there were a few areas which it was a little weak and where there were errors Wahlberg's character of a military officer with a science background, would not have made.  Wahlberg was good and helped the film along.  Tim Roth was also good and gave the film a sinister side.  Michael Clarke Duncan gave an explosive performance which in my opinion gave brought a lot if character to the film really helps make the film.Overall, good and worth your while (8 out of 10).

This was a fantastic film, the best of the year...so far.  I say that because Lord Of The Rings hasn't been released yet.  This one had it all, great visual and special effects, and a wise choice to use costumes instead of CGI for the apes.  A fantastic cast, great script, and some of the best directing by the one and only Tim Burton, one of my all time favorite directors.  I give this film an 8 out of 10, go see it at any price, you won't be disappointed.

I'm old enough to have seen and enjoyed, when it was first released in 1968, the original film directed by Franklin J Schaffner, with its now legendary ending as astronaut Taylor (played by Charlton Heston) finally realises where he is and screams `Damn them all to hell!' Also I'm an admirer of director Tim Burton's innovative work in such movies as `Batman', so I looked forward to Burton's effort at `re-imagining' Pierre Boulle's imaginative novel. Sadly the result is nothing to go ape about.As one would expect with Burton, the work has a distinctive and impressive look, even if it is frequently as much Gothic as gorilla. The location shooting in Hawaii and Arizona and the prosthetics of five-times-Oscar-winner Rick Baker give the film strength. The problem  as so often in today's Hollywood  is the script which seems to have been produced by sitting a bunch of chimps in front of some keyboards. Much of the dialogue is risible and the thoughtfulness and sharpness of Schaffner's work is missing.
Mark Wahlberg, in the role of the lost spaceman Leo Davidson, is adequate, but he does not have the presence or the anger that made Heston's performance so powerful. In fact, Heston makes a cameo appearance in this re-make and manages to reprise his 1960s closing line. Many of the other stars, who include Tim Roth (`Reservoir Dogs') and Michael Clarke Duncan (`The Green Mile'), can only be recognised by their voices.In the original, Taylor was fleeing Earth because war and famine had caused him to become totally disillusioned with mankind. In the reprise, Davidson is desperate to return to the Earth he knows, even though he is on a planet where he finishes up with a God-like status among both men and apes and he can choose between the bee-sting lips of Estella Warren and the simian charms of Helena Bonham-Carter. Anyone that silly deserves what he finds in a brave, but essentially futile, attempt to provide a variation on the 1968 ending.

reviews.review_title: Not an ape,A DOG! The stench should have put an end to awful remakes forever
reviews.content: The saddest observation(s) on this lame-dog, utterly unnecessary remake are that it managed to squander the contributions of three alumni from the classic original: RICHARD ZANUCK-responsible for green-lighting the 1968 version when he headed 20th Century Fox in 1967,was also at the helm of this travesty of cinema-- it also wastes CHARLTON HESTON, the great mega-star who so effectively inhabited the character of GEORGE TAYLOR (here in ape-make up panting through a clichéd, embarrassingly written cameo/death scene), and once again poor LINDA HARRISON (Nova in the first two APES entries) is reduced to a token 3 second cameo shot,essentially lampooning her original character.This film's announcement created a huge buzz in Hollywood, and among the fan-base of the original classic APES franchise. Instead what audiences receivedwas a pathetic, unengaging,poorly executed load of overblown B.S Tim Burton seemed to very removed from his usual hands-on approach that made his best work so imaginative. The make-up is pretty well done, but unappealing and the actors sure had their work cut out for them, trying to reinvent the genius of former characterizations made by Kim Hunter, Roddy McDowall and Maurice Evans.--but all was for naught with such a lame-ass script, lead character and senseless "action".I will say that H Bonham Carter did do a respectful job at her character, and gave a noble performance. But she was conducting it aboard a sinking ship.Weeks after this 2001 version opened (to 120 MILLION dollars worth of box-office!) the tragedy of 9/11 occurred, and it was quickly forgotten-where it has remained at the very bottom of Tim Burton's resume.And judging from most every other comment on this board, the bottom of the barrell-period!It never should have been made-plain and simple

Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes, is a solid, entertaining action flick. The apes are outstanding, the humans, though not as good, are passable. This is just guilty pleasure summer fun. Overall, Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes, is solid, entertaining summer fun. *** (out of four)

No, no.  Please, No!  After seeing the previews for this movie I was actually looking forward to seeing it.  How should I have known that Hollywood would crank out another blockbuster with the high quality of "Blown Away" this summer?  This movie could easily be described as Superman 2 and 4 rolled into one, with the camp of Mr. Belvedere mixed in.  What was going on at the end there?  How did general Thade get to be on the lincoln memorial 500 years before he lived.  If you want to see a really good ape movie watch Congo.  Or better yet, watch an episode of Maude.

reviews.review_title: Rather than making a bad pun, I'll just tell you it stunk.
reviews.content: I hope whoever green-lighted this "Planet of the Apes" remake kept the receipt when he sold his soul to Satan.  It might be tax-deductible.  I can't possibly imagine why the heck they chose to (1) remake a film that still holds up just fine after three decades, or (2) completely remove all the likeable characters and cool plot twists from it.  The only way anyone could possibly like this movie is if they'd never seen the original.  Also, this movie had the stupidest ending I've ever seen.  But hey, at least the Apes looked better...which I believe was the entire reason they decided to remake this movie in the first place.  If you're thinking about shelling out the money to see this movie, save your money and buy the original on video.

reviews.review_title: The Remake utterly failed to set the tone of the Original Cinematic Masterpiece
reviews.content:
How to describe what's so disappointing in this movie? Others have described many of those points so ill not go into them here, but for me, what ruined the remake was the crash landing.In the remake, the main character, astronaut Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) crash lands on an unknown planet into a jungle!
Compare this to the original where astronaut Taylor (Charlton Heston) and his crew crash land into a bleak desert, its awe and desolation so well portrayed that it firmly set the tone for the movie going forward, add to that the brilliant sound effects during the various desert scenes, and the tone stayed with you until the very last scene of this cinematic masterpiece!In the remake, the jungle landing instantly deflated expectations, and drowned the tone in the swampy shallow waters of the cramped confines of the dense jungle foliage. While the tone was artfully and carefully developed in the original, where the astronauts spent some days traversing this vast eerie desert, cleverly building up expectation and and a certain level of suspense, the remake assumed the audience has no attention span, and immediately sends astronaut Leo to the ape city just a short walk away from his crash site.From there, one scene runs to another, as the plot and setting is further dumbed down.
