While I wouldn't go as far as saying that, it was still well worth the price of admission!I'm not much in the way or writing long, drawn out comments, but let me just say that the ending MAKES this movie, it was the perfect fit, even if it was a tad predictable, I couldn't help but grin and give a silent "oh, man!" to it.My only major problem with the film is Mark Wahlberg.  He is a fine and up and coming actor, but I haven't latched onto him yet.  Perhaps one day I will.  He's hot right now, and he's certainly better off than his "Marky Mark" days.As far as other standouts, Paul Gianetti is a riot as Limbo, and Charlton Heston is excellent in a cameo apprerance!Highly recommended viewing.***1/2

reviews.review_title: Apes that rules a planet, has to be Tim Burton
reviews.content: When i heard that they were going to make a new version of the old planet of the apes movie, featuring a bunch of apes that rule an entire planet, I just knew that Tim Burton somehow was involved, the only thing logical about the whole thing is that he's behind it. they movie it self was not what i hoped it would be. one of the big things this movie lacks is that it cant really follow the footsteps of the original movie, if the original was none existent then this movie would probably have rose a bit in my book.But after all its a Tim Burton Movie and its at least worth to rent

2001 may well be memorable as the prime year for really stupid movies.  Tim Burton's ambitious attempt to remake a dubious classic is certainly not the worst offender of the summer, but it may be the one that wastes the most potential.  In trying to avoid the pitfalls of most remakes, Burton and his scripters have tortured logic to contravene the "surprise" ending of the original to the point that their story makes little dramatic or logical sense.  With decent make-up (the lady apes are a little silly-looking), cool sets, and impressive stunt-actor acrobatics, the movie has great visual appeal, but the story veers between an allegory of man's inhumanity to man-like beings and an epic action film without ever managing to be entertaining.  See coincidence stretched once again to the breaking point, lame one-liners that no one laughs at, meaningless characters who serve no dramatic or thematic purpose, all in the service of a story with no real point.  Have to applaud the hilarious scene where perennial NRA pimp Charlton Heston as a dying father ape reveals that the secret family treasure is a hand-gun, and some of the ape cultural touches (loved the way they mounted horses) are really neat, but generally this movie left me feeling like I had wasted over two hours of my life and several points of my IQ.  And after this summer, I don't have much left.  Easily Tim Burton's worst movie.

What a disappointment.  Someone keeps forgetting that in movies there are things called "characters".  These "characters" should be written well and portrayed with good acting so as the audience that has spent its hard earned money may relate to them, believe in them, and ultimately give a damn about them.  Poor Mr. Burton, this film has but a trace of his talent.  It you love bad dialogue and some cool looking dudes in Ape suits  this movie is for you.  The best part was when Bubbles got his but kicked.  I'm sorry, but not even a descent performance by Tim Roth could save this plotless film. I haven't seen the original since I was a kid, but from what I remember there were a few characters in it that people gave a damn about. Two thumbs down.

reviews.review_title: Great retelling of a classic story
reviews.content: When Pierre Boulle wrote the original book "The Monkey Planet", he was mostly known for the classic story "Bridge Over The River Kwai".When it was made into a movie in 1968, Charlton Heston ingrained this movie permanently in our minds.  He was also a driving force in the creation of the original, having read the original book and helping to bring it to the attention of the money men in Hollywood and carrying it from original concept to final completion.In fact, the original movie is such a classic, it spawned 4 sequals and 2 TV series (1 live action and one animated).  It's influence was so wide, that when "Welcome Back Kotter" premiered on TV, the character Arnold Horshack carried a POTA lunchbox wherever he went.This new version in many ways is both closer to the original book, and also deviates much more.The effects and makeup in this version are spectacular.  Much as the original revolutionized makeup for decades to come, this one will also show it's influence for a long time.  Rather then use computer graphics to create the apes, the use of makeup and appliances is spectacular.Tim Burton did a fantastic job on this movie.  And of course, what is a Tim Burton movie without Danny Elfman doing the musical score.  Combined, they have made a movie that is sure to be a classic for years to come.One of the biggest differences is that the classes of ape are not as seperated as they were in the original.In the original, Chimps all wore green and were scientists.  Gorillas wore black and were military, and Orangutangs wore orange and were clergy/politicians.  In this they are more diverse, and there even seems to be hints of cross-species breeding.  This makes for a much more diverse history, and more potential for both conflict and support.Also, the humans in this version are able to talk, but they strive to hide that fact from the apes.  And as the humans are more human then in the original, the apes are more ape like.  They frequently jump around and climb on things, write with their feet, touch and groom each other, and in general are more like evolved apes should be.The cast is excellent, with both Michael Clarke Duncan and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa playing excellent roles.  Michael Clarke Duncan is one of the best new actors in the business today, and this role is as far as possible from The Green Mile.Tim Burton added several subtle and not so subtle pokes and images from both the original and contemporary society into the movie.  From Charlton uttering his classic "Damn them all to hell" again, to an Orangutang saying the Rodney King line "Can't we all just get along", to having another orangutang rub himself with flower petals while upside down, very reminiscant to "American Beauty".Of course, the most memorable part of the original movie is the ending. The image of Charlton Heston looking at the wreckage of the Statue Of Liberty is forever burned into our minds.  In much the same way, this ending will also be burned into our minds.  And in many ways, the ending this time is much closer to the original ending as written by Pierre Boulle.I am curious to how they will do a sequal to this movie.  In today's market, everything from American Pie to Wayne's World have sequals.  And this is really the first time that a movie spawned a series of sequals (the 007 movies do not count, since they do not sequal in any order, and were based on a series of books).  So it will be interesting to see if this movie spawns a similar series of sequals.If you loved the original movie, you have to see this one.In addition to Charlton Heston, look for a cameo by Linda Harrison, the actress that played Nova in the original movies.

reviews.review_title: Anger doesn't begin to express my feelings.....
reviews.content: If there is a bigger waste of time than this movie was, please let me know so I can avoid it at all costs!!! Makeup:  good, set design: outstanding, acting: awful, script and dialog: the worst piece of rubbish yet this year. Just because it is said to be a revision doesn't give it the right to completely be disrespectful of the audiences intelligence. To go from sleepy hollow (which I enjoyed throughly) to this?  Tim why don't you write your own movies anymore? The original was thought provoking, insightful, revolutionary, and downright entertaining.  This........this was worse than Armageddon!!! This is what happens when you let Hollywood decide what is best for a remake...oops I mean redelusion. Blah. I'd rather watch the Battle for the Planet of the Apes (the weakest of the series) on a 24 hour loop then ever see this again. At least Aldo would make me smile with his terrible acting because his was probably only paid in peanuts (no pun intended) due to budget restraints. Not paid a fortune like Marky Mark to be the Hero in this movie. He can only muster himself up to sounding like Dirk Diggler in the documentries from Boogie Nights, only there is no fake apendage to help him out this time.........I must stop now or I will explode....ahhhhh!!!!!

Hated it!  I terribly disliked the original so I thought this new version would be different.  It was in a way but it still has a disappointing ending.  After viewing it I had to do some reading the rest of the night to get it off my mind.  The point of humans and apes living in harmony was appealing but it should have stopped right there.  It was very disheartening to get away from one nightmare and crash land into another.Save your money, save your electricity. Don't bother!  Humans rule!

reviews.review_title: I like the Burton-version more than the old version!
reviews.content: This afternoon I finally watched Planet Of The Apes by Tim Burton. Majorly cool movie. I still remember watching the old version when I was still a kid. I somewhat liked that stuff, but I didn't expect I'd still like the idea now that I'm grown up. But now I finally understand where the storyteller was coming from. He just turned the real world around and made monkeys treat human beings the way human beings treat monkeys. When I was a child I didn't see it like that. I just took it as a story about a planet of apes, but not really like a story somewhat criticizing the way monkeys are treated by us. Pretty cool. And as far as I remember I like the Burton-version more than the old version.

This movie serves its purpose, assuming you go in with the attitude that it's the Apes against the humans.  Tim Burton's imagination makes the new Planet of the Apes a wonder to watch and look at.  As with every Tim Burton film, there are certain things that aren't necessary...I could have taken or left the ending.  But there is plenty to like about this film, more likeable than not.  The only major flaw with the film was casting Mark Wahlberg...and thank the almighty, that he doesn't have enough screen presence for us to even pay attention to what he's saying.  I found myself sort of skipping over Wahlberg's part and paying more attention to the real stars of the movie...those damned dirty apes.  Rick Baker will win an Oscar for his makeup...(you've done your job if the actors are unrecognizable).  General Thade is a villain we can all love to hate and Tim Roth should be proud of the job he did in bringing this character to life.  I was convinced of his genuine evil.  Helena Bonham Carter and Michael Clarke Duncan were almost equally as convincing and I hope to see all 3 of them back in the next movie.Tim Burton has gained my respect.  He surprised me with Sleepy Hollow and has me back on his good list with Planet of the Apes.  His storytelling abilities have improved and he's toned down the "unbelievable silliness" factor (IE Edward Scissorhands, Batman Returns, Any of the Pee Wee movies). Instead of going nuts with how bizarre the characters can be, he redirects his talents into making you FEAR the Apes...as in Sleepy Hollow, you FEAR the Headless Horseman.  So much that you're fascinated with how evil these villains are.There's no need to talk about the genius of Danny Elfman's musical talents. He's been doing it for years and if anyone knows how to make even an average movie come to life, it is Elfman.Kudos to Burton....a well done film, minus Marky Mark.  He'll get it right next time.

I went to see Planet of the Apes and got just what I expected. Tim Burton could do a lot better than this, but it wasn't terrible. The apes looked pretty good, and the movie was full of twists, which made it more fun. The ending surprised me, but I don't plan to see any sequel. This is an average film--not to good, not too bad--but I would suggest waiting for it to come out on video. The acting of the apes was good, as well as most of the human characters. After a while, however, it became a little boring seeing people fly through the air over and over again. ** out of ****.

It has been always very delightful to enjoy Tim Burton's unique and talented way to show his artistic view of very interesting stories and not so usual portrayed characters. At least that began to create all the excitement for "planet of the apes".This time Mr. Burton comes with a script that basically represents the main concept of its predecessor, but the story since the beginning until the end, never gets to reach the ground.Burton handles the audience with the help of a very dull and confusing plot that ends in deception as well as most of the actor's performances. Not even the costumes, the very great art direction, the excellent makeup and Danny Elfman's good piece of clear score, can save it.The only possibility of salvation for this movie is wait for that ape to come back and once again rule the government.Robinson Almanzar.

I think that the best possible review for the latest Tim Burton movie comes directly from the source material, Pierre Boulle's 1963 novel "Planet of the Apes.""I soon succeeded in convincing myself that well-trained animals might well... become expert in in all the human arts, including the art of cinematography." -Pierre BoulleTim Burton was so wrapped up in the idea that this was about the apes, that he apparently was humanitarian enough to let a real live ape write the script.The film was 15% Planet of the Apes, 15% Tim Burton, and 70% Hollywood Bull Crap.The plot is thin, the dialogue ridiculous, and the ending a completely predictable insult to viewer intelligence.  Fortunately the special effects are perfect... so what you end up with is a lump of coal wrapped in pretty wrapping paper.A waste of potential!

I loved the original.  It had a lot more to it than a simple sci-fi flick. Everyone agrees with that.  Did I expect this remake to be up to the same level?  No.  I went in with a fresh perspective, letting the movie stand on its own.  What a mistake that was.One plot' point that bothered me was all the people wanting to see the man who defies the apes, since they defy the apes every day by congregating in roving bands of scavengers evading capture.  Also, there is a difference between giving the ending a hanging twist, the sort that requires you to think, and incomprehensible one.  Oh, and the two swiped lines from the original ("Get your stinking hands off me..." and "Damn them...") had the feeling of being forced into the script.  They just did not flow.Warren is a horrible actress.  Wahlberg was fairly stiff.  Bonham-Carter was a caricature.  Roth was the stereotypical mister-mean-man.  The script was just plain weak and the craft of storytelling was nonexistent.So, I thought I would read the book.  Let's see, the beginning was nothing like the book, the ending had little in common with the book, the middle wasn't really that much like the book.  However, there were talking apes... So, yeah, it was similar in that respect.I am glad I only rented this.  Well, not really.

I thought the new re-creation of "Planet of the Apes" had a lusher visual style and a better script. Of course the new technology also made for upgraded f/x in a film heavily dependent on that end. The acting was commendable generally, but especially by Helena Bonham Carter & Tim Roth behind all that monkey make-up.

reviews.review_title: Stop trying to compare it to the original. This is a good movie!
reviews.content: I am at a loss as to why so many reviewers disliked this movie so much. I wonder if it's because everyone seems to be comparing it to the original, and that's probably not fair, as the original is one of the world's all-time classics. I think this new version deserves to be judged on its own. I rather liked it. It did get off to a bit of a slow and predictable start, but the second half of the movie was excellent. I must, however, agree with some of the other reviewers here in that I did not understand the ending!About the ending (MAJOR SPOILER TO FOLLOW): At first I was thinking that something Davidson did somehow changed the past, and hence he returned to Earth to find the apes in charge. But on reflection, Thade's face & name replacing Lincoln's has its own meaning -- not just the apes in charge, but Thade in particular. When and how did Thade come to Earth? Or was the other planet really Earth, too, just in the distant future? I am still confused about this. I would welcome hearing anyone's theories (my e-mail address is shown above). All in all, I think this was a great movie, and very undeserving of all the criticism I'm reading here. Give it a try with an open mind and don't try to compare it to the original, and I think you'll enjoy it!

Only a couple of good things to say here. The makeup is, of course, amazing. Rick Baker deserves awards galore for his work on this film. General Thade is probably the best villain I've seen on screen since Darth Maul, but being probably the worst movie of the year, likely no credit will be given. The dialog is insipid, the acting is grade school and the action never gains momentum. What a waste of a premise. No scathing social commentary, no clever nods to the original (only a few stolen lines), no real development of any kind. Save your time and see something else.

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton is In Sever Need of a Life...
reviews.content: Oh My......Let me start out this review with one word.....Run. Run as fast as you can. Save yourself. Stay away from this move....Now, moving on....Horrible, revolting, bad, unwatchable, Plain out Bad. There are a million other words I could use to describe this film. First, let me start of by saying, Mr. Burton, get a life. You need it. I have yet to see a movie from you that is actually GOOD. You have ruind this Great Franchise! I fear what Charile and the Chocolate Factory Will be like.....*cowers at the thought of another HORRIBLE Tim Burton Film*For the movie itself.....like i said earlier, run. Bad Acting. Bad Plot, Bad Everything.

if you are comparing this to the original, you will hate this, because this is not a remake, but it is a journey into Tim Burton's head while he was watching the film. it is nothing like the original. Of course, nothing can beat the original classic, but this is jsut as exciting and fun. the speciall effects were amazing. unlike most movies these days (jurassic park 3, pearl harbor) that use the F/X as the main star, POTA does not. the F/X are not overdone, and when used, they are fantastic. Tim Roth, Mark Wahlberg, and even Estella Warren give good performances that are top notch. overall, the new story that is followed closely to the first movie, is fantastic, and i reconmend this flick as long as you don't compare it to the original.

After reading some of the early reviews of this film, I was beginning to worry that Tim Burton had finally become just another cog in the mind-numbing machinery of the SFX-laden film industry.  It was a huge relief to discover that Burton's *Apes* -- easily the most entertaining film so far this summer -- is perhaps his most visually and dramatically gripping film ever.  This is despite Mark Wahlberg's woodenly resolute performance, which displays about as much screen charisma as an orangutan's hairbrush.  The apes, however, in their far more pliant makeup, steal the show. Paul Giamatti absolutely steals the film as the conniving human-trader "Limbo," and Tim Roth's General Thade is robustly animalistic.  The apes' habit of leaping in the air in displays of anger owes something to Jane Goodall and something to Hong Kong action flicks -- but wherever it comes from, it adds an extra zest to the simian world. While it doesn't reach the darkly sublime heights of Batman or Edward Scissorhands, *Apes* is Burton's best in some time, and easily steals the show from the series of  stumbling (and expensive) zombies the studios have vomited forth so far this summer.

This movie is by far the movie of the summer.  I didn't like the original but I loved this!  Tim Roth plays one of the best villans that I've ever seen.  This movie keeps you thinking and leaves you thinking even more after the credits. ****10 out of 10!******

reviews.review_title: Ome of the better summer movies
reviews.content: Planet of the Apes was a real delight after a summer of disappointing movies.  This summer has been one disappointment after another.  First there was Tomb Raider, which was full of dumb cliches.  Then there was A.I, which had too much hype behind it and was too long to keep your interest.  After all the disappointments it's a real relief that the studios can still come up with a good movie. 	Tim Burton brings us another blockbuster hit.  This is Burton's best work since Sleepy Hollow.  Burton uses his unique techniques to bring the apes alive for the film.  His artistic expertise that Burton displayed in the making of Planet of the Apes has probably made him one of the most well known directors today.  The mere talent that Burton brings to a film makes him one of the most unique directors of our time. 	Mark Wahlberg is wonderful in this film.  He plays Leo Davidson, a United States captain who crash lands on the planet and discovers that the apes rule the planet.  This is a step up for Wahlberg from 1994's Renaissance Man, where he plays Private Tommy Lee Haywood.  This is probably Wahlberg's best film since Boogie Nights. 	Tim Roth plays the evil General Thade, general to the ape army.  He despises the human race.  Charlton Heston makes a small cameo appearance as General Thade's Father, the only ape with a gun.  Overall I gave Planet of the Apes a 6.  If you liked this I would suggest renting Sleepy Hollow, Batman, and Edward Scissorhands.

(Some spoilers in this review...)Even without comparing this film to the original, I was rather disappointed. The first half, the effects, costuming, score, and some of the characters were all very good. The story was interesting and somewhat original and suspenseful up until the midpoint of the film. However, in the second half the film degenerated into a rather derivative, uninspired, Hollywood-ized, feel-good ending. It appears as if THE MATRIX (and XENA) has set a new standard for fight scenes (i.e., unbelievable aerial moves, violence that results in nary a scratch, etc.), which is getting rather tiresome. I'm also disappointed in the obligatory mass-combat scene (granted it is necessary in some films: GLADIATOR, THE PATRIOT, etc., but not in EVERY film). POTA also continues my dislike of children in most science-fiction films. The main human child character in this film was uninteresting and your typical film child character (rebellious and obnoxious) and he gave a stereotypical non-suspense scene during the climatic battle. I was also disappointed at the lack of atmosphere that one would expect from a Tim Burton film.SPOILER: Normally I can figure out any sort of time-loop, paradox thingy that a story has. However, the "surprise-ending" in this version of POTA does not seem possible at all, at least not as a consequence of Leo's actions.Because this is a remake, it begs to be compared to the original POTA. Because Burton's version is not set on Earth, it lacks the emotional punch that the 1968 version did and still does. One thing I appreciated was Burton's inclusion of two classic lines from the original version, but with a nice twist.

Planet of the Apes is definitely a good movie.  No, it's not as good as the original of 1968, but it really is an entertaining movie.  The make-up they used to create the illusion of apes being the dominant species is breathtaking and quite realistic looking.  I'd say that's one of the strongest points of the film.As for the storyline, it is changed up from the original.  In fact, it is a very different story all together.  However, this does not change the fact that this is a good movie and I'm willing to bet just about anyone who goes to see it will like it too.You've probably all heard about the surprise ending (which isn't that much of a surprise... me and my friend managed to guess it right!) DOES make sense.  Really, trust me it does.  I don't know, certain people might look at it from certain and different angles... but I managed to come to the conclusion that no matter what time or planet your on, the apes still manage to evolve and overtake the humans.  That may not make much sense to you if you haven't seen the movie, but it will.All in all, I do recommend seeing this movie.  I went to see it with my friends and we all agree it was a good movie.  I think it has both funny moments and interesting ones... but don't expect a drama.

reviews.review_title: Excellent Apes and Music, but No More
reviews.content: I agree with a lot of the commenters.  The apes and their clothes were fabulous.  But the sets and the plot weren't.  Actually, I thought this movie was boring.  There was no characterization.  Motives for actions were hard to discern.  (Maybe the idea of the Mark Wahlberg character was: What happens when a basically shallow, dumb person ends up as the key man in a complicated situation?  Answer: He becomes a vehicle for action  --- of which there was a lot.)  I think that this movie is summed up in the credits which were somber and elegant all by themselves --- the film is about great costumes and the power of design.  But That's All, Folks.

At some point, while watching the hordes of marching soldier apes as they rocked side to side like Stevie Wonder on speed, I had a sudden cinematic flashback - yes, I had seen this before: the flying monkeys from the Wizard of Oz!  Slow paced (it's a thin story, so the plot had to be squeezed out for all it was worth like the last tube of toothpaste on a deserted island) and mundane, I started wondering when something was actually going to happen.  Nothing ever happens, not even an ending.  Ok, there was an ending, but it wasn't like finding the Statue of Liberty buried in the sand... Skip this and watch reruns of FARSCAPE on the telly - far more entertaining.  And why *is* Mark Wahlberg a movie star, anyway?  The chimp astronaut had more charisma than Markie Mark.

This is a great movie! The special effects, and the retelling was excellent... In my opinion theres no beating the original, but this was a great recreation.  If you liked the original, this is a must see!

reviews.review_title: Not to bad for a remake!!!
reviews.content: Well well, very impress about that remake, I mean I am sick ofthose old show and movies that they remake, no more inspirationor what?  But that remake was good.  I loved the costume over all,they were fantastic, they play of Tim Roth as the mean Ape was thetop, I would like him to get the award for the mean bad guyhehehe!  No but he was great.  The action scenes were alsoamazing...  I must say that I am not crazy about Estella Warren as aactress, but she might get better, I was a little disappointed to seea nice cast like that and having her for one of the major character... but it was ok...  I tried to watch it as if it was not the remake, and itworked, maybe that is why I liked it more than some people I know. Anyway it is a very nice movie to see...  enjoy it!

Perhaps there's no such thing as a bad Tim Burton film, but Planet of the Apes comes perilously close. Visually the make-up is generally impressive  the overall effect of seeing so many simian humanoids at once is quite overpowering, even if most of the set-design is pretty unimaginative.
Tim Roth's performance as a sort of Richard III ape is perhaps the most memorable  his strangulated restless manner is reminiscent of the mortally wounded Mr Orange in Reservoir Dogs (although he wasn't a monkey). Bonham Carter is also impressive in a decisive departure from her flowery Merchant Ivory image. Only the make-up lets her down  her visage seems to have been tampered with in an ultimately futile attempt to make her look her like an attractive ape. This fails. On the other hand, Estella Warren's Daena is far too much like a supermodel to look like a convincing native girl.So why does Planet of the Apes fail? Here are some ideas.1) Why do the humans on the planet speak? In the original film and the novella there was a direct human-apes reversal situation  the humans could not speak or communicate anymore effectively than monkeys can on Earth. That was why the arrival of Heston's character stirred the waters. Here the humans are clearly ruled over by the apes, but given their supposed mastery of technology' which the apes lack, there seems no real reason why the apes should be so dominant. Burton seems to be striving for a civil rights parallel. Roth's ape even misquotes the reactionary Senator Barry Goldwater at one point. But this paradox still makes little sense.2) Too much of the dialogue is banal or just stupid. There are a number of signs the film is rushed.3) The comedy' orang-utan is annoying. 4) Wahlberg is no action hero. He got away with it playing a porn actor but not here. 5) The ending seems to be an attempt to echo that of the novella. Yet that made sense. This one doesn't. It is not clever, just inexplicable. I HEREBY DEFY ANYONE ON THESE PAGES TO EXPLAIN THE ENDING SATISFACTORILY! It's impossible - it's nonsensical.Overall, not a disaster, but highly disappointing.

reviews.review_title: When is the Sequel coming and whats with that long stupid trailer????
reviews.content: Man I went into this movie really thinking it was going to be a dog because of the poor trailers for this movie. I mean does every movie have to show the dumb trailers that either show you every laughable line or worse yet, show you a synopsis of the whole movie??? I think a simple teaser would suffice for any and all movies before they are released. Unless we are all turning into little children as adults and need the whole movie pratically explained to us before going to go see it.Anyway, this was a very good version of POTA. I was very pleased and a little surprised at the outcome of the movies ending. They practically gave it away, probably for the slower people who like long trailers.This is very much worth seeing and I hope they get the sequel done by next year. They better not leave this one hanging too long. They never made people wait too long in the past series.Thanks, Gary
You know when your walking along and you step in something unpleasant well this is that something what a load of crap

I went in seeing the Tim Burton Planet of the Apes, with my hopes aimed low.  I loved the first Planet of the Ape, though i have yet to see the entier series, I was wondering how they were going to pull this off.  I was very suprised.  The angel that they took was better than i expected.  They didn't go for a "Remake" of the original, but took some elements of the first one, and gave a Buton-esq spin on things.  WARNING< SPOLIERS:  The direction of not making the planet Earth was much better.  Knowing that nothing could live up to the orginal, they basicly said "Screw it" and gave a whole new origin to the Apes.  Mark Walburge's charecter is very belivable. Unlike Chuck Heston's charecter, Walburge's Leo excepts that apes are in control.  He could care less.  All he wants to do is get out, get this monkey, and go home.  The ape in the movie are also presented more human like than that of the original one.  They are more reminisant of people in the mid to late 1800's as where people were into slavery, those who flet it was wrong, began making their voices heard.  Same as with the Apes.  They felt that Humans where inferior, and thus should be slaves, but then there where those who felt that humans should be free and equal.  Tim Burton was an excelent choice for director.  Though Planet of the Apes was an odd movie for him to make (unlike the genius Sleepy Hollow, which he was born to make)  Burton really makes what he has to work with, work.  The dark theme of the  movie is not the usuall "Gothic" dark that Burton has in most of his movies (Edward Sisccor hands, Batman 1 and 2, Bettle juice, Sleepy Hollow)  he gives a dark theme that is some what moody and evil.  My only small problem is that they used the great Chuck Heston on liners, only the Apes said them.  But it was Chuck Heston himself that redeliverd his great "Damn them, Damn them all to hell" line, but as an APE!!  I recomend it highly.

reviews.review_title: APES is not so bad of a PLANET...
reviews.content:
PLANET OF THE APES: BThe plot of "Planet of the Apes" doesn't take much thought. Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) crash lands on a distant planet run by ape people. They're scary, aggresive, and they hate humans. They inprision humans and make them slaves. But, Leo is the macho, egotistical type (a must for these kinds of movies). He breaks out along with the beauty Daena (Estalla Warren) with the help of ape Ari (Helena Bonham Carter). General Thade (Tim Roth, one scary looking dude) quickly finds out about this and doesn't take to it lightly. He gathers his whole army so they go searching for the humans. Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) is humble assitant who is second in command.
For about 45 minutes of the movie it wasn't looking so good, because of the character of Leo and his cliché. The characters were kind of a problem. They were old and tired. Ari posses the most heart, though. Also, a love triangle emerges between Ari, Leo, and Daena.. Th film seems scared, though, to take on the subject of "inner-species" dating. It doesn't, until about the last 30 minutes, give us anything we've already seen before. Except great make-up. But the thing about it is, it's a lot of fun. I picked up the problems I listed above, but really didn't care. Tim Burton, personally, is my favorite director. He has yet to make a bad film. He has a certain style that is dark and ominous, Here, it is muddled and doesn't show up until about the last 30 minutes. You can sense it's there but it doesn't show up  until then.
"Planet" has one of the greatest endings of the year, which is the high point of the movie. It's also got some other neat twists in it along the way. So, despite it's many problem, "Planet" is an enjoyable, often funny, often scary, summer movie.Note: Pay attention to Danny Elfman's tremendous score. He had done most of Burton's films and each score is terrific. I don't feel he gets enough recognition, so I thought I'd mention it.

Tim Burton's "re-imagining" of Planet of the Apes is pretty good except for that ending (no spoilers) that I really didn't like.  Burton really didn't nee that ending to make it good.  it was great by itself. USAF space station Oberon is doing experments on geniticly altered monkeys in space.  One day a chimpanzee named Periclese  gose to investigate an elctric magnetic storm and disaperes.  The film's hero, Leo Davison (Mark Wahlberg), who has become freinds with Periclese, gose out to find him and is swept up in the storm.  He eventualy crashes on a planet that is contrloed by apes, and is captured.  He then mets Ari (Helana Banham Carter) and escapes "Ape City".  The group is being hunted by the comander of the ape army, Thade (Tim Roth).  They reach the sacred ruins of CALIMA, and have a hugh battle with the ape army. The film had incredible scenery and make-up.  I loved "Ape City" (probubly so did everyone else), and all the scenes were the veiwer gets a look at ape civilization.  The action sequences are also outstanding with a whole lot of apes flying through the air.  I also liked that the actors actualy moved and looked liked apes.  Mark Wahlberg's preformance could have been better, but was berible.  The stand-out preformances are realy Tim Roth and Helana Bonham Carter.  Both did exelently in their roles.  Roth is no where. It's all Thade.  This is undoutibly one of Burton's most imaginitive films, but not his best.  I give Planet of the Apes 8/10.

Tim Burton's "re-imagining" of Planet of the Apes was actually pretty good. I think it's just the ending that brought it down.Astronaut Leo Davison (Mark Wahlberg) goes to find a chimpanzee named Peracliese who was lost investigating an electro magnetic storm.  Leo is swept up in the storm and sent to a world where apes rule over humans with an iron fist.  He is captured and brought to Ape City.  A human rights activist named Ari (Helana Bonham Carter) frees Leo and Daena (Estella Warren).  They all escape with others and soon become  hunted by General Thade (Tim Roth).  The group reaches the sacred ruins of CALIMA, and have a huge all-out battle between the ape army and the humans.This movie has intense action sequences, amazing make-up, a good score, fair visual effects, and great directing.  The best performances are Roth's (who I think needs a nomination for best supporting actor) and Carter's.  Burton again does a superb directing job.  The movie itself is good.  I just hated that ending.I give Planet of the Apes 8/10.

reviews.review_title: I payed money to see this...
reviews.content: This is a terrible film. I have nothing against a good no-brainer action film, but this film is terrible. It's more hole than plot, even before you get to the "twist". The make-up's not bad and generally the effects are passable, but they're nothing special either, and they certainly can't rescue the film from its profound and obvious deficiencies. The performances are atrocious, even from those members of the cast that I know to be capable of much more. The plot is what most sticks in my craw though. Without even dignifying the "twist ending", the rest of the story makes no sense whatsoever either. It's terrible. Just awful.

reviews.review_title: Visually Stunning, Impressive... and of course, Flawed Version of "Apes"
reviews.content: I first became a fan of the "Planet of the Apes" saga when I was 12 years old. HBO was showing the original film and I came in on the scene in which Charlton Heston's Taylor was being interrogated in the apes' court. I was hooked from that moment on. I bought all five original films and watched all of them countless times and re-bought them when Fox put out the THX-Widescreen tapeset for the 30th anniversary. What did Apes do for me? Well, to begin with, it made me examine my religion. The end result? I determined I wasn't Christian. It also made me want to be a film director even more. THIS WAS WHAT SCI-FI COULD DO. Even the weakest entry of all, "Battle for the Planet of the Apes," was above standard sci-fi entertainment.So here I am, 22 years old, exploring religion, life, and directing my first ambitious independent film, which is even titled as a small homage to the fourth "Apes" film, "Conquest of Area 52" (there will be an IMDB entry on it next year sometime). "Planet of the Apes" is among my biggest reasons for wanting to make films and it's impacted the way I think as well.I've read the wonderful Pierre Boulle novel (and own the first printing, which I um, borrowed from my high school library) and I will be buying the "Apes" TV series on DVD. And of course, I saw Tim Burton's "reimagining" of "Planet" on opening day.From the beginning, I'm already biased. The original Apes saga was my Bible. To paraphrase, "Everything I Needed to Know I Learned From Apes." Heh-heh. Tim Burton... love the guy. He made "Ed Wood," one of my top ten favorite films. His unique visions and styles have always intrigued me. Admittedly however, Burton normally did not have strong points in plot or character development. His "Batman" films were a mixed bag, not showing enough of the psychology of what it meant to be Batman, but they were so visually entrancing that I am still able to watch them on their own merits. In fact, both "Batman" and "Batman Returns" get an 8.5/10 from me. "Mars Attacks" is a joy to watch on the right day, and the same goes with "Edward Scissorhands" and "Beetlejuice." By the time he directed "Sleepy Hollow," I felt that Burton had evolved so much as a visual storyteller that he really could not be judged for weak plot or character. That's the way he wants to be as an artist, so let it be.But...This time, he's done "Planet of the Apes." If it were anything else, like say a remake of "2001", I could still watch it and not crucify it. No, this new version is not anything worth crucifying. "Apes 2001", shall we call it, has the all the Burton standards- plot and character on the back burner, awesome visuals at the forefront. What sets Burton aside from say, the biggest hack of all time Michael "Pearl Harbor" Bay, is that while his character drama may not be the most engaging, it's not exactly boring or annoying. It's just SIMPLE. This version plays out like the 1968 version except cut down to the core: an astronaut crashlands on a strange planet, he gets caught, is imprisoned at Ape City, gets away with the help of a lovable chimp, goes into the Forbidden Area, finds out the origin of the apes, and leaves the apes to go home. That last part is the only thing really different in the overall structure, except this time, the film does not end there, and we get an ending which both pays its respects to Boulle's original novel and Franklin Schaffner's original film.There are several references this version makes to the original series. With the Apes army we get a nod to "Beneath." With the love story, er, triangle, there's a similar feel to Zira and Cornelius' plight in "Escape." The look of the astronaut costumes is very similar to those in the first two. And the origin of the apes rings in similar tone to the fourth film, "Conquest."Did I like it? I've only seen it twice, so its a bit hard to say that without going, "except for this... and that... and this... and that..." What I liked: the cinematography, the sets (which are never all that real-looking but invoke memories of illustrated children's books, which is a Burton constant), the movement and makeup of the apes (maybe the two most noteworthy things done here), the cameos by Chuck Heston and Linda Harrison (Nova from Apes I & II). I also liked the love triangle between Ari, Leo, and the blonde; this was very humorous. Wahlberg didn't add much depth to a written character already lacking depth, but he certainly had the right expressions for his character. I wouldn't be particularly overjoyed by my stay on the Planet of the Apes either. Helena Bonham-Carter is always good in whatever she does, and her character in this was endearing enough to accept her makeup, which differs greatly from the others. Paul Giamatti's Limbo may be the best character of all, providing the most comic relief. Tim Roth as Thade is brilliant, as are the rest of the key players. I didn't appreciate that the social commentaries were sometimes rather clumsily slapped on; indeed a lot of the time they seemed like desperate attempts by Burton to put SOMETHING in there saying ANYTHING when the script had little to give him (Burton arrived on the project fairly late and had little time to shape the film).Overall, this 2001 version of "Planet" is far better than it should have been, given the success it had to live up to. It doesn't hold a candle to the original, and I certainly never expected it to. I'm glad Fox put a commercial artist in charge of it, rather than a commercial hack such as the afore-mentioned Michael Bay or Tony Scott. It may have been more intriguing had Oliver Stone worked on it (Stone was attached several years back).Tim Burton did the near-impossible for me: I didn't want to kill him after watching this. And for an Apes fanatic such as myself, that is saying a heck of a lot. Let's all hope that when Fox greenlights the sequel, they don't hand it over to Joel Schumacher. I'd take Ed Wood's Planet of the Apes over his anyday.I do have one quibble I think is more than worthy of consideration to even a non-Apes fan not familiar with the original series:We know where the Apes come from in "Apes 2001." But why the heck would that space station have HORSES on it?! Sorry, I'm not gonna take the old lame scientific explanation about how life on other planets must be similar. I may be a Darwin enthusiast, but come on. That's stretching it.

*SPOILIERS*I think this movie was re-edited shortly before it's release. I say this because there are two things I've noticed: One, the line in the trailer "Bring me the space man!" is omitted. Two, there is not one, but two big plot twists in the film. The first one is cool and works well, the other is HORRIBLE. Burton, if this was your fault, you are an idiot. If it was Fox's fault, all you studio execs are idiots.The similarities between the original and the Burton films are few. There's the forbidden zone, there's a quick cameo of Dr. Zeus (ever so briefly, you have to be looking for him in the background). There's a bigger cameo of Charlton Heston as General Thade's father, also saying the like "Damn them! Damn them all to hell!" which brought on cheers in the crowd. There's also the first line between Marky Mark and an ape: "Get your hand off me you damn dirty human!" which wasn't received so well.The main plot twist was a good adaptation of the original, and perhaps a bit more realstic. However the second one brought on "boo's" from the crowd. People were really p***ed off at it. I won't give it away here, but let's just say that the other 99.9% of the film BARELY makes up for how bad this ending is.Tim Roth as Thade was INCREDIBLE. He stole the show. He was evil incarnate, and I'd watch the movie again just for him (and then I'll walk out of the theater right before the crappy ending).9/10, would have been a 10 but minus 1 for the ending.

reviews.review_title: not as good as the original
reviews.content: The `reimagined' version of this story pays due homage to the 1968 classic (at the time of its release the biggest sci-fi film yet made) while retaining Burton's unique flavor and comic book atmosphere.  But comparing this to the original is like comparing Li'l Debbie snacks to Hostess-a little more style but a lot less tasty saturated fat.  Wahlberg stars as Air Force cadet Leo Davidson, stranded on a strange planet after flying recklessly into a cosmic anomaly (I believe the proper sci-fi CYA term is `a rift in the space-time continuum').  After Davidson finds the planet ruled by simians who keep humans as slaves he escapes from their clutches, finds a few sympathetic monkeys, and sets off across the country to find his ship and get back home.  The group runs into a little trouble finding any crewmates, but what they do find is the truth behind the planet's origins in a finale not nearly as fun or coherent as the original film's surprise ending.Putting plot issues aside for a moment, what you'll like about the film are the ape actors.  Tim Roth hams it up wonderfully as the ruthless ape leader Thade, even if his performance leans a little too heavily on the snarl and glare department.  Helena Bonham Carter is bewitching as Ari, an upper-class liberal ape who even manages to flirt convincingly with Davidson on their journey together. Paul Giamatti is actually funny as the orangutan slave-trader Limbo, rather than the usual obnoxious comic relief fare.  And Michael Clarke Duncan and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa are excellent as Attar and Krull, two old war comrades who have now found themselves on opposite sides of the battlefield.  Unfortunately, the human counterparts in the film are much less impressive.  Kris Kristofferson steps in and out, stopping briefly to perhaps pick up his paycheck.  Estella Warren may as well not be there at all as her role seems to be defined as merely a pretty face among monkeys. But the most disappointing role by far is Wahlberg's, who in the past has been at least charming, but remains wooden throughout this feature.  For someone billed as the hero it's a bit off-putting that his entire focus remains on getting back to earth-in the end he spends about two minutes being noble before blundering off into the weakest `shock ending' I've seen in a film since Fight Club.But even with feeble lead performances and plot holes bigger than a baboons hot red ass we still get a few kicks out of the story.  Burton also isn't afraid to pull a couple of one-liners coupled with a Charlton Heston cameo that will set fans of the original laughing out loud in the theater.  And while POTA 2001 is not going to impress any die-hard fans of the first version, this might not be a problem-chances are, many of the young audiences watching today (sadly) never got around to seeing the forerunner for comparison.

I've begun to appreciate the massive value of editing action sequences. When it's done well, there aren't any questions about who's hit whom, where the action's taken place or whether the sequence is even plausible. 
In "Planet of the Apes", I think that the editing sucked lemons. 
In fact, the movie as a whole was really three inches shy of being very annoying.  I found myself admiring the make-up, for heaven's sake! 
If you must see it, check your brain in at the popcorn stand.

Luckily for everyone Planet of the Apes didn't follow Tomb Raider and the many other summer movies into the major disappointment catagory.  Simply put, the latest from Tim Burton is exciting, perfectly paced, and a hoot! Rick Baker's makeup is the most convincing makeup work ever to grace the screen.  The performances by those wearing it is phenomenal.  Tim Roth may be one of the most engaging FX aided villains ever as General Thade.  The story isn't too complicated, nor is it nonexistant as we have come to expect from this summer's crop.  It lacks the predictability that makes so many FX laden movies fall on their face.  This is a movie that will be mixed with critics, mixed with fans of the original (this strays a lot from the classic's elements), extremely popular with young audiences, and worth everyone's dollar at the box office.  Only gripe is the casting of Mark Wahlberg.  He can usually turn in an engaging performance, but he's no Charlton Heston.  The ending is a mind blower, but teeters on a little too confusing.  Yet, you will leave the theater wishing the sequel came out tomorrow!

reviews.review_title: Visually stunning but otherwise same old Hollywood plot line.
reviews.content: Tim Burton presents a magnificent movie for the eyes, but alas opts for the usual poor screen play. I left the movie feeling that I had been well entertained. The magicpecial effects, make-up, musical score all produce a feast of movie fantasy. The ape-ing is inspired. Tim Roth, as the fanatical Chimp General, is worth the price of admission alone. Paul Giamatti has some nice moments, but no-one else is given much to do except to imitate apes or fearful humans. The female chimps look too much like the original Kim Hunter, bereft of facial hair and facial creases.As usual with these kinds of movies the throw away line is ever present, and some make for a good snicker or two. I wonder how many people caught the irony of Charlton Heston defending gun control!It's really best to see this movie with your inner child on your lap, and leave the critical adult home. This is especially true for the ending which gives a momentary smile of pleasure at it's salute to the original, as long as one doesn't think about how it doesn't make any sense!

Watching this garbage was a complete waste of time. I had pretty high hopes with Tim Burton directing, but he spent way too much (time and money) on the dumb things: makeup, effects and not enough time on the important things: story, character development.  It makes me wonder why they bothered to make this crap. Answer: money, the movie is rediculous and has no value add to the original. Sure the apes look more real, but their dialog is rediculous and a huge missed opportunity to even make the apes scary: something that shouldn't be too hard.I hold Burton responsible for this blunder and I'll never see another movie he makes in the theatre again, he's violated my trust by churning out this crap. He should be embarrassed and retire.Oh well, at least I have the original on DVD.

reviews.review_title: Rated H for HORROR -- and for horrible.
reviews.content: OK - They definitely tried to make this one different from the first film -- hence the term re-imaging. Of course, like the first film, it was only BASED on Pierre Boulle's novel. Like the 1968 film -- the only thing this film has to connect it to Pierre Boulle's work is the title (and a single plot twist). This film does deal with the same moral issues as the original (bigotry) and has some interesting angles of political ambition thrown in to the mix. However, the film ultimately failed to capture my interest as the original did. The characterizations were just flat and 2-dimensional. The ending was the only thing that was shocking. THADE had been beaten, yet his defeat ultimately won him the world he had sought to make.This twist ending was straight out of the book, but I wasted my time for all intents and purposes. If they wanted to resurrect the franchise, they should have done a continuation from where the originals left off. I rate this film H for HORROR and horrible.

reviews.review_title: Great New Visualisation of the "Planet of the Apes" Idea
reviews.content: As a fan of the original Planet of the Apes movies, I really enjoyed this new motion picture.Normally, remakes suffer from the fact that they are just copies of the original movie, mostly without the excitement or fun of it.Planet of the Apes is a new attempt to use the idea behind Planet of the Apes. Thus, it is worth to be seen even by die-hard fans of the original movies.Mark Wahlberg can never match the quality of Charlton Heston, and was probably not a good choice, but the Apes are even more realistic and differentiated than in the old movies, as far as their characters are concerned. The girl which was Nova in the 1968 movie is also much more intelligent and has more to offer than just to look good.All the cruelty of manhood is being shown to as like in a fable on the example of the monkeys - sorry, apes! This content alone makes it really hard to create a bad movie upon it.Planet of the Apes (2001) is really worth the money, it has impressive shots to offer, a smooth storyline, interesting characters and an idea which should make us think about ourselves and our history.Only the end is really poor and doesn't fit the rest of the movie. It looks as if this was only added to ensure future sequels. It is very primitive and doesn't match the quality of the actual movie.

This movie(if you want to call it that) was a complete debacle!!! I really wish that people would leave the classics alone and come up with new ideas. It is impossible to try to capture the feel of the original movie, even with modern CG effects. Then to add insult to injury the producer even went as far as to re-write the movie to their liking! The only place this should have been seen was on the cutting room floor, and that is even being nice! To the Producer... please... if you want to remake a movie... please choose something that you have a chance at making better instead of ruining classics that will be around longer than you will! What a legacy for you to leave... I destroyed a classic!

reviews.review_title: Good special effects and costumes; weak writing.
reviews.content: Everything about this remake was better than the original except for the screenplay and acting. The ending was inexplicable and may have set the stage for another movie. I thought the acting in both movies was about the same. Not great, not bad.

Although, still not as good as the original Planet of the Apes (1968) it was pretty darn close! Great make-up work, great music,and special effects!! Planet of the Apes (2001) is a must see movie! Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth, and Paul Giamatti do a great job as their parts of Attar, Ari, Thade, and Limbo! You've really gotta see this movie, and also the original Planet of the Apes (1968), Beneath the Planet of the Apes, Escape from the Planet of the Apes, Conquest of the Planet of the Apes, and Battle for the Planet of the Apes!

Although, still not as good as the original Planet of the Apes (1968) it was pretty darm close! Great make-up work, great music,and special effects!! Planet of the Apes (2001) is a must see movie! Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth, and Paul Giamatti do a great job as their parts of Attar, Ari, Thade, and Limbo! You've really gotta see this movie, and also the original Planet of the Apes (1968), Beneath the Planet of the Apes, Escape from the Planet of the Apes, Conquest of the Planet of the Apes, and Battle for the Planet of the Apes!

reviews.review_title: A welcome addition to the Apes franchise
reviews.content: It was brave for Tim Burton to take on the challenge of trying to recreate a classic which many would consider unnecessary but some how the director with one the best minds when it comes to imagery to recreate the classic tale and It shared many aspects of the original. I really liked the soldier uniforms given to the apes. Another great addition was casting Mark Wahlberg as the leading character Leo Davidson and Helena Bonham Carter as the ape, Ari who assists him to escape the ape village along with her bodyguard. It might not match the masterpiece from way back in 1968 Burton remains true to his image and it will welcome new fans into the franchise.

reviews.review_title: should be called Planet of the Pants
reviews.content: A horrid, hateful, hash of a movie. A totally needless exercise. What is the point of remaking a perfectly good film made less than 30 odd years ago? Put simply, it's because Hollywood has run out of ideas. Why waste effort trying to create something new when it can simply rehash superb older movies and create garbage.For all you people out there who've never seen the original I urge you to. It's a wonderful and powerful film with a truly exciting and surprising ending, which if you don't know will come as a startling shock.I saw this 2001 abomination when it first opened I was hoping that perhaps Burton might be able to do something with it - sadly, Burton did. He took a fantastic film and turned it into a turkey, filling it with tedium, nonsense, overblown effects and Walhberg. It's so obviously a film made by committee - 'we can't have the humans silent! We need a sexy, strong female freedom fighter, we need massive war! We need sexy female apes! And we need to out-shock the original film's ending with an ending so shocking, the audience will leave their seats shocked by the shocking revelation of it all!' Boy, was I shocked.There's so much wrong with this film I'm not going to even try.Don't waste your time with this, don't waste your money.It was shown on TV recently and I thought I'd give it another go and work out when it goes off the rails. Actually it's not difficult to spot. It's happens just after the main credits have finished rolling.I'm surprised the entire film isn't just listed in the goof list.Goof - the entire film.Avoid and save a precious couple of hours of your life. Because when you're lying on your death bed wishing you had a few more hours of life left, you're gonna wish you hadn't wasted them with this trash. I know I am.

The movie was great, but not as great as the original Planet of the apes which was made in 1968. There are a few reasons why I did not find this film more interesting than the original: number 1, if the humans were mute and the apes hated them more, the movie would've been great because there is more conflict, number 2, Cornelius and Zira did not appear and I liked them because they were good actors in the original and in the second Apes saga and the last, but not least, there was no reason to remake the Planet of the apes, I mean, of course it's an entirely different generation and kids are curious of why they want to remake it, just to let them know that there was an original movie of the Apes in the late 60's. But, there was no reason to do a remake of the apes because the original movie was a huge success.My rating: 5 out of 10 stars

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies I have ever seen!!!
reviews.content:
In case you can't tell from my one line summary, I really thought this movie was a terrible waste of my time and money. Unfortunately, my husband wanted to see this, so I went along to be polite.If you love science fiction, you will hate this movie.  If you hate science fiction, you will REALLY hate this movie even more(if that is possible). Let's see, what what missing from this movie?  Character development, interesting dialog, interesting plot , good acting, character motivation, an ending that made sense...I could go on, but you get the idea. 
Obviously, this was a blatant attempt to cash in on the original (and vastly superior!) original Planet of the Apes. My suggestion, don't see this movie, don't even rent it when it comes out on video.  Rent or buy the original movie, and save yourself some wasted time and money.  One other comment, Mark Wahlberg might want to go back to singing for a living, 'cause he can't act to save his life!!!

reviews.review_title: So bad that it's kinda good
reviews.content:
Tim Burton is obviously a B-Movie fanatic.  I bet he has Roger Corman's entire collection.  Why else would he make a good film about a terrible filmmaker (Ed Wood)?  Why else would he make his own B-movie contribution (Mars Attacks), and why else would he remake the most famous B-movie EVER? 
Well I will say one thing; Burton is true to the genre.  What we have with Planet of the Apes is a somewhat diverting, overbudgeted, ridiculously scripted and acted movie.  However the worst part of this movie is not anything inside the movie.  It was the promotion.  This movie looked like a serious sci-fi attempt to succeed where the old version ridiculously (and entertaingly) failed.  But Tim Burton is unfortunately too true to the original.  Sure the make-up and special effects were cool, but there was nothing truly spectacular.  There were no moments where the audience was left in awe.  The battle sequences were huge disappointments and there was no real conflict set up anywhere.  It seemed that the screenwriters tried too hard not to let the movie drag and subsequently there was no tension or catharsis at the end.  The enormous cast is given criminally little to do.  Especially Tim Roth.  Yes the same Tim Roth that a few years ago created the deliciously evil Archibald Cunningham in Rob Roy is wasted.  His character Thane does nothing but snarl, growl, and bare his teeth.  There are attempts to make him human, but the script keeps the character so flat that the audience doesn't hate him, they just think he is annoying.  Luckily Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, and Paul Giamatti are all given a little more to do, but none of them are really compelling.  As for Whalburg, I can't find a thing to say about him, which means he did his job, but he didn't necessarily shine.  So the characters are flat, there is no dramatic tension and no catharsis, save at the very end when you find yourself laughing hysterically at how incredibly bad this movie is.  And then you realize that Burton is laughing too.  He meant the movie to be bad.  his tongue is planted firmly in his cheek.  And then you think maybe just maybe it's not so bad at all.
But while this movie succeds in being good by being bad, it falls way short of greatness.  You may be entertained, but I guarantee you will be disappointed.  5/10

reviews.review_title: Tim How Did it All go Wrong - Stick to Gothic 'Horror'
reviews.content: Oh dear, I had such high hopes for this film.At first I was worried when I heard that 'Planet of the Apes' was to be re-made. It all seemed like a rather cheap (well not if the budget is $100m) attempt at a 'sure-fire' summer blockbuster - but on hearing that Tim Burton was to directed I began to look forward to seeing the finished product. After all wasn't this the man who had brought us Edward Scissorhands, Sleep Hollow and BeetleJuice.But after seeing the film all I can say is stick to gothic horror Tim. It doesn't engage at any a level, its not exciting, not at all interesting, predictable and worst of all the shock ending makes no real sense. It does look 'authentic' and the make-up was first class with Tim Roth and Helen Bonham Carter doing their best to kick some life in a hack script. But with little success - a dead dog (or ape in this case) is still a dead dog. One of the worst of the Summer 2001 blockbusters.

I saw this movie and I was completely blown away! I love the first films and when i heard they where making a re-make I was happy. Not that the original needed one but it was nice to see yet another "ape" adventure! This one has more action than the original, The casting was good and the score was amazing! The ape make upp was way more realistic than the first films. But one thing kept bugging me. The ape voices! In the original they all had perfect voices for the apes but in this one its a little bit off. Maybe I just watched the old ones to much, But still. The ape society was more advanced this time around (not in electricity and such but when you watch the movie you'll know what I mean.) The story is very similiar to Battlefield Earth now that I think about it. Very. But it is still an awesome must see action movie!

Planet of the Apes is missing the comedy and the edge of Tim Burton's other films.  Though stranded on a strange world, Leo Davidson lacks the outsider quality of other Burton heroes like Edward Scissorhands, Ed Wood, or Lydia Deitz (Beetlejuice).  Similarly the comedy seems wedged in, rather than forming an integral part of the story, as it does in the likes of Mars Attacks or Ed Wood.It is really only the performance of Tim Roth that redeems this picture. He has never really had a reputation for being a physical actor but here he shows himself to be up with the Oldmans and the Nicholsons.  It would have been good to see someone more animated than Mark Wahlberg in the Davidson role.

Once again it is summer and the big blockbuster movies come out and they all stink such as Jurassic Park 3. (Which you can read my comment on if you want.) But this is not a bad movie. This is a great movie. Mark Wahlberg does a terrific job and so does the whole cast. It is incredibly interesting how it is made. Now since I am only a thirteen year old boy I have not seen the original but the person I saw this with says that they are incredibly different and it is hard to compare this and the 1968 version. When I heard a few years ago that they are making a remake for Planet of the Apes  i didn't think that it was going to be very good and I already knew it would be very hard to make with just the apes and at the end there is over a couple hundred apes. They had put in an extrordinary amount just when they had put the names up at the beginning. Although it is a good movie it is also confusing at the end. I won't ruin it for you but be prepared to use your brain in the last few minutes. Well it is a very good movie and I hope you found it as entertaining as I did.

reviews.review_title: Don't waste your time or your money.
reviews.content: Tim Burton, Mark Wahlberg, Tim Roth - could it be that bad??  Yes!!  Its that bad and worse.  Don't waste your time or your money.  I did not expect much but thought I would at least be somewhat entertained.  I was wrong. This movie is boring and stupid.  The same things seemed to be happening repeatedly and pointlessly.  Roth's was the only part that had any kind of emotion or character.  On the surface there should have been tension in the plot but none whatsoever was conveyed.  The dullness of the characters and even the so-called action scenes, was astounding.  There is no mystery about the ending of the film and it would be another waste of time to try to decipher one.  I suppose it would have been an even worse film if there had been no "surprise" at the conclusion - but I'm not so sure.  I think the end just added another note of idiocy.  Its difficult to understand why any critic would ever recommend this film.

reviews.review_title: Got To See Again And Again!
reviews.content: 2nd night the movie opened, i went to the drive-in (along with Kiss Of The Dragon) and watched it with a good friend.  We both thought the movie was awsome.  He had already seen the older Planet Of The Apes films and stuff, but all I knew about it was Talking Apes Controlling Humans, but it is so much more.  I would love to tell you all about but I don't want to give it all away.  Everyone "BOW YOUR HEADS!" cause you MUST see this movie, and go see it again.  See it till you're eyes bleed.  The make-up makes the actors really look like monkeys ("No! We Are APES!")  It really is amazing, but don't take my word for it, go see it for yourself! Again & Again & Again & Again...Plus, go see it again, haha

This movie is not boring, it is entertaining indeed, but that is all there is at it. There is no tension, no suspense, the relationships are empty and not worked out and even the main theme (where do the apes come from and how did they get in charge?) is hardly worked out at all. In short, I wonder why this movie has been made at all. There was an older -better- one already. Why had this one been added? Of course, special effects are better now, but that is no reason for a new version. The makers did not use the challenge to give the movie the tension and suspense it really needs. They did add some -misplaced- humor, which really almost makes the film a kind of cartoon.Where is the time when SF films were full of suspense? "Alien" is an example, although that one has a bit too much of suspense. But was Tim Burton not able to make something better of it? In that case he should restrict himself to animated movies, like "The Nightmare Before Christmas", which was brilliant.

reviews.review_title: Couple of Monkeys have been written this to
reviews.content: This is bad, I cant even find one part in this movie that I actually liked , I think its stupid mostly , it was also only one female monkey and she had makeup ,,, come on.

Went to the sneak preview on South Beach tonight (Thursday 07/26/01).  Do NOT listen to anyone reviewing this movie that tries to tell you the ending. This version remembers its earlier incarnations so the mythology continues. The special effects and music are excellent.  The story is new with plenty of original twists that make this an exciting movie to the very end.  "The Planet of the Apes" should make the dinosaurs of Jurassic Park extinct once more.  RULE THE PLANET.

It's not often that I find a movie that I literally wanted to walk out of during the film.  This movie just happens to be one of those movies.  Mark Walhberg was not the cause of this movie to stink, nor was it the acting in general.  I liked the acting and the special effects.  However, the story and script should never had made it past the producers.  In fact, I am surprised the ink in the pen wanted to write it out.  This whole story does nothing but tarnish the original movies good name.  I literally, as soon as I left the cinema went and rented the original Planet of the Apes to wash the bad taste this one left in my mouth.Let's compare the new movie to the old;Actors: Charlton Heston & Mark WalhbergWhile Hestons brand of acting may not appeal to all, it IS brilliant acting. Mark Walhberg is an up and coming star, this is true, but for him to rise to the level that Heston sits upon, Mark is going to have to start looking for some seriously good scripts and take some more acting lessons, maybe even from Heston himself.  ADVANTAGE: OriginalSupporting Ape Cast Old & Supporting Ape Cast NewApes are Apes but there are aspects from both the new and old films that I liked.  The Original movie had Dr.Zira and Dr.Cornelius and who could forget Dr.Zaius, who were all pretty great characters which added a lot of character interaction and development for Hestons character(Taylor). While the new movie has Ari? An Ape with a serious case of the hots for Walhbergs character(Leo).  ADVANTAGE: OriginalSupporting Human Cast Old & Supporting Human Cast NewBased on the fact that the original only had Linda Harrison as Nova, I have to give the advantage for this class to the new movie.  ADVANTAGE: New MovieSpecial Effects:While the old has some fantastic sites where they shot the film, we do have to give the new movie the advantage in the special effects department. The only thing I really did not like where the Gorillas that were leaping distances of 30 or so feet.  Advantage: New MovieStory:Well this is the big kahuna.  The old movie had an amazing script.  The new movie was geared too much towards quick action where the old movie was a lot of character development with enough action to keep it interesting.  After watching the new movie there were definite aspects that I really would have liked to see in the old movie.  Such as the fact that the Apes were using primitive weaponry.  Makes sense.  Also they lived in the trees, again.. makes sense.   I was very dissappointed when the humans in the new movie opened their mouths and could speak perfect english.  WOW, it's actually very  difficult to see, at least in my point of view, how the apes could regard humans, that can speak just as eloquent english as they.. AS SAVAGES. Or question whether or not they have souls??  Hello?!?!  I thought the whole reason they were "savages" was because they could not be taught, were stupid and were almost neanderthalic in behavior.  What I saw in the new movie was an excuse to have at least a few more characters for Walhberg to talk to since they did not have the character interacton with the Apes. I liked the idea or Thade.. but he was just a tad bit too insane for my liking, then again, maybe there just wasn't enough character developement for me to like him.  Overall.. ADVANTAGE: Original
In short, this movie is a waste of time, don't see it, don't rent it, don't buy it.  I give it 4 thumbs down

reviews.review_title: I have, with trouble, figured out the ending to this movie!
reviews.content: Okay, this would be easier if you all knew about time paradoxes like in Star Trek.  Don't stop reading because I mention Star Trek.  Here goes: (One thing you have to know first, when Mark goes through this storm in space, he thinks he is taken to another planet, when he is really taken to another time on his). If you remember, when he was crash-landing on the "other planet" (Earth), his digital calendar was moving the years ahead very quickly.  He was going into the future.  The space-station he came from was pulled in too but not at the same time as him.  The space-station got pulled into a time 1,000's of years before him.  That space-station was carrying many genetically enhanced chimps.  When that station landed (crashed), the apes got out, killed the humans and populated the planet.  Since, Mark was sent to a time ahead of that, the apes had already evolved (genetically enhanced).  So, they evolved.  Remember, this is Earth.  Remember that at the end when Mark locks the General in that room he doesn't kill him.  So, after Mark leaves to go back to what he thinks is his planet, but is really another time, the General escapes and still has his armies so he exterminates the humans.  Mark goes through the time portal and really instead of going to what he thinks is Earth, he goes ahead in time even farther, to where the apes have evolved into a society like ours.  The statue (Abraham Lincoln) is of the General because he saved the planet for the apes (by exterminating the humans).

I was captured for a moment, perhaps two.  The plotline was marginal.  In a nutshell, I nodded off a few times.  You think Burton would have researched apes a little more behaviorly...one would think jumping around was the primary emotional response of apes.  Get real...and please no sequel...much rather see the intelligent dolphin and apes of the Uplift War saga made into film.

reviews.review_title: Another Disappointment in a Summer Replete With Mediocrity
reviews.content: Does anyone else out there fondly remember summers past when James Cameron would wow us with intelligent action flicks like "True Lies" or "Terminator 2," or Steven Spielberg would show us the true measure of his genius with an Indiana Jones adventure or the original "Jurassic Park"?  Much to my dismay, those days are long gone."The Mummy Returns" was an exercise in overkill.  "Pearl Harbor" was a tedious bore.  "Tomb Raider" and "Swordfish" were both so thoroughly awful they don't even merit discussion.  Spielberg's "A.I." was a pretentious mish-mash of vague concepts.  And you know things are bad when the usually reliable Disney delivers an uninspired dud like "Atlantis: The Lost Empire." Only slightly better were "The Score" (buoyed by its actors) and "Jurassic Park III," whose makers were wise enough to give us only 90 minutes of a rapidly tiring novelty.Which brings us to this disgrace.  While I am not a huge fan of the original, I am sure this version is sure to enrage those who are.  The writers of "Planet of the Apes" have substituted a series of lame jokes and puns for an actual plot, while subjecting us to a bunch of bland, one-dimensional characters and familiar action sequences.  The incessant screeching and growling of the apes stands as the most annoying redundancy in a film since the depth charges of "U-571."  Only the superb make-up by Rick Baker et al. make this film worthy of a one-time viewing.Finally, some thoughts on the director, Tim Burton.  For the life of me I cannot figure out why so many people adore his work.  Yes, I love "Pee-Wee's Big Adventure," and the original "Batman," while no masterpiece, is one of the best comic book movies to date.  But his track record of late is atrocious:  "Sleepy Hollow" was awful, and until I saw "Mars Attacks!" I never thought I'd see Jack Nicholson give a truly bad performance in a film. I will give "Beetlejuice" full marks for comedic value and originality, but "Edward Scissorhands" is a cheesy sentimentalist abomination.I find it interesting that "Ed Wood," far and away Burton's best film, is the one least remembered or mentioned by his legions of acolytes.  The talent of which he is capable shines through that film, but it appears he has sacrificed it for the allure of big-budget bombast like "Planet of the Apes."  Chalk Mr. Burton up as another casualty of Hollywood's war on artistic filmmaking.

reviews.review_title: Unlike the original which is good.... but...
reviews.content: but it's a very weak story with unremarkable special effects and full of gaping holes.  Which is bad.  Very very bad.I went in expecting a good movie that would live up to the name of the franchise, despite the presence of Burton in the director's chair.I cannot believe a story resembling an early draft and not much more than a comedy sketch in someone else's production would have received final approval and the go-ahead by an entire studio.When it's available on video (DVD), watch this along with the original 1968 Apes.  If you care for nothing more than MTV special effects, maybe you'll come away with a distaste for the original.  But if you value any type of consistency and plausible story, in an implausible world, then the newest Apes movie will leave you wanting a lot more.
