The scene where the little human girl is pried away from her mother to be made a pet is something anyone considering taking a primate as a pet should see. And the line about getting rid of her before she hits puberty because "one thing you don't want in your house is a human teenager" is apt on several levels.I liked the humor in this film, too.  The comic relief of the human trader and the human sayings the apes used were good.  And the best bit of humor was achieved through irony in the cameo part played by Charleton Heston. Heston, a known NRA lacky, portrays an elderly Ape who cautions his son to be wary of the humans because they possess the power of dangerous technology; he holds a gun in his hands and declares it the root of human evil.  That was masterful!So, overall this film was a joy to watch.  From good jokes and clever irony to a plausible plot and interesting characters and conflict, this movie had it all.  I will see it again and again, just to take in all the details of the apes' world.  I will, however, not watch the final two minutes, because I think the obligatory Hollywood ending spoils an otherwise great film. It's still better than most movies made today, but Burton's remake would have been better without the ending.  As I said before, though, I forgive him for it, and I thank him for making a movie in accord with primatology.(Spoiler alert)One side note about the movie... one other problem with the believablity was created by a simple fact of biology that some people may not be aware of.  At the end of the movie when Leo's chimp lands and exits his spacecraft, it is obvious that he is much smaller than the "evolved" chimps, and that creats a visual inconsistency.  That is because that chimp, as with all chimps used in films and TV shows, is a very young ape, probably just four or five years old.  An adult chimp is close to the size of a small adult human and would have looked much better.  However, adult chimps are not used because they are so large, agressive, and strong.  An adult chimp is easily three times as strong as an adult human, has large canine teeth, and could kill a man in a few seconds.  So the necessity of using an immature chimp in the role is evident, and we can forgive the movie that small inconsistency as well.

reviews.review_title: Looks like we're not in Kansas anymore, Toto!
reviews.content:
SPOILERS!!! Watch the movie.  Here, there is NO mention of Earth, America, etc. Therefore, wherever "here" is, it certainly is NOT Earth.  An alternate Earth?  Another planet altogether?  Maybe.  But this is pure silliness and irrelevant.  I mean, if this was Earth, I'd take an interest and enjoy it more.  But alas, it isn't, so who cares??  I don't.  Why care about humans or apes or even horses??  I say kill em all.  Ravage the land and destroy all that exists.  I mean, this is supposed to be another planet, right?
Planet of the Apes is SO much different from the original.  Of course it is supposed to be!!  But this has become altogether changed for the worst.  I don't see how I am made to care.  Tim Burton has gotten us to another world where we DO NOT sympathize nor feel for.  IF apes that talk land on Earth and threaten human existance, that'd be so cool and I'd care.  Charlton Heston landed on future Earth and I cared as well.I gave this movie a 3.  3 based on Special effects and AWESOME music.-4 on story and -1 on acting.  6 for directing and 9 for music.  9 for action sequence and -5 for credibility.  This is a pure Hollywood popcorn movie so many people love/hate.  I personally love these kinds of movie, but with a Superior version done so many years ago, I say this was done in utter disgrace and disappointment. Come on, does anybody actually care about the humans in this flick???

This movie is Tim Burton. There is no use comparing it to the original. Forget the original, for now.There is great special effects and a lot of humor around the edges.
You could tell this was a Burton movie.A few points. Wahlburg cannot fly, or at least cannot land well. The plot devices to set up the whole time line twist don't work. Don't even try to figure them out. Just watch the movie and enjoy the (over) acting.Wahlburg's character is an idiot. Roth's character is too overdone. Bonham-Carter was fun to watch.Tim Burton makes a great fantasy movie. Reality takes a back seat. Enjoy.

I was hoping I would enjoy this film and I did!!!!Planet of the Apes really is a wonderful and engrossing film to watch. It has a unique look throughout, with some wonderful and vast sets and locations. The scenery is always slightly different, and that makes it interesting to look at.The conversations between the characters are involving, entertaining and in places even charming. There is some very amusing humour in there as well, nothing hilarious, but enough to get a laugh from the audience.... "There's nothing you want around your house LESS than a human teenager" for example, or the Ape with false teeth!The plot is also good. And to a certain extent keep you wondering what will happen next. Mark Whalberg is excellent as the main character. He's just the type you want in a film like this. Lets face it, you wouldn't want Sylvester Stallone or some other muscle bound 'Conan' type bloke down there. But Whalberg makes a very believable main character. General Thade's character is fantastic throughout also.Finally, you know throughout that SOMETHING will happen at the end. It was inevitable. And what IS at the end was very satisfying, hard to get your head around, but really cool none the less.And anyone who thinks that your a shallow individual for thinking that a 're-make' (or re-imaging) is good, is totally wrong. Planet of the Apes is a fine film that entertains throughout and doesn't disappoint anywhere......... and thats ALL anyone can ask for!

reviews.review_title: Better than a sharp stick in the eye
reviews.content:
Okay, I enjoyed this film and in spite of a not-so-good script, I think it DID make a small attempt a social commentary at times. From what I understand, the first movie was a commentary about race relations and the sort, but I think this movie did try to cover animal rights to a degree (please, if you desire, email me at let me know if you agree or disagree and why). There were plot holes ****SPOILER (kinda)****** Where did they get those horses, were they already on the planet and if so, why did they look like earth horses? Or, were they carried on the ship. If so, where? There didn't seem to be enough room for horses. My semi-theory is that perhaps there were horse embreyos or something, though I am not sure where they were "grown" into maturity. Also, and this really doesn't take TOO much thought, but if I recall that it was mentioned that ALL the humans died when the ship crashed, obviously, they didn't ALL die, or else there wouldn't be humans on the planet, but anyway..it was silly. ******SPOILER END*****Finally, the end confused me, though I might have missed something. *ONE MORE SPOILER** Was he on earth at the end, if so, how did Thade influence earth? What other options are there? I read that he really didn't return to earth, but went back to the same planet later in time, but this only makes partial sense, I mean, we were led to believe that everything was cool with humans and apes, so what was up with that?**Spoiler end***
Anyway, this movie was fun, and I enjoyed it in spite of all the problems I had with the plot. The make up was cool and Tim Roth was super! I give it 7 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Can you be entertained watching a terrible movie?
reviews.content: I am not quite sure how, but watching the worst movie of the summer was not a complete waste of time.  It has been a while since I saw a movie where the audience actually groaned and mocked the movie while it was playing.  The movie is so poorly written that it should have insulted each one of us watching but the Tim Burton visuals do help pass the time quickly.  We were stuck there so we made do, don't waste your money and you will be ahead of the game.

reviews.review_title: Get your hands off me, you damn dirty human!
reviews.content: Tim Burton has always been an atmosphere artist, and in Apes he does an excellent job.  The scenery is compelling, and the ape costumes are fantastic!  There is a cloud to that silver lining.  It's called, character development.  He does a below average job portraying Wahlberg's character, the star of the film.  Other characters get slightly better treatment, but what about the kid who Wahlberg's character saves as the ape army attacks? Almost no background, just a couple of shots of him being insubordinate to Wahlberg, a person that the humans on the planet are in awe of.  Would a kid really be that brash?The story is good, the acting is fine, the scenery is superb.  The climax of the film is great, though I won't spoil it for anyone who hasn't seen it. However, one thing can always ruin a good movie: a bad ending.  Let me just say I think Mr. Burton wanted to see apes in police squad cars and ape tourists.  The last five minutes ruin an otherwise very good summer flick.

This is not a remake as Tim Burton states it is more of an update
The original was good but as the ending is so well known it spoils it allot cos you know where the hero is all along.  But on the other hand it does have it's advantages over the new Tim Burton version.
In the original version, Humans are treated like animals because they can't speak, and the apes are being like humans cos they have the ability to speak.  And it shocks the apes when they finally hear one man speak.
So there's a conflict in the ape kingdom because the scientists see the human more than just an animal, whilst the others do not want to know and still prefer to think humans are still animals.Where as in the remake, the humans and apes can speak yet they are treated as slaves and also as animals (which contradicts itself in a big way).
With slavery- there's always pressure groups and other organisations that will try to abolish slavery no matter how different they are, so I couldn't understand why an entire race would hate humans-for no reasons other than they are humans- and only one person who sees them as something more than.
************************************************************************ ***************************WARNING SPOILER ALERT************************ ************************************************************************I thought finding out who Calima really was was a dead rip off to Star Trek: The Motion Picture.  Where Kirk finds out who V'ger(the creator the alien race was searching for) is buy scrubbing the dirt away the name V'ger, and finding out that it's actually Voyager.  So Calima when Mark scrubs the rest of the dust away was actually Caution Live Animals (And there was me thinking that Calima was homage to Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom).I can't understand why people are confused about the ending to Tim Burtons remake.  What Tim Burton is trying to say, is that as Darwin's evolution tells us, we are direct descendants from apes, now that Mark and his scientist friends, they have tampered with the evolution process, and now the apes are direct descendants from humans.  And the statue Mark sees isn't Thade or anyone else but An "Ape"briaham Lincoln (I know corny joke).Another thing is that according to the (TWIST) ending he was on earth all along so therefore where did all those people come from in the ape world? Are they cave people if so how can they speak English perfectly well?  If they are on a different planet, are we supposed to put our brains in to Star Trek gear and believe that everyone in the universe speaks English?******OVERALL VIEW OF THE FILM ((((NO SPOILER))))******On entertainment value it is good, but if you're looking for a Tim Burton film- you won't find it here,There's none of his trademarks- the humour is more Hollywood than Tim Burton, and there's nothing strange, or unusual, or magical, that you get when your watching a Tim Burton movie, it's all Hollywood and no Tim.Floyd_Dylan 2001 (review 1)

reviews.review_title: "Apes" is a fun movie, but not as deep as original.
reviews.content: Even though this version did not try to be as thought provoking as the original, I enjoyed it as an action-adventure version of  basically the same story. The makeup by Rick Baker is amazing and the CGI effects are used well. You can hardly tell they're there at all. Tim Roth practically steals the show as General Thade. My quibbles: Mark Wahlberg wasn't the best choice for the lead. Burton should've cast someone a little older, with a little more presence. George Clooney perhaps. The humans being able to speak in this version  (as oppossed to the mutes in the original) added nothing to the story as they really had nothing interesting to say. All in all, a fun time at the movies. Peace.

reviews.review_title: I fell asleep... effects without a movie!
reviews.content: while watching this piece of crap! The Day after, I saw a 1min Trailer - that one minute included all, ALL what was at least not boring to watch...so don't waste money or time on this one, get the original, it's much better though the effects might not be up to date...

The Movie Is Not Bad And Also It Is Not A Great One Either. The Plot Is Engaging And Entertaining But Some Of The Things Didnt Make Sense. The Production Design Is Great. The CGI Was Good. The Acting Was Mediocre. The Characters Are Poorly Written And Underdeveloped. The Ending Is Dissapointing. Except Leo, Most Of The Characters Are Forgettable. I Liked The Pacing And Cinematography. The Editing is Good. The Sound Track is Easily Forgatable.

Finally saw this film recently.  I was expecting another duplicate of Planet Of The Apes '68 with hyped-up special effects and celebrity actors (well it did, but they where apes).  Acting was ok, Wahlberg was not that great (loosen up man, it's just a movie), but found Tim Roth, Paul Giamatti, and Carter to be very entertaining.  We got a completely stand-alone movie that went in a different direction than the other five films with the same namesake (or maybe not, we may see...).  I can see where alot of people may not like this movie. For one, I think too many people went into the movie thinking it was going to be more closely related to previous films, from what I understand they where not even going to call it "Planet Of The Apes". Overall it is nothing spectacular, a few nice surprises on the way, but equal to most action/sci-fi movies out there nowadays.  As for the ending, come on people, not every single big-budget movie has to have a happy, close-minded, all mysteries solved ending.  It's refreshing to have a thought-provoking ending.  Although, I did find that the apes driving cars and all that a little awkward looking, not because they are apes, but something just did not look right, and somehow if this whole thing was supposed to be a two-way time travel deal and the apes took over years and years ago, I would think that cars, buildings, and so on would look slightly different, then again maybe they took over a few years before he got there in the end, who knows?  In most cases, sequels can kill a series of movies, but in this case I think it can only get better if written and directed correctly.  One thing is for sure, I am sure they could get the audience and sales for a second movie just based on people wanting a resolution to that ending!  I got stuck watching the crappy pan & scan version and to me the shots where framed way to contrived for a movie like this, then again maybe I just need to see the widescreen version.  Overall I gave this a 7 out of 10

reviews.review_title: One of the best sci-fi movie......
reviews.content: One of the best sci-fi movie tha i ever seen. Movie about 3 astronauts that land some where in the galaxy after 2000 years that they leave earth,and descover planet of apes and humans are primitive like apes in our days. this movie have a moral message, I look at this movie like aprotest against nukleer bombs and war when in the end of the movie "Taylor" say "they finely do it" he meens that finely people destroy them self whit they bombs and primitive animals [apes] conquest the earth. This movie have a big problem : "Taylor" playd by Charlton Heston come to earth and belive all movie that is not earth......so hove apes speeke english ??? the biggest problem wit this movie is if some one speeks so it will be only english even in out space.... and when "taylor" comes to city of apes is normal that they speeks english ---in other planet---

If you want to see another example of Hollywood dumbing down cinema, then please watch this film.The film completely misses all of the story that made the original compelling. What happened to the compelling points of the original, such as:Relegion vs Science ?Evolution ?Animal Cruelty ?Ethics of Zoo's ?Animal Experiments ?Racism?All of these wonderful points (and more) of the original are left out of the movie, to make way for an awful script, predictable chase and fight sequences, and one awful ending.SPOILER!!!!!!!!!!!Explain to me this, we leap forward in time, to where General Thade etc are, and then, at the end of the movie, leap back again.Yet, at the whitehouse, there is a General Thade statue, and the earth is ruled by apes , and yet, at that point in time, General Thade had not even existed!Whether you take it that the Ape planet was earth or not, the time sequencing of events is a paradox, and completely naff.I loved the first movie, and was hoping that this new version would bring in new arguments (such as genetics and DNA, discussed by another posting here), and yet all we get is another dumbed down picture.Hollywood is showing a contempt for its history, and for the viewing public.A big, big shame.

I just wonder how is it possible to dispense so many money to make such a pour film. Except the apes everything has no interest in this movie and we can't say that it is better than the first version of 1968. Just one thing : if you want to laugh just go and see the five last minutes (I don't want to say anything more).

reviews.review_title: good to look at, script not so great, some spoilers
reviews.content: Planet of the Apes was not a brilliant movie, and nowhere near as good as the original.  Tim Roth completely over-did the whole husky-voiced bad guy thing, Helena Bonham-Carter was no more than annoying, and Estella Warren couldn't act to save her life.  However, Mark Wahlberg gave a good, solid & good-looking performance and he makes it rate 10/10.

First I'd like to say that I really enjoyed this movie and Mark Wahlberg's performance in particular.Many people have wondered if there will be a sequel, well I did a google search and found this article entitled "No Apes sequel, says Burton": http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1496974.stm If this article is true, then someone other than Tim Burton would be directing it. Here we are 5 years later and still no sequel. It's unfortunate, because amidst all of the speculation about the meaning of the ending - it certainly screams SEQUEL! Another observation - a lot of people seem to think the ape planet that Leo crashes on (in beginning of the movie) is Earth. But Tim Burton's ape planet has two moons - it can't be Earth. However, the planet he crashes on in the end of the movie is Earth - it has one moon and the correct continents.

I have no idea how people could bash a movie like this. Movies like these (ESPECIALLY Sci-Fi movies) are very rare, and i must admit, when I was walking into the theatre, I thought this was going to be an awful movie ripping off the previous "Planet of the Apes". I was so wrong.The movie starts off with Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) in a USAF Starbase that experiences a strange nebula. The captain sends out one of Leo's monkeys to explore the nebula, but they lose contact with the monkey. Leo jumps in another spaceship and goes looking for the monkey (Which was very strange in the beginning, but they had to get him on the planet somehow, I guess). When he gets trapped in the nebula, he goes forward in time and lands on an alien planet (Unlike the previous movie, where Leo lands on a futuristic earth). He encounters a group of humans who are running from the apes. Leo is very confused, which becomes a major point for the beginning of the movie.The film is a direct remake from the original, but is much darker, thanks to the wonderful directing of Tim Burton. He captured the atmosphere from the previous film perfectly, but he also added a bit of an extra touch by making the apes seem much more menacing. The performances aren't Oscar-worthy, but they aren't bad (Including Mark Wahlberg, who I think was always a good actor since his starring role in the movie "Boogie Nights), and the make-up by Rick Baker is sure to get him an Academy Award. The music by Danny Elfman is amazing (Including the opening theme, which in my opinion is probably one of my top 5 themes) and it perfectly captures the atmosphere in the movie. But probably the most controversial point in the movie is the ending. It was either you understood it, or you didn't. Luckily, I was one of the people that understood it, and it almost made the movie for me. But without spoiling any of the ending, let me just say this: It's very sequel-friendly (Which in my case is a good thing)Review: ****1/2 / *****

What a waste. The original idea was so interesting but got spoiled by this terrible re-make. It takes more than an heroic USAF officer to save the audience from boredom. I was expecting much more besides the special effects. A stunning end for instance?... please, someone explain the last scene! A personal note to Mark Wahlberg. Here is a tip for your new movie: take a breath and stop panting for two hours even when there is nothing exciting on sight!

reviews.review_title: Talk about having a monkey on your back..
reviews.content: Tim Burton delivers once again.  When talk first began about an update for "Planet of the Apes" I was taken back when it was first reported that Arnold "The Terminator" Schwartzenegger was tapped to play the lead in the James Cameron directed film.  Thank all that is wholly that Burton took over. Could anyone really see Arnold delivering such lines as "get your stinking hands off me you damned dirty ape!" Talk about your comedy films.Burton, who is probably best known for his dark and mysterious works such as "Batman" (the first one and only really worthy one) and "Sleepy Hollow", has scored once again with his retelling of "Planet of the Apes"  By showing a certain reverence to the original ( the above referenced line by Heston is now spoken by one of the apes ) as well as certain character names (Nova for one) he has given it an original twist and (although I must admit a somewhat confusing) ending that will have people talking in the breakroom for days about it.The actors, story all of it is first class and well worth the admission price.  Remember, these aren't your 1968 apes.  Burton has them behaving less human and more ape-like, complete with hanging off the ceiling and grunts and squeals.  But then again, when a director like Tim Burton takes on a project as daunting as "Planet of the Apes" he must feel the pressure of having the monkey on his back.This is two hours of make believe that will do just that -- make you believe.  enjoy.

There was absolutely NOTHING good about this movie. It was predictable, and cliche ridden. In the original, Heston's character could speak when no one else could....the suspense built waiting for him to speakout & show that he was more advanced than the other humans. In the remake, ALL the humans can speak, and there's nothing that differeniates Wahlberg's character from the others. The story was terrible, to say the least. People say "oh, but the special effects were great". Well that may be true, but don't you need a story to go along with it? Is this what the movie going public has become? And, is it too much to ask for some acting to be thrown in there, too? Lastly, where did that blonde get the lipstick she wore throughout the movie? I knew going into this film that it wouldn't hold water compared to the original, but this was just an all around bad movie.

I just got home from seeing this movie. I went in not expecting much, but boy did I get a surprise. This movie very definitely does the original justice, and then some. Though the movie was at times predictable, the story was rather original and very entertaining. Throw in Estella Warren in a loincloth, and we have a winner. :-) I enjoyed it right up until the end, then they lost me. I didn't get it. I'll probably spend the rest of the day trying to reconcile how the story got from point A to point B.

Beware! Spoilers for those who have not seen the movie! I'll just question one glaring plot flaw I have not yet read, before I offer a possible ending to the movie. In discovering the 'mayday' message on the Oberon where Leo finds that he has unwittingly caused all the events etc. We hear the female animal/chimp handler stating that the monkeys have started killing them all. If this were the case, how could humans have eventually out - populated the planet 4 -1? With this and the horses (and certain aspects of the ape civilization) these to me are the major let downs in the story. I quite liked the time paradox angle. And remakes will always be viewed with scepticism by a generation old enough to have enjoyed an original.I watched it without any plot info on purpose (so it could unravel honestly and maybe I could enjoy it more) Anyway, I mostly did enjoyed it until the end then I got the impression there was enough plot for a sequel jammed into the last 15 mins. So if I sum up a few of the plot twists: Apes are descendants of our genetically engineered space cadets. They are deeply religious - except for Thades' bloodline (was his great grandaddy the violent one in the cage they were talking about in the beginning?) Ok we've got that sorted. I think that Leo's character was fairly honestly acted by Wahlberg. He didn't really care about any of the people or apes but just used them to get back to his ship (or what he thought would be his ship).  So if for a minute we agree that he is a selfish individual, and that he has no choice but to rally the human troops or be killed by the approaching ape army even quicker (and ignore all that 'we can do it' crap) Heres my version of the ending: The second pod comes down with his chimp mate onboard (this is ok as we know the cosmic whatever has cause this time displacement) Leo doesnt just walk over to it and start man-handling the 'deity' as I'm sure the Gorilla Commander would have taken him apart. But the Space cadet bounds out into Leos arms in Friendship at least giving the still pumped up ape army something to think about for a minute. General Thade who lets face it is not going to calm down for even Simo himself goes all out to kill Leo as he is obviously threatened by the possible shift of power. The Fighting kicks off again and in the scramble Simo is killed, Thade has to kill his own Commander (who is religious) and Leo makes a run  for the pod and escapes. In his escape into the sky we see the human element being once and for all dealt with by Thade and his now un-opposed command. Leo enters the cosmic anomally again and is ejected on the other side to what he can visibly see is earth (maybe just thinks he is lucky) he chooses america and flies in etc. Then the end could play out as written. I know I've rushed that a bit but at least it would have tied in the twist ending more plausibly. It also keeps with his selfish character, the total ape population of the 'final' planet and with the overall dark tone (Thankyou Mr Burton) of the movie. The overall massage of these films is what B******s we as a species are. So why even attempt a happy ending, and then mess it up even more with a meaning less twist at the last minute?

reviews.review_title: Thank God I saw it for free
reviews.content: Okay, I'm not Matt Drudge, I'm not going to give away the ending.  But I will say this.  If you like movies that FORCE you to make leaps of faith as to what is going on, if you like trying to figure out why a "good" actor like Kris Kristoferson is in the movie for a total of 30 minutes, then this is your movie.  If you know that remakes almost always stink and that your better off trying to get laid in a convent then this movie is not for you. Sorry,  but if you can see it for free like I did, you'd still feel like you've wasted your time.~Q

OK, so loose-canon Mark Wahlberg decides to violate regulations and orders to rescue his monkey friend who was sent into a strange nebulaic disruption (a la Star Trek: Next Generation), and winds up hurled through space and time to a "strange new world" where apes rule.And there begins my sadness.I'm sorry for seeming smarmy, but I would have expected so much better from Tim Burton.  Although direction wasn't the main problem with this film, the writing was 2-dimensional and atrocious to character development.  It relied heavily on apes screaming and tossing humans 20 feet in the air at the drop of a hat (not that I blame them; I would've done the same to Mark based on his wooden performance).  The battle scene was solved with such an element of corniness, the teeny boppers behind me with eyes glued to Mr. Wahlberg actually came to their senses and laughed.  This movie deserved better craftsmanship of plot vehicles.The only really redeeming thing about this film was a "pretty good considering" performance by Helena Bonham Carter, monkey makeup and all. She found a wry character and an interesting crush on Mark Wahlberg's character, handling everything that she came across with a fair amount of grace.All in all, the movie is worth checking out- once.  And on video.  It ranks higher than "Starship Troopers", but is certainly not the best thing that Tim Burton has laid claim to.

Firstly, I think the original Ape movies are among the finest films ever produced.  The entire series is brilliant and I frequently watch them.  I'm not a big Sci-Fi fan, but those movies are just about the best representation of a mix-and-match between social satire and pure "what if" filmmaking that makes viewers question themselves.But anyways, the new Apes movie is no different.  The only thing that I really have issues with is the fact that some of the characters didn't really serve much purpose.  I don't know if they had all their lines cut out or what, but they don't really do a whole lot for the film.  Even Mark Wahlberg doesn't have a hell of a lot of dialogue.  But the film starts off much different than the first, and continues along that idea.  Most of the same themes are revisited, but skewed a bit.  The cinematography and makeup are both amazing.  This movie lived up to my expectations.  Go see this movie and judge for yourself.  I heard people coming out of the movie and saying that it sucked.  But, they probably have no basis for comparison if they haven't seen the originals.  I would give this movie 9/10.  Nearly perfect.

reviews.review_title: PLANET OF THE PLOTLESS, ANNOYING, UNENJOYABLE PIECE OF GARBAGE
reviews.content: I am growing so very tired of Hollywood and the junk that they have been putting out. This movie certainly was not worth my time or my money. The only thing good about this movie is Danny Elfman's theme and that's it. The make up effects are down right horrible as well as the acting and what little of a screenplay there is is absolutely disgraceful. The ending, which I will not give away so not to ruin it for the poor souls who are still considering seeing this piece of garbage is absolutely pointless and adds nothing to the movie. In fact the ending makes absolutely no sense and feels as though it was a last minute ending that was added on a week before the movie was released. This movie will also be very offensive to a certain minority group. A lot of what I guess Hollywood executives think are funny little inside jokes are actually extrmely racist and serve no purpose in a film like this. Yes the Planet Of The Apes films have always reflected the racial tensions in this country but they certainly never made a joke of it.I think it is time for Richard Zanuck to retire being he hasn't made a good film since Jaws and Tim Burton should stick to making films like Ed Wood which showcased a lot more of his talent than this piece of garbage.

reviews.review_title: What Else Left Besides Makeup and Effect?
reviews.content: The biggest problem in the Planet of the Apes is that there are no deep feelings within the characters. Leo (Mark Wahlberg) does not care for any of human on the planet of the apes but himself. His goal was just get himself out of the planet as soon as possible. The director knows too well that he is not a hero, that's why he decided to add a scene of heroic rescue of a young boy in the movie. But it doesn't help to make him a better character but too obvious of an effort. Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) was a confusing idealistic character that she believes ape and human should be equally live together. But the movie fails to show her feeling when she watches human killing her own kind. Instead of an internal struggle inside her, she just blindly help human beat up her own people. And the third main character, Daena (Estella Warren) she was just a pretty figure follows Leo everywhere until the end. It's not her fault that she couldn't act, it's the movie doesn't give her any chance to act. It was a failure when Leo farewells to Ari and Daena in the end, there's nothing there to drive the audiences to any feeling. It's as if we watch some stranger say goodbyeThey could have brought up much more than this. They could use the scene when Ari heard about how human treat Apes on Earth (lock in the zoo) as an ironic moral in the movie. But they didn't go further Everyone agree that the makeup in this movie is awesome. There's no doubt about that. But beside the makeup, Tim Burton directed nothing shine in this remake of sci-fi classic.Everyone agree that the makeup in this movie is awesome, but beside the makeups, there's nothing shine in this remake of sci-fi classic.HinxLinx

reviews.review_title: A warped plot line wrapped in incredible acting and makeup.
reviews.content:
The film overall was only mediocre but some performances and all the make up jobs were done so well you might think they were apes.The star of the film in my opinion is Tim Roth. He acts the psychopathic homicidal ape perfectly. Even the walk he seems to have perfected. No wonder Quentin Tarantino hires him so much; he works well with twisted characters and plotlines. (Watch Reservoir Dogs if you don't believe me... Mr. Orange)The love triangle of Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and the blond chick with a big chest [i think she was called Deana] (Estelle Warren), is hilarious. Some critics have said that they wished that Davidson and Ari had more of a relationship instead of the blond chick with a big chest and Davidson. This is totally crazy! Have they SEEN THE MOVIE??? The only thing that blond chick with big chest did was kiss Davidson once and look exactly like a blond chick with big chest. She is a token piece in this movie.... The relationship with Ari and Davidson not only involves a kiss but he saves her life more than once, and they even TALK! I think that some critics need to cut back on their drinking!Speaking of blond chick/big chest being the token piece, she is only in the movie because people expect her. They screwed up the ending, so why keep her? But yet again the adolescent male attitudes that every guy keeps hidden SOMEWHERE rear their ugly heads. Look at most of the movies these days, find one that doesn't have a token chick with a big chest? It doesn't seem well. Natural.Well then, the makeup jobs. INSANE! Each of the prosthetics that the actors wore was individual created. Unlike the original movie, every ape has a different face, which is highly expressive and flexible, Kudos to the makeup crew:Rick Baker,   Brigitte Bugayong,  Gabriel De Cunto, Toni G, Teressa Hill, Jamie Kelman,  Patricia Miller (II),  Denise Paulson, Alex Proctor, Robin SlaterI was highly impressed.The directing was impressive as well, timing the movements and brining a vision to life was left up to Tim Burton and yet again he brings the screen to life. Every scene in the film was well thought out and well held together, this was an impressive feat for a remake.Forgive me but the ending of this movie sucked. I wont say more but it did....
Adios

'Planet of the Apes' is yet another example of Tim Burton´s excellent director skills. When Burton gives us a movie we can be sure not to get another Hollywood show of their big special effects. Instead we get a movie where the superb effects are just minor details that support the story´s substance.Burton´s "remake" of 'Planet of the Apes' is as surprising as the first because the story is different. Yet the themes are the same: racism and equality being the most important. Another theme in the movie is the complexity of time travel that Burton deals with in the same way as e.g. ex-Python Terry Gilliam did in '12 Monkeys'.The apes are outstanding e.g. because of their walk and their interactions in general. Another thing I truly love about this movie is that the music score has been kept in the same stile as the score in the original Planet of the Apes.All in all an exceptional movie that is a must.

Tim Burton has shown many things in his life as a filmmaker: a knack for gloomy atmosphere; a real sense of empathy for the lonely and different ones; a wicked sense of humor; he's even shown that he can play by the rules of the studios, delivering not only once but twice, even making a sequel and pulling it off.Sadly, none of that shows in "Planet...". The problem does not lie in the fact that they tamper with the story from the first film. As they've made clear, the producers and director are not trying to remake a classic, but use it (and the book it originated from) as a stepping stone to build the new movie, so their deviations from the original would not be a problem... if they were good.Burton doesn't have a good starting point: the script is very, very bad, your usual Hollywood-esque pastiche of old lines with (supposedly) new parallelisms and not-very-bright pop culture references. All that would be interesting if something happened, along the story, to the characters. Sadly, it is not so: the astronaut, the good apes and the pretty girl remain the same (that is, totally uninteresting) throughout the movie. Even the bad apes are not really changed, as the ending goes. And let's not even start with the inconsistencies...This is by far Burton worse movie ever, light years away from his classics. His trademarks barely show: we don't care about what happens with the characters at all, the sets lack the grandeur that we've learn to love and expect ("Sleepy Hollow" and "Batman" come to mind) and his "wicked sense of humor" is limited to changing classic lines from being spoken by humans to simian mouths.The acting is really bland, too. Mark Wahlberg has proven that he can act. But he wanders through "Planet..." with his best "Keanu-I-don't-know-what-the-heck-is-going-on-Reeves" look on. And Stella Warren... well, she IS pretty. Helena Bonham-Carter is as boring as usual and Tim Roth has lots of fun but is well below some of his best movies.The summing up of all of this is in one word: disappointment. Not from what it is (even at this point the movie can be seen if one has enough popcorn and soda) but from what it could had been with the talent implied. And yes, the make-up is awesome and Heston's cameo is really cool, but somehow they are not sufficient to save a picture from being just another fancy way of wasting your time and your money.

reviews.review_title: So Much Promise Turned To Waste
reviews.content: You know what happens: human crash lands on planet ruled by apes that can talk and think humans are beneath them, human has to fight to survive, twist ending. Blah, Blah, Blah.This new "Planet Of The Apes" is probably the most-hyped and most-anticipated summer release for 2001. You've got extremely dark and stylish director Tim Burton paired back up with scoring buddy Danny Elfman. Cool ape costumes and Marky Mark out in front. How could any of this go wrong you ask? Well, it does.Now, don't get me wrong, I did like this movie. That was until the last ten minutes of the film. The ending is so ridiculous that it cause the rest of the movie to make NO SENSE at all. The ending is terrible and I cannot express enough how much sense it does not make! I'm not going to give anything away, but you aren't missing anything life-changing. The movie was good, except for this contrived and senseless plot twist that is completely tacked-on.Besides the fact that the movie ends up not making any sense after it was on the right track, the musical score, I hear, had to be completely redone mere days before release. So, the new score has no resemblance of Danny Elfman at all. It's your generic action movie score. Thanks, studio executives! That's why you guys collect the money to back the film and you leave the movie-making to the movie makers! What an original concept.I don't need to go into the story or the plot, you know it. The only thing you don't know about is the new ending, which causes the whole movie to be worthless. Oh, and did I mention that there is no resemblance of Tim Burton's style anywhere? Then I'll say it here: nada on the Burton style.I was really, really excited about seeing this movie. I really was. But then the ending made no sense, which I cannot repeat enough, and it all went to hell.

i would just like to say that planet of the apes was a really good movie. the only thing that i did not like about it was the ending but i think that they are thinking of making another one and thats how they decided to end it. oh ya and Mark Wahlberg is really hot!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Tim Roth as the Feral Chihuahua
reviews.content: I REALLY wanted to like this movie.  I'd hoped Tim Burton would bring the same clarity of vision he brought to Sleepy Hollow, Ed Wood and even the first Batman.  Instead, he gave us the second Batman: some great visuals, a few strong archetypes and a terrible script.  Tim Roth as the feral chihuahua was ridiculously over-the-top and not in a good way.  Perhaps Rick Baker should've stopped punching Estella Warren in the mouth long enough to find her motivation.  Or at least a personality.  This was a straight-ahead, cliched escape movie, with no pause for character development.  The ending wasn't as bad as many suggest and is definitely feasible if you consider that Thade's ultimate fate is left up in the air.  It'll take some explaining but it's possible.  All in all, I'm hoping Burton will take a pass on the sequel and let someone with stronger STORYTELLING skills take over.  NOTE TO JOEL SCHUMACHER: THIS DOES NOT MEAN YOU!

reviews.review_title: Great special effects... Painfully bad script and plot.
reviews.content: I went to this movie with real anticipation considering the great cast, Tim Burton at the helm and thoughts of the classic 1968 original.Anticipation is the only thing this movie offers.  It's awful!  If they had let me in for free, I would have asked for my "walking in back."The makeup was amazingly good, but 20 minutes into the movie, the great special effects could not make up for what was painfully obvious.  The plot and script were just downright laughable!This is a "see jane run" script and plot nearly all the way.  Really, it's that bad.  No... on second thought, it's worse.

While there were some parts of this movie that were too campy for my tastes, the ending is brilliant.  It's not just a surprise shocker, but actually based on the original ending from the novel, which had been changed for the first film.  The first film stands on its own, of course, but it was an inspired idea to go back to the novel in order to give this new film its own edge.

reviews.review_title: I am wowed again and again by such a reverent remake.
reviews.content: Tim Burton never ceases to amaze me.He had me from "Pee-Wee's Big Adventure", kept me in awe through "Beetlejuice", "Batman", "Edward Scissorhands", and "Nightmare Before Christmas" and has not slown down since.Burton has a way of turning an ordinary story, perhaps even one you've seen before, into a work of art.  He turned the campy original series "Batman" into a dark, seething masterpiece of a film.  He transformed his own "Nightmare" into a moral tale that kids and adults could both appreciate.And now he has remade "Planet of the Apes" with reverence and technical prowess.From the get-go, this film has you hooked with its brooding atmosphere and careful storytelling.  The plot is carefully laid out from the beginning, and even though you might begin to think you know what's going to happen, you are constantly surprised.I found my jaw hanging open throughout the whole sequence where the hero (played by Mark Wahlberg) crash lands on the planet.  The effect was so well done it was hard to imagine it being anything but totally real.In classic fashion, the heroic characters are super-good, though not without their flaws, and the villainous characters are supremely evil.  The roles are reversed in this film, with the apes being the masters and the humans being the ones who are caged and kept as pets.  By the way, monkeys don't make very nice masters.  Which reminds me, the addition of a young monkey girl keeping a small blonde-haired waif as a pet was a classic Burton touch.I don't feel like I can talk too much about the plot without giving it all away.  From the first moment of the film to the surprise ending, it's a non-stop roller coaster ride of a movie, and might possibly now be one of my top five films of all time.  It's a masterful work of art.  Tim Burton surely has his place in history now as one of the greatest directors of all time.I have not read any reviews of "Planet of the Apes" before writing this review, as I did not want them to taint my feelings about the film.  Even if the critics pan this movie, though, there is no way my feelings will change. I am in awe.Finally, I cannot end this review without a nod to Danny Elfman, my favorite singer/songwriter/composer of all time and a frequent Tim Burton collaborator.  Elfman's music in this film is quite different than his usual style, but at the same time fits right in with the theme and darkness of it. The beginning of the film is like "Batman", with a close-up shot through the credits while the music builds up an-almost frightening momentum until the movie actually begins.See it.  You won't regret it.

reviews.review_title: Weak story clings to spectacular visuals
reviews.content:
Visually, this film is what you might expect from the man who created Batman and Edward Scissorhands.  The attention to scenery and detailed makeup and costumes were wonderfully crafted and grabbed the viewer's attention from the beginning.  So now you've gotten used to the ape planet, what's next? The story and characters.  That's what this film seemed to lack.
The original Planet of the Apes had the advantage of a brand new idea (to anyone who hadn't read the book) to enthrall the audience.  The story was new and the characters had feelings and interactions that fit well with the effects.The 2001 version, unfortunately, had Mark Wahlberg playing an unfeeling robot of a character.  From the moment he lands on this mind-blowing planet, he never deviated from his primary motivation.  Granted, this is a necessary element for all scripts, but usually the motivation is complimented with other story elements and characters along the way.Wahlberg's character never takes notice of any other character or for that matter, any event that is taking place around him.  This becomes frustrating for the viewer as a story is desperately trying to reveal itself but is constantly stunted by the main character.As for the ending, well, it's a thinker.  I'll be interested to see if the sequel will acknowledge more than one perspective or dimension to the story. (6.5/10)

reviews.review_title: ending makes sense if you've read Boulle's novel
reviews.content:
All the confusion over the ending is understandable if you have not read the original Pierre Boulle novel on which Planet 2001 (and its predecessor, to a much lesser degree) is based.Boulle spends a lot of time on evolutionary theories and we learn as the story develops that Cornelius, a very bright chimp scientist, is on the verge of a discovery that will destroy the foundations of the apes' beliefs concerning their evolutionary superiority.In Boulle's Ape world, the apes believe they have always been the intelligent ones and the humans have always been incapable of rational thought.  Cornelius discovers the opposite to be true during his archeological dig in the forbidden zone -- he finds among the ruins a human doll with a voice mechanism, which hints at the previous existence of a hi-tech society. (a similar scene occurred in Planet 1968).The real shocker comes towards the end of the novel, when Cornelius, desperate to show that apes are not just skillful imitators (he is afraid that this truth may explain their progress up to this point -- they have simply copied what humans have already done throughout history), demonstrates via shock therapy on human subjects that he and his colleagues can actually tap into HISTORICAL human memory and shock subjects into babbling about events that took place hundreds of years ago.
Some of the snatches of vocalized historical memory reveal that humans rested on their technological laurels, became lazy, and, before they knew it, apes had taken over their world.  Snatches of these ancient memories reveal that apes were hungry for knowledge while humans were hungry for leisure (what, humans hungry for leisure?!  never!)  The takeover was violent and humans were enslaved.  Fast forward to Boulle's planet Soror and you have apes in control and mute humans with brains turned to mush.When Boulle's hero Ulysse Merou heads back to earth, he too is shocked to discover that apes now rule his home turf.  Yet, how hard is this to believe when we've already seen what has happened on Soror?  The formula is well-understood by now.  Superior species accomplishes much and then loses its edge.  Formerly inferior species, long discriminated against, tortured, etc., takes advantage of human sloth and eventually assumes control.In Planet 2001 we have seen the same thing.  Leo returns to earth naively expecting it to be similar to the way it was when he left.  Thade is worshipped here for the same reasons he was feared/worshipped on his planet -- he is the alpha-warrior and leader of the apes.  What happens on Earth is similar to what happened on Boulle's Soror.  Human minds melted after too much television, pornography, and sports/entertainment.   Though Leo eventually went back in time to return to earth, he still had to make the trip back to earth and that means hundreds of years have passed while he's been in space.  Thade's legend is well-known throughout the cosmos at this point and we should not be surprised to see him worshipped on earth as well, where he's obviously been the inspiration for the ape takeover.One last note: during the feast at the senator's home early in the movie, we hear one of the table guests exclaim (paraphrase):  "We're getting lazy, we should be careful lest the humans take over."  This is a nice homage to Boulle, who works the reverse angle in his novel when the human electroshock subjects reveal through historical memory that it was the human race that dropped the ball the first time around.The lesson is clear:  let your mind melt and you will perish.  I think the homage just mentioned actually telegraphs the plot of the sequel, in which the apes will be corrupted by the same mindless entertainments that corrupt us today.  Leo will lead a revolt and a new breed of humans -- men and women hungry for literature and learning -- will rise up and reclaim their planet.

reviews.review_title: Not a pure Burton movie but a really good entertainment !
reviews.content: I remember having seen original 'planet of the apes' when I was young. The apes at this moment didn't impressed me at all, and now I can't even remember them. In Tim Burton's you are really looking at apes. They are, I was going to say 'human', they're true. And this is a very good point for Burton, having done an impressive movie. Burton's universe is there, but not too much, I mean it's not Sleepy Hollow! Even Danny Elfman has made an effort on not doing his kind of music :) You spend a really good time, it's funny and smart, and well, Mark Wahlberg is nice!

reviews.review_title: If your airconditioner is broke & you need get out - maybe
reviews.content: They put a lot of time and effort into getting the apes right. But they forgot to put the same effort into the story.Good:the apes Helena Bonham Carter Charlten Heston as an ape.Bad:Mark Wahlberg - why does Carter and the humans follow him? He is a jerk.Carter says this human is different - How? The eyebrows on the female chimps - I'm sorry they annoyed me. Every "surprise" I could see coming a mile away.

Tim Burton's remake of the 1968 film PLANET OF THE APES was OK. It wasn't anything special. The make ups were excellent and the acting was decent. But the story line was rather weak. Tim Roth steals the film as General Thade. However, the original is a lot better.

reviews.review_title: The first is really good, the last part sucks
reviews.content: The first part of the movie is really good, and keeps up with the original, it even is a little better - but the last ½ hour (give or take..) really sucks. I was so disapointed at not only the ending, but also the story that leads to the ending. So if you ignore the ending, it's a 8 or 9 movie - but since the last ½ hour is there - I give i a 3...

First off, Tim Burton is one of my all time favorite directors.  Batman, Beetlejuice, Nightmare Before Christmas, all excellent movies.  All of that aside though, this is one damned good movie.  The special effects and make-up look fantastic.  Each ape actually looks different from each other one, and they all move like you would expect an ape/human hybrid to move. The acting is great, especially Tim Roth.  His character Thade is one of my favorite parts of this entire movie.  I have to say I think that the only real weak link is Mark Wahlberg.  I usually like Marky Mark too, but this time his performance seems to fall a little flat.  I know alot of people probably aren't going to like this one.  Some people will mistake certain aspects as being corny, but that can be said about just about every piece of Science Fiction in existence.  The end is good, maybe not as good as the beginning of the original, but good nonetheless.  Overall I enjoyed this film a great deal and recommend it to all.

The new installment to the "Planet of the Apes" saga is a skillfully made film.  It combines a new adaptation to the familiar story of the original. However, it is by no means a remake.  The new movie has some very striking similarities, but is a new and different film.  This "Planet of the Apes" uses enough of the now famous content, that made the original great, to sell it to the older fans, as well as a new story to win over a younger generation which would not properly understand the social gripping message of the 60's version.  This film is clearly Tim Burton's best work.  The cast does a very good job, especially considering all of the makeup.  Charlton Heston steals the show as Gen. Thade's father, proving once again that no one does a "Planet of the Apes" film like Mr. Heston. Despite the overall excellent nature of this film, it is flawed in one major aspect.  This film has no star quality.  No offense to Mark Wahlberg, but he is not capable of carrying a summer blockbuster by himself.  Mr. Wahlberg is a fine up and coming actor, but he has not yet reached the point in his career (and maybe never will) where he can open a film by himself, let alone a major film such as "Planet of the Apes".  Wahlberg tries his best to play the reluctant hero, but the key word is "tries".  He lacks the major presence that Charlton Heston provided in the original.  Wahlberg is unable to sell himself as an "action star".  His lines are not believable, and are quite commonplace.  In order for such a film to have been properly done it would have required a big time action star.  That star could only have been Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose name was mentioned for the Wahlberg role. His presence in the film would have made a big summer hit into a mega summer blockbuster.  Just imagine Arnold delievering the lines "I'll be back..you dirty apes!" If the casting directors have any sense they will make sure that Arnold is back when they make the sequel. Despite all of this it was still a very entertaining film. 3.5 out of 4 stars.

reviews.review_title: Edward Scissorhands trip to Planet of the Apes
reviews.content:
I have been so often disappointed in the past going into movies with high expectations: Indianna Jones and the Last Crusade, Phantom Menance, Batman, to name a few.  So I suppose my learned skepticism somewhat saved Planet of the Apes for me.  I had absolutely no expectations for this film, after having enjoyed the first one so much.  And of course, the new version does not live up to the original.  The original was filled with layers of political, racial, and sociological themes; and it had an incredible ending.  And who can match the tortured, almost humorous essence of Heston.  Oh, and it was fun too. 
But the greatness of the original does not make the new version a bad movie. In fact, it was in my opinion quite an enjoyable movie.  It surpasses the original in terms of its visual effects. While the theme/story is more simplistic, it is very well told; it moves very fast and fluidly, yet is not so packed with chaotic action (see Armageddon) that it does not allow for slower moments that can be saviored.  For example, there is a great scene with Heston in a cameo.  I wonder if he knew what he was saying when he said it: humans are deceptive and dangerous and are even more so because they have guns; beware of them?  Not exactly the NRA's mantra.  Anyways, he had a great cameo.  There are many other humorous moments as well.  Basically, the movie did not take itself seriously.  It tipped its hat to the original without trying to mimick its feel.  It is obvious Burton wanted to have some fun with this movie, paying tribute to the original while at the same time trying to give this movie its own unique perspective.  I believe he succeeded and I believe that that is the movie's saving grace.

reviews.review_title: Yet another movie that relies on it's effects instead of a plot
reviews.content: ***SPOILER***Apparently Hollywood has come to rely on special effects and makeup to carry movies, rather than a decent plot  and character development enhanced by these elements (i.e. The Phantom Menace)Granted, the makeup was stunning and Tim Burton once again succeeded in creating a world. However, I found myself yawning and checking my watch about 40 minutes into the movie. Mark Wahlburg, while not a great actor, was not showing much talent (probably due to his cheesy lines and shallow character). On a positive note,Tim Roth was wonderful as Thade and Helena Bonham Carter was also wonderful as the human loving ape (although it seemed her makeup was a bit of a hinderence).The battle scene at the end was good action, but we've been there done that before (Gladiator, Patriot, etc.)As for the ending, what the hell??? Lame attempt at a surprise ending that was supposed to be similar to the original (a reimagining of the ending I suppose).Wait for the rental. It's not worth your $8.00.

The story behind Planet Of The Apes is such a great one that it is almost impossible to mess it up. This new version of the film thankfully does not do that. I liked the original and I like this one as well. It adds a lot of special effects to an already great story to create something that I would want to experience again.

Worst movie I've seen in a decade... sweet jesus, how did this happen.  It says this has to be four lines long, but that's a problem cause I think saying it was a total suckfest with no redeeming qualities sums it up pretty good.  Well, look, I just got four lines.
Mark Walberg should only do comedies. He has one facial expression: extremely confused.

reviews.review_title: sticking with the theme and style of the original films
reviews.content: I am a big fan of the original films and I enjoyed this one just as much, if not more. It is the perfect balance of sticking with the style of the original films and branching off as its own film. I enjoyed it very much. The special effects are great. Marc Walburg to a great job, as did the rest of the cast.

My fears when I heard that 20th Century Fox had enlisted Tim Burton to direct a resurrection of their "Apes" franchise was that he would omit most of the spirit of the first series of films, rely on production design and quick editing to carry his movie, and spend a lot of money making it...oh yeah....and it wouldn't be any good....And...it isn't any good!!!!! The only "ape" character who is able to look convincingly like a gorilla rather than a man in make-up is Michael Clarke Duncan. Now, of course, one could make the same complaint about the original, but one of the stated reasons for remaking an SF film is that the special effects have progressed to the point where the story can be better told. Not the case here.....Because the film relies so heavily on production design and quick editing, the viewer is never able to invest in the story or the characters. Mr. Whalberg, you are no George Taylor, though in some calculated way, I'm sure you appeal to a certain demographic.This is a film contrived by marketeers and sociologists. Apparently, Mr. Burton shot 6 endings in an attempt to find the one that would guarantee the most box office. The one that made it onto the print is non-sensical (unless it is explained in a sequel). If you want time travel, Star Trek has done it ad nauseum over the past few years. Mr. Burton isn't doing anything new here.The original film had facets and layers. No characters were truly evil, none truly good. George Taylor was a cynic and a loner. There were aspects of adventure in the story, aspects of suspense, social commentary, comedy, all done in a subtle enough manner, with enough change in theatrical pacing to make it a classic that still stands up to repeated viewing today.The new film is "good guys vs. bad guys", there's the requisite central antagonist, Mr. Whalberg's sole motivation appears to be saving his pet chimp, and his only expression is a blank stare.Lines from the original film (there are two of them that I could tell) have been thrown in, and delivered with little context, and therefore not fitting into film. They serve as a reminder of the superiority of the first series.The marketeers have called this a 'reimagining' of the first film. Mr. Burton likes to 'reimagine' other people's work: Batman, Sleepy Hollow, Mars Attacks. His one good film was an affectionate (therefore, non-moneymaking)tribute to the "B" movie film-maker Ed Wood.Mr. Wood would be proud of this remake. Both Burton and Wood share an 'understanding' of SF, and this is a film that stands proudly and comparably with "Plan 9 From Outer Space". Congratulations Tim and Fox. Well done!!!!!

Does this movie MOVE! Don't blink or you might miss - the plot? You didn't miss it, it really was that short.Here's a tip off for a bad script: If you see more than one name in the writing credit, WATCH OUT!There are alot of reviews of this blockbuster, so I will just ask a few questions which you could answer as you watch the film:Was Michael Clarke Duncan was the only ape that sort of looked like himself? (A nice touch that George Lucas did in the Phantom Meanace).Did you catch the meaning of CALIMA? CAution LIve ANimals, easy to miss!If the apes wanted no one to go to CALIMA, why was the it so poorly protected?If it was the center of their universe for thousands of years and so easy to reach, why were there no apes AT ALL there? Wouldn't they come to "worship" at least?How come Davidson all of a sudden cares about this kid? Just exactly what was the point of having him stay behind the ship? Who was the kid? What the heck was going on there?Did you care at all when Kris Kristofferson got killed? Nope!
Did you care a little when a couple of guys in Davidson's original band got iced? Only a little.What was the point (from the writer's point of few) of taking out the (cool) gun? He brought back later, anyway. With two guns, that might have been fun. One guy shooting up himself was just stupid, didn't you think?Just exactly where did all the aps and all the humans come from? I mean, seriously, would the humans live so close to the apes if they were rounding them up as pets and slaves? Give me a break! I'd have found a better neighborhood.  (On top of that, there's a little problem of genetic diversity here of there were no natural apes and humans on this planet in the first place. But, we'll give Tim poetic license on that).So, the GOD arrives, literally out of the sky in a space ship. NO ONE is scared of this technology AT ALL. They recognize this is a prophecy come true yet they have NO PROBLEM letting the UNCLEAN Davidson walk right up to their DEITY.  Then, they proceed to beat the daylights out of the diety nearly kill him.  (I guess that answers why no one was worshiping). Question: Is there a story here or not? No!Would a good alternate title be "Crouching Humans, Hidden Monkeys?"Who exactly would have the Lincoln-esq Thade have liberated to get the statue? I think it might have been humans, don't you? So, maybe Davidson didn't do as bad as is implied. (But, now, it looks as if he should have stuffed the girl into the capsule with him, eh?)How did this movie get made? Here's a senario:(Office of Richard Zanuck, producer)
ZANUCK: What did you think of that script I told you to read?FLUNKY: Great movie, sir.ZANUCK: Who does the make up on "Star Trek?" Do we have anyone who can do that stuff?FLUNKY: Yes, sir!ZANUCK: Don't just stand there? Where's my bagel?(Two days later, Tim Burton's office)ZANUCK: Well, Tim, what do you think of the script I sent over. My brother-in-laws newphew's Dentist calls it "The Visitor."BURTON: I wouldn't have my name associated with this recycled waste. It's a remake of Planet of the Apes!ZANUCK: I knew that.BURTON: Well, then, get lost. I don't do remakes!ZANUCK: (non plussed) We're offering 25 million.BURTON: Well, my Rolls is looking rusty. OK! I'll do it!

reviews.review_title: remake or re-creation... weak either way
reviews.content: Crash landing... capture... escape... battle... the end.  Intricate plot isn't it?  Burton decides to sidestep any meaningful themes in this film, and that's a shame.  There are a dozen social issues that could have been examined in the movie, but apparently Burton was in a hurry to get to the Braveheart-style Ape vs. Human battle.  As for the acting: Wahlberg was a jerk, Roth was too dramatic, Michael Clarke Duncan was bland, and Estella Warren hardly said a word.  The only worthwhile performance was from Helena Bonham Carter.  As for the ending, it's sad that Burton felt he had to match (or top) the original by throwing in that outrageous ending.  He fell short by a longshot.  I suppose the movie was entertaining if you didn't compare it to the original... but can you really watch it without comparing?

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the first one...
reviews.content: All though this was an excellent movie with awesome special effects and costume design, it still can't compete with the original Planet of the Apes. It was not at all what I expected. I expected a total remake of the movie (same exact story, same characters, etc.). However, this movie has a more easy-to-understand story.

Looks great! Tim Roth is excellent as the villain of the piece. Newcomer Estella Warren is given little to do but she does display a "star-like" screen presence.Tim Burton creates an original "re-imagining" of the original story. The plot, however, has a major logical flaw.SPOILER ALERT>>>>Our hero, Mark Wahlberg, tells the others he is from Earth. He crashes on some planet and discovers his ship of origin also crashed on the same planet. When playing the computer logs of that ship, we all hear the commander saying they are about to crash on an UNCHARTED planet. We subsequently learn that Wahlberg actually crashed on a future Earth.SoooooHow come people FROM Earth didn't realize they were crashing ON Earth?

reviews.review_title: Look at all them fancy monkeys!
reviews.content: I guess I should warn you that there are a few minor spoilers in this review. So if you don't want to know even minor details about the plot, do NOT read on... (but judging how much money the film made over the weekend, most of you have already seen this film...twice.)I went in to Tim Burton's PLANET OF THE APES really expecting to see one of the worst films ever. This was a surprise since I love every Tim Burton film I've ever seen (definitely not counting Batman 3 & 4 which he produced, but had no other evolvement and it shows). From his first big screen film Pee Wee's Big Adventure, to my favorite Ed Wood, to the recent Sleepy Hollow, I've admired his style and direction...though most of his films seem to have been edited overnight in some parts.His latest is a "more faithful to the original book" adaptation of the french book; Planet Of The Apes...and just so you don't get upset while watching the film, the book is NOT set on Earth like the original was. In case you were born in the eighties and never knew the joys of playing with the Mego toys of the same name back in the 70s, I'll explain the basic story. A guy gets trapped in a space-storm that flings him to a world where monkeys rule and people don't. Yep, that about sums it up.The book was adapted to film in the 70s starring Charlton Heston and a bunch of similar guys with beards. I believe that the original's sequel Return To The Planet Of The Apes won a special achievement award for Best Beard in a Speaking Role. Not much is known about what happened to those beards after the 70s. I'm sure we'll see an "E True Hollywood Story" about those beards one day, but I digress...Actually one of the first things that sticks out in this new version of Planet Of The Apes is the lack of beards on most of the human characters. Mark Whalberg (of Boogie Nights) plays beardless human astronaut Leo who trains geneticly engineered monkeys to fly spaceships. When one of his monkeys gets lost, he follows it into a space-storm that hurls him to the planet below. This is where the story most of you all know kicks in. Leo is hunted down by human-like bearded apes. Soon he meets a human woman named Daena, her father, a chimpanzee woman who believes in Human Rights, and an orangutan slave trader who deals in humans.So basically we get a peek into Ape society and meet General Thade played by Reservoir Dog star Tim Roth who hates all humans, but loves to jump around and make monkey noises.I won't give any more story away, but lets just say that man and monkey fight and surprisingly the Apes do NOT throw poo. If there is one way to catch a human off guard it would be to throw "monkeypoo" (which, by the way, is my 1 word review of the film Monkeybone) at them. Actually, if they did throw copies of the movie Monkeybone at the humans they would have surly been destroyed much like our own society almost was when it was released.Ok so I liked this movie... There were a few things that bugged me like the make-up on the female "apes" and all the "wired" jumping and, of course, some of the dialogue. But in the end it's a movie about a planet where apes rule and people don't (see 3rd paragraph above). It's campy and yet interesting.Mark Wahlberg continues to bury his Marky Marc image in a role in which Keanu Reaves would have said "Whoa" a lot like in all his films.Helena Bonham Carter's Ari character is actually interesting unlike Estella Warren's Daena character who stands around gape-mouthed for most of the film.The make-up is excellent. Can't get much better `cept for the female apes that I mentioned already.And, YES, there is a "twist"...just not the one you remember. Check it out. Also look for cameos by Danny DeVito and George Clooney. If you blink, you'll miss them. And also look for interesting twists on dialogue from the original film.So, again, I went to this film with the most lowered expectations due to a lot of bad pre-press, but came out liking the film a lot. I'm actually going to see it again and you KNOW I'll buy the DVD when it comes out too. So go...enjoy. Buy candy at the liquor store and sneak it in. $2.00 for candy? Please!Reviewed by Chris "Beyond" aka Chris S. Morrill

For those not familiar with that expression, it dates from a 'Punch' cartoon of 1895, where a nervous curate is breakfasting with his bishop.Bishop: I'm afraid you've got a bad egg, Mr Jones.Curate: Oh, no, my Lord, I assure you that parts of it are excellent!So, parts of Tim Burton's 'Planet of the Apes' are excellent. The lifelike and varied ape makeup, combined with the effort that has gone into making the apes... well, apes, and more individual than the oppressed humans can manage to be, makes their society utterly believable. Helena Bonham Carter delicately brings out the character of Ari, shewing us that a full face prosthesis need not handicap a great actress, and Tim Roth camps it up completely as Thade (which you may not think is a good point).On to the bad parts. Mark Wahlberg does nothing to arouse my sympathy, or indeed interest. It doesn't help that his character is halfway between James T Kirk and Dorothy from the Wizard of Oz, and does not develop at all throughout the film. The plot is stupid, ridiculous and yet utterly predictable, and forces characters to act unrealistically. The eventual resolution is contrived and unsatisfying, it gives no extra depth to anything, in fact, it seems to be the only way the writers could think of to finish off the plot. The ending is tacked-on and inconsistent.I would recommend avoiding this film unless you really have nothing better to do, and no expectations of intelligence. But stylistically it's worth something, and Helena Bonham Carter's performance is worth adding a couple of marks, so reluctantly, i give it 4 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: The reason why I don't like Tim Burton anymore
reviews.content: Before seeing this film, I was a fan of Tim Burton's famous work such as Beetle juice, Batman, Edward Scissor hands, and Mars Attacks! When I learned that this move was directed by him (I didn't see the film until 3 years after it came out), I was dying to see it. I had watched the 1968 original and was familiar with the original novel. After seeing it, in all honesty it was the biggest waste of garbage I had ever seen. Oh sure the make up and special effects were good, they always are, that's why they spend so much time working on that stuff rather than writing a good plot or developing characters. The dialogue was cheap and the acting was more wood than a redwood tree! Mark Wahlburg's acting was so out of place for this film, throughout the entire film, he really shows no emotion and when he does it's only for a split second. I wasn't expecting something like that of Charleston Heston's epic role in the original (heck his role in this film was only minor yet beats the crap out of the rest of the cast), but I'd at least expect some effort to be put in it. All the characters really just filled out the stereotypical roles seen in the real world today from the war mongering general, the peaceful animal loving hippie, the rebellious doubtful sergeant, the ignorant leaders, the royal waitress, and the bumbling idiots the humans. The plot was as straight forward as a derailed train. Everything was just hoping around and far fetched even for a movie like this. It is basically this, guy lands on planet, gets caged, frees a bunch of prisoners, goes through a chase in the desert, rounds up prisoners, rebels, uses rocket buried in the sand for centuries to blast away charging army. Than monkey comes from the sky and everyone is best friends with each other. h yeah, Apes can not swim, because... well that's never explained. And the end was the worst attempt at a twist I have ever seen. And it's bad when the director in the commentary couldn't even make heads or tails out of it. I was relieved when the end credits came. That was the last Tim Burton film I have seen and since seeing this utter failure I avoid all his films, even the ones I liked before. If you don't want to take my word for it, fine, but don't blame me for wasting your time with this sad excuse for a movie.

reviews.review_title: leave it to tim burton to ruin movies
reviews.content: ********warning: spoilers*********i've always hated tim butron, but this totally uncalled for. it first starts out good, emphesising on the space part of the story and explaining the origin of the ape domination. it also got rid of that whole "the planet being earth" bullcrap (i mean, of course it's earth dingleberry you can breath on the planet!!!!!).then we hear the humans talking. it then becomes automatically awful. the only reason for the ape domination is that the humans can't talk. then there's that stupid ending that makes no sense at all (and isn't suposed too, remember, this is a tim burton movie).terrible acting by mark wahlberg too.

I would like to respectfully disagree with jackzen from Wales. To be fair though, I will preface this by saying that I never saw the original TV shows, and if there was a book, I never read it.But, that said, I would say that this movie stands as a fine piece of work in it's own right. It was, I believe, very well acted and filmed, and I believe that the plot was basically good. I did however dislike the ending, but don't feel that it was a fault of poor plot, just personal taste.I won't say more, because I don't want to spoil this for anyone that has not seen it. I believe that it is a movie you will enjoy watching.

Ok, we saw the film on opening night. It was showing on 3 screens at a multiplex and every showing was sold out. We waited to see this at the 10:20 showing-so maybe I expected too much or was tired. Having said that... The movie was so-so at best. The makeup was phenomenal as were the special effects. The apes were BRUTAL. Exceedingly so. This is one PG-13 movie that our girls will not go see for a long while. We carefully screen "older" movies and deem some appropriate-this is not one of those. The original was so fantastic-perhaps it was too good to ever improve upon. This version did stick closer to the original book story, however. Lastly, the ending was horrible. I have no interest in re-watching this movie, once was more than enough. Happy Viewing!
