I admit that I've only seen the original for the first time this month (though I'd seen a making-of-the-series show and thus was aware of the basics), and I acknowledge that this new version is only supposed to be inspired BY the original -- not a faithful adaptation.  Therefore I was prepared to accept the new movie on its own merits.Even so, I walked out of the theater scratching my head and wondering why they'd bothered doing it at all.Yes, I love Tim Burton.  Yes, the costumes, make-up, and sets are amazing. Yes, it was fun, had some good lines, and featured some marvelous acting on the part of Helena Bonham Carter, who was remarkably believable in her chimpanzee-inspired mannerisms and movements.Other than that...so what?Without spoiling too much of either movie, I have to say that the message of the original was far more intelligent.  It really made you stop and think: who's right, who's wrong, do we have any right to judge the apes or should we learn lessons about our own failings in theirs?  This one was merely simplistic summer-movie fare, with a predictable plotline I was correctly forecasting as little as five minutes into the movie.(Yes, and I easily guessed the "surprise twist ending" everyone is raving about.  Yawn.  You want a REAL surprise twist ending, go watch "Sixth Sense" or "Unbreakable.")Last but not least, I find it interesting that Heston's character was likeable precisely because he WAS such a crusty cynical old b*****d. Wahlberg's "brash hotshot pilot" persona conforms to almost every "hero" stereotype in the book...and, thus, is entirely bland and uninteresting, though I do not knock him as an actor.  I DO give the writer(s) full credit for not going the obvious route with the annoyingly "perfect leggy blonde" potential love interest, but other than that...well, not much I can say.In short: rent the original and pretend you don't know the ending.  You'll get your money's worth.

I have to agree that the makeup and visual effects and even the look of the movie are vintage Tim Burton. Compared to the original film the ape effects are great, and actually make you feel that you are seeing human sized apes, and not some guy in a monkey suit. A+However all looks and no plot make for a bad film. The film starts of promisingly enough, but one we get to the planet of the apes it is as if the scriptwriters figured just shooting scenes of flying apes and a ragtag group of humans trying to escape (Hmmm sounds like something from the Wizard of Oz) would be enough. F-One feels sorry for the cast for having to muddle their way through this script, but then cast is not up to the task of even handling this script. Only Tim Roth as the evil General Thade turns in a great menacing performance, and winds up out acting the rest of the cast. D (Roth A+)And let's no even talk about the ending! Anyone who has watched any sci-fi films involving wormholes, etc, must have seen where this film was going from the opening few minutes. As the final climatic scenes, yawn, made me wish I had some popcorn left over to occupy myself with something useful, no wait I could have put the bag over my head to hide me from the shame of wasting $12.50!!

reviews.review_title: Not Tim Burton's Best, Certainly Not His Worst...
reviews.content:
This film will always be much debated amongst Tim Burton fans. The original idea of the movie was not to re-make the classic film, but to "re-imagine" it. At first, this seemed like a brilliant idea. Who better to direct a new version of Planet of the Apes than the odd yet brilliant Tim Burton?Well, great ideas often do not lead to great finished products.And that is what this film really is. It is not a great movie. It is an average, sometimes funny(especially Paul Giamatti), sometimes thrilling(battle sequences are amazing) film. But as a whole? Average.
The problems with the movie all come from the fact that Burton did not know exactly how he wanted to re-imagine the movie. Should it be a serious, sci-fi version? The last 20 minutes seem to point in this direction. Should it be a "spoofesque" movie that doesn't take itself too seriously? The entire middle section of this movie seems to point in this direction.In the end, this film is confused and awkward. Tim Burton wants you to like this movie, it's clear the entire time. Unfortunately, the acting is strained and the movie too muddled to ever develop into a classic.I am suggesting that this movie is worth renting or going to the theater, but it's not worth owning(unless you are a huge Burton fan). This movie is better than Mars Attacks and Sleepy Hollow, but it does not even approach Batman or Edward Scissorhands.I give this movie ** out of **** stars. Add one star if you are a dedicated Tim Burton fan.

Although I'm not a fan of the previous Planet of the Apes movies (I've never seen them), I was pretty excited about seeing this remake/sequel.
Unfortunately, I was very much unimpressed with what I viewed. The special effects were great, the scenery was realistic, and the cast seemed to be very talented (opinion not based on this movie). However, they were lacking in one MAJOR department: the script! As someone said before, I agree that you and a bunch of your friends could have written a better screenplay for the movie than these talented, well-paid writers did.There were many interesting directions this movie *could* have taken and didn't. I noticed that in the beginning of the movie, the woman scientist on the spaceship mentions that with chimps the female is dominant sexually. Of course, this led me to think; `What an interesting twist to the movie! The female apes could be really domineering instead of the males!' But instead the comment seemed to hold no relevancy to the rest of the film whatsoever! It turns out there were hardly any female apes at all, and those were hardly very aggressive.Maybe I shouldn't have gone to see the movie with such high hopes for a great flick, but I did. I am officially insulted at spending good money on a film that seemed to have lots of possibility but no delivery. For those of you who haven't seen the movie and plan to, my advice to you is to go into the movie with lowered expectations and maybe you'll appreciate it more than I did.5 out of 10

reviews.review_title: No action + bad script + bad plot = Shockingly bad movie
reviews.content: Q:  What do you do when an action film has little or no action?A:  You start analyzing script, plot, character development, acting ability...etc.Guess what?  The script is poorly written and contains major plot and character inconsistencies.  The plot (and about 10 sub-plots) never gains continuity or momentum.  And we learn virtually nothing about the characters. I know I shouldn't be worrying about this, but when there is no action, what else is there to do? I guess the acting was OK--I mean, Tony Danza's not in it.Tell your friends not to see this movie if they want action.  This is not an action film!P.S. Mark Wahlberg's character seemed to adapt very well to being hurtled through space and time, crash landing on a planet, and being captured and enslaved by talking apes.  I wish I could adapt that well.This movie stunk with a capital "S".My two line review of this movie is "Shockingly Bad".  I expected so much and got so little.Go rent the first one--please!

reviews.review_title: A good satire depicting human nature and apes that can act humanely
reviews.content: I had never seen a good science fiction movie since "Star Wars: Phantom of the Menace" until I saw "Planet of the Apes". Although the two films are about future human interplanetary adventures, "Planet of the Apes" stresses more on human compassion for and understanding of other living creatures. The film is also a good satire on men's foolhardy behavior to launch nuclear wars that could annihilate everything on earth only to find that, in the end, they would be ruled by "wiser-than-human" apes. For such a good film, all the kudos go not only to Director Tim Burton but also to all the crew, particularly the makeup artists, set designers and the actors.

reviews.review_title: Great film. I have a few quibbles
reviews.content: Taking this movie for its own merits instead of needless comparison to the original, I thought it was quite good. As many have said, the acting (at least of the apes) was astonishing. The villain chimp (Tim Roth) and Ari the sensitive chimp (Helena Bonham Carter) were amazing, both the acting and the technology to support the believability. Yes, the ending was strange and didn't follow logically whereas for the most part the rest of the movie was logically self-consistent. However, it was a good ending and I'm willing to reserve judgment to see how they develop it in the next film. My few quibbles with the movie were these: * I didn't see any gorillas on the space station and such large apes seem entirely inappropriate to the space mission, so where did the gorilla breeding stock come from? * I realize the apes are stronger than humans, especially the gorillas, but when they hit someone, the impact of the punch was ridiculous even considering their strength. If you could hit as hard as 5 Mike Tyson's on his best punch, you couldn't even come close to getting the target rocketing through the air like they did. And if you hit that hard, it would seem to be instant death but wasn't in the movie. I know, I know, Hollywood needs to really exaggerate. * The year was something like 2032 that it all began, right? Well, there is no way the world will even be close technologically and space achievement in 31 years. Transportation pods smaller than a compact car that can land on an earthlike planet and launch again? The apes genetically engineered to be very smart? The military has a massive space station?                This would be more believable in 2132. Enjoy, Jon

There is a certain perception that is suggested when Tim Burton takes the helm of a movie. That perception is that you'll see something very different than the usual lint that's produced after good movies are tumbled about in the Hollywood dryer; with all their wrinkles removed, sickly pseudo fresh (like a Downey fabric sheet that touts it smells of `Fresh Rain' yeah right), and softened as not to cause chaffing. But Burton is different. Burton has vision. Burton is a visionary. I have uttered those words before in reference to his litany of twisted, incredibly clever and dark films. Burton's early shorts, Vincent and Frankenweenie, are things born of a mind and an eye that's capable of seeing the world through gray colored lenses. Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, Beetlejuice, Edward Scissor Hands, The Nightmare Before Christmas, Ed Wood, Batman, Mars Attacksevery one of these movies had that visionthat dig up the dirt up and put it under the light feel.Which is why then, with Planet of the Apes, I can claim as the only explanation for such appalling drivel is that Burton completely and utterly sold out for the lure of a `Big Budget Hollywood Summer Blockbuster'. Who better than Burton to `revisit' P of A (as Burton nearly screams in every interview that this is NOT a remake), one of the darkest and engaging sci-fi films made? But, here's the question: if this is not intended to be a remake, then why not cast that famous Burton vision on this piece and make it something more strange, moredare I sayhuman? Take Burton's other filmsthe hero is most often an odd, socially maladjusted, misunderstood, feared, decidedly melancholy, alone, scared and scarred, but somehow better than the lot of others around him. His characters, in their own eerie way, show the more benevolent side of human nature.So, then Mark Wahlberg's self-serving Leo in P of A is someone NOT from Burton's world. So, then the `plot' (and I use the word `plot' with hesitation) of P of A is also something not Burtonesque. Thus the whole experience is such a total let down that it makes one wonder if big budgets and high profile stars stifles anything creative as easily as a 40ft wet blanket thrown on a single lit match (enter into evidence America's Sweetheart). Burton usually strives on lancing the boil of our perceptions and getting to the raw under layer of culturesand P of A (the original was a hearty, if campy, examination and damnation of the snobbery of humans to dub ourselves as rulers of any planet) would seem to give Burton the chance to perform a wonderful social surgery.The gray colored glasses though were replace by the $green$ colored lenses, and so we are left with just another shell of a movie. The only vision Burton can see, for what are supposed to be genetically enhanced apes, is that they will emulate human social customsthey will form armies, they will have a senate, conduct dinner parties and sport Jackie O bobs; this is visionary? Hardly. In the end all we learn from Burton's P of A is the same thing we see in too many movies and the same thing we see in nearly every nook and cranny of the world; whoever can beat one's chest the loudest, whoever can physically beat the other side down, whoever has better weaponry will ultimately prevail. Burton had the chance to show a better wayinstead he merely aped his lesser peers and created another loud, ridiculously expensive and mindless testament to violence.

After watching this film, you appreciate the films of the past that so many have tried to redo. There really not a lot of action in this film except for some fight scenes toward the latter half of the movie. Looking back at the original Planet of the Apes, you could see where there was a definate plot and goal. This remake doesn't have that cohesion. It does work well with the relationship between Whalberg and Carter. But the relationship between Warren and Whalberg develops too quick after the demise of Kristofferson. In that type of primitive society, Kristofferson could be father or husband but we don't know because Warren just says "my family". It's too obvious that the writers used her as competition for Carter. In fact you really see no reason for Kristofferson to even be in the movie. Whalberg's involvement with the primitive humans comes too quickly also. It's like they cut out a part where Whalberg should find out what this planet is for the sake of the length of the movie. The fight scenes seem inconsistant. One minute an ape kills a human with one blow but our hero (Whalberg) takes several blows and falls. But somehow,again, Whalberg maintains the common sense he has in many of his movies. Somehow through all his movies, writers give him lines that make him act (or react) realisticly. While the others have lines and actions that don't seem be what it would be if it was real, Whalberg comes in and acts like the only one sensible or realisitic being. (as though he walked from the seats into the film) So much so that when we see him in the end....an ending that makes absolutely no sense or connection with what we just saw in the rest of the movie, the look on his face is as though he thinking, "what kind of stupid ending is this to a movie" right on the screen.*see more in goofs for inconsistant content

reviews.review_title: The late Rod Serling would be proud of this ending created by Tim Burton....
reviews.content: What is all the buzz about the ending to this movie?!?  I almost fell for all of the bashing that you IMDB fan-critics were saying about the ending to this movie. Luckily I watched it for myself. Whew!!!! What a creepy ending!!! I walked out of the theater thinking about it.  It kind of gave me that eerie feeling like the end of the Blair Witch Project. I think Tim Burton took the right direction in going this route with the ending.  When I thought about it it made sense to catch us off guard with this version to the end.  I mean if you saw the original Planet Of The Apes you already knew what to expect for the remake but Burton fooled us all and I think some of you fan-critics do not like being catched off guard like that. Despite the fact the battle at the end was stop short due to a "MONKEY" arrival and despite the fact that Estella Warren was the only "female human" that looked like she had access to a hair stlylest and a makeup person this movie was AWESOME.  You know whats scary....after watching Sleepy Hollow and Planet Of The Apes, Tim Burton is starting to grow on me. Damn!!! I never thought I would say that....

Awful, just awful! Bad casting, bad acting and not a patch on the original. It could have been so much better. I know the idea is somewhat far fetched about apes ruling the earth, but the original film was entertaining and thought provoking. This version is just downright silly. Sorry, but it stinks!

reviews.review_title: Nothing Special......1968 Apes were better period.
reviews.content: Honestly, my expectations for this movie diminished right after I watched 2001 version of the "Apes." I thought that Tim Burton would bring something fantastic but it was a total failure.....Not as much passion inputed as an old "Planet of the apes." I wasn't fully disappointed with the special effects but I was well disappointed with the story lines and the visual content of the film. Apes didn't look as real as the 1968 Ape.I would just like to say that this movie is for an entertainment, not for an enlightenment of the hidden meanings and themes behind the film. If you just want to relax and watch the film off the curiosity then this film is a perfect feature. However, if you are a person who wants to be in awe of unexpected glimpse and extraordinary story lines, then either read the novel or watch the 1968 version of "The planet of the Apes." I personally didn't enjoy 2001 version of "The planet of the Apes." 6.3/10 I would give.

reviews.review_title: Great Movie, LAME Ending ! SPOILERS AHEAD!!
reviews.content: well first of this was a really good movie. The ape makeup blew me away, i nearly thought it was real monkeys acting!SPOILER AHEAD Second the story behind how the apes got to ruling over humans on the unnamed planet was actually better than the original apocalyptic earth thing in the Charleston Heston epic. The whole about time warp and the station with the apes crashing and Mark Wahlberg crashing a thousand years later was cool. Everything was going so amazingly well......when it came to the end. SPOILER AHEAD!!The movie should have ended with him staying on the planet...but he takes off.....and crash lands on earth in the past(1990's)and its ruled by apes....how did that happen????? i mean earth was far from everything......well i hope a sequel will explain everything.....7.5/10

reviews.review_title: Great Movie, LAME Ending !!MAJOR SPOILER AHEAD!!
reviews.content:
well i have to say overall this was better than the original. I mean, first the makeup was amazing it makes you think its actual monkeys acting! Second the story about how the apes came to be was better than the original story in th '68 version. I mean the space station with apes crashes on the empty planet and the apes become superior than humans. Mark Wahlberg lost in a phenomenon in space and crashes a thousand years after the station after only minutes since he left. The culture of the apes is more defined. The ending if directed by me would either have him leave and go to HIS time period or stay on the planet. BBUUUUTTTT .......... how on earth did that happen??? weren't the apes ruling on another planet???? that ending was lame.......will stay this way until a sequel explains what happened!!!!!! overall it's worth your $$.
7/10 stars!!

Outstanding makeup and possibly the most evil screen villain since Darth Maul won't save this movie from being placed on many peoples' worst lists of 2001. Insipid dialogue, rote acting (by humans, mostly) and action sequences that almost never gain momentum are but a few of the indignations marring what could have been a triumphant revisitation to the Ape planet. After seeing this, after seeing another down in the up-and-down career of Tim Burton, I almost wish this HAD been made by originally planned director Oliver Stone with Arnold Schwarzenegger starring. That version may at least have enjoyed some campy fun.

Let's get real here.  The remake is fine for today's audience. But I must stress this point. Tim Burton did a fine job visually, but there can be no comparison between the '01 Apes and the '68 version.Dramatically speaking, scene for scene, these newcomers to the Apes myth have dropped the ball. Where are the scenes with "Leo" confronting the Ape Senate? Wondering, along with us as an audience how this "Ape" world could have come to fruition? Those narrative points are sorely missing here-- so Leo becomes a most passive hero. Do we care for him? Do we follow his point of view with much fervor? Not much. But we dig the visuals, and we don't like Thade too much, so we go along with it. Ari is a breeze of fresh air, for sure. But they dropped the ball when it comes to nailing the apes v. human conflict at the climax. I'll take Taylor with his rifle holding Dr. Zais hostage any day.Am I nuts? Where's the drama in this new version? What are the stakes involved? What happened to Cornelius holding the doll that mutters "mama""? I love Danny Elfman, too. But, for God's sake, give me a little Goldsmith to ground me on this one.

reviews.review_title: A terrible film that totally sells out.
reviews.content: I was anxious to see this film, thinking that it might pay tribute to the greatness of the original. What I found was that the film was poorly written, and it lost all of the flavor of the original. All of the social commentary is gone, as well as all of the mystery. The plot has been replaced by some substitute filler, and the entire thing wreaked of recycled plastic. Although I did find some scenes laughable (most notably the ones that required acting) I would see it once just to know what I am talking about. If you are looking for some of Tim Burton's better work, look elsewhere.

I've never seen the original Planet of the Apes, so I went into this movie cold.  I had no expectations other than what I've seen on the previews, and Tim Burton's reputation.  The only thing I really liked about this film was the make-up effects (except for Helena Bonham Carter's make-up.  She looked more like Michael Jackson than a "lower" primate).   ... And, I would have changed the ending.  I hate it when movies go for the obvious sequel ending.

Compared to the original, it has much better effects, much more realistic looking scenes and ape-suits.  But the story just falls flat.Essentially, the story runs along so darn quickly that the hero never seems to stop and think.  He never considers options, he never hesitates for a moment, and he never takes a wrong turn.  As a result, the audience never stops to think, or worry, or wonder.Because the story is racing, the characters are never developed.What we want is: a roller coaster ride, where riders are hurled and twisted and turned and jerked around, with lofty highs and gut-sinking lows.What we get is: a rocket ride, shooting at a target 2 miles away, straight ahead, with the end always in sight and closing quickly.It's okay, but not great.  I was left longing for Charlton Heston's (the original film) agonizing, pondering gaze.  We *FELT* him struggling with the situation.  We felt his pain.  Not so here.It's a rental.

reviews.review_title: Rather entertaining, rather memorable, rather good
reviews.content:
I think Burton did well in creating Planet of the Apes for a generation that did not know it, and as well, keeping the ones who did satisfied. The acting by the human-played apes was marvelous, mannerisms such as hoots and grunts in amusement, anger, or excitement were quite well done.  Burton was also able to create a scientifically logical theory behind the concept, engineering the thought that the primates were tampered with in the human image, and taught English when they were genetically engineered, which all of course was fantastical but eerily plausible.  The ape culture was intriguing as well.There was moments where I was saying, "Wow, that was a really great idea".  However, there was also times when I found myself saying, "Jesus Burton, not that!", although the latter was less common.
All throughout his career, Tim Burton was trying as hard as he could to balance entertainment with his cinematic vision, and this time he struck gold.
All in all, Planet of the Apes is not the kind of remake that people who loathe action films would enjoy, nor people who despise art films, but if you have no preference (Or you can at least stand both), the new Planet of the Apes is truly great science fiction! My only complaints were the blonde supermodel (Paper thin character), and some really lame dialogue(More character developement would have been nice too).  Both a B movie and a cinematic marvel (If it's possible).Ah, and on a final note, Helena Bonham Carter (the period-piece-princess) made a rather attractive chimpanzee!

This one is an absolute shocker! I can't believe, Tim Burton is responsible for this mess (but then again, everyone can have a bad-hair day). The story makes no sense at all. The characters are all one-dimensional, their actions implausible, the attempts at humour feeble. The whole Ape culture/religion is a sad mush of Ancient Rome and Early Christianity. And the ending, people were raving about it, but it's a complete letdown, kind of: 'Oh, we gotta go out with a bang, like in the Original. But it has to be a different bang....Mmmh, don't have any ideas...Oh, let's just do this  OK, won't spoil. One positive thing : The gorilla masks are quite scary (and allow the actors to hide - which is probably a good thing).

reviews.review_title: If you don't try to compare it to the original, you will enjoy it!
reviews.content: Being a big fan of the original Planet Of The Apes, I went to see this movie with some trepidation.  Fortunately for me, I found out beforehand that it was NOT a remake, but a re-interpretation of the original. Knowing this, you shouldn't expect many similarities between the original movie (other than a few lines), and this version. About the only thing really similar to the original is "Apes ruling humans." The similarities essentially stop there. I thought the makeup was superb, and Tim Roth's Gen. Thade was an outstanding nemesis to Mark Wahlberg's Capt. Leo Davidson. Michael Clarke Duncan was a GREAT Gorilla! I think that, as long as you don't try to compare it to the original, you will enjoy this movie.

This is a good movie.  I love Tim Burton's style.  The character's were good, the scenery(as always in a Burton movie, especially Batman).  It was very cool.  Everything was all good until...the ending. That came outta left- field.  I won't tell you guys the ending but, let me till you that it had me and other people little confused on how it happened.  The score is GREAT. Danny Elfman rules. The score is a little like Batman.  Also, the opening Credits are EXACTLY like Batman, which is great. 8/10- Go check it out.

i have been a long time fan of tim burton, he has a very vivid imagination and his films always have a style that is unlike any around them. that being said Planet of the Apes looks great. it has burtons usual flair and his almost always present scarecrow figure. however the dialogue and meaning of the film falls flat on its face. a lot of this, in my opinion, stems from the fact that it had a pg-13 rating and seemed to try to be a film that pleased the majority of the population. this is the second film in as many weeks that i have seen that has presented a beautiful visual presentation, only to be sucked into mediocrity(or worse, as final fantasy proved). had burton and his writers attempted to make this a more intellectual film it could have been grand, however as it stands it is simply a "popcorn" film with a lot of let down. the score by burtons usual Mr Elfman should be noted as being great as always.

Like almost every viewer of the latest "Planet of the Apes" who has chosen to comment on the film, I too have been disappointed by the latest version, seeing how it falls short of the freshness that Tim Burton brought to many of his films. In some respects though, I am not as harsh in my criticism as others.It is naive to compare Burton's latest film to his more offbeat successes like "Ed Woods," "Edward Scissorhands," and "The Nightmare Before Christmas". Those were personal projects, conceived and driven by him, not projects like the "Batman" films which were studio-driven and intended, first and foremost, as money machines. As such, it was highly unlikely that he would have been allowed a great deal of license. (Remember the fate of his planned version of "Superman" with Nicholas Cage? I'm sure Burton does.)However, Burton *can* be faulted in two places. First, the one point in the story where originality and daring might have played a role was in the Leo/Ari/Daena relationship. I wouldn't call it a love triangle--even though it was promoted as such--since Wahlberg's Leo never registers any particular emotion towards either female. Part of this must be attributed to the script which doesn't give him any lines or action to suggest attraction towards either Bonham-Carter's Ari or Estella Warren's Daena (though that a more resourceful actor could have communicated something nonverbally).Despite having Bonham-Carter display obvious interest in Wahlberg, Burton fails to follow through by having his Leo reciprocate (or at least display ambivalence about a female chimp flirting with him).
The studio's reported objections to a graphic love scene are not surprising. What *is* strange is why Burton introduced the idea and then failed to develop it. Certainly a skillful director can explore the idea of such an unusual relationship without resorting to explicit sex; but Burton just teases us with the idea and then drops it.Equally disappointing is the ending. While I will not divulge it, I think it is enough to say that it has no meaningful connection to what precedes it. A "problematic" ending of a film at least allows workable interpretations. Burton's ending does not. A *major* flaw in any sort of story.

reviews.review_title: mark wahlberg is a heck of an actor.
reviews.content: At first i thought this movie sucked, but the longer it went to the more i realized how well it was written.  I am 18 yrs old i watched this film with 5 other peers.  i am the only one who liked this movie.  i think this film is great.  it had some low points but overall it was worth the 7 dollars i paid to see it.  if i had to pay to watch it again i would.  this isn't like the original planet of the apes, this is not a sequel and the ending is what makes me like this film more and more.  i think that anyone who is openminded and likes sci-fi movies will love this film.  overall i thought this was a good movie.

reviews.review_title: Awful remake of great sci-fi classic
reviews.content: I've just seen the movie, and man did I sit through one of the most tasteless, tacky, non-inspired remake of one of the great sci-fi classics there is out there...I know it's tough to make a good remake of an older film, with regards to the conflict between fans of the original film and the fans of modern-day action, blockbuster movies, but - come on! A total rip-off of the original plot, except for the classic ending which had to be different since the ending was so surprising and by now well-known in the original, an un-inspired casting (lets face it; Mark Wahlberg will not be remembered for his great acting skills) and an over-all feeling of "Oh, I know what's going to happen next" throughout the movie. I felt totally cheated and exploited after coming out of the theatre!My five cents worth to you: Save your money, it's not worth it!

reviews.review_title: Go Bananas! Go Ape! Just go see this movie!!
reviews.content: First up. I don't think this is as good as Burton's other work. Edward Scissorhands has been his best so far- I think because it was his concept, it was so bizarre and yet he made a boy with Scissorhands the most emotionally engaging story I have ever seen. As the critics said "beauty told in simplicity".Planet of the Apes (POTA) is very distinctive from the opening credits as a Burton film. There are elements of 2001: A Space Odyssey and other little movie references to be found throughout the film. Wahlberg is ideal as the Taylor/Leo character. As an actor he can't go as far as some others but the role is suitable for him. The supporting cast are excellent as apes/chimps/gorillas- the whole bag of bananas. While some will see their antics and comments as corny or cliche, keep in mind this is Burton's own vision (reimagining- that itself is now a cliche!) of Boulle's original novel "Monkey Planet".The social comments are very clever and will have you chuckling at certain points. Look out for a classic moment where Burton's partner Lisa Marie performs an exotic ape dance for her man, err ape, err orangutang. The make up is amazing and the set design of Ape City is very stylish. The only quarm I have with it, is it comes across as more like "Ape Housing Commission" because it seems so small or claustrophobic.The story is strong, but missing certain power in some parts- however where one element weakens, Burton knows how to fill the screen with something else to take your attention away. I have no doubt in saying Rick's makeup will score him a 2002 Oscar at the Mann Chinese Theatre, not to mention a few others possibly for other areas....And the ending. Oh, the ending. Many will not like the ending, but many will be very intrigued. I thought the ending was unreal- totally Burton!I definately reccomend you go see this film. It is one of the better films of the year. It is not Burton's best, and in a way he has slipped. But we are talking about Burton here, so rest assured he will quickly pick himself back up and create something BRILLIANT again! I'd give it 7 out of 10 bananas.

reviews.review_title: Buy or rent the original, please!
reviews.content:
Having seen Planet of the Apes 2001 I decided to rent the original series (not having seen them since the age of eight). I suppose I should thank Tim Burton for that.Burton has produced a standard "good versus bad" action flick, with special effects and stunts succeeding each other rapidly (presumably to distract from the lack of dialogue or characterisation). It is a shame on at least two counts: one would expect more of Tim Burton (this is a film Emmerich would make); more importantly it lacks the ambiguity and moral challenges of the original series. General Thade is wicked and our hero (whose name I fail to remember) is resourceful, brave and no doubt washes behind his ears.
As I say, stunts, special effects, make up, the occasional twist. Like anyone of a dozen films every summer. Get the original.

I went into this movie not expecting very much, and came out with the same attitude. This movie was predictable and boring. Three major flaws stood out for me. #1. How did horses, exactly the same kind as we have here on Earth, evolve on this planet, when no other animals seemed to? What did the horses eat, is their food from the jungle or the desert? #2. How did Leo grow no facial hair in this entire movie, which I am assuming spanned a larger amount of time then a day. #3. Was it just me, or did nobody else miss the character development of Estella's character? At the end of the movie, when she kissed Leo, I realized I had yet to learn what her name was. My rating: 2 stars

This was a good movie visually speaking.  However, the jumping monkeys got old after a while.  Maby if they had a monkey saying some old cliches... oh wait, that's what they did.  It's just too bad they had an 8 year old write the dialogue for the movie.  I didn't pay to see a new take on a pop-classic just to get cliches tossed at me for a couple of hours.  Not even all the special affects could cover the corny dialogue used to try to make this movie funny.

reviews.review_title: It's not Scottish so it must be....Crrrrrraaap!
reviews.content: This was so inane and awful I actually for fun starting picturing Jean-Claude Van Damme in it for laughs. I think what's so flabbergasting about it's awfulness is it's the same director who brought us Edward Scissor Hands and Sleepy Hollow. How did such cheesy dialog and typical action movie twists and turns get by him. Maybe they should never give large action movies to more artistic smaller budget directors. They get so swallowed up the studio machine protecting it's investment in a franchise and happy meal tie-ins kinda way. I bet someone like John McTiernan might have actually been a better choice. We'll have to see what he does for Rollerball. This movie makes Mighty Joe Young look like a Dickens classic.

reviews.review_title: SPOILER ALERT - interpretation of the ending
reviews.content: ************SPOILER ALERT******************This is my interpretation of some of the events about the movie that people have argued about here.Go to the next review if you don't want to know what happens in the movie!First off, I don't believe that Leo (Wahlberg) ever goes to the future. Sure you see the year in the ship fly up, but I still don't believe he went into the future.  I believe he actually goes into the distant past, on Earth.  Why else would there be humans (and monkeys, as noted in one conversation) on that planet?  All the humans on the ship were killed by Zemos.  It's too hokey to think there are humans on another planet.  By the time Marky Mark gets there, the humans will have learned the English language that the apes had been speaking all this time, thanks to the brain enhancements the ship scientists had been making to the apes.At the end, Leo goes back to the present-time of the movie (2100something, I don't remember) and lands on Earth, as the monitor on his ship stated.  He never notices he landed on Earth the first time, because he was going after Alpha Pod, and was busy trying to land safely, etc.  And in one scene in the beginning, the people in the Obeuron start getting the signals on their monitors that are showing all the events of Earth's past - hence, giving Thade and his future generations, the idea to construct things like the Lincoln Memorial and cop cars, etc (ok, it's strectching a bit, but it still works).So basically, if Leo didn't chase after the chimp, thus having the crew chase after him and crash land on ancient Earth, and if humans weren't trying to manipulate the Apes' brains chemically, the Apes would not have evolved, and in the end they would not have taken over the Earth.The movie, especially the ending, which I thought was a little silly, but still satisfied me, makes a lot of sense when you think that he actually never did go into the future in the first place, but the past instead.Which brings this movie to the same lesson that the original one did: Humans are always F-ing themselves over....Oh yeah, I gave it a 9 out of 10.

First off I expected a good movie, similar to the other movies from Tim Burton.  There wasn't much good in this movie that I could see. It starts off with a space ship that has a strange resemblance to the Quake symbol.  The space ship also somehow has gravity even though it doesn't spin or have any explanation as to how gravity is achieved.  The other thing that was kinda weird was that Marky Mark puts on a space helmet right over his t-shirt so if he was actually exposed to space he would die, it didn't even seal.Okay, the movie is okay, the costumes, and masks are great.  But obviously all the budget went to those rather than making a good movie.  It had great potential but just never got to the good level.The time travel isn't explained well enough and the obvious screwy ending is setting the viewer with a to be continued feeling. Suggesting that maybe a sequel will be coming even though most sequels are terrible.  The movie had too much money making stuff in it and not enough Tim Burton.If you want to see this movie I would suggest waiting until the video comes out because I felt like I was always one step ahead of the movie, including the ending.  It was not worth $8!

What a disappointment, especially in light of the budget provided, the technical resources available, and the talent assembled.  Isn't the fundamental rule for science fiction/drama to create in the audience the willing suspension of disbelief.  POA 2001 creates a plausible beginning, suckering us in, but thereinafter Mr. Burton forgets that his moviegoers have working brains.  The over the top libertarian of Helena Bonham Carter's chimp, the worthlessness of the humans' lockup, the ease of their escape, their extraordinary skills of horsemanship (this is an astronaut and a group of human primitives suddenly riding full tilt), the massive and immediate human rebellion all are too unbelievable.  Mark Wahlberg never once projects any sense of real fear, danger or comeuppance in this world turned upside down.  Compare to the original, in which Chuck Heston's nakedness metaphorically captured his utter helplessness and astonishment at his turn of events.  The uniformed Wahlberg preserves his modesty, but also his apparent sense of management and control in an inherently wacky situation, and we never really wonder about his well being.  Unlike Heston, he seems never to be in real jeopardy.  Tim Burton should have used some of the f/x budget for some competent screenwriting.  In fact, after this inferior fiasco, I wonder why Hollywood's producers ever bothered to settle the screenwriters and directors strike threats. Let them walk.  Trained monkeys could have done as well as they did in Planet of the Apes 2001.  I'll bet the repeat viewings of this effort will be nonexistent.  It could have been a new franchise, and a wonderful new step for imagination.  Another opportunity lost.

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton, Please Help Me, I'm Freaking Out Over Here!
reviews.content:
***SLIGHT SPOILERS*** Well, I'm not going to lie to you but, YES, I did enjoy this movie. The special affects were decent to good, the makeup was excellent, and the scenery had some room for improvement. Characters such as Thade(Roth), Attar(Duncan), and Ari(Carter) were mostly flawless, With my hat going off to Mr. Roth for his more than excellent portrayal of the "Ape General". Leo(Wahlberg) was well... about what I expected from Wahlberg (He was a better Dirk Diggler then Leo Davison), and Daena(Warren) was either to attractive for her part, or should have had more lines, (i may have enjoyed this movie more if her and her family were developed a little more) but whose to complain. This movie also laid good homage to the original '68 version, especially With Heston's small part as Thades father. No matter what others may say, Yes I liked the original just as much, however, i think the whole way the plot unfolded was definitely more complex then its predecessor. This version doesn't only question race(which it may or may not supposed to do), however it definitely questions religion and evolution more.
I'm not going to bore everyone reading this huge comment on plot summary, because you'll be able to read in in 99% of the other reviews on this movie.
On the other hand getting to the ending. Someone please tell me what Burton was thinking. Not that it was bad, but what does he want people to think happened. Some people say it was obvious that it was Earth all along, but could you be sure of it, I distinctly remember seeing two moons ( I even went to see the movie twice just to prove to myself that they were there) It couldn't be earth with 2 moons could it?? So maybe its not earth that they're on the whole time but, first of all where do they get horses, was that the only animal oiginally there? And how did Thade get to earth and lead a revolution? Does he brake out or is he lead out, and by himself find a way to do space travel to earth, somehow to lead a revolution of apes on earth?Who knows maybe When Leo passed through the electrical storm he passed between parallel universes, or dimensions. Does he even land back on earth? Maybe he lands back on the same planet in the future and they have similar statues to earth??? Am I just looking in to it to far. I wish Tim Burton would just give us a straight answer, Please oh Please, don't ruin it with sequels. Tim if your out there just tell me what you wanted everyone to think, because personally my mind is going in circles trying to pinpoint what the explanation, Hey maybe its just to be left open with the intention to drive us to think about it this much.8.5/10 (It had some room for improvement, but it makes you think(For me way to much).)

Characters such as Thade(Roth), Attar(Duncan), and Ari(Carter) were mostly flawless, With my hat going off to Mr. Roth for his more than excellent portrayal of the "Ape General". WoW.....Oscar material for best phony art design...director..Tim Barfon..Best Actor Mark Wallflower...(Diggler)then Sound and Costume...a music score that you just have to run to the store and buy the sound track for and after spending $31.75 on tickets and food.....an Oscar to the guy in promotions who thrilled us with movie trailers to see this piece of garbage. "Applause please". **Spoiler** there's a sequel coming...BEWARNED..BEWARE..BECAREFUL...because in 2 years counting inflation of the dollar this trash will cost you $65.50 and a smiling ape will take your ticket stub at the door. Proof that the future does belong to the primates.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the worst dreck I have seen this year
reviews.content: I debated through the whole movie, "should I leave this mind numbing experience, or might I miss something original and entertaining appear?" Alas, the answer was... I should have left.Mark Walhberg again shows he can't act his way out of a .... paper bag? When he is attempting to show pain, his pathetic grimace looks like an act. When he attempts to lead the humans in the final confrontation, you can see what's going through his head: Hmmm, I can't act, let alone lead this rag tag bunch of humans. I HAVE NO COURISMA.Then there are the technical issues regarding the pod, able to fly about like a space ship in and out of the atmosphere? At least Charlton Heston had a real ship to crash into the earth with. And then there are the  plot holes and contrivances I could drive a Mack truck through. Arggg, enough.Sorry for any errors, omissions, or spelling mistakes.

reviews.review_title: All Window Dressing, No Substance Here!
reviews.content: So sad! As a fan of the original, and Tim Burton as well, I had high hopes for this movie.  Well, dispense of any ideas of suspense or sci-fi drama! This movie is totally predictable, but COMPLETELY, TOTALLY, nonsense.  It has become a complete fantasy, with no tie in to reality or logic that made the original so compelling.OK, the filming and mood is nice, but the story is so stupid you will cry.Save your money.  Rent it later if you have to.  But take my word...one of the biggest disappointments awaits you here.Soon to be covered by MST3K!!

Wow, what a bummer! As I am a fan of the original, 1968, movie, I was excited when I heard they were doing a re-telling. I thought that with today's effects technology, and a story idea as compelling as Planet of the Apes, I thought there was no way this could fail. But boy was I wrong. There is utterly no character development aside from pointing out to us who are the villains and who are the heroes. There was no motivation for General Thade's (Tim Roth) hatred or Ari's (Helena Bonham Carter) great compassion. To call the plot shallow would be to imply that there was any substance at all. And all the inside jokes concerning the original series got old, too. However, nice touch having Charlton Heston appear in a cameo as General Thade's dying father. Mark Wahlberg, who has consistently turned in very good performances in films like "The Perfect Storm" and "Fear," falls flat with a one-note character stolen from the pages of a comic book.Sure, the effects were great and the costumes were superb, but no matter how much make-up they pancaked onto my grandfather at his funeral, he was still lifeless, as was this film. All in all, a disappointment; no drama, no suspense, no depth of plot. Just another forgettable action film. My rating: D.

reviews.review_title: Well made movie even though it was full of holes.
reviews.content: This movie was extremely entertaining to watch.  Mostly, it was quality filmmaking.  The story is definitely lacking in several places and you really have to forgive certain things that don't make sense but it makes a great summer blockbuster.  It is absolutely worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: Burton spins the boredom out of the original.
reviews.content: I was only seven years old when the original "Planet of the Apes" was released in 1968 and, compared to other films of that era ("2001, A Space Odyssey,"  "Bullitt,"  "You Only Live Twice," etc.) I was able to recognize "Planet" for what it was: pure, unadulterated schlock, and boring schlock at that.  The sorry parade of Ape movies that followed into the '70s was my first experience with Hollywood's "Sequel System" of pumping as much revenue as possible from any spavined idea that is a hit with audiences.  This may, in fact, have been an early iteration of that now-standard practice.Needless to say, I had no expectation of anything more than a mild diversion when I wandered into a matinee showing of Tim Burton's take on this shriveled old chestnut. To my surprise, and despite the fact that Mark Wahlberg sleep-walked his way through the entire movie, it worked a lot better than the original.  General Thade (Tim Roth) is by far the most engaging character in the movie, and the only one that overcomes his ape makeup with an identifiable personality. I was almost rooting for HIM by the end of the movie.Burton's portrayal of the preening, officious Ape Elite and their personal habits is a sly look at some of our own human foibles. I recognized a couple of ex-bosses during those scenes. Original cast member and current NRA President Charleton Heston has a cameo that becomes hilarious when he shows son Thade his "proof" of human ingenuity. I wonder how many viewers missed the humor in that because they are ignorant of Heston's NRA activities? It's refreshing to see an actor of his age and station who is able to poke fun at himself.Happily, this "homage" to the original carries enough originality to keep it interesting (let's just say there was never a Statue of Liberty on this planet) and has better pacing and a lot more action than the original. The effects are seamless and there is enough humor to break up any monotony.The movie climaxes about 10 minutes before it ends, which is too bad. The last few scenes are a total throwaway (and perhaps a foreshadowing of the dreaded Sequelitis), but hey, we can't all be Shakespeare all of the time.

The previews of this movie were very promising: directed by Tim Burton, with such stars as Helena Carter and Tim Roth, and a huge budget for special effects, it had the potential to be one of the year's hits.  However, a smarter move on the part of the directors would have been to scrap the film, and screen the preview in theaters.  This film in the region of the worst film I have ever seen.  Mark Wahlberg, as usual, adds nothing to the film with his despicable acting and moronic facial expressions, except the impression that he is severely constipated; Tim Roth (who has contributed to such great films as Reservoir Dogs and Little Odessa) was physically painful to watch; and I still don't understand why they bothered to include Helena Carter in the cast at all.  It takes a flight of the imagination to imagine Tim Burton saying "cut!" on the set, and being pleased with what he had created.  Bottom line: DO NOT SPEND ANY MONEY ON THIS FILM.  The actors are pathetic, the new ending is as pointless as it is absurd, and Tim Burton should beat himself in the face with a frying pan for this one.

This movie is one of the most horrible movies I have seen in a very long time.  From the very beginning of the film, it is obvious that Planet of the Apes is just another costly bloated piece of trash that Hollywood has been quite adept at producing in recent times (Phantom Menace anyone?).  Tim Burton's stamp is all over this movie.  However, his style (along with Danny Elfman's great music) hardly make up for one of the silliest and emptiest scripts ever.  How in the world did it take 3 people to write the cliched dialogue and come up with the completely improbable scenes that saturate this movie?  Everyone screams, "Wow, the special effects were awesome!" The special effects were great, but special effects do not a movie make (Phantom Menace anyone, again?). To make things worse, the ending of the movie was so open that you can see at least nine sequels coming out of it.  I sincerely hope that the makers of this film will reconsider making any more movies like this one, and I hope Tim Burton will go back to making better films.

reviews.review_title: These were always bad movies, the good kind of bad.
reviews.content: I remember renting and re-watching all of the VHS movies before I even went near the theater to see this one. Yes people the movie is bad and cheesy and whatever else you'll make of it, but many seem to forget that is exactly what we have always loved about these films. This addition does not ruin the series at all it just adds on a slightly prettier addition to the wonderfully awful movies we have always enjoyed. The acting is decent and the action is fun so take a moment and remember that these movies were never as splendid as they are in our hearts. Just try to enjoy the movie and stop fighting it because of its style.

reviews.review_title: Don't compare to original, don't hold against it
reviews.content: This reimagining is sheer eye candy, but through the surreal direction of Tim Burton's past features, what is wrong with this? The original 1968 film was heavy on themes of social tension, the hierarchy of class systems, and evolution. In my opinion, there is no need to improve on the first film simply because there was no room for improvement. It seems that this film is designed for popcorn summer entertainment and it does not sell short of this intention. Tim Burton's dark vision is one of the strongest directorial forces of all time. Whether it's the dark comedic tone of "Beetlejuice" or the ethereal romanticism of "Edward Scissorhands", the man is genius and "Planet of the Apes 2001" is no exception. I do forgive him for "Mars Attacks" though.

I'm ambivalent about which of the two is more significant: It's a beautiful movie, but the story has more holes than swiss cheese.I was impressed by the production values: the makeup, sets, editing, and such. I'm less sure about the costumes. (Most outfits appear to look like they're made primarily from vinyl.) In many ways, it's visually stunning. A lot of the things they did with ape culture, modes of expression, even movement were very creative. Though some turned out silly, like the "running".The acting was, on balance, pretty good. Some of the characters were preposterous (even ignoring the ape makeup), but in particular Tim Roth and (in stark contrast) Paul Giamatti were amazing in their roles. In some sense, just the variety of personalities shown in the apes was impressive.But the story had holes in it bigger than the ones the spaceships flew through. While I understand that it's a fantasy, rather than SF, given the "auteur", the inconsistencies in the plot, if you will, were too much for me. I can suspend disbelief for the big things, but the details are too much to handle. (Some of these questions may be spoilers.) How did the apes become masters of vinyl-making, when they can't produce a decent knife? Where did the horses come from? And for that matter, where were the gorillas from? Their "escape route" from the city was laughable. The climactic battle was *terrible*! And the "twist" at the ending evoked more stupefied laughter than awed thrill.Maybe upon repeated viewing, I can gloss over these flaws, but I don't think so.

First of all: I'm a HUGE fan of the original 1968 POTA. And this is not a remake of that movie. It's simply a reinvention of the same story, filtered through the eyes of one of the most creative Hollywood directors. Everything in this show work in a perfect way: the screenplay is inventive and brilliant. All the performers gave their best, in particularly Tim Roth portraing the main villain, General Thade, and Helena Bonham Carter under the make-up of the kind chimp Ari. Costumes, art direction, special effects are amazing! Great part of the success of this film is due to the wonderful make-up effects by the genial wizardy of Rick Baker and the complex score composed by the talent of the sublime Maestro Danny Elfman. Main titles (music and images together) are simply astonishing! Absolutely a must see by all the fans of fantastic cinema. Rating: 9/10.

Misguided rehap of the 1968 film gives the apes more character than the humans! Wahlberg is underwritten as the astronaut who has only one major objective: get the hell out of there. Movie doesn't quite surface as potential genius, lacking thought and enigma that could leave it memorable. Still, Burton's own slick style and ambitious special effects make for a fun romp. Excellent, necessary score by Danny Elfman carries the film well.

reviews.review_title: I cannot believe how bad this movie was
reviews.content: Let me just start of by saying that this movie was a total waste of time, money, effort and was possibly the biggest dissapoinment I have ever seen.With all the hype behind the movie I expected a lot, and I mean a whole lot more out of this.  The acting was second rate at best, characters were so predictable, and the plot so thin that I was about ready to get up and leave 1/2 way through the movie.  How many of you out there actaully managed to predict the movies ending at about the half way point???  And the Ka Li Ma thing?  Makes you think they ripped that off from Star Trek when the spacecraft came looking for "v y ger".Absolutley no premise was given to the scientific background that would make such a series of events possible.  Not just the time shift but the whole evolution of monkeys into something more.  If in the thousadn years or so that the monkeys had become dominate then why had the humans not also changed?  Wouldnt the humans be a lot smaller and dumber?  And all the perfect teath in the movie?If you have to see it wait for the video to go into the $.99 special of the week section.

I thought that the movie was great. Being a big fan of the first movies. I was happy wish the new version. I can't wait for a sequel. It was different then the first in that it gave a great leads into sequels. Like why was the planet uninhabited at first and the end had a great twist to start right there. The Apes themselves were outstanding. I love that Charlton Heston was in the movie and thought all of the main characters were great. I would say that everyone should own a copy of this DVD. It will make you wish you had seen it on the big screen (I did so I am happy). The only bad thing is that instead of being 2 hours long it should have been four.... lol... then i wouldn't have to start it over so soon and have a larger story line.

reviews.review_title: Not the disappointment purists make it out to be.
reviews.content: Is a movie bad if it doesn't live up to its ideal potential? No. Does "Apes" live up to such a potential? Not quite. Is Burton's "Apes" a bad film? Absolutely not. And this coming from one of the original's biggest fans. Where the original Apes film (note that I only refer to the first of the original series...no business involving underground A-bomb zealots or Ricardo Montalban as a circus master in this review, thank you very much) was more character driven and used social and political issues as its driving force, Burton opts for a richly visualized, humor-laced action film that features more Saturday-matinee gusto than most films I've seen in a long while. It's a different flavor of ice cream from the first folks, and it's still tasty. And while I won't give away the much-talked-about twist ending--which I quite enjoyed--I managed to find a perfectly logical (though mightily implausible) explanation for how it could have happened...and before the final credits even began rolling (based on elements laid out earlier in the film.) Misters Burton and Broyles must have done something right if I reached such a conclusion that quickly...and if I'm right, and they've done what I think they've done for the reasons I think they did them in that finale, I personally would love to see a sequel. On a scale of 1 to 10, I give this "Apes" a solid 8.

Expecting an enjoyable evening of cinema-going, i went to see Planet of the Apes. Last week I saw Sleepy Hollow for the 5th time, so I hoped (and expected) for some more Burton-magic. When I left for home I had seen almost none of that.First the story. The script had to many flaws. During the whole movie the story stays mainly too shallow, for instance the character of Leo is always two-dimensional. I also missed some big-scenes. Their were just a few moments in the movie that 'resparked'the movie. Also Burton could have done better, for instance the big fight-scene could have been a lot better. Also disappointing was the scenery, it looked like a set all the way. The acting was mainly poor, Wahlberg en Bonham-Carter can be good actors, but this time he couldn't convince me. Warren was a big laugh. The exception was of course Tim Roth. Maybe sometimes over the top, but in general great.
In general: 4,5/10

This movie sucks.  The plot is W-E-A-K and rife with holes.  The acting was on par, but the script was horrible.  With so many writers, how could it be so bad?  One can only guess that so much attention was paid to the makeup (fantastic) that a good script was overlooked.Tim Burton has officially sold out and Mark Wahlberg is capable of so much more when he has a good script to work with and a director more concerned with storytelling than points on the back end.If you just HAVE to see "Planet" on the big screen, save some money and go see a matinee.  Or better still, just wait until "Chimp Week" on Animal Planet.

Tim Burton's new remake of Planet of the Apes is pretty disappointing... visually interesting but shallow.  It really doesn't explore the issues of the day as did the original.  In fact, it's best moments were based on contrived references to the original with familiar dialogue. Interestingly, the only people in the theatre laughing when those references were made were my friends and I (proving my contention that we were among the oldest attendees).  Sadly though, most of these high school students will never see the original and won't know what they're missing.  This film is predictable at just about every turn...  lacking any of the punch that allowed the original to hit audiences with its stunning visual revelation at the end. This movie should have been be more than an opportunity for the makeup artists to remind us that it's 2001 and not 1968.  Shame on Tim Burton for not engaging the challenge!

There was virtually no character development.  Especially with some of their actions you really need that to get anything out of the story.  The ending meant nothing to the story, only to set up a sequel.  Nothing in the movie will make you think on any profound level.  I left the theater thinking it was an OK movie, but for no real reason.

reviews.review_title: Another attempt at a remake of a great film that ultimately fails
reviews.content: Usually they blame the director when a film goes awry...but I'm afraid that this time the blame must be put on the moviegoing audience. I actually can't believe the overwhelmingly positive response by fans and critics alike to this movie!Okay...it looks great...but there are several major flaws...first, did anyone else notice how a few of the apes (Paul Giamatti's "Limbo" in particular) too closely resembled The Grinch?...second, notwithstanding the great acting by Tim Roth, everyone else seemed stiff as a board...third, and most importantly, and without revealing the ending, did anyone else notice how preposterous it was for that ending to be possible? There is NO possible way that the events at the end of the film could have followed anything that came before it. Instead of a twist ending that meant something, we are left with a sense of confusion that seems to have been tagged on to make jaws drop...until common sense prevails and you realize that they couldn't figure out how to end it in a realistic manner.I guess that the average moviegoer will walk away semisatisfied at what amounts to little more than style prevailing over substance...something we have too long settled for...but as always, most people will forget about it as soon as the next overblown hyped summer blockbuster comes along!

The 1968 version was truly a sci-fi masterpiece. The remake however, was not. The fact that the humans were not mute was completely un-disturbing, and meant that some terrible dialogue was included. As humans go, the acting was woeful, especially Estella Warren's performance. On the positive side, the special effects were impressive, the soundtrack was flawless and the ending was a welcomed shock, however this less than makes up for the rest of the movie. A huge disappointment for fans of the original movie series.

reviews.review_title: Mark Wahlberg a bit wooden - watch the original first
reviews.content: In this version the ending is not the same as the original.  However I would strongly recommend watching the original first as it develops the idea of the human/animal relationship being turned upside down.  The original has same corny lines but that was 1968, filmakers nowadays should have no excuse.

reviews.review_title: PoTA - Never send a monkey to do a man's job
reviews.content: I wanted PoTA to be my favourite film of the year, which on reflection it probably ended up being. Lacking the originals social comment, and released at a time when the World's social ills and insurgency are less than in Charlton's '68 original, the film nevertheless provided good action sci-fi and a clever (if not a bit confusing) ending.HBC gave a good performance, and Roth probably outshone Wahlberg as the mean and devious Thade. A great looking film, well delivered by Tim Burton, who was the ideal director to carry the primate adventures into 2000.Burton brought subtle humour to the film (which I had anticipated being a lot darker than it turned out). The orang-utan love pastiche, the little girl as a pet, and the two card playing apes - one calling the other a "Cheater" (Cheetah).A lot of acknowledgements were given to it's father film. Several quotes and a cameo Heston. I preferred the fact that the apes on Burton's planet were unarmed, other than with clubs, the original (especially the TV series had them kitted out with all sorts of weaponry). It was a shame one of the original underlying mantra of "ape shall never kill ape" was dropped, but by and large it stayed relatively true to it's original.Overall: A good re-working. 8/10

Lots of action, a great sound track , special effects and make up, made this film an enjoyable two hours on a hot July evening. Helena Bonham Carter as Ape Avi is wonderful...so were the apes of Tim Roth and Michael  Clark Duncan. Very menacing for sure. Tim Burton has done a fine job putting this remake together.I rated an 8 out of 10. Visually, it won't disappoint anyone. If you like action and fighting, it is here also.

I am bothered by the perception of almost everybody seeing this movie. The misconception of this is that it is a remake of the original movie. It is NOT! It is his own perception of the book. I think it was well done. People, when you watch this movie, keep that in mind. IT IS NOT A REMAKE!!!!! I am not a huge fan of Wahlberg, but he still seems to do well in this film. I also agree that the effects were extremely impressive. And if you need help figuring the end, it is easy. What happened is that you don't see that the General was able to travel back and take over and change the planet. You are not meant to see it when it happens. So when you see this movie, don't compare it, take it on it's own merit.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as everybody thinks, but...
reviews.content:
Okay, so I have seen the original and therefore am unquestionably biased, but I have read other reviews and I would just like to say that I DON'T think Tim Burton should be shot.Of COURSE it was hyped up to be more accomodating to Hollywood, and of COURSE Tim Burton wasn't going to simply "Cut & Paste" from the original, so DON'T go see it thinking it's the original with nicer makeup. It's not.But it's not a load of crap, either!! I don't think the characters were as shallow as has been said, and frankly, I am not embarrassed to admit that General Thade scared the bejeezus outta me. Seriously!I wasn't expecting this to turn into my favorite movie, so maybe that's why I actually liked it. I only have ONE major gripe, and that is:
SPOILER ALERT!! SPOILER ALERT!!Why why why why WHY a Lincoln Memorial scene which I STILL don't understand rather than the epic, dramatic and mindboggling Statue of Liberty scene??????!!!!!! Damn them! Damn them!! Damn them all to HELL!!
Thank you.

reviews.review_title: Visual achievement make up for plot deficiencies
reviews.content: I must say, after seeing the PotA edition of Exposure I took their advice and went into the movie without considering that this was the second adaptation of a French novel from the sixties--trying to watch it as if it were an original script.  That gave me no expectations and disappointment that things were so different.The surprises (including Charlton Heston's cameo) just kept me glued to the screen.  I even enjoyed the ironic twist at the end even if it made very, very little practical sense.  Paul Giamatti deserves extra credit for an outstanding comedic performance.  Tim Roth has never been sexier.My only disappointment was the serious lack of explanation, mainly toward the end.  I think they allowed way too much freedom for our imagination and we deserve to know just how (...)Rich Baker can look forward to his Seventh Oscar for Best Makeup at next year's Acadamy Awards.

reviews.review_title: Great movie with a rotten ending
reviews.content: Let me start of by saying that I loved everything about this movie except for the ending.  The ending made me think of a line from a Bette Midler concert film that goes "What the f---."  The problem is that their is not any logical explanation to this films ending (to say more would mean giving a major spoiler to the film).  It seems that Tim Burton and company felt they had to have a stunning ending like in the original "Planet of the Apes" but it doesn't work (unlike like in the original where the surprise was quite logically explained to the audience).With that said please check out this remake because besides for the ending it truly is a great movie.P.S.  Mark Wahlberg once again proves to movie audiences as to how great an actor he truly is.P.P.S.  Mr. Burton when the film is released on DVD would you please record a commentary track in which you explain the ending to this movie.

reviews.review_title: A missed opportunity but fairly enjoyable.
reviews.content: WARNING! PLOT POINTS REVEALED! Hmm, Tim Burton tries his hand at a remake - sorry, "re-imagining" - of the 1968 "classic". Inevitably, comparisons to the original abound, however, not having seen the original thankfully precludes me from such comparisons (though, yes, we all know it was the Earth. damn them).Burton's film is helped firstly by his imagination. The ape abodes and milieu are beautifully and naturally presented. The considerable advances in makeup technology allow more depth of character to be achieved when it comes to the citizens of the ape community, and the sheer variety of simian forms and facial expressions is itself impressive. The only quibble I would highlight is the "muffling" of the actor's voices and the obvious difficulty which they had speaking through the stuff, however this was not too distracting. Wahlberg meanwhile is a sound action hero, but provides little sympathy or interest for the viewer. Bonham Carter is well drawn as the radical humanist ape, but the "semi-romance" between her and Wahlberg seems half-hearted and therefore uninteresting. A rivalry between her and the ridiculously-costumed human love interest is just a waste of time, and the girl really serves no other purpose but eye candy and therefore becomes annoyingly superfluous to proceedings. Roth, however, is superb as General Thade, chewing scenery like nobody's business and delightfully hamming his way through revenge dialogue and lots of shouting and leaping about. His body movements too are by far the most excellently observed.Clearly Burton does not wish us to take the film too seriously, given the comic touches which he has added, which include a slightly farcical (and very predictable) lampoon of the Lincoln memorial. The ending, however, does indeed seem tacked-on - useful for interchangeability (he apparently filmed 4 different ones) but not so good for continuity. Considering Burton had a choice of endings, it would appear that he chose the least original, however, it is refreshingly surprising to find that the ending is not as upbeat as may have been expected from the more sentimental proceedings of the rest of the film. All round this is still a good watch, but you can't help thinking that there was far more potential in the material. Burton avoids re-hashing the political stance of the original, however the result is visually stunning and well imagined but with little beneath the surface. Roth steals the show and provides most of the interest throughout the film, and it's a shame that Wahlberg and Bonham Carter never get much to work with.

reviews.review_title: A set-up for many sequels to come
reviews.content: After seeing this Planet of the Apes, I wonder if they will make 4 sequels to this too. Unlike the original movie, this one leaves you with a lot more questions. At the end of the original, we realized that he was on earth after all. Simple as that. But this movie leaves me with so many questions that I am counting down the days till the next one is released. I compare the ending of this movie to that of the original Star Wars.....abrupt. But I did indeed enjoy the movie, for several reasons. One was the great special effects and terrific Make-up and Costume usage. (Give em the Oscars now). I had to keep reminding myself there were humans under all that make-up. I didnt care too much for the beginning, it just seemed a little far-fetched, like this might have been the best idea out of a bunch of bad ideas on how to begin the film. Man risks life for monkey? As it went on, we saw the viciousness of General Thade and wondered "Whats up his butt"? Although thoroughly p***ed off the entire movie, Thade does display a side of him that is very human. His scene with Heston as his father bleeds with politics, because the one possesion he has of the humans is a gun, and considering its Heston, Pres of the NRA, I couldnt concentrate on what they said to each other, because I was chuckling at the Irony of this scene. Heston saying humans are dangerous for creating this kind of technology? Did I hear that right? Wow...... We have all heard of movies that are too slow. This one went too fast. I wanted more explanations, and more about the apes...the general daily life of these apes is hardly delved into, and we go into the sequels knowing very little about them, except they dont like humans and they screech a lot. The ending did leave a lot of doors open for sequels, but will this movie go down as being better than the original? Probably not. Will this movie be remembered for its stunning visual images? Yes. And thats why you should see it. Dont get too entangled in the plot...because you will be tangled for a while. Enjoy the movie, and wait for the sequels to explain what we dont know.

You wanna see a bunch of guys in ape suits?  Okay, this is your film.  You wanna see good acting?  Go far far away, as far as you can from this movie. The only one worth his weight in bananas is Tim Roth, but don't go expecting to see his Four Rooms/Resevoir Dogs personality because you'll never recognize him.  Kudos to Roth for actually ACTING.  Everybody else, well, I stick out my tongue and beat my chest at you.  And who would have thought that all of Charleton Heston's classic lines would be hijacked by the apes themselves?  And this "incredible new twist-ending"?  They could have brainstormed a thousand years and never come up with anything sillier.

reviews.review_title: Pale imitation pulverizes where original mesmerized
reviews.content: A pale imitation of the 60's classic, obviously made only with the intention of raking in big bucks at the box office.  It has no resonance, no spark, no soul.  No reason for being.  I was suckered into seeing it by the promise of Tim Burton's visionary direction; but the end result could have been filmed by anyone (just a few more explosions and it could have been Michael Bay). While sitting through it, I indulged in a fond reverie of watching the original in a theater, way back in the day, mesmerized.  Monkeying around with this classic only left this audience member pulverized.

Sometimes I wonder if people go to the cinema purely for the purpose of moaning and sniping about the films they see. While I will admit that far too many films are moronic today, so to are far too many of the audience. The original Planet of the Apes is undoubtedly a good film with some stunning moments ( it's wonderful how a film gets elevated to the level of masterpiece when people need a reason to moan about its sequel / remake ), but the potential was in the premise for a different type of film. For all the original's strengths I think you'd be hard-pushed to claim it was exciting, or visually interesting. Tim Burton has seized the opportunity to explore these possibilites, resulting in a highly entertaining if undemanding film. As a complete redraft of the original it is ultimately a very different entity, but it in no way embarrasses  the original nor takes anything away from it. Honestly, what do the 'how dare they do this to a classic film' brigade imagine is going to happen? Do they think the original is going to cease to exist? That from now on people will only ever discuss the remake? Unlikely. There is little in this film that will cause much discussion, but then I've never heard anyone discuss the original either. And yes, the ending is obvious and not as good as the first one ( as the most known 'twist' ending of all time they could scarcely have repeated it ), but there is nothing in the original that scarcely comes close to the amusing satire on human behaviour to be found in the first half of Burton's remake. Most important of all (and this goes out particularly to those who decry the tarnishing of the original 'classic'): This movie is FUN. You can't say that for the '68 version...

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton needs Batman and Batman needs Tim Burton
reviews.content: Tim Burton's new vision for the "Planet of the Apes" is completely dumbed down for the increasingly tolerant American movie audience.
