Why can't the studios just bring out the original films, instead of remaking them? I will admit that I went to see this film with as much trepidation as going to see Gus Van Sant's misguided redo of Hitchcock's "Psycho" a few years back. This isn't as bad as that, but it's very close. Franklin Shaffner's original 1968 film is a classic (yes, classic!).  It holds up very well today and should be seen by anyone who hasn't. The new version has none of the political and social satire that makes the original so fun to watch.  I knew that Mr. Burton wouldn't even attempt a political film, so we are left with a fairly mundane film in which our new time traveler encounters a planet ruled by apes, and then immediatly wants to get the hell out of there.  The problem is there is absolutely no danger.  Mark Wahlberg doesn't face immasculation or lobotomy like Charlton Heston faced in the original. He is only faced with a villain that hates humans, but we never find out why.  Tim Roth is quite good in the role, but we need a backstory. The film does brighten up for a few minutes at the midway point, with a brief cameo.  Let's just say it's the best acting in the film. If we are going to have to sit through remake after remake, please let's try to make a film that is inspired.  Tim Burton is a very original filmmaker, who this time out is hampered by a very poor script. If William Broyles cannot come up with anything more witty than an ape saying "Get your stinking paws off me, you damn dirty human!" then perhaps he should start working on that script for "Apollo 13 Part 2" What the audience should be saying is "Keep your stinking paws off of classic movies, you damn stupid producers." In conclusion, I hope that Tim Burton can find some way to get the "Batman" franchise back from Joel Schumacher before he causes any more damage, save Michael Keaton from doing "Jack Frost 2" and stop screwing around with classic films from the past. As for Producer Richard Zanuck: PLEASE DON'T REMAKE 'JAWS'or 'THE STING' Leave those films alone for the love of God. COMING SOON: 'PAPILLON' STARRING LEONARDO DECAPRIO AND JASON BIGGS!!!

reviews.review_title: Typically Burton - huge on style, light on substance
reviews.content: First up, I'd like to say that I liked POTA.  It is absolutely gorgeous to look at.  The make-up, effects, cinematography, costumes and sets are all pretty hard to fault.  On the acting front, Tim Roth is utterly fantastic as General Thade and he just about makes up for the price of admission on his own.So what's the problem?  Well as much as I want Mark Wahlberg star to continue to rise, I just don't think he has the charisma to carry Charlton Heston's role.  Not that he was bad or anything, his acting is fine and he is certainly a lot better looking than Chuck ever was.  But is he really the brave and indignant leader of the human race who defies the apes and their dirty paws?  Maybe he would have been better as the plucky young male that defiantly chases after the hero (read George Clooney) after being told to stay behind with the others?But in Mark's defence, I don't think replacing him would have necessarily made the film any more satisfying.  This was a difficult film (conceptually) to make when you consider how highly the original is regarded.  Do you just remake it with the same emphasis of script and story, or if you are going to do something different, what do you change?So Burton does what he does best and creates a film that emphasises style over story, and action over acting (or actors).  It worked for Batman and I think it does for POTA.  Time will tell after the franchise has come and gone whether people criticise "POTA Forever" as not holding a candle to Burton's original!Enjoyable: 7/10

I've seen a lot of bad movies lately and I refuse to pay full price anymore because the quality is crap!  But this one is truly a stinker for the ages. I am continually amazed that people shell out their hard earned money for a story with so little forethought.There were so few entertaining scenes that I found myself yawning through most of it and just as we seem to reach a (aww) happy ending that explains everything.  Marky Mark flies through the universe in about three minutes, lands on earth, and sets the scene for probably one of the worst sequels that will ever be made (Next to Jurassic Park II of course).Exactly how stew-pod (book reference) do movie makers think we are?  How much crap will we actually put up with before we refuse to go to movies anymore?  Oh yeah, never mind, JP 3 made 80 million last week,  guess that our stupidity has no limits.Save your money, read and book and leave something to the imagination.2 out of 10

reviews.review_title: What's all the fuss about? - it's fine!
reviews.content: I spent a long time reading review's of new new Planet Of The Apes here at IMDB. I got the general impression that this movie was a waste of time. Yes, Estella Warren spent the entire movie uselessly pouting with those inappropriately glossed lips.  Yes, Mark Wahlberg was not nearly as dynamic and emotional as would be expected for someone crash landing on to a strange planet to find himself suddenly faced with ape-rule.However, I still enjoyed the movie very much.  Tim Roth as Thade was a powerhouse, Bonham Carter was good and Michael Clarke Duncan as General Attar was perfectly cast.  He actually made a very funny quote which I read about in a newspaper.  He said "when my agent called me about a part in this movie, I knew I wasn't gonna be no human!"Anyway back to my comment... this is an entertaining movie, yes it is. Purists, please stop this quest for perfection, it doesn't exist, not anymore anyway.  Entertainment is what matters.  Planet of the Apes with Charlton Heston is brilliant, and emotionally stirring, but it is history. Appreciate it, but move on.  Please.

reviews.review_title: I'll be seeing this one again.
reviews.content: This was my most anticipated film of the year and I was not disappointed. Like many others, I have been a huge fan of the original Planet of the Apes since I first saw it in 1968 and had great misgivings about a remake. Once I learned that Tim Burton was to direct I knew that I would be seeing something wonderful. There isn't any other director around today that I would have picked to make this film. I was also delighted to learn that he was not just remaking but re-imagining the entire story which opened up huge possibilities. The result is an exciting, rousing adventure with thought-provoking ideals that set it apart most of the bang and blow-up action films put out today. It manages to keep many of the elements of the original that made it so enduring while adding new twists to the story. The make-up by Rick Baker is astounding. Certainly his best work to date. The cast is uniformly excellent with special kudos to Helena Bonham-Carter, Tim Roth and Paul Giamatti. This film must be seen on the big screen. I'll certainly be seeing it again at least once if not more.

I whole heartedly concur with the user comments dated August 12, 2001 which were printed by Just_Voards.  If you HAVE seen the movie, read their comments as they are spot on and filled with lots of POTA trivia.  If you HAVE NOT seen the movie, see the movie and THEN read Just_Voards comments. Would someone give this writer a newspaper column!?  Well done!!!!

reviews.review_title: A Chance to Go Ape Ruined by Tedious Audience Junkfood
reviews.content:
Contains SpoilersNo one can expect a remake to equal up to the legendary sci-fi classic even with all the special effects and ape costumes in the world. Well considering that Mark Wahlberg doesn't show a single expression beyond stupefied' doesn't help either. It's also his character, Leo Davidson, who gets transported to the future after he dives into a nebula of testosterone.If you need me to explain the plot, go out and rent the 1968 version. But Burton and friends took liberty with adding typical action flick characters and scenes that'd not find home in the 1968 classic. Like General Thade (Tim Roth), who sets himself apart from all other Apes by talking in a series of near incomprehensible grunts. Or Karubi (Kris Kristofferson), who not surprisingly sacrifices himself to save everyone else because he's old (originality?). The movie, like the entire franchise, is hauled into a dark alley and beaten to death, kicking and screaming the entire way.
One thing that I loved so much about the original was it's unique score, primarily composed of drums and horns. The opening of the remake has exactly that, even better. I loved the opening score, yet that's the problem; it was only used during the opening. I faintly remember hearing it in the background for about twenty seconds later in the film. But Burton and Elfman decided to follow traditional boring action movie music, the kind that makes you want to attack the screen in a flurry of shotgun blasts.
I sat bored through most of the movie. It's really really boring; half the scenes are dominated by General Thade bouncing off the walls and howling `Get the humans!' Or Mark Wahlberg (who can't be surprised by anything, even landing on a planet rules by tyrannical apes) heroically taking the lead with lines such as `Uhhwe've gotta escape' Scenes invite groans, such as Wahlberg's insta-army. Once the escaped humans, and their ape companions have made if far enough away from the ape city, an army of humans come to join them. What's so terrible about this scene is that the army comes in from all directions simultaneously. In the next five minutes an army of humans are ready to go. Also, the ape city was walled off, with no room for expansion, what are they trying to wall out? Or in?You may remember Charlton Heston's kiss to Dr. Zira (Kim Hunter) in the original. Considering that Helena Bonham Carter's character Ari is nearly a spitting image of Dr. Zira (the reason why I liked her the most in the film) it isn't surprising that she gets a little smooch from Mark Wahlberg. This is the big disappointment in Burton's `Apes'. Here is a chance to go over the top and really screw with the audience. Why didn't spaceman Leo Davidson sleep with Ari? Instead of kicking the audience in the ass, he's just invited snickers from the audience moms. If you're making a movie about a planet that's ruled by tyrannical monkey-men, how can you not go over the deep end? The 1968 version was a great movie with mixed satire, the remake fails.From the way I sound, you must think I hate this movie. The remake had some redeeming features I loved. I loved the ape costumes and how director Burton used the apes in a more primordial fashion. In the original the apes stood up and ran straight. In the remake Burton lets them run hunched over and perform bouncing leaps. The greatest thing about the remake? The ending of course, I won't spoil it, but it's genius. It doesn't make sense, it doesn't have to (just look at the title to the movie).The remake should've been titled 'Mark Wahlberg vs. the Planet of the Apes' because that's what it is. Instead of producing a social satire that explores dual bestiality and the inner workings of a nations ruled by apes (which would've been great). Burton throws a summer action movie at us with little redeeming features and wooden characters (except Ari, of course).

reviews.review_title: No social elements needed when loving special effects
reviews.content: Just like the other comment states, the movie lacks every kind of characterisation and social statement.In fact, the main characters is in fact seeing how the humans are treated by the apes, thus the apes being treated by humans in our life, and still he doesn't even come close to thinking: aren't we humans doing something wrong in our world?No, he keeps on stating: in our world, the monkeys (and all animals) belong in cages.It is a pitty that the director did not go into this more deeply.It is like watching Animal Farm, but without words, thus being interested only for children.Did I like the movie however? Yes very much ! The special effects are superb, the monkeys are very scaring, Thade is brilliantly casted and acts like he truly is an Ape's general.Really nice when watched in a big cinema with a big screen and great Dolby surround sound!I liked it very much, although it could be a historic movie.Too bad.

reviews.review_title: Not sure if I count this as a reboot anymore.....
reviews.content: So after watching the entire collection in the 'timeline' order... The only way I see this movie fitting in is following the 1974 movie when Cesar learns of the original timeline of his parents. So it's changed and this movie could be explained as one of the "different lanes into the future" as described in the 1973 and 1974 movies.As a movie with in of itself it's still not great. But I do think it has a place in the timeline! But that will only make sense after watching all of them...

I could have never imagined that something more idiotic from "mummie 2" would come to me this year,but it happened...The remake of the famous and outstandingly good "Planet of the apes" from 1968,I think...I went to the cinema anxious,I came out p***ed of.What the hell was that?The incredible "flight to neverland",the characteristics of the apes,idiotic plot and outline,and MOST OF ALL,the image of the true,brave,intelligent,handsome all-American heroe.I wanted to vomit on the carpet and leave the cinema.Like all American air-pilots,this one has a knowledge of pursuading people(apes),making weapons,riding,fighting simultaniosly with 300kg gorillas,natural lidership...Go home Rambo.Make place for one and only captain Leo Davidson!Incredible.And the pure,pure acting of an "Victorias Secret" model goes well with the movie(we all know who that is).The director is a genious of its own kind.Tim Burton.Yeah.I think everyone will notice the unforgettable clishe-scene of the "american airborn" hero on the horse and the sunrise(or sunset,whatever)behind the mountains waiting for the final countdown.Truly original.The only think missing is the pack of Marlboro (welcome to...) and Morricones score from "The good,the bad and the ugly"...

reviews.review_title: Much to like, much to hate
reviews.content: There's a lot to admire about the remake, and a lot to hate.It's an admirable attempt at a re-imagination of the saga but, please - why, oh why, were certain scenes played for laughs?The underlying story is so intrinsically interesting that surely it warranted a serious approach. Do serious approaches exist in modern American cinema? Would "Soylent Green" contain line-after-line of Arnie's witticism if they were to make it now?I'm not a huge Science-Fiction fan - for the most part, because most of these films never suspend my disbelief - but they can work, and they only work when they're played straight.I know that on rewatching the original, many have commented on Heston's bad acting or the film's just plain silliness in places, but give it the one credit it deserves - it played the concept straight-as-die.Most detrimental comments of the original derive from a certain misplace nostalgia:On rewatching, we feel like the film lets us down in some way - That's because our memory of the film is stronger than the film itself, and it tells us that we should expect so much more because the incredible premise of the story has haunted so many of us for so many years.All I asked of the remake was that it treated the story respectfully.I knew I shouldn't go in there expecting a comparable ending or a scene-by-scene remake, but does a re-imagination mean we have to deal with Paul Giammatti's ridiculous slave trader, or Wahlberg's cardboard stock hero one-liners, Heston's embarrassing cameo or the Senator's wife's home-in-the-Hamptons dialogue?Take the remake's phenomenal art-direction, make-up and effects, (and Tim Roth's amazing performance) mix it with the originals heart and you'd have one hell of a movie. Instead we have an off-the-shelf, early 21st century popcorn pusher. Come on Burton, what ever happened to the kind of imagination you had when you enthralled us with Scissorhands?

I expected the new 2001 Planet Of The Apes movie to be a high-tech blast of chills, thrills, and spills.  It had none of that, I was not chilled or spilled.  But I was thrilled at the end! That was pretty cool.  But I won't tell ya anything about the ending so don't worry.  Of course, the ending was nothing compared to the original- (and if you haven't seen the original I won't give that ending away, either.) Some scenes were quite ridiculous, though.  And the storyline was not as good as the original.  Although at least Tim Burton had his own special storyline instead of copying the original's. Overall, it wasn't a bad movie.  If you like movies without blood and a lot of swearing, and you are not totally opposed to science fiction, I think you won't be disappointed, but won't be exactly thrilled either.Not Too Shabby!-madmax-1

The film was decent for a summer movie, but this is not vintage Tim Burton. Too commercial like Mars Attacks.  What is true Tim Burton?  Edward Scissorhands, Batman and Sleepy Hollow.  When I heard that 20th Cent. Fox rushed this movie for a summer release I started to get worried.  Out of all the summer movies this year (which has been a horrible year for movies) this ranks up there with The Score.  THe make-up is some of the best you will ever see and the one of the fun things to do is to guess who is playing the ape.  I would recommend it, but remember it is a true summer movie (bad script, good special effects and some bad acting).

reviews.review_title: More fun than a barrel of...(oh, come on, its funny!)
reviews.content:
I loved the orignal PotA.  But I didn't think it was this magnificent epic that many fans do--I thought it was a fun, cheesy, clever flick with some great societal commentary.  No more, no less.  So, I was not nearly as hopped up about the remake.  Frankly, I assumed it would be a fun, cheesy, clever flick, possibly adding some societial commentary.  And I was right!
I had a ball watching the new PotA.  It was funny, it was clever, and the ape makeup and physical action was brilliant.I think that people were looking for some serious remake, rather than a lighthearted (somewhat--this IS Burton we're talking about) homage.
SPOILER BELOW--YOU HAVE NOW BEEN WARNED, so don't come crying to me if I wrecked the ending for you.  This is your last chance....ok, you really want spoilers, huh?  Good for you!  Suspense is for the weak!Granted, the ending was...well, it was weird.  I personally felt it was predictable.  As the camera lingered on the back of the head, I was silently saying "its an ape, right?"  The fact that I still am a bit hazy about the whole explanation does not lessen my enjoyement of a good darkly ironic twist.  So, was it the same planet after all?  Two different planets?  Did Thade being locked in the control room have something to do with it?  Was the storm a "permannt" one?  If so, dosen't that make it a wormhole or portal or something, rather than "a storm"?  How does this fit in with the general space/time continuum theories?  Did they see any of the myriad Enterprises in there?Aw, who cares, it gives me something to discuss over lattes after the movie. That reminds me, where the hell is my frappachino?!  Ah, there it is, Bubbles.  Thank you, there will be an extra bananna in your paycheck.
Damn dirty apes...he forgot my cinnamon sprinkles!I give this movie a full 10 because I wouldn't change a thing about it. Come on, what did you REALLY expect?  Its a Burton film!  It has RUBBER APE MASKS in it!   IT WAS RELEASED ON THE LAST WEEKEND IN JULY!  Its a summer blockubster homage to a great cheesy flick.  I loved every silly, noisy, ape-intensive minute of it and am looking forward to seeing it again (at matinee price, natch).Ooga ooga.

i went into this movie thinking it would be a good, fun movie, i was way off.  the story was bad, the humor was stupid and it was very predictable. it also had barely any action and way to many apes screaming and howling. i really reccomend not bothering seeing this, especially with the line you have to wait in to just get in.  you may think differently and very much enjoy this movie, but you're probably wrong.

reviews.review_title: possibly a spoiler - fantastic adaption of the original
reviews.content: firstly it has to be said that this is not strictly a remake. it approaches the story from a whole new aspect while paying homage to the original movies (not just the first one), for instance look out for a certain Mr Heston saying a few familiar lines! without giving too much away, the setting of the story is not earth. at first i though "no!!!!!! you cant do that!!" but it does eventually fit itself into the original story, as you will realise when you see the ending. also, if anyone can explain the ending to me i would be grateful! tim roth is excellent, u would not know it was him, the makeup is breathtaking as are the special effects and the movements of the apes. this is a strange genre for tim burton to be involved with, but his influences are highly visible! i will watch it again!

Well, I won't pretend to be a professional critic... just a guy who saw a terrible movie. I'd been hot to see 'Apes' since it was first announced so I went to see it on opening night. When the lights came back up I sat still, stunned at the atrocity I had just witnessed.Let me see if I have everything right... the days on this planet are what... 100 hours long and the planet itself is sometimes huge, other times somewhat larger than a football field, but not by much. The continuity problems were a constant, and I do mean CONSTANT distraction. The story line was insulting to even the most forgiving sci-fi fan and the acting, well... for the humans it was tepid at best.Now... the apes themselves. Hands down, the technical Oscars will be gobbled up by this movie and deservedly so. Despite all of the flaws, the work put in by Mr. Baker and the actors themselves <Tim Roth was, as always, fantastic>  to give a complete and realistic image of a talking monkey made 'Apes' worth the trip. Just don't go in there expecting anything more than a technical spectacle and you should be fine. Me? I expected so much more.... and I wish the kid had been left to the apes. Who the heck was he anyway? I didn't even know his name yet I am expected to care? Sigh... go.. see the movie... but check your brain at the door.

reviews.review_title: Makes me want to stare at the sun so I don't have to watch movies like this ever again
reviews.content: Remake of Planet of the Apes....worse than battlefield earth, worse than Howard the Duck and much much worse than Congo.  This movie sets the bar for awful not only in film but in metaphors for life.  Tell your friends only to see this if they want motivation for killing themselves.

reviews.review_title: Do not give out the name
reviews.content: Well, this movie is good for eating popcorn however, the original one was sooo much better than this one. The plot itself is not original however it has some changes which I won't spoil for you. The acting was average. The make-up was  really good, the special effects were cool as well. Directing has the typical Burton style.The movie is very entertaining however, if it wasn't because it has that name it wouldn't be so good. I am not disappointed but I'm not amazed because it is an average movie.

An enjoyable one, none-the-less.  As I was watching it, I thought to myself, "You know, I'd really like to see this with my 9 year old brother".  It's a slightly original action movie that supplies enough twists from the usual good guy v. bad guy flick to make it interesting.The movie makes some ham-fisted attempts at social commentary.  At one point in the movie an ape played by Paul Giamatti even exclaims "Can we all get along?" That line has been parodied so many times, it's almost painful.  In fact, as memory recalls Tim Burton had Jack Nicholson say the exact same line (to a much greater comic effect in "Mars Attacks!"  The racism allegories seem so forced, it's distracting.  You almost expect Helena Bonham Carter's ape character to organize a big human-ape chain and start singing "I'd like to teach the world to sing"But aside from the failed commentary, the movie succeeds.  All of the performances were above par. Tim Roth treaded the line of overacting, but never crosses it and makes a great, and perpetually angry, Thade.  Micheal Clark Duncan surprises as a loyal, and religious gorilla general.  Mark Walhburg makes a convincing action hero, although the tough guy role doesn't allow his trademark less-than-brilliant charm to come through as well.  And Estella Warren, well, she stands there with a look of constant surprise on her face. But, hey, she looks great doing it.The only thing I thought was missing was more of Tim Burton's trademark quirkiness.  If you had shown me this movie, and told me to guess the director, I would have had no clue.  Burton's eye for the odd is what excels good movies to great ones.  But, all in all, a fun couple hours. I'll give it:7.5/10 bananas

reviews.review_title: Think of it as a Twilight Zone episode...
reviews.content: No points for originality or creativity, +2 points for visuals, +2 points for make-up, +1 point for Helena B's excellent work, and +2 more for the director being Tim Burton (his stories are always fun.) I liked the movie for the most part, a good 70% of the movie. There are some really bad scenes, but they're mostly countered by the wonderful Helena Bonham Carter role as Ari. I dunno, but she's the sexiest Chimpanzee I've ever seen. Almost to the point of contemplating beastiality. But does Ari count? Thank god it was a movie. The best way to enjoy the film is to think of it as a Twilight Zone episode. i think it pays a great homage to Rod Serling (co-writer of the 1968 original) and his strange, almost predictable, but twisted endings. Go see it if you're a Burton fan, and/or if you liked Sleepy Hollow.  7 points.

If you've seen one Tim Burton movie, you've seen them all, and once Mark Wahlberg lands on the monkey planet you know you're in a Tim Burton movie--dark, depressing, and with lots of offbeat humor.And Tim Burton's PLANET OF THE APES is BATMAN, BEETLEJUICE, and EDWARD SCISSORHANDS all added to the original PLANET OF THE APES to make the latest of the Hollywood remakes, and it's still not as good as the original.But Mark Wahlberg is sensational as Astronaut Leo Davidson, young enough to make you believe he's fighting for his life, and tough enough to make you think he can win.  Estella Warren is as good as advertised as Daena--in the same science fiction sexpot role that Raquel Welch started in ONE MILLION YEARS, B.C., and that Linda Harrison improved upon in the original PLANET OF THE APES.  Warren looks even better than her predecessors, can run better, and can actually act.
Unfortunately, this PLANET OF THE APES has no flow, no focus, and none of the sense of isolation that Charlton Heston--who has a terrific cameo in this version!--made you feel in the original--how could one man survive on the Planet of the Apes???Wahlberg carries the movie, but when you get to the disappointing ending, instead of the feeling of awe at the end of the original, you have a feeling of "I WANT MY MONEY BACK!!!"
Tango2200@Hotmail.Com

This was a very disappointing film. It was far too childish for my liking. The bad ape, was ridiculously "bad". He was putting faces and making sounds with the apparent intention of being scary. Clearly intended for the younger audience. There was even a "smart ass"-"joking" character, as in the typical Walt Disney films.

reviews.review_title: Save yourself a few bucks -- renting the original is both cheaper and time better spent.
reviews.content: Be warned, there are minor spoiler warnings here. You might not want to read farther if you don't want to know anything about the movie.I left this movie wondering at what point the creators thought this was a GOOD movie.It's difficult to review this version of PLANET OF THE APES without comparing it to the original. Visually, it's stunning, but the story holds together about as well as sand castles in high tide. True, the remake does a better job of having actors, you should pardon the expression, ape the movements of simians, but little else of this movie is an improvement over the original.The movie doesn't really create an ape society so much as it takes aspects of present human society and has apes do them for satiric purposes. Not only does this joke grow old very quickly, it's frustrating to watch the movie squander the opportunity to produce real satire or explore more deeply the aspects and workings of this ape society. That could have been interesting. Unfortunately, the movie moves quickly to the action sequences so doesn't spend enough time in Ape City to do much more than give satire or social commentary lip service.Still, the movie wasn't bad up to a point, but you hit that point -- the final reel and the ending -- with all the grace and abruptness of a crash test dummy.About that end: without revealing what the end is in the remake, said end pales when compared to the end of the original. The famous surprise ending of the original was set up in that movie. It made sense within the context of the movie, because Taylor's speech at the beginning of the movie, when he's recording his log entry, lets us know that conditions exist which make the surprise at the end possible. The ending of this remake is not set up. It comes from nowhere. (Yes, I know where the ending REALLY came from, but, again, in the context of that source material, its ending made sense. In this movie, the end has no context and no set up.) The remake's end simply made no sense. Nor did the several plot contrivances or the unexplained personality-altering epiphanies of main characters which all occur within the final ten minutes. No sense other than that they were necessary to end the movie. It was as if writers William Broyles Jr., Lawrence Konner, and Mark Rosenthal and director Tim Burton realized, we only have ten minutes left, we'd better throw out logic for the sake of expedience.Then, just when you thought the ending couldn't get any worse, well...

reviews.review_title: A horrible ending to an otherwise great movie.
reviews.content: The movie was very cleverly done up until the last 3 minutes.  After that I wish I had walked out of the theatre.  The ending is so bad it makes the film look like a masterpiece that is crossed with Battlefield Earth.

reviews.review_title: I'm not sure what to think.
reviews.content: I haven't seen any of the original Planet of the Apes films so I can not compare the remake to any of them.  However, I do know how the original Planet of the Apes film ends and I would say that it seems a much easier ending to understand.  Don't worry, I won't give any spoilers for either film.The acting was very good, especially Tim Roth as Thade and Bonham Carter as Ari.  I don't understand why others have complained about the poor acting. The special effects are also unbelievably brilliant in every department and a lot of effort was put into the little things like the behaviour and mannerisms of the apes.However, there are plotholes and the ending is very confusing.  This doesn't mean it doesn't make sense as so many people have claimed.  No offence to anyone but you should really make sure you understand the ending and it's relationship to the rest of the film before you judge it.  I myself don't understand the ending 100% and am therefore making an effort to find out what it means.Some of the plotholes pointed out by others are minor and don't really make the film any less enjoyable.  Then again, I don't fully understand what happens in the film so maybe the plotholes are significant.  Anyone who claims to understand the end can feel free to explain it to me.Possibly the poorest area of the film was the action scenes.  They just weren't exciting enough.All in all, although I didn't fully understand the ending, the film is entertaining and definitely worth seeing.  I might change my mind if I ever see the film on video, seeing how the special effects and sound effects were breath taking, but I'm sure I won't ever consider this to be a dismal pointless movie.  There's just too many clever ideas for that too happen and I can't stop thinking about the film now.My provisional rating: 7.5/10.

reviews.review_title: A fine film that in no way resembles the original, ending is crap.
reviews.content: Well, well, well, where DO I begin with this film? The beginning is a nicely done introduction, letting you see what Mark Wahlburg's charachter is all about, he is the classic american hero He doesn't take orders well, which makes you wonder why he is in the Air force, but whatever, this Is an action movie, and the plot takes a side role to the suspense and fight scenes anyway.  The film wastes no time enslaving him, and wastes less letting him escape, it gets better after he leaves the hatefull city, and the interesting side plot about his divivded love between the gorgeous human, and the intelligent, compassionate ape.  The final battle does an excellent job of tying up all the loose ends, both by fulfilling the ancient prophecy, and taking care of the antagonist Thade. There my like for the film evaporates as Tim Burton ends it with something only one large fan of the original series has been able to explain to me as "jumping to another dimension". I don't know about you, but "another dimension" is code for, "the writers ran out of GOOD ideas". the biggest shock of all comes after you've seen the film, and then realize that Mr.Burton shot an additional 4 DIFFERENT endings, and THIS is the one he chose! overall: two hours of entertainment, followed by 10 minutes of mysterious crud.

reviews.review_title: Better storyline than original, but could have been even better...
reviews.content: I usually prefer originals to the remakes, however this one is an exception. I was trully surprised by Burton's handling of this story with a respect for the original in intent. The cameo appearances and treasured lines we all look to hear were brought back and with a twist in context. When reviewing the deleted material on the DVD, I was puzzled why two very detailed scenes were redone which tied up a couple of loose ends the finished story failed to answer. The time differences were not great, so I am not sure why they were removed. With the exception of the choice of Mark Wahlberg (who I still feel cannot act his way out of a paper sack) Tim Burton did a superb job. This one is worth the purchase if you have a great home theatre system.

I went into this movie with no expectations.  I loved the original, but understood that this was a re-imagining rather than a remake, so the movie was bound to be at least a bit different.  Burton does an excellent job of visualizing what a city built by primates might look like, vaguely jungle-like, but with buildings.  The plot is at least as good as the first one-I found that whole humans are mute angle just a bit much in the original.  This deals with rights of a stronger group over a weaker, touches on the dangers of allowing military leaders to make political decisions, and in general creates a believable world, especially when it becomes clear just how the apes got there in the first place.  (Just a note of science here-genetically altered chimps can only mean mixing DNA with a compatible species and we share 99% of the same DNA as chimps)  Carter and Roth are outstanding, details such as the gait of the apes are considered and the special effects are kept to a minimum.  I admit I am still undecided about whether or not I like the ending, but let's be honest here-Burton would be less than human if he wasn't planning on a possible sequel.  So why the uproar?  It's not every day you get to see an interspecies love story either.  There are some minor complaints I had, such as why Wahlberg was hell-bent on trying to get all the way back to Earth in what was obviously nothing more than a landing craft, but that hardly detracts from what was an enjoyable and entertaining movie. I recommend it.

As a sci-fi fan (and a fan of the original movie) I was drawn to this remake. I had plenty of doubts after seeing the trailers, cast choices etc., but had hoped that Burton could do something interesting with it. Suffice it to say, I walked in with the "lowered expectations are best met outlook".My god, what a waste of time and money this was. Once in a long while my judgment lapses famously, Apes is the winner this time around. Never mind being true to the theme of the original, suspension of disbelief and such - this movie has no redeeming qualities that I can cite; casting and acting were poor, the story was bad beyond belief, and the visuals & effects were weak to laughable. I have enjoyed some of Burtons past flicks, but this effort seriously calls his talent into question.Save yourselves...

reviews.review_title: A typical Hollywood attempt at a remake...typical failure.
reviews.content: Everyone we talk to agrees: Planet of the Apes 2001 is a disappointment. Did they spend a ton of dough to make it? Yes. Is it a blockbuster like Armageddon, Independence day and the like? Almost. Did Shrek and even American Pie 2 make more money (which means more warm bodies and eyeballs)? You bet. Without giving away the weak plot, Tim Burton has screwed up, and had his first bad story, bad acting and his first sell-out. When analyzing a movie, I look at the director's choices: cast, editing style, photography, dialogue and subtext. Cast: Mark Wahlberg deserves a huge movie, he deserves the cash and the popularity. Michael Clark Duncan is typecast as a big tough guy. Tim Roth plays a good bad guy. Helena Bonham Carter could have been replaced by anybody. The savage humans were poorly used, and where did the female human store her MAC makeup kit? Editing: Typical use of quick cuts, swish pans, high speed shutter shots, typical of current batch of action films, usually disguising a bad action sequence. Photography: adequate, did not give away effects, slow motion overused in action sequences. Dialogue: Terrible. Granted, even the Star Wars films have crappy dialogue, but the actors pull it off. Much of the conversation is trite, and the exposition is blatant. The humans should not speak, making the astronaut all the more unusual to the humans and the apes. Subtext: Not enough of it. They hardly touch upon the whole issue of the sensitive apes wanting to free the humans. And the sappy speech by Helena about the human who came from the stars...gimme a break.That being said, the makeup was good for the men, bad for the women, overdone for the female human lead. The sets were overdone. If they had metal helmets and spears and shields, why are the cages made out of wood. The whole time for bed escape scene was too campy for this film. Finally, as a movie that keeps one's interest, this movie fails. About 30 minutes in, I wondered if it was over yet. Thank goodness it's over now. Rule the Planet? I'm afraid not, Tim. Stick to superheroes and Johnny Depp. And if you've got Kris Kristoferson on your payroll, I think the world is ready for Pee-Wee Herman and the Last Crusade.

All the advances in makeup, computer graphics, and whatever other expensive high tech stuff went into this film could not overcome a plodding and ultimately boring script and pedestrian acting. Where are Charlton Heston and Roddy McDowell when you need them? I never thought I would say that.

Can I start off by saying despite what people say about critics, they do prove their worth like warning us about trash like Pearl Harbor so in the case of Tim Burton's POTA I would merely say they are wrong but then everyone sees the film in their own way. I'm a fan of the original series and was looking forward to this version. Of course it has its bad points like some atrocious dialogue like "..a human from the stars" from Helena Bonham Carter but its a more ambitious film with more content and ideas than say Jurassic Park 3 which was just another tired franchise film. The ending was a fun homage to the original and was not supposed to top that original film but is a part of Tim Burton's reimaging. Mr Burton said in a recent interview that he would rather jump out of a window than make a sequel even though Fox want to turn it into a franchise so maybe there should not be a sequel but just let this film stand as a worth successer to the 1968 version. I can't wait for the DVD with the extras to savor from this excellent version. 10 out of 5

*MINOR SPOILERS*I liked this film. I went to the cinema, paid my money and was entertained for the 2 or so hours it was on. It is a good film. Not a great film, but a good film. Too often people compare it to the original (which in itself was hardly a cinematic masterpiece), stating silly things like; "Why can the humans speak?"... Because it's a different film! There's simply no reason why they couldn't speak!? They are the decendents of english speaking humans! "How can I not compare it?"... okay, they're both about monkeys! But the story line is completely different from that of the original. Star Wars and Star Trek are similar but the two are very rarely compared.The make-up is fantastic, the movement and acting is generally above par. The special effects are pretty awsome. The sets range from spectacular to pretty unimaginative, but this was possible intended (how interesting can you make a barron desert?)The statue of liberty style "twist" at the end isn't done in the same format. After seeing the original you would say: "Oooooh, right! That's what happened!?" After seeing POTA 2001 most say: "How the hell did that happen?" - though this has been critisised I think it was a deliberate attempt by Burton to give the viewer the option of drawing his or her own conclusions (yes, you have to use your brain!). Why people see this as an opening to a sequel, I don't know - it's not! There won't be a sequel... bets anyone?

reviews.review_title: not terrible but a senseless remake
reviews.content: I didn't find this film as terrible as I thought I would.  I am a big fan of the original films and was very skeptical of a remake.  Some of the allusions to the original were clever, but not all of them.  One of the biggest flaws, to me, was the fact that when I left the theater I didn't remember the names of many of the characters.  There was also a lot of wasted talent here (everyone but Tim Roth) and Marky Mark is no Charlton Heston.

reviews.review_title: As Long As You Don't Compare it to the Original...
reviews.content: I'm going to say that I love the original. It's great. The sequels to it get a little strange, but the first one is wonderful. Now, this movie I rented to see with an open mind. I knew that they can hardly ever do better than the original when remaking a film, so they always get crap and do their best to compare.My advice: don't compare. Sit back, relax, and forget everything you know about the first one. You may just enjoy it. I must say, a plus from the original is that the people talk. But the whole kissing the ape was just wrong.Being a person who doesn't believe in evolution, I find I have to swallow my tongue while watching both the first one and this one. Leave your personal beliefs at the door, along with anything you know about the original, open your mind, and you may just like it.

I liked it , but saddened by what could've been syndrome , the anticipation was more exiting than the finished product , the story originally was a covert Military space station , tuck away behind Jupiter , doing " Genetic " experiments with apes , hence the apes become super intelligent or close to it . (very similar to another fox franchise, the "Alien"series,) ,by human meddling , but the topic genetic interference not has frightening as the previous film / films.with the prospect of WW3 As a plot thread who can forget the scene with ,what is left ,of the Satue Of Liberty..The updated film the hero is transported a short time into the future ,to find a thriving ape society , they that way via genetic manipulation . at the I read this ,in one of the trades , But it ended up in the Rise:Of The Planet Of The Apes . Please someone out there , would have read the same information as well please let others know . 34 years it took to get a new Planet Of The apes film of the ground and a lot of pitches . I personally liked the film , faults and all , I do believe it is Tim Burton deserves , any criticism , The is Twentieth Century Fox , The Dark Force of Hollywood ...

Tim Roth and Michael Clarke Duncan are fantastic in their roles and they truly convince as evolved apes.  Mark Whalberg and Estella Warren, on the other hand are more wooden than a log cabin convention.  The make-up is impressive, but from such a visionary director as Tim Burton, you'd have expected far more.  It seems that the executives were convinced that as many references to the original 'Apes' film will be funny, but instead they only emphasise how much worse this 'reimagination is'.The apes are great, it's the humans that don't convince.

***CONTAINS SPOILERS***This was a strange, great movie. As you're watching it, it all seems to tie in with the original. The planet does not seem to be earth. The special FX and sound are wonderful. The acting is average and the movie almost seemed a little boring at times. But what I really hated was the quotes from the original (one made by the man that originally said "Damn them all to Hell!!" as he lay in his death bed. The ending of the movie makes absolutely no sense whatsoever and this totally ruined the it. He clearly lands back on earth and clearly shown to be going back in time. Now if it's all about inter-dimensional travel, it still makes no sense as the present cannot be altered by an action in the future. But images of General Thade were on display everywhere indicating he was a hero in the past. It just cannot be put together to make sense and that's why I hated it so much.

Let me first start of by saying Tim Burton is a visionaire, he has proved that over and over with films like Beetlejuice and Edward scissorhands, etc... but as far as telling this classic tale he kind of got lost along the way in expressing his vision on this tale. Resulting in the end in having more and more beautiful pics and awesome action cut scenes but the story stays behind, and even though the actors do put on a great show, as we can see that Tim Roth is on a roll while portraying a vicious Ape General, even a bit over the sadistic side. But nevertheless it is an OK flick, just that when u expecting the great story told in the novel u would come out deceived.But for pure entertainment reasons I would go for it

I'm going to be one of the few to say that this movie is not as bad as everyone makes out. I often feel that people just jump on the bandwagon when they slate it, especially the hardcore Burton fans. It's certainly not a great movie, nor is it a bad one.Visually it's amazing, as with any Burton film. The sets are spectacular, the CGI is convincing and not burdensome and the ape make-up/costumes look truly realistic and in some cases, menacing, particularly the character of Thade. Danny Elfman's musical score is suitably brooding and savage and I think the slew of weird percussion sounds is inspired. The acting is good, with stand-out performances from Tim Roth, who is the perfectly grotesque Burton villain, and Paul Giamatti, providing light relief.The story and script seem to be the main culprits for all the controversy. I actually like the fact that there is little dialogue. Sometimes movies suffer when there is too much dialogue, as it just becomes convoluted. Although Planet of the Apes is nowhere near as profound as Kubrick's 2001, this is the perfect example of 'pure cinema'. There is not one word of dialogue until 40 minutes into the film. Not everything needs to be explained with dialogue, a picture paints a thousand words, as the saying goes. As for the ending, it's more true to the novel. I will say that the Ape Lincoln memorial makes a mockery of the film, which is a fabrication and NOT in the novel. Although there is humour throughout the film, the ending loses its impact as a result of Burton's outlandish joke.

reviews.review_title: Burton goes bananas with an action-packed ape-fest...
reviews.content: If you go into this looking for Tim Burton's usual quirkiness, you may be disappointed: it takes a backseat to good ol' movie spectacle. This "Planet" is a full-on action/science fiction thriller that barely lets up.  It's funny, fast and loud; the special effects don't overpower the story, and Rick Baker's ape make-up is amazing - after a while you believe you're watching an advanced race of apes, rather than actors buried beneath layers of latex and fake fur.  The whole cast is very good, especially Helena Bonham Carter, whose performance as the ape-woman Ari is witty, sharp and sweet. Two things: Chuck Heston should retire from films after this, since I can't imagine a better exit than the one this movie gives him, and the film's final gag is funny, but doesn't really make sense (especially in light of the story we've just seen).  Other than that, though, big Hollywood summer popcorn flicks don't get much better than this.  Viva la Movies!

reviews.review_title: Could have made it better (Contain Spoilers)
reviews.content: I haven't seen the original version of the film so I can't compare the two versions.  I just saw this film and I must admit, they could have done a better job.  The special effects were good and there were some funny moments but the plot had a lot of holes in it.  Capt. Leo Davidson was captured, sold as a slave and escaped on the same day!  How realistic is that?  There were too many unexplained scenes.  Why did the Army Commander kill those two apes that told him about the crash?  How did they know this particular human was from space?  Why did the General switch sides?  It may be a fiction but even a fiction can be made more believable.  It was a good film but it could've been much better.

I liked the first 100 minutes of the movie even though it doesn't even compare to "Batman" or "Edward's Scissorhands". I liked the ending because I thought it was a good and interesting departure from the original. Only one thing ruined everything for me:WARNING: SPOILER AHEADThe only thing that made me mad was seeing Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan's character) turn his back on his best friend because of what Leo tells him. Come on! The guy is in the army, is the best friend of the great General who hates every human, has believed in his religion his whole life, a religion that has existed for a long time and that everyone believes in, and the guy is ready to listen and BELIEVE what a human has to say?!?! And by the way, it takes about 3 seconds to Attar to reject everything he has ever believed in during his entire existence and accept and believe the exact opposite concerning humans and his god.Nonetheless, the beginning was good because of makeup, costumes and simian attitudes.

reviews.review_title: no comparison, well maybe 2 or 3 (possible minor spoilers)
reviews.content: Everything you see, except the ending, is explained more or less as you view the movie. You will notice if you have seen the originals that several lines of monologue were reproduced for an insider's bit of hilarity. It's a bit flipflopped from the point of view in the first Planet Of The Apes but is memorable in that people having seen the first one recognize these quotes immediately. The first and last quotes by the human astronaut(after capture and escape) in the first film are reproduced from an ape's perspective in this latest one. For example, "get your paws off me you damn dirty ape" has been reinvented as "get your hands off me you damn dirty human". Also, the famous "damn them, damn them all" was used by the same actor but in an ape role. All Hail, Charles Heston.K1

reviews.review_title: Predicable movie from start to finish
reviews.content: ******************************************************** ****** SPOILER ALERT *********************************** ****** I will talk about the ending ******************** ********************************************************I saw this movie the first weekend it was out and thought the movie was entirely predictable but I can enjoy movies where you already know the plot line and the ending. There were no surprises I knew what was going to happen next.  Like James Bond movies you know Bond is going to get the girl and save the day. I liked this picture better than the original not because of the story line but because of the sets, acting, and costumes.  The characters behaved in a more realistic manner other than the first one which just humans dressing up in ape suits.The ending was a disappointment to me.  When I first heard they were going to do the Planet of the Apes again, I thought to myself "here we go again the movie will end with human hero of the picture in front of a monument with Earth being conjured by the Apes".  This is what I expected from the beginning, when I walked in the movie theatre, all the way through the picture, and at the end when the space craft landed.  I heard that the movie wasn't going to be a remake, the picture took place on another planet and the ending was going to be shocking.  I was personally waiting, hoping and praying for a different ending to the picture that would be surprising and shocking.  So much for that idea. Hollywood came through again with the same old same old.  I guess there was no other way that Hollywood could end the picture, but it was incredibly predictable. What a disappointment but I enjoyed the movie up until the ending.

Terrific "retelling" of a classic sci-fi pop culture icon. But this ending will leave a lot of folks scratching their heads like monkeys. You should really rent and watch the original film first, which I think was still better than this new one but just as enjoyable. While the original 1968 film was more a statement against nuclear war, Tim Burton's 2001 version focuses more on racism and religion. Still, it's the best popcorn movie of this summer.

Bad, bad script. In greek theater, they used to make use of Deus Ex Machina, which literally means "God from a Machine." Just when the plot seemed like it couldn't be untangled, or the hero couldn't win, they would lower one actor (playing a God) on pulleys and ropes. He would suddenly right all that was wrong.Here it is in modern day cinema. Big fight seen with the hero in trouble. Big explosion in the sky and down comes a spaceship with a test-monkey in it, which turns out to be the God off all the apes. Of course it saves the hero, Mark Wahlberg. They should have spent some of the special effects money on the plot. I'm surprised that Tim Burton did this film.

I saw Planet of the Apes last night, and I loved it. I saw it with a friend of mine who didn't like it much the first time, and it turned out that she simply didn't understand that plot. I think that most of the comments of people who didn't like it just didn't get it. Let me try to enlighten you: **SPOILER SPOILER** 1. they said at the beginning that the monkeys were genetically enhanced to be smart enough to control the ships. that's why they evolved into talking apes when they got to the planet. 2. yes, the blonde girl was totally underdeveloped. but in the original, she didn't even speak! so give burton some credit. 3. the end DOES make sense. if you look at the pod's calender, the numbers go backwards, but it never says that Leo got back to the right year, which would be 2029. there was no uniformity in the electrical field, so how would he be able to aim directly to the right time? he didn't go back in time at all; he went forward. obviously if there are genetically enhanced monkeys in space, they had to have been created in earth labs. so the same thing happened on earth that happened on the planet. the earth apes eventually heard the story of the human rebellion on the ape planet and commemorated Thade. **END OF SPOILER**So there you go. But I suggest just watching the movie and enjoying it, without all of the analysis. I didn't think about the end until I got home, but when it happened in the movie I flipped out. It was awesome and surprising and scary. And even if you didn't think it made sense, you must have had fun watching it.

I had high hopes.  I love Tim Burton.  Since Kubrick is dead, I believe Tim Burton is the best director alive.  This, to me is NOT a Burton movie though.  Tim has a lot to make up for after giving us this junk.  Granted I know it's mostly the scriptwriters' fault.  Just look at their credentials: Entrapment, Mighty Joe Young, Beverly Hillbillies, and Superman IV?   Who here is surprised by this drivel?Ok, the makup WAS good, but I HATED the female makup.  It all looked fake. I couldn't get it out of my head that these were human women with masks on. They looked stupid and plastic.(Fair warning... SPOILERS here.)The main problem though, and here's where I just CAN'T forgive, TECHNICAL flaws.  There are three.  Where did the Apes come from?  Yes, there were chimps on the space station.  But where were the Apes.  There were no apes on that small space station.  And even if I missed them or if they were implied, Apes do not belong in space.  They are too large and heavy and not intelligent enough.  This space station didn't need the muscle.  But then, could chimps have evolved into apes?  NO! Apes and Chimps are on different branches of the evolutionary tree.  And Chimps are HIGHER that Apes.  Chimps cannot evolve into Apes. They would have to DEVOLVE into Apes.  It just doesn't make sense.  And where did the Orangutan come from?If the apes killed the humans, where did the human inhabitants come from? Of course, they must not have killed them all.  But if even a small group of humans survived a chimp or ape attack, especially a group of scientists and engineers from the future, they would not let the Chimps evolve into intelligent apes that would take over the planet.  They would hunt down and kill the Chimps, before their numbers got out of hand.Another flaw: the end.  How did the apes get to Earth?  (Here's where I smell the sequel.)  The apes were sent into the future, not the past.  If the space station were sent into the past, the chimps would have had time to evolve enough to get to space and conquer Earth.  Of course they will say that the intelligent apes went through a wormhole into our past.  This would work, but it isn't very clean.  It would have been better if they had had the apes go into the past.I can abide holes in a story, if they do not pertain to the story itself. Example: The Star Wars trilogy had quite a few holes.  Who is this Jabba the Hut?  How did Leia and Luke get separated at birth?  How did Bobba Fett get his Mandalorian Armor?  None of these holes affected the story though.  They did not happen during the timeframe of the movie themselves.  These holes added interest, not confusion.  Planet of the Apes' holes happened DURING the timeframe of the movie.  If Tim makes a sequel, I'm going to sneak into it because I paid to see a whole and complete Planet of the Apes, and he only gave me half.

reviews.review_title: Think back to when you first heard the news...
reviews.content: When I first heard they were going to "re-imagine" the original Planet of the Apes I just about freaked out. It is impossible. The original has such an intense impact. It works because the viewers are expected to suspend disbelief at least a little bit in order to really feel the power of the movie. The original runs more like a parable or an urban legend than it does a believable action movie. This was also in a time where almost all movies and TV shows were done in the same vain- look at Alfred Hitchcock films, The Twilight Zone, and even Welcome Back Kotter - the list goes on and on. In this day and age people want to criticize the reality of everything and the filmmakers(and TV producers) see that as a challenge. This fact makes Planet of the Apes(2001) fail. I admit that after finding out Tim Burton and Danny Elfman (both of whom I am a gigantic fan) were on board I got very excited. I believed it might be done properly. I knew it couldn't be done but still got suckered in. After seeing it I realised that what I knew all along really was true. The costumes and makeup were perfect and so were the sets but there is no denying that this movie falls flat where the other made it's mark - the ending. They did pretty good with the story by putting a whole new twist on the origin of the Planet of the Apes, but in the end it all turned sour. When I first watched the original I thought of how they were going to end it and there was a certain ending that I (and many others) thought of that would make the movie stupid and very cliche. Thank god they didn't do it and instead made history. Unfortunately the new version of this movie has the EXACT twist ending we were afraid of seeing in the original. Very stupid, very easy and worst of all VERY unimaginative. I was actually cringing in my seat hoping they wouldn't end it the way they did. All I can say is "Bummer".

reviews.review_title: Avoid POTA entirely, go to the zoo...
reviews.content: Ok...so, normally when I head out to the movies I have a pretty good idea of what I'm going to get. I made the mistake of expecting something from this, um, 'pseudo-remake' of Planet of the Apes. It looked fantastic (the make-up and costuming was amazing...) and the score was rather intriguing...but the 'acting' was, well, sub-par (to put it nicely). I don't know what was going through Tim Burton's head.At no point during the film did I think that any of the characters (simian or otherwise) were believable. The dialogue (what there was of it, anyway) was appalling. Characters acted rashly for no logical reason, and there didn't seem to be any cause for these actions. The super-intelligent apes treated the humans like dirt...but why? There was no explanation for anything.The worst example of this lack of explanation comes at the end. I won't say what happens (don't want to ruin the 'fun' for everyone), but its absolutely impossible and it really doesn't make sense. Sure, it was jaw-dropping...but only since it was utter nonsense...As opposed to the original, I don't know what Burton's purpose was (other than <chi-ching> $$$). Well, in any case, kudos to Carter, Roth, Duncan and the rest of the apes for going to school and learning to act like an ape. And as for the 'human' cast, maybe they should have gone to a school to learn to act like, well, a human (emotions are an integral part of life)...The bottom line is: if you want to look at a bunch of animals, go to the zoo...oh...and stick to the originals...

Well I have just seen the movie and all that I can really say is that it is O.K., not a masterpiece or a total dud.  The main problem I had, apart from the well signposted ending, was the fact that the constantly changing tone. The script goes from standard sci-fi to action movie to almost a love story, along the way there are attempts at slapstick and satire. There is even a bumbling sidekick! Towards the end it really lost the plot, don't want to give anything away( but trust me you will easily guess the ending) On the plus side the make up and acting were very good.*******SPOILER ALERT*******************SPOILER ALERT************The ending is quite simply a tacked on piece of nonsense, many people have posted ideas about it but none of them hold water.  The writers needed a "surprise" ending and from the looks of things used the first one that came to hand. I know that it was the ending used in the book, that does not make it any better.Overall the bad points outnumber the good points but its close.

When 'The Haunting' flopped at the box office while the ultra-low budget 'Blair Witch Project' became all the rage, it was a prime example of how the most sophisticated high-tech special effects don't guarantee a good remake of a classic movie (or, for that matter, any other movie). Consequently, I expected much the same when I heard of the 'Planet of the Apes' remake: today's advanced effects, prettier actors perhaps, and essentially expensive rehash. Tim Burton's version of the classic epic is a pleasant surprise. Sure enough, the movie does have dazzling special effects--the most impressive beyond a single doubt Rick Baker's ape makeup. And the actor's are, for the most part, new-millennium pretty (even some of the apes). But the story has also been completely and compellingly re-imagined and re-created. This is a new tale which has little in common with the original movie except that they are both based on Pierre Boulle's book--and that they are both excellent. The attention to (often hilarious) detail in Tim Burton's movie is delightful, and for those who remember the original 'Planet of the Apes' well enough, there are also a few pleasantly twisted nods to the classic to discover. The story moves along at a brisk pace and never fails to involve, making the movie seem shorter than it is, and the plot surprises in intelligent ways during the final part of the action. Another wonderful thing to observe is how well the makeup allows the actors behind it to bring their characters to life. While the masks in the original films were impressive, they allowed for little more than moving mouths and the occasional twitching nose. The masks in the new movie, on the other hand, accommodate a seemingly unlimited range of facial expressions. It takes more imagination to picture that there are human faces behind the makeup than it does to accept the simian characters as genuine. This new 'Planet of the Apes' is indeed not a remake, but an original movie based on the same novel that inspired the first one. A strong story, solid characters, AND amazing special effects, that's the stuff the 'suspense of disbelief' is made of. Let's just hope it won't suffer from the same sequel-itis as the original.

reviews.review_title: Great tribute to a classic film
reviews.content: This movie is a stunning tribute to the original films.  Tim Burton took elements of the original story and created something surprisingly new. Tim Burton, as always, demonstrates incredible cinematography; the ape makeup is near perfect; and the acting is fine (Tim Roth as Thade is particularly good). People complain about it's "plot holes" and "confusing ending".  The movie doesn't conflict with itself, does it?  Since when are movie makers required to spell out every detail of the story they are telling? It's not as good as the original, but it's got a lot going for it. Don't let the whiners who are afraid to think about a movie after it's over convince you not to check it out..

Standard Hollywood action fare which we have numerous times seen before. The film is completely flat and predictable with zero originality. Canned food, as opposed to a delicious meal that one might expect.

reviews.review_title: A horrible re-make of a classic
reviews.content: This movie has fails to create any sense of empathy towards its human characters.  There is absolutely no reason to care for the humans aside from the fact that they look like us.  Very poor script. I have no idea why Tim Burton let this script, with its crappy dialogue (I'm going to get my chimp!) be realized into a film that will waste millions of people's lives as they sit in darken theaters for no reason.

I had extremely high expectations when i entered the theatre, for the first 3 quarters of the film, my expectations were being fulfilled, however.... with the last quarter i became a tad bit disappointed. Aside from the ending, i would say that it was a pretty good movie.

I was pretty satisfied after walking out of Planet of the Apes, and I couldn't see how many could outright complain about the movie. Then I heard it...for the first of many times..."It's not like the original". How many people walked into this movie expecting to see the original? These people should have saved some time and effort and rented the original. For those of us wanting a fresh look at the story, we couldn't be disappointed. You have Mark Wahlberg and Tim Roth doing outstanding jobs...especially Tim Roth. You have fantastic make up work by Rick Baker. You have Charlton Heston making one of the most ironic statements in history about guns. What more could you ask for? Possibily a little more of Tim Burton's touch, but that isn't a huge complaint...it is still a fantastic movie, even without some of Tim's signature looks. If you aren't expecting to see this movie and watch the original all over again, then this movie is for you. If you want the original, just redone with Mark Wahlberg, rent the original and use your imagination. To make up for the lack of Tim Burton's touch in this movie, I would suggest following this up with Sleepy Hollow.

I remember that the original Planet of the Apes frightened me badly the first time I saw it- the first image of gorillas on horseback bearing firearms was an effective attention-getter.  If nothing else, Tim Burton's new APES carries the torch in this respect- even though I knew what was coming, the gorillas, orangutans and assorted other talking simians repeatedly raised the hair on my own neck, especially Tim Roth's incredibly athletic and menacing Thade.  On top of that, Burton manages to throw in quite a bit of humor, including some goofball nods to the original APES. The sets of course are magnificent, and so are the makeup and effects.  The SciFi sensibility of this version, however, is lacking (especially compared to how far ahead of its time the original was).  The beginning of the film has a rushed feel to it, and there are some plot holes regarding space travel and basic physics that will turn off many hardline SciFi fans.  All in all, though, summer audiences don't ask too much of their summer blockbusters, and this one delivers on that count.  Never a dull moment, lots to look at, and the simians in this version are a LOT more ape-like. The acting achievements of Roth and Bonham-Carter are amazing, and steal a lot of thunder from the human co-stars, including Wahlberg (who unfortunately for his female audience never appears bare-chested... sorry girls).  7 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Disappointing movie, could have benefitted from better editing.
reviews.content: I can't stand movies where the characters are stupid.  The new Planet of the Apes immediately got off on the wrong foot with me when in the first few minutes of the movie Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) disobeys his commanding officer and takes a pod cruiser from the station.  It's stupid and it makes no sense.  The script writers could have come up with a dozen better ways to get him out into the storm in the pod.  It just makes the characters unbelievable from the start.Once we're down on the planet, things move along, but we don't seem to make any real progress in character development.  Why does Ari (Helena Bonham-Carter) care so much for the humans?  What's with Karubi (Kris Kristofferson)?  He shows up, but the character never develops.  Daena (Estella Warren) is easy on the eyes, but contributes little else. Ultimately I didn't really care all that much about these people.  There was no outpouring of sympathy from the audience when any of the characters died. That's because no one cared.I could possibly accept the complete lack of characterization if this were an action flick.  It failed there also.  The climactic fight sequence needs re-editing.  The climax was incredibly slow moving.  The pacing during the climax was all wrong.  For no apparent reason, this kid that we barely see and know nothing about (Birn, played by Luke Eberl) is all over this sequence.  Why?  Please, cut him, or at least make us care about him.  The climax needs to be tightened up a lot.Leo also manages to reinforce his stupidity with his plan (or lack thereof) for the climactic battle sequence.  Why blow your one big shot on the initial charge?  Why not come up with a plan that take advantage of your enemies obsession to make a bigger dent in the attacking army?  I like movies where the characters are smart or clever, again the characters just stumble along here with barely a semblance of a plan.  (Leo's escape sequence earlier in the movie suffers from the same problems.  He gets away, but it's mostly dumb luck.)The conversion of Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) is also just not believable.All of this could have been fixed with a better script and better editing. Perhaps what disappointed me most was that you could see a good movie stuck behind this mess.  I can't help but feel that with just a little more work on the script and with better editing this could have been a good movie.

reviews.review_title: Uneven, but by no means horrible
reviews.content:
I have never seen the original Planet of the Apes nor its numerous sequels. So, I wasn't going into this movie expecting to not have any "cult-classic" expectations dashed upon the rocks.  I was hoping that 1) This film earned its "Directed by Tim Burton" tag, 2) I wanted a half-way intelligent story, and 3) I wanted to marvel at the monkey (excuse, me, *ape*) makeup.Let me take those points in reverse.  You've probably heard that the makeup is incredible.  Well, it is.  Different species of simians are represented, from baboon to monkey to chimpanzee, and the "evolved" forms represented in the movie are pulled off well.  But it would be for naught if the actors themselves couldn't "get into character."  Let me tell you, the ape cast did superb jobs.  Mr. Roth, playing the villain general Thade, should get an award; his imitations of simian mannerisms (pawing of his comrades, wild vine-climbing screeching fits of anger) were spot-on.  Helena Botham-Carter kept up with her costar in her role of human beneficiary; she would toggle back and forth between heated intelligent arguments on the worth of humans and "ooh ooh ooh ah! ah! aaahh!"-ing when she'd panic.  Ok, that's exaggerating, but you get the idea.Story-wise?  Ehh... I think I would have liked it better if we were focused on the monkeys rather than the "spaceman".  Mark Wahlberg (sp?) was decent, but he was a bit rough in some parts, and when the movie trailed behind him and his rag-tag bunch as they fled the city, it dragged.  When the focus switched back to the apes (especially Thade), you had interesting dialog exchanges, wonderful acting, and a generally more interesting movie.
Are you going to this movie to see a Tim Burton movie?  ... Well, you *may* be disappointed somewhat.  I didn't get the Tim Burton feel like I did watching "Sleepy Hollow".  But if you go in simply expecting to see a well-directed movie, you'll probably like it better.  Burton fans need to draw their own conclusions, but it felt like the movie was being directed by someone else, though someone equal to the task.Bottom line: It's not the best film.  But it's a good film.  I didn't feel like I wasted $7.00 seeing it in the theater.  I hope you don't, either.
Rating: 7/10

reviews.review_title: The Plot is like Swiss cheese: there are holes everywhere.
reviews.content: I understand that Mr. Burton was handed a heavy load to take care of when he decided to create a remake of the classic, original Planet of the Apes.  He apparently attempted to add new twists that would set it apart from its predecessor, but the strings he uses to try and surprise us only end up caught around the throat of the scripts, which is unquestionably D.O.A.Here are some supporting facts (minor spoilers): -Trying to explain why Apes have taken over the planet was a huge mistake. That should have been left alone. -Where did the horses come from?  And why aren't there any other animals? -The humans outnumber the apes 4-1, can speak perfect English and seem at least as intelligent as their simian brethren: why couldn't they ever muster forces to fight back? -Mr. Burton expects us to swallow the fact that our ape friends can create metal armor and helmets, invent sports and create cities, but just haven't figured out how to make a boat?  And why can't the apes swim, anyhow? -The ending is corny and really, unless you're kinda slow, won't shock you at all. -There are just too many things wrong with the whole mother ship crashing thing, so I won't even touch.So, my advice is: Avoid this piece of excrement like the plague.  You'll be much happier if you do.

bad, bad, bad.Cliche ridden from the start and only momentarily salvaged by the purposefully vague ending. nice job, only two hours too late... Suffers from deep amounts of cheese (Damn them all to hell... pleeze!) with a complete lack of attention to tone. as soon as it started to get going... bam! - I was drowning neck deep in overdone cliches and or cheezy dialog way out of place in regards to the previous scenes tone...
** out of 5

reviews.review_title: Very disappointing, but pretty, and isn't that all we can ask these days?
reviews.content: Planet of the Apes remake - it's not good. Too much dialogue that elicits groans, plot elements that don't make sense, poor acting, wooden dialogue, predictable "surprises" at the end. It's obvious that no one connected with this movie had much respect for the original series or for any intelligent member of the audience. On the plus side - the sets were fabulous, the ape costumes great. Some individual scenes were quite striking. Filmed in the dark, with the Dolby soundtrack cranked up to 11. See it in the theatre at matinee prices so you can get the full benefit of the special effects which is about all that is worth watching anyway.

i was hoping for so much more than this from a director as good as tim burton, but i left the cinema extremely disappointed. visually this film is impressive, you can see nearly all the budget being shown on the screen, the apes themselves are very convincing. the main problems lie firstly in the acting (the apparent love between Estella Warren and Mark Wahlberg is laughably unconvincing).... only Tim Roth and Helena Bonham Carter show any form of skill... the second problem is the terrible script which doesn't waste it's time in resorting to cliche and annoying post-modern referential dialog.... and the ENDING(!) is the biggest load of rubbish I've ever had the misfortune to witness this film pales in comparison to the originals

I managed to see an advance preview of this movie and it just blew me away. All the acting was unbelievable and it had a brilliant script to boot. I suggest that everyone should stop whatever they are doing and go out and see this movie.

reviews.review_title: Don't treat this as a remake and you'll enjoy it.
reviews.content: Burton's "Apes" is a new movie. If the film were a straight-up remake then of course it wouldn't hold up to the original but guess what?, no movie can ever hold up to what the original laid down, so why try? Burton obviously recognized this and did a great job with a NEW story. Great work.

There's only one thing worse than paying $8.50 for a movie that has an axe to grind:  a movie with APES doing the axe-grinding.It's hard enough to suspend one's disbelief and get into this whole farce based, essentially, on Darwinistic evolution (which in itself is nothing more than ideological dogma, rather than anything truly scientific).
