But to believe, in a "relativistic universe," where we all supposedly evolved by pure chance without intelligent design nor moral purpose, a BEAST like an ape is going to develop a moral sense and espouse a knowledge of "right and wrong" (where this came from is never stated) is just laughable.  And this is almost how the movie comes off.I would have been more able to suspend my disbelief had the apes--ALL the apes, been truly beasts.  It would have been horrific and been, FINALLY, this remake's only shot at equalling (let alone improving over) its 1968 original by creating a more potent nightmare.  Instead, it tries to re-create the original's formula--as if any of us would still be "oh'd" by the notion that this "actually could happen."Been there, done that.So, instead of exploiting the truly hellish potential of this concept, we are constantly reminded that this is a remake.  No risks are taken.  No opportunity missed to "sensitize our political ignorance" (thanks, Ms. Ape). For lessons on creating a masterful (read 'believable') science-fiction world, the makers should have studied Ridley Scott's ALIEN and BLADE RUNNER, or Cameron's TERMINATOR series.

I think I should have realized that the 7:45 showing of Planet of the Apes selling out was a veiled premonition not to watch this movie. But my chakras were unaligned and I stuck around anyway for the 8:25 show. The plot goes like this. The year is 2029. American astronauts are testing chimpanzees as pilots on a space station. After losing a prized chimp in an electric windstorm, Leo, played by Mark Wahlberg tries to rescue him. The electric windstorm also acts as a time warp and transports Leo into the future onto a planet where Apes are evolutionary superior to humans.What has it been about Tim Burton's recent movies that have just left a bad taste in my mouth? Sleepy Hollow was bearable but certainly not up to par with Burton's earlier work. Call me nostalgic, but I think back to the days of Batman and Beetlejuice and I see genius. I watch Planet of the Apes and I think sellout...I went to this movie with no real expectations. Admittedly, I was suspicious of all the hype this movie was getting but I was interested to see it, soley because Burton directed it. Where do I begin? I was disappointed with the acting. Mark Wahlberg played his lead role of astronaut turned hero with complete stoicism but no human depth. Estella Warren was there purely for eyecandy; if she is capable of acting, she wasn't given the chance. Even Tim Roth and Helena Bonham Carter, well established thespians, were held back with a dry, clicheed script. Of course the special effects and set were amazing...blah, blah, blah. But Burton doesn't usually forego story for effects. His effects from earlier years have been just as impressive even with a smaller budget. The set is supposed to add to the movie and storyline, not surpass it. Speaking of storyline, where was it? This movie didn't have one, or at least an original one. I know you're thinking it was just a remake...how could the story be original? If you're going to bother remaking a film, you should do it for a reason...to show a different viewpoint or take on it; go somewhere the first one could have but didn't. For example, the 1968 original was very philosophical and dealt with religious issues. It was kitsch for the time, but it also made you think. 2001's Apes seems to have bypassed all philisophical debate and just provided a limited plot, excellent makeup and set, set, set.  Thats basically all that this movie has to offer, which in my mind is not worth $9 and two hours of my time.

As a fairly big fan of both the original Apes movies and Tim Burton, not to mention the novel, Tim Roth, Helena Bonham-Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, etc, I had high hopes going into this movie. I don't think I could have been more let down.I, unlike many others, will back up my feelings. What is the sense of setting up the big battle between Apes and Humans if it's not going to happen? It's a complete waste of screen time.As for the ending, I suppose that Burton and/or the studio wanted to have something of the shock value that the Statue of Liberty had in the original and set themselves up for a franchise of sequels, but this one ruins all logical sense of the movie. If Leo traveled back in time instead of forward (That's what I took the ending to mean, anyways...) how did human civilization exist BEFORE the Apes'? How were there guns before guns were invented? And how do apes believe in Hell before Dante wrote the Inferno? As in "Damn them to Hell."

The original Planet of the Apes was a brilliant satire of human nature that touched upon such themes as how man treats animals, how science being led by religion leads to nothing, and of course mankind's ability to destroy themselves. Every moment in the film was earned through a slow and effective pacing, good dialogue, and a horrific visual ending that put a chilling exclamation mark on everything the movie had been saying throughout.Tim Burton's new Planet of the Apes valiantly tries to make some of these same points again but never lets it sink effectively in our minds due to choppy dialogue, non-existent characterization, and a tacked on ending that will again cause a lot of discussion. But not in the way the filmmakers intended.The good parts of this film are how it plays with your expectations of the original. Hearing some of the classic Apes lines said in a new way gives the audience some laughs. Charleton Heston plays with his own role by being an ape in this film, and getting to talk about some of the film's best themes of humanity's power of invention and destruction. (I'm sure Heston never imagined being in another Apes movie, especially after convincing the producers of the original series to let him blow up the planet...) The apes themselves are reimagined in a spectacular way. The different species are more noticable and the primal way they move and interact with one another is better in the original making them seem more animal like. Some of the plot is revealed in effective and believable, at least as much as can be for a film of this type, ways. The setup of the film is compelling and effective enough. Which unfortunately makes the payoff more dissapointing.The bad parts of the film start to show up as more and more characters begin interacting. Characters are introduced in as simple of terms as possible. Their is no shading of these characters. Characters also seem to come to grips with difficult choices, change their views of the world, or suddenly change character with no effort at all. All this seems to stem from what seems to me to be someone wanting to show us 'cool moments' and then not knowing what to do with the characters after. SPOILERS: Examples being when an ape gets a human girl as a pet. Our heroes rescue the girl and then LEAVE THEM WITH THE APES! If you don't want your daughter around apes, don't leave them with them. Characters dies with no effect on anyone. Apes scar one another with no explanation really given other then to create a 'cool visual moment' later in the film. Suddenly a character becomes rebellious and almost ruins our heroes chances. Since this wasn't effectively established into a character I liked, or let alone noticed. I didn't care and really hoped the apes would get him. An ape's entire religion changes in a split second and it doesn't seem to effect him. The secret of the planet can work, but is highly, highly unlikely given the information shown to us onscreen. And where do the horses come from? The only explanation for them at all is that they were in the original so they should be in this remake. But having horses in the original makes sense. The climax feels very by the numbers with a huge fight scene that plays too messily. And we have our hero kiss both women, way to make a choice screenwriters. And the ending is the worst of these 'cool moments' of all. A shock ending was written just to have a shock ending. I know the ending is true to the original novel but the original novel didn't really earn that ending anyways. This film earns it even less. The original film's ending was truly an extension of everything proceeding it. This ending will cause a lot of division among filmgoers.In the end Planet of the Apes has some great makeup, great physical acting with the way everyone moves, and honestly some cool little moments. But it's script is a great example of bad big budget filmmaking. Huge plot holes that are created through the need for 'cool moments'. With the original film being such a great insight into human nature bringing to the big screen the idea that we are able to destroy ourselves the only thing this film shows us is that Hollywood also has the ability to destroy themselves.

reviews.review_title: This is not a good movie!
reviews.content: Everything that was good about the original is gone from this movie, Wahlberg is terrible, the story limps along from set piece to set piece and Tim Burton seems to have decided to concentrate on making an action movie. Some of the ape make-up was incredible but I thought Helena Bonham Carters make-up was awful with its painted on eyebrows and lipgloss! The ending of the original was perfect and made up for any deficiencies in the rest of the film but this movie has a typical Hollywood happy ending with a contrived twist bolted on to the end as a nod to the original. I did want to enjoy the movie but I was just glad when it was over!

My father bought it on DVD and I watched it with him. The movie was quite good right up to the ENDING!!! The ending basically ruined the movie. If they ended it totally differently, It would have been an awesome ending. The Ending came out of nowhere when all they had to do was end it with Mark Whalberg crashing into his mother ship to make the cycle complete!

reviews.review_title: The little movie that could... but didn't.
reviews.content:
Planet of the Apes has many things going for it.  The first three are the creative minds of Tim Burton (director), Rick Baker (Make-up), and Danny Elfman (Music).  The sets and locations work well with the costuming and make-up to give this an original look and an authentic feel even though it is a remake.  The cinematography and music work well together because neither one overshadows the other making the combination very powerful.
The acting was good and I must take my hat off to Helena Bonham Carter and to Tim Roth who did exceptional in their portrayals.  The supporting cast didn't stand out like Carter or Roth, but they did a good job of holding their own ground.  Mark Wahlberg's character, Leo Davidson, is the classic military hero who never shows too much emotion because he is trying to stay in control of the situation.  It almost seems that if Wahlberg weren't an actor, he would have actually been this guy.  Estella Warren's character could have easily weighed down the movie by being the typical sexy woman, but thankfully Burton never really draws attention to her in that way: we know she's beautiful, but we don't need to waste 20 minutes of the movie proving it.  She doesn't have any dense lines bent at attracting Wahlberg or any slow motion shots of her character taking a hot bath.  Instead Estella Warren does a good job of playing a character simply caught in the story and reacting in a realistic way.  A personal favorite part of mine was the cameo appearance of Charlton Heston, who almost has the same classic line that he had in the original.The story, though shaky at the beginning, quickly regains its composure and holds the audience's attention.  Once upon the actual planet, there are many satirical references to the way our society has treated animals, the environment, and each other (in cases of slavery).  It is this ability of holding a mirror to society that has made Burton a genius in his craft. Even though the storyline is a tad simple and any audience member can guess or just about guess how the whole story transpired, it doesn't matter because we are trapped in this world and we become interested in the characters interaction with each other.The ending is what could have wrapped up the entire experience into a good movie but didn't.  The last ten minutes of the movie was a horrible attempt at a twist ending.  If you watch closely you can see the movie end, but for some reason, another whole ending is added.  The problem with the second twist ending is that there is no bridge that connects this ending with the rest of the movie, so instead of discovering an ending you didn't even know you were looking for, you leave the theater thinking `Ummm ok, that doesn't make very much sense.'  The storyline should take you from point A to point B, but the ending tells you that you are actually at point C and doesn't attempt in any way, shape, or form to explain how you got there.I gave this movie a 5 because it has the attempt, it just doesn't have the follow through.

reviews.review_title: Don´t forget it is a FANTASY movie
reviews.content: WARNING! Don´t read if you didn´t see the movie yet!At first I have to say that I didn´t see the original movie yet (shame on me!) but I don´t consider this to be important for this review. As I´m a Tim Burton-Fan, I had to watch the new "Planet of the Apes" - and I liked it.It is a great movie, full of fantastic pictures - the great comic-style, which I love Tim Burton for. The soundtrack is perfect, the special effects are great and , what is the most important: the story is very entertaining and full of suspense.Of course, as many of you did, you could ask many logical questions as: - Why are there horses on the planet? - Why are there different races? - How is it possible for a few humans and two apes to ride through a complete camp of aggressive apes? - Why does the chimp land exactly at the moment when Leo is about to lose his fight? - How is it possible for a small spaceship, to fly from the planet of the apes back to the earth? And why does it only take three minutes? - Why does Estella Warren wear lipstick? - Why is the earth full of apes at the end?I read many questions like this, and of course there are many more you could ask! But please don´t forget, it is a fantasy movie! A fantasy movie doesn´t need to be realistic, and it also doesn´t want to be!Nobody asks why it is possible to hear noises, when space ships in Star Wars shoot at something - although it is impossible to hear noises in space! A fantasy movie lives of exaggerations! Why do you always bother about realism in fantasy films? If you want to watch a realistic movie, then you should watch a drama or something, but no fantasy or science-fiction movie! - Or at least, don´t wonder about exaggerations!Of course it was not a perfect movie. Mark Whalberg really didn´t act very well, and I often asked myself why Estella Warren is in this movie. She is always in the middle of the plot, looking beautiful but speaking only five sentences over the whole movie.But altogether it was a very nice movie. I will have to buy the DVD as soon as it is available!Therefore 8 out of 10.Well, I think I will watch the original movie soon, but I´m not looking forward to compare the movies!

OK, so they can build houses, but cannot build boats or bridges? I'll take that. Space ships power still there? Alright, and all the little fun holes I won't even bother on. The ending? Yuck. A movie where the time travel is worse than what Bill and Ted's excellent adventure, and an ending which tries but fails to get close to the original. Wooo another monument used, how impressive. (snore)

reviews.review_title: Summer movie filler...could've been better with more thought and time...
reviews.content: A summer movie, popcorn, bad script and cool FX...The Make-up creations by Rick Baker kicked butt!!! But I cannot recommend the 'new' version of 'Planet of the Apes' even for that point. Tim Burton has helmed a film that has the 'taint' of 'HOLLYWOOD' all over it...I was expecting a PIZZA HUT box to show up on the obvious sets...Everyone involved has simply hacked it out...besides the rightious make-up, the only other noteworthy aspect of the film is the decent acting by the actors playing APES...(Especially Tim Roth as the main villian...he was very menacing...) those without make-up had little or nothing to do. Sitting down and thinking it over, I realized that I hated seeing this film, and hope that Tim Burton and all involved will have better luck on their next projects...I'd rather watch 'Dude where's my car?' that sit through this big budget hooey again...4 out of 10

reviews.review_title: good movie, nice rework of the BOOK
reviews.content:
***spoilers***   ***spoilers*** ++Spoilers++People need to remember that this movie is a reimagination of the 1963 BOOK...not the 1968 movie.Also, the ending of Burton's Apes equals the ending of the BOOK...why blame or criticize Burton for remaining faithful to the BOOK?  If you have fault with the ending, take it up with the BOOK...not the movie.  Stop acting all surprised (er, ignorant) about the ending of the Burton Apes.  Better yet, go read the book and compare for yourselves.  Reading takes time and effort, of course.The POTA Book, written in 1963, was written by Pierre Boulle.  He also wrote the Bridge Over The River Kwai.This movie does a good job of updating the original premise put forth in the BOOK, without giving away everything and explaining every little detail in full technicolor for the movie going audience.  Both the book and Burton's Apes are similar in a few ways.  For one, the main character(s) travels through time, into the future, to a planet inhabited by Apes.  We learn that the planet was once ruled by humans (Thade's father and the pistol, a doll in the Book), and that the Apes would prefer keeping this secret. Finally, the main character returns to Earth only to find out that Apes inhabit Earth.On the main plot points, the Burton Apes is similar to the BOOK, even the ending.  On lesser points, the book and this movie are also similar.  The Apes, having taken control of the planet, haven't made much technological progress in the last X thousand years...still using tools, weapons, etc., that existed way back when, when they took control.  The book explains this by mentioning that while the Apes are good with mimicking what they see already...they lack the ability, for the most part, for creating new ideas. They simply took over, while humans left for the jungle areas and lived that way for 10,000 years (a short time in evolution standards, agreed) until the main character (Ulysse) shows up.  The "ape hunts human" scene in the beginning of both movies is similar to the book as well.In other areas, they diverge.  In the book, the humans cannot talk (much like the 1968 movie version) and Nova plays a large role.  The Apes don't speak English (actually French...the main character (Ulysse) in the book is French) but rather an ape language, so at first Ulysse doesn't understand them.  He learns their language in time, however.  Both Cornelius and Zira play critical roles in the book, similar to the 1968 movie as well. However, Dr. Zaius is not as powerful in the book as he was in the 1968 movie; in fact, "gorillas" are the dominant players in the book, the Chimps and Orangutans are in leadership positions only because gorillas allow them and support them in those roles.  The gorillas are the real doers in the book.
The book was more of a satire...an updated Gulliver's Travels, that poked fun at society, thinkers, educated people, etc.  The ending of the book involves Ulysse, Nova, and their son returning to Earth.  On both the trip away from Earth, and the return to earth, much time has elapsed on Earth (due to scientific explanations of which I won't bore anyone).  When they land, Ulysse is expecting to see futuristic vehicles and buildings and so forth, and is at first surprised that things look not much different than when he left (which would have been hundreds/thousands of years previously). He is shocked, of course, when he sees a police car pull up and 2 gorillas step out.  At that moment, he realizes that what happened on the Planet of the Apes (decline of Humans, rise of Apes, not much technological change for X thousand years) also happened on Earth!In the movie, this is not entirely clear.  What really happened, it appears, in the movie is that Wahlberg returns to Earth well into the future (not the present) and learns that humans declined, apes took over, and not much technological advances occurred in between.  In other words, the ending of the Burton Apes is similar to the book!  The explanation of "Honest Ape" Thade at the end could be one of two things, at least.  One, it could be a monument to another "Thade" that rose to power on Earth and has no connection whatsover to the Thade left, in captivity and decidedly NOT killed on the Planet of the Apes.  Or two, it could be that Thade escaped from his cell, commandeered a flying vessel (either repaired the one in the water, or perhaps another pod lands shortly after the chimp's did) and flies to Earth at a time much sooner than Wahlberg and precipitates an uprising leading to the downfall of Man and rise of Apes.In all, a very interesting movie based on a very interesting and funny BOOK that provides the viewer with much to think about.  Special effects are very good, and while I don't think it's a perfect movie by any stretch, I do think it's definitely worthwhile and entertaining, worthy of seeing. Also, read the book...and stop complaining about the ending of the Burton Apes.

It seems the actors in this movie were so busy portraying apes that they forgot how to deliver a line. Tim Roth over-acted completely, start to finish, and Michael Clarke Duncan under-acted. The ending is also completely out in left field; come on, would the apes really have evolved EXACTLY like we did? I don't think so. Okay, I've just listed all of the flaws with this movie that I can think of. Otherwise, it was well choreographed and had a decent plot. Even Mark Wahlberg did a good job.  I think, given the ending, a sequel will be ridiculous, but there's not much that can be done there. Go see the movie, though. 7 out of 10 stars.

Well, not really... but it was a lot of fun.  For all those who didn't like it, I'm curious what you were expecting.  Did you really expect a movie about angry talking monkeys to be a masterpiece?  Yes, it has it's flaws, but for the most part was well executed.  Tom Rothwas pure evil, some have said that he was "too evil", but isn't that the point of a super-villain?  His character was over the top, and I loved it.  The only real flaw for me was that Mark Whalberg kept slipping into Dirk Diggler, but I was able to ignore him for most of the film.  As for the ending, it was great.  I don't think that it was supposed to be logical, so stop whining!  It was a great over the top way to end an over the top film/concept.  So...go see it, expect to be entertained, not educated and you will love it!

That was a complete waste of time. The script was so jagged, simple and ridiculous that it was almost painful to follow. The visuals like most of Hollywood these days were good, but forced to compensate for the badly written script. May be it was written for an audience of monkeys.

Planet of the Apes was done extremely well for a remake. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It was not far-fetched and silly like other recent movies. There was no jumping through glass, and not getting a scratch type movie. And I was not over overwhelmed by so much action and special effects. The special effects were outstanding, and you could sometimes make out the faces of the actors. I give it *** 1/2 stars out of 4.

I saw Planet of the Apes last Friday and I got a say that although it's not a bad film, it could have been much better. The film s biggest flaw is that some characters are just plain useless. Especially the boy who always wants to help Leo and Leo's love interest ( he talks to her like 3 times in the whole movie!).On the plus side the acting is pretty good, the special effects are A+ and the ending, while it doesn t have the same impact the original had, wont disappoint you. Tim Burton is known for his great visual style(Sleepy Hollow, Batman) and he does a great job here too.7/10

First of all, I would like to say I liked the film... in spite of all the problems I had with it.The ape make-up rocked!  If not for Ari's (Helen Bonham Carter) "too human" make-up, it wouldn't take you too long to forget that they were actors only made up to look like apes.  Tim Roth WAS Thade! Both Tim Roth as General Thade and Paul Giamatti as Limbo deserve a nod come Oscar time. Unfortunately the majority of the cast looked as though they were phoning it in.In a couple of scenes you could see that Estella Warren was wearing heavy lip gloss but this could be a cinematography problem as in another scene it appeared as Mark Wahlberg was also wearing lip gloss.As for the story, it is one that a non sci-fi fan would assume was "good" science fiction, however it wasn't.  The plot had holes the size of Texas and there was no sign that anyone had tried to fill them.  The original movie ended with a "Gosh WOW!" and this one ended with a "what the f..., HUH?"  I can still remember coming out of the theatre after seeing the orginal for the first time with a sense of wonder.  Of course that was back in a time when the thought of the human race nuking itself to oblivion wasn't that big a stretch.  I was thinking about the ending of that film for weeks, I doubt I'll be thinking about the ending of this one tomorrow.  One good thing to say about the ending is that it more closely echos the ending the book "Monkey Planet" by Pierre Boulle than the original film did.Having said all these nasty things, there is still much to enjoy about this film.  The direction was very good and the score was delightful.  The music over the opening credits was very much an homage to Jerry Goldsmith's original score.One can only hope that the inevitable sequel can shed some light on the confusing ending.

As one who reveres the 1968 original, I admit to approaching this "reconstruction" with some amount of skepticism, but I was determined to go in with an open mind.  I tried to like it but in the end I'd have to deem this attempt at a new "Apes" as a disappointment.Sure, Tim Burton's masterful visual style and Danny Elfman's evocative musical scoring are in full effect as always, but in service to a mediocre script that plays like a typical action movie.  The pointed social commentary of the original film, released at the height of the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War is not quite as effective here.Sure, there's also a couple of plot twists that rival the final revelation of the original.  A couple of classic lines from the original are cleverly worked in, and Charlton Heston, who carried the first picture and made us believe in the story, this time plays an ape. Nice touch!But the bottom line is, there's nothing new here to justify the time and expense of this film.  I expected more from Tim Burton!

Being a fan of Tim Burton's, I was highly anticipating the release of this movie. After seeing it, I was definitely not disappointed. Burton's version of "Planet of the Apes" is just as good, if not better than the original idea. He adds just the right mix of action, adventure, and comedy in the movie, making it a thoroughly enjoyable experience throughout. As for Charlton Heston's cameo...that almost made the whole movie for me...absolutely classic. Tim Roth does a fantastic job as Thade, the evil leader of the Ape Army, and the costumes and effects are simply amazing. The ending was an interesting piece...leaving some I know confused. I just smell a possible sequel if things go well for this movie, which it should.

reviews.review_title: not Burton´s best, but not bad
reviews.content: I must say that I was very dissapointed when I saw this film. The "re-imagine" concept just does not work in the movies (just ask Gus Van Sant). But I thought Burton might make it work. Well, I was wrong. I adore Burtons work and in my personal opinion he is Hollywood´s greatest director, but that does not mean that I love every piece of celluloid that he comes in contact with. POTA has some potentials but somehow they just fizz out. You can never stop asking yourself "Why?" Why make a remake of a near perfect film? If POTA 2001 would have been the first ape film, this might have been hailed as a great film. The fact simply is that we have seen this before. And what what is Burton doing with a comic relief?! Limbo is doing the same for this movie as Jar Jar did for Episode one! He is to much, to "haha funny" and should have been killed when the humans escaped. But no, we have to endure him throughout the whole film! The movie does have some good points though. First of all it has Tim Roth. He is without a doubt the best actor in this film and his ape impression is at times very frightening. The sets, costumes and everything in that department was impeccable, in a Burtonian way. There have been some who say that the make up in this film is no better than in the original. That is pure nonsense. I am inclined to think that these people are only blinded by some hate of Burton and his POTA and for fouling the memory of the original that they can´t give credit where credit is due! The makeup in this movie is sheer brilliance. The movement of the actors lips are now visible and so are other discreet features. This is better make up and saying otherwise just underlines that some people can´t judge films without letting feelings cloud there judgement. Last words. See the film at least two times. The initial shock wears off an you like it better the next time.

reviews.review_title: A movie that need not be observed
reviews.content: This film is a huge disappointment. Having seen the original 5 films from the 1960's - 1970's, only the first three warrant viewing. The new film doesn't capture any of the uniqueness, excitement, and action. Poor script writing, casting, acting, and editing...which is worse? It's hard to tell. Hopefully, there will be no sequels to the new remake. Let the originals live as proof positive that remakes seldom can equal or surpass the quality of their originals.

reviews.review_title: "Damn Tim Burton!! Damn him to hell!!"
reviews.content: Remakes can sometimes be as good as the original from what I hear, but in this case, its just wrong!  The movie wasn't a snoozefest because of the action (well most of the time its inaction) sequences, the comic wit of Paul Giamatta was well placed, and the little inside jokes made it a good enough work to make me wish there was more.  Tim could have done so much more with this picture, but for some reason chose not to.  At best, Marky Mark was a wooden actor.  Total textbook anti-hero.  The plot holes were big enough to drive a Mack truck through (If humans outnumber apes 4 to one, why were they winning?  The ENDING?  How a few hundred ape warriors get blasted by an afterburner rocket and none wind up to be extra tasty crispy?  How all of a sudden Pericles KNOWS where the ship is and comes "just in time"?)The saving graces of this movie were superb performances by Tim Roth (general thade), Michael Clarke Duncan (general Attar), and Paul Giamatti (Limbo).  I wish I was the guy who owned the local hydraulic catapult supply house for Hollyweird.

The idea that anyone would expect for this to be a complete remake is completely silly. In fact taking the basic idea and writing a whole new plot is nice. WARNING: This deals with the ending.  The story does take place on the Planet Earth. I don't think enough people got this. In the original "apes" Heston gets sent forwards in time which is the big "surprise ending". In the 2001 "apes" Burton has the clock forward to make you think they are following the old plot. In reality Mark goes back in time and the Station in following him gets sent even further back and populates the Earth with men and apes. Then when he goes back into the future he returns to a world that is the outcome of the man/ape war. This isn't a remake think of it more as a remix.

I really liked this version of 'Planet of the Apes'. The costumes were excellent and the acting was very well done but I was really p***ed off with the ending. I feel the lead up to the ending needed to be explained more. Over all it was a good movie.

I went to see this movie opening night and boy was dissapointed. I'm not a big fan of Tim Burton. But I saw Mark Whalberg in three kings and The Perfect storm and he wasn't ha;f bad. I also thought that Helena Bonham Carter was great in Fight Club. The Movie starts off alright. It had excellent makeup and fairly good special effects. The acting wasn't bad either. Up until the ending it was about a c+. But once it got to the end it was downhill. I was just plain p***ed off. I reccomend seeing this just so u can see what i am talking about. My final rating. D.

I have been disappointed to one extent or another all year long.  Usually, I pick one or two movies each year which go on my "buy the video" list.  Last year, it was "The Matrix."  This year so far, it's "Shrek."  What do these two have in common?  They were well written.  Good writing, when accompanied by good visuals and a good score, can make a movie great.  "The Matrix" and "Shrek" prove that people actually appreciate good writing.  Most of the reviews concerning "Planet of the Apes" complain about plot holes (bad writing), the ending (I liked the reviewer who revealed the clue Ape Lincoln---in fact, the ending may have been "forced" on the writer because of this pun, and now they have to make sense out of that pun by writing a sequel that explains it), uncreative face-offs / battle scenes, and character development.  I think this country is full of good writers, but they apparently only infrequently make it through the Hollywood meat grinder.I have to agree that "Planet of the Apes" suffers tremendously in the writing department.  I liked only three characters, Ari (a fine line between human compassion and simian behavior), General Thade (convincingly evil), and the human slave trader (a few good laughs).  These characters were minimally written, but at least they had character.  No other ape or human in the film was developed.  Estella Warren was totally devoid of any character, and did not exist in this plot for any reason.  She wasn't even good eye candy.At the very least, the movie should have ended after the chimpanzee in the pod removed his helmet before the ape masses, giving Burton more time to develop the characters from the beginning of the film up to this point.There are many points to make about how to write a good script.  One point is that a battle between two good characters is almost always more interesting than a battle between a good and evil one.  As a point of reference, think about the ending of "The Vikings," where Kirk Douglas and Tony Curtis battle to the death on a seaside castle.  You really care about both characters.  You don't want either one to die.  It's so much easier to play the "I want comeuppance" card than the "tragedy" card in a battle scene. In "The Vikings," it's not even brute force that determines the victor.I love science fiction, and my favorite is still "Aliens," which defies most sci-fi cliches in the sense that it's an action picture with good writing and a child who actually enhances rather than detracts from the film. However, "The Matrix" is on my top five list.  Hopefully, the Matrix sequels will be well written.In short, Hollywood needs to go back to basics and only film well written stories.  I'm sure there are thousands of average people out there who could do a better job (the reviews here prove there are a lot of good heads) writing a movie like this.  But the average person will never get a chance.So, if you go see "Planet of the Apes," do so for the visuals and a decent score.  Maybe that's enough for casual entertainment.  But it won't stir any activity in your brain (unless you write movie reviews afterward!).

"Planet of the apes" was good film, it was not a great film like the 1968 classic and in fact it was horbble remake. Most of you  have probbly seen the original "Planet of the Apes" so i wont bother explaining the plot. But while I was watching this remake I was wandering, why did Tim Burton direct this? As I said this was a good film but, Tim Burton has directed some great films like "Edward Scissor Hands" and "Sleepy Hollow" It should have been directed by somebody else since this was a remake the whole movie was laid out, so Tim Burtons brains were wasted. But still it is a good popcorn movie witch can be viewed by the entire family.

reviews.review_title: Where do we go from here?
reviews.content: Tim Burton is my favorite director, he's never made a bad movie...(Mars Attacks! isn't bad, just grossly misunderstood), but I have mixed feelings about some of his decisions.  As an aspiring film maker, I understand that in order to get paid, one must first appease the investors, (studio's). Burton however has managed to do this, without compromising his art, up until now. It seemed that Burton wanted to make a...for lack of a better word, darker movie, that addressed some perverse issues, but was forced to back up by a force off camera.  (Perhaps the whole bestiality issue would have been interesting?)  there were plenty of other issues that could've been explored but weren't. I loved the little details however, the ape with the music box and the human midget as his pet, it was great, you really got a sense of culture, I just wish I saw more of it.  Many of the issues in the film were greatbut there could've been more. I also felt that the political aspect of the film wasn't addressed.  Perhaps a scene that took place in the ape senate would have been interesting.  (Or maybe that's just the Sparticus inside me talking?) I really would have liked to see Glen Shadix a bit more. As usual, the film was visually stunning...but for the first time ever, I feel that Burton has sacrificed substance for style.  The film was eye-candy indeed, but lacked that human, (or ape...sorry), quality. Marky's character was also lacking.  He was the outsider, Burton's on-screen alter-ego...why would Burton not developed him more?  Burton's renowned for glorifying the "outsider"...how could he let this one slip?  He got Carter's character right, why would he over-look the obvious freak? Last but not least is Elfman.  His score was lacking as well.  That beautiful sense of pensiveness or melancholy wasn't present in this score. Perhaps I'm getting too picky, but like so many others, I expected so much more. I'm not criticizing Burton for "selling out"(after-all, isn't that the goal of every director)?  And I didn't think this was a bad movie, as a matter of fact, I liked it and thought it was a good movieI just hope that Burton doesn't compensate his art for the sake of a sequel again.

reviews.review_title: The only thing I didn't like about this movie was what the adolescent character was asked to do.
reviews.content: I recently saw this movie and was surprised to find a line.  This was the first time I had ever waited in a line to see a movie.  It was especially noteworthy because I live in a moderate size town. The stuntmen in this movie seem to be trying out for "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon".  At the same time they made it look very simian.  I thought this movie was well done.  It is a little too dark most of the time but I'm pretty sure this is on purpose.  There is one problem with this movie that I noticed.  Actually I've been noticing it for years.  That problem is the adolescent actor (in this case Luke Eberle).  For the past years both televison and Hollywood have written two main types of characters for adolescent actors.  In the first type the adolescent character is told to: go in the house, go over there, etc.  Why is it that the "adult" actors are afraid for the adolescent characters to be an integral part of the defense of the home or whatever the movie entails.  The second type is where the adolescent character either is allowed to help or just does.  However, the "adult" character either has to fix what the adolescent character did or save the adolescent character from death etc.  This movie is no different.  In it the Luke Eberle character is basically told to go hide by Mark Wahlberg.   The Luke character then refuses and decides to try and help.  Then in typical fashion the Mark Wahlberg character has to save the Luke character from certain death.  When is the establishment and the "adult" actors going to realize that adolescent characters actually can  help in defense situations and many other situations as well?  I realize that many of these adolescent actors have not "paid their dues" yet but to me that is a terrible reason to perpetuate a stereotype.  For that is indeed what it is.  So even though this movie perpetuates both of these stereotypes I think it is still a rather good movie.  However, it could have been better had the writers filled the stereotype spot with something important.

I found nothing noteworthy in this movie. The story line was ok. The acting was competent. The effects were good, but not outstanding given today's technology.This movie managed to get campy at times without having any redeeming qualities to compensate for it. It struck me as very politically correct and thus didn't really have anything to say.It is a simple action flick, and an average one at that.It is immediately forgettable, except perhaps for the ending which breaks any chance of the movie being self consistent.

I'm tired of reading comments that state the ending is 'unrealistic' or 'implausible' or 'it doesn't make sense'. It's make believe. Things can be made up. Does everything have to be spoonfed to this lazy american society? Talking computers did not exist in the early 70's. So maybe Kubrick's film 2001 should have not included them. That's silly. If Burton wanted to warp time back and forth then more power to him. It's FICTION you can make things up.

I was fired up to see this movie.  I went right away so no one could spoil the surprise ending.  I was extremely disappointed in the film and urge you to save your 9 bucks.  For the record, I think the original was excellent. Here are the main reasons why this movie falls short. (No spoilers) - Many plot holes - Cheesy humorous references to the first movie...why is this necessary? Apparently, they rightly felt that this movie couldn't stand on it's own. - Stereotypical bad guy (ape) - Stereotypical good guy( female ape , made up to look like Janet Jackson) - Drags at times. - Gratuitous "surprise" ending...not well thought out and inserted merely for the sake of having a surprise ending like the good, first movie.Rent it when it comes out and you'll see what I mean...or better yet, go rent the original.

Let me start by saying that I am a huge Tim Burton fan. I consider his visions on film absolutely fantastic! I see Tim's hand in about  the first 2/3rds of this film.The last  1/3rd seems like the work of "suits" rather than "artists. While the film has a certain awesome visual style-give Rick Baker the Academy Award for Makeup right now-we are constantly challenged to suspend disbelief for shallow plot points and trite dialog. Forget character development. Forget logic and check your brain with your ticket stub. The ending (which I will not reveal here so as not to spoil for those who have not seen yet) is a nightmare. I understand that there were possibly 5-7 different endings- maybe a DVD Special Edition or definitive director's cut could make more sense than this "barrel of  monkeys." Hollywood get original. Less effects more story. No  more sequels - I'm feeling sick.

So far I've seen Pearl Harbor, Moulin Rouge and now this movie and I had great expectations for all three but they turned out to be a big disappointment. Especially this re-make of Planet of the Apes was so disappointing that I'm even embarrassed telling I went to see it. My next movie choice will be Captain Corelli's Mandolin and I hope it won't be another disappointment. Where are the good movies?? Anyway, the atrocious acting in Planet of the Apes was embarrassing to watch. I liked Mark in the Perfect Storm but in this movie he was horrible, also miscast, I believe, remembering how Charlton Heston was so much a better choice in the first movie. I agree with so many other negative comments about this movie and so I won't repeat them. All the promotion that went into this movie made me believe it was a worthwhile movie but what a waste of time and money. By all means, go see it if you're that curious to compare it with the first one, the list of people disappointed will only grow longer.

***SPOILERS AHEAD****Ok, I read a little bit about this movie before i saw it and went in not looking for the original. I liked the original, the best part being the ending which tied everything together - just like a movie should be done.
Now i go into this one knowing that is will be different, and was enjoying it for the most part. One thing i cant figure is how a monkey can make a perfect landing on one try and the Air Force pilot crashes twice? Aside from that i enjoyed the movie very much. I am not one to blast acting so other reviews i have read talking about the acting does not bother me as long as it is not terrible and this was not. The costumes were very good, action good all in i would have given the movie about an 8 or better.............until the end. Someone has to explain this to me. I am totally lost. This ending put a rotten cherry atop a very good sundae. The story till the last 5 minutes was great things made sense everyone was able to follow along till that ending.The only thing i can think of is DVD sales. You throw in deleted scenes and alternate endings and sell a ton of DVDs.

reviews.review_title: Boooo, Mr. Burton, Boooo indeed. SPOILERS
reviews.content: I have been a big Planet of the Apes fan since I was very little. It is the first "grown-up movie" that I can remember watching. So you can imagine my excitement when this remake was announced.You can imagine that my excitement was doubled when I learned that Tim Burton would direct! And  can you believe it they even hired one of my favorite actors of all time Tim Roth to play a starring role.Now Imagine if you will that it "stinked"!!!!!They spent millions on elaborate sets and costumes and years in production, just to miss the whole point of the original movie: The "Planet" of the Apes was EARTH! You know the whole reverse evolution thingy ... What was Burton thinking!?! I'll admit that if this was an original movie I would have liked it, but it's not! There are certain elements of any classic that just shouldn't be messed with.Maybe if they would have changed the name a little, say "Ape Planet" or "Marky Mark goes Ape" or "Clash of the Vertebrates"Boooo, Mr. Burton, Boooo indeed.WAIT FOR THE VIDEO!

I'll have to agree with everyone... I was very disappointed with this film, the storyline was weak and didn't make all that much sense, but the makeup and graphics were very cool. What I think would have made a good movie is a remake of the 68 version and to stick with that plot.

This is the movie I have been waiting for 30 years to see, ever since I peeked over the back seat of the station wagon at the drive in theater waiting for Doctor Dolittle (http://us.imdb.com/Title?0061584) to start.  I was five years old, and this was before the days of real ratings.  Besides, the original Apes movie was rated an amazing 'G' as was that other talking animal film we went to see.That said, I was terribly disappointed in the 2001 re-visioning of the 'Planet of the Apes'.  Tim Burton is one of my favorite cutting-edge directors, and Danny Elfman a top composed.  The cast looks excellent - on paper, but in reality the characters are mainly one dimensional and shallow. The possible exception is Helena Bonham Carter as Ari, who at least seemed to have fun playing a rather muppet-like Chimp/Human rights activist. Burton didn't dare go anywhere but the obvious places, and even with the attempt at a surprise twist ending (which left me slack jawed at the sheer disconnectedness of it).  There were so many opportunities to build these characters in an otherwise visually stunning universe.  Would it be bestiality for two sapient members of different species to actually explore their apparent sexual tension that Burton was trying to portray?  Could it have been possible for Daena (Estella Warren) to do anything other than pine and heave her fur-bikinied breasts about?  There was a real opportunity to explore something here that Burton ignored.  And Burton usually hits these on the head.The first ape line of the film made me dread what was an otherwise decent start to the movie.  I won't reveal what it is, but it was too obvious an attempt to try to a) make you laugh, b) set the tone of the film, and c) nod to the original film.Overall, I give this film a 3 out of 10 for an overall impression.  I give Rick Baker a 10 out of 10 for an AMAZING bunch of creatures.  I give Mark Wahlberg (Capt. Leo Davidson) a -2 out of 10 for mailing in his performance and avoiding any sort of commitment to his role.  Helena Bohnam Carter (Ari) gets a 7 out of 10 for her role, and Tim Roth (General Thade) gets 8 out of 10 for being a peeved chimpanzee and a vicious character, and making me truly dislike him.  Or was it the complete shallowness of his character that I hated?  Wait, I give Tim Roth an 8, and I subtract two points from Tim Burton for not allowing such a fine villain to have any depth for a total Tim Burton score of 3 out of 10.  Visually, the film gets 8 out of 10 from me.Nutshell summary:  A mediocre attempt worth seeing for the makeup and soundtrack, and for the uncomfortable laugh at the end when you realize how much Hollywood is spending to produce crap these days.  This film is definitely worth a rental, but save yourself the $8.50 to see it in the theater.

reviews.review_title: Mark is great in the movie!
reviews.content: i would just like to say that planet of the apes is the best summer movie and the best movie i have seen in a long time....it is funny and full of action....the actors/actresses such as Estella Warren, Mark Wahlberg, Michael Clarke Duncan, Tim Roth, and Helena Bonham Carter did so well as their characters and they made the movie better with how they really got into their characters...and for everyone that was an ape/monkey/orangutang they did so well in the training and in the movie and i would just like to say that they made the lives of apes become real and i think this re-make was so much more realistic and interesting and i love the ending because it makes you want to see the next one of planet of the apes and i have to say that i hope everyone stays the same characters....and for all the actors, makeup artists, directors, producers, composers, and the rest that were involved with the film did so well and i am glad to see such a great movie be on top....thanx buh bye!!

Hey everyone i just wanted to comment on "Planet of the Apes" i think it was a great movie and they picked a real good person to play "Leo Davidson" (Mark Wahlberg)...i think that Mark Wahlberg is such a great actor because he can be so many characters..and make it look good...and for all the apes such as Helena Bonham Carter, and Michael Clarke Duncan were so good and so well trained to be apes and monkeys...i think that the new "Planet of the Apes" was well made (fixed up) it is much more realistic and the director Tim Burton and all the makeup artist couldn't have done better...i have heard from Mark Wahlberg that there is going to be a part 2 or second one and i can't wait until that comes out because the first one was awesome!!

reviews.review_title: you think you're better than me...and you probably are!
reviews.content: Uhoh, big surprise...a big special effects movie with a stupid plot caused by misbudgeting (i.e - $50000000000000000000 dollars spent on special effects, and then they paid the writer in tuna sandwiches which he quickly devoured before returning to his cardboard-box home) see: Godzilla, Batman & Robin, Practically every Sci-Fi movie since Return of the Jedi. Mark Wahlberg was horrible (another big surprise...not!) the average door-to-door vaccum salesman would have been a better choice. Helena Bonham Carter (disguised by thick layers of polyurethane and "you can see all their mistakes on every close-up shot" make-up) was the only one who played their part well. She seemed oddly out of place, but made the movie a little more watchable. The ending was so absurdly stupid it gives me an aneurysm every time I try to think about it. The genius of it is: It's stupid on every conceivable level. It doesn't matter if you're Steven Speilberg or Steven Jones (the 80 year old crazy looking janitor at Homeland), you're simply un-able to like the ending at all. What's really sad is that this could have been a "good" movie. Wahlberg sub-par acting skills could have been overlooked if they just didn't add all the stupid scenes. If you choose to inflict this movie upon yourself then you'll know what I'm talking about. Certain things just didn't need to be there. Estella Warren, for instance. Her character did nothing of relevance at all. There was no romance between her and Wahlberg, she only had a few lines, but you could tell that they were trying to give the impression of romance, but it didn't work at all. And, despite the fact that she has lived her entire life in a desert wilderness being captured by Apes and forced to do slave-labor, and then escape, her lip-stick never fades! It's amazing! It seemed like a really "americanized" film though, all the way. But, if about 20 minutes of the film was cut (including, most-importantly, the retard ending) then I would give it like a 7 out of 10. But as is I'd have to give it a 7 out of 100

The movie was decent, not great but good enough to be a good remake. I'm a Tim Burton fan, and while I think that this is not his best film, it's still worthy enough to be a part of his work. The make up is great, and Tim Roth probably gave the best performance of a villain I have seen in quite some time.It's good but it needed a better Story.

Wow this was one heck of a crap film,I dont get it I am only back from watching it and I've spent the last 1hr or soo trying to fiqure out which one the main character likes (I think his names Leo or something) Is it Monkey Woman or the Blonde Supermodel?? I honestly didn't get it,I;m totally lost......Ok so it was ok,the acting was hmmm all right,Special effects Cool but the story? I ask you a question WHAT STORY????I give this a 6/10 for the costumes and effects!!

The story is not quite as good as the first film, but is definitely alot of fun to watch. The one downfall of the film is the overall substance of the human beings and their relationship with one another.  It was pretty cold in that area.  I would have given the lead to a different actor other than Mark Wahlberg. His character needed to be as big as the apes in the film.  And the apes in this film were just as good as the characters in the first movie.  Super makeup by Rick Baker and the sets looked fantastic.  One final note...I wish the battle scene at the end had more substance and a little more thought put into it.  This would have given the film its climax that it badly needed.

reviews.review_title: Good, but did anyone understand the ending?
reviews.content: To sum it all up the movie was alright, I wasn't expecting to be as good as the originals, but I just wanted to go see a film to see some good action...and excellent makeup.  I gave it a 6/10, it would've been rated possibly a 7 or a 8, but the ending was confusing...and I still don't get it....

Tim Burton's rendition of planet of the apes is just an interesting interpretation, not a remake. overall i thought it was well done. i do enjoy the originals quite a bit. after watching almost every original form of POTA, watching the Tim Burton version was fun, but just as long as you see it as his interpretation. the first time i saw the movie, i thought the ending was messed up, but after i saw it again years later, and understanding the time line of events i figured it out. many people have different opinions on what it means, but no one is close. the whole time Leo is on another planet. we know this from the 2 moons. then at the end he jumps into the alpha pod and heads for the electrical storm again, in hopes of going home. after Pericles arrives and just before Leo leaves the apes and humans have a respect for each other and now live in harmony, good job. then he leaves. however, general thade is still left there and being the ape-supremacist he is, is surely nothing less than disgusted. now, in an effort for revenge or even to alter his present, Thade becomes preoccupied with the delta pod. he is still one of a select group that knows about it. he somehow manages to resurrect it and get it to work. more than likely it still has power because A) its run with nuclear energy that "lasts forever" or B) just because Leo didn't use that much to get to the ape planet to begin with. Thade then takes off in the delta pod (possibly with another ape but i'm not sure, it is unlikely though) and manges to get into the electrical storm and make his way to earth. and because of the electrical storm he arrives long before Leo does. i think it may even be in the early 1900's. while he is there he, no doubt, wreaks havoc among the humans and through a series of unknown events, procreates and eventually overtakes the human race. and mysteriously history stays basically the same (except of course for the appearance of thade). thus when Leo gets to earth around the same time he left apes have long since ruled earth. we know its thade because if you look at the inscription on the back of the Lincoln memorial its says that it was built "in memory of general thade" (and it looks just like him). also, given that we now are back in time to the first present, Leo more than likely will not be able to go into space and have the beginning of the movie happen again and the first ape planet stays uninhabited.

I saw the film on opening day with hopes for air conditioned diversion, I got exactly that.  I am going to see the film again today with my father so I decided to check the showtimes and noticed that there were something like 520 reviews and checked some out.  You people are really moronic.  Anyone who was disappointed by this film did not use common sense.  Do you really think a movie this big, with this kind of budget, this kind of A-list director and this kind of cast was really going to satisfy you when it comes to plot and character development?  There has not been a hollywood movie out in years that has satisfied my intellectual yearnings, I have stopped seeking this kind of satisfaction in a hollywood film because it is Sisyphean.  This film did exactly what I expected it to do, it kept my attention for a full two hours.  Anybody who wanted to have the social commentary of the first movie, the melo-dramatic over-acting of the first movie, the garish orange costumes and the justified willful suspension of disbelief that the first film supplied you with you should have rented the first movie and stayed home.Anyone who enjoys Tim Burton's beautiful productions and just wants to sit in an air conditioned theatre for two hours without expectations should see this film, maybe even twice if your father missed it when you went with your girlfriend the first time.  And for the jackasses who keep trying to fault the film on its technical "inaccuracies" and anachronous plot holes: shut up and sit down!  It is popcorn fare for popcorn people.  You want to discuss technical boo boos, go to StarTrek.comI'm sorry I have to be so harsh with you but you have to learn somewhere along the line that Hollywood will not satisfy you anymore.

How many times have you seen a remake of a movie and thought that it was much better than the original?  If you are lucky you might be able to answer 1, possibly 2 or even three if you are very open minded (personally I've got one, John Carpenter's The Thing 1982).  Well Mr Burton knows that movie patrons and critics are very critical when it comes to the remaking of a classic film, especially if it is one of their personal favorites.  Thats why from the very conception planet of the apes 2001 was never intended to be a remake of the original classic film.  This seems to be the biggest handicap everyone seems to have getting in the way of actually giving this movie a fair shake.  I enjoyed this movie.  It wasn't a waste of 2 hours. I did like the original movie better.  But so what, there are a lot of movies that were are than the original planet of the apes.

reviews.review_title: Dumbing down for the current generation?
reviews.content: Whether written or film, Sci Fi works best when it's either ahead of it's time and cautionary, or of it's time and satirical. The original Apes' films fell in the latter camp, using the generation gap of the late 60s, the optimism and expectancy of the moon shots and (increasingly) the racial tensions building up in the states as its themes. Tim Burton's film does neither, living with the glib message that "we should, uh, just all get along and live with each other".Though there's a fair amount of spectacle to enjoy and a cracking performance from Tim Roth, POTA is ultimately unsatisfying. Up to this point in his career Burton was part of that small (miniscule?) group of American directors who had managed to deliver witty, scary, ironic, enjoyable films AND managed to get them distributed to your local McMultiplex. POTA sadly whiffs of compromise and poor editing ending up being confused and confusing.Go and see it (at the end of the day it IS fun) but don't let the phrase "hang on, why...?" appear in your mind at any point and don't be be tempted to wonder that if, in 30 years during which we've been able to shrink computers to a tenth of their size and digital watches have come and gone, monkey make-up still looks as ropey as it did when Roddy McDowell first started piling it on to spook Charlton Heston.

reviews.review_title: Could someone please turn on a light?
reviews.content: Ugh!!!  Aside from some inventive costumes and makeup, this movie blows. That is, when you can actually see what is going on.  Predictably, the sets were dark in an attempt to make it appear foreboding.  But, my God, the writing was atrocious -- and that blonde with the bee-stung lips......! I did enjoy Helena Bonham Carter, but she was one of just a few bright spots in the film.  Marky Mark was so-so, but Tim Roth was WAY over the top.  It was cartoonish.  The first 15 minutes of this film was so badly written and acted, I nearly walked out of the theater.

i feel like i am the only person who "got it" SPOILER ALERT!the problem with alot of the reviewers is they dont get this movie. this is a time travel movie...  all of the ships come out in a different time. notice that the main ship is on the planet 4 generations before mark wahlbergs landing, at the begining of time on earth, populating the earth with humans and genetically enhanced apes, who eventually become dominate over humans, changing the history of earth for all time. ( making a statement about genetically enhanced anything).  Mark shows up, then at the end the monkey shows up. now they were DEFINATELY ON EARTH!!!  changing the history of earth again by showing the apes that they need to live with man in harmony to gain their ability for technology. it gets into theology about man messing with gods plan and paying a price. then when Mark goes back to earth to the same year it was when he left the Oberon, it is to the earth with it's altered history. it is all there ari said it before he left " someday they will tell this story and some will say it is just a fable." that is the setup for the end sequence. you have to read between the lines and read the inscription behind thade/lincoln at the end. Thade became known through telling of the story, as the great emancipator of humans.  it was all there you just had to put it together. the apes could not use technology, so he had to had to have landed in a world that has humans and apes living together hence the hybrid people shown in closeup. burton is a master storyteller, and because he made people think they say the movie is bad.  the acting is teriffic.... mark is just trying to get back to the ship ignoring all else. the reluctant hero, this no buisness of his... was this not obvious? this is the best SF movie i have seen in along time.

I loved this film, and think that all the bad comments it has received are undeserved. Although I haven't seen the original, this film looks wonderful and dark, and this is surely thanks to Burton's skill as a director. It manages to make the slightly detached characters really work well together, and the acting was great throughout. Very interesting race/ animal rights issues are raised by this film and, although I'm guessing that the original also raised these issues, I suspect it provoked much thought with teenagers who wouldn't dream of watching the original. Of course, you've got to compare it with Burtons other films, and, as far as spooky, Gothic atmospheres go, this doesn't really live up to them. But as an action film it surpasses so many. My favourite character was the Tim Roth evil general. He is the kind of bad guy whose evil has been set so deep within himself that he can no longer control it, and when he kills those gorilla-type creatures it's absolutely amazing. He also emanates pure evil through his wonderfully made facial features. The ending is an issue that raises much debate, but I loved it, the master plan, killing one wave of the enemy with an explosion, was beautifully futile, and the coincidental monkey landing was pleasantly ridiculous. And his return to earth was just really cool. All in all, a great film, watch it. By the way, did anyone else find themselves fancying Helena Bonham Carter in this film. Although, because of the amount of hair and her weird posture, it sounds quite wrong to think that, it just feels so right!

The trailers were good, and I'd heard that it was supposed to be a good movie. Unfortunately, I left the cinema quite disappointed.The costumes and make-up was magnificent! The special effects were very good (though we're all becoming used to computer generated special effects these days, aren't we??)But the story was pathetic and poorly acted. Disappointing, even.

reviews.review_title: Nothing compared to original but worth seeing. Kept me entertained.
reviews.content: The film was nothing compared to the original BUT you have to understand that going in.  Otherwise, it kept me interested and entertained even though it left alot to be desired.  I rated it a solid 6 - its worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: Too Many Questions Arise From Movie.
reviews.content: The beginning of the movie really sets up the rest of the movie; "Marky" Mark is not going to be acting in this movie.This movie left me me with too many questions.1) If the Planet was uninhabited when "The Oberon" crashed landed there, and the apes and the humans were the only ones on board, where did the horses come from?2) Why isn't Captain Leo surprised to find out everyone speaks English?3) What was the point of Kris Kristofferson being in this movie?4) What kind of an ending was that?5) Why should I really care?If you see this movie for any reason, go see it for Tim Roth and Pau; Giamatti.Two opposable thumbs down.

CAUTION SPOILERS WITHINHaving just viewed this film last night, it is fresh in my mind and I wanted to make a few observations. Not a review per se, just some thoughts.Although flawed, it does have a few good things going for it. Rick Baker's work is truly amazing. The flexibility of the masks/make up used allows the actors to produce varied, expressive and very believable expressions. Nicely done.Most of the art direction and costume design is creative and well implemented. The ape army is cleverly and boldly realized.The acting, overall, is good, and especially in the case of Tim Roth, David Warner, Michael Duncan, & Helena Bonham Carter. They help create believable, if somewhat two dimensional characters. The lovely Estella Warren does fine in an underwritten role.Danny Elfman's creative score, effectively covers a wide variety of moods ranging through suspense, comedy and militaristic combat themes quite well.And then there's the other side of the coin, an at times interesting, but largely wooden formula driven plot, with dialog suffering from a bad case of pun infestation.A few things that don't work:At no time did I get the feeling that Captain Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) was all that surprised or impressed that he had discovered a culture where apes could talk, and ran the planet. It was sort of like `hmmm, that's odd, talking apes in charge of the world, hey look over there, we don't have oak trees like that on earth, this is INSANE!'And then the escape from the ape city, whose route cleverly goes right through the center of about a half dozen ape houses, `we'll keep running through these houses until we find the forest, its got to be around here somewhere. Once we've checked all the houses we'll start searching for the forest outside.'What's up with people (and apes) flying twenty feet or more through the air when they are struck by any ape (not just the gorillas), not occasionally, but everytime?  The great strength of apes? It would happen on earth. Lower gravity? Then apes would fly when humans struck them. Lots of stuntmen with springboards? Maybe.And then there's that one scene that just defies any logic, and I'm not talking about the `surprise ending'. Its when Captain Leo, wins the battle, brings a new understanding and compassion between apes and humanity, finds himself as the leader of a new world order, and then immediately hops in the space pod to return to earth. WHAT??? I mean, what's the hurry? He knows his crew have been dead for thousands of years, he's just won this planet's version of the Superbowl, the Nobel prize, and been elected President, clearly Estella Warren wants to jump his bones, and even Helena Bonham Carter's Ari is obviously intent on more advanced and exotic interspecies research. Even if he chooses not to lead this world through a new political, cultural & scientific revolution, how about taking some time to smell the roses, you know, a few weeks to gather scientific samples to bring back, to help advance anthropology by studying cross cultural (and species) mating rituals, to work at turning his space pod into a two seater, or to even bring extra food and water for what is likely to be a long and possibly fatal journey? I just don't get it.Worth seeing and entertaining, even for its flaws.Six out of ten stars.

reviews.review_title: Don't be too hard on the chimp.
reviews.content: This is from the goofs list. Revealing mistakes: Captain Leo Davidson pushes the throttle on his pod forward to accelerate towards the storm while the chimp pushes his in different directions. Then again, it is just a chimp.My thought is, perhaps he's doing it wrong. After all, the chimp made a perfect landing, while the human crashed not one but two pods.That says something doesn't it?Also, perhaps the chimp was trying to avoid the storm and got sucked in anyway. The human, was 'trying' to enter the storm. Remember, he was on a rescue mission for the chimp.

When I heard that Tim Burton was making a new version of the sci-fi legend Planet of the apes,I was really excited.I'm a huge Tim Burton fan, and the combination seemed too good to be true.Unfortunately,the movie was one of the biggest disappointments of the year and Burton's worst movie since Mars Attacks! Don't get me wrong!The new version of Planet of the Apes is not a bad movie and in it's own genre actually quite satisfying.The ape-masks are great(even though they make almost impossible to tell which actor is which) and the sets are pretty impressive.The biggest problem with the movie is that it doesn't have the unique visual look and oddness of Tim Burton.The second problem is Mark Wahlberg.He has the same one impression on his face throughout the movie and is one of the most unintresting hero of all times. All in all,not a bad film,but when compared to massive hype,a huge disappointment

reviews.review_title: I've seen David Lynch movies that made more sense than this
reviews.content: Absolutely horrible.  God only knows what Burton was thinking with this. This movie lacked the intelligence to make it a "make you think" film and the action to make it an action film.  It falls somewhere in between.  The ending tried to be as clever and shocking as the original, but was simply idiotic.  Avoid this movie.  If you want to see a movie with a great surprise ending, watch Memento.

reviews.review_title: Great movie, but green ape sidekick ruins highscore.
reviews.content:
I watched the 1968 Planet of the Apes and afterwards I was amazed how well I liked it. It was sent on TV and I thought like " I am going to die along with the movie runtime " but it was really good. So therefore I thought that Planet of the Apes Redux, or whatever one calls it, would be fun to see. And when I read Tim Burton had directed the whole thing I was even more excited. Edward Scissorhands- director doing a redux of one of the true movie classics, is that great or not.So I saw the movie and I was delighted to see how the masks had got even more realistic. And we also had Mark Wahlberg performing quite good, but alas he did not prove to be better than old Heston of the original. Helena Bonham Carter as sweet ape Ari was perfect for the role but this human-beings-seller in green? A typical sidekick, and I have never liked sidekicks. He has these spot-on comments to the movie's happenings but this true " evil ape empire "-feeling at once gets toned down by this fellow.
Tim Roth plays evil ape general Thade, the ultimate bad guy, breathing a little bit like Darth Vader in Star Wars. Michael Clarke Duncan have been showing off for the Apes- posters, so naturally he plays a great role as armyleader Attar. I have now seen the movie three times, one time on cinema, two times on VHS and I can't still figure out how the ending was like.

A real turkey and I want my two hours back.This is not a worthy remake of the Chuck Heston original.  The plot tries to have twists, but they are more like contortions.  The acting is terrible and the costumes are pretty bad for the most part.If you want Planet of the Apes, watch the old one.

A question to the author or the director: Why is the movie ending with the apes again being dominant? After the captain has showed humans and apes to live together, how can apes win again? Either apes and human cross breed and apes genes were dominant or the author or the director might have answer.. Your answer will be greatly appreciated. The movie is overall good for a fiction but I think can be made with a fantastic story in sequels. I do not think this is a remake of the 69 movie. Even the director himself might have tried to make this a remake. I see no possibility of this one matching anything with the first movie.Thanking you.BGhimire- A Physics and Philosophy student

reviews.review_title: Mediocre film, but succeeds in doing what it was made to.
reviews.content: I say.  This movie, while poorly written, acted, and for the most part, executed, was entertaining and though provoking.Many of the reviewers don't realize that the movie is NOT a remake by any means, and obviously doesnt pretend to be judging by the fact that the plot is almost entirely different, and any messege the film tries to get across to the viewer is also quite different.The purpose of the film is to confuse and disorient the viewer and make them sit through the credits with a perplexed look on his or her face.  The ending is much too bizzare to make any conceivable sense, and not even the director could clearly explain it.Though it falls short when it comes to the script and acting, the pace of the film is sporadic, and its clear that Tim Burton didnt give it his all, this is not a bad movie.  Its an entertaining film that succeeds in doing what it was meant to.  I give it a 7 out of 10.

I will give this movie some credit; it's not just a remake, which is probably the best thing it has going for it While the make-up is great, the film ends up being too serious to be campy, too silly to be taken seriously, and there are more loose ends than an unraveled sweater. (Which are sure to be tied up by the obviously sequel that the end sets up) Mark Walberg's tries to find his monkey and lands on a planet where Monkeys are superior and humans are the lesser primate. The make-up is astounding, and Mark proves to be a pretty good no-brain action star. Tim Roths is a pretty good monkey-gone-bad, but as I said before, this movies too silly to be taken seriously and his intense performance is kind of lost.After it's revealed how the monkeys got the way they were, (and why their English was so good) the plot just get's silly and builds up too a fairly laughable ending. The blond girl, Estelle, isn't bad as far as models-turned-actresses go, but her character serves no purpose other than to give 14 year old boys something to look at. Plus, even with more makeup than the cast of Cats used for 20 years, the best apes-actor is still the real thing, Mark's chimp Pericles, who gives a better performance than half his human-cousins.It's not a bad movie, it's a style-over-substance movie, but then again, so's most everything else that's at the theater. But underneath the latex it's just a campy monkey movie destined for cult stardom.

I like the concept behind the Planet of the Apes franchise, and I like all of the people involved in this project.Beyond patronage and past accolades, there is simply no hiding from the fact that this is a bad movie -- poorly written, poorly directed, and poorly filmed.It stands as a kind of parody of the original films, combined with only the sort of slow boiling inner turmoil that Tim Burton seems to understand.Instead of being indifferent to this film's existence, I wish I could watch this film more than once a year like any of the "real" Planet of the Apes films.Herein lies the beauty of cinema... one can dream.

Hardly can hold a torch to the socialpolitical themes that the 1968 original tackled.  Obviously, special effects are well beyond what could be done then.  The action holds your interest, but the story is lacking.  If this is a "re-imagining", the Mr Burton would have done well to stick with what the original did so well.  Then, we might have a movie well worth watching.

I'm a big fan of the original movies. This version is fairly well based on the original concepts. Some good action (for apes).  An okay storyline. I felt the ending was a little twistful but it's one way to leave it open for a sequel. I recommend seeing it.

reviews.review_title: Some great performances squares out the unnecessary use of violence.
reviews.content: Inevitably you must compare the 1968 original with the 2001 reimagining. What I missed the most was the scientific approach that the original had.
