Showing why the apes' beliefs were covered in lies and why humans actually were intelligent.In this Tim Burton movie it seems he has to add the violence and fighting needed to get the big movie producing budget from 20th Century Fox.In one sequence Leo (played by Mark Wahlberg) points a gun at an ape, but is told to not sink to his level (the ape was a trader-in-humans) by Ari (magnificently played by Helena Bonham-Carter). Yet in the end there is no problem to fight the Ape army in Braveheart-style.The whole magic usually included in Tim Burton movies is never there, and somehow he falls for the blockbuster-syndrome: a cool action-hero and a lot of incredible stunts.And the ending, without spoiling anything, must be the worst ever displayed on the screens.However, the costumes and make-ups are incredible, but they are in line with modern movie-technology. They could give one or two Academy Awards next year. But I don't understand why apes covered in body-hair/fur would want to wear clothing or uniforms. Overall, the great performances by Helena Bonham-Carter as a Senators daughter and revolting youth preaching humanism and equality and Tim Roth as the dangerous and evil general Thade makes this movie a pretty good entertainment and raising the Rating to 5/10.

reviews.review_title: A different take on the Ape concept.
reviews.content: When I first saw the original "Planet of the Apes" film on DVD, it blew my mind.  It was such an incredibly moving film and was so brilliantly well done.  Even the 1968 ape make-up was amazing.  So when the 2001 film came out, I was anticipating seeing it.My first sitting of the film was somewhat mixed.  The opening progresses quite quickly and jumps straight into the point rather than dilly-dallying with any character development.  There was an awful lot that happened in the film, and I didn't really get the chance to process it all until after the film had finished.  That's not to say that the plot was hard to follow; it just took me a while to process everything that had happened.  During that delayed reaction, I commented rather negatively on the film, but once I'd processed it all I appreciated the film a lot better, and thus the film was much better.During my second viewing of the film, I saw it for what it was: really good sci-fi action film.  That's not to say that the re-working of the film is a bad thing: the remake gives a fresh angle on the ape concept, which can be a great thing if it's executed correctly.  And the 2001 version of "Planet of the Apes" executes it brilliantly.In the modern film, genetically-enhanced monkeys pilot survey pods through unexplored space while the humans stay safely on their space station.  When one such monkey is lost in an electromagnetic storm, pod pilot Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlburg) decides to attempt a rescue.  With his navigation instruments down, Leo crash-lands on the planet of the apes....just as an ape hunting party is rounding up a fresh wagon-load of human slaves.Critics will say that the new film completely ignores Pierre Boulle's original novel, but it doesn't.  The modern story is very different certainly, but it is still closely tied with the novel.  Human-sympathising ape Ari (rendered absolutely superbly by Helena Bonham Carter) suggests a reason for why Earth's apes don't speak ("the way you treat them; maybe they don't want to"), which comes from Boulle's original novel.  And the movie's ending (one that'll make you gasp out loud) is lifted straight from the original novel.Everything about this film is excellent: the modern ape make-up is amazing, the peformances are of an incredible standard (especially Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth as the human-hating ape Thade), and the characterisation is just as superb as in the original film.  The film is brutal enough to make a statement about man's inhumanity to man (and ape), yet there is still a definite humour in the ape parodies of society.This truly is a great film.  Go out and enjoy it.

I went to see a preview of Planet of the Apes with some reservations. After all, I grew up with the original movies, and didn't think Tim Burton was the one who should "revisit" the franchise.  But the special makeup was incredible, and the mannerisms by the actors seemed so realistic that it blew me away.  Tim Roth is amazing - truly menacing, and wonderfully intense.  And the explanation of how the planet's inhabitants came to be was one of those last-minute "Oh - NOW I see it coming!" moments, where it wasn't obvious from the get-go.  All in all, I'd highly recommend seeing it!

reviews.review_title: This movie was pure drivel, absolute crap. Rent South Park instead.
reviews.content: This movie was pure drivel, absolute crap. Rent South Park instead.  I'm not sure what was more painful, the $5 matinee ticket price or the fact that as I sat through it I was trying to figure out what I was going to do for the rest of the weekend.  Plot was predictable and there were not surprises. Not even the "surprise" ending.

Okay, sure, it's very (very) cheesy here and there. I laughed where I'm sure you're not supposed to laugh (although most people did). But if you can get past the cheese, and just kick back and let your imagination flow for a while, this is a really good movie. The monkeys.. sorry apes, are not just ordinary humans that look like apes, they have their own culture and ways. There's alot of aggression and sexual tension between them, and things boil down to who's the strongest. I liked all the twists, the last one being a predictable one, but it can still tickle your imagination, if you let it. So, I say open your eyes and ears and go see it. There are not a whole lot of movie out there that works from beginning til end, if you compare them and their plots to real life. "Planet..." never tried that, it's all about a  really cool experience, and Tim Burton is a master of making that happen. 8/10

reviews.review_title: It could easily have been so much better!
reviews.content: *******************************************Spoilers all the way, don't read this if you're planning to see the movie.SPOILERS! SPOILERS! SPOILERS! SPOILERS! *******************************************I am not going to say anything major about the plot, as it has been related better before.This movie irritates me a great deal. It could easily have been so much better, by some simple adjustments.This film has a lot of plotholes, and most of them could easily have been avoided.1. The language problem Both apes and humans speak english. Pretty stupid if the two species have been on the planet for 1000'nds of years. Why couldn't the two species have spoken some unknown language which Davidson could have been taught in some months' captivity among the apes. This could also have given us a better chance to learn more about ape history and ape culture.2. What are the characters motives for doing certain things? This is a big problem, perhaps the biggest in the movie. A. Why do Thade hate humans so enormously? B. Why do the slave trader switch sides so easily? This could have been better explained. C. Why did Leo Davidsom escape so soon? Wouldn't it have been more sensible to learn more about the place he had come to? D. Why did the blond bomb have a role in the movie at all? Her actions didn't have any significance. E. Why did Ari return to general Thade if she was interested in "The human cause". F. Why did Attar turn against Thade at the end of the movie? H. There are much much more...3. I believe there was something about a man coming from the stars. If this was better explained it could have made Thade's killing of the two space-arrival spotters more easy to understand. It could also perhaps have explained why Attar switched side in the ending.4. There are more, but i gotta go to bed now...------- Im not sure if i will comment much on the ending of this movie as i'm not sure if i understood it. Here are some ways it can be understood. (Perhaps...)A. They were at the earth all along by some strange twist of fate and Davidsons actions altered history so that we got an "Ape" Lincoln. That does not explain that it said general Thade on the statue though. I don't like this explanation, and i hope it is not correct.B. The travelling through and forth in the magnetic storm got Davidson into some other dimension beside ours, where Thade was a hero. This could explain why there were fairly nowadays police equipment and cars when the cops showed up.C. Thade may have travelled back to earth and changed history there after Davidson had gone. We have to note though, that the cops seemed to be evolved apes. This seems to suggest that it must have been a vast amount of time since Thades arrival and Leos arrival at earth. Difficult difficult... Another problem: If Thade and the apes fixed the Oberon in some way, and got it flying, isn't it kind of strange that the original crew didn't managed that some time directly after the crash? Even sophisticated technology is best BEFORE it has been lying around for some thousands of years...This is perhaps just rubbish, and i will be very thankful if someone did this explanation better than me!!!

This was one of THE WORST movies I have ever seen in my entire life (and I've seen Sugar and Spice, Jane Doe and Smokey and the Bandit III). The only part worth seeing was Chartlon Heston's cameo. If you MUST see this movie, walk out after that part, go into another theater and watch another movie, any movie will do (and I do mean ANY). I wish I'd brought a book.

Ya' know movie critics are bad enough; but "wanna be" movie critics are the worst! This is a great fun movie about monkeys, excuse me "apes".  You can't deny the special effects are great. I enjoyed it. I don't know what these other reviewers were expecting. I don't think any of the actors expected to get awards for acting like monkeys, nor took on the role for the acting "stretch".  I assume they wanted to play the roles because it was fun or that they liked the original.  And you know what "it is not the original"... it is a different movie.  I get so sick of people comparing remakes.  You can't make them identical and why on earth would you want to?  Get a life and find some good things in the things you do and don't be so critical. Judge this movie on what it is not on what you think it should be.  I think this movie is worth seeing and I think the ending is a great addition.  So what if it leaves the franchise open to a sequel? That's why our film community is called an industry.  I appreciate Mr. Burton giving me the opportunity to think a little bit more about the movie rather than handing the ending over to me.Go ahead and give this movie a try...

reviews.review_title: An excellent movie...right up until the last ten minutes.
reviews.content: The special effects and the makeup in this movie is the stuff of legend. The script is tight and moves at a respectable pace.  The acting is above par given the accomplished supporting cast.  Now the downside...Mark Wahlberg isn't a strong enough actor in his own right to carry this film. His character doesn't grow at all from the start to the end.  And speaking of the end; I'm not going to give it away but it made no logical sense in the context of the story that we had been watching for the previous two hours.  I was completely hooked into the movie until this ending that seemed as if it was filmed later and tacked on.  If they had left off the last ten minutes of the film I would have given this movie an 8.  But the crapola ending brought the whole picture down to a paltry 5.

This could have been a great movie, but they dug themselves into a hole and then couldn't figure out how to get out.  I enjoyed the up until the "battle" scene.  Then things stopped making sense.  Leo's big plan turned out to be a dud.  The humans should have been wiped out.  Then, even though the highly trained human pilot crashes not once, but twice, we are expected that the chimp pilot experiences none of the same problems and can land his pod without difficulty.  Why does a cute chimp landing in a space craft make the apes suddenly believe that the humans aren't so bad after all?Then there's the stupid "suprise" ending.  The whole movie is based on the premise that the smart apes evolved from genetic engineered apes that crash landed on the planet with the humans.  So why are we supposed to suddenly believe that Leo would crash land in a second parallel world where Washington D.C. looks just like ours, but everybody is an ape instead of a human?  This ending had nothing to do with the rest of the movie.It had potential, but it bombed instead.

reviews.review_title: Oh, so THAT'S the surprise ending
reviews.content: Surprisingly contrived maybe, or surprisingly pointless.  The original had a memorable twist at the end, so I suppose they felt they needed one too. I'm torn between whether the idea behind it was bad or just poorly executed. Either way, I can see why they didn't want it to leak out. It wasn't a horrible movie.  The effects were decent and the make-up was outstanding, but I just couldn't help thinking all the way through that I should have been enjoying it more.  I tried, but it just wasn't happening. None of the people I saw it with really felt satisfied at the end.  And the Goofs page for this film should be pretty interesting once people get going. Maybe my expectations were a little too high, but I was glad I saw it at Matinee prices.

reviews.review_title: As good as one would expect
reviews.content: Initial while watching the movie I liked it, however the more I think back on it the more I think it was only average.    It was however a very well done remake.   Very tough to improve on the classic Planet of the Apes movie.

**SPOILERS**I'll start off by syaing that I'm not much for remakes.  I roll my eyes whenever I see a preview for a remake of a classic (i.e. The Time Machine this Christmas).  Nevertheless, I'm in line opening day.  Ever since Elementary School when my Dad made me watch the original Planet of the Apes I've been enchanted by it.  A school friend Robbie told me the ending before I saw it; yet it still captivated me.  The dialogue was a little weak in the original, and the special effects and makeup are a joke now; but they were pearls in the late 60s.  The ending was a mystical cliffhanger that made you want the world to freeze and allow you to just ponder life and our society for a moment.  I commend those actors, they did great back then, but it's just not a movie for the 2000 years and on.  This brings me to the remake. Not many people know, in fact, that both films were remakes of the original French novel by Pierre Boulle.  It upsets me when people call the new one a "remake" of the old one.  It's not...It's a new idea on an old book.  I commend Tim Burton.  He did a great job with the futuristic feel of this movie.  Most movies these days do a HORRIBLE job conveying the future. It's better to watch 2001: A Space Odyssey because the effects look reasonable. Take "The Sixth Day" for instance.  That movie was nothing but an excuse for Arnold lines and special effects.  They overused the effects, in my opinion, which created an overly-exotic, extremeley wild picture that I couldn't keep controlled.  Our current technology needs to be limited in the display of our future; a fine line George Lucas walked with Episode One.  However, I think Tim Burton did pretty good with not overly-special-effecting this film.  The opening scenes in our not-too-distant future seemed reasonable and not too stretched and wild.  I also really enjoyed the scenes on the space station, in which Tim paralleled our relation to apes with the apes relation to us.  They didn't do this in the original film.  It allowed younger viewerd to more basically understand the parallel between the two relationships.  The one thing I didn't like in the film was the humans. They didn't seem evolutionary-backtracked at all.  They seemed like normal humans who had just been scavenging around for 3,000 years while the monkeys evolved tremendously into an entirely new identity.  The "Nova" character, Daena I think, was interesting.  Obviously placed as a sex object, she didn't quite pull off enough of a attraction with Davidson (The "Taylor" of the film).  Oh ya, one more thing I didn't like.  The ending, after the struggle with the apes is over, I thought was too rushed.  THey should have slowed it down and taken it a bit steadier.  Otherwise, I loved this movie. The two parallels to the original film were great, and I felt out of place as being one of the only people in the theatre who was laughing at the line "Get Your Stinking Hands Off Me You Damn Dirty Human."  Ya so it was corny, it was great.  The Charlton Heston cameo was an awesome tribut to a great American symbol.  It was awesome, and his last words "Damn them all to hell..." made me laugh really hard.  It was a great tribute and I applaud the writers for it.  General Thade I thought was great, he did a good job acting.  It was much different than the book's/original movie's Dr Zaius, but he still had the same premise.  All the ape characters were outstanding, especially the two Generals and the comic relief slave trader.  The premise was quite different AND IF YOU DONT WANT TO KNOW THE ENDING ***STOP READING NOW*** and I liked it but I didn't.  The idea of the space station going back in time and the monkeys taking over and evolving was interesting.  As said above, I thought it strange that the apes would advance so much and the humans not, but still.  I liked that idea; it was an interesting new idea. But it still lacked all the glamour the original ending got.  It didn't make me think and it didn't really spark an interest in me to question existence. It was good, but not POTA worthy.  The ending was, however.  I thought that all the cliffhangers were over with.  After Thade was locked up I think it was rushed way too much.  It all kinda wrapped up and took off too quick. When Davidson crashed on Earth I knew something fishy was up.  And when I noticed the Lincoln Memorial I knew what I was about to see.  What I didn't know, however, was that the modern-day Earth would end up completely controlled by apes.  This was a great cliffhanger ending and it made me puzzled at first.  However when you think about it, it leaves little to the imagination.  Obviously, somewhere in Planet of the Apes re-imagining sequels 2-5 Thade will go back in time and alter past.  When this will happen, how it will occur, how well it will be pulled off, who will be the characters, and exactly how many boring sequels we will have to sit through are all questions that lay heavily on the shoulders of director Tim Burton...good luck...   8.5/10

reviews.review_title: The worst movie I saw this summer
reviews.content: This movie is a joke!  One of the worst movies I have ever seen!  The only thing that kept me from walking out of this nightmare was Estella Warren. Not only do I think Tim Burton has completely lost his originality and independent risk taking but Mark Walburg???  This guy is the most over rated actor to date.  Are you kidding me, all he does is breath heavy and talk breathy in every movie he's ever in.  My rating for this flick would be GARBAGE if there was one.

reviews.review_title: What a silly movie - see it if you must.
reviews.content: The best parts of this movie were Tim Roth's deliciously evil general and Danny Elfman's music.  I had a great time with my friend making fun of the movie as we watched it - flying monkey theme song from "Wizard of Oz" and the "Star Trek" series action music.  At one point we made a reference to the Monty Python "dead parrot sketch" - when the first wave of ape soldiers got hit with the afterburner and were lying in the sand - "they're not dead, just stunned." What a silly movie - see it if you must.

i was expecting a great movie since i'm a enjoy tim burton's movies. I was amazed with sleepy hollow and was looking forward to this movie. but what i saw was a piece of crap!! the story made final fantasy's look incredible, the acting was pathetic (except for the apes), the ending was horrible. and what's with charlton heston's speech? how can it be so full of clichés; i really hope someone gets fired for that one. so, kudos to tim roth, micheal clark duncan but the rest of the movie is awful. please don't make a sequel!!!

On exiting Planet of the Apes, my friend uttered "What the hell?" I quickly replied "No kidding."  For the next two hours we analyzed and reanalyzed Burton's "re-imagining," which turned out to be two hours of completely and utterly nonsensical filmmaking.  However, Burton was TRYING to explain the course in which he thought that the human evolutionary pattern is following. For those who have seen the movie, you would remember that Leo's pod crash landed around 2400, when he had left from the 22nd century. The apes on the planet had said that the ruins of the origin of the apes was thousands of years old. This explains that the Oberon when passing through the electrical storm went back in time thousands of years. IF we say that the planet of the apes is really earth we can deduce that in the end when apes ruled present day it was because the oberon had crashed before Leo's departure from it. Because the ship's apes took over thousands of years ago they built up their technology the same as we had in our present day. Burton therefore is suggesting that the apes civilization fell and they were reverted to their ancient primitive ways. Then Leo crashed. Therefore although Leo was trying to make it back to his time, it no longer existed!PS.  I went to this movie thinking that even if it was bad, Burton's visuals would be nice as they usually are but all I received was two hours of run-of-the-mill scenes, with nothing special whatsoever.In conclusion, the only thing good about this movie was the music. Ironically Planet made you think, something the filmmakers obviously did not do.

reviews.review_title: Tim Tim Tim... You're killing me here..
reviews.content:
BAD MOVIE!!! It's just that simple... This was a horrible movie...
As Charlton said in the 1st movie... "YOU BLEW IT ALL UP!!! DAMN YOU!!! DAMN YOU TO HELL!!!" Little did we know he was talking about the remake..

There is only one thing to say about this movie. Uuuugggghhhhhhh!!! No plot, bad acting and an ending that confused everyone in the theater killed this movie. There are some movies that are classics without a remake. Tim Burton, shame on you.

I thought the movie was all right, up until the end.  I can't agree with the first person's comments - that ending would not satisfy me even if I were to see this movie multiple times.  It had the feel of a run of the mill Sliders episode.  Of course, Hollywood's almost always got to set things up for possible sequels.  Though they could have come up with something a lot more plausible.

reviews.review_title: Great...but I should have left before the last minute of the movie!!
reviews.content: I was impressed by the majority of the movie.  I especially like Thades' (Tim Roth) walking motion as i have been imitating it all day.  Apart from some of the cliche comic relief remarks (you know what i mean), and the very end (last minute or so), i thought the movie was GREAT!!  But that ending .. .

reviews.review_title: For once a summer movie that thinks its audience is SMART!
reviews.content: To sum up the monumental movie Planet Of The Apes in one word would be a discredit to Tim Burton and his wonderful remake of the groundbreaking movie.  A deep movie that managed to keep my attention for about 2 hours, spark questions and for once, NOT EXPLAIN EVERY LITTLE ACTION THE CHARACTERS TAKE.  My pet peeve today is that movies have to take so much time in explaining every tiny detail about the plot.  In essence they are preaching to the lowest common denominator. In a movie that contains so many sub-plots, Tim Burton does a great job of presenting the foundation though dialogue, and then the rest of the plot though visual aids.  If you want to understand the movie you have to look for the details and then come to your own conclusions, which isn't that hard if you were actually watching the movie, and have some reasonable level of intelligence (which of course is rare into days movie viewing demo graph, and no I'm not an old cranky manI'm only 16).  If your tired of the same mush that infests out cinema today and want to see a movie that is smart, funny, and makes you think see this movie.  If you don't you can always go for the special effects, make-up (Wonderful job), and of course Supermodel Estella Warren! ;-)10/10!!!

reviews.review_title: Best watched when someone else pays for it!
reviews.content:
NOTE: For those who haven't seen this film, please do NOT read my review. I will be outlining the plot, or lack thereof, in my critique.Several years ago, legendary scriptwriter William Goldman lamented that it was no longer fun to ridicule current films.  The present author agrees, citing Hollywood's limited imagination and obsession with proper packaging. One example can be found in Tim Burton's `reimagined' Hollywood's classic, Planet of the Apes.  Mr. Burton is known for the Batman series, The Nightmare before Christmas, and Beetle juice.  His Planet of the Apes is another dark foreboding film aimed at summer moviegoers.
Burton correctly did not compete with the original movie's screenplay written by Rod Serling.  The creator of The Twilight Zone was inspired by Pierre Boulle's satirical novel Monkey Planet.  Now one can buy the novelization of the Tim Burton film.  As one local paper observed, Burton created another contemporary action film.   A US Air Force pilot marooned on a strange planet, pleas for us to love our neighbors, as we would love ourselves.  In other words, Batman passed through the Stargate to discover EnemyMine.  The author is grateful that he did not have to pay to see this forgettable remake.  However, one should keep perspective and view this film as part of Hollywood's highly successful strategy as an electronic baby sitter. Its core audience is probably unaware that Planet of the Apes launched the first commercially viable nerdocracy nine years before Star Wars.What was Planet's secret?  Great costumes, breath taking special effects, eye-catching explosions, token comic relief and of course sex appeal. The film team cut and pasted this formula onto the script but added his trademark: darkness protects evildoers.  Instead of swaggering through Gotham's streets, these nefarious characters literally swing from tree to tree.  Then our hero with the subtle last name of Davidson leads his people into the Wilderness.   Meanwhile eye candy masquerading as characters diverts the male lead's attention: Helen Bonham Carter and Estella Warren. His young male audience secure, Burton enlisted living legends Charleton Heston and Kris Kristofferson ostensibly to develop the plot.  However, the author suspects they were bait to lure the Baby Boomer generation.
Thus, one can discern a movie's full power without distractions like plot or dialogue. One applies this Zen-like state when watching Burton's film. You should suspend disbelief when learning that the US Air Force in 2068 cannot prevent a rogue space launch. Then Mark Walberg, our Rambo-like hero, travels thousands of years into the future not because of technology. He is a cosmic Dorothy sucked into a space tornado that accelerates his vehicle past 88 miles per hour.  Once in Oz, the newly arrived prophet reveals several millennia of tradition as a lie.
How does he do it one might ask?  Because Marky Mark is charismatic and bright.  His character only needs a couple of days to gather a band of followers and discover the ruins of his old space station.  Somehow falling out of orbit, the facility's nuclear power plant and computers still work. Our intrepid Spaceman discovers the truth:  On Space Station Oberon, human and apes astronauts lived in happiness.  Then the chimp Semos, like the Serpent in the Garden of Evil, spread hate.Apparently, Burton's filmmaking team believes that current moviegoers are unable to grasp ambiguity.  Whereas the original film showed a world of mute humans, Burton's world is one where man had nothing to say.  Heston's conflict at the ruins in the Forbidden Zone revolved around the clash of ideas.  Kung-fu trained gorillas fought  ideological issues the original film never resolved.In conclusion, the author believes he is too harsh.  After all, the movie had hot leads, good production values and the plot was enough to keep me awake.  My favorite part was ending, partially because the torture was over. However, another reason was Burton's ending was reminiscent of Boulle's finale.  In the novel, our hero lands his spacecraft at a Paris airfield is met by a police car.  Which was driven by a gorilla.

WARNING: MY COMMENTS MAY HAVE SPOILERS IF YOU HAVE NOT SEEN THE MOVIE. READ AT YOUR OWN RISK.I couldn't enjoy Planet of the Apes because of the gaps of logic taking place.In the original, Heston (Col. Taylor) landed on a planet with air, with apes ruling over humans, and they could speak English!--all these strange things were explained with the ending--Heston had returned to the Earth of the future.In the remake, I was thrown off from the beginning.Why are we using apes in space exploration? This would have made more sense in 1968 original, with Russian cosmonauts and apes being sent into space.But right now we use robot probes to explore Mars. Wouldn't that technology be all the more advanced and probable than using simians in the future?This planet is not Earth. It's convenient that Leo landed here and that there is oxygen to breathe. But in addition to that minor point, this planet was populated with ape and human survivors that crash landed on a ship. This begs the question--WHERE DID THE HORSE COME FROM?Again, it made sense in the original--they were on Earth from the beginning. But here, on another planet, it doesn't make any sense.Where did Ape Charlton Heston (Thade's dad) get the gun?Again, everything on this planet started from what survived the crash of the ship on the planet. Leo uses a modern laser-like weapon. Where did Ape Charlton Heston get an old gun even by our current standards, to present to his son, Gen Thade?How can the apes evolve so quickly, and yet the surviving humans are in the caveman stage of things?Apes can speak, ride the "native" horses of the planet, have a whole society and hierarchy, yet man, with all his technological know-how is now running around in loin cloths. Righttt.I knew this movie wouldn't be perfect, but even the couple of beers I downed before the movie could get me over that idiotic ending.Okay, Gen Thade somehow got smart enough to get back to Earth before Leo, and change history. But it isn't a new ape-history, it's a parallel Earth history where identical versions of things exist--The Lincoln Memorial with an Ape head, Cop cars with Gorilla cops, society in duplicate form to ours, the only thing changed is apes instead of humans.I give up, maybe it'll be explained in the sequel--but I ain't going to cough up 8 bucks to find out why.

reviews.review_title: Great new visionary Planet of the Apes
reviews.content: Tim Burton has once again created a visually stunning and a "new" Planet of the Apes. It is NOT a remake; and never tried to be but another "tale" on the same concept as the old movies. The old ones were great as well - masterpieces in itself. But this DOES NOT reduce the great work that Tim Burton has done in creating this movie. A great movie and well worth watching in it's own rights. If you want the "old ones" - watch the old ones; if you want to watch a great new movie - watch this one. And WHY not watch both the OLD and the NEW ones.Happy viewing!

reviews.review_title: Bad Remake, Zero continuity, Serling turning in his grave
reviews.content: This is a horrible remake/ new version of this classic movie. There is no continuity. Characters appear and disappear for no apparent reason. A troupe of Mark Walhberg and other humans and Apes trek across the Forbidden Zone - I thought I was watching the Wizard of OZ. The movie is packed with through away 'one-liners' making it more like an action comedy instead of science fiction.

This would have been a much better film if Tim Burton had not sought out to "reimagine" the original story.  Granted, the makeup and special effects do surpass the original, but that is where the superlatives stop. The story in the current version just does not work.  It does not adequately explain how the apes came to be where they are.  The ending does not have a fraction of the impact of the ending of the original film.  It is ridiculous and illogical.  This is one movie you can wait for the video on..and only if someone else pays for the video and invites you over.

Planet of the Apes will not give you a mental workout.  It will not show you a skillful piece of cinematic mastery.You will not be wowed by the tightness of the script (it isn't).  You will not be impressed by the structure of the plot (it's hole-filled).But, no question, you will be entertained.The makeup is first rate.  The real actors among the cast (Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth) do better than reasonable jobs with the limited material they have been given.  The special effects are -- special.You will be intrigued and entertained for the entire movie -- right up until the pointless, nonsensical, tacked-on, made-for-sequel surprise ending. Once you leave the theater with that nagging problem gnawing on your psyche, the remainder of the movie crumbles into a heap of mental rubbish.My brain snacked noisily on the movie for two hours.  Then the flavor ran out in the last minute of the picture.  So I spit it out, gave it not another thought, and moved on to my next piece of cheap gum...

This film is quite horrible... I can't believe they've made so much hype about that! The plot follows no logic. It seems that the writer stopped the film at that point so he'll have two more years or so to make the story sounds logical. The end is so pathetical that looks like a comedy and not a sci-fi adventure. It's bad directed, things are just thrown away and the scenes have no elaboration. The camera work is nothing but elementary, and, also, the make-up of the female monkeys looks fake and unreal. A real class on how to NOT make a film. 2/10.

reviews.review_title: Could this movie get any worse?
reviews.content: Let me summarize this up. The costumes and makeup are vastly outdated, the acting was forced, and please, the ending was so obvious. My advice? DO NOT waste your money on this horrible waste of time.

Despite all the bad reviews "Planet of the Apes" is a thoroughly enjoyable film.  Perhaps Wahlberg, while clearly trying to avoid the over the top melodrama of Heston's character, could have been a little more passionate at times, but the apes, especially Thade and Ari are wonderfully portrayed with a rich dimension helped along by Rick Baker's fabulous makeup effects.You must bear in mind that this is 21st century post-cold war America and this is a Tim Burton film.  There is no substantial socio-political commentary here, although there are plenty of gentle nods to racism, classism, sexism, religion, and the rest---along with several well placed winks at the original production [including a splendid cameo by Heston]. This is much more of a "fish out of water" and "search for belonging" movie that is Burton's specialty.

The ending just made me want to barf.  It was so tacked-on and disconnected that I just couldn't take it... it was worse than the end of the remake of "Mighty Joe Young"... I wonder if the DVD version will have the option to roll credits 3 minutes earlier.On another note, I think it's amazingly hilarious the way some have misinterpreted Charlton Heston's "support" for gun control.  Let's see, he's an old-guard member of a genocidal regime that wants to eliminate humans or at best enslave them, and warns his son to beware of the human power of invention, symbolized by firearms.  DUH!  Of course tyrants want gun control -- it keeps them safe from their victims!  Charlton Heston made EXACTLY the point about guns that he wanted to make, some people apparently just missed it!On the whole, the movie isn't as bad as some have made it out to be, nor is it as good as others have said.  It was a good action movie, but not much else.  I give it a 6.

In my opinion this is a fine film and deserving of better treatment than its gotten here. Tim Burton brings his unique bag of tricks to a film that is perhaps uniquely suited to them. His dark Gothic visuals blend surprisingly well with the topic. The plot contains much of his trademark satire, which replace the heavy moralising of the first film and makes for lighter, more summereaque fare. The cast has its ups{Helana Bonham Carter and Tim Roth being the standouts} and downs {most of the human actors seem to be chosen for their physical archetypes}. The Danny Elfman music is superb as always, adding to the powerful action scenes which stress the sheer physical strength pf the apes . The only major criticism I have is the bizarre ending, which does come as a small shock to those who haven't had it given away for them by some useless trailer trash. But it doesn't mesh well with the rest of the film and actually to me makes a sequel harder to visuallize. All in all, I think this movie is the most entertaining film this summer {altho' that's not saying a lot}, worth your time and money and deserving of better reviewers {both for and against} than have been shown here so far.

Forget all of the critics. This is not supposed to be a physiological thriller. This a great movie. Visually spectacular.This movie delivers excitement and lots of action. I cannot wait to see the sequel. This (so far) is the best of the summer of 2001.

I had high expectations from Tim Burton's new film, hoping his unique genius would improve upon the dated preachiness of the 1968 original, but, alas, I was greatly disappointed. Of course, this is a high-class action movie and the apes' looks and movement are quite stunning, but the plot is so corny and juvenile. As for the ending, I don't see any difficulty in understanding it (although I'm not going to spoil it to anyone), it is just a pointless twist on the 1968 ending. And Back to the Future I-II handled time-traveling paradoxes so much better. Acting is quite horrible, with Helena Bonham-Carter as her usual pathetic self, underneath all the make up. 6/10.

I'm gutted, one of my all time favourite movies Planet of the Apes' is to be remade by one of my favourite directors Tim Burton' at last a film to really look forward to. Oh dear! What's with these filmmakers, why do they seem to pay no attention to the story and script? Planet of the Apes (2001) is a stunning piece of film work with great make-up, effects (a few actors aside) an excellent cast.The first half of the movie is entertaining and builds well though it doesn't take a genius to work out where the story going. The second half comes across as though they ran out of time and were not sure which way to take the movie. Because this it becomes farcical! It looks like they panicked, the problem is the original movie is a classic and easily stands the test of time, the end, still a very powerful image. They concentrate of trying to replicate (in a different way) this but it's desperate. If you're going to see this film try to forget about the original and just enjoy it as a different film. This is difficult because they insist on repeating the classic lines from the first movie. I suppose they were trying to be funny, it was funny but for the wrong reasons. Planet of the Apes is an entertaining movie that does not carry much impact Michael Clark Duncan is big, Mark Wahlberg is good, and Tim Roth is great, though given the costume, setting and make-up not a difficult task! People will not be watching this film in thirty years. Yet another disappointment.

reviews.review_title: A horrible, cliched, schmaltzy waste of money.
reviews.content: As a huge Tim Burton fan, I anticipated greatness and creativity. Imagine my dismay as I sat through a big-budget Hollywood crapfest with the worst dialogue (so laughably bad!). The special effects were cool, but there was nothing remotely Tim Burton-ish about this movie- this is exactly what you'd expect from some hatchet artist like Michael Bay, not from the usually delightful Tim Burton. I am thoroughly disgusted by this- he has clearly fallen for the Hollywood method of fearlessly distributing crap, so long as he makes a buck (or a million). DON'T see this trashy, stupid, waste-of-time movie. Mark Wahlberg's acting is totally sub-par and boring. The rest of the characters are background filler and serve no purpose. Tim Burton is capable of so much more. Let's hope he chooses something more substantial with original dialogue next time.

Sorry everyone, this reinvention of the 1968 classic just isn't up to par. Mark Walhberg as the astronaut is awful. His acting ruined what might have been a strong male lead. He is not believable in his role. The ape make up is Oscar worthy, though at most times it distracts from the already weak plot and make most dialogue incomprehensible. This film parodies the previous "Ape" film with several one-liners. This is not supposed to be a comedy or satire, it is a "message" movie on how we treat and behave towards other beings. At least that was what the novel and 1968 version was about. I think another problem was that the director did not know whether to have the apes behave like apes or humans. Dd they evolve and become human like or retain there ape behavious and just learn to speak? So many questions? Goofs? Disjointed plotlines and other errors that cannot be detailed without giving away the plot. Enjoy the make up and effects but that's it!!!!!

reviews.review_title: "Apes" 1968 is to original Star Wars as Apes "2001"...
reviews.content: ...is sort of to Star Wars: Phantom Menace (only better with no annoying sidekick)As far as the acting, the apes do a great job dealing with the challenges of walking differently (*almost* completely upright), and the humans are also very good. The romance subplot does not overtake the movie and is not very obvious. The direction, with Tim Burton at the helm, would have to be said as really good. Like a music CD can have good songs badly produced (or vice versa), this is a pretty good movie with a great director. The dark sides of other films like Edward Scisorhands and Batman don't influence the style of "Apes", and the genre allows him to play with things. I would recommend that you see the movie at some point, but be aware that the ending is not the greatest of endings.

reviews.review_title: One million monkeys at one million typewriters...
reviews.content: ...could write a better movie then this. I walked in expecting a ok movie, I loved the original and some of the sequels. I ended up laughing through the entire thing. The only problem was that I wasn't suppost to. "Touching" moments in the movie were amazingly poorly handled. The "surprise" ending wasn't really much of a surprise because most of the people in the theater had the entire movie's plot figured out within the first five minutes. I can honestly say that this was the worst movie I've ever seen and that's a real shame because the look of it was fantastic. The makeup was great and the actors playing the apes really moved like monkeys. As Charlton Heston once said "They finally did it! They blew it up!!". They sure did...

I was so excited for this movie, and man, what a let down.  Granted, casting, make-up, costuming, and sound were wonderful, but that's about it. The script was poor, and actually made the audience laugh at parts that weren't supposed to be funny.  Everyone coming out of the theatre gave the movie two thumbs down! The ending could've been better written by a 5 year old!  Don't waste your money on this one!

reviews.review_title: A great re-interpretation and under-rated film ruined by nostalgics
reviews.content: I for one love this modernised view of Planet of the Apes. Coming from a younger generation of Film viewers, watching movies with 30 year old plots and FX isn't as captivating as newer renditions with updated technology and plots. The Hatred towards humans feels more genuine especially from Thade as well as the fear shown when the apes realize the power marky has. Obviously the makeup and effects are a lot more advanced which helps remove some of the silliness of the notion of a planet ruled by apes. I enjoyed the ending, it makes you think and left me wanting to see more, perhaps the ending meant nothing whatever the case it left people thinking and debating. I would love to see a sequel to this version if it were possible.

reviews.review_title: Good but had the potential for excellent
reviews.content: Really enjoyable, good remake, the attention to detail is very impressive however the character development could have been stronger.Good piece of escapism, nice to see a half decent sci-fi film again, however the potential was there for a more complicated storyline.The film also was crying out to be more violent and even a little gory, but has obviously been sanitised to give it a 12 certificate(uk) to cash in on a younger market, shamefollow up films a certainty

reviews.review_title: Guess Tim did what he could...
reviews.content: As a HUGE Tim Burton fan, I must say I was disappointed. Problem is I think Burton did what he could with a script that probably could fit on infants fingernail. At most, three lines are exchanged between the actors which leads to an almost non-existent dialogue. Some scenes sparkled with magic, but sometimes it felt like the scenes were pasted from Xena, Warrior Princess.This of course, made it difficult for Mark and the rest of the actors to create personalities which actually were interesting. I was however impressed by Tim Roth and the other monke..I mean apes.Time-travel.Always trouble.In this case,big trouble.MAJOR trouble.I didn't understand a thing.At least the ending opened for a sequel and hopefully a better one. (And why on earth did the little chimps have to play basketball??)

SPOILER ALERT After watching the latest Ape Caper I walked out of the cinema thinking that the film made no sense whatsoever, but it was actually pretty enjoyable nonsense. After a couple of days I came up with a scenario that sort of makes sense. Apologies to anyone who's heard this before, or thought of it already.Spaceman flies into future(NOT the past), crashes on strange planet(NOT Earth).  Spends 90 minutes faffing around finding his spaceship with his new found cross species mates, gets into a few fights.  Snogs a monkey.  Pretty average day so far.Finds spaceship, goes back into the past to find Earth overtaken by the same evil Ape he thought he'd left on a different planet in the future. Mmmm...go figure.After Leo goes 'home' Thade retakes control of the Monkey planet, uses found technolgy to develop space travel, tries to follow Leo with army, ends up even further back in the past than Leo does.  Conquers Earth with army, Earth becomes Monkey planet.  Leo arrives back on Earth after all this has already happened.Does any of this make sense, probably not...but hey my name's not Kevin Smith...only joking!Scenario for next movie, Leo has to get back to the future to prevent Thade from getting to Earth in the first place.  Them darn time travelling space monkeys are nuthin' but trouble!

-- A little bit of spoilers --Well i can tell you that I have not seen the Original movie, so I cannot compare like most people I hear are doing! Let me just say this, if you have seen the first one and now are seeing this one.. Sure... you might not enjoy it as much because:(1) You know they are on Earth (2) You know what the Story is about anyway.. So no thinking is involved, No thinking no Fun :)For me it was all new so it was very nice Story! I Recommend this movie to anyone who has not seen the Original. And for all you folks that have seen the Original.. Ease up a bit.. It is only meant to be a fun Entertaining movie based on a "novel" NOT THE ORIGINAL MOVIE for a new Generation to Enjoy!I give this movie 9/10! Later!

This movie is well worth seeing, for the story, for the special effects, and for the apes (which are fantastic!)...but, be forewarned, you won't understand the ending.  The only good thing that I can say about it: it definitely causes a lot of discussion, with many different interpretations.Truth be known...we will only be able to judge the ending by the sequel. There is no doubt they have tried to set one up, and, I can think of one that would fit...one that would be brilliant.  But, somehow, I don't have faith that Hollywood could be quite that creative.  I hope so...but, if they are, I will be greatly surprised.  And, I really can't figure out how they could make my idea work and still stay true to the movie.If they don't do a sequel, or if they do a lame one, this movie will be added to my list of Great Movies with Terrible Endings.

With it's excellent effects and direction this film was always going to be a big summer hit and unfortunately that has given them the excuse the forget about the plot. The film starts well enough dropping clues and introducing the main human. It flows along nicely with alot of references to the original film ('Take your hands off me you damned dirty human'). There is a humour and darkness to the film that can only be provided by Tim Burton as well as his trade mark scarecrows. But as with all good things, what was right about this film came to a crashing end and that comes at the end. The initial plot resolution seemed to be an afterthought and then the 'shock' ending was illogical and did not seem to tie in with events in the rest of the film. If anybody has any theories as to how the ending is possible please let me know as we haven't been able to work it out.So for effort, cast (especially Estella Warren), direction and initial plot I give this film 6 out of 10. But it would have been higher had the ending been better.

The original Planet of the Apes was an epic of sorts, the remake, or re-imagining' as director Tim Burton prefers to refer to his film as, is slightly different, it strives for a more simple action film, which is not necessarily a bad thing as it proves to be a, linear, but nonetheless entertaining hour and half or so of film.The standard of acting varies considerably, on the whole the ape characters are acted superbly, most notably Tim Roth as the evil General Thade. Helena Bonham Carter is also good in her role as human rights activist Ari. The greatly underrated Paul Giamatti provides a little comic relief as Limbo and Michael Clarke Duncan, who played the giant John Coffey in `The Green Mile', is well suited in his role of Colonel Attar, a giant silver back gorilla. Sadly the human characters are far from as interesting, not to say that the acting on a whole is bad, just a little wooden at times. However Mark Wahlberg is a worthy successor to Charlton Heston (who has a little cameo as Thade's father). Sadly the weakest part of the film is Estella Warren, who plays Daena, it is quite clear that she is in this film for one reason only, and that's not her acting ability.The ape make-up, done by Rick Baker, of `Star Wars' fame is absolutely amazing. Several different species of ape are recreated with exceptional realism, and when compared to the original it is clear how far special effects make-up has come.The ending is a bit predictable, a little ill conceived and on the whole a rather confusing affair, you really need to see it to understand why, it is clear that Burton was aiming for a twist worthy of the original, this is where he falls short as his ending is a little messy, although it does leave it open for a possible sequel, so watch this space.On a closing note, it is quite sad to see that the twisted genius that is Tim Burton, the man who brought us Beetlejuice, Batman, Edward Scissorhands, Ed Wood and Sleepy Hollow, has apparently been manipulated by Hollywood into making a film for the mass market, hence the 12 certificate, to increase merchandise possibilities. It still has all the visual expertise of Burton but lacks the darkness associated with most of his films. However `Planet of the Apes' is still a highly enjoyable film, if not as memorable as the original. So I highly recommend it to anyone who likes their films with plenty of action, great special effects, and full of apes.

I did what the author of a previous comment suggested and watched this film with an open mind and tried not to compare it with the original.  Compare it or not there was definitely something lacking in the story.  I won't spoil the origin of the apes for those who haven't seen the film but (and pardon me but I can't resist) even a monkey could figure it out and the ending while it does open the door for a whole new set of possible sequels is really disappointing and lacks the punch of the originals ending.  One high point however has to be the talents of the actors playing the apes, their not just actors in costume but really become the apes they are portraying and for an instant you do feel like they are really talking, civilized apes. Much less can be said about the actors portraying the human slaves, I liked it better in the original when they couldn't talk.  Director Burton was definitely trying to go somewhere different with this one but seemed to not really follow through with his ideas.  Out of a possible four stars, I give it ** 1/2.

Well, i just have to say one thing. This movie is really good, and, WE FEEL the movie...the only problem is this: don`t try to compare ot with the originals. Let that "retro-stuff" out of your mind.Tim Burton is great, even Wahlberg acts really good. 2 fingers up for the Ari`s and Tim Roth`s facial expressions....the sounds are great...

reviews.review_title: Its Planet of the Apes, set for a new target audience.
reviews.content: Unfortunately I've seen a few bad reviews of this film floating about, at first i thought that this was because of the films somewhat confusing ending.  Now i see that people didn't get the idea behind the new film. The film IS a 're-imagining' or whatever you want to call it, and it is not a 're-make.'  If you go to the cinema expecting to see the original 'Planet of the Apes' only with different actors and better effects you will come away feeling disappointed, if you go expecting to see a Tim Burton film on a par with the likes of 'Sleepy Hollow' and 'Batman' and with different messages behind it you'll get what the film was trying to do.  This is a problem of any film trying to do something thats been done before, the film its self is lost in the comparisons, take 'The Phantom Menace' for example, if you hadn't of seen 'Star Wars' you'd probably thing it was a great film on its own.Long story short:  They've taken the original 'Planet of the Apes' and set it to a new target audience.  Take that into account when you see it and you'll see a truly great modern film.

Tim Burton does a spectacular job of re-imagining and re-telling planet of the Apes. In watching Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes you can see the simularity's to the original film, but Burton also manage's to tie in his usuall twists and turns that make him such an amazing and one of a kind Director. When watching this film you tend to forget that there are only people under all that fur and makeup and not real Apes,thanks to Rick Baker.As if all that is not enough the casting for this film couldn't have been much better. Tim Roth Plays Thade the General of the Apes that despieses the humans.Tim Roth Delivers an unbelievably frightning performance that he should be recognized for. Helen Bonham Carter gives an absolutely steller performance as Ari. Ari is an ape that has pity for the humans because she see's how poorly they are treated by the Apes, after she meets Leo Davidson (Mark Whalberg)  she starts to realize that Leo is different from the other humans and she starts to believe in the humans more and more. Mark Whalberg Delivers a good performance but nothing that he will be remembered for. And last but not least Danny Elfman, Elfman composed perfect music for this film which I guess was not that big of a surprise because he always gives a 110 percent. Great music, great acting, Burton+Elfman= Great Movie!!!

reviews.review_title: did everyone see the same movie?
reviews.content: slow, predictable, and lacking any real magic at all.  I didn't care if all the apes died or the humans were wiped out.  The big battle at the end was about as "epic" as the jim carrey fight scene in Dumb and Dumber.  Cheese ball ape-human love scene with some out-right horrible add-ons, like having the young boy ride out to help and oops, don't you know it, his horse falls. I guess since humans are animals and don't have horses readily available we shouldn't expect them to be doing and jousting are dressage.  Predictable ending that lacked the jaw dropping effect of the original.  Terrible cameo with Heston, ain't it funny the president of the NRA is now dressing up in ape make-up and preaching the evils of technology and guns.  The make-up was beautiful and some performances were actually good, but the real problem is, if you're going to use the same name as the original, it better be as good as the original.  I expected better.  Sleepy Hollow, Beetlejuice, Edward scissor hands..... Tim Burton was not up to par with planet of the apes.

I just previewed this movie at the theater that I work as a projectionist for last night. I especially enjoyed the great audio in the movie. Halfway through the movie and especially in the battle scene I was right on the edge of my seat. Very very good movie, well worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: A movie which I didnt expect much from and enjoyed.
reviews.content: Well, I have never seen any of the original Planet of the Apes movies so therefore I cannot compare between them. But after seeing this movie I might just go out and rent them. The costumes and sfx in this movie are pretty amazing, and it has a good cast. And overall its a movie I enjoyed, I give it a 8/10.

reviews.review_title: A parody? A social satire? A darn fine movie!
reviews.content: I saw this recently at a preview show in Japan and I have to say that, despite being an affectionardo of the first series of films, this one rocks!The special effects are what you expect these days, special, and the make up is a true work of art (it's really difficult to tell who's who, though I think the main guy might be Mark Whalberg under all that stuff.) and the writing is crisp, if obvious.A special mention has to go to Tim Roth here, because he pulls off one of the most original, deeply motivated, frightening villains I've seen for a long time and manages to sound nothing like himself. If this were an eighteen film it'd be Silence of the Apes! He won't, but should be up for an oscar.And for effectionardo's off the first movie and it's glorious ending, don't panic. I have to say that (despite the improbability of it) the writers have managed to come up with a nice play on the original.I have to say that of all the summers movies so far this is the one I'd want to see again, and while Tim Burton can't resist getting cheezy for a moment or two with us throughout the movie, it won't make you gag as much as most of his others.Go, enjoy, ape it up.

the movie simply was not good. Tim Burton had good IDEAS, but never executed them well. the movie was so god awful predictable. there were NO surprise story twists(EXCEPT the ending which was AWESOME), and no reason to care for any of the characters(well, i cared about the lil' chimp in the spaceship). Tim Burton DID develop the ape social structure very well, but it took HALF the movie to do so. the whole humans versus apes battle was not exciting at all. The action just wasnt good.the big PLUS of the movie though were the Apes. The makeup and set design were awesome, and the actors LOOKED like apes! so, kudos to Rick(or rich?) Baker for the makeup, but that wasnt enough to save this movie.it is worth going to see once.

Well,I had been waiting for the last few years (after hearing of a new Planet of the Apes being in the works)for this film to become a reality.After many script changes (not to mention stars & directors) was it worth the wait?YYYYYYEEEEEEEEESSSSS!!This version ROCKS! Now, I am almost 40 years old and grew up with the original films,TV series & cartoon.I was an apeaholic back in the day!I had everything from the Mego figures to the Don Post masks. I had realized early on,that this was NOT a remake but a "re-imagined" Planet of the Apes by Tim Burton.I am not a huge Tim Burton fan,though there are a couple of his films I enjoy.After seeing his version of POTA last night,I have to say that I am very impressed!Great story,great acting and fantastic make-up! Though the story and the names have changed,Burton's film is exciting to the core.I will not give much away as the movie has yet to be released on Friday,but I will say that there are more than a couple of original POTA quotes thrown in and the ending is a nice twist (as it was in the original). Don't be too hard on this version,even though it is not the APJAC vision,it stands on it's own!APEAPHILES ENJOY!! 9 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: It's a Movie not a Film. Well worth seeing for Sci Fi Fans
reviews.content: In a few days this web page will be filled with people bashing this film. People expect a life changing experience when they go to the movies. If you have this kind of attitude then Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes will disappoint you.I saw it at the Washingtonpost.com Uptown Theater Screening (July 24th)I enjoyed this movie very much. The Makeup was fantastic; the action was great. The ending (seems out of place but take a look at the original book, you may be surprise to find no mention of the Statue of Liberty buried in sand in the book. Tim Burton's take is similar but may have been able to tie more with the rest of the film)I don't want to spoil the movie for anyone (I know that even a SPOILER warning doesn't always prevent me from reading)The movie is well worth seeing for Sci Fi or Action movie fans. Everyone likes monkeys (Just don't call them that, they don't like it!) so I think people will like this film.It won't be a classic like the original, but only because it's not an original idea, but an re-imagining of someone else's work!

We saw Planet of the Apes at a free movie screening...I was glad I did. Because if I would have paid money to see this, I would have cried myself home.It's a comedy...it has to be.  And a bad one at that!  The ending is unbelievably stupid.

SPOILER WARNING!!  Most of the negative reviews I have read blame poor plot, illogical events, and a seemingly uninspired performance from Wahlberg.  I, too, was confused by the ending, but upon discussing it with some friends, feel that I now understand it.  In fact, I now feel that the ending was extremely cool, and for the most part can be supported with logic.  Also, given the ending, Wahlberg's understated performance and lack of sympathy for the other humans makes perfect sense--how ironic that his entire mission was to get back to Earth at all costs, making "no promises" to the other humans, only to accomplish his mission and find that taking a little more time, and caring a little more for the other humans, may have made all the difference.  All in all, I feel that this movie has all of the things that movies should--basically making a worthwhile statement or telling an interesting story, done in an artistic manner.  Go see it, the pure spectacle of it is worth the price of admission, and let your mind explore the possible meanings of the end.

I just saw this movie and i can tell you that is really great!, all in burton bizarre view of the original.First you must stop comparing Cheston (in a cameo btw) whit Wahlberg, they are diferent, and if any of you read any burton´s commentary he sad that he never try to top the original, he only wants to praise it. The make up is top noch, and thank god burton hates to make any overkill CGI efects, that plagues many of new Hollywood "super productions" And for all of the people crying about that humans "did talk" heres Burton´s view of it:second striking difference in the re-imagined APES is the fact that the planet's homo sapiens can actually talk. If you recall, the original portrayed humans more as animals (much like how apes are seen today), hunted and caged for sport by intelligent (almost human) apes. In Burton's film, the dichotomy between the two species presents a truer political allegory  a more spot-on metaphor for socialComing to this planet [at this point in] its evolution where the apes are still retaining some of their primal instincts, even if they're at odds with themselves  you have some apes that are kind of moving more humanesque, you've got apes that are wanting to maintain their apedom and you've got people who still talk. Eventually, the history of this planet will probably go the way [of the original], but the human's self-esteem is still being beaten out of them at this stage.'My complains? yes how the hell Estella Waren keeps a incredible make up all the movie, please!!! make it ugly and dirty, even few scars heeheSimply the best of this summer, and i really love the ala Twiligth Zone ending!!!

Thought there would be more to it. The end was dumb, movies are better when they are sumed up, not just left to wonder. If there was more stuff explained in it, you kind of had to piece stuff togethre, also he should not have kissed the monkey.

reviews.review_title: I want 2 hours of my life back (**spoilers**)
reviews.content:
I can't believe I lost 2 hours of my life to this movie.  Some of it was ok, like the music, set design and costumes.  Most of it was lame, especially the dialog and plot.  I won't elaborate too much on what others have already noted as too much of a stretch - the ending, for example.  There was a perfect opportunity to end the movie as (SPOILER!) Leo gets sucked back into the electric storm.  That would have been believable, and would even have set viewers up nicely for a sequel - as well as letting us imagine the ending on our own, leading to debate, speculation, and better box office receipts when/if a sequel ever does come out.My biggest beef is with other requirements of the suspension of belief. For starters, where the hell did the horses come from??  If everything was supposed to come from the space ship, then why weren't we shown any horses on the spaceship?  How come more apes weren't killed in the rocket blast? They may be strong, but they're not immortal.  How come Thade wasn't killed by a ricocheting bullet??  C'mon, he unloaded a whole bunch of them, why didn't *one* touch him?  Why was there always a branding iron laying conveniently nearby, ready for use?  How could the humans have fought the apes when they were probably starving and dehydrated?
Obviously this film did not entrance me enough to ignore or not even notice these inconsistencies.  I suppose Burton thought the movie would be action-packed enough to induce the audience to overlook them.  The theatre was full, but the only reaction everyone had (SPOILER!) was to the half-second where Leo kisses Ari.  Gasps of disgust (what'dya expect - it's evolution-free Kansas).  No one was involved enough in the film to cheer when the rocket blasted, egg on the bad guys, or laugh at the comic relief.
I did enjoy the Charlton Heston scene. OK, so I want 1 hour and 55 minutes of my life back.

I am a huge fan of the original series, maybe that's what ruined the new one for me. I was looking forward to an all new installment and what we got was a boring plot-less mess that decides to use movie lines from the original as jokes. The Makeup and sets are great but who cares? This movie is lifeless and dull for the first hour as apes sit around discussing human rights.The New Planet of the Apes lacks the mystery and intrigue and character the first movie had and only decided to capitalize on the fact that Apes can talk. The ending is a ridiculous mess too that only sets up a sequel possibility. This movie is garbage and you should spend your time watching the original instead. I came as close to crying when I walked out of the theater as I ever had in my life.

reviews.review_title: ACTION should not be metioned in the same sentence as Planet Of The Apes
reviews.content: Other than that I was not disappointed in the slightest bit from this movie. Most people are bashing this film because they've gone into the theatre with the MORONIC idea that this film would be jam-packed with action. But knowing TIM BURTON and how he's always "actionly" impaired, I did not going into the theatre with that frame of mind and walked out completely satisfied. It sucks the surprise ending was spoiled for me but I was still satisfied with that also. But to be honest, even if I hadn't known the ending, I thought it was a bit predictible as the film led up to the ending.

reviews.review_title: Roger Ebert missed the main point
reviews.content: In case you missed Roger Ebert's review, he didn't like Mark Wahlberg's role as a hero, or his lack of heroism in the movie.  He must have been asleep during the part where his character points out to Carter's female ape character, that "...we are not alike, you care about everybody else but yourself."  For me, this whole statement defines the movie. He only wants to go home.  He only cares about himself.  And all without the arrogant 'attitude' we're used to seeing in movies.  It's either Look at me I'm cool, or Look at me I'm a hero, Wahlberg's character and final decision in the movie pave the way for turning upside down everything you ever thought you knew about what's really going on.  A perfect sci-fi where the seemingly explainable goes unexplained.The plausibility of the opening year at 2029?  A stretch...only if you believe we're in the same reality, which you will find out becomes one for the X-files.   The original 1968 movie left you with a shock, so you could figure out the timeline and the ape evolution.  This movie doesn't try to shock, as many are thinking it's supposed to.  It's actually supposed to make you THINK who came first, human or ape?  You will realize that you would have never reached this point if Wahlberg walked the path of the true hero.

reviews.review_title: I knew it, I knew it and I like this Ending Too
reviews.content: I knew it, Hollywood Loves a Hit, The public loves a hit and Burton's POTA is certainly a hit with the potential to ride out the remainder of the year. Im a 34 year old who saw the orginal movies and series on Tv or video but never in a Theater. Burton and crew really entertained me without taking on the unnecessary and futile task of re-inventing the wheel. They knew that we know the basic premise and they made what was predictable exciting and awesome with a plausible story that doesn't compete with the action. Guessing who's in Ape face, he Puns, and the effect could easily catipult POTA 2001 into a midnight movie cult fave for some time to come. (spoiler Alert) In fairness I must say that the filmmakers seem to play it safe and in 3 areas and traggically comical in another.1. Where are the female gorillas and orangutans - were they left out as no to offend certain ethnic groups. 2. The undone/editted out love scene between female chimp Ari and hero Leo is noticeably missing. 3. Where are the half breeds there would certainly be some given the ape/human relations in this movie 4. Last man standing, Leo,s more attracted to an ape than to a woman. How funny! Overall no dissapointments here. Whalberg has a franchise, Roth's anything but a pacifist chimp, gen. Thade, rivals Nicklauson's Joker as Burton's best Villian. Hey i even like and understand the ending!

Great make-up...big deal. I can see that in my own mirror! Not that I hated the movie, I didn't even mind so much the stupid ending and the cheesy thumbs-up chimp. I was too irritated by Estella Warren. OK, she's beautiful. Happy for her, but that was her only purpose in the whole movie! Why was she the only one to be running around half naked and with her cleavage showing(Maybe apes don't have cleavage)? Maybe I was supposed to be so blinded by her lips that I didn't notice that the little girl(that was taken as a pet and then rescued) seemed to disappear. Maybe I fell asleep and missed something, but what happened to her? I don't remember seeing her after that. I guess you can't have a movie without the token woman and cute kid, even if it is ridiculous. Another thing...since when do apes fly around like Peter Pan? I think a simple jump would have sufficed. I should be hired as a movie consultant. I could save these film studios a lot of money!

reviews.review_title: Great Movie Overall, in Spite of Mark Wahlberg
reviews.content: I agree with everyone who has commented that the Makeup is great as are the effects.  In fact, while there are some that trash the ending, I happen to think it was really good.  If you are the type of person who doesn't like to have a movie ending spelled out for you, you'll love the thought provoking ending of this version of Planet of the Apes.  Not unexpectedly though, the movie was great in spite of Mark Wahlberg, who is a terrible actor and really did not add anything to the movie.

reviews.review_title: Two awesome hours, followed by two awful minutes.
reviews.content: I awaited this movie with great anticipation.  I love Tim Burton's work; and I was greatly intrigued by the new APES movie idea.  For two full hours, I was thoroughly convinced that this was the best movie I've seen all year. Better than Proof of Life, better than X-Men, better than Moulin Rouge, better than The Pledge, Traffic, or Shrek.  I was minutes away from leaving this movie in awe.Then, the walls came a-crumblin' down.I thought that this "reimagining" had many great additions to the plot that were excluded from the Heston classic:  an explanation of the origin of the ape population and intelligence, the early fate of the humans, the origination of the holy scripts of the ape culture, a reasonable and more realistic adaptation of evolved apes (keeping some ape attributes in the process), and a less predictable twist-of-fate discovery on the foreign planet by the hero.  This time, it's not Earth he discovers, just like the pre-movie trailers say it isn't, but he discovers his role in the history of the planet.  It works well, as does the whole plot, in a wonderfully designed planet with great costumes and backgrounds.  It was an A+ movie until the ending.I had heard that Burton filmed many endings for this film and then chose one.  If this is true, then I have a great idea for him:  send out the alternate endings in the next coming weeks and tell the public you've done so.  Let us see the different endings on the big screen, never knowing which one is with the movie! It would be a real first, and would give us a chance to make peace with the end of this movie.The end of this movie, of course, being the only part of the movie that was not spectacular.It's not that we movie fans don't love a surprise ending, or a happy ending, or an unhappy ending, or a predictable ending;  it's just that we do like it to make sense.  The ending of this movie makes absolutely no sense, none. It is in logical, chronological, and collossal error.  It does not correspond with anything else in the movie, and it simply makes no sense whatsoever.  This is perhaps the worst ending of a movie since Waterworld, and ruins what was over two hours of the best movie I've seen all summer. It was a great movie, it should have ended greatly.  I give it an A++ for two hours or so, and an F-- for the last few minutes.  With a better ending, this could have been the best remake (excuse me - "reimagining") I've ever seen.Damn this screwy ending, damn it all to hell!

Why would you remake a classic? Why would you spend 100 million to make such a bad movie? And for that 100 million could they not have come up with a better script?This movie is horrible, save your money and catch the original some weekend at 2am... And if you really want to see what this remake is like, then catch one of the sequels to the original planet of the apes. Those are just as painful..

Very Tim Burton.From the beginning to the end, you will see the movie through the eyes of Tim Burton. It was beautifully crafted, from the very realistic ape make-ups by Rick Baker to the actions acted by the actors. Though critics may be divided by this one, it is a summer movie. Something you will watch to have fun and be surprised. This remake is very reimaged. This means that people should expect something extra with this film but what the film gave was 10 times that people expected which is good. The sound is good. The cinematography is very clear. But the story may be quite simple than what people expect. The actors were very in to it. All in all, the film has good sides and bad but see for fun and for summer.

reviews.review_title: *******BIG SPOILER ALERT******* Did anyone else notice. ... .
reviews.content: The date indicator in Leo's pods??(My movie going companion had to confirm this one for me, but she saw the same thing.) BIG SPOILER ALERT!!!!!!!!! In the first "time jump", the date display in Leo's pod shows numbers rapidly advancing as he hits the magnetic storm, indicating to me that in the world of this movie, Leo would end up in, duh, the future.Now in the final "time jump" after resolution on Planet Ape, the date display DOES INDEED appear to be going BACKWARDS, from the late 2000's to the earlier, indicating to me that in the world of this movie, hmm, Leo is going BACK in time, possibly to before the crash of his space station occurred, but even if not, LONG before the generation of apes that included Thade.Which brings me to my question.  Given these circumstances, I invite ANYONE to explain to me how the movie ends the way it does, with any kind of logic whatsoever.  If there's something I missed, I would greatly appreciate a response.However if my theory is correct, then some needs to give editor Chris Lebenzon a swift kick in his simian tail. . ."Oh, sorry Mr. Burton, that must have been the day I had that liquid lunch. . ."Grumpier than Thade over the state of affairs

reviews.review_title: A real disappointment and conclusion begging for a sequel.
reviews.content: ***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** I was about 12 when the first movie came out. I have seen it about 10 times since.Not since "Back to the Future" was an ending more ripe for a sequel.The story-line was definitely different.The major differences between versions were: 1. Humans could speak. 2. Apes had no technology. 3. Planet was not earth. 4. Overall acting was inferior. 5. Special effects however were OK. 6. Apes were more ape-like in attitute and mannerisms.It was obvious from the start that the world was not earth. Yet the conclusion of the movie ended on earth.  This was very confusing to me.

reviews.review_title: An exercise in what not to do.
reviews.content: In brief, this is a tragic example of a movie that should not have been made. I am not saying that the original was so amazing that it is blasphemous to re-do it, far from it.
