What I am saying is that this movie is so lacking in a compelling story that the truly amazing Ape effects and acting are utterly wasted. The human actors are uniformly wooden and seemingly unaffected by thousands of years of oppression, not to mention that lipstick and hairspray seem to have been developed in the jungle somehow.If you can overlook the glaring plot holes, and somehow completely ignore the, lets face it, ridiculous ending, then you stand a chance of appreciating the truly fantastic apes. If this movie could have been made without the human element, it would be an excellent portrayal in itself, as it is, this film never rises above mildly entertaining. If you are old enough to have seen the original in it's time, you will probably loathe this disaster.

There are movies which invite deep thinking and reflection; there are movies that do not. This movie is of the latter type. Don't expect deep plot or social meaning--remember, it's just for fun! The original had pretensions of social commentary, while this version is obviously designed to be enjoyed. The effects are great, the script adequate and it is one of the few movies I've seen this summer that haven't left me feeling cheated. 8 out of 10 from this movieholic.

reviews.review_title: POTA was a great film with a terrific ending...
reviews.content:
After reading many reviews, many folks don't get this movie--and they never will. POTA was beautifully done.  I, for one, don't want everything explained to me.  I want to ponder and have several ah-ha moments while I'm watching a film.  I thought the comedy was great and something I didn't expect.SPOILER ALERT:I wouldn't have wanted Mark to be more "human", after all he was a military guy. My biggest gripes were that the apes had more strength than they should've and the female apes were poorly designed.  You immediately knew which ape species the male ones were, but the poor females (what few there were) looked worse than the '68 ones.  Maybe the makeup artists should've paid closer attention to HOW female apes looked when they went to the zoo for research...
Everyone wonders about the ending. (for all who haven't figured it out), there were 2 spacecrafts on the planet, remember.If you still don't get it, you never will.  Just wait for the sequel.Even my 10 year old got the ending...

reviews.review_title: Seeing it for the first time
reviews.content: Unlike most people, I did not see the original Planet of the Apes before I went to this movie.  So, I did not get a lot of the jokes that pertained to the previous movie(s).  Based on that, I have to say that this movie is not as good as I thought it would be.  The action is great, and the costumes phenomenal (Rick Baker is awesome).  But the dialogue lacked depth.  Go see the movie for the action and laughs, but don't go if you don't like cheesy lines delivered badly.

reviews.review_title: Don't think and you MIGHT enjoy this movie.
reviews.content: The entire movie lacked foundation.  I understand that it is fiction, but since we are having to accept talking apes, they could attempt to make something plausible. One easy way would be to change the date.  The movie starts in the distant future of 2029??  In 28 yrs we will have star trek like shuttle that can go in and out of orbit with a single stage and then travel across the solar system.  We will have a magnificent research center somewhere around saturn that has batteries that last thousands of years. I just can't wait to see what we will have before I am 50. The next big gripe is the uninhabited planet that has only apes and humans...and horses.  Where'd those horses come from?  While I appreciate the attempt to explain the source of the apes, it could have been much better.  How'd the apes rebel against the armed humans in the first place? I'm sure an ape can kick my butt, but I can blow it's head off with a gun. There are countless other problems with the movie that I don't feel like bringing up.  The movie was also slow for an action flick, two hours pass and you can count major moments on one hand. The final gripe is the ending which I won't "spoil" for anyone.  Try as hard as you want to defend it, but it makes absolutely no sense.  It was meant as a shocker, but the surprise came from how ridiculous it was.  People laughed in the theater where I was. Don't waste your money on this movie.  Maybe rent it, but I'd recommend waiting for it to be on a movie channel.

SPOILER ALERT, SPOILER ALERT, SPOILER ALERTMy guess is that the ending is a setup for a sequel. The inscription at the monument in the end refers to General Thade, who is aware of the location of Leo's spaceship that crashed in the swamp. After being rejected by Attar and the other apes, Thade must at some point recover the ship and travel back to Earth to exact his revenge, setting off a chain of events where the apes take over control of Earth.

reviews.review_title: OK ... so it wasn't the best movie ...
reviews.content:
So I went to see Planet of The Apes at the Cinerama theatre here in Seattle (nice giant 65ft screen, wicked sound system, etc ...)I think that all I can really say is that this movie was no academy award winning piece of art, however it wasn't the terrible production that people make it out to be here in the user comment section of IMDB.Of course, like all the other crud coming out of Hollywood, this film was definitely aimed at the dumber bunch of us humans ... i.e. the lowest common denominator, then again it is a summer popcorn movie.Anyway, I enjoyed this movie for what it was ... simple fun.Now, having read many if not almost all of the comments posted here, let me answer a few things that people have been asking and in most cases incorectly answering.  SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!!1) Time & Place / Where & When:  The film begins in an orbit around/near Saturn in 2029.  Mark Wahlberg's character goes through the "storm" and gets booted to about 2329 (according to the ship's computer) and crashes into an uncharted planet with multiple moons ... in close proximity to a number of other planets which in no way resembles our solar system (past or present)... i.e. it is not Earth.2) Mark Wahlberg's spaceship:  There is no way that anyone on the ape planet could salvage the ship. a) no technology available b) ship's electrical system is fried (that's why it crashes) and what wasn't destroyed on planetary-entry was surely destroyed while underwater c) the pod crash-landed on a planet. its broken. d) the capsule's window/door was blown off by explosive bolts e) its under water f) nobody knows how to fly it (well except for the Pericles ... but I don't think he is going anywhere soon)3) The "ancient" gun: General Thade's lineage was said numerous times to lead directly back to the progenitor of their current species.  The ape that killed most, if not all of the humans after the crash ... who killed them with a gun.5) The Oberon wreck:  1) We did not know when the Oberon crashed into the planet, but since the storm was messing up their systems (remember the power going out?) it is safe to say that the station was pulled into the vortex so to speak.  It probably got kicked backwards quite a bit.  Remember, the pods went through numerous time-jumps becasue they were powered and had lots of forward momentum. So, the ship crashes way way in the past on the same planet that Mark Wahlberg lands on in the future.  Apes escape and continue evolving ... (it is possible that there were other animal species (maybe not horses) on the station (it was afteral quite large) like Gorillas, etc ...)  Station has three fuel tanks (2 empty and 1 full) and a nuclear powered electrical system ... which seemed to be shut down until Mark Wahlberg's character reactivated it.  He said it would keep its power for 1000 years or so ... but if it was turned off ... well who knows.  As for the ship surviving at all ... who knows.  It seemed to be in the desert (dry air preserves things) and it was in the "forbidden zone" so it wasn't messed with so it could have lasted a long time in its current state.6) When the ape's attack and they start the main engine, it is highly probable that most of the apes would have survived ... albeit badly burned becasue the engine exhaust was not pointed parallel to the ground, but rather upwards at an angle ... the point of the tactic was not to kill but more to confuse/scare the apes.7) Thade is doomed.  He cannot escape the ship's control room for a number of reasons: a) the only hand that can open the door left the planet. b) considering the glass wall/door survived impact from space into a planet without breaking probably means nothing on the planet is going to do the trick c) nobody likes him8) Someone asked why he was in such a hurry to get home?  Well, would you want to stay in a primitive world when you had the opportunity to go home to all that you know and loved?9) When Mark Wahlberg's character re-enter's the storm, he clearly re-arrives back in the orbit of saturn and he clearly sets course for earth where he crashes.  The chronometer on his computer display also indicates that he is back to 2020 something or other ...If anything is true ... I would have to say that when they jumped in time and space they also jumped realities. Saturn = mystery planet     Present = way in the future Humanverse = apeverseon the return trip, he didn't manage to jump back from apeverse > humanverse although he did get the time and space parts correct
Now for my personal issues with the logic:1) Where did the horses come from2) If the original apes killed the remaining crew from the space station, where did all of the humans come from (remember humans purportedly outnumbered the ape population)3) If the humans are also descendants from the space station, and the apes evolved along with them, wouldn't the resultant society have been a bit more egalitarian?4) if the ape's planet really was a "mirror" to our own ... shouldn't all of the politicians have been humans?Well that's my take on this film ... again ... you can't go into summer event movies expecting anything to be really good ... you just have to enjoy films like these for what they are ... mindless entertainment (that costs $200 million or so to produce)

reviews.review_title: Smooth plot, Impressive apes, and Great overall aura
reviews.content:
The look and feel of this film is great!  It's a different, yet consistent aura, which makes the film very interesting and feasible.  Danny Elfman's score fits in seamlessly with the film, and the casting is very good.
The plot is very smooth and the film carries along well, which is to be somewhat expected, as it's a re-make, but that shouldn't be taken for granted, because even with little changes, re-makes can be screwed up.The actors and makeup artists did an amazing job creating believable apes. The movements of the actors are astounding - the walking especially.  The makeup is incredible - becoming more rare as cinema progresses because directors and producers want to do things computer generated, because it's quicker and easier, even though makeup is more realistic.  Tim Burton's decision to go with makeup was very shrewd.Planet of The Apes is a fascinating film and provokes much thought, if you are open to it.  I liked it very much.

reviews.review_title: Great movie, but doesnt stay true to the originial
reviews.content: I remember watching the original, with good ole NRA leader, Charleton Heston.  I remember it being meaningful, instead of this new-age "save the little people" approach that try to teach us animal rights and how humans are cruel and unpredictable.Let me just get this out in the open, the ending sucked.  Sure it was a surprise, but it made no sense and it forces a sequel to explain it.  I would've enjoyed it better if it was more like the original (and not the book).If you've seen the original, it's nothing like this version.  He lands by himself and is quickly thrown into the conflict.  A minor change (that I wasnt expecting, actually) was that he could talk as soon as he landed, where in the original it took Heston a while to talk.  Dr. Zaius is back, thrown in a comedic role thus losing the serious role he had back in the original.  Again, it's just a matter of taste.  If you want a reved up, updated classic...this is the movie for you.Something has always bothered me.  It was in the original and in this one as well (I dont know if it's the same in the book as well), but why doesnt the main character get that HOT human chick?  He seems more interested in that female monkey!  Sheesh, Estella Warren is very VERY hot, and she's a Canadian as well! ;)  That chick from the original was hot too, but she's like 4 000 years old now... :(The effects were there, the musical score was there...the plot and development of characters was not.  We get a sense of the theme, but neither the main character or his human friends are developed in any way.Overall, it's a very enjoyable movie, however they took a lot from the original that hard-core fans such as myself dont like.

WARNING: I will be talking about the ending, and possibly some other events that may "ruin" it for you. Just so you know.Yes, the script was bad, no charater development, useless people (Warren). most of those are talked about in the other reviews.Yes, as I said before the script is pretty bad, but some things can be the actor's fault. Some of mark's (leo davidson) lines were very poorly delivered. In my opinion, marky shouldn't have joined the Funky Bunch, and he should have gone to acting school (or a better one if he already has). Besides him, everyone one's acting was pretty good, but some of Duncan's deliveries were also poor.Yes, I liked this movie, but I did like the original better. It seemed that everything that was wrong with the original, was good in this one, what was bad in the new one, was good in the old one. Was Burton trying to make it better, and just missed the things that were good, concentrating only on the bad parts?Yes, the ending was bad. When Marky (leo) landed on earth (it wasn't the same planet, the solar system is our own, and it is earth when they show the large picture). He lands on the steps, and sees that the memorial now has Thade's head on it. The cops pull up, apes jump out, in full cop clothing, they pull guns on Leo. About this time I put my head in my hands, and just lost it. I laughed for a couple minutes, because of how rediculous it was. Hoping, that there was more, but no. Sure to be more if and when there is a sequal. Will it be a reimagining of the second original (lets hope not)?Yes, many people have tried to explain the ending. This specifically mentioned before in the movie contradict those theories. I have my own, which, fits EVERY thing mentioned in the move. It's not a realistic ending, but it FITS with EVERYTHING.

reviews.review_title: Great movie, if you understand it
reviews.content: When I walked out of the theater, I was initially disappointed; I thought it was nothing special, and didn't really understand the ending.  After one day of trying to figure it out, I realized that this new version of POTA is great!  A lot of the people who say it 'sucked', obviously weren't paying attention.  Complaints about the super-strength of the apes, and the exaggerated leaps are wrong.  The apes were GENETICALLY ENHANCED, that's why they EVOLVED and turned into the talking apes that they are.  How else would the apes have revolted against the Oberon crew, unless they had that strength? The ending, although extremely confusing, is good for two reasons: would you REALLY want a cliché ending where Wahlberg goes back to Earth and lives happily ever after, and it causes discussion and deep thought even long after the movie is over; something that is rare in movies today. Roth's performance steals the show, while Wahlberg does an OK job (not like you'd expect him to be spectacular anyways).

reviews.review_title: No Story, very bad ending, just a hide and seek movie, very bad
reviews.content: This movie as no real story. An ending that is totally out of context and not in the line of the movie, it is only good to make a sequel. It is just a hide and seek movie (get in and get out like a bad alien movie) Only the mask are a little better that the one in the original.

I've just come from the cinema after watching Planets of the apes, and i can only say that it was one of the best i have seen for years...I've always enjoyed watching movies made by Tim Burton and this one was no exception!

reviews.review_title: Ah, Tim, you've done it again!
reviews.content: For anyone who has seen the original "Planet" movie, this must have been quite a giggle, as it was for both my husband and I when we went with our children.Great movie!  Truly loved that fact that Tim took the old story and gave it a totally new look and meaning.Make-up aside, the actors must have worked quite hard with someone who knew primates of varying "classes," and while I have to admit that I was hard-pressed to believe "interspecies relationships," considering the various mixed marriages of humans, why not primates?Someone stated they didn't like the movie because the primates couldn't swim across the water.  Ever do any research?  It's true, they don't swim; they sink and drown.  And anyone who has ever been to the zoo should ask the keepers about the accuracy of some of the primates with various "missiles" such as food or feces.  They are DARNED accurate! :)I loved that Tim used people from the original movie!  Anyone notice Charleton Heston?  Or that he was anti-gun?  What a blow to the NRA! :)I loved Tim's use of action, movement, reality, fear, emotion and just plain FUN throughout the whole show.Perhaps some of the people who really didn't like the movie should go once more, with a very open mind, and see the movie for what it is: an excellent story of what COULD be, WILL be, or WAS...Grade from our family: A+

Planet of the Apes... I highly recommend you spend your money on something else. It was insulting, predictable and pathetic.Good Points. The opening titles.Bad Points. The quasi-science was just plain ignorant and hard to follow. Where was he? On Saturn? On Earth? And I thought Star Trek was bad with "Using the forward deflector array to spew gravo-metric techno-trash gibberish!" Just blame it all on an "electro-magnetic storm " or a "quantum sigularity tear in space-time" syndrome.The old plot was a masterpiece. Burton tried to impose a new plot but it was not creative enough to be thought provoking or intelligent in the least. His allusions to the old film were obvious and over-used.NOT A SPOILER: But what most really really really sucked  - TIM BURTON'S SURPRISE ENDING!! The ending was not only bad, wrong in so many ways, but really inappropriate. It just wasn't funny (except maybe to Burton). It was an insult to audience, Charlton Heston and the makers of the first movie. Actually, Wasn't this ending already in a Simpson's episode!In all, a disappointment. Especially since he had such a unique opportunity to do something really good.

reviews.review_title: This is bad science fiction, and a wasted opportunity.
reviews.content: *Warning contains vague spoilers, but nothing specific*I liked Aliens. I did not like Independence Day. I liked Contact. I did not like Red Planet. I liked the original Planet of the Apes. I did not like Planet of the Apes (2001), not even a little.From the opening of the movie until the end, I found the cinematography to be amatuer, I was never able to get into the movie as it appeared fake, a movie set.Not one human character in the movie could act, with the male and female human leads being horrible actors (Mark W. and Estella W.) and badly cast. The worst scenes in the movie are when these two are together, she in her "just from the salon" hairdo and inflated lips, and he with his immature camera presence nearly made me groan out loud when they were on screen together.The human characters were all over the place with a polished butler and maid, a grizzled old bushman, an african-american with face-scar tatoos, and the hot babe, all speaking perfect English that they learned in their tribal villages in the mountains...The only two actors of note in the movie, Tim Roth (as the Chimpanzee General Thade) and Michael Clarke Duncan (as the Gorilla Commander Attar) were quite good, with great fierceness and expression, but their excellent performances only showed the flawed performances of the other actors, even Helena Bonham Carter (as Ari the Chimpanzee Humanist) performed poorly in this movie.The makeup I heard so much about was very good for the ape males, but I found the ape female makeup to be far inferior and distracted me from their characters so much that I could not enjoy watching them.Many times during this movie I wanted to groan out loud, especially at the ridiculous events that completely ignored science and probability.  Humans randomly running through ape quarters kept bumping into every character you had met previously, how convenient.  Two spacecraft getting hit by random time distortions show up at the same time in the future.  Apes killing apes without remorse, even hundreds at a time.The ending is just plain stupid, won't mention it here but most people walking out of the theater hated the "surprise" ending.  A surprise ending is supposed to have been foreshadowed during the movie, this ending was just pulled out of someone's rear for shock value.Rating: 1 Star out of 5Some good recent movies to see:  Memento, Sexy Beast, Snatch.

reviews.review_title: Worth seeing, but not an all-time fave.
reviews.content: I sat through the movie and thought it was awesome. Later: I have a real problem with the storyline. There was not hardly any character interaction.  The "love" between Wahlberg and the two girls was never even examined.  There were looks, but absolutely nothing to believe that he cared even a little about them.  It was a little mind boggling with the crazy ending.  After I left the theatre everything got to me, and I decided I was trying to hard to interpret it. Now: I can only say it is worth seeing and try not to be too critical.

reviews.review_title: The ending just ruined it for me
reviews.content: I think Tim Burton has shown in the past that the aesthetic and his love for 1950's B films are the predominant factors in how he goes about his work, and this time it was the latter that ruined that work for me. Time and again, Burton has disregarded the entire concept of suspension of disbelief, and that's fine, but when the end of your film is as ludicrous as that of the new Planet of the Apes, it makes one forget the positives the film may have presented. Not as good as the original (what remakes are?), I found everything in the film to be 'acceptable', even some of the cheesier heroic scenes from the Wahlberg character, but the ending just went too far. That drastically changed my impressions of the film, which I was thinking of as a 5 or a 6 until the finale reduced it to a 3. Wait for HBO: You won't be missing much.

Ok, I guess it wasn't too bad.  It could have used a little (lot) more character development.  The special effects were great, and Tim Roth did an excellent job as the main bad guy.***SPOILER WARNING*** I had a few problems with some of the technical stuff though.  Like, why would we need to train chimps to operate spacecraft?  Our military is already working on remote control flight.  I'm sure by 2029 this will be perfected enough to use in space.  And where did the gorillas come from? Not to mention the horses.  I have a headache from trying to figure out the ending.  The time line just doesn't work.  I have read and heard a lot about the ending, and NO ONE knows how it happened, so I know it's not that I'm not smart enough to figure it out.  And how about that little space pod with all the fuel and speed to break free of the planets gravity.  Oh yeah, and how does the clock on board the craft know that it's traveling though time? Charlton Heston's cameo was a neat twist.  Too bad my wife got up for a popcorn refill and missed it.  "Get your stinking hands off me, you damn dirty human!" I couldn't have said it better myself!

reviews.review_title: First some comments, then some Spoiler
reviews.content: 1.  I did enjoy the movie.  I agree that there was no character development and thought that was a shame.  And the plot wasn't much.  But hey, it was just fun.  I think the jokes are funnier if you know the original.  I also think the humor would have been enhanced if we knew something more of the characters.  When I think of Batman you really fell in love with the Joker. Batman wasn't developed too much, but the Joker was.Much of what would happen was somewhat predictable, although not to the point of destroying the film.I would recommend going to see the film.  Don't compare it to the original, and don't look for any deep message or plot.2.SPOILERS!Having watched a lot of Star Trek (which as one person commented, helps to understand Holywood's love of time travel screw ups), I thought I'd try and comment on some of the things that don't seem to mesh.On the ship landing thousands of years earlier, Whalberg showing up thousands of years later, and the chimp showing up days after that:The chimp had to show up or you couldn't fix that scene!  (LoL).  With time travel through a storm, everyone would end up at different unmapped points.On earth being all apes:Whalberg had probably been on earth the entire time and just not have known it.  At first I figured he ended up on the same planet thousands of years later (which he did) but I didn't think the planet was earth.  Remember the signals they were getting from the storm?  All images from earth at different times.  They thought it was a reflection.  It may have been the actual signals coming through the storm.  When the ships passed through the storm they were actually be transported to earth at various points in time. Once again, since they did not know how to navigate the storm they would have no way of controlling where in time they would land.Who really knows at what moment the space station crashed on the planet (I assume crashed, not landed as someone else hinted at).  If it was thousands of years before modern man, these super monkeys could have taken over and destroyed man's progress at whatever level of civilization they had grown to.  I doubt it was 2029, otherwise someone have known the space station came down from space.  It could have been in the future (as in the original) in some sort of post apocalyptic thing.I thought the Abe Lincoln thing was kind of cheezy, but it helped lay it all out neatly and will garner another 20 bucks out of many of us.

***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** I really enjoyed this movie.  As remakes go, I thought it was done well. It did justice to the original, while changing enough of the story to make it unique on its own.  As for the ending, when I read through the other comments posted on this site, I realized that many people did not understand it or they have alternate explanations to what I believe.  Unfortunately, these other explanations do not make sense.  Therefore, I will explain the ending to clear it up.  First of all, and this is the most important fact, the planet that Mark Wahlberg crash lands on is not Earth.  The whole story and everything that happens on this planet is a separate issue from what has happened on Earth when he returns.  When he does return, he finds that Earth is now controlled by apes, obviously leading us to the question of how it happened.  Well, we are given the most important piece of information to understand this, the statue of General Thade.  We then know that he is the one who led the apes to the control of the planet.  The next question would be how he accomplished this task.  Well, he must first get to Earth in order to affect any change there.  And the only way to get to another planet is to fly there in a ship.  What ship?  The one that Mark Wahlberg crashed in and the one that General Thade knows all about.  How will he fly or learn to fly it?  The chimp pilot that is left on his planet.  So basically, here it is. General Thade is alive when we last see him.  He escapes or maybe just pretends to accept the changes that have occurred on his planet.  In order to flee the planet and perhaps to get some revenge against the human who changed his world, he salvages the ship from the water, somehow repairs it, assuming it needs to be repaired, since all we know for sure is that it had a rough landing, and then learns to fly it with the help, possibly by force of the chimp pilot.  He travels back along the same route as Mark Wahlberg and enters the storm.  He is transported back in time, but farther back then Mark Wahlberg.  Once there, he leads a rebellion of apes on Earth against humanity and wins.  That's it.  It is simple and makes perfect sense and contradicts nothing we saw in the movie.  And it is not even a new idea. If you have watched the old movies, and have seen "Escape from the Planet of the Apes," you will remember that the apes got to Earth in almost the identical way.  They salvaged Charlton Heston's ship from the water, somehow repaired it and learned to fly it and returned back in time to Earth.  I actually think that is part of the reason this ending was used; as a throwback to one of the elements of the old movies.  Of course, this ending is a stretch to the imagination, but this is science fiction and the fact that it is possible is all that is required.  If you have watched the old Planet of the Apes movies, you will know that the stories stretched the line of believability even thinner.  This ending also adds the irony that is needed in these types of stories.  Mark Wahlberg changes the course of history on another world and then leaves to go back to his own, but is thwarted by General Thade, who basically does the same thing to his world. Now he is stuck on Earth in an even worse environment then the one he wanted so badly to leave.

reviews.review_title: Lighten up, it's science-FICTION! (that means not real)
reviews.content: ***Spoiler Alert*** I don't actually tell the ending of the movie, but I'm sure I've written something that could ruin it for someone.Everyone who hates this movie seems to dislike if for the same reason-the ending. I loved the original POTA, and feel it has one of the best surprise endings of all film history. While the original movie followed the overall plot of the book, (yes, book. It was a book first, and obviously NOBODY who has posted here has ever read it) its ending is vastly different. This new incarnation has absolutely no similarity to the book other than an astronaut being stranded on a planet of apes-AND the ending!This is what I think happened, Burton knew he really couldn't top the ending of the original, and so settled for the next best thing by paying homage to the book's ending. A quick synopsis of the book's ending for those who haven't read it: The astronaut flies off of the planet of the apes. He flies back to earth, makes radio contact with ground crews, and lands. On the ground (I seem to remember him landing at an airbase) he sees jeeps and trucks approaching his ship. But as they get closer he sees that they are being driven by  APES! My details may be a bit off, I read the book over 10 years ago, but that's the gist of it. The planet of the apes and Earth were two different planets in the book, as I believe they are in the new film. You see, the thrust of the story is that the hero isn't merely trapped on a planet controlled by apes, but trapped in a universe populated by them. Alternate reality, parallel dimension, whatever. It kind of ticks me off that all these sci-fi geeks that are ripping the new movie for time-travel flubs can't broaden their minds to possibly accept the fact that Wahlberg was traveling through dimensions as well as time. Think about it people, in this film you buy into the idea that inter-stellar travel is possible in 40 years, apes can walk and talk, and a `magnetic space storm' can toss a tiny little ship through time, but it's too ridiculous to think it could open portals to another universe.I'm not claiming that this is a perfect solution to all the problems and questions the movie brings up, but I think it is closer to what the film makers were trying to convey.Was it just me, or did anyone else think the faces in those fuzzy, static filled video images at the beginning and near the end of the movie looked rather ape-like? More clues that it is an alternate reality?Did anyone else catch the Wizard of Oz line? `You go this way, you go that way, the rest come with me and we'll surround them!'Oh yeah, I enjoyed the movie. It entertained me for two hours and that's all I was hoping for. I never really expect Oscar-like performances from mega-hyped summer blockblusters. The original is still better in my book, though.

***SPOILERS***    ***SPOILERS*** The "suprise" ending that the trailer harks about was not really such a suprise. I saw it coming but it still makes no sense at all.If he travels back to his own time and lands back on earth how did what he did in the future effect the present? How is it that there is an Abraham Lincoln ape at the Linclon memorial. Flawed cop out ending

This movie was just plain horrible, it didn't do the originals justice, and is probably one of the worst Tim Burton films I have ever seen, The Movie was bland at best, and was a total waste of my $8.The thing that disturbed me the most, was the ending, while it was quite a twist, when I was watching it, I was thinking to myself "I've seen this before...." ... The ending of this movie did indeed resemble a frame in a "Jay & Silent Bob" Cartoon, (I have the issue in front of me, I managed to dig it out). now it may be total coincidence ... but ..... well ... who knows?My Grade on this movie: D

reviews.review_title: Great Production values, but cheap-shot ending
reviews.content: It must be our species' somewhat perverse curiosity that'll make this remake, or as they say in their publicity material, "re-imagining," one of the summer's boffo hits.  I am not big on science-fiction, but indeed, I was very curious to see Tim Burton's darker version of an already dark story. For the most part, the film holds up since Burton gives it a lot more intensity than the original.  However, notwithstanding everything, including Mark Wahlberg's lightweight performance, the much debated ending is a cop-out; a cheap shot of Hollywood's creative bankruptcy.  It just doesn't make sense, and isn't worth debating about because it is shot thru w/ holes. Why they didn't end earlier, with Leo just leaving the planet, is beyond me.

This was truly a great movie, I loved it! The ending though was really strange! So I really hope for a follow up!But I recommend it! Tim Roth plays the role of general Thade great! I´ll just say one thing to you: SEE IT!!!!

This film has taken a bit of a bagging and I did not know what to expect. POtA is a great "retelling" of the orginal. The story is simple and well rounded with only some minor faults. The major fault is how do the humans find out and track down the hero so quickly.The best part of the movie are the characters especially the apes, all played very well especially Tim Roth.The twist at the end is not to bad and does leave you thinking.

Overall I would rate the movie as poor.  The last 20 minutes especially were so so predictable.I am also find Tim Burton's dark, gothic style sets and use of lighting is starting to get boring.  He has used the same style in Edward Scissorhands, Batman and Sleepy Hollow.It would be good if Mark Wahlberg displayed more than one set of facial expressions during the movie as well.Don't waste your money.

reviews.review_title: Chuck has nothing to worry about
reviews.content: Huge Disappointment. As a fan of the original 'Apes' and Tim Burton I was doubly disappointed with the new "Planet of the Apes" The story is almost non-existent. The dialogue is terrible and/or self-mocking. The much-heralded make-up by Rick Baker is actually not that big a leap from 1968 (except perhaps for Tim Roth and the orangutang). And as for the new shock-ending-please! It might have worked except for a stupid illogical name turning up (you'll know what I mean when you see it). All in all, much anticipated but a major disappointment

Okay, I generally like the first version of a film and tend to skip the sequels, remakes, and anything else designed to remind me of the first film. Being a child of the 80s, I recognize that some sequels are inherently superior to others (i.e. Star Wars films, Indiana Jones, but not _Temple of Doom_, and others), so I tend to be suckered into repeats.So I purchased my $5 IMAX ticket (thank you, Canada) and was eager to see the newest addition to the _Apes_ saga.  From the first scene the sound and special effects are great.  You get wrapped into this film quickly and intensely.  You are, in fact, held throughout the entire film.Burton, as usual, has created a very, very dark film that seems to offer no hope for salvation.  Characters become aware of their "sins" and misconceptions of reality.  The battle seen of ape vs. man shows the reduction of man to his survivalist instinct, and a hope, albeit distant, for reconciliation.Most films would have stopped there.  Kudos to Burton for going further, but where did he think he was going to take us?  A great film was RUINED by the ending.  Too predicable, too "I need an ending, let's go with this one." You lost me, sir.  As we left the theater, my friends and I all echoed the same disappointment.  Tsk-tsk for going the easy way out.

I found the movie Planet of The Apes very interesting. Although I admit that I never saw the original series, I found this movie very entertaining. I also found that it was very refreshing, I needed to see a good movie this summer. I'm not interested in the mindless comedy of American Pie 2, or even The Princess Diaries. Even though I walked into the theatre slightly sceptical of "talking apes", I walked out completely satisfied. Definately a movie that will leave you thinking even long after it's over. If your sick of all the teeny bopper movies, and ready to see an unforgetable tale of human kind being turned upside down, I recommend this movie to you!

I never watched much of the original, and figured this one could have gone one of two ways.  I wasn't even sure if I wanted to watch it, but did just out of pure curiosity.  I personally was impressed, and liked it a lot. This left me wanting to go watch the original, and possibly the other movies that followed.The ending was pretty cool, and a lot different from the original (I did see the last of the original, that part I do remember).  Being confused, I just decided that Leo Davidson deserved his ending because he had been selfish. When I saw it the second time, I just had to search out the possible theories on this.  I couldn't accept the ending without having something behind it.  Then I saw the possibility of a Sequel, which should definately explain the ending.  The theory I've got is decent enough and will hold me up until the sequel comes out.All in all, this movie pleased me, and I can't believe a lot of the bad reviews I've seen some people give it.  Oh well.-Gryphon

reviews.review_title: Planet of the Apes starts out like a dream and gladly I fall into its surreal and beautifully produced reality, only to be jolted awake by my constant disappointment with the dialogue and character developme
reviews.content: I have not seen any of the previous "Planet Of The Apes" movies, so my review is purely based on this film's success as an entertaining Hollywood flick. That said, "Planet Of The Apes" succeeds in many ways as just that. The fast-paced plot moves along nicely, and the colorful special effects awed me into partial submission. Indeed, if I wasn't such an intelligent human, I might be able to close the part of my brain that yearns for better character development as well as some dialogue that stimulates a human above kindergarden age. Perhaps, what I suspect is true; that Tim Burton is partial to the apes, and truly believes that us humans aren't really that intelligent.Most of the characters in "Planet Of The Apes" do things for no good reason. Mark Wahlberg's character risks his life for a monkey for no reason. Helena Bonham Carter's character risks her life for a human for no reason. Neither one of these characters has a history that warrants such actions- yet they forge ahead with such heroic impulse! Estella Warren's character just shouldn't even be in the movie. In fact, I didn't really notice her until the end when Mark Wahlberg kisses her for no apparent reason- did he steal glances at her that I didn't notice? Did he really have time to notice her "t and a" while escaping from the apes and planning a battle? The only character which was developed was Thade. There is a scene with his father that explains why he hates humans so much.In a movie where dialogue is sparse, sentences are loaded. When a character opens his mouth, the audience has expectations.Hollywood action movies always have some one line jokes. In this movie that's all there is. Action sequences are interrupted by marvels such as "don't touch me you stinking human", or "in my planets monkeys live in cages and beg for treats". These utterances only serve to emphasize what we already know from the intense visuals. It feels like they were placed there to help the PG audience understand what is going on. It's as if Tim Burton is telling the audience "Look guys, the humans and the apes don't get along on this planet. I mean they really don't get along. Get it?They don't get along. Get it?"Okay, I've already spent too much time on this review.  I wish the producers of this movie had spent as much  time on their script! Oh wait I didn't explain the surprise ending! That's okay, the movie didn't either.

It's easy to feel sorry for the actors in this weak update to the Sci-Fi classic.  These are cartoon characters with about as much depth as a rain puddle.  The script they're forced to use is chockablock with utterances such as "I'm sick of this human" which kicks off the key battle scene. And, simply "Gotta go," as Leo (Mark Whalberg) bids adieu to his gorgeous model Daena (Estella Warren).  Maybe the only reason to see it is to try to puzzle through the twisty ending.  Better yet, have someone tell you what happens and save the money.

reviews.review_title: Mark is not the Good Dr.
reviews.content: I was have breakfast at the diner with my friend Chuck, the ultimate "palnet of the Apes" fan, and having our usual discussion about time-travel, worm holes, and why Charlton Heston couldn't go that fast to perform time travel, First, he couldn't carry the amount of fuel necessary to make the trip, even if going near the speed of light, because as he approached even a fraction of the speed of light, the mass of the accelerating object increases.  Of course then the time to an observer moving at that speed would seem to slow down relative to an observer outside of that frame of reference (time dilation effect).  This was explained by Albert Einstein in the early part of the last century.  Worm holes are another consequence of Einstein's relativistic theories. Regardless of how a being views the "device" that propels the travelers in both movies, I must concede that the first movie was better written, and that even in fantasy with a willing suspence of belief, there are certain rules of internal logic that should be followed. That is why so many people are struggling to make sense of this movie.  In a good movie one does not need to work that hard.  Dr. Who was a much better time traveler, and the writing was much more consistent.  Besides, the hero in this movie can't even fly a space pod as good as his ape assistant! Saying that this movie is as good as the original is like trying to say the "Who Wants to be a Millionaire?" requires the same brain power as "Jeopardy."

My overview is that the special effects and sets are good, the make up and costuming are excellent, the dialog is silly and the plot is ridiculous. The lesson learned is, don't monkey around with a good thing! What more can I say?Recommendation:  Go to Block Buster and rent the original movie.

I liked this movie much better than the original.  The story was good, and I love the look of everything. The sets and the character make-up were wonderful.  Thade was an excellent character, as was Ari.  I'm interested in buying this one when it comes out on DVD.

reviews.review_title: Keep an open mind and wait for a terrific ending
reviews.content: The movie is ok the more I think about it. Dont spoil the ending for everyone and try to see the original to get a better feel for this movie. The cast is good but you dont realize who half of the people are. It is worth the matinee and the rental costs. If you like sci fi and now more bout the movie its good. Not a 10 but maybe 6 or 7 like the newer Lost in space.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as some say, and not as good as others say...
reviews.content: ***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** Yes, here's another person so full of their own opinions that he feels compelled to post them on the internet.  Here's my $0.02:First off, I agree with Leonard Maltin that POTA 1968 is a near-classic. However, people who espouse the movie's cultural importance are exaggerating to a certain extent.  Let's "talk turkey" for a moment.  The chief concern with POTA 1968 was to produce a well-scripted, entertaining family movie. Concern #2 was that the Ape prosthetics were believable and not something the audience would laugh at.  Here's a little bit of trivia:  As revealed in Arthur C. Clarke's "The Lost Worlds of 2001," Stanley Kubric and he were furious that POTA beat out 2001:A Space Odyssey for a special make-up effects Oscar.  Go figure.The political commentary was tertiary.  It was craftily woven into the script but was not the key purpose of the movie.  Indeed it was so well written some viewers didn't even realize they were watching a work containing political metaphors and social critique.  In fact 20th Century Fox studio exec. Richard Zanuck himself didn't even see those aspects of the movie, or to this day refuses to admit they exist.  It is of some note that he produced POTA 2001.Modern day viewers who criticize POTA 1968 (or even go so far as to say the 2001 version in better) should keep in mind that we watch a movie with eyes affected by the era that surrounds us.  The perceptions of a person who watched this movie when it first came out (or during a re-release sometime in the 70's as I did) will not be the same as someone who watches it for the first time today.  I can only imagine what disparaging comments viewers in thirty years are going to say about the vapid quality of Hollywood excreta nowadays.Now let's look at POTA 2001 piece-by-piece: Script:  I had a bad feeling when I saw three screenwriters, three executive producers plus a full producer!!!  Whoah!  This is just way too many hands dipping their opinions into the cake mix.  It's no surprise that the story often screeches to a halt or leaves viewers scratching their heads in confusion.  I won't go into the plot contrivances and holes except to say that Tim Burton should have asked for at least five more drafts.Make-up:  Who needs to say anything more about this?  One of the best parts of the movie.  Previous user comments say all the chimpanzee women look like LaToya Jackson.  Don't you think this is just the teensiest bit racist?  I guess I'm the only one who thinks Ari (and Helena Bonham Carter for that matter) is pretty.Sets:  Burton only directed this, folks.  He didn't write, produce or design sets.  However, it still comes off feeling like a peek into Burton's mind: dark, grim and definitely moody.  The set direction is somewhat claustrophobic.  Though this may be purposeful, it doesn't quite match the expansiveness conveyed by the long shots of the city.Acting:  There's a reason so many of us love Tim Roth.  I agree that his Thade will go down in the annals of cinematic villains.  Are some of his lines incomprehensible because of the way he speaks?  Yes, but Tim Roth sometimes mumbles and grumbles with any of his roles.  So what?  At least he's not Estella Warren.  Guys think this woman is beautiful?  Yuck. That's beside the fact that she couldn't act her way out of a paper bag.  Why did they decide to have the humans talk anyway?  Nothing was added to the story by their dialogue.  Then again, almost none of the dialogue adds anything to the story, so what the hell. Carter is okay as Ari, Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa gets a decent role, David Warner is still alive and kicking, Mark Wahlberg is cardboard and emotionless (though this may be on purpose to reflect most modern day men) and the cameo by Chuck Heston is simply priceless.The ending:  The next part is a bit spoily, so proceed at your own caution. As far as the ending is concerned, this is going to be disparaged and debated amongst pro and anti groups for some time.  First off, before you put down a movie, try reading the book (for those that don't know - that's what you do with books; hold them in your hand and read them.)  As stated in another user comment, the Boulle novel took place on a world other than Earth.  When the astronaut returns to Earth we get a similar situation as in POTA 2001.  But how could this coexist with the explanation of the ape origins in the 2001 movie?  Simple, as explained in another user comment, with Thade recovering Davidson's pod, repairing it, and learning how to use it.  In fact if a person thinks about what's going on instead of just letting their mushlike brains stagnate, this adds new irony to the end wherein Thade does to Davidson's world what Davidson did to Thade's.  On the other hand, much of the rest of the movie cultivates our brains into mush so it's not surprising the end did nothing but confuse most viewers.Yes, this theory is hard to believe.  But the entire premise of the third Apes movie, Escape from the Planet of the Apes, is based on Cornelius, Zira and a worthless throwaway character finding Taylor's ship, lifting it out of hundreds of feet of water, learning how to use it, finding fuel for it, and somehow managing to travel back in time with it.  And all this is back story; it is never explained.  At least Thade knows exactly where Davidson's pod is.  And we're talking about a pod, not some multi-thousand ton craft. It's sitting no more than thirty feet below the surface of a tiny pond. Also, Thade has a tutor:  the Ape Davidson left behind.  However, it's a stretch even for someone who suspends his disbelief as easily as I that a little pod has 1) The power to achieve the velocity to break free of the planet's gravity well as well as 2) Fuel capacity to travel from Saturn to Earth.All this being said, I enjoyed this movie.  Why?  Because it was fun.  Tim Roth was Damn scary.  Wahlberg was convincing as a bland, everyday "stranger in a strange land."  Much, though not all, of the supporting cast makes the world come alive to a certain extent.  There's just enough of a story and hints of character development to pique interest, though granted not enough to last the entire movie.  There are a lot of little things that are likeable, such as the tongue-in-cheek references to the 1968 POTA with the lines, "Get your stinking hands off me you damn dirty human!" and "Damn them all to Hell!"  There's the reference to V'Ger (Star Trek: The Motion Picture) and Zardoz (Zardoz) with the name of the forbidden "Calima." POTA 2001 has it's flaws, but what doesn't these days?  If you don't want to risk 8-9 bucks, go see a matinee.To the people who say "This isn't science-fiction":  Let me put it this way: If I film myself lighting a match, that's science.  If I film myself lighting a match in a cro-magnon setting, that's science fiction.  Don't be a sci-fi snob.

reviews.review_title: Visually brilliant, scriptally good but not great
reviews.content: The apes look good and are menacing in Darth Vader manner.  The characters ape or human never really get time or the opportunity to grow.  The script does just enough to try and explain the main characters actions but a lot more time should have been spent on building relationships between the characters.  The pace of the film is good but the most disappointing part of the film is the ending just before the ending.My advice is to sit back and enjoy the film because it looks great and for the most part is engaging and interesting.

reviews.review_title: One of the Worst Movies ever
reviews.content: I was a fan of the original Planet of the Apes and all of its sequels, which told a fairly convincing story.  This new version blows all of my expectations away.  It was one of the worst movies I've ever seen.  The acting was terrible and if we ignore the little facts (like how easily Ari let herself be lead by humans or how Daena has lipstick and a boobjob on this planet), the overall plot made no sense.  This movie was made to have a sequel, because there was no explanation of why earth was exactly as it is now, just with apes.  All in all, DON'T SEE THIS MOVIE!!!

reviews.review_title: Marky Mark can't carry this flick
reviews.content:
Just saw this over the weekend. It's bad. Not bad meaning good either, OK? Mark Wahlberg is expected to be the hero, but he can't keep this dog alive. Nice costuming, effects are OK (but what's up with that upside-down fishbowl Wahlberg puts on his head when he takes off in the pod?).
The dialog is pathetic. Estella Warren has what, 8 lines through the whole thing? The comic relief was lame. The best (unintentional) comic relief was when the commander tells Wahlberg, "No more arguments, your monkey launches at 16:30!." There was inappropriate laughter at other dialogue as well.Just overall quite lame, you can wait for it to come on HBO or Cinemax.

SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!! Hi Folks! Please excuse my poor English - I'm just a bloody German... But to those of you who found the ending gag of PLANETS 2001 quite unlogical: consider THIS! The film starts (and Whalberg leaves Oderon station) in the year 2029 (it is written when Oderon station is shown for the first time) and Whalberg returns through the wormhole in 2165(!!!!) - this year is shown on his display for a very short moment when he passes the hole. So, if you take in consideration, that even without Oderon station, mankind has made experiments with apes to make them more intelligent to be a help us, apes whould have had a plenty of time to take over earth...! and the Lincoln memorial??? - eehh, well, may be there was a war between mankind and apekind with an ape leader looking quite familiar... and the apes won. hey, this is a sci-fi-film - I've seen worse! It's not THAT unlogical.

reviews.review_title: Intriguing and strange with a twist at the end.
reviews.content: I found the movie to be quite exciting and strange.  I had to give great credit to the make-up artists for the movie.  The make-up was so terrifyingly real.  I was kind of lost at the end, but that was just because I had seen the original and was expecting something different.  But it was all in all a wonderful film.

reviews.review_title: Review of the film - caution comments on Ending!
reviews.content: <Caution, possible spoiler comments here!> I have just seen the movie and to be honest I do not know if I really liked it or not.  There were some great aspects of the film, some of the characters had real depth, the acting and special effects were very good, and the general feeling of the Ape world was certainly believable.  The problem for me was that firstly the initial plot twist was very obvious from the first minute of the film (expecting a twist, a space station with Apes and Humans above a strange world - an unusual space occurrence, straight from Startrek Next Generation?) and I'm still actively puzzled by the ending.<Do not read onwards if you have not seen the film and wish to do so> The end of the film, the hero locks general thade in a zoo with supreme irony, kisses the ape, kisses the girl and fly's back to earth (surprisingly quickly for a space exploration shuttle). He arrives to find that General Thade has beaten him to it, and that Apes evolved as the superior species to man on Earth.  That's where I get confused, was it a parallel universe (star trek again?), in which case how did Thade get there? Was the Ape planet actually earth, and after 'Leo' leaves the planet he returns to find that millennia have passed and Thade had taken over and become the leader? Is it all a coincidence, why have the timelines changed on earth?  how did Thade appear as Abraham Lincoln and just how did Apes invent fire engines and police cars etc when Charlton Heston himself (Thade's dying father) had told us that Apes lacked the creative genes necessary to do this?In conclusion, I think I liked the film, it is amusing, thrilling and intelligent.  The ape effects are really good, and whilst some characters are nicely developed, there is a shallow element to some.  The ending does have me mystified, but its possilbe that I missed the point.

I have watched every Burton's film but this seems to be a job which was taken by accident. The movie is average and there's little of 'the Burton' influence. I hope the next project will be more independent. Danny Elfman's music has a bit change of style. But it remains mysterious and attractive.

I paid $8.50 to watch this sad remake and TIM ROTH (General Thade) had been the only worthwhile thing in it. The other characters were disappointing and shallow. So what if the slave trader guy was FUNNY?!? The special effects were NICE, but that was to be expected. Marky Mark's character made me angry throughout the entire movie. I wish his character had died.

No need to raise the same points as other writers here.*******SPOILER ALERT************A couple of things.1) If it really is Earth Capt. Davidson (Wahlberg)  has landed on and his clock doesn't work, since in the film the planet is reported to be uninhabited, given the normal rules of Evolution (random mutations with slight selection coefficients etc.) that it would take millions of years for the laboratory apes to turn into these feisty creatures not thousands?2) Also if the planet is uninhabited and it is Earth wouldn't that mean it would have to be millions of years in the past?
Still, I did really enjoy the film and found that, although the plot was weak and the acting was at times laughable, I was entertained from start to finish. Definitely worth seeing, if for no other reason than to join in all this complaining.

Awesome costumes but an absolute CRAP movie...they should have kept closer to the original story-line and avoided the love triangle confusion.  It was embarrassing to watch the two women vying for the attentions of Mark Wahlberg.

This film isn't nearly as bad as lots of people are making it out to be, there are weak areas and it isn't perfect but most people just got over-hyped and expected a perfect film. There's some good characterisation for Ari and Thade and the plot wasn't all that bad and leaves plenty of room for a sequel. Some people thought it was boring but they are just petty minded simpletons who went to see a horror/action film which is more like the originals and don't understand anything outside that. Don't go expecting more of the originals, like Burton said, it's not a remake, more of a rehash.

This COULD have been one of the best movies of the year. But alas, twas not. As soon as he crash-lands the story goes badly downhill and never really seems to get going again. I would recommend this film to anyway who always likes to know what is going to happen in the next 10-30 minutes every 10-30 minutes. Make up and effects are as you would expect, superb. Also Estella Warren plays the part of a "wild" slave girl brilliantly and the guy who plays Thade...well. Nothing short of brilliance in a all round not too good film. You'll be sitting on the edge of your seat throughout the entire film (bearing in mind the point of this is to fall off and get concussion so you DONT have to see the whole film) and as one last piece of advice. Leave 5 minutes before the end of the film. It's too obvious anyway and it's down right confusing unless you happen to follow the whole film. Overall, not too good, but had the potential to be a hit. Shame really considering all the originals were masterpieces...

reviews.review_title: Not as good as it could have been, or should have been.
reviews.content: While this movie did have a couple of upsides to it, like Tim Roth's excellent performance, the make-up, and the gun thing with Heston; I still feel like I should have just mailed the theater $5.50.It was way to over the top and exceeded the limits normally given to action-adventure films.  I know that the concept of the movie is over-the-top in and of itself, but c'mon.  Heston's last line as he dies was murder.  I think Burton went a little to hollywood.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as word of mouth!
reviews.content: This isn't anywhere near as good as Tim Burton can do but it was an adequate film. I can't believe it's been panned as it has. It has the usual Burton dark flavour with his  all his quirky touches and I really enjoyed it. It's been let down by the script - which is banal - despite the  nod to the original with the ending and the few clever quotes and also by Mark Wahlberg. He can act so much better than this so why did Burton let him get away with it? The superbness of Tim Roth (even under a few pounds of latex!) made them an embarrassment to watch together. Go see it. It's not as bad as it's made out to be and it's worth it for the sight of Charlton Heston railing about the iniquity of  using guns......

reviews.review_title: Just the name and lots of money
reviews.content: How dare they? I was hoping to see something new, modern and interesting. What I did see, was Marky -I look so good-, a bit blabla and a very expansive looking decoration and mask. Nothing more. I had some hopes, that the Three angle story, the hero, the ape and the girl will get more weight at the end. The character girl was so ironic and the ape the one to fall in love with. No, nobody must have had the ambition to use the tones of money something like this cost, to create an interesting story. The voting in imdb.com is 6.1. What is up with you? Don´t you know, how a good film looks like? Sad, but true, let´s hope, they don´t sequel this one,tooRichard

I thought I would be one of the lucky ones. I never saw the original movie nor read the novel so I thought I would be able to judge the movie   on its own merits and have an enjoyable two hours.Well, if you have not yet seen the movie then please, save your money. The movie has little in the way of merits - the ape costumes are impressive,... but that is about it. The music is cliched, the plot is completely inconsistent, the script would have been more intelligently written by an eight year old and the actors are put to shame by those in Final Fantasy.
I found Pokemon more entertaining and thought provoking.

Tim Burton is one of the most original and appealing directors of all cinema history, but this time, he seems not to be believing in what he is doing. What is more, you can easily realize, that this is not an own fiction. It is perfectly truth that make-up, special effects, costumes design, mourning atmosphere and its production design are brilliant, but the screenplay as well as the some of the performances are uneven. The movie easily bleeds because of its narrative weakness and its forced final twist. It has also a great rhythm and spectacular action moments, by far the best, however it sinks rapidly not only because the relations between characters are a kind of childish, but also because of its sense of humor. In spite of that, it is a decent and interesting motion picture.

I think bas rutten summed it up pretty well. I got the DVD of the Planet remake for free from the video store, and I still got ripped off! 2 hours of my life that I'll never get back! Yep, cool CG, adequate make-up (I'm not as impressed with the make-up as are others) and an uncredited cameo that made me smile when I realized who it was under the make-up. Aside from that, I can't think of anything else that's noteworthy about this movie.As I watched the remake of Planet, my mind began to wander.... I lost interest in the movie and was preoccupied with making a mental list of crappy movies that must've "looked good on paper." That is, instead of screwing up classics like Planet, go back and remake old movies that had potential, but didn't come through for whatever reason (direction, editing, cinematography, screen adaptation, etc.).

Pick, pick, pick : ). Sure you can quibble about the details, but I grabbed the kids and took them to see it when it first came out and no one was disappointed. We all got a kick out of it and afterward we rented the original so that we could compare. The kids thought the newer version was better, but I suppose a lot of that has to do with the updated technology and all. Now that they've gotten hip to DVDs and all the features they include, they want me to get it for all the inside stuff so I suppose I'll preorder it here. The make-up jobs in this film were certainly much better than in the original. I expect that will make its category at the Oscars. I had no problem with the acting, Tim Roth is always great, look forward to anything he's in. I didn't get Wahlberg's performance till I thought about it a bit more and realized that was his character, a bit selfish and tunnel-visioned. He kind of deserved the ending ; ). And I rather enjoyed seeing a different version and wouldn't mind seeing more directors do this. Seeing the second version of Psycho mimicked shot for shot left me cold. This version of Planet of the Apes still dealt with the important issues and I'm glad for that. We all had a lot of discussion about the nature of human behavior and how we all need to get along somehow. I know the cynics are scowling now, but its true. I see some folks don't get the ending and I'm not sure I do either. Perhaps that was intended, because it was left wide open for a sequel. Anyway, I'm not going to quibble, it was enjoyable and fun to watch, worth the money. Lord knows we could use a little entertainment nowdays.

I don't know where Tim Burton gets his ideas to make a movie but somebody, someday should wake him up.  I could go on about the endless flaws in this movie but I just don't have the time.  I will touch base on a few to keep those interested in viewing it far from it.  In one instance, Captain Leo lands in a mud filled swamp on the Ape planet.  Sure enough when they show an underwater scene the water seems clearer than the Great Barrier Reef.  I paused the DVD to see if I could see Coral.  Another HUGE flaw is the fact that the Apes hate humans much like humans dislike wasps in cars. Funny thing is that the Apes live so much like us humans all the way down to their Versace clothes.   Like I said, I could go on and on but I will not.  This movie is awful!!!!  2 out of 10 stars.

reviews.review_title: the best movie of Apes i've seen-GREAT
reviews.content: The performance by the cast are pure class. Mark Wahlberg as Capt. Leo Davidson was superb. Tim Roth as General Thade was exellant as a ape and a villian and i say he should at least be nominated for the Oscars as Supporting actor. Helena Bonham Carter as Ari was great and sexy even as an ape. Michael Clarke Duncan as Colonel Attar had a great performance and the scariest ape there. Estella Warren as Daena the sexiest and portrayed as a normal human to save herself and others was brill. i hope they would make another movie this. Great!

Did you remember the film you saw before? Did you remember the hunting of us by the humanroled wild apes? Had you been influenced by the  "human" doll of innocent baby ape? Or, did you want to feel that old shiver when you see the old acquaintance ruin at the end?  So you are in wrong movie! But; if you  came to the theater for Tim Burton, it's okay: If you say that; since I won't ask for "why", the answer "by chance" is not a disappointment for me, you won' t search for support of Darwin. You will enjoy nearly as if in Mars Attacks or Bettlejuice with the rich effects, colorful scenes and very very convincing apes! But if only Burton would make a movie like Edward Scissorhands, again.

reviews.review_title: Not so Sure how I felt about this movie
reviews.content: I am a huge fan of Tim Burton's, his dark themes and special effects are always fantastic and dynamic.  I could not wait to see this movie, unfortunately I had to until it came out on video.  The original Planet of the Apes and this are very dissimilar, both are quite enjoyable in their own right.  The special effects in this movie were, as usual,Tim Burton amazing, however the story-line was a little weak and hard to follow.  Mark Wahlberg was of course his sexy self - his brooding good looks make the weak plot more enjoyable.  It seems with every movie he does his acting ability increases, I felt that he played the character very well.  I was very confused by the ending of this flick and wish that there were a little more detail that would have helped me understand it more.  I look forward to seeing a sequel to this film, so I can finally put my mind at ease over the ending.

reviews.review_title: Waste of Four dollars and Eleven Cents!
reviews.content: I was unfortunate enough to pick this movie up today at the local video store after seeing a slightly above average rating on this site.  Sadly, this is the first time the ratings have been, in my opinion, totally inaccurate.  From the savages to the apes, I can't help but laugh at the pathetic dialogue, poor, uhm, acting?, and the, well, general atrocity of the overall movie.  The blond savage was the highlight of this movie with her sequined(I didn't actually notice the sequins, but it was commented by the rest of the excited crowd gagging on the movie), tight-fitting, low-cut cave woman swimsuit, and I can't forget to mention the sexy red lipstick she manages to keep smudge-free throughout the movie. *note:  i just heard "what a crap movie!" as i'm typing this review.  For some odd reason, the rest of them are still watching the blockbuster.Don't waste your time!!!

reviews.review_title: Crap: DON'T WASTE MONEY ON THIS
reviews.content: Was there any actual acting in this movie??  Characterization amounted to grunting, snorting, chest-beating and the occasional "me the big man with gun, me lead group through forest, you woman, you listen to me, that applies to ALL species."  Mark Wahlberg's pseudo Henry V St. Crispian's Day speech amounted to crap: "sometimes a single man can do great things".  The implausability of ALL of it amounted to crap, and in general, this movie was crap.  In conclusion: AVOID if possible.

It is by blindly choosing the unknown that everything in the world gets thrown upside down. He enters a time warp, finds that he has traveled in time (forwards, backwards -- who knows?) Ends up on a planet dominated by apes that his ship previously planted there -- irresponsible time travel with powerful results over the course of time.Then there is a whole lot of action, climaxing to the insight of the hero. One man has the insight into these phenomenon... and what does he do? when he gets the chance he jumps right back into a time warp and sees the results of his actions as they have spiraled out over time.. He left a peaceful situation on the ape planet only to find that had he stayed, the course of history could have been drastically different. Thought provoking movie wrapped up in a modern day action flick.

I don't really know what to say about this.....this is nothing compared to the 1968 Masterpiece. The acting isn't that good surprisingly. Mark Wahlberg has no chemistry with anyone really and the villain in this isn't good and is extremely forgettable. Some of the big apes are well designed but the small chimp looking ones are stupid. The humans are extremely forgettable and have no chemistry either and almost no backstory and are the definition of one dimensional. Even the friendly girl ape who I can't even remember her name was just ok. Paul Giamatti was terrible in this and completely miscast as the comedic relief. His character should've been cut completely. The biggest shortfall here is the dialogue is NO WHERE near as compelling and riveting as the first and can be very boring at times especially the part in the first half where they all have dinner and it reminds me of Coursant in Phantom Menace. The cinematography isn't bad but is one of the most frustrating parts watching this. you can tell there is lots of effort in the ape designs, sets, lots of practical effects that are well done and SHOULD WORK but they are weighed down by the stupid chimps jumping 10 feet, stupid ape noises/expressions, and during night scenes it is way too dark lots of times. The CGI is dated and average but 85% of this is practical so it's not a big deal. The ending is also sooooo dumb and bad. The music is boring and forgettable. The editing and pacing are not good either. This is clearly trying to be a Action/Adventure movie with Sci-Fi mixed in more than the first was a clever Sci-Fi Social commentary. This has NONE of the underlying messaging or thought provoking moments the original had that sets it apart from all others. It tries to focus more on the background of the apes and their backstories and society. But the dialogue isn't as riveting, and it loses focus on the humans and at the expense of giving the apes more backstory it doesn't give the humans hardly any. Heck for 30 minutes in the first half Mark Wahlberg just disappears into the background. This is sooooo boring to watch by the second half because of the boring characters, dumb villain, miscasting's, the lack of backstory of the humans, the dumb interjected chimp fighting moments, and the worst part the stupid ending. The plot twist of the monkeys on the ship they were testing evolving into the apes makes no sense either because were never given a reason how that happened. Also are you telling me the chimp police drive Ford Crown Victoria's meant for humans and mimic the Lincoln Memorial....it's so dumb and looks bad. The whole monkey he was chasing after at the start in the ship being their god is sooooo dumb as well. It has good parts to it but just never makes it work together in a cohesive way. Just watch the 1968 one. This is a insult.

Wow. Just wow. Tim Burton's 2001 remake of the brilliant 1968 original Planet Of The Ape's movie, could not be worse if it tried. Nothing other than baffling directorial decisions, extremely cringe worthy dialogue & really bad acting (looking directly at you Mark Whalberg!) are to be found here! F
A completely irrelevant remade, seen and forgotten
Not a very good movie in any respect.
Watch the original. It's better.
A lot of the movie I find entertaining. They just messed up with the ending.
First act was slow, gradually got better. Final fight scene was average but the dust made it really difficult to see. The ending was a shock but still confusing.

Really not part of the Planet of the Apes series of movies - totally different origin story and some unanswered questions - like how did the humans arrive on this planet? It was fun to watch and the characterization of the apes was fun to watch.

this movie is action packed with great movie stars like Bruce Willis and many others movie kept me on the edge of my seat when I saw it in theaters and I watch it almost every year with my wife we can't get enough of this movie

Burton seems to originally want a more fun, stupid B-movie throwback to this but it's obviously fucked with by the studio trying to make it a typical blockbuster for the time, feeling a mix of two different visions.

Besides Rick Bakers brilliant makeup designs, this movie had absolutely nothing to offer, and a big emphasis on the word NOTHING.
Could we perhaps... find that space time anomaly, and travel back in time, and just maybe... Stop Tim Burton, from making this abomination?
Wishful thinking, I guess...

I'm not quite sure why people don't like this reboot of "Planet of the Apes."  I thought it was a rather imaginative take on the original film(which I think was pretty groundbreaking and well done for its time).  Mark Wahlberg was great in this.  The makeup and the "look" of the apes were also very good.  You could definitely see Tim Burton's style in this and I liked it.  To me, this deserves a little more credit than the critics and the audience give it.  Well worth watching and I could see myself sitting through it again one day.

I'm re-watching this for the first time since it came out at the cinema.  It is absolutely terrible. It doesn't capture anything of note - whether it be cruelty, or environmental challenges, which I think the film does try to address.  The first film captures this. 
The acting is cringeworthy - such amazing actors normally.  Nothing in the movie is endearing at all, but I am still watching to the end, not sure why.
Predictable oh-no, oh-no, oh-please-no ending.

Yeah... pretty poor.

I didn't even know this existed until a week or so ago. Gotta be frustrating for all involved that they were in a remake/reboot of 1968's 'Planet of the Apes' that wasn't the 2011 version. This one walked so that one could fly etc.

Speaking of flying, what the heck is with the high jumping apes in this? It looks so silly and doesn't add anything; a very odd choice. It is, though, a surprise that this film flopped given who got attached to it. Tim Burton as director, with the acting talents of Mark Wahlberg, Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan and Paul Giamatti. It's neat that Charlton Heston and Linda Harrison (stars of the original) made cameos, though.

Wahlberg feels a bit miscast, though Bonham Carter and Giamatti are solid; the latter particularly seemed to enjoy the role. The film does have a Burton edge to it, as expected, but this is one of his weaker films no doubt. Some other negatives, for me, include the make-up, esp. for General Thade, - I'm in the minority there - and the story's pacing.

The make-up is great and I like a lot of the other design elements. Plus that final twist is so psychotic I can't help but appreciate it a little bit.  With the exception of that ending everything else in the plot feels like a collage of studio notes so it really doesn't end up saying much of anything.
I didn't mind this update from the classic.  It is nowhere as good as Heston but Burton did not do a bad job.
Not even a Wahlberg can save this movie.
It's fine. Definitely not as bad as everyone says it is. The visuals and soundtrack are pretty amazing.
