Arguably one of the least Tim Burton-y films that the man has ever directed, the 2001 remake of Planet of the Apes boasts great makeup effects, looks great and has a talented cast but the unremarkable acting, outside of Tim Roth's entertaining performance as the Big Bad, uneven script, forgettable characters, cheesy callbacks to the 1968 classic and, of course, the WTF ending that I'm surprised hasn't fully reached "It Was His Sled" status (though that turned out to be closer to the actual source material's ending than the 1968 film, go figure; not to mention the amusing reason that Burton did that ending just to be a troll in case this film got a sequel, which it didn't) make this franchise's first journey into the 21st-century an inferior alternative to the brilliant Andy Serkis trilogy that would come out a decade later. Though I'm honestly surprised that I found it better than some of Tim Burton's other movies that I've seen, given this one's reputation as possibly the worst Burton film ever. Huh.

Another re-imaging of the first movie Planet of the Apes but not without the
lousy ending!!

Could have been so much better . Good special effects.some of the ape make up is really good . Some is just terrible like h b carters. It looks like set in a studio but the desert scenes are pretty good

Tim Burton remake of Planet Of The Apes is underrated. No deep message like most of the franchise but the comic relief gives some breath. The acting, Human eyes underneath it all makes it more real for me. Ending people cry about was a nice twist.

Planet of the Apes by Tim Burton is the remake of the 1960s original classic about anthromorphic apes who have created their own civilization. This one pales compared to the original due to the fact that is filled with bland characters, stupid dialogue, and some plot issues. Yet this movie quite well entertains and is filled with great special effects, great make up by the legend Rick Baker. Mark Wahlberg does ok somewhat likeable but mostly bland which makes it hard to buy since he is the main hero.Tim Roth does a great performance as the antagonist Thade an ape general covered in terrifying makeup. Helena Bonham Carte also does a warm and powerful performance as a female ape who sides with Mark's character. The most disappointing is to see Estella warren in a character that does nothing other than look pretty and an ending that is clearly egregius in light of the original.

If it wasn't remaking an iconic piece of movie history, I could enjoy it as a stupid popcorn movie. But it's not necessary, and the ending still makes me salty 20 years later. I left the theatre after watching it a bit amazed that they thought that was a good ending! No one in the whole process of making the movie said, 'This ending doesn't make sense.'

One of the best movies I've seen in a while very enjoyable film brilliant acting brilliant cast excellent storyline superb special effects and makeup can't really fault it in any way brilliantly executed
this is a classic and one of the best twists in movie history!

They tried a little too hard to make this a deadly-serious film in the dialogue and acting performances for there to also be some very obvious wire-fu going on with the apes leaping around as it looked unbelievable and goofy. The script felt like it had suffered rewrites without proofreading as there were some inorganic scenes like Thade telling Giamatti that he stank like humans immediately after he'd left the cage full of them. The plot was confusing only in that it was illogical for the main spaceship not to have been pulled forward in time when the same electrical storm worked to send Wahlberg back where he came from. That said, Rick Baker knocked the makeup effects right out of the park and really kept the movie from turning cartoonishly bad on all on his own. The cinematography was recognizably effective and the score was plenty good, as all Elfman scores are.
I was gonna give it 5 stars but no sex scene.

You gotta hand it to Burton: when he makes a bad movie, he makes a BAD movie. I question whether they had any real idea of what made the originals so great. Gone are the unique philosophies, nuanced characters, solid comedy & entertaining old-school sci-fi thrills. In their place is the very worst of turn-of-the-century big budget bores: visual dullness, story ineptness, bland characters, tired performances, & a gluttony of embarrassing fan-service callbacks. A film that's as disastrous as it is completely useless.

It has impressive makeup effects, but its underwhelming narrative and bland performances, except for Tim Roth in a chilling villain role, make this a dissapointing remake and a great disrespect to the original movie.

The 1968 original is a literal transformative classic for the genre, topping it off with a final shock that furthers its status and garnered a cult following favoring the storyline. Tim Burton's reimagination of the story honors the merits with more primitiveness as the story's true nature and a misdirected twist that erases predictability due to being a remake in its own fashioned direction, surprisingly away from his signature stylish eccentricity. The welcoming return of the story is something for the new generation, particularly the millennia, before they eventually visit/discover or actually re-discover the original, and they might prefer the old ones over this due to faltered writing and void of attachment to the film's appeals besides the entertaining genuine B-movie spectacle. (B)
Nonsensical  remake with some really dumb changes from the original.

I really wanted to like it, even considering the blowback it has received over the years. Yet, I cannot defend this film in any way. The plot goes nowhere, there is almost no character development, and it is downright confusing. Plus, any effect of humans ruling apes is gone because the humans are smart and can talk, while the apes are savage like, grunting and snarling the whole way through. There is no sophistication about them...other than the fact that they can talk. It is extremely disappointing, and I now understand why it ranks near the bottom of the series. What a shame...

As a fan of Planet of the Apes, I do find this movie lacking something that the original was just so good for. oh, I know its the intelligent plot and good dialogue. This movie isn't the worst and I still like watching it mainly because I like the cast and Tim Burton.
So much potential yet ultimately very disappointing.
One of the worst films with the title Planet of the apes

Wow! We all thought that Tim Burton was going to turn the already classic into a masterpiece. He ended up very short of my expectations. The original could relate to racial injustice with the apes thinking that the humans were bad and couldn't think similar to animals. Treated like aliens. The original addressed stereotypes. It showcased the great Rod Serling's writing talents. And then you see the remake and it falls way short. Humans are pets. Didn't feel like something that Rod Serling would make. Creepy apes. Strange ape rituals. Yet somewhat amusing.

Similar to the first Planet of the Apes movie. The difference is that the CGI started improving to where they did not use humans to where costumes. The thing is, it was really different than the original. The astronaut lands on Earth, where apes rule the planet. But before that, him and his crew at his timeline, sent an ape in space as an experiment. Of course, the ape disappears into some sort of orbit or particles. The man goes to retrieve him back, but he gets sucked into it. There, he is sent to the future where apes are ruled. The story is the same as the original, but this time, the humans can talk in this one. The ape that he sent in his timeline, turns out to be the king or the ruler of the planet, where they respected him. After the battle ended to where they accepted the humans, the man goes back to his timeline. This got confusing. General Thade is an ape that wanted to kill the man when he was there. After he came back to his timeline, he looks up at what appears to be the Lincoln Memorial, only to find that it is now a monument to General Thade, who had later escaped, also traveled back in time through the same electromagnetic storm and conquered humanity. Leo is descended upon by a swarm of police officers, firefighters, and news reporters, all of whom are apes. It seems they wanted to make a sequel of this, but I guess they haven't.

Planet of the Apes was at it's best with the first two films where humans were cloth wearing primitive mute savages. That built a world and set a narrative. In this one, Marky Mark crash lands and within seconds is being chased by apes! No world building. No story, no point. Instead of savages the humans are like the crowd at a hippie festival. You would have thought that of all people, Tim Burton would have made a great looking Planet of the Apes movie. What a waste.
A waste of money and everyone's time, there is not comedy not action or drama in this tasteless attempt of rebooting a saga
IDC about this movie. If you want, watch the original 3!!
Tim Burton's reimagining of Planet of the Apes succeeds in terms of makeup and costume designing but falls completely flat on its face with its script, acting, and direction.

If having your intelligence insulted is your thing then this is the film for you. The year is 2029 and explorers have eschewed the use of robots to perform dangerous space missions in favor of ... chimpanzees. Why? Because the producers needed to shoehorn an ape into the opening scene of this pathetic attempt to cash in on the original franchise. Instead of good writing we get lavish special effects and instead of actors we get Marky Mark Wahlberg, proving once again that his acting abilities range from large biceps all the way to ripped abs. An actual cardboard cutout would have been equally as watchable. Marky is however perfect for the role - this soulless attempt to cash in is emblematic of his own acting capability, which is comparable to a mannequin filled with botox.
This garbage has no redeeming features, from appalling dialogue, stock characters and writing that was presumably done by the chimps themselves.
The producers probably thought putting Marky beside less evolved simians could possibly place his performance in a favorable light. They were wrong.

This movie is awful, but you know what? I could forgive it all if it wasn't for the completely absurd ending.Mark Whalberg escapes The Planet of The Apes and finally returns home to earth only to discover it is a second freakin planet of apes. Marky Mark somehow manages to land his ship right on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. And guess what. The memorial is now an ape. But he's not just any ole monkey its General Thade. Oh yeah and by the way this planet of Apes was some how started by Thade, who was defeated on the other planet of Apes. How the hell did Thade even get to Earth to begin with? This ending never fails to boggle my mind. I will never understand how somebody read this and decided to give it the green light.
Not terrible but very Tim Burton
Planet of the apes is the worst film of 2001

Not as bad as many think, but it is a movie with a lot of flaws. To be honest though, I prefer this to the CGI-Trilogy, that lacked any impact or emotion, since this movie felt like original one, though, Mark Wahlberg was a terribly actor at that point in his career and it shows greatly. Tim Roth and the whole Make-Up Department (as well as the AWESOME score) steal the show and make this movie a joy for me to watch. Compared with the remakes of today... this is actually not that bad!
a.k.a. Tim Burton sells his soul to Hollywood

This movie was weird. Everything about it looked right, but there were several plot points that were scattered throughout that didn't make sense. I've seen it a couple times, and I don't remember a thing about it. The only thing that I do remember was it's lackluster ending. With President Lincoln statue as an ape. It doesn't make any logical sense. Some parts with the apes attacking was good. But this? It doesn't work for me.
I liked this as a kid but I absolutely hate it now. I will be a bit forgiving in my rating however because the visuals are good and it somewhat kept the ending of the book

This movie under performed in almost every measure possible. I really had to strain my attention span to finish this one. I feel bad for Charles Heston. How did he get tricked into this remake. Costume and make-up are one of the only things well done. The ending is terrible.
Tim Burton's reimagining of Planet of the Apes succeeds in terms of makeup and costume designing, but falls completely flat on its face with its script, acting, and direction.
Tim Burton's worst film, one of the worst remakes ever in film history.

I know most people did not like this movie, but it was not that bad. If we look at it as if it was a reboot, rather then a remake, then the story is great. Lets just pretend the original five movies were not made and this was the first of its kind. Not sure how it would have done in the box office but for what it is, I really enjoyed it.
Welcome to a world where apes rule... and their pet humans can talk, but still act stupid, but aren't stupid, just bad actors.
This is so clingy. The effects are horrible. I cant even take it seriously

Tim Burton's reimagining of Planet of the Apes succeeds in terms of makeup and costume designing, but falls completely flat on its face with its script, acting, and direction.

1/10
It's better to remain silent that thing.
Only deserves one star for adding outer space, but there is still no backdrop on the Apes creation.

This is a beautiful film to watch and much better than the recent trilogy which are totally far fetched and not a patch on the originals. However it only gets 1 star due to the god damn awful ending that undermines all the good bits before. No wonder there was never a sequel.
The best part is when there is an awkward kiss between mark Wahlberg and a woman in full ape makeup without control of her lips.
Awkward and misguided, this reboot is entirely lost and the ending will leave you laughing a d scratching your head.
Entertaining if you don't think about it too much

Many years in the waiting, finally the Planet of the Apes remake made it on the screen after years and years of lingering, it ended up with a Burton directed, Wahlberg staring ...meh...film.  In this remake, an ape constantly referred to as a monkey that is being trained to fly space ships ? is lost and Mark Wahlberg's character Leo goes after him only to find himself in the future.  Like the original he is chased by the apes and rounded up with a group of primitive humans.  We see Burton's vision of Ape Planet, and the  film makers decided to go with make up and prosthetics instead of CGI, it was a good call as the CGI would not have been up to par in 2001, the new Planet of the Apes showed it was possible to make great CGI apes, but that is now, and this was then.  This film again suffers from a watered down and confusing social and philosophical commentary, the caste system is gone, gone is the conflict of race, nuclear war and religion.  Instead there are call backs to some of the other Ape films, with humans as pets etc.  The humans however primitive do not act that way so again there is some confusion, and the twist at the end is funnier than it is original, the movie lends itself to some silliness that has a B movie quality to it, so it is watchable, but is very much more inferior product.

This does not hold a candle to the original and never really tries to. More of a sequel/reimagined sequel to the original. Mark Wahlberg is miscast but the apes are a delight with Tim Roth delivering a menacing portrayal.
Along with a chilling if confusing last scene

This remake/reimagining of the 1968 classic starts on the right foot with a captivating introduction that differs from the original's. Also Rick Baker's makeup and prosthetics are very good and Paul Giamatti is terrific. Yet somehow the film falls short. It can't measure up to the original narratively or thematically and therefore emerges as both less captivating and more superficial. But even without making this comparison, it's haphazardly written and only mildly thrilling at best.
Tim Burton put this development hell movie in theaters and it sent us to hell. Tim, why did you make this when you should have made another Edward Scissorhands movie?
Just an atrocious movie. 2 hours of my life I will never get back.

A boring slog of a movie, with an ending that makes absolutely no sense at all.

The costumes and make-up are good, but apart from Tim Roth and M.C Duncan's performances the rest are forgettable, being particularly hampered by a terrible script and some weird action sequences.

This was a terrible remake. The make up was good and some of the action was decent. But the plot was forgettable and the acting was not good. This is one of the worst Planet of the apes movies.

3.8/10

It is what everyone knew it would be. A corny late 90's early 2000's remake of a classic. It's a fun concept, and its okay to watch after you have seen the other movies. Do not let this be your first Planet of The Apes movie.

I like this movie, it was good. Don't listen to those emo Tim Burton fans that only want to watch movies that make you want to commit suicide or cut yourself. Tim can make a decent movie to without all that other dark crap! this was a good movie.

It lacks a lot of the satirical nuance of the original film, replacing it instead with more sci-fi and action, and is pretty much totally unnecessary as a result, but it's enjoyable unsubstantial popcorn nonsense nonetheless.

Well, this was a total letdown. I had some hope for this film, what with Tim Burton being involved and me having fond memories of the original 1968 film. Now I really just want those two hours of my life back ...
Tim Burton's f***** up Planet of the Apes!

Over the years I've grown a little more fond of this film version of Pierre Boullere's classic novel. More of re imagining of the source material as opposed to a remake of 1968 Sci Fi masterpiece, I hated this movie when it first came out. Funny thing was, at this time, I wasn't quite fond of the original movie. I love them all now, because I understand them. This movie's sets and art design are top notch. Rick Baker's work on the ape makeup is second to none. As well as the performances by Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Paul Giammanti, Cary-Hiroyoki Tagawa and Michael Clarke Duncan are earnest and perfect. I am a huge Burton fan, so I kept giving it another chance. Upon further review, I've concluded it has a few small flaws and one huge one. The small ones could've been solved if Tim wasn't rushed to meet a release date. A friend asked me what did you hate about this movie, I could only come up with one answer. The ending. I understand it was setting up a sequel but yikes. So there you go. Not the worst Apes movie. Bottom 3 but not worst.
My God this is awful. I felt like I was throwing up in my mouth the entire movie.
Impressive cinematography does not even come close to redeem this bizarre, dull and unnecessary reboot.

Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes is such a butchered, misguided and thoroughly unappealing effort that I was surprised that he made such a bad movie as his movies are usually very good. The costumes are admittedly very good, but Mark Wahlberg's performance here is so bad, the film is overly dark and action oriented and the plot is one giant incomprehensible nonsense leading to one of the director's worst films and one of the worst remakes I've seen.

The original 1968 Planet of the Apes is a classic, and always will be. It was new for the time, and was an extremely fresh and exciting look at the future world. Is this a good film? No. Not at all. This isn't even hilariously bad, it's just a flat-out terrible film. The script is the worst. 30 years ago, this film would've been great, but this is supposed to be a serious film, and the way it is presented doesn't allow it to be taken seriously. This looks like a film that should've been made in the 80's, thanks to its terrible acting and cheesy ending, as well as the horrible jokes that are meant to deliver but fail to send. The action is dull and boring, colorless and uninventive. It's nothing that hasn't been seen before, and Burton has proven on numerous occasions that he can do far better. A bunch of monkeys jumping around like frogs and hitting each other isn't appealing anymore, and while it may have worked three decades ago, it certainly doesn't now. The characters are also insanely bland, acting as clichés for the story. None of them have any major development and are simply used as plot devices to move the story forward instead of characters you can actually care for. Don't bother watching this garbage. It's not worth your time.
A stirring intro theme from the master danny elfman, and great performances/make-up effects fade through the rather un-intriguing story.

Probably Burtons worst movie, which says a lot. Some kind of remake also, putting men in to the roles of slaves while dumb apes rule the so-called little world. Seldom does Wahlberg carry a movie, but in this case it really isnt his fault, even though his acting is horrible.

This movie takes the perfect message and thought provoking commentary of the original source and gives it an incredibly insufferable and insulting spin. There are more holes in this plot than in a bee hive and the only things that they keep from the original is either handled poorly or made fun of. The action scenes are weirdly choreographed and surves no purpose and every single one of these great actors has nothing of substance to work with. Sure, Tim Roth seems to have a lot of fun playing his role, but other than that this movie is a massive, boring piece of garbage with one of the worst cop-out endings to ever hit the block buster standards. Hands down, one of the worst remakes (or reboots) ever made. 2/10
It's good movie to watch
An inferior remake that lacks the political undercurrent of the original film.

Reinventing a classic film is one thing, but if you're going to remake something beloved by film fans worldwide, do it for a reason.  This Planet of the Apes reboot brings little to nothing new to the series with a brutally dull outcome.

Look, it's easier said than done.  Remakes and reboots have a lot of pressure and usually wind up being a waste of time.  But there was serious potential here.  With Tim Burton coming off a few solid films with Johnny Depp and box office success with Batman, you'd think he would have a grapple on what to do with the Apes franchise.  Sadly, it was the exact opposite.

The original 1968 classic was thought provoking and lead to a couple really well done sequels, but Burton's take is disappointingly more creepy and awkward than it is cerebral.  I'm sorry, but I just don't care for seeing Mark Wahlberg have a strange romantic relationship with a female ape.  Or, rather, an equally dull relationship with a human, played by Estella Warren.  No chemistry between the two, whatsoever.

But there are a few redeemable qualities surprisingly.  Instead of a massive Statue of Liberty reveal at the end, Burton makes a few middle act changes that actually benefit the story in the long run.  Having the very cause of the apes taking over earth being due to Wahlberg's mistake was interesting, but I'm just not sure it was earned.  Something else that wasn't earned is the entire third act.  Talk about an atrocious piece of mess, the third act tries to propose so many ideas and take twists and turns that it just all feels tiresome.  Unfortunately, by the time the big battle comes around, you just don't care.

It's easy to look at a film in hindsight and say it shouldn't have been made, but seriously, this Apes entry should not have been made.  It wasn't yet the time where visual effects offered up the opportunity to do great motion capture or picture perfect-looking Apes (Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, 2014) and using old make-up was the wrong choice.  It's nice for the 60's but using it in 2001 is a completely different entity.  But the main problem is that the characters and story are second to an attempt to build out impressive set pieces.  Tim Roth's one-note villain and the film's choice for romances make for one brutal viewing.

+Some interesting subtle changes

-Lack of reinvention

-Awkward romances

-No reason for 2001 to be the time for a remake

It's no secret that the pinnacle of the "Planet of the Apes" franchise was the original film.  So it's no surprise that the latest installment of the franchise is a remake of the first film.

That said, a movie is not really a remake if it's nothing like the original, and Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" bears no resemblance to the original.  This isn't a terrible thing, since the movie doesn't inherit the problems the original had.  This "Planet of the Apes" is much more exciting and action-driven than the original.  This one also has impressive visuals and the updated monkey suits look even more believable than before.

However, this film has its own problems.  As per Burton's usual style, this film is very strange; much stranger than the original.  The movie delves so deep into the apes' religious mythology, it becomes hard to follow, and even harder to take seriously.  Also, the final battle, though exciting, is a pretty generic battle and nothing special.

In remaking "Planet of the Apes", the hope was to revitalize the franchise and recapture the charm of the original film.  This failed.  Though entertaining, this film is not destined to be the classic that the original is.  Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" remake is not as captivating as the original, but what it lacks in story-telling, it makes up for with exciting action and convincing visuals.

Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes has way too many problems: mainly, it depends too much on exposition/backstory, and while at first it seems that Leo is the only one that can talk, a little later all humans are revealed that they not only can talk, but fight against the apes, so what in the hell they are afraid of them? Also, the villain acts and looks obvious from the first second you see it, lacks the build-up that charmed the film series, Not-Zira and all females look unrealistic in comparison to their male and female 60's and 70's counterparts, forced romances, stupid villains, stereotypes like the dumb teen and those that shouldn't have existed by then like black guy 60's attitude in white's point of view, modernizing the apes too much and out of place, ripping the kiss and other elements from the 1968 original, sci-fi elements that do not belong to the franchise, and on top of all, a horrible ending that is only less worse than the second film. Still with so many cons, there were a few pros, the make-up (for the male apes) is outstanding, the music by the great Danny Elfman is powerful, and the action sequences are the least bad of the franchise (because the series doesn't belong to the action genre). But overall, this film is the second worst of the franchise, just behind Beneath.

I went into Planet of the Apes with my standards set pretty low because as I learned from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and Dark Shadows, Tim Burton is no mastermind of remakes and is better at sticking to his own original material. And since the film he's remaking is famous for having one of the most surprising plot twists in cinema history, the surprise isn't there anymore and the plot is obviously predictable, and for a man not skilled at making remakes to handle a story that's been told so that it seems fresh is a case of the blind leading the audience through what has been seen once and doesn't need to be seen again.

And his faults as a director, the man who was supposed to bring this film to life make themselves apparent very soon. 
For one thing in terms of poor storytelling, I don't think the first thing that Astronauts would do upon finding a deadly electromagnetic storm is to send an inexperienced monkey into it followed by an astronaut in to find the monkey. There's a certain sense of logic in storytelling which Tim Burton naturally fails to pick up on.
Next, Tim Burton's poor direction makes Planet of the Apes into a Science fiction comedy B-movie with its apes being largely used to comedic extents in human situations, but it's not funny and not beneficial to the science fiction theme which renders it a double failure. Not to mention that combined with a crappy script which can't go 20 minutes without butchering the classic line "Take your stinkin' paws off me you damned dirty ape!" by paraphrasing it in a manner that can be deemed insulting to the original film. But even worse the crappy script repeatedly hits viewers over the head with its message about how Planet of the Apes is an allegory for slavery of black people, because it makes humans not just the pets of apes, but the chefs and maids too. Not to mention the fact that humans can all talk in this one which removes the concepts of human beings being animal slaves to apes and replaces them with being general slaves. This isn't convincing, because they're a bunch of f*cking monkeys! If you can't figure that put, Tim Burton, then what had this all been for?
And lastly, the actual 2 seconds the film spends reminding us that this is supposedly set on another planet from Leo Davidson's perspective is a prime example of the half-baked writing that went into Planet of the Apes. If I was half baked I'd probably enjoy it more, but I believe in saying no to drugs as well as saying no when Tim Burton wants to remake a film. This should be a good enough reason why.
And the cast emit a mixed response.
Mark Wahlberg uses a routine charm as a means of giving decent line delivery, but his physicality makes it look like he's taking too long to figure everything out, and for a supposedly intelligent astronaut he looks like he's on some mix of marijuana and cocaine which can't decide on making him to calm to worry or too stressed to act. He isn't presented with any sort of character at all, so he just does a routine Mark Wahlberg job. If not for the terrible direction, it would be a routine success. Alas, Tim Burton tries hard to make sure this is not the case.
Helena Bonham Carter proves to be of no benefit to the cast in Planet of the Apes, because her single tone of human voice, her humane physicality  and unconvincing costume make her seem like she's just an attempt to make a female look like I without remembering that this is a film about Apes which she seems to have forgotten too. Planet of the Apes is one of her much lesser efforts as an actress.
Estella Warren's only real benefit to Planet of the Apes is to make a presence similar to Raquel Welch's in One Million Years B.C. where she had few lines and the focus was on her visual appeal. This is the same case for Estella Warren who has few lines and is only really there to give the pre-pubescent male viewers a boner. She may have done a better job if she had more lines, but hen again based on her monotonous stare in Planet of the Apes and poor performance in the sports film Driven which was released the same year I wouldn't be surprised if this was a false assumption. She succeeds at looking good though.

On a more positive note for the cast, Although Paul Giamatti is unfortunately stuck in the part of playing a comedic orangutan, which isn't benefitting to the film, luckily, Paul Giamatti's skilled physicality make him a convincing ape and his line delivery is pretty good.
Michael Clarke Duncan is a great ape in Planet of the Apes because his intimidating physical structure and iconic voice make him reminiscent of the ape played by John Huston in Battle for the Planet of the Apes, which was the high point of the film. Michael Clarke Duncan is a good casting choice and does a good job, making himself seem like a real badass villain.
Kris Kristofferson is a genial presence in Planet of the Apes because his classic heroic western persona and facial hair cause the filmmakers to decide to model him after Tarzan. This is cool, because it's Kris Kristofferson and it's just cool to see him active on screen again.
Tim Roth did a decent job too, capturing a sense of sadism and insanity.
Planet of the Apes features great visual effects which capture the true science fiction essence of the story, and the film editing and cinematography help combine to make sure that Planet of the Apes is some kind of technical achievement. Much of the time these technicals make Planet of the Apes reminiscent of 1960's science fiction adventure films but with upgraded visuals, and so there is some satisfying nostalgia involved in Planet of the Apes. The musical score is also good because although not that iconic, it's intense and atmospheric which makes it effective.

But despite some decent cast members and technical elements, Tim Burton's direction ultimately brings Planet of the Apes down, making it start up on an unsatisfying note and end on an even more unsatisfying one.

Tim Burton's further indulgence within the b-movie science fiction genre with this remake of the classic Planet of the Apes has its appeal, and its eccentricities may please some of its audience. Ultimately, however, it's shallow and devoid of core creativity, perhaps all to half hearted and lacking that Burton appeal of his best works.

If you're a fan of the original, you likely burned this movie along with any other Tim Burton films you have lying around.  The one word to describe this is goofy.  Apes living, dressing and acting like humans in our time is laughable, and make many of the scenes from the first half of the movie come off as something from a bad 70's sitcom. Burton focuses way too much time on the apes and not enough working up interesting scenes for the humans.  Either way, both species suffer with having to say bad lines and fall into flat stereotypes.  At least the actors can't be blames for that.  The insanity and preposterousness continues to escalate to the final act until reaching the twist ending.  At that point, throwing your tv out the window and screaming "F*** logic!" wouldn't be very frowned upon.  Planet of the Apes is a disgrace to the very intelligent original, and should have been put down long before production began.

A failed reboot to POTA directed by Tim Burton. You can tell it was rushed and put together. The story is an interesting different to the original, and the twist end to their journey is okay. But the ending is confusing, the acting is off, and the special effects are questionable.
Imaginative, fast and fun. As far as remakes go, this one works pretty well. Unlike most remakes, this one tries to be its own thing.

This new Planet of the Apes is one of those lazy remakes: it does everything it wants in a very rushed and simple way, and it does nothing that the 1968 original did right. I do wonder how Tim Burton could make such a mess out of the Planet of the Apes. I guess we can blame some of the writers, as two of them worked on another big lazy and rushed movie: Superman IV. But still, how come Burton thinks a script like this one could be the best for a remake of a classic? This is a big misfire, a letdown and a self-indulgent movie that cares little about its uneven tone and structure.

We have a great cast here, but surprise, there's Tim Burton and her Helena Bonham Carter, but not Johnny Depp. Instead we have Mark Wahlberg, who does a decent job, but his character barely has any emotional resonance, ultimately nothing compared to Taylor, played by Charlton Heston in the 1968 original. The rest of the cast is top-notch, but their characters have little to workout. It doesn't help that every single character uses pure exposition to tell their stories: they tell what happened, instead of why it happened. And the movie sadly has exposition as the mechanism to tell the whole movie. The story itself is nothing special, it's very simple and the twists at the end are weak and self-explanatory, but cryptic. It's like the movie is always trying to end as quickly as possible, but the thing that made the first movie so great is the build-up of every single part of the story, until we finally see the truth at the very end: all build up lead to that. Here, it's only to make the story end, no build-up, no intensions of leaving a lasting impression, no intensions of care the bit less about the original. It deftly destroys the legacy of the Apes. In the original, it made sense that the humans were slaves, they were dumb, and they couldn't even speak or think. Here, it doesn't make sense, as the humans can talk, can think, THEY EVEN CAN FIGHT AGAINST THESE APES! Seriously, how did the Apes conquer earth when the humans had all the weapons at their hands? That is dumb, insulting to our intelligence and an insult to the original. Plus, the Apes are also dumb too. Auch, that hurts. There's one scene, when the humans are escaping, we see a bunch of apes doing the stupidest things: about to have sex, one of them is using a wig, another one is putting flowers around him...man, it ridiculous and shameful, that IS a big insult for the original Planet of the Apes. Plus, the ending is very...mixed. So much going on and so little explained...many declares this ending as one of the most horrible, but i didn't find it that bad. Surely a sequel was planned at the time, and plus, after almost two hours of shitty things, what other kind of ending could you expect?

And yet, I found this movie admirable. It does have some B-movie elements and nice visuals. I like B-movie elements and visuals. It's the same case with the Clash of the Titans remake: I like it because it does everything wrong, but in a semi-epic way. I liked that they make the Apes characters still the most interesting in the movie, I liked the fight at the end, I liked the tone they gave to this movie, I liked the sets, I liked the short and fast-paced story-telling, I liked those make-up techniques, even if the female apes look very unconvincing, I liked the score by Danny Elfman, I liked the environment of this movie, I liked how they wanted this to be an action packed movie, damn this movie is full of my most basic movie instincts. I recognize why the hate, I sort of do too, but I also love it because of that, it's a guilty pleasure to say the least.

When it comes with the other Planet of the Apes movies, this one is the second worst; the first is Beneath the Planet of the Apes, which is a bigger misfire. I'm sure I will return to watch this crap over and over. Curse my likes for B-movie charms.

It would take a man like Tim Burton to grossly misconceive an over-budgeted remake like PLANET OF THE APES. This special effects spectacle looks great on screen, but lacks the character and intelligence of the original. As a result, APES was a commercial success, but a critical failure. Astronaut Leo Davidson is thrust through time to find himself trapped on a world ruled by apes. After a planned escape, Davidson becomes the unexpected hero in a human revolt against the apes! The only real hero in PLANET OF THE APES is seven-time Oscar winner Rick Baker for his phenomenal make-up designs, which bring the apes to life in a wide array of different shapes and sizes. The apes simply look incredible, but unfortunately, the appliances hinder the performances of the actors, and often cause them to stumble through their lines. This is not the case for Helena Bonham Carter, who prefers to whisper incoherently, or Tim Roth, who just spits his vile contempt for humanity like venom. Where screenwriter William Broyles Jr. makes his biggest mistake is in allowing all humans to have the capacity of speech, which completely destroys the impact of Davidson's arrival on the planet. There can be no questioning of ape ethics or breakdown in ape philosophy if the lead character is no different than the humans that already exist on the planet. Coupled with Mark Wahlberg's stagnant performance, PLANET OF THE APES misses the point entirely. What is left is an entertaining but empty space epic that will be long forgotten in the years to come. 

-Carl Manes

My original review did not due justice to my dislike for this remake of the 1968 classic, especially after seeing every film in the franchise. This film deserves a fierce critical bitch-slapping, and I intend to give it one. I have no problem with remakes, and I have enjoyed several notorious remakes...but not this one. I could not find it in my very forgiving nature to give this giant middle finger/piss stain of the franchise a pass. The film was pretty doomed from the start since not only does Tim Burton seem out of his element directing a film like this, but the studio had the audacity to hire complete hacks for writers to pen the script - two of whom were the same two people who penned the script for the infamous Superman IV: The Quest For Peace, I shit you not. The biggest problem of the film, is the storyline, which is a major problem since storytelling has been a very pivotal aspect of the series, even during some of the wackier entries like Battle For The Planet Of The Apes (Which I enjoy as a guilty pleasure, but it views like a high-class art house flick in comparison to this piece of crap). The storytelling in this film is an absolutely horrible disaster with no focus, virtually no character development, ham-fisted messages about the evils of war and racism, and conflicts that feel forced and pointless. I didn't give a shit about any of the characters and I didn't even know the names of most of them by the time the film was over. I also didn't enjoy whatsoever how the film completely butchered classic lines from the original film. When I heard these new lines, they sounded like a cross between nails on a chalkboard and Justin Bieber music simultaneously occurring.  The film also fails miserably to be salvaged as a trashy action flick in the tradition of Conquest Of The Planet Of The Apes and Battle For The Planet Of The Apes, but even both those films were far more intelligent in terms of plot. Compounding the horrible storyline and horrifically dull action scenes is the horrible acting, which is surprising considering the talented cast that was assembled, which includes a brief cameo from Charlton Heston (Who only stops by to piss all over his legacy and then die unceremoniously. What a great use of a cameo!). Despite three horrible areas of the film, I must compliment a few things. First, the special effects (Both makeup and CGI) were absolutely spectacular and stunning to look at. I also must compliment the people who built the set pieces because those also look fantastic and should have been used for a much better film. And, finally, Danny Elfman manages to put together a decent score (It's certainly not his best work, but it's good), which feels suitably epic (Too bad it was wasted on such a turd for a film). However, those are the only things I will praise about the film, because the rest of it is an atrocious mess that insults the franchise and can't even be salvaged as a standalone film. This is one of the worst sci-fi/fantasy films and one of the worst remakes I've ever seen. No wonder it killed the franchise for another ten years! Thankfully, the franchise seems to be back on track and hopefully we will never see another film like this to curse the franchise.

Tim Burton's remake of the epic classic, that is Planet of the Apes, fails in nearly every way at creating the atmosphere, the mystery and the suspense that was present in the original. The directing is rather dull and bland, the acting lacks depth and the story lacks the thrill that we all know and love from the original. Comparing the Mark Wahlberg's character to Charlton Heston's, we see straight away what Tim Burton's remake lacks, the depth, the intrigue and the emotion. Many have said the film has a B-Movie feel and I agree with that 100%, however, the film deserves some recognition for the fantastic work done in the make up department for the Apes and Tim Roth was one of the actors in the film that stood out as being decent. Some changes in the plot were unnecessary and drew away from what made the original special and the great reveal and plot twist at the end was somewhat lackluster and failed to raise any hairs on the back of my neck or create any interest. Compared to the original, which it always is, Tim Burton's remake is abysmal and never quite reaches the standard of an alright movie.

Visionary director Tim Burton delivers a new and provocative Planet of the Apes.  In this re-envisioned tale, an astronaut gets lost inside of an electrical storm and ends up crashing on an alien planet controlled by apes.  The film has assembled an unusually group of actors, including Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Mark Wahlberg, and Estella Warren.  Not surprisingly, the actors playing the apes make for some of the most compelling and interest performance, but Wahlberg and Warren suck the life out of this film with exceptionally pathetic performances.  The sets, costumes, and make-up are all remarkably good and help to enhance the film.  However, the film concludes with one of the most ridiculous, nonsensical "twist" endings in history.  While it has significant problems, Planet of the Apes provides a fairly interesting and action packed science fiction film.

This film, directed by Tim Burton, is a sci-fi work based on a simple script: an astronaut inadvertently falls on a planet similar to Earth, where humans are subjugated to a dominant monkey race. From there, he tries to organize a resistanceThis film, directed by Tim Burton, is a sci-fi work based on a simple script: an astronaut inadvertently falls on a planet similar to Earth, where humans are subjugated to a dominant monkey race. From there, he tries to organize a resistance and create conditions to return to his ship and travel back to Earth. That is, Burton didn't know how to use his famous creativity to show us something new. This story is almost entirely something we have already seen and read (if we consider the origin of everything, Pierre Boulle's book), dressed in new clothes, more modern or different. The work of the actors is generally acceptable, with Marc Wahlberg standing out with the main role, followed by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth. The human characters are downright poor and main character's love interest attempts always seem out of context. Overall, it's a movie good enough to be seen but not enough to be remembered.

Planet of the Apes is perhaps one of the brainiest and most visually stunning film I've ever seen. Planet of the Apes stars Mark Whalberg as Captain Leo Davidson a 22 century astronaut who while his genetically altered Ape is investigating an electro-magnetic storm suddenly disappears into thin air, Davidson defies orders and takes a pod out into the cloud to look for his chimp. But as soon as he enters he losses all control of his ships and is sent into an alternate reality where Apes rule and humans are there slaves. Now Davidson has one shot of getting home, he has to tread across uncharted territory to find a sacred temple which could hold the shocking secrets to mankind's past- and the last hope for it's salvation. Planet of the apes is an amazing Si-Fi epic that will have you cheering for the little guy and will have you on the edge of your seat through out. I give Planet of the apes a 4 out of 5.

I liked the start...However, as soon as we got to know the nature of the apes, I started to really despise this movie. I thought it was pathetic, gay and boring. Personally, I found it hard to take the ?ape city? thing seriously. That lasted for about 25 minutes or so and then BAM! the action hit me like a bomb and I loved it. That lasted for pretty much the rest of the movie. All of it was a blast after the crappy parts in the ape city and I was really entertained watching the adventure and escapist story. The apes themselves can be sort of unintentionally funny at times, but the make-up for them was amazing! Wow, I just gave up trying to guess who the actors where after a while because the ape make-up was so astounding and convincing, you couldn?t even tell who?s eyes were under that hunk of hair! The actors do well, Mark Wahlberg fits the leading role well and gives it his all. I don?t think his character was very considerate and I think he tried to be a little too much like Leonardo DiCaprio in Titanic, but apart from that, he?s done well. Helena Bonham Carter was really fantastic and has the pleasure of playing the most developed character in Planet of the Apes, giving her character and performance depth, more-so than Wahlberg?s sometimes selfish hero. Tim Roth was evil and believable and the most ape-like actor in the film. Tim Burton?s direction shines through the movie, especially the final reel. He puts focus to his camera-work and knows he?s up to the job. Some of the characters are annoying at times but you all care about what happens to them.
This is one of my favorite movies this year. I love what Burton brings to the classic story of Planet of the Apes, and I'm looking forward to owning the DVD as soon as I can!

The first act was great - incredible makeup, and fascinating story watching the apes' lifestyle. However, the film loses speed near the middle and ends up turning into a pretty uninvolving road movie with many boring and useless characters,The first act was great - incredible makeup, and fascinating story watching the apes' lifestyle. However, the film loses speed near the middle and ends up turning into a pretty uninvolving road movie with many boring and useless characters, particularly the human love interest, played by Estella Warren, who has like four lines of dialogue. However, Burton deserves credit for not making a direct remake of the 1968 original, instead creating his own vision. I did like the slow revelation to what the planet of the apes is (not exactly what you'd expect, those who have seen the original), and the unexplained but fabulous twist ending.

It would take a man like Tim Burton to grossly misconceive an over-budgeted remake like PLANET OF THE APES. This special effects spectacle looks great on screen, but lacks the character and intelligence of the original. As a result, APES wasIt would take a man like Tim Burton to grossly misconceive an over-budgeted remake like PLANET OF THE APES. This special effects spectacle looks great on screen, but lacks the character and intelligence of the original. As a result, APES was a commercial success, but a critical failure. Astronaut Leo Davidson is thrust through time to find himself trapped on a world ruled by apes. After a planned escape, Davidson becomes the unexpected hero in a human revolt against the apes! The only real hero in PLANET OF THE APES is seven-time Oscar winner Rick Baker for his phenomenal make-up designs, which bring the apes to life in a wide array of different shapes and sizes. The apes simply look incredible, but unfortunately, the appliances hinder the performances of the actors, and often cause them to stumble through their lines. This is not the case for Helena Bonham Carter, who prefers to whisper incoherently, or Tim Roth, who just spits his vile contempt for humanity like venom. Where screenwriter William Broyles Jr. makes his biggest mistake is in allowing all humans to have the capacity of speech, which completely destroys the impact of Davidson's arrival on the planet. There can be no questioning of ape ethics or breakdown in ape philosophy if the lead character is no different than the humans that already exist on the planet. Coupled with Mark Wahlberg's stagnant performance, PLANET OF THE APES misses the point entirely. What is left is an entertaining but empty space epic that will be long forgotten in the years to come. -Carl ManesI Like Horror Movies

This was the first remake I watched that I clearly knew that it was made only for profit, it wasn't the first remake I saw, but it was one of the worst ones I watched so far. First of all this is a remake of one of my favorite movies of all time, so that's a check for me. It is made by Tim Burton so there was some hope for pleasing visuals and interesting dark storytelling. I got one of those aspects, this movie is great to look at; much like how the Bayformers are great to look at, but is yet lacking in any depth. there's also a big name star; I think, in the leading role, who I can say safely I don't care about. Okay so I don't like the main character, this isn't going so well. I can say at least that the costuming in this film is very good, I might consider it better than the original, but that alone doesn't make up for this film has done. First of all, why do the apes jump so damn high? I never knew apes as such aerodynamic creatures, whenever I see the bad guy; I don't care who his real name is, jump around like the Cocoa puffs bird, it makes the realistic makeup loose all of its effect. The climax is so cliché, of course it is fun to watch like I say repeatedly, and i feel like the end to that climax is really unsatisfying. The ending is by far one of the most stupidest of all time, it's no where near as clever and dark as the original. That about wraps it, and all there is to this flick is some good visuals and jumping apes.

rt_summary: Director Tim Burton ("Batman") reinvents one of the most acclaimed and beloved works of science fiction, Pierre Boulle's classic novel "Planet of the Apes." Burton's "Planet of the Apes" begins with the famed original's premise -- a pilot finds himself in a world turned upside down after landing on a strange planet.
meta_summary: Burton's Planet of the Apes begins with the famed original's premise - a pilot finds himself in a world turned upside down after landing on a strange planet - with the celebrated filmmaker's unique personal vision and style breaking new ground in story, design, makeup, and visual effects.  (20th Century Fox)
